description: In this course, the viewer will learn the following, design and implement functional networks as well as configuring, managing, and maintaining essential network devices. They will also look at various network devices such as routers and switches, also well as identifying  benefits and drawbacks of existing network configurations. They will also look at common network security, standards, and protocols and well as troubleshooting common network issues.

name: CompTIA Network+ (N10-007)
subtitle: Vendor-neutral networking

episodes.description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore different ports and protocols used for communication in modern computer networks. They look at protocols like SSH, DNS, FTP.....etc and their associated ports.
episodes.title: Ports and Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.584
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:02.584 --> 00:00:08.266
[CROSSTALK]

[LAUGH] Hey, how you doing tonight?

I could barely get that one out.

There we go.

12

Well I tell you it's great to be here.

13

And that's right,
we're gonna be looking at, well,

14
00:00:33.830 --> 00:00:37.140
some communication types,
ports and protocols.

15
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:39.699
So before we dive into
all the various ports and

16
00:00:39.699 --> 00:00:44.026

just kind of step back for a second and

17
00:00:44.026 --> 00:00:46.802

all right.

18
00:00:46.802 --> 00:00:48.071
When we look at a protocol,

19
00:00:48.071 --> 00:00:51.670
a protocol is nothing more than a
structured set of rules for communication.

20
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:54.100
We have different communication types,
different services,

21
00:00:54.100 --> 00:00:58.610
different applications that need to make
communications across our network today,

22
00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:00.770
more specifically,
are TCP/IP based networks.

23
00:01:00.770 --> 00:01:04.700
And in other episodes,
we will talk more about something known as

24
00:01:04.700 --> 00:01:07.790
the Transmission Control Internet Protocol
model.

25
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:11.830
The TCP/IP model is responsible for
moving traffic along the Internet.

26
00:01:11.830 --> 00:01:15.591
While we need to know what services,
certain, well,

27
00:01:15.591 --> 00:01:17.930
what protocols I should say,
certain services are gonna use.

28
00:01:17.930 --> 00:01:21.360
So that's what we're gonna
look here in this episode at.

29
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:24.860
Now the next thing I also wanna
talk about are ports all right.

30
00:01:24.860 --> 00:01:27.300
With the protocol is a rule for
communication and

31
00:01:27.300 --> 00:01:31.800
it means that if you're gonna use that
form of communication, both the source and

32
00:01:31.800 --> 00:01:35.890
destination of the communication have
to be using the same protocol, right?

33
00:01:35.890 --> 00:01:37.650
We don't really mix and match.

34
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:41.290
So for instance if I'm gonna send email,
for my client.

35
00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:44.860
The application that is sending that email
is gonna send it out a certain port.

36
00:01:44.860 --> 00:01:45.620
Well guess what?

37
00:01:45.620 --> 00:01:49.230
On the other end of that communication,
that protocol and

38
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:54.220
port It have to be the same or we're not
gonna get that intercommunication, right.

39
00:01:54.220 --> 00:01:58.420
Ports if you will are a logical
identifier, right, what do they do is they

40
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:01.820
logically identify what's known as
an endpoint of a connection, right.

41
00:02:01.820 --> 00:02:06.267
So again if I'm gonna send communications

43
00:02:10.283 --> 00:02:12.938
Well we associate that
with a transport protocol,

44

which we're gonna talk about in this

45
00:02:16.766 --> 00:02:21.490
then identify the traffic with a port
number that's associated at the end.

46
00:02:21.490 --> 00:02:25.640
Now, I do want you to understand that when

47
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:30.960

48
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:34.770
Today, it's ICANN, the International

49

Numbers have basically just allocated

50
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:43.360
And they're basically broken up
into three categories, right.

51
00:02:43.360 --> 00:02:45.870
We have what is known
are well-known ports.

52
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:48.570
All right,
our well-known ports are zero to 1023.

53
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:51.498
And inside of this port,
these ports if you will,

54
00:02:51.498 --> 00:02:56.382
we identify all of our common networking
services, all the communication types,

55
00:02:56.382 --> 00:03:01.960
things like DHCP are in this range, things
like what you're gonna see here, SSH.

56
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:07.710
All of these commonly used services
fall under this port range.

57
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:13.800
Now the next port range we have is 1024,
again 1,024 all the way to 49151.

58
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:16.370
And these are what are known

59
00:03:16.370 --> 00:03:20.510
And register port ranges are certain

60
00:03:20.510 --> 00:03:22.324
Companies would go to IANA and

61

IANA would allocate them for

62
00:03:26.160 --> 00:03:31.500
Now the register port range you
will see sometimes is used for

63
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:35.530
applications such as things like for
instance remote desktop protocol.

64
00:03:35.530 --> 00:03:39.670
A remote desktop connection if you

65
00:03:39.670 --> 00:03:41.840
It's been in Windows for
a very long time right?

66
00:03:41.840 --> 00:03:44.060
That uses something known as port 3389.

67
00:03:44.060 --> 00:03:46.440
And you can see that Microsoft,

68
00:03:46.440 --> 00:03:50.800
let's say if you were to identify that
type of traffic out on your network.

69
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:52.210
We could see that port 3389,

70
00:03:52.210 --> 00:03:55.930
if we have that traffic traversing our
network using things like protocol

71
00:03:55.930 --> 00:04:00.060
analyzers, we know that it's associated
with a protocol known as RDP.

72
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:05.417
All right, now the last range,
the last range is that 49152.

73
00:04:05.417 --> 00:04:11.251
That's right 49152,
all the way up to 65535.

74
00:04:11.251 --> 00:04:12.909
Don't worry,
I don't have any of these individual.

75
00:04:12.909 --> 00:04:17.118
Well, a few of them I have memorized and
you're gonna have to memorize some of them

76
00:04:17.118 --> 00:04:21.220
for the exam, but you don't have to
memorize all 65,535 ports, right?

77
00:04:21.220 --> 00:04:25.645
But the port range, again as a recap,

78
00:04:25.645 --> 00:04:29.660
49152 to 65535.

79
00:04:29.660 --> 00:04:33.370
These are ports, if you will,
they're temporary ports.

80
00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:35.530
Sometimes you'll hear them
called dynamic port range,

81
00:04:35.530 --> 00:04:37.450
the private port range, if you will.

82
00:04:37.450 --> 00:04:39.150
And this is a way, basically,

83
00:04:39.150 --> 00:04:42.210
computers will use these ports
just to set up a communication so

84
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:46.000
that we can identify the endpoint of
where that communication is going.

85
00:04:46.000 --> 00:04:47.934
And then once the communication is done,

86
00:04:47.934 --> 00:04:50.927
they get reserve basically thrown
back over in that large pool.

87
00:04:50.927 --> 00:04:54.631
And your computer is, again, they use them
dynamically, so that's why they have a few

88
00:04:54.631 --> 00:04:57.630
different names, dynamic,
private ports, if you will.

89
00:04:57.630 --> 00:05:01.420
Dynamic because of the fact that
my computer might be using one

90
00:05:01.420 --> 00:05:05.140
of those ports now and when that
port closes down, well, guess what?

91
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:08.588
It could use a completely different
port after the fact, all right.

92
00:05:08.588 --> 00:05:13.420
They also call them ephemeral ports or
temporary port if you will because, again,

93
00:05:13.420 --> 00:05:15.370
they associate the endpoint
of the connection.

94
00:05:15.370 --> 00:05:16.939
Once those ports are used,

95
00:05:16.939 --> 00:05:21.514
they're not necessarily associated with
really any type of communication and

96
00:05:21.514 --> 00:05:25.826
you can see all different types of
computers and devices using them today.

97
00:05:25.826 --> 00:05:29.742
And once they're no longer needed,
they go back over into that pool but

98
00:05:29.742 --> 00:05:33.009
nothing in that pool specifically
is typically reserved by

99
00:05:33.009 --> 00:05:35.950
our Internet standards
bodies within that range.

100
00:05:35.950 --> 00:05:39.540
So the three range is, again, well-known
port range, we have the registered port

101
00:05:39.540 --> 00:05:42.800
range, and, last but not the least,
we have the dynamic port range.

102
00:05:42.800 --> 00:05:46.160
These ranges are gonna be important for
you to know in the exam because they might

103
00:05:46.160 --> 00:05:50.220
give you some of these ports that we're
gonna talk about here in this episode.

104
00:05:50.220 --> 00:05:53.830
And essentially what they're gonna
say is what port range is that in?

105
00:05:53.830 --> 00:05:56.690
And it's gonna be up to you
to understand and know and

106
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.200
identify those on the exam, All right.

107
00:05:59.200 --> 00:06:02.870
So with that being said, let's talk
a little bit about the protocols that we

108
00:06:02.870 --> 00:06:06.580
have that we need to be aware of or
the Net+ exam.

109
00:06:06.580 --> 00:06:09.494
The very first one, all right,
I'm gonna talk about,

110
00:06:09.494 --> 00:06:12.920
I'm actually gonna kinda go out
of order here on this one, Zach.

Because one of the first ones that

Telnet's an oldie but

And what I mean by that is I have a

Now Wes I know you're terrific with

telephone Telnet,
I mean was that involved with that or no?

So what is happening?

351
00:19:00.350 --> 00:19:02.450
Remember our little protocol
we started out with?

352
00:19:02.450 --> 00:19:06.400
SSH how it encrypts communications between
end points to do things like remote

353
00:19:06.400 --> 00:19:07.100
log ons.

354
00:19:07.100 --> 00:19:08.060
Well guess what?

355
00:19:08.060 --> 00:19:12.330
We set an SSH tunnel up and
we connect to that FTP server.

356
00:19:12.330 --> 00:19:16.300
That's it, we pulled the blinds
down on anybody that's gonna

357
00:19:16.300 --> 00:19:18.210
be trying to gather our information.

358
00:19:18.210 --> 00:19:19.650
So if we could take a look here.

359
00:19:19.650 --> 00:19:23.400
An SFTP client starts what's
known as an SSH tunnel.

360
00:19:23.400 --> 00:19:25.810
All right, and that's that encrypted
tunnel, no different than SSH.

361
00:19:26.960 --> 00:19:31.570
And then when we connect all of the
information that we're either transferring

362
00:19:31.570 --> 00:19:36.830
to the FTP server or pulling down from
the FTP server now becomes encrypted.

363
00:19:36.830 --> 00:19:39.990
And guess what, it's great for
confidentiality.

364
00:19:39.990 --> 00:19:42.798
It means, picking on Zach,
Zach you have been a good sport so far.

365
00:19:42.798 --> 00:19:46.480
Zach is our hacker and he wants to
get access to that information.

366
00:19:46.480 --> 00:19:47.700
Ethical hacker.

367
00:19:47.700 --> 00:19:48.660
That's right, that's right.

368
00:19:48.660 --> 00:19:49.770
We'll remind it.

369
00:19:49.770 --> 00:19:52.760
[LAUGH] Zach's got his white hat on,
not the black hat, right?

370
00:19:52.760 --> 00:19:59.010
And all seriousness, though, keep in mind,
you want to be using something like SFTP.

371
00:19:59.010 --> 00:20:05.306
Now, FTP and SFTP, these are
connection-oriented services, all right?

372
00:20:05.306 --> 00:20:09.170
And FTP has a lot

373
00:20:09.170 --> 00:20:12.880
of overhead in the fact that you can
issue commands, you can transfer files.

374
00:20:12.880 --> 00:20:18.830
But sometimes what you need
is just a very simplistic way

375
00:20:18.830 --> 00:20:24.460
to send files across the network, right?

376
00:20:24.460 --> 00:20:26.170
And that's the other one
I want to talk about.

377
00:20:26.170 --> 00:20:30.030
And if I didn't mention it,
SFTP uses the same port as SSH.

378
00:20:30.030 --> 00:20:30.780
So Port 22.

379
00:20:30.780 --> 00:20:35.878
And Zach, [LAUGH] I absolutely love
that when you can remember two ports,

380
00:20:35.878 --> 00:20:39.343
two protocols, and they've got,
the ports are identical.

381
00:20:39.343 --> 00:20:43.430
SSH, and if you need to remember,
remember SFTP uses SSH so

382
00:20:43.430 --> 00:20:46.950
you can remember it also
uses its associated port.

383
00:20:46.950 --> 00:20:51.400
Now sometimes like I said,
even as highly optimized as FTP is,

384
00:20:51.400 --> 00:20:54.340
right sometimes you don't
need those commands.

385
00:20:54.340 --> 00:20:58.400
You need just a really quick minimalistic
way to send things like even small

386
00:20:58.400 --> 00:21:01.520
firmware files or
config files, if you will.

387
00:21:01.520 --> 00:21:06.790
That's where something known as
Trivial File Transfer Protocol comes in.

388
00:21:06.790 --> 00:21:09.820
Now this is a little bit different because
what it uses is something known as

389
00:21:09.820 --> 00:21:11.460
user datagram protocol right?

390
00:21:11.460 --> 00:21:16.430
So it's a little bit more streamlined,
a little bit faster and it doesn't have

391
00:21:16.430 --> 00:21:20.520
the overhead if you will, network
overhead, communication overhead as FTP.

392
00:21:20.520 --> 00:21:24.520
So, know that Trivial File Transfer
Protocol, again it's a stripped down

393
00:21:24.520 --> 00:21:30.260
version that runs over the User Datagram
Protocol and it uses port 69, all right?

394
00:21:30.260 --> 00:21:34.840
So important stuff to remember there.

395
00:21:34.840 --> 00:21:40.480
All right, so that takes care of a handful
of the ports that we need to talk about.

396
00:21:40.480 --> 00:21:43.660
I think the last one, Zach, looks like
we've got enough time, we might have to go

397
00:21:43.660 --> 00:21:48.350
into a part two on this one, that I wanna
talk about are the email protocols.

398
00:21:48.350 --> 00:21:50.020
And the email protocols are important.

399
00:21:50.020 --> 00:21:54.580
And they are important to understand
because even if you're not gonna be, let's

400
00:21:54.580 --> 00:21:58.990
say, a networking guru, we definitely
want you to be a networking guru.

401
00:21:58.990 --> 00:22:02.290
And if you're gonna go
into a networking position

402
00:22:02.290 --> 00:22:04.010
you're definitely gonna
have to know these.

403
00:22:04.010 --> 00:22:07.790
But even from basic client
configuration on the email side you're

404
00:22:07.790 --> 00:22:09.336
gonna have to know these ports, all right?

405
00:22:09.336 --> 00:22:10.770
And if we could take
a look at the screen here,

406
00:22:10.770 --> 00:22:14.270
I've got one of the first ones
I wanna talk about, all right?

407
00:22:14.270 --> 00:22:16.920
This is known as SMTP, all right?

408
00:22:16.920 --> 00:22:19.260
This is another one of
those email protocols.

409
00:22:19.260 --> 00:22:20.760
Been around for a while, right?

410
00:22:20.760 --> 00:22:24.090
This is what's known as
the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.

411
00:22:24.090 --> 00:22:27.300
Now I want you to pay attention to
the direction of the arrows, right,

412
00:22:27.300 --> 00:22:30.560
because this is one that you
might overlook if you're not

413
00:22:30.560 --> 00:22:32.470
paying attention close
attention all right.

414
00:22:32.470 --> 00:22:35.760
Sometimes I get these arrows out here and
it looks nothing more than like I don't

415
00:22:35.760 --> 00:22:40.170
know a road map to downtown New York but
in this case what we're talking about is

416
00:22:40.170 --> 00:22:45.080
we're actually sending information
outbound to the server right over port 25.

417
00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:47.980
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
is responsible for

418
00:22:47.980 --> 00:22:50.360
forwarding traffic from
a client to a server.

419
00:22:50.360 --> 00:22:53.280
And the other thing I want you to
understand too is notice that we have

420
00:22:53.280 --> 00:22:58.190
an SMTP server here and
an SMTP server here as well.

421
00:22:58.190 --> 00:23:03.030
Well why do we have SMTP being
forwarded between servers?

422
00:23:03.030 --> 00:23:04.390
Well, guess what?

423
00:23:04.390 --> 00:23:06.090
Servers also use port 25 and

424
00:23:06.090 --> 00:23:09.700
when they're sending SMTP that
means they're forwarding traffic.

425
00:23:09.700 --> 00:23:14.850
So if company A has an SMTP server and
company B has an SMTP server, guess what?

426
00:23:14.850 --> 00:23:18.010
From server to server communication,
rather than just the client,

427
00:23:18.010 --> 00:23:20.370
a little piece of software
running on my client here,

428
00:23:20.370 --> 00:23:22.978
they are also going to use port 25,
all right.

429
00:23:22.978 --> 00:23:28.590
So port 25 for
sending email SMTP, all right?

430
00:23:28.590 --> 00:23:31.900
And the reason I make mention
of that is because that is in

431
00:23:31.900 --> 00:23:34.880
a contrast to the next one here.

432
00:23:34.880 --> 00:23:38.600
Post Office Protocol version 3, I don't
know what the heck happened to version 2.

433
00:23:38.600 --> 00:23:41.170
But we've been on version 3 for

434
00:23:41.170 --> 00:23:45.310
a while now, Post Office Protocol
version 3 is what POP 3 is.

435
00:23:45.310 --> 00:23:47.930
Now notice the direction
of the arrow on this one.

436
00:23:47.930 --> 00:23:50.590
All right, just a little bit
different here, all right?

437
00:23:50.590 --> 00:23:55.781
This is for retrieving email, all right,
this is for downloading your email.

438
00:23:55.781 --> 00:23:58.901
POP3, and I'm always gonna say POP V3, but

439
00:23:58.901 --> 00:24:03.520
POP3 is what I would use to
connect to an email server.

440
00:24:03.520 --> 00:24:04.728
Pull the email, or retrieve it.

441
00:24:04.728 --> 00:24:08.370
Pull the email down from
the server to my local hard drive.

442
00:24:08.370 --> 00:24:13.896
Now, I do want you to understand that POP3
has a specific port as well, all right.

443
00:24:13.896 --> 00:24:17.660
If you are gonna connect to a POP3 server,
you're gonna be connecting on port 110.

444
00:24:17.660 --> 00:24:20.537
Again remember, identifying
the endpoint of the connection, right?

445
00:24:20.537 --> 00:24:22.770
That's what those ports are there for.

446
00:24:22.770 --> 00:24:24.811
It is retrieving email though.

447
00:24:24.811 --> 00:24:28.430
There is one thing that you
gotta worry kind of about.

448
00:24:28.430 --> 00:24:30.373
There's a little concern over POP3.

449
00:24:30.373 --> 00:24:35.361
And that's the fact that when I connect
to my POP3 server or a POP3 server and

450
00:24:35.361 --> 00:24:38.060
I download my email, guess what it does.

451
00:24:38.060 --> 00:24:40.991
It erases the copy of that
email off of the server.

452
00:24:40.991 --> 00:24:44.430
Now, that doesn't seem
like a big deal all right?

453
00:24:44.430 --> 00:24:48.920
Because we're so used to using the third
email protocol which we'll talk about here

454
00:24:48.920 --> 00:24:51.590
in a second,
that we don't think about it right?

455
00:24:51.590 --> 00:24:55.410
If you think Zach, I don't know if
you're like me, but I use Gmail a lot,

456
00:24:55.410 --> 00:24:56.654
or I use Office 365.

457
00:24:56.654 --> 00:25:01.500
And it doesn't matter where I go to log
in, I have access to my email right?

458
00:25:01.500 --> 00:25:04.814
Well, with the POP3 server,
let's say that you're at home and

459
00:25:04.814 --> 00:25:09.213
you connect to your company's POP3 server
and you download your email, and it's got

460
00:25:09.213 --> 00:25:13.392
a copy of some important statistics that
you need to present to your boss, right.

461
00:25:13.392 --> 00:25:17.423
Well, when you connect to that POP3 server
and download or retrieve your emails,

462
00:25:17.423 --> 00:25:20.431
it erases those emails from the server and
then you go to work.

463
00:25:20.431 --> 00:25:24.450
Get them into work and you connect
to the POP3 server and guess what?

464
00:25:25.550 --> 00:25:26.775
Those emails are gone.

465
00:25:26.775 --> 00:25:29.330
You downloaded them locally to
the client when you first connected.

466
00:25:29.330 --> 00:25:30.245
Now I do know and

467
00:25:30.245 --> 00:25:34.058
I am aware that there is an option
to leave a copy up on the server.

468
00:25:34.058 --> 00:25:39.390
But that's one of the drawbacks to POP3,
all right.

469
00:25:39.390 --> 00:25:43.136
Now if you wanna be able to manage
your emails on the server and

470
00:25:43.136 --> 00:25:48.426
you wanna work with them, create folders,
doesn't matter what computer you go to,

471
00:25:48.426 --> 00:25:52.108
that's what you're gonna,
use, if I can say that right.

472
00:25:52.108 --> 00:25:55.753
Don't lose, that's where you're
gonna use the last email server or

473
00:25:55.753 --> 00:25:58.640
email protocol that we
wanna talk about here.

474
00:25:58.640 --> 00:26:02.812
And what I've got here is an example
of what is known as IMAP, all right.

475
00:26:02.812 --> 00:26:06.360
That's the Internet message or
mail access protocol.

476
00:26:06.360 --> 00:26:11.550
What this allows me to do is this
allows me to connect to the server.

477
00:26:11.550 --> 00:26:13.430
And I could manage, download and

478
00:26:13.430 --> 00:26:17.658
work with my emails, just like I
could if they were stored locally.

479
00:26:17.658 --> 00:26:22.090
And i can log into any web browser,
really, that supports it today.

480
00:26:22.090 --> 00:26:25.850
That's what we commonly we use today,
right, IMAP.

481
00:26:25.850 --> 00:26:30.410
And that's why if I log into Gmail I can
go to one web browser, one computer,

482
00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:33.190
I can look and retrieve my emails but
they're on the server.

483
00:26:33.190 --> 00:26:34.960
They look to me that as they're local,
right?

484
00:26:34.960 --> 00:26:38.328
I can see them in the web browser but
then I can go over to another computer and

485
00:26:38.328 --> 00:26:39.290
I can log in.

486
00:26:39.290 --> 00:26:41.760
I can connect to that IMAP server and
guess what?

487
00:26:41.760 --> 00:26:45.386
Still have access to my email, all right.

488
00:26:45.386 --> 00:26:50.483
So, three of the email protocols, and
the last one there IMAP, that's port 143.

489
00:26:50.483 --> 00:26:55.171
All right, so we've got port 25 for
SMTP, we've got port 110 for

490
00:26:55.171 --> 00:26:58.090
POP3 and we've got port 143 for IMAP.

491
00:26:58.090 --> 00:27:00.212
Keep in mind your email protocols, and

492
00:27:00.212 --> 00:27:03.443
Zach is giving me the old evil
eye when it comes to this time.

493
00:27:03.443 --> 00:27:06.390
So it does look like we're gonna
have to put a comma in this episode.

494
00:27:06.390 --> 00:27:07.173
We'll come back with a part two.

495
00:27:07.173 --> 00:27:10.693
[LAUGH] Wes, you doing a fantastic job.

496
00:27:10.693 --> 00:27:12.783
And it's amazing everything
that you remember and

497
00:27:12.783 --> 00:27:14.560
you're able to share with us so fluidly.

498
00:27:14.560 --> 00:27:15.555
Thank you so very much.

499
00:27:15.555 --> 00:27:17.810
And so of course this is ports and
protocols part one.

500
00:27:17.810 --> 00:27:18.841
There will be a part two.

501
00:27:18.841 --> 00:27:21.690
And this is inside
the CompTIA Net+ series.

502
00:27:21.690 --> 00:27:23.620
Make sure you watch every single episode.

503
00:27:23.620 --> 00:27:25.348
Course library,
hundreds of videos are there and

504
00:27:25.348 --> 00:27:26.921
they are all designed
to help you go further.

505
00:27:26.921 --> 00:27:28.350
Check that out too.

506
00:27:28.350 --> 00:27:29.890
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

507
00:27:29.890 --> 00:27:31.597
They'll be very happy you did.

508
00:27:31.597 --> 00:27:32.146
Thanks for watching.

509
00:27:32.146 --> 00:27:32.876
I'm Zach Memos.

510
00:27:32.876 --> 00:27:33.669
And I'm Wes Bryan.

511
00:27:33.669 --> 00:27:36.166
And we'll see you soon.

512
00:27:36.166 --> 00:27:42.209
[MUSIC]

513
00:27:42.209 --> 00:27:45.284
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore different ports and protocols used for communication in modern computer networks. They look at protocols like SSH, DNS, FTP.....etc and their associated ports.
episodes.title: Ports and Protocols Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:04.778
You're watching ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.778 --> 00:00:07.098
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.098 --> 00:00:08.537
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.537 --> 00:00:10.516
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.516 --> 00:00:13.385
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.385 --> 00:00:16.940
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.940 --> 00:00:19.601
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA and Net+.

8
00:00:19.601 --> 00:00:23.730
This is Ports and Protocols Pt 2,
make sure you see Pt 1.

9
00:00:23.730 --> 00:00:27.200
And our IT expert bringing us all the
great information we need is Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:28.640
Wes, thanks for coming on back.

11
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:30.140
>> Hey, thanks for having me here, Zach.

12
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:32.680
That's right,
we left you with a cliffhanger in Pt 1.

13
00:00:32.680 --> 00:00:35.752
Remember, we were talking about in Pt 1,
we kinda set the stage.

14
00:00:35.752 --> 00:00:38.300
And I'd like to just recap
just a little bit, right?

15
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:40.930
Remember, we're talking about ports and
protocols, right?

16
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:43.109
Protocol is a rule for
communication, right?

17
00:00:43.109 --> 00:00:46.080
A structured organization,
if you will, rules for communication.

18
00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:48.465
And if you have a service that is needed,

19
00:00:48.465 --> 00:00:51.974
you have a client computer
requesting a service out there,

20
00:00:51.974 --> 00:00:56.412
both endpoints have to be speaking
that same communication type, right?

21
00:00:56.412 --> 00:00:59.660
And that's essentially what a protocol is,
right?

22
00:00:59.660 --> 00:01:03.830
Now the port is what helps us to identify
that connection, where it's going, right?

23
00:01:03.830 --> 00:01:05.880
So for instance,
we talked about in the first episode,

24
00:01:05.880 --> 00:01:08.630
we talked about things like
our email servers, right?

25
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:13.630
If I'm going to send email to
an SMTP server, it's port, right?

26
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:15.760
The port that it's listening out on,
that's open.

27
00:01:15.760 --> 00:01:19.430
And it's saying, hey, you could send
me your email, is port 25, right?

28
00:01:19.430 --> 00:01:23.600
So it identifies that logical
endpoint of a connection.

29
00:01:23.600 --> 00:01:26.194
So I do want you to be aware of that.

30
00:01:26.194 --> 00:01:28.312
Now continuing on, basically,

31
00:01:28.312 --> 00:01:33.380
we have quite a few more protocols
that we need to talk about, right?

32
00:01:33.380 --> 00:01:36.230
We've got one service, protocol,

33
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:40.465
if you will, that's out there that is
probably one of the most important.

34
00:01:40.465 --> 00:01:44.520
They're all important, Zach, but this
really, from administrative standpoint,

35
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:48.020
helps us to reduce
the complexities of addressing

36
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:50.710
all of the computers that
are across our networks, right?

37
00:01:50.710 --> 00:01:53.811
Now if you're on a small network,
it might not be so bad, right?

38
00:01:53.811 --> 00:01:58.360
If you've got 5 or 6 computers, but can
you imagine if you have 5,000 computers?

39
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:01.690
And you need to assign an IP address
to every single one of those

40
00:02:01.690 --> 00:02:02.920
computers, right?

41
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:05.770
Well, if you're an hourly employee,
that's just fine.

42
00:02:05.770 --> 00:02:06.358
You start now,

43
00:02:06.358 --> 00:02:09.354
by the time you're done, you'll probably
have to start over again, right?

44
00:02:09.354 --> 00:02:11.720
It's like mowing a 1,000-acre
yard with a push mower.

45
00:02:11.720 --> 00:02:14.236
By the time you're done,
you need to start back over again.

46
00:02:14.236 --> 00:02:19.546
But we really want to try to reduce
the administrative complexities,

47
00:02:19.546 --> 00:02:24.080
like marriage complexities,
of assigning IP addresses.

48
00:02:24.080 --> 00:02:26.420
And that's where something
known as DHCP comes in, right?

49
00:02:26.420 --> 00:02:30.690
Now in other episodes,
we go more into depth on the DHCP process.

50
00:02:30.690 --> 00:02:33.020
But you need to know,
again, the protocol, right?

51
00:02:33.020 --> 00:02:35.260
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

52
00:02:35.260 --> 00:02:40.220
In fact, I got a little diagram here,
just as a real quick refresher

53
00:02:40.220 --> 00:02:45.350
if you haven't seen our episodes where
we talk about DHCP more, all right?

54
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:50.680
Remember that DHCP,
it allows dynamic host configuration.

55
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:53.230
I love to break down
the acronyms on this because

56
00:02:53.230 --> 00:02:55.970
in this acronym it tells
you what's happening.

57
00:02:55.970 --> 00:02:58.980
Dynamic, it means it's not automatic, but

58
00:02:58.980 --> 00:03:01.310
it just does mean things can change,
all right?

59
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:02.490
Host configuration, right?

60
00:03:02.490 --> 00:03:05.739
We're gonna send out some
configurations in a protocol, right?

61
00:03:05.739 --> 00:03:08.251
We already know what protocol is,
we've established that,

62

00:24:18.210 --> 00:24:21.632

00:24:34.853 --> 00:24:35.805

00:24:35.805 --> 00:24:39.555

00:24:41.660 --> 00:24:43.920
That would be connection list service,

00:24:54.806 --> 00:24:58.785

00:24:58.785 --> 00:25:04.845
All right, when I talk about TCP, there's

00:25:04.845 --> 00:25:10.372
This is a connection-oriented service

00:25:10.372 --> 00:25:13.724

00:25:13.724 --> 00:25:18.085

00:25:18.085 --> 00:25:20.385

00:25:32.174 --> 00:25:34.029
But in order for that to happen,

00:25:34.029 --> 00:25:37.140

And I want you to know that about

00:25:40.047 --> 00:25:43.790
To set up this reliable connection,

00:25:43.790 --> 00:25:45.730

00:25:45.730 --> 00:25:48.459
All right, so in the TCP 3-way handshake,
we have what's

00:25:48.459 --> 00:25:52.327
known as synchronization request, remember

00:25:52.327 --> 00:25:54.766
[LAUGH] What time is important, right?

465
00:25:54.766 --> 00:25:58.954
I'm gonna reach out, I say it's gonna be
the computers that are doing this, but

466
00:25:58.954 --> 00:26:01.000
I'm going to reach out this computer.

467
00:26:01.000 --> 00:26:03.678
I'm must say,
I need to study some reliable or

468
00:26:03.678 --> 00:26:06.020
some information in a reliable manner.

469
00:26:06.020 --> 00:26:07.863
So we're gonna send what's
known as a SYN packet.

00:26:07.863 --> 00:26:11.070
It's a synchronization request.

471
00:26:11.070 --> 00:26:14.472
Zach's computer is gonna hear it and
it's gonna respond back, okay, yeah,

472
00:26:14.472 --> 00:26:15.409
I acknowledge that.

473
00:26:15.409 --> 00:26:18.120
You just sent a synchronization request.

474
00:26:18.120 --> 00:26:20.691
That's called a snack or
a SYN-ACK [LAUGH].

475
00:26:20.691 --> 00:26:23.752
The synchronization
acknowledgement all right packet.

476
00:26:23.752 --> 00:26:28.624
Final process,final part of this three way
handshake is an acknowledgement back to

477
00:26:28.624 --> 00:26:33.080
his computer that yes,
we have established that communication.

478
00:26:33.080 --> 00:26:35.270
But it goes a little bit farther than

00:26:35.270 --> 00:26:39.280
Transmission control protocol does
something kind of interesting.

480
00:26:39.280 --> 00:26:42.089
When you've got a large amount of

481
00:26:42.089 --> 00:26:44.273
We've established
the three we handshake and

00:26:44.273 --> 00:26:47.880

00:26:47.880 --> 00:26:51.382
What's gonna happen is the TCP
is gonna take that package and

00:26:51.382 --> 00:26:55.580

00:26:55.580 --> 00:26:58.150
This is what's known as, segmentation.

00:26:58.150 --> 00:26:59.744
And user gonna become segments, all right.

00:26:59.744 --> 00:27:02.736
Now it's gonna go a little farther than

00:27:02.736 --> 00:27:05.440

00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:07.720
Now please don't take 1,

00:27:07.720 --> 00:27:10.810
These could be large numbers,

00:27:10.810 --> 00:27:14.784
But what it's gonna do is it's gonna

00:27:14.784 --> 00:27:18.320
So now, what we have is segmentation and
sequencing, right?

493
00:27:18.320 --> 00:27:20.900
Well why are we doing the segmentation?

494
00:27:20.900 --> 00:27:21.672
For more reliable delivery.

495
00:27:21.672 --> 00:27:23.160
Why are we doing sequencing?

496
00:27:23.160 --> 00:27:26.540
Well, sequencing works like this,
let's say that I'm the source of

497
00:27:26.540 --> 00:27:29.770
the communication here, and
let's say Zack is the destination.

498
00:27:29.770 --> 00:27:35.095
Well, notice something, Zack's computer in
my diagram here has received packet one,

499
00:27:35.095 --> 00:27:38.720
packet two, or segment one,
segment two, segment three.

500
00:27:38.720 --> 00:27:40.830
Notice what's missing.

501
00:27:40.830 --> 00:27:42.219
Segment four, all right?

502
00:27:42.219 --> 00:27:45.900
So transmission control protocol, and
this part of the handshake process.

503
00:27:45.900 --> 00:27:51.334
Zack's computer is going to say hey, hey,
hey hold on I'm missing four, I got one,

504
00:27:51.334 --> 00:27:56.410
two, three but now you're sending me five,
we've got something wrong here.

505
00:27:56.410 --> 00:28:01.080
So what he's gonna tell my computer, I'm
missing segment four, can you resend that?

506
00:28:01.080 --> 00:28:03.627
And my computer will resend segment four,
but

507
00:28:03.627 --> 00:28:08.020
then it'll start back in the process of
all those sequence segments behind it.

508
00:28:08.020 --> 00:28:12.260
So not only does it ensure that it's
broken down into a reliable manner, but

509
00:28:12.260 --> 00:28:15.720
then when they're processed
on the other end, guess what?

510
00:28:15.720 --> 00:28:17.255
They're processed in the right order.

511
00:28:17.255 --> 00:28:22.519
Guarantee, first of all, connection
oriented service with reliable delivery,

512
00:28:22.519 --> 00:28:24.483
your delivery confirmation.

513
00:28:24.483 --> 00:28:30.240
And that is unlike something
known as User Datagram Protocol.

514
00:28:30.240 --> 00:28:35.050
All of that extra stuff that is going on,
takes a little bit of overhead.

515
00:28:35.050 --> 00:28:36.520
Your computers have to do this.

516
00:28:36.520 --> 00:28:40.000
They have entire offload engines for
TCP to maintain communication.

517
00:28:40.000 --> 00:28:42.515
Especially when you have hundreds
of hundreds of thousands of these

518
00:28:42.515 --> 00:28:44.060
communications.

519
00:28:44.060 --> 00:28:46.498
Sometimes you just need
things that are fast, and

520
00:28:46.498 --> 00:28:48.889
that's where user
Datagram Protocol comes in.

521
00:28:48.889 --> 00:28:52.165
I want you to think about,
here in the states,

522
00:28:52.165 --> 00:28:57.122
if I need to mail a snail mail and
I don't need to go to the postoffice and

523
00:28:57.122 --> 00:29:02.425
do all that delivery confirmation,
return receipt, what do I do?

524
00:29:02.425 --> 00:29:05.425
Well, here in the states, we find one
of those blue mailboxes right and

525
00:29:05.425 --> 00:29:07.527
I take my letter and
I throw it in it and I walk away.

526
00:29:07.527 --> 00:29:10.418
That's best effort delivery,
no guaranteed delivery but

527
00:29:10.418 --> 00:29:12.260
you don't have all that overhead.

528
00:29:12.260 --> 00:29:16.815
My time isn't gonna be spent on delivery
confirmation, and filling paperwork out,

529
00:29:16.815 --> 00:29:18.853
I'll just throw it in the mail and go.

530
00:29:18.853 --> 00:29:22.988
My time is money, well that's
the same thing that you use with UDP.

531
00:29:22.988 --> 00:29:24.837
If I need to stream data,

532
00:29:24.837 --> 00:29:31.440
I don't care if there's that football
player that's running into the end zone.

533
00:29:31.440 --> 00:29:36.356
I don't need to pick up a couple of little
segments that we maybe we lost, right?

534
00:29:36.356 --> 00:29:39.520
No, just let them go and
let's just keep going.

535
00:29:39.520 --> 00:29:40.260
It's streaming information.

536
00:29:40.260 --> 00:29:43.475
I needed there fast and
I cannot worry about rebuilding it, right?

537
00:29:43.475 --> 00:29:46.480
File transfers, I want to rebuild it.

538
00:29:46.480 --> 00:29:49.244
I want to make sure that the data
state maintains its integrity.

539
00:29:49.244 --> 00:29:52.077
In something like streaming media,
we drop a couple of packets,

540
00:29:52.077 --> 00:29:54.810
you see it glitch in the video and
we move on, right?

541
00:29:54.810 --> 00:29:58.850
So there are reasons why you would
use a connection list service.

542
00:29:58.850 --> 00:30:01.476
You can also have things where
the application has built-in,

543
00:30:01.476 --> 00:30:02.490
reliable delivery.

544
00:30:02.490 --> 00:30:04.780
Well, then there's no reason to
use transmission control protocol.

545
00:30:04.780 --> 00:30:08.640
You can let the application handle it,
all right.

546
00:30:08.640 --> 00:30:11.940
Two protocols there,
I know we're getting out of time here.

547
00:30:11.940 --> 00:30:14.055
But I also wanna mention one is ICMP,

548
00:30:14.055 --> 00:30:16.930
that's the internet
control message protocol.

549
00:30:16.930 --> 00:30:21.000
Internet control message protocol doesn't
actually send information, right?

550
00:30:21.000 --> 00:30:23.874
Not like these transport protocols,
UDP and TCP that we're talking about.

551
00:30:23.874 --> 00:30:28.242
This is actually for things like
sending diagnostics information,

552
00:30:28.242 --> 00:30:30.360
flow control, error messages.

553
00:30:30.360 --> 00:30:34.341
If I am sending too much information into
Zach's computer and Zach's computer,

554
00:30:34.341 --> 00:30:37.284
the network adapter for
whatever reason gets overwhelmed,

555
00:30:37.284 --> 00:30:39.555
it sends me a squelch message and
says hold on.

556
00:30:39.555 --> 00:30:44.059
Slow down, you don't slow down I am going
to start dropping packets cuze I can't

557
00:30:44.059 --> 00:30:45.527
process them fast enoug.

558
00:30:45.527 --> 00:30:46.851
So it does flow control,

559
00:30:46.851 --> 00:30:50.079
some of the utilities that you
use actually use ICMP as well.

560
00:30:50.079 --> 00:30:54.720
PING, Packet Pnternet Grouper that we use
to test communications between two end

561
00:30:54.720 --> 00:30:58.770
points, it uses ICMP to send
those PING packets, trace RT.

562
00:30:58.770 --> 00:31:02.575
We determine the path a packet takes
from source to destination, guess what?

563
00:31:02.575 --> 00:31:04.210
It also uses ICMP.

564
00:31:04.210 --> 00:31:08.935
So we've got protocols out there that
don't necessarily transmit data or

565
00:31:08.935 --> 00:31:13.735
use the transport information, as they
are used to do things like manage and

566
00:31:13.735 --> 00:31:16.142
diagnose issues within the network.

567
00:31:16.142 --> 00:31:18.160
Last but not least is IP.

568
00:31:18.160 --> 00:31:21.492
We've got a whole entire section that
we're gonna go into the Internet Protocol

569
00:31:21.492 --> 00:31:23.415
and how we obtain, and
what IP addresses are.

570
00:31:23.415 --> 00:31:29.200
Just know for now that IP, it's
responsible for your addressing, right?

571
00:31:29.200 --> 00:31:31.953
Source and destination,
where do I send that traffic to,

572
00:31:31.953 --> 00:31:33.479
where did it come from, right?

573
00:31:33.479 --> 00:31:36.860
We've got an identifier just like
you have in any kind of mail system.

574
00:31:36.860 --> 00:31:38.010
We have a source and destination address.

575
00:31:38.010 --> 00:31:42.212
IP is your source and destination,
an electronic packet,

576
00:31:42.212 --> 00:31:45.430
the electronic envelope if you will.

577
00:31:45.430 --> 00:31:48.755
It is a connectionless protocol.

578
00:31:48.755 --> 00:31:52.760
It has no clue how to get
the information where you need.

579
00:31:52.760 --> 00:31:56.182
It just says, I stamped it with
an address.now we gotta worry about,

580
00:31:56.182 --> 00:31:57.980
the network has to worry about that.

581
00:31:57.980 --> 00:32:01.594
That's the last one of these protocol
types that we want you to be aware of.

582
00:32:01.594 --> 00:32:03.880
Keep in mind,
some of it's just memorization.

583
00:32:03.880 --> 00:32:06.297
I do understand that,
some of it's theory, some of it's, hey,

584
00:32:06.297 --> 00:32:08.210
you gotta understand what
the protocols are doing.

585
00:32:08.210 --> 00:32:11.568
Sometimes it's just a matter of writing
things down and just memorizing and

586
00:32:11.568 --> 00:32:13.350
committing it to memory.

587
00:32:13.350 --> 00:32:14.638
Don't let it worry you.

588
00:32:14.638 --> 00:32:17.500
If you keep practicing,
you're gonna get these protocols down.

589
00:32:17.500 --> 00:32:19.347
And before you know it,
it'll be a thing of the past.

590
00:32:19.347 --> 00:32:22.350
>> And if you keep watching
the videos that Wes is creating here,

591
00:32:22.350 --> 00:32:24.520
I'm sure you won't have any trouble.

592
00:32:24.520 --> 00:32:25.993
Ports and Protocols, Part 2.

593
00:32:25.993 --> 00:32:27.910
There was a part 1, watch them both.

594
00:32:27.910 --> 00:32:30.302
Watch everything in the comp series.

595
00:32:30.302 --> 00:32:34.096
And, the course library, check out
the hundreds of videos that are there, and

596
00:32:34.096 --> 00:32:37.630
they're all created for one purpose,
to help you go further.

597
00:32:37.630 --> 00:32:38.329
And thank you for watching IT PRO TV.

598
00:32:38.329 --> 00:32:39.429
Tell everybody you know about it.

599
00:32:39.429 --> 00:32:40.390
Because you know what?

600
00:32:40.390 --> 00:32:41.986
They're gonna be very happy that you did.

601
00:32:41.986 --> 00:32:43.555
I'm Zach Memos
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

602
00:32:43.555 --> 00:32:48.947
>> And we'll

603
00:32:48.947 --> 00:32:56.139
see you soon.

604
00:32:56.139 --> 00:32:58.830
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the Open Systems Interconnection model \(OSI model\). They look at some of the applications, devices and protocols that operated within the different layers of the OSI model.
episodes.title: OSI Model
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.270 --> 00:00:03.485
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:03.485 --> 00:00:04.510
I'm you host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.510 --> 00:00:06.457
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.457 --> 00:00:08.302
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.302 --> 00:00:11.978
>> You are watching IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:11.978 --> 00:00:13.075
>> Hello and thank you for

7
00:00:13.075 --> 00:00:16.780
choosing ITProTV empowering
the world through engaging learning.

8
00:00:16.780 --> 00:00:17.660
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

9
00:00:17.660 --> 00:00:22.819
As we continue on with CompTIA Net+ and
for this episode, it's OSI model.

10
00:00:22.819 --> 00:00:25.639
And we've asked our IT expert and
all around great guy,

11
00:00:25.639 --> 00:00:26.910
Wes Bryan to help us out.

12
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:27.900
Wes, good to see you here.

13
00:00:27.900 --> 00:00:29.220
>> Hey Zach, thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:29.220 --> 00:00:31.500
That's right,
we're gonna throw acronyms at you, and

15
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:34.622
we're gonna put them right there in
the title to confuse you, right?

16
00:00:34.622 --> 00:00:39.178
We're gonna talk about something that
was actually started back in 1984 and

17
00:00:39.178 --> 00:00:40.188
is still around.

18
00:00:40.188 --> 00:00:44.615
We're gonna dive into a little bit of
the theory in this episode and we're gonna

19
00:00:44.615 --> 00:00:49.610
be talking about a structured set of rules
for communication known as the OSI model.

20
00:00:49.610 --> 00:00:53.200
>> And Wes, right off the bat, I just
would like to ask, what is the OSI model?

21
00:00:53.200 --> 00:00:54.430
>> Yeah, Zach, that's kind of interesting.

22
00:00:54.430 --> 00:00:56.240
I'm gonna go ahead and
throw you a curve ball on this one and

23
00:00:56.240 --> 00:00:58.870
tell you that the OSI was made by the ISO,
right?

24
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:00.930
Boy, if that's not confusing, I tell you.

25
00:01:00.930 --> 00:01:04.490
Actually, if we take a trip back in time,
right, and

26
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:07.400
in the early days of networking everybody,
all these different vendors,

27
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:09.540
they were coming up basically
with their own rules, right.

28
00:01:09.540 --> 00:01:11.720
They were making it up as you go.

29
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:14.880
Not really, they were brilliant,
I'll let you know, brilliant engineers but

30
00:01:14.880 --> 00:01:18.300
if you were with one vendor,
you had to stay with that vendor.

31
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:21.990
You would get vendor locked and again they
were really wasn't a set of standards.

32
00:01:21.990 --> 00:01:25.900
So the international organization of
standardization, I know it sounds like

33
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:31.305
they can't even standardize their name
right, ISO and the OSI there, right.

34
00:01:31.305 --> 00:01:35.500
But International Organization
of Standardization.

35
00:01:35.500 --> 00:01:37.920
The ISO actually stands for,

36
00:01:39.170 --> 00:01:43.400
it's a shortened form of a Greek word
called, isos, which means equal.

37
00:01:43.400 --> 00:01:47.330
But they said, let's go ahead and
we'll come up with a way,

38
00:01:47.330 --> 00:01:51.030
a structured set of means, or
a structured set of rules, if you will,

39
00:01:51.030 --> 00:01:56.010
an architecture that will standardize
the way we do network communications.

40
00:01:56.010 --> 00:02:00.070
So they came up with a seven-layer
abstract model, they're abstract layers if

41
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:02.680
you will, a seven layer model
that would really do that.

42
00:02:02.680 --> 00:02:06.460
It would standardize the way we
communicate between end systems, or

43
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:08.460
end points within networks.

44
00:02:08.460 --> 00:02:09.440
And it also allows,

45
00:02:09.440 --> 00:02:12.530
well, just like anything that we do
when we do standardization, right.

46
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:14.030
We do standardization why?

47
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:17.680
Because it allows interoperability,
and actually you as the customer,

48
00:02:17.680 --> 00:02:20.900
myself as the customer typically,
we benefit from that, right?

49
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:23.730
Because, if we know that
somebody's following a standard,

50
00:02:23.730 --> 00:02:27.550
then really the only thing I have to make
a choice from is which vendor is making

51
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:28.530
a better product, right?

52
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:31.820
We know that they're gonna be
following the same set of rules,

53
00:02:31.820 --> 00:02:33.420
the same set of architecture.

54
00:02:33.420 --> 00:02:35.530
We just gotta figure out who
we like better as a vendor.

55
00:02:35.530 --> 00:02:38.460
So as customers,
we really win out on that.

56
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:43.270
And then the interoperable nature of this
means that you can have these dissimilar

57
00:02:43.270 --> 00:02:47.160
systems that can communicate again,
as long as they're following that model.

58
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:50.810
So, the OSI model is actually
a seven layered system and again,

59
00:02:50.810 --> 00:02:55.750
abstract layers that again, standardize
how we communicate between source and

60
00:02:55.750 --> 00:02:58.520
destination across a computing network.

61
00:02:58.520 --> 00:03:02.360
Now, we have to know a little bit
about those seven layers for our exam.

62
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:06.910
We gotta know, by each layer,
what the layer is doing.

63
00:03:06.910 --> 00:03:09.380
Some of the protocols that you can
potentially see on those layers,

64
00:03:09.380 --> 00:03:12.075
as well as things like
what are the devices?

65
00:03:12.075 --> 00:03:14.580
Cuz we do have devices that
work at these different layers.

66
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:16.310
Now, I keep talking about these layers.

67
00:03:16.310 --> 00:03:18.910
Let's go into the layers
a little bit more there.

68
00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:19.730
Talk about layers.

69
00:03:19.730 --> 00:03:23.000
What we're talking about is
a seven layered model, all right?

70
00:03:23.000 --> 00:03:26.990
In these seven layers each layer
assists another layer, right?

71
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:29.110
And depending on if you're sending or

72
00:03:29.110 --> 00:03:33.370
receiving the communication it'll dictate
which end of these layers you're on.

73
00:03:33.370 --> 00:03:37.540
So really, when we look at the top layer,
the top layer is layer seven, right?

74
00:03:37.540 --> 00:03:38.930
And you might say, wait a second Wes,

75
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:42.320
doesn't the numerical
system start with one?

76
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:43.380
Why are you starting with seven?

77
00:03:43.380 --> 00:03:46.730
Well, if I'm sending information I
actually start at layer seven and

78
00:03:46.730 --> 00:03:49.480
I work my way down to layer one.

79
00:03:49.480 --> 00:03:51.530
Now, if you're receiving information,
so in this case,

80
00:03:51.530 --> 00:03:54.290
let's say that I'm sending
information to Zach here.

81
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:57.920
When he receives that information, what
he's doing, his network adapter really,

82
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:01.790
and the cable of the wireless
radiated energy if you will.

83
00:04:01.790 --> 00:04:03.640
It's receiving the raw bits, right?

84
00:04:03.640 --> 00:04:06.210
The electrical impulses,
the binary ones and zeros, so

85
00:04:06.210 --> 00:04:08.340
he actually starts at layer one, right?

86
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:10.430
The bottom most layer, and

87
00:04:10.430 --> 00:04:15.030
he works his way up until we get to layer
seven, where the last thing that's left is

88
00:04:15.030 --> 00:04:18.280
the data that we intended to send
information between two systems.

89
00:04:18.280 --> 00:04:21.340
So that's a little bit about
what the OSI model is.

90
00:04:21.340 --> 00:04:24.930
Let's talk a little bit more about
each one of this individual layers.

91
00:04:24.930 --> 00:04:26.830
So I've got a little diagram here and

92
00:04:26.830 --> 00:04:29.670
it could help us out to
understand these layers.

93
00:04:29.670 --> 00:04:31.640
Notice that we have application.

94
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:34.650
All right, that's Layer 7 and
you could see both side of this, right?

95
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:36.390
I went ahead so you know what layer it is.

96
00:04:36.390 --> 00:04:38.310
And it is important because on the exam,

97
00:04:38.310 --> 00:04:42.103
when we are talking about the application
layer, they might tell you Layer 7.

98
00:04:42.103 --> 00:04:47.715
And it's up to you as a Net+ candidate to
know that layer seven is the application

99
00:04:47.715 --> 00:04:52.433
layer all right or that the presentation
layer is Layer 6, right.

100
00:04:52.433 --> 00:04:56.213
So I've got both of these here, right so
then also if you are happily to be talking

101
00:04:56.213 --> 00:05:00.104
to somebody about it, you know that Layer
4 right that could be the transport layer

102
00:05:00.104 --> 00:05:02.240
right and
you just have to understand these.

103
00:05:02.240 --> 00:05:04.640
So I'm gonna kinda use
them interchangeably.

104
00:05:04.640 --> 00:05:05.900
You have them here, you see them here,

105
00:05:05.900 --> 00:05:09.390
you can always pause the video and I would
memorize this information cuz there's

106
00:05:09.390 --> 00:05:13.330
no telling what questions they might
ask you when it comes to the exam.

107
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:16.900
All right, an OSI model is
something that I have been known to

108
00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:19.640
hear about questions that have
come up quite frequently, so

109
00:05:19.640 --> 00:05:21.830
it's a good thing to get
this under your belt.

110
00:05:21.830 --> 00:05:25.160
All right, so let's go ahead and
we're gonna start at the top layer there.

111
00:05:25.160 --> 00:05:27.590
And what I mean by the top layer,
I'm gonna say Layer 7,

112
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:31.000
right, because when we send information,
this is where we start.

113
00:05:31.000 --> 00:05:33.400
We start with the application layer.

114
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:35.930
And the application layer
is really responsible for

115
00:05:35.930 --> 00:05:38.870
giving us access to the network, right.

116
00:05:38.870 --> 00:05:42.590
Your user applications at that
application layer are responsible for

117
00:05:42.590 --> 00:05:45.710
giving you access to network resources,
all right.

118
00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:46.880
So that's the very first layer.

119
00:05:46.880 --> 00:05:49.590
Some of the examples of the protocols
that you would see here.

120
00:05:49.590 --> 00:05:51.210
Things like file transfer protocol.

121
00:05:51.210 --> 00:05:52.080
SMB is one.

122
00:05:52.080 --> 00:05:53.530
And I don't have all of
them in the list here.

123
00:05:53.530 --> 00:05:54.570
There are tons of them.

124
00:05:54.570 --> 00:05:56.060
So, it is up to you.

125
00:05:56.060 --> 00:05:58.280
Remember that we're just
giving you some examples here.

126
00:05:58.280 --> 00:06:01.130
I would definitely study these
protocols that we've talked about so

127
00:06:01.130 --> 00:06:03.750
that you know where they set
in the OSI model, right?

128
00:06:03.750 --> 00:06:05.480
So we have FTP, right?

129
00:06:05.480 --> 00:06:08.510
SMB.
We have POP3, right?

130
00:06:08.510 --> 00:06:10.420
SMTP, you'll notice these right away,
right?

131
00:06:10.420 --> 00:06:11.740
IMAP, these are email servers.

132
00:06:11.740 --> 00:06:15.570
All right, so an email application
is a type of application.

133
00:06:15.570 --> 00:06:19.580
And any kind of network-aware application
where you're sending communications,

134
00:06:19.580 --> 00:06:23.730
right, that's your entry point into
the networking side of things, right?

135
00:06:23.730 --> 00:06:29.210
HTTP, DNS, these are all examples
of application layer protocols.

136
00:06:29.210 --> 00:06:30.680
But then we move down,

137
00:06:30.680 --> 00:06:34.590
now that we've got access to the network,
where do we go from there?

138
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:37.590
Well now I want,
I've got this data, right?

139
00:06:37.590 --> 00:06:41.640
And the application layers given my data
access to the network, but the problem is,

140
00:06:41.640 --> 00:06:45.560
it's not in a format that
the network can really move, right?

141
00:06:45.560 --> 00:06:50.220
We wanna make sure that our data that
we're gonna send across this network

142
00:06:50.220 --> 00:06:52.750
is in a format that's
transparent to the network.

143
00:06:52.750 --> 00:06:54.260
I want you to think about it another way.

144
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:54.970
Think about it this way.

145
00:06:56.010 --> 00:07:01.690
If I have a handwritten letter and I need
to send it across the snail mail system,

146
00:07:01.690 --> 00:07:05.310
here in the states the USPS,
the postal system.

147
00:07:05.310 --> 00:07:07.790
I can't just take that letter and
throw it in the mail.

148
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:08.990
Now you might say, well, yes, you can.

149
00:07:08.990 --> 00:07:09.530
No, no, no.

150
00:07:09.530 --> 00:07:10.690
Technically, I can't, right?

151
00:07:10.690 --> 00:07:13.830
I can't get done writing that letter,
fold that letter up, just like that, and

152
00:07:13.830 --> 00:07:15.540
throw it in the mail, right?

153
00:07:15.540 --> 00:07:16.380
Why?

154
00:07:16.380 --> 00:07:19.060
Because it's not in
a format that the carrier

155
00:07:19.060 --> 00:07:22.910
understands how to get it from where
it was to where it's supposed to be.

156
00:07:22.910 --> 00:07:27.180
So we need a way that we format it,
so that starting point,

157
00:07:27.180 --> 00:07:31.070
the carrier can use it,
can transport across the network, right?

158
00:07:31.070 --> 00:07:33.210
So the presentation layer's
all about formatting.

159
00:07:33.210 --> 00:07:35.500
It's like taking the envelope,
opening it and

160
00:07:35.500 --> 00:07:37.030
putting your letter in the envelope,
right?

161
00:07:37.030 --> 00:07:37.930
That's just the start.

162
00:07:37.930 --> 00:07:42.240
But at least the envelope or a box or
whatever you might be shipping, right?

163
00:07:42.240 --> 00:07:45.451
If you're shipping like a,
I don't know, candy to somebody,

164
00:07:45.451 --> 00:07:46.706
you might put it in a box.

165
00:07:46.706 --> 00:07:51.620
But you need a container that we can now
put it across the carrier's mail system.

166
00:07:51.620 --> 00:07:54.517
Well it's the same thing with
your network communications.

167
00:07:54.517 --> 00:07:56.563
I have a letter,
I need to put it in a format.

168
00:07:56.563 --> 00:08:00.937
I need to start a way putting it in
a format that the network can understand,

169
00:08:00.937 --> 00:08:01.640
all right?

170
00:08:01.640 --> 00:08:04.005
And that's where the presentation
later starts, right?

171
00:08:04.005 --> 00:08:06.643
Sometimes it's called the syntax layer,
cuz again,

172
00:08:06.643 --> 00:08:08.960
it's about the syntax to the network,
right?

173
00:08:08.960 --> 00:08:12.700
We don't want the network to have to worry
about the formatting process, right?

174
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:14.399
So this is the first part.

175
00:08:14.399 --> 00:08:16.714
This is where things like data
encryption happen, right?

176
00:08:16.714 --> 00:08:18.744
This is where things
like compression happen.

177
00:08:18.744 --> 00:08:24.612
If you are familiar with JPEG, TIFF,
GIF, all these formats, right?

178
00:08:24.612 --> 00:08:26.503
These formats sit right here.

179
00:08:26.503 --> 00:08:31.100
And again, I want you to remember things
like data encryption and compression.

180
00:08:31.100 --> 00:08:32.830
So thats the presentation layer, right?

181
00:08:34.400 --> 00:08:37.740
Now that I've got this envelope, right?

182
00:08:37.740 --> 00:08:41.435
Now I got to start making some
decisions on, how I'm gonna send it?

183
00:08:41.435 --> 00:08:43.153
How I'm gonna set up the communication?

184
00:08:43.153 --> 00:08:46.020
And that's where the next layer comes in.

185
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:47.890
The next layer you'll see
that we have right here,

186
00:08:47.890 --> 00:08:49.870
is what is known as the session layer.

187
00:08:49.870 --> 00:08:52.660
Now the session layer, you'll see some of
the things that I've written down here,

188
00:08:52.660 --> 00:08:56.830
but I know you guys can read those,
these three things here.

189
00:08:56.830 --> 00:08:58.910
I want you to make it easy on yourselves.

190
00:08:58.910 --> 00:09:01.660
You can always pause the video, and
you can look and write these down.

191
00:09:01.660 --> 00:09:05.430
But think about it this way,
the session layer is responsible for

192
00:09:05.430 --> 00:09:09.490
negotiating the parameters,
end to end of the communication.

193
00:09:09.490 --> 00:09:13.630
Bringing that session online, so
we can send that information, maintaining

194
00:09:13.630 --> 00:09:17.870
the session, and then tearing the session
down once we no longer need it, right?

195
00:09:17.870 --> 00:09:19.490
So that's what the session layer does.

196
00:09:19.490 --> 00:09:21.390
It's part of the communication
establishment.

197
00:09:21.390 --> 00:09:23.930
Defining those, in this case,
communication parameters.

198
00:09:23.930 --> 00:09:26.290
Defining the parameters
of the communication,

199
00:09:26.290 --> 00:09:27.760
maintaining the communication.

200
00:09:27.760 --> 00:09:30.180
And again,
one thing that I didn't put up here is

201
00:09:30.180 --> 00:09:34.500
actually tearing the communication down,
once we no longer need it right?

202
00:09:34.500 --> 00:09:38.190
So it's responsible for
session establishment.

203
00:09:38.190 --> 00:09:42.047
All right, now that we've got
through the first three layers,

204
00:09:42.047 --> 00:09:44.130
here is where it's interesting.

205
00:09:45.470 --> 00:09:49.630
When we get to the first three layers,
our data is in a format

206
00:09:49.630 --> 00:09:53.990
that is transparent to the network
from now on, all right?

207
00:09:53.990 --> 00:09:58.260
Now we've got a package
that is ready to go.

208
00:09:58.260 --> 00:10:01.060
Now we've got to determine what

209
00:10:01.060 --> 00:10:04.510
kind of delivery do we want across
that communication session?

210
00:10:04.510 --> 00:10:10.940
And in another episode, Zach and I talked
about connection oriented sessions

211
00:10:10.940 --> 00:10:15.430
using reliable communication methods,
reliable protocols.

212
00:10:15.430 --> 00:10:18.070
We also said that, hey, sometimes
you don't need all that overhead.

213
00:10:18.070 --> 00:10:21.689
I just need a, you throw it in that
blue mailbox and walk away from it.

214
00:10:21.689 --> 00:10:24.760
And I know that postal carrier
can get it where they need to.

215
00:10:24.760 --> 00:10:27.510
Again, sometimes though you
need delivery confirmation.

216
00:10:27.510 --> 00:10:30.750
And the transport layer is where we
choose the protocols that are gonna

217
00:10:30.750 --> 00:10:35.230
be responsible for actually moving
our information, all right?

218
00:10:35.230 --> 00:10:36.650
Two come into play.

219
00:10:36.650 --> 00:10:39.500
So if we take a look here,
we can see that at the transport layer,

220
00:10:39.500 --> 00:10:41.860
right, it moves the data
along the network.

221
00:10:41.860 --> 00:10:44.230
And we've got a couple choices, all right?

222
00:10:44.230 --> 00:10:46.470
We've got transmission control protocol.

223
00:10:46.470 --> 00:10:50.680
We've also got UDP as well,
User Datagram Protocol.

224
00:10:50.680 --> 00:10:54.260
Now I wanna take a second, I want you to
understand too that sometimes it's not so

225
00:10:54.260 --> 00:10:57.765
clearly defined which layer of
the OSI model certain things sit on.

226
00:10:57.765 --> 00:11:00.970
You're gonna notice that some will sit
across a couple of the layers too,

227
00:11:00.970 --> 00:11:03.160
just based on what they're doing, right?

228
00:11:03.160 --> 00:11:05.581
So if it's UDP, transport layer, why?

229
00:11:05.581 --> 00:11:08.233
Because I don't need any
connection establishment.

230
00:11:08.233 --> 00:11:12.924
But a connection establishment with TCP,
imagine where that also starts.

231
00:11:12.924 --> 00:11:14.435
It starts with the session layer, right?

232
00:11:14.435 --> 00:11:18.585
If you're doing communication
establishment, defining the parameters,

233
00:11:18.585 --> 00:11:21.465
maintaining the communication, and
then tearing it down, guess what?

234
00:11:21.465 --> 00:11:24.095
Transmission protocol
is a reliable protocol.

235
00:11:24.095 --> 00:11:27.955
It is a connection oriented protocol
in which the session has to be

236
00:11:27.955 --> 00:11:29.215
connected first.

237
00:11:29.215 --> 00:11:33.015
So it has functionalities that are also on
the session layer, but when we talk about

238
00:11:33.015 --> 00:11:38.120
it as a transport protocol,
that's happening there at layer four.

239
00:11:38.120 --> 00:11:41.000
Now remember that the transmission
control protocol at this point,

240
00:11:41.000 --> 00:11:43.580
what we have is we have that
data formatted in a way, but

241
00:11:43.580 --> 00:11:47.840
we might not be able to reliably
move it across the network.

242
00:11:47.840 --> 00:11:50.160
So what is transmission
control protocol do?

243
00:11:50.160 --> 00:11:54.650
Not only does it maintain that connection,
it will take your data and

244
00:11:54.650 --> 00:11:55.870
it will segment it.

245
00:11:55.870 --> 00:11:58.240
It will take it and break it down
into more manageable pieces, and

246
00:11:58.240 --> 00:12:01.680
then it will sequence it like we've
talked about in other episodes, right?

247
00:12:01.680 --> 00:12:04.170
And then as we send that
information over to the end point,

248
00:12:04.170 --> 00:12:07.210
it's gonna maintain that communication.

249
00:12:07.210 --> 00:12:10.700
It's like your delivery confirmation
on that little snail mail that we're

250
00:12:10.700 --> 00:12:11.840
sending right now.

251
00:12:11.840 --> 00:12:14.500
Now I gotta talk to the post office,
and I have to say, you know what?

252
00:12:14.500 --> 00:12:16.610
I want you to transport this
across your network and

253
00:12:16.610 --> 00:12:17.810
I wanna know when it gets there.

254
00:12:17.810 --> 00:12:21.210
I wanna make sure it gets there, and
I want you to let me know that it's there.

255
00:12:21.210 --> 00:12:23.040
I want an acknowledgement
that comes back that says,

256
00:12:23.040 --> 00:12:25.810
hey, Zach got that
package that I sent him.

257
00:12:25.810 --> 00:12:28.780
That's what transmission control
protocol is doing, okay?

258
00:12:28.780 --> 00:12:30.715
UDP, it's connectionless.

259
00:12:30.715 --> 00:12:33.500
It's best effort in delivery is
what really what they call best

260
00:12:33.500 --> 00:12:34.640
effort delivery.

261
00:12:34.640 --> 00:12:36.850
Now at this point,
I'm not looking at the post office saying,

262
00:12:36.850 --> 00:12:38.210
I need delivery confirmation.

263
00:12:38.210 --> 00:12:40.900
I'm walking over to the blue mailbox,
I'm throwing the letter in the mailbox.

264
00:12:40.900 --> 00:12:42.320
And I'm walking away, and
I hope it gets there.

265
00:12:43.560 --> 00:12:46.010
The difference between the two is
one is a little bit more complex,

266
00:12:46.010 --> 00:12:49.680
because of all the extra stuff that
transmission control protocol has to do.

267
00:12:49.680 --> 00:12:53.270
UDP, it's not so complex, it doesn't
take as much computational power.

268
00:12:53.270 --> 00:12:57.300
So if you need things like streaming
video, you need fast delivery,

269
00:12:57.300 --> 00:13:01.329
UDP is where it goes, where you know
give you another example like for

270
00:13:01.329 --> 00:13:02.802
instance when we do DNS.

271
00:13:02.802 --> 00:13:06.882
Remember, we said DNS gives you access
to the network, when we need do

272
00:13:06.882 --> 00:13:11.239
a DNS resolution request, you don't
care where you get your answer from,

273
00:13:11.239 --> 00:13:15.280
you don't even need to maintain
a communication, right?

274
00:13:15.280 --> 00:13:17.905
I just need to send it to
the DNS server and say, hey,

275
00:13:17.905 --> 00:13:20.551
tell me where www.google.com is,
I have no clue.

276
00:13:20.551 --> 00:13:22.180
I don't care where my answer comes from.

277
00:13:22.180 --> 00:13:24.530
I just need my answer, so
it doesn't have to be that complex.

278
00:13:24.530 --> 00:13:29.100
We can attach it to UDP port 53,
and send it to the DNS server.

279
00:13:29.100 --> 00:13:31.660
However, when you have two DNS
servers that are communicating and

280
00:13:31.660 --> 00:13:36.480
they're transferring zone information, you
don't want that database being corrupted.

281
00:13:36.480 --> 00:13:39.810
So DNS again, application layer
gives us access to the network.

282
00:13:39.810 --> 00:13:41.810
But this time,
when we get down to that transport layer,

283
00:13:41.810 --> 00:13:46.720
actually it's gonna start at session
layer, we're gonna do a TCP transport.

284
00:13:46.720 --> 00:13:50.350
Which means the two DNS servers are gonna
start that three way handshake,

285
00:13:50.350 --> 00:13:53.320
and they're gonna maintain that connection
to ensure that it gets there and

286
00:13:53.320 --> 00:13:57.820
the zone transfer happens without
corruption, all over port 53 again.

287
00:13:57.820 --> 00:14:00.780
So again, there are the transport layer
what we are saying is that it's really

288
00:14:00.780 --> 00:14:04.130
about the top of communications dealing,
all right?

289
00:14:04.130 --> 00:14:05.232
So keep that in mind.

290
00:14:05.232 --> 00:14:08.450
All right,
here we did even more fun stuff.

291
00:14:08.450 --> 00:14:10.405
These is where a lot of
the action happens, [LAUGH] and

292
00:14:10.405 --> 00:14:11.615
these is the networking layer.

293
00:14:11.615 --> 00:14:15.004
And if we can take a look at
the networking layer is responsible for

294
00:14:15.004 --> 00:14:16.610
forwarding your packets.

295
00:14:16.610 --> 00:14:19.160
It's responsible if you will, for routing.

296
00:14:19.160 --> 00:14:22.976
It's responsible for
addressing as well, right?

297
00:14:22.976 --> 00:14:25.930
When we talk about IP addresses and
we talk about that in other episodes,

298
00:14:25.930 --> 00:14:27.020
well guess what?

299
00:14:27.020 --> 00:14:29.920
IP addresses get attached
at the network layer.

300
00:14:29.920 --> 00:14:33.480
Now I've got this envelope, but
I can't do anything with it, right?

301
00:14:33.480 --> 00:14:35.330
I don't know where it's going,
so what do we do?

302
00:14:36.450 --> 00:14:39.660
We put a mailing address, right?

303
00:14:39.660 --> 00:14:41.330
And we put a return address.

304
00:14:41.330 --> 00:14:44.575
Now I know where it came from and
where it's going to, well IP says that,

305
00:14:44.575 --> 00:14:47.734
let's go ahead and take that data
packet and we'll add a header on it.

306
00:14:47.734 --> 00:14:51.180
And it's gonna have the source IP
address and the destination IP address.

307
00:14:51.180 --> 00:14:54.410
We can hand it to the router, and the
router's gonna use routing protocols to

308
00:14:54.410 --> 00:14:58.190
make sure that it hops through the
networks and gets to the right location.

309
00:14:58.190 --> 00:14:59.300
Great stuff, right?

310
00:14:59.300 --> 00:15:01.720
So we have some examples of some
protocols that you see here, and

311
00:15:01.720 --> 00:15:04.390
these are just a few, all right?

312
00:15:04.390 --> 00:15:08.400
So for instance you have IP, ICM,
the internet control message protocol.

313
00:15:08.400 --> 00:15:12.690
Hey, slow down there, you're sending
too much information, too fast, right?

314
00:15:12.690 --> 00:15:15.610
Flow control,
control message protocol, right?

315
00:15:15.610 --> 00:15:19.211
And many other things
like diagnostics too.

316
00:15:19.211 --> 00:15:20.580
Things like OSPF, right?

317
00:15:20.580 --> 00:15:25.560
The open shortest path first,
that's our distance vector protocol.

318
00:15:25.560 --> 00:15:31.120
I'm sorry, open short this past birth,
link state routing protocol.

319
00:15:31.120 --> 00:15:33.990
Rip version two, the next one, I'm
looking at rip, rip version two, right?

320
00:15:33.990 --> 00:15:36.300
That's our distance vector protocol,
right?

321
00:15:36.300 --> 00:15:38.310
BGP, Border Gateway Protocol.

322
00:15:38.310 --> 00:15:42.380
It's what we use to basically send
information between autonomous systems

323
00:15:42.380 --> 00:15:43.220
across the network.

324
00:15:43.220 --> 00:15:44.500
It's path vector protocol.

325
00:15:44.500 --> 00:15:49.398
But there are other ones there too that
I haven't mentioned, RIP version one

326
00:15:49.398 --> 00:15:54.390
is there, EIGRP could be here as well,
Cisco proprietary routing protocol.

327
00:15:54.390 --> 00:15:57.980
What else do you have IS-IS,
intermediate system, intermediate system.

328
00:15:57.980 --> 00:15:59.183
So there are more.

329
00:15:59.183 --> 00:16:01.577
We don't want to leave you hanging and
think this is all of them.

330
00:16:01.577 --> 00:16:03.620
This is just some of the more
common ones you might see.

331
00:16:04.650 --> 00:16:06.760
Now, here's one that
gets a little confusing.

332
00:16:06.760 --> 00:16:08.690
If it hasn't been confusing
with theory already,

333
00:16:08.690 --> 00:16:11.600
here's where it gets really confusing,
right?

334
00:16:11.600 --> 00:16:18.070
The Data-Link layer, layer two or
maybe we should say layer 2.1 and 2.2.

335
00:16:18.070 --> 00:16:19.425
Why is that?

336
00:16:19.425 --> 00:16:24.231
[LAUGH] Well, the Data-Link layer,
there came a point when they said,

337
00:16:24.231 --> 00:16:25.305
you know what?

338
00:16:25.305 --> 00:16:28.220
There's a little bit more happening

339
00:16:28.220 --> 00:16:32.030
here at these layers than
just a signal layer, right?

340
00:16:32.030 --> 00:16:36.236
So what they did is they came out with,
I believe it has an 802 standard, 802.2,

341
00:16:36.236 --> 00:16:38.010
that's the logical link control layer.

342
00:16:38.010 --> 00:16:42.070
So, they divided it into two sub layers
because they figured after a certain

343
00:16:42.070 --> 00:16:46.610
point that one layer didn't correctly
define what that layer was doing and

344
00:16:46.610 --> 00:16:48.640
it would almost be two sub layers.

345
00:16:48.640 --> 00:16:51.360
And that's technically what it is.

346
00:16:51.360 --> 00:16:52.750
So, LLC, don't let it confuse you.

347
00:16:52.750 --> 00:16:54.000
That's the logical link control.

348
00:16:54.000 --> 00:16:58.660
When you look at logical link control,
understand that this provides addressing.

349
00:16:58.660 --> 00:17:00.680
All right, error and flow control.

350
00:17:00.680 --> 00:17:02.970
But this addressing is
a little bit different, right?

351
00:17:02.970 --> 00:17:06.110
Now we're not talking about network
layer addresses, those are IP addresses.

352
00:17:06.110 --> 00:17:09.140
Now what we're talking about
are what are known as MAC addresses.

353
00:17:09.140 --> 00:17:11.110
Media Access Control addresses.

354
00:17:11.110 --> 00:17:12.105
Now be careful,

355
00:17:12.105 --> 00:17:16.350
because the Media Access Control layer
technically is not a MAC address.

356
00:17:16.350 --> 00:17:19.360
All right?
What it's responsible for,

357
00:17:19.360 --> 00:17:23.550
is actually controlling how the media,
the physical media,

358
00:17:23.550 --> 00:17:26.440
which we'll get to that layer in a second,
is accessed.

359
00:17:26.440 --> 00:17:28.590
That's what it's responsible for, right?

360
00:17:28.590 --> 00:17:31.100
It determines who's allowed
to access the media.

361
00:17:31.100 --> 00:17:33.780
We're gonna talk about other
technology standards, right?

362
00:17:33.780 --> 00:17:36.850
We're gonna talk about something known as
carrier-sense multiple access collision

363
00:17:36.850 --> 00:17:37.670
detection, right?

364
00:17:39.140 --> 00:17:40.480
CSMACD, right?

365
00:17:40.480 --> 00:17:45.020
This is how Ethernet would detect,
hey, is the media present?

366
00:17:45.020 --> 00:17:49.100
Right, remember where how are we gonna
place the information on the media going

367
00:17:49.100 --> 00:17:51.480
down to that physical layer.

368
00:17:51.480 --> 00:17:52.750
Is the media there?

369
00:17:52.750 --> 00:17:54.760
Okay, I can sense the media is there,
all right?

370
00:17:54.760 --> 00:17:57.950
I'm gonna send my information and
then I'm gonna listen again.

371
00:17:57.950 --> 00:17:59.170
I'm listening.

372
00:17:59.170 --> 00:18:02.350
I didn't detect a collision,
so that must've got there.

373
00:18:02.350 --> 00:18:06.200
Let me send another frame of information.

374
00:18:06.200 --> 00:18:07.000
All right.

375
00:18:07.000 --> 00:18:09.920
So, it controls things like your
carrier-sense multiple access

376
00:18:09.920 --> 00:18:10.720
collision detection.

377
00:18:10.720 --> 00:18:14.310
It also does things like
determining frame synchronization.

378
00:18:14.310 --> 00:18:16.410
And that's also something to be important.

379
00:18:16.410 --> 00:18:23.390
Basically, it determines where a frame
ends and where the next frame begins.

380
00:18:23.390 --> 00:18:26.000
Now, that leads us into
the physical layer.

381
00:18:26.000 --> 00:18:29.220
>> Actually you know, let's make mention,
cuz you know up here on my slide, I don't

382
00:18:29.220 --> 00:18:33.320
really have anything for the Data-Link
layer, but let me go ahead and give you

383
00:18:33.320 --> 00:18:37.420
an example, another example where you have
technologies that operate on both layers.

384
00:18:37.420 --> 00:18:40.240
And the reason I say that,
notice frame relay and

385
00:18:40.240 --> 00:18:41.870
down there at the physical layer.

386
00:18:41.870 --> 00:18:46.910
It actually operates at both layers,
right because frame relay defines not only

387
00:18:46.910 --> 00:18:51.970
things like how addressing is happening
and how frames are sent across a switch.

388
00:18:51.970 --> 00:18:55.410
It also defines the physical
characteristics of the media

389
00:18:55.410 --> 00:18:56.700
that connects to it.

390
00:18:56.700 --> 00:18:58.140
It's operating at both.

391
00:18:58.140 --> 00:18:59.030
Ethernet.

392
00:18:59.030 --> 00:19:00.310
Ethernet is another one, right.

393
00:19:00.310 --> 00:19:01.860
Ethernet we use MAC addresses.

394
00:19:01.860 --> 00:19:02.485
Well guess what?

395
00:19:02.485 --> 00:19:06.750
Data-Link layer, MAC addresses, but
Ethernet also, in things like our 10-based

396
00:19:06.750 --> 00:19:10.460
standards and our CAT cables, defines
the physical transmission media as well.

397
00:19:10.460 --> 00:19:13.790
So it's one of those things that
you can see again at both layers.

398
00:19:13.790 --> 00:19:15.680
Your network interface controllers, NIC.

399
00:19:15.680 --> 00:19:18.760
Your network adapters They
operate at both layers.

400
00:19:18.760 --> 00:19:22.260
And there's I know sometimes there's
contention in forums and stuff like that.

401
00:19:22.260 --> 00:19:25.410
But if you look at it, I mean physically
you've got a cable that connects to

402
00:19:25.410 --> 00:19:27.460
a network adapter, so
that's on the physical level.

403
00:19:27.460 --> 00:19:30.330
Inside of that network adapter
is burned in MAC address.

404
00:19:30.330 --> 00:19:32.990
So technically that's
at the Data-Link layer.

405
00:19:32.990 --> 00:19:34.340
So it's operating at both.

406
00:19:34.340 --> 00:19:35.340
But those are some examples.

407
00:19:35.340 --> 00:19:39.350
Switches, and we'll come back to that here
in a second and revisit that because we'll

408
00:19:39.350 --> 00:19:41.450
talk about some of the devices
that work on these other layers.

409
00:19:41.450 --> 00:19:42.980
Cuz that's also gonna
be important as well.

410
00:19:42.980 --> 00:19:45.260
But Zach is giving me that evil eye and

411
00:19:45.260 --> 00:19:48.265
he's telling me I think we might
have to go into a part two.

412
00:19:48.265 --> 00:19:50.960
>> [LAUGH] Looks like it might happen.

413
00:19:50.960 --> 00:19:52.850
