OSi model part two coming your way.

414
00:19:52.850 --> 00:19:53.870
Enjoyed part one.

415
00:19:53.870 --> 00:19:56.020
Wes, once again, fabulous job.

416
00:19:56.020 --> 00:19:59.630
And make sure you watch everything
in the Comp T and Net Plus series.

417
00:19:59.630 --> 00:20:02.620
While you're at it, check out the rest
of the videos on our course library.

418
00:20:02.620 --> 00:20:05.190
Hundreds of videos,
all designed to do one thing.

419
00:20:05.190 --> 00:20:06.300
Take you further.

420
00:20:06.300 --> 00:20:07.690
And tell everybody you
know about IT Pro TV.

421
00:20:07.690 --> 00:20:09.170
They'll be really glad you did.

422
00:20:09.170 --> 00:20:09.830
Thanks for watching.

423
00:20:09.830 --> 00:20:10.470
I'm Zach Memos.

424
00:20:10.470 --> 00:20:11.290
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

425
00:20:11.290 --> 00:20:12.180
>> And we will see you soon.

426
00:20:13.600 --> 00:20:19.576
[MUSIC]

427
00:20:19.576 --> 00:20:22.613
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: OSI Model Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.644
Welcome to ITProtv,

2
00:00:03.644 --> 00:00:08.495
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.495 --> 00:00:12.007
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.007 --> 00:00:14.027
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.027 --> 00:00:15.830
helping you learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:15.830 --> 00:00:21.730
I'm your host Zach Memnis as we continue
on with Comp net plus OSI model part two,

7
00:00:21.730 --> 00:00:23.400
Wes said, we'd come back with part two.

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:24.360
And here we are and here's Wes.

9
00:00:24.360 --> 00:00:25.000
>> All right.

10
00:00:25.000 --> 00:00:25.870
>> Good to see you sir.

11
00:00:25.870 --> 00:00:27.060
>> And let's roll it, the endings.

12
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:27.660
No, just kidding.

13
00:00:27.660 --> 00:00:28.720
Gosh, we wouldn't do that do you.

14
00:00:28.720 --> 00:00:29.480
That's right.

15
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:31.030
More of that OSI model.

16
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:32.060
Remember in the first part,

17
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:37.010
we talked pretty extensively about
the first few of the layers, right?

18
00:00:37.010 --> 00:00:39.630
I left you with not telling you
what the layer one was about.

19
00:00:39.630 --> 00:00:43.150
But remember that the OSI model,
the Open Systems Interconnection model,

20
00:00:43.150 --> 00:00:45.780
it goes back to 1984 if you will

21
00:00:45.780 --> 00:00:48.940
by the International Organization
of Standardization.

22
00:00:48.940 --> 00:00:52.010
Again, remember that it's
an abstract seven layer system.

23
00:00:52.010 --> 00:00:52.830
That defines or

24
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:57.760
standardizes the way we communicate across
open systems across computer networks.

25
00:00:57.760 --> 00:01:01.980
And we, in the last episode we
talked about the application layer,

26
00:01:01.980 --> 00:01:06.220
we talked about the presentation session,
transport,

27
00:01:06.220 --> 00:01:10.380
networking and the data link layer which
is comprised of the LOC and the M.

28
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:13.660
AC or the Mac layer, but
we left you with a cliffhanger.

29
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:15.630
Just like Zach said,
thats why were back here.

30
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:18.030
We left you not talking
about physical layer.

31
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:21.860
So, if we could go ahead and
look at our document here that we have.

32
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:22.400
Yeah Zach?

33
00:01:22.400 --> 00:01:26.610
Well I'm just gonna say so the physical
layer, this is the receiver, right?

34
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:28.310
>> You could see it this way.

35
00:01:28.310 --> 00:01:29.710
>> I'm making it very simplistic.

36
00:01:29.710 --> 00:01:30.370
>> Absolutely.

37
00:01:30.370 --> 00:01:32.970
>> But you are the receiver if you're
getting the physical layer here.

38
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:36.435
>> At this point what we're talking
about is there's no more addressing.

39
00:01:36.435 --> 00:01:38.950
>> Mm-hm.
>> What we have is we have the data link

40
00:01:38.950 --> 00:01:44.430
layer, the frame, essentially is placed
on the media in its raw bit form.

41
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:47.440
Now we're talking about the hardware,
right?

42
00:01:47.440 --> 00:01:48.390
The electrical,

43
00:01:48.390 --> 00:01:53.190
the mechanical characteristics that are
defined at this layer, and it is important

44
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:57.140
to understand that this is where we
talk about If we're using ethernet.

45
00:01:57.140 --> 00:01:58.880
Are we using fiber optic media?

46
00:01:58.880 --> 00:02:01.940
If we're using fiber optic media
are we using the 10 megabit?

47
00:02:01.940 --> 00:02:03.060
Are we using the 100 megabit?

48
00:02:03.060 --> 00:02:04.470
Are we using a gigabit?

49
00:02:04.470 --> 00:02:06.220
Are we using ten gigabit networks?

50
00:02:06.220 --> 00:02:09.390
And usually with fiber optics today you
won't waste your time with the older,

51
00:02:09.390 --> 00:02:10.200
slower standards.

52
00:02:10.200 --> 00:02:11.595
It'll be a gigabit and beyond.

53
00:02:11.595 --> 00:02:15.370
Ten gigabit standards right, but
that's all where we talk about those

54
00:02:15.370 --> 00:02:19.762
binary ones and zeros, that are actually
going from source to destination.

55
00:02:19.762 --> 00:02:23.020
All right, so
some of the technologies that we see here.

56
00:02:23.020 --> 00:02:25.170
Ethernet is one of those, DSL, ISDN,

57
00:02:25.170 --> 00:02:28.900
and let me step back and quit hitting
you guys with so many acronyms.

58
00:02:28.900 --> 00:02:32.970
Digital subscriber line, DSL modems,
they operate here at this layer.

59
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:36.033
ISDN, the integrated
services digital network.

60
00:02:36.033 --> 00:02:40.033
SON, the synchronized optical networking,
which is what it's called here according

61
00:02:40.033 --> 00:02:42.586
to the American National
Standards Institute, ANSI.

62
00:02:42.586 --> 00:02:45.497
But in the European nations,
right, yeah, the ITU,

63
00:02:45.497 --> 00:02:48.096
the International Telecommunication Union
and

64
00:02:48.096 --> 00:02:52.230
what they call is the synchronous
digital hierarchy, so SONET SDH, right?

65
00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:56.370
Again, same technologies that just
how they're standardized here in

66
00:02:56.370 --> 00:02:58.880
North America Versus
the European Nations and stuff.

67
00:02:58.880 --> 00:03:00.110
Frame relay, ATM.

68
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:04.230
We're not talking about
automated teller machine,

69
00:03:04.230 --> 00:03:06.310
we're talking about
the asynchronous transfer mode.

70
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:10.530
So another networking communication as
well as all happens here at this layer.

71
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:12.360
We talk about our base standard, right.

72
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:18.854
Ten base T, Ten megabits baseband
technology T being twisted pair.

73
00:03:18.854 --> 00:03:22.175
Not baseband but
those base technologies, right?

74
00:03:22.175 --> 00:03:25.124
They're part of the physical layer as
well, so you do have to know that.

75
00:03:25.124 --> 00:03:25.688
All right,

76
00:03:25.688 --> 00:03:29.537
now it's important to understand these
things because you have to understand.

77
00:03:29.537 --> 00:03:34.557
Let's go ahead and go into a little
bit more about, well we'll say for

78
00:03:34.557 --> 00:03:38.630
instance, how are these
Layers assisting each other.

79
00:03:38.630 --> 00:03:41.370
Well, let's talk a little bit about
something known as encapsulation.

80
00:03:41.370 --> 00:03:44.080
Now my head's kinda covering this one
up but we're gonna start up here and

81
00:03:44.080 --> 00:03:45.890
we're gonna start at Layer 7.

82
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:47.580
So we're gonna say, hey.

83
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:49.500
We're sending information.

84
00:03:49.500 --> 00:03:54.170
When we send information what's going
on here is the application layer,

85
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:56.810
again, it gives us access to the network,
right?

86
00:03:56.810 --> 00:04:00.220
And an encapsulation happens alright?

87
00:04:00.220 --> 00:04:03.040
Those of you out there that maybe
have seen those Russian dolls.

88
00:04:03.040 --> 00:04:04.100
>> Babushka.

89
00:04:04.100 --> 00:04:07.930
Thank you, thank you, very good Zach
>> Those little Russian dolls right?

90
00:04:07.930 --> 00:04:10.690
We one little Russian doll in a bigger,
in a bigger, in a bigger and

91
00:04:10.690 --> 00:04:11.930
then when you take them apart right?

92
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:15.500
You set there and stack them side by side
>> And they all look like my grandmother.

93
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:18.590
>> [LAUGH] Absolutely,
well I don't know about that.

94
00:04:18.590 --> 00:04:21.490
Apparently, it looks like Zack's
grandmother, and its also,

95
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:24.025
an analogy for encapsulation.

96
00:04:24.025 --> 00:04:25.780
[LAUGH] Because that's what's happening.

97
00:04:25.780 --> 00:04:28.870
All right, what you have is you
have something known as an SDU.

98
00:04:28.870 --> 00:04:32.970
An SDU is a service data unit and that
means that the application layer, right?

99
00:04:32.970 --> 00:04:38.170
Our SDU, or service data,
data units, service data units,

100
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:43.620
excuse me, is basically going to be
relying on the layer below it, all right?

101
00:04:43.620 --> 00:04:47.350
And when the layer below it
services the layer above it,

102
00:04:47.350 --> 00:04:50.080
that becomes what's known as
a protocol data unit, right?

103
00:04:50.080 --> 00:04:54.950
So keep that in mind but the application
layer, basically format your data in a way

104
00:04:54.950 --> 00:04:59.620
that it can, basically the application
gives access to the network, right?

105
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:01.780
Then we take it to
the presentation layer and

106
00:05:01.780 --> 00:05:06.720
the presentation layer adds its header to
it, basically encapsulating it as well.

107
00:05:06.720 --> 00:05:09.990
Again, little bit bigger of a dog, right?

108
00:05:09.990 --> 00:05:13.180
Now it is assisting the application layer,
right.

109
00:05:13.180 --> 00:05:17.450
So the applications layers SDU, all right,

110
00:05:17.450 --> 00:05:23.325
now becomes the presentations
layers Protocol Data Unit PDU.

111
00:05:23.325 --> 00:05:26.565
But now the presentation layer,
we can't stop there right?

112
00:05:26.565 --> 00:05:29.015
We got session establishment to happen.

113
00:05:29.015 --> 00:05:30.864
So now that it's got it's format.

114
00:05:30.864 --> 00:05:34.961
We've got one doll in another,
it's gonna pass it's information needing

115
00:05:34.961 --> 00:05:37.277
the assistance of the old
A layer below it.

116
00:05:37.277 --> 00:05:41.910
So now it turns into a service data
unit and it hands its information

117
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:46.309
requiring the services,
I'm going to keep saying surfaces.

118
00:05:46.309 --> 00:05:49.453
Services of the lower level
now in the session layer.

119
00:05:49.453 --> 00:05:52.003
The session layer treats that,

120
00:05:52.003 --> 00:05:57.343
basically that presentation
layer as its protocol data unit.

121
00:05:57.343 --> 00:06:00.503
So just understand that when an
application needs a service from a lower

122
00:06:00.503 --> 00:06:03.313
application, that's considered
a service data unit.

123
00:06:03.313 --> 00:06:07.183
When that lower layer actually
provides that service,

124
00:06:07.183 --> 00:06:10.423
that becomes the protocol data unit,
and then it hands that down and

125
00:06:10.423 --> 00:06:12.885
that process happens all the way
down to the physical layer.

126
00:06:12.885 --> 00:06:18.290
All right, and we go through this process
of adding and adding and adding, right.

127
00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:22.040
Just adding those,
basically those layers upon layers.

128
00:06:22.040 --> 00:06:25.910
The other way we could consider
it is like an onion, right.

129
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:27.502
Well what do you do?

130
00:06:27.502 --> 00:06:29.600
All right,
well if I was to pass this information.

131
00:06:29.600 --> 00:06:33.390
If we could take a look at that
information right there one more time.

132
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:35.910
Notice that the physical layer
down here at the bottom,

133
00:06:35.910 --> 00:06:39.190
those are your raw binary ones and zeros.

134
00:06:39.190 --> 00:06:42.070
Now, I want you to think about this,
if we don't think about the,

135
00:06:42.070 --> 00:06:44.650
maybe the Russian dolls,
maybe we'll think about an onion, right?

136
00:06:44.650 --> 00:06:48.290
I'm passing Zach over an onion, now we're
not gonna make Zach cry here on camera,

137
00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:49.222
we wouldn't do that to him.

138
00:06:49.222 --> 00:06:50.520
All right, but

139
00:06:50.520 --> 00:06:54.260
what he's gonna do, his computer is
gonna peel off the first layer, right?

140
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:57.620
In this case,
it's gonna be the data link layer, right?

141
00:06:57.620 --> 00:07:01.640
The data link layer is responsible for
sending traffic between two

142
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:06.020
physically connected machines, all right,
across things like our switches.

143
00:07:06.020 --> 00:07:08.170
So he peels off that layer.

144
00:07:08.170 --> 00:07:09.960
Says hey, is that my Mac address?

145
00:07:09.960 --> 00:07:11.060
Yes, it's my Mac address.

146
00:07:11.060 --> 00:07:14.420
Okay, so let me go ahead and
I'll process that a little bit more.

147
00:07:14.420 --> 00:07:14.960
Peel that off.

148
00:07:14.960 --> 00:07:16.680
Is this my IP address?

149
00:07:16.680 --> 00:07:18.050
Yeah, that's my IP address.

150
00:07:18.050 --> 00:07:22.010
So I'll process it a little bit more,
and we keep, basically, peeling

151
00:07:22.010 --> 00:07:26.180
off the onions to the layer to the center
part of that onion is your raw data.

152
00:07:26.180 --> 00:07:28.780
And that's what happens when
I told you in the first part,

153
00:07:28.780 --> 00:07:33.080
where we essentially get Layer 7 from
1 if I'm sending information right,

154
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:37.290
because if I'm sending information,
I've got my raw data or data in general.

155
00:07:37.290 --> 00:07:38.920
And it goes down through the layers,

156
00:07:38.920 --> 00:07:43.160
little header after header is added on
until we get down to the Data Link Layer

157
00:07:43.160 --> 00:07:47.170
that finally that MAC layer
puts it on the network, right?

158
00:07:47.170 --> 00:07:50.870
Puts that information on the network, once
it's on the network it's now in the format

159
00:07:50.870 --> 00:07:53.040
of those electrical, or raw bits, right?

160
00:07:53.040 --> 00:07:57.430
Electrical impulses, as we process
the information each one of those

161
00:07:57.430 --> 00:07:59.560
layers they're in capitulations, right?

162
00:07:59.560 --> 00:08:04.160
Become decapitulated, and
that is up the OSI model, so

163
00:08:04.160 --> 00:08:07.480
you might hear the term down the stack,
or up the stack.

164
00:08:07.480 --> 00:08:11.660
All right, and for troubleshooting
purposes you also troubleshoot

165
00:08:13.390 --> 00:08:15.400
down the stack or up the stack, right?

166
00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:18.140
So, the OSI model starts out, for

167
00:08:18.140 --> 00:08:20.360
a lot of people it just
starts out as theory, right?

168
00:08:20.360 --> 00:08:22.300
But then they get away from this,
it's just theory,

169
00:08:22.300 --> 00:08:25.660
well it's not really theory and
let me tell you why.

170
00:08:25.660 --> 00:08:30.100
When we talk about the devices that work
at these layers, I got a little diagram

171
00:08:30.100 --> 00:08:36.040
to kind of show you some of the different
components that operate at each layer.

172
00:08:36.040 --> 00:08:41.000
Here's why I tell you figure out what
layer in the OSI model's having the issue,

173
00:08:41.000 --> 00:08:42.450
if I have a DNS issue.

174
00:08:42.450 --> 00:08:45.510
Is it my DNS application
that's having a problem?

175
00:08:45.510 --> 00:08:50.600
Well if it is it's up the application
layer and I know where that sits or

176
00:08:50.600 --> 00:08:54.060
maybe it's the fact that
the IP address is wrong.

177
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:56.890
Well if the IP address is wrong
that's at layer three right?

178
00:08:56.890 --> 00:09:00.790
That's the network layer, so you can
use the OSI model to figure out where

179
00:09:00.790 --> 00:09:03.000
the communication breakdown is happening.

180
00:09:03.000 --> 00:09:05.890
Right some of the devices that you see,
some of these higher devices you'll see

181
00:09:05.890 --> 00:09:09.530
some of these devices that operate
at different layers as well too, and

182
00:09:09.530 --> 00:09:10.630
I'll explain that as I go.

183
00:09:10.630 --> 00:09:13.900
So, for instance, you have certain
firewalls that have to understand

184
00:09:13.900 --> 00:09:18.120
the session layer, they understand
application layer information, right?

185
00:09:18.120 --> 00:09:21.050
They understand ports if they're
doing stateful packet inspection and

186
00:09:21.050 --> 00:09:22.930
that's what the NGFW is.

187
00:09:22.930 --> 00:09:24.860
It's next generation firewall.

188
00:09:24.860 --> 00:09:29.050
These current, the next generations, our
current generation, firewalls are very,

189
00:09:29.050 --> 00:09:29.610
very smart.

190
00:09:29.610 --> 00:09:33.850
They operate on just about
every level of the OSI model.

191
00:09:33.850 --> 00:09:35.370
All right,
when you get to the transport layer,

192
00:09:35.370 --> 00:09:38.090
this is where things like gateways happen.

193
00:09:38.090 --> 00:09:40.950
Now, I want you to understand that
a gateway is a little bit different than

194
00:09:40.950 --> 00:09:45.380
what we're talking about when
we say a TCPIP default gateway.

195
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:46.170
All right?

196
00:09:46.170 --> 00:09:50.960
The TCPIP default gateway is just
an IP address that basically

197
00:09:50.960 --> 00:09:54.420
connects you to your router and allows
you to send traffic off your network.

198
00:09:54.420 --> 00:09:56.780
When we talk about a gateway device here,

199
00:09:56.780 --> 00:09:58.660
we're talking about something
a little bit different.

200
00:09:58.660 --> 00:10:01.970
This is what allows you that
interoperability between two

201
00:10:01.970 --> 00:10:03.410
similar systems.

202
00:10:03.410 --> 00:10:07.740
All right, so for instance maybe you
were in a TCPI based network and

203
00:10:07.740 --> 00:10:11.370
in the earlier days, maybe you were
still on an IPXSPX network right?

204
00:10:11.370 --> 00:10:14.230
Well, a gateway device is
actually translating between two

205
00:10:14.230 --> 00:10:17.200
dissimilar protocol so
that we get the interoperability together.

206
00:10:17.200 --> 00:10:18.930
That's what we mean when
we say a gateway device.

207
00:10:19.930 --> 00:10:21.520
Now, when we come down
to the network layer,

208
00:10:21.520 --> 00:10:24.320
you're gonna notice that we
have things like routers.

209
00:10:24.320 --> 00:10:24.830
All right.

210
00:10:24.830 --> 00:10:28.000
Well, routers, I want you to think
about what they do, all right?

211
00:10:28.000 --> 00:10:32.050
If I need to troubleshoot, I can't send
information of of my local network well,

212
00:10:32.050 --> 00:10:34.590
I do have to check things like
the physical cables, right?

213
00:10:34.590 --> 00:10:37.610
We have to make sure that our
network adaptors are turned on.

214
00:10:37.610 --> 00:10:43.150
That the switches are available but
then we get to the network layer and

215
00:10:43.150 --> 00:10:45.250
we find out that maybe the IP
addresses are wrong, or

216
00:10:45.250 --> 00:10:47.820
maybe there's a bad route in
the routing table, right?

217
00:10:47.820 --> 00:10:50.890
I can tell where the breakdown
is happening and

218
00:10:50.890 --> 00:10:53.720
that's something that you should know,
and not just outside of theory but

219
00:10:53.720 --> 00:10:57.090
you should also take it into
your networking career as well.

220
00:10:57.090 --> 00:11:00.570
So routers, IP addresses,
routing protocols right?

221
00:11:00.570 --> 00:11:05.020
That's what the routers
basically operate off of.

222
00:11:05.020 --> 00:11:09.820
Layer 3 switches and
why do we call it a Layer 3 switch?

223
00:11:09.820 --> 00:11:12.110
Well, you're gonna have to wait
till I explain a switch and

224
00:11:12.110 --> 00:11:13.160
then we'll come back to it, right?

225
00:11:13.160 --> 00:11:14.785
That's not too nice of me, right?

226
00:11:14.785 --> 00:11:17.750
[LAUGH] A switch operates traditionally,

227
00:11:17.750 --> 00:11:20.930
switching happens at Layer 2,
we talked about MAC addresses, right?

228
00:11:20.930 --> 00:11:25.830
We talked about forwarding frames
between end points, right?

229
00:11:25.830 --> 00:11:28.190
They understand MAC addresses,
but some switches, and

230
00:11:28.190 --> 00:11:31.110
a lot of switches today
are also Layer 3 switches.

231
00:11:31.110 --> 00:11:32.450
Because what does that mean?

232
00:11:32.450 --> 00:11:34.650
Well, it just means that they
understand IP addresses.

233
00:11:34.650 --> 00:11:37.950
They can act like a router and that's
why they call them a Layer 3 switch.

234
00:11:37.950 --> 00:11:41.780
You might hear the term brouter, and
I've always thought that that's funny,

235
00:11:41.780 --> 00:11:44.570
but don't worry about it,
it's not a bridge router,

236
00:11:44.570 --> 00:11:47.490
it means it understands Layer 2 and
it understands Layer 3.

237
00:11:47.490 --> 00:11:50.650
When we say a Layer 3 switch,
we're talking about one that essentially

238
00:11:50.650 --> 00:11:53.827
understands the functions
of a router all right?

239
00:11:53.827 --> 00:11:56.780
Now switches, network adaptors.

240
00:11:56.780 --> 00:12:01.330
Now you'll notice I've said before that
some of these things operate at two layers

241
00:12:01.330 --> 00:12:02.560
just like the layer three switch.

242
00:12:02.560 --> 00:12:06.050
It operates natively at layer two and
it understands IP so

243
00:12:06.050 --> 00:12:07.430
it operates at layer three as well.

244
00:12:07.430 --> 00:12:10.030
Well guess what?
A network interface card has a physical

245
00:12:10.030 --> 00:12:11.890
cable plugged into it.

246
00:12:11.890 --> 00:12:14.940
All right, but
it also operates on Mac addresses, right?

247
00:12:14.940 --> 00:12:19.990
And it does encoding and stuff so we do
have some functionality that is happening

248
00:12:19.990 --> 00:12:25.020
at the layer too as well as
the physical layer as well.

249
00:12:25.020 --> 00:12:29.260
So there are certain functionalities and
I went ahead and just put it at layer one.

250
00:12:29.260 --> 00:12:34.239
Again you'll see many different people
will kind of debate where it should be,

251
00:12:34.239 --> 00:12:37.452
but it does have
characteristics that share both.

252
00:12:37.452 --> 00:12:42.451
Now down here in the physical layer,
a couple people I don't

253
00:12:42.451 --> 00:12:47.560
think really would have any issue
with is hubs and repeaters.

254
00:12:47.560 --> 00:12:52.440
See a hub is a, it's a really dumb device
as far as network connectivity devices.

255
00:12:52.440 --> 00:12:54.430
It doesn't understand addressing,

256
00:12:54.430 --> 00:12:57.350
it doesn't make logical
decisions like a router does.

257
00:12:57.350 --> 00:13:00.200
It doesn't even look it like a Mac table,
like a switch does and

258
00:13:00.200 --> 00:13:02.980
make sure it knows where
to forward information.

259
00:13:02.980 --> 00:13:06.890
It is electrically hardwired to
receive a signal on one port and

260
00:13:06.890 --> 00:13:09.990
then broadcast it out on all other ports.

261
00:13:09.990 --> 00:13:13.050
It's electrically wired that way,
there's no logic all right.

262
00:13:13.050 --> 00:13:15.070
Repeaters, what is a repeater do?

263
00:13:15.070 --> 00:13:17.350
Well, a repeaters a way
to regenerate the signal.

264
00:13:17.350 --> 00:13:21.500
When a signal is getting to
the end of its physical media,

265
00:13:21.500 --> 00:13:24.590
the maximum transmission distance.

266
00:13:24.590 --> 00:13:27.220
If it went any further pass
that then we can get errors,

267
00:13:27.220 --> 00:13:30.410
we get communication errors,
we get what's known as signal attenuation.

268
00:13:30.410 --> 00:13:33.520
And attenuation is just the progress
degradation of the signal as it gets

269
00:13:33.520 --> 00:13:35.120
farther and farther from it's source.

270
00:13:35.120 --> 00:13:36.915
When you get a while.

271
00:13:36.915 --> 00:13:38.435
Wireless repeater in your house?

272
00:13:38.435 --> 00:13:40.115
Well, you got a physical
layer device right?

273
00:13:40.115 --> 00:13:41.825
Because what is the wireless
repeater doing?

274
00:13:41.825 --> 00:13:44.725
It's receiving that wireless signal,
it's regenerating it and

275
00:13:44.725 --> 00:13:46.155
it boost it out further.

276
00:13:46.155 --> 00:13:50.315
So it thereby extends the length of
the transmission distance, right?

277
00:13:50.315 --> 00:13:52.550
Have wire repeaters and
you have wireless repeaters.

278
00:13:52.550 --> 00:13:55.080
These all operate on the physical layer.

279
00:13:55.080 --> 00:13:56.270
We'll also have things like modems.

280
00:13:56.270 --> 00:13:58.430
We'll talk a little bit more on
other episodes about modems,

281
00:13:58.430 --> 00:14:02.590
but modem is just short for modulator
demodulator, modulation demodulation.

282
00:14:02.590 --> 00:14:04.900
All right, it takes an electrical signal.

283
00:14:04.900 --> 00:14:07.080
It modulates it with a modulation scheme,

284
00:14:07.080 --> 00:14:11.130
and it sends it across
an analog PSTN line, right?

285
00:14:11.130 --> 00:14:15.680
Physical public switch telephone network
lines and then on the other end,

286
00:14:15.680 --> 00:14:16.720
what happens?

287
00:14:16.720 --> 00:14:20.000
Right, the modem does the demodulation,
and it removes the encoding.

288
00:14:20.000 --> 00:14:23.130
And it leaves the digital bits that are
then delivered to the network adapter and

289
00:14:23.130 --> 00:14:27.040
processed by your computer, and
back up the stack we go, right?

290
00:14:27.040 --> 00:14:30.860
So these are some of the things that you
have to be aware of when it comes to

291
00:14:30.860 --> 00:14:31.850
the exam, all right?

292
00:14:31.850 --> 00:14:33.920
Know what your layers are.

293
00:14:33.920 --> 00:14:38.350
Know the processing models, or
how our computer's process.

294
00:14:38.350 --> 00:14:40.700
Know what encapsulation is.

295
00:14:40.700 --> 00:14:43.580
Remember, encapsulation
is just the process of

296
00:14:43.580 --> 00:14:47.500
one layer handing its information
to be assisted by the lower layer.

297
00:14:47.500 --> 00:14:52.300
It basically puts it in this envelope
if you will and it adds its data to it.

298
00:14:52.300 --> 00:14:56.070
And then the process repeats all the way
to we get down to the switch and

299
00:14:56.070 --> 00:14:59.250
that MAC layer defining who
can access the media, right.

300
00:14:59.250 --> 00:15:00.390
These are important things.

301
00:15:00.390 --> 00:15:05.160
Remember what layer of the OSI model,
things like switches operate on,

302
00:15:05.160 --> 00:15:07.460
things like routers,
gateways, if you will.

303
00:15:07.460 --> 00:15:10.750
Understand what an application
layer firewall is.

304
00:15:10.750 --> 00:15:13.900
You might have heard that term before and
never understood what it meant.

305
00:15:13.900 --> 00:15:15.660
You say, well,
we've got an application layer firewall.

306
00:15:15.660 --> 00:15:16.956
What does that mean?

307
00:15:16.956 --> 00:15:21.562
It means, a firewall, and that's your
next generation firewall that are smart

308
00:15:21.562 --> 00:15:24.693
enough to know that just
because you tell me it's DNS.

309
00:15:24.693 --> 00:15:26.823
That firewall can look at and say,

310
00:15:26.823 --> 00:15:31.620
I understand HTTP traffic and
that's not the DNS, that's HTML in there.

311
00:15:31.620 --> 00:15:34.030
So now nice try but
that's a web based attack.

312
00:15:34.030 --> 00:15:36.480
It's smart enough to understand this,
right?

313
00:15:36.480 --> 00:15:38.185
And you wanna be aware of it, right?

314
00:15:38.185 --> 00:15:42.490
One of the things we talked about
TCP is session identifiers.

315
00:15:42.490 --> 00:15:43.145
Those port numbers.

316
00:15:43.145 --> 00:15:45.582
Port numbers happen at the session layer.

317
00:15:45.582 --> 00:15:49.984
We want you to be aware of these
technologies and certainly, you could

318
00:15:49.984 --> 00:15:54.990
spend an entire month, in just the OSI
model, but remember some of the basics.

319
00:15:54.990 --> 00:15:59.820
If you remember these basics, you're gonna
be doing well for your next Net Plus exam.

320
00:15:59.820 --> 00:16:00.750
>> Fantastic.

321
00:16:00.750 --> 00:16:04.830
OSI model, part two and there's a part
one and you watch them both, and

322
00:16:04.830 --> 00:16:06.930
you'll see that Wes has put
together all this information for

323
00:16:06.930 --> 00:16:08.590
you, to help you in the exam.

324
00:16:08.590 --> 00:16:10.620
And make sure you watch
every single episode,

325
00:16:10.620 --> 00:16:14.620
in the CompTIA Net+ series,
and every other video!

326
00:16:14.620 --> 00:16:16.330
And of course, library,
hundreds of videos.

327
00:16:16.330 --> 00:16:18.720
So they're all designed to
help you go further and

328
00:16:18.720 --> 00:16:21.880
tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be mighty glad you did.

329
00:16:21.880 --> 00:16:23.200
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

330
00:16:23.200 --> 00:16:23.910
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

331
00:16:23.910 --> 00:16:26.272
>> And we'll see you soon.

332
00:16:26.272 --> 00:16:32.261
[MUSIC]

333
00:16:32.261 --> 00:16:34.220
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the various characteristics and attributes of network communications. They look at concepts like unicast, multicast, broadcast domains and more.
episodes.title: Network Traffic Properties
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.704
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.704 --> 00:00:06.106
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.106 --> 00:00:12.067
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.067 --> 00:00:13.245
>> Hello and thank you for

5
00:00:13.245 --> 00:00:16.420
choosing ITProTV,
helping you to learn everywhere you go.

6
00:00:16.420 --> 00:00:20.024
I'm Zach Memos, you host as we
continue on with CompTIA Net+,

7
00:00:20.024 --> 00:00:23.316
Network Traffic Properties is
the title of this episode.

8
00:00:23.316 --> 00:00:26.686
And Wes Bryan is here once again to
help us out because he likes us.

9
00:00:26.686 --> 00:00:29.040
Wes [LAUGH] it's good to have you here,
thanks for joining us.

10
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:32.143
>> Hey, Zach, thanks for having me back,
that's right, you guys are okay,

11
00:00:32.143 --> 00:00:34.876
you're all right with me,
I don't care what Zach says about you.

12
00:00:34.876 --> 00:00:36.846
>> [LAUGH]
>> No just kidding, that's right,

13
00:00:36.846 --> 00:00:41.545
we are back to talk about the different
characteristics, right, the properties,

14
00:00:41.545 --> 00:00:44.143
if you will,
of our network communications.

15
00:00:44.143 --> 00:00:47.801
Cuz believe it or not really all we've
been talking about is the source and

16
00:00:47.801 --> 00:00:48.874
destination right.

17
00:00:48.874 --> 00:00:50.713
The end points of communications, and

18
00:00:50.713 --> 00:00:53.724
we've been talking about
the redistribution points, right,

19
00:00:53.724 --> 00:00:57.070
whether that be your connectivity
devices or a repeater, right.

20
00:00:57.070 --> 00:00:59.440
But we have to look a little bit more,

21
00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:03.080
a little bit more in depth on some
of these characteristics, right.

22
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:03.960
Some of the properties,

23
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:07.770
because in certain scenarios your
computers might communicate one way.

24
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:12.670
Another given scenario, your computers
might communicate completely different.

25
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:16.547
And then in other ways, they all will
differ from all the other ones that we'll

26
00:01:16.547 --> 00:01:18.449
talk about as we go into this episode.

27
00:01:18.449 --> 00:01:20.127
So, and it's gonna be important for

28
00:01:20.127 --> 00:01:22.998
you guys out there to understand
some of the characteristics or

29
00:01:22.998 --> 00:01:26.024
properties that we're gonna take
care of here in this episode.

30
00:01:26.024 --> 00:01:27.425
>> So,
Wes it sounds like you're talking about

31
00:01:27.425 --> 00:01:28.910
there's more than one communication type.

32
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:30.760
So can you tell us a little
bit more about that?

33
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:34.180
>> Most definitely,
when it comes to communications,

34
00:01:34.180 --> 00:01:36.370
largely it's broken down into
three of the most common.

35
00:01:36.370 --> 00:01:38.962
There's a fourth one here
that isn't on the list,

36
00:01:38.962 --> 00:01:41.254
so Zach,
I'm gonna throw you a curveball and

37
00:01:41.254 --> 00:01:44.530
kinda steer it off the beaten path
when we get to that fourth one.

38
00:01:44.530 --> 00:01:46.980
Because even though it's
not called out on the exam,

39
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:48.170
I want you to be prepared for it.

40
00:01:48.170 --> 00:01:51.910
Because we know here at ITProTV that many
of you that are gonna sit the Network+

41
00:01:51.910 --> 00:01:54.450
exam might go on to other certifications.

42
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:58.980
So it's not always just about what is on
the exam, but to try to give you some

43
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:01.010
additional information,
even if they don't call it out.

44
00:02:01.010 --> 00:02:04.744
So the very first one I want to call out
is, and I got a little diagram here and

45
00:02:04.744 --> 00:02:07.554
this communication type is
what's known as a unicast.

46
00:02:07.554 --> 00:02:12.255
And when we look at unicast, unicast is
a one to one communication, all right,

47
00:02:12.255 --> 00:02:15.973
that's really what is boils down
to when we say we got a source of

48
00:02:15.973 --> 00:02:19.720
the communication, and
we got a single destination, right.

49
00:02:19.720 --> 00:02:23.723
Source and destination, that's a unicast,
so for instance if I'm gonna communicate,

50
00:02:23.723 --> 00:02:27.320
let's say Zach and my computer, I'm
gonna send him some information, right.

51
00:02:27.320 --> 00:02:31.120
Or maybe I'm gonna connect to his
computer over like a share if you will,

52
00:02:31.120 --> 00:02:33.465
like a shared resource
that's on his computer,

53
00:02:33.465 --> 00:02:36.160
it's a straight one to one communication,
right.

54
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:40.370
Or if I do something like, maybe I
ping Zach's computer from my computer,

55
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:44.450
just to see if, test reachability,
right, and I get replies back.

56
00:02:44.450 --> 00:02:48.610
Well those are one to one,
right, one to one communication,

57
00:02:48.610 --> 00:02:50.532
is what we know as a unicast.

58
00:02:50.532 --> 00:02:55.527
Now I do want you to understand that in
a unicast no other computer, none of these

59
00:02:55.527 --> 00:03:00.538
other computers actually receives any
signal and that's important, right.

60
00:03:00.538 --> 00:03:04.403
Not only to know that it's a one to one
communication but also to know that these

61
00:03:04.403 --> 00:03:08.340
other computers aren't going
to receive that communication.

62
00:03:08.340 --> 00:03:12.319
Now we have another type of communication
and that's what's known as a broadcast and

63
00:03:12.319 --> 00:03:15.427
that's really, Zach,
that's the polar opposite of a unicast.

64
00:03:15.427 --> 00:03:17.092
We say unicast being one to one,

65
00:03:17.092 --> 00:03:20.733
a broadcast communication is like
going to the food court in the mall,

66
00:03:20.733 --> 00:03:24.697
standing up on the table and yelling out,
and everybody hears you, right.

67

290
00:15:17.830 --> 00:15:19.012
Remember what we said about a hub?

291
00:15:19.012 --> 00:15:22.290
Even though this is a star topology,
right?

292
00:15:22.290 --> 00:15:26.350
Physically, when one
communication goes in to and

293
00:15:26.350 --> 00:15:30.710
probably be better to even go over to our
broadcast, because this is actually, know

294
00:15:30.710 --> 00:15:36.790
that this is a physical star topology, but
because of the hub, the way the hub works,

295
00:15:36.790 --> 00:15:40.770
it receives the communications and it
just broadcasts it out to all the ports.

296
00:15:40.770 --> 00:15:46.420
That means every communication that
goes into the hub is gonna be broadcast.

297
00:15:46.420 --> 00:15:47.590
It means there's a potential for

298
00:15:47.590 --> 00:15:49.900
an electrical collusion especially
when you have shared media.

299
00:15:49.900 --> 00:15:53.115
That is what's known
as a collusion domain.

300
00:15:53.115 --> 00:15:59.337
All right, and what it means is that a PC
one sends information Into this hub.

301
00:15:59.337 --> 00:16:02.089
It's going to broadcast
it out all other ports.

302
00:16:02.089 --> 00:16:07.139
That means there's a potential for
two of these PCs, if not all of these PCs,

303
00:16:07.139 --> 00:16:11.024
to try to send information into
the hub at the same time, and

304
00:16:11.024 --> 00:16:13.970
we get an electrical collision.

305
00:16:13.970 --> 00:16:16.600
That's what's known as a collision domain.

306
00:16:16.600 --> 00:16:21.730
And you have to understand that anytime
you put a hub in your networks,

307
00:16:21.730 --> 00:16:26.280
you increase the contention because
it's all broadcast communications and

308
00:16:26.280 --> 00:16:28.846
you actually degrade
the performance of your network.

309
00:16:28.846 --> 00:16:30.690
>> And, Wes,
can I bring it back to a certain point?

310
00:16:30.690 --> 00:16:32.440
A little bit earlier you
mentioned about being within

311
00:16:32.440 --> 00:16:34.030
earshot of a broadcast domain.

312
00:16:34.030 --> 00:16:35.690
Now, what exactly did you mean by that?

313
00:16:35.690 --> 00:16:40.080
>> Yeah, well, when I said being within
the earshot of a broadcast communication,

314
00:16:40.080 --> 00:16:43.380
that is what is known as
a broadcast domain, right?

315
00:16:43.380 --> 00:16:47.240
If I said that if you can hear
that broadcast communication.

316
00:16:47.240 --> 00:16:48.306
Well, what do I mean by that?

317
00:16:48.306 --> 00:16:53.280
Well, every communication, if we look
at our hub, right, every communication

318
00:16:53.280 --> 00:16:57.390
is essentially a broadcast communication,
just the way it's electrically hardwired.

319
00:16:57.390 --> 00:17:00.159
It has no logic,
it doesn't look at addresses at all.

320
00:17:01.280 --> 00:17:05.040
But at layer two, we have switches, right?

321
00:17:05.040 --> 00:17:08.820
And switches inspect Mac addresses.

322
00:17:08.820 --> 00:17:12.230
Well, believe it or not,
there is a MAC address for

323
00:17:12.230 --> 00:17:14.440
a broadcast communication, right?

324
00:17:14.440 --> 00:17:19.150
In our IP addressing we talked about
having a broadcast address for

325
00:17:19.150 --> 00:17:19.970
the network, right?

326
00:17:19.970 --> 00:17:25.460
And that's the IP address that a computer
sends a broadcast communication when that

327
00:17:25.460 --> 00:17:30.320
computer over IP wants every node within
that subnet to hear what's going on.

328
00:17:30.320 --> 00:17:32.990
Well, that's also layer two
that that happens as well.

329
00:17:32.990 --> 00:17:39.508
Understand that layer two, in fact,
I can kind of show you this.

330
00:17:39.508 --> 00:17:42.390
There's actually a broadcast MAC address.

331
00:17:42.390 --> 00:17:45.810
And if we use another command that we've
used in our network troubleshooting tools,

332
00:17:45.810 --> 00:17:51.140
arp, we do an arp -a,
we can actually see that right here,

333
00:17:51.140 --> 00:17:54.336
that they're, and
you know what, I do not see it.

334
00:17:54.336 --> 00:17:55.740
Yes, I do, I see it right here.

335
00:17:55.740 --> 00:17:56.830
Sorry about that.

336
00:17:56.830 --> 00:18:00.415
Here is the IP address, that's
the layer three rebroadcast address.

337
00:18:00.415 --> 00:18:04.385
But remember, we're talking about the OSI
model, we still have the data link layer.

338
00:18:04.385 --> 00:18:08.705
All fs is a broadcast communication
there at the data link layer, and

339
00:18:08.705 --> 00:18:10.665
that's what switches respond to.

340
00:18:10.665 --> 00:18:14.890
So when this switch receives
a broadcast communication, so

341
00:18:14.890 --> 00:18:20.390
let's follow this train of thought
here down the wire quite literally.

342
00:18:20.390 --> 00:18:26.290
So PC1 sends a communication in
the hub that is addressed to all fs,

343
00:18:26.290 --> 00:18:28.180
t hat broadcast address.

344
00:18:28.180 --> 00:18:29.290
Remember the hub?

345
00:18:29.290 --> 00:18:32.300
It's dumb, it doesn't look at
that address, it doesn't pair,

346
00:18:32.300 --> 00:18:34.410
it doesn't know any logic at all.

347
00:18:34.410 --> 00:18:36.204
It receives the information and

348
00:18:36.204 --> 00:18:41.105
it broadcasts it to everybody that is
connected to it, including the switch.

349
00:18:41.105 --> 00:18:44.995
Notice how the switch is
also connected to the Hub.

350
00:18:44.995 --> 00:18:48.695
Now, the switch is gonna, this is were
we start to get into the logic, right?

351
00:18:48.695 --> 00:18:50.995
That's what differentiates
a Hub from a switch.

352
00:18:50.995 --> 00:18:55.625
A switch is looking at the MAC address and
it's saying, I see the destination,

353
00:18:55.625 --> 00:19:01.410
the destination is all fs, so you want
this to be a broadcast communication.

354
00:19:01.410 --> 00:19:03.100
So what does the switch do?

355
00:19:03.100 --> 00:19:09.230
The switch broadcasts that
communication out all of it's ports.

356
00:19:09.230 --> 00:19:15.920
And when it does that, every device that
is connected to that switch will receive,

357
00:19:15.920 --> 00:19:20.807
and is within the earshot of
that broadcast communication.

358
00:19:20.807 --> 00:19:22.110
That make sense now?

359
00:19:22.110 --> 00:19:23.726
>> Yes.
>> So that means if this, and

360
00:19:23.726 --> 00:19:27.696
again, let's kinda follow this down
the wire so we know what's going on.

361
00:19:27.696 --> 00:19:32.585
PC1 sends a broadcast all fs
as the destination MAC address

362
00:19:32.585 --> 00:19:34.652
in that Ethernet frame.

363
00:19:34.652 --> 00:19:38.462
It goes into the hub, hub's blind to it,
hub doesn't look at addresses,

364
00:19:38.462 --> 00:19:40.290
it just looks at raw bits.

365
00:19:40.290 --> 00:19:43.771
It's like a repeater,
it just broadcasts it out all other ports,

366
00:19:43.771 --> 00:19:47.950
including sending it up to the switch,
cuz the switch was connected to the hub.

367
00:19:47.950 --> 00:19:52.742
But then the switch says,
that is a broadcast communication,

368
00:19:52.742 --> 00:19:57.448
and it floods that out all of it's
ports including up to this Hub and

369
00:19:57.448 --> 00:20:01.501
then back out to these three
computers here, all right?

370
00:20:01.501 --> 00:20:06.613
Now, one of the reasons we don't use Hubs
anymore on our networks, or you shouldn't

371
00:20:06.613 --> 00:20:11.092
be using Hubs, is because you will
increase the competition, all right?

372
00:20:11.092 --> 00:20:15.123
If a Hub is just like a logical
bus topology which if one computer

373
00:20:15.123 --> 00:20:20.599
communicates everybody hears it within
the network, well, then the more computers

374
00:20:20.599 --> 00:20:26.310
I hook to that Hub, the more competition
we have, the more Hubs and more computers.

375
00:20:26.310 --> 00:20:29.320
You're just creating one
big broadcast storm.

376
00:20:29.320 --> 00:20:31.990
The one great thing about switches today

377
00:20:31.990 --> 00:20:35.160
is that switches isolate
contention domains, right?

378
00:20:35.160 --> 00:20:38.590
Because essentially what we've
done is we've removed the Hub,

379
00:20:38.590 --> 00:20:42.980
we have plugged each device, if you will,
into it's own port on the switch.

380
00:20:42.980 --> 00:20:46.970
And if you check out the network
devices that we've talked about,

381
00:20:46.970 --> 00:20:51.440
the Hub can forward between each ports
based on its destination MAC address.

382
00:20:51.440 --> 00:20:52.630
So essentially,

383
00:20:52.630 --> 00:20:57.570
what's happening is each computer is
now on it's own collision domain, but

384
00:20:57.570 --> 00:21:03.140
I want you to know that this would still
be a single broadcast domain, right?

385
00:21:03.140 --> 00:21:08.160
According to the switch, if it sees
an all f destination MAC address,

386
00:21:08.160 --> 00:21:11.190
it's going to send it to every computer
that's connected to the switch,

387
00:21:11.190 --> 00:21:16.460
which is the larger portion, if you will,
that's the Broadcast Domain, all right?

388
00:21:16.460 --> 00:21:20.540
So know a little bit of the difference
between the Broadcast Domain and

389
00:21:20.540 --> 00:21:21.490
the Collision Domain.

390
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:24.660
When you have a shared media
where there's competition for

391
00:21:24.660 --> 00:21:27.850
that shared media,
you have a Collision Domain.

392
00:21:27.850 --> 00:21:30.700
Because we don't use
bus-based topologies anymore,

393
00:21:30.700 --> 00:21:35.470
we don't see too many of these like
a lot of competition going on.

394
00:21:35.470 --> 00:21:39.800
But you still have broadcast
communications using Broadcast Domains.

395
00:21:39.800 --> 00:21:42.280
You put a Hub into your network, and

396
00:21:42.280 --> 00:21:46.410
now you've essentially created
a Collision Domain, if you will.

397
00:21:46.410 --> 00:21:52.340
So definitely understand that because
how it affects your communications,

398
00:21:52.340 --> 00:21:55.600
how it affects the performance
of your network, really matters.

399
00:21:55.600 --> 00:21:58.455
The more Hubs,
the worse you network's gonna be.

400
00:21:58.455 --> 00:22:01.260
Cuz again,
what you are doing is you're increasing

401
00:22:01.260 --> 00:22:04.120
how much extra communications
are going on your network.

402
00:22:04.120 --> 00:22:08.040
And what I mean by that,
if we go back to our diagram here,

403
00:22:08.040 --> 00:22:13.390
what if PC 1 only really needs to talk to,
let's say PC 1, 2 and 3, right?

404
00:22:13.390 --> 00:22:16.380
PC 1 only needs to talk to PC 3.

405
00:22:16.380 --> 00:22:20.740
And in the MAC address is
the destination MAC address for PC 3.

406
00:22:20.740 --> 00:22:24.000
Well, it doesn't matter the Hub,
it doesn't understand that.

407
00:22:24.000 --> 00:22:27.380
It just receives the signal and
it broadcasts it out all over the port.

408
00:22:27.380 --> 00:22:30.605
So that means PC 2 is gonna
receive the signal as well.

409
00:22:30.605 --> 00:22:32.080
It's not gonna process it.

410
00:22:32.080 --> 00:22:36.111
So again you can see there's wasted time,
wasted communications on your networks.

411
00:22:36.111 --> 00:22:39.080
So that's why we gotta worry
about broadcast communications.

412
00:22:39.080 --> 00:22:43.420
And that's why I said earlier on when we
first started this episode, that you have

413
00:22:43.420 --> 00:22:48.430
to be careful, you have to know what type
of communications are going on because in

414
00:22:48.430 --> 00:22:54.290
certain scenarios you will
communicate differently, right?

415
00:22:54.290 --> 00:22:57.550
If I'm sending a one-to-one
communication between source and

416
00:22:57.550 --> 00:23:00.960
destination, I'm sending
a unicast message.

417
00:23:00.960 --> 00:23:06.260
There are times where we need to use IGMP,
Internet group management protocol.

418
00:23:06.260 --> 00:23:10.990
And what we end up doing is
essentially the node is saying, hey,

419
00:23:10.990 --> 00:23:14.090
I've got multicast group, sends the
communication to the multicast address,

420
00:23:14.090 --> 00:23:18.170
makes the connectivity device aware
that there's a multicast group.

421
00:23:18.170 --> 00:23:21.810
And then that connectivity device turns
around and advertises the fact that hey,

422
00:23:21.810 --> 00:23:23.950
there's a multicast group out here,
and if you want to join it,

423
00:23:23.950 --> 00:23:27.410
just talk to me and
I can get you that information, right?

424
00:23:27.410 --> 00:23:31.070
And then, obviously the broadcast
is one to everybody, and

425
00:23:31.070 --> 00:23:34.430
we really don't want,
there's times when we have to, right?

426
00:23:34.430 --> 00:23:36.020
It's not something that we can get around,
right?

427
00:23:36.020 --> 00:23:40.590
You're not gonna eliminate broadcast
communications until you go to IPv6 and

428
00:23:40.590 --> 00:23:41.730
we're all IPv6.

429
00:23:41.730 --> 00:23:44.245
See, IPv6 does away with broadcast.

430
00:23:44.245 --> 00:23:47.320
There's multicast, unicast and any cast.

431
00:23:47.320 --> 00:23:48.689
That's all, all right?

432
00:23:48.689 --> 00:23:50.888
Because we still have an IPv4,

433
00:23:50.888 --> 00:23:55.420
we have technologies that rely
on a multicast communication.

434
00:23:55.420 --> 00:23:56.780
Like let me tell you specifically.

435
00:23:56.780 --> 00:24:00.950
We've talked in other episodes about ARP,
the Address Resolution Protocol, right.

436
00:24:00.950 --> 00:24:04.610
And here's our ARP table here
on my Windows 10 machine.

437
00:24:04.610 --> 00:24:06.260
Remember what's going on with arp.

438
00:24:06.260 --> 00:24:09.750
Remember that it doesn't
understand the IP address.

439
00:24:09.750 --> 00:24:14.580
So if I run ipconfig, right, and this is
my IP address for this windows 10 machine.

440
00:24:14.580 --> 00:24:20.520
If that the routers are passing
information across themselves and

441
00:24:20.520 --> 00:24:26.280
it gets to the destination network
where my computer 10.10.10.10 resides,

442
00:24:26.280 --> 00:24:29.580
IP is dumb it does not
understand a MAC address.

443
00:24:29.580 --> 00:24:30.660
So what does it do?

444
00:24:30.660 --> 00:24:33.260
It hands it over to the address
resolution protocol,

445
00:24:33.260 --> 00:24:36.212
the IP address, and says, man,
I need your help, help me out here.

446
00:24:36.212 --> 00:24:40.410
And then ARP, Address Resolution Protocol,
turns around and sends a broadcast,

447
00:24:40.410 --> 00:24:44.016
stands up in the table in
the food court and says.

448
00:24:44.016 --> 00:24:47.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> Who has 10.10.10.10?

449
00:24:47.000 --> 00:24:48.870
And then my computer is listening.

450
00:24:48.870 --> 00:24:50.720
Now, all the other computers heard it,
too,

451
00:24:50.720 --> 00:24:52.290
because it was a broadcast communication.

452
00:24:52.290 --> 00:24:55.200
But they don't respond because
that's not their IP address.

453
00:24:55.200 --> 00:24:58.790
And my computer sends an ARP
response message back and says,

454
00:24:58.790 --> 00:25:02.770
hey, tell old lazy IP out there
that you can find 10.10.10.10.

455
00:25:02.770 --> 00:25:07.391
And then what it does is it
turns around and it gives,

456
00:25:07.391 --> 00:25:13.073
well, my MAC address,
if I rerun that ipconfig all.

457
00:25:13.073 --> 00:25:16.694
I can spell,
I cannot spell all today, Zach?

458
00:25:16.694 --> 00:25:17.917
>> There's an a in it.

459
00:25:17.917 --> 00:25:18.820
>> There we go.

460
00:25:18.820 --> 00:25:23.800
Then, it turns around and
says, hey, you can find this

461
00:25:23.800 --> 00:25:27.830
IP address at this MAC address.

462
00:25:27.830 --> 00:25:29.690
I'll get it right here eventually.

463
00:25:29.690 --> 00:25:30.760
At this MAC address.

464
00:25:30.760 --> 00:25:31.710
We'll get this right again.

465
00:25:31.710 --> 00:25:35.170
Hopefully you guys took your Dramamine
out there, got your sea sickness going.

466
00:25:35.170 --> 00:25:36.080
Now that's was ARP does.

467
00:25:36.080 --> 00:25:41.170
It says, hey, tell the router
in this case, that 10.10.10.10

468
00:25:41.170 --> 00:25:46.300
is at this MAC address, and then IP can
finish the delivery to the local network.

469
00:25:46.300 --> 00:25:49.620
So again, there are reasons you
have to know the characteristics,

470
00:25:49.620 --> 00:25:50.510
the properties, right?

471
00:25:50.510 --> 00:25:53.100
Characteristics, properties, I keep saying
them because they're interchangeable.

472
00:25:53.100 --> 00:25:56.510
It's not technical jargon that's
gonna get you on the exam.

473
00:25:56.510 --> 00:25:57.200
Know those.

474
00:25:57.200 --> 00:25:59.900
But I will tell you that we've
got a little bit more to go and

475
00:25:59.900 --> 00:26:02.132
doesn't look like we have
enough time in this episode.

476
00:26:02.132 --> 00:26:03.638
>> Keep doing a wonderful job, Wes.

477
00:26:03.638 --> 00:26:05.470
Network Traffic Properties, part one.

478
00:26:05.470 --> 00:26:06.320
There will be a part two.

479
00:26:06.320 --> 00:26:07.730
Make sure you see both parts.

480
00:26:07.730 --> 00:26:10.940
And see everything inside of COMPTIA Net
Plus that Wes has put together for you.

481
00:26:10.940 --> 00:26:12.310
And when you're in that course library,

482
00:26:12.310 --> 00:26:15.740
hundreds of other videos all
designed to help you go further.

483
00:26:15.740 --> 00:26:17.440
Thank you for watching, and you know what?

484
00:26:17.440 --> 00:26:19.070
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

485
00:26:19.070 --> 00:26:19.800
I am Zach Memos.

486
00:26:19.800 --> 00:26:20.590
>> And I am Wes Bryan.

487
00:26:20.590 --> 00:26:22.900
>> And we will see you soon.

488
00:26:22.900 --> 00:26:28.729
[MUSIC]

489
00:26:28.729 --> 00:26:32.083
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the various characteristics and attributes of network communications. They look at concepts like CSMA/CD and CSMA/CA as well as MTUs and PDUs.

1

2

3
00:00:05.904 --> 00:00:08.535

7

I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA Net+,

8
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:23.960
and this is network traffic
properties part two.

9
00:00:23.960 --> 00:00:26.889
And part one was great, but part two is
gonna be even better, I'm telling you.

10
00:00:26.889 --> 00:00:29.089
And Wes Bryan is here to give us
all the information we need, Wes,

11
00:00:29.089 --> 00:00:30.062
good to see you again today.

12
00:00:30.062 --> 00:00:32.660
>> Hey Zach, thanks for having me back,
having a lot of fun, that's right.

13
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:36.595
And there are some more characteristics,
or just like Zach said, more properties

14
00:00:36.595 --> 00:00:39.814
that we need to be aware of when it
comes to network communications.

15
00:00:39.814 --> 00:00:42.731
Now, if you didn't check out part one,
definitely go check that out,

16
00:00:42.731 --> 00:00:44.531
because it's really
gonna set the stage for

17
00:00:44.531 --> 00:00:47.276
some of the concepts that we're
gonna talk about in this episode.

18
00:00:47.276 --> 00:00:53.251
We talked about the communication types,
unicast, broadcast, as well as multicast.

19
00:00:53.251 --> 00:00:56.250
And then we talked a little bit about the
difference between a broadcast domain and

20
00:00:56.250 --> 00:00:57.688
a collision domain, right?

21
00:00:57.688 --> 00:01:00.630
And that's gonna set us up for
some additional properties or

22
00:01:00.630 --> 00:01:03.095
characteristics that we
need to be aware of.

23
00:01:03.095 --> 00:01:07.055
And the very first one that I'd like
to talk about is a whole bunch of

24
00:01:07.055 --> 00:01:09.337
alphabet soup right off the bat here.

25
00:01:09.337 --> 00:01:13.932
So let's see if we can help you out
with this one, this is CSMA CD.

26
00:01:13.932 --> 00:01:16.609
All right, so
what the heck does that mean?

27
00:01:16.609 --> 00:01:18.324
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can see Zach over there.

>> Let me officially ask it,

>> [LAUGH] I can see Zach going,

That is carrier sense multiple

00:01:27.630 --> 00:01:30.963
And what we mean now, and

Break down these acronyms and kind of

So we can kind of get a good

Carrier sense, all right,

the carrier's essentially the network,

37
00:01:47.870 --> 00:01:52.470
Carrier sense, if you will,
it's sensing, is the network available?

38
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:53.692
Multiple access, and

39
00:01:53.692 --> 00:01:57.430
I might have said media access

00:01:57.430 --> 00:01:59.800
It's carrier sense multiple if I did,

41
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:01.860
multiple access is what

42
00:02:01.860 --> 00:02:05.430
So think of it, carrier sense,

43
00:02:05.430 --> 00:02:09.350
multiple access,
more than one node accessing the network.

44
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:13.100
And then the last part,

45
00:02:13.100 --> 00:02:16.140
Remember, one of the things that I told

00:02:16.140 --> 00:02:20.472

Ethernet-based network, cuz it's

00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:30.460
Again, we have multiple computers striving

if you will, competing to send their

The coalition detection part is

One of the things that I also

just because the devices themselves could

That's what brought the price point for

Ethernet communications compared

which is also one of the reasons

57
00:02:59.577 --> 00:03:03.949
Now, how do they do that, when we say
carrier sense multiple access collision

00:03:03.949 --> 00:03:06.380
detection, how does that process work?

59
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:09.060
Well, let's go ahead and
let's take you through a few steps here

00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:12.080

00:03:12.080 --> 00:03:16.410
So we've got a couple of computers here,

62
00:03:16.410 --> 00:03:18.770
I am listening, and do we see data,

No data is being been transmitted, right?

00:03:25.706 --> 00:03:29.335
First, you gotta sense, is the media

That's when we get things like our

00:03:35.160 --> 00:03:38.020
If you have no activity,

69
00:03:38.020 --> 00:03:41.477
But the link light's there,

70
00:03:41.477 --> 00:03:44.730
Well, I'm listening out,

00:03:44.730 --> 00:03:46.430
Well, I don't hear anything,

There could be another computer

00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:50.740
I don't know why I got

00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:55.167

75
00:03:55.167 --> 00:04:00.920
[LAUGH] I'm listening, and I don't hear

00:04:00.920 --> 00:04:04.950
So guess what, we're gonna go ahead,

78
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:08.978
Guess what happens to the second computer?

79
00:04:08.978 --> 00:04:13.350
The second computer says,
I'm gonna transmit my information.

80
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:14.730
Well, now we've got a problem, remember,

81
00:04:14.730 --> 00:04:18.620
when we've got two computers that are
sending information across the same shared

82
00:04:18.620 --> 00:04:23.860
medium at the same time,
this is where we get a collision.

83
00:04:23.860 --> 00:04:27.066
Now here is something that's kinda,
I wanna say magical,

84
00:04:27.066 --> 00:04:28.934
nothing in computing is magical.

85
00:04:28.934 --> 00:04:32.410
Nothing in computing happens unless they
program it that way, nothing is magical.

86
00:04:32.410 --> 00:04:37.011
Right, I don't care what,
Steve Jobs says, right,

87
00:04:37.011 --> 00:04:41.025
this is actually kind of the cool part,
right?

88
00:04:41.025 --> 00:04:43.739
And this is the fact that when
the collision is detected, you say,

89
00:04:43.739 --> 00:04:46.630
well, wait a second, Wes,
how's the collision detected?

90
00:04:46.630 --> 00:04:53.040
Well, remember, we send the electrical
communication down the same shared medium.

91
00:04:53.040 --> 00:04:57.710
It's going to collide, and
it's going to bounce back to the sources

92
00:04:57.710 --> 00:05:02.430
of the communication in
the form of a fragmented frame.

93
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:05.555
And they're gonna see that,
they're gonna detect that,

94
00:05:05.555 --> 00:05:07.815
hence why we call it collision detection.

95
00:05:07.815 --> 00:05:09.043
They're gonna detect that,

96
00:05:09.043 --> 00:05:12.695
and what they're gonna do is, they're
gonna wait a random back off period.

97
00:05:12.695 --> 00:05:15.637
Now, I know it's programmed
in there somehow,

98
00:05:15.637 --> 00:05:18.669
I don't exactly know what
the back off period is.

99
00:05:18.669 --> 00:05:23.035
And understand, we're not in an electrical
or a network engineering class here.

100
00:05:23.035 --> 00:05:26.120
We're taking a Net+ exam,
they're not gonna want you to know that.

101
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:28.830
But just understand,
they wait a back off period, right?

102
00:05:28.830 --> 00:05:36.270
And once that back off period is reached,
they re-transmit the information.

103
00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:40.335
Now, what happens is,
if they wait a back off period, right,

104
00:05:40.335 --> 00:05:44.497
they randomize it to try to make sure,
and it's pseudorandom.

105
00:05:44.497 --> 00:05:49.160
They pseudorandomize it so
that we don't send it at the same time.

106
00:05:49.160 --> 00:05:52.937
All right, well if it happens,
which it can, if it happens again,

107
00:05:52.937 --> 00:05:55.339
they're gonna adjust that back off time.

108
00:05:55.339 --> 00:05:59.339
And they keep adjusting that back off
time, and the thought process is,

109
00:05:59.339 --> 00:06:03.536
if you have two trains going down the same
tracks, it's kinda like when they

110
00:06:03.536 --> 00:06:07.690
switch the gates open, right, and
they kind of veer off to the side there.

111
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:12.290
We're hoping that the tracks have
switched, and we've got a side rail here.

112
00:06:12.290 --> 00:06:16.080
Basically, what's going on is, they're
trying to eliminate those collisions.

113
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:21.560
Now, that's collision detection,
we see that this media access method,

114
00:06:21.560 --> 00:06:24.470
and it's inside of your
Ethernet-based networks.

115
00:06:24.470 --> 00:06:25.297
Now today,

116
00:06:25.297 --> 00:06:30.773
I do want you to understand that every
computer is plugged into a switch today.

117
00:06:30.773 --> 00:06:34.608
We've pretty much eliminated the hubs,
however,

118
00:06:34.608 --> 00:06:38.190
I want you to know that
we still have collisions.

119
00:06:38.190 --> 00:06:39.530
And how can we have collisions,

120
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:42.070
cuz there are broadcast
communications that can happen.

121
00:06:42.070 --> 00:06:44.580
The more broadcast
communications you have,

122
00:06:44.580 --> 00:06:48.270
the more potential there is for
a collision to happen.

123
00:06:48.270 --> 00:06:52.600
It just happens, so don't think
that you eliminated it altogether.

124
00:06:52.600 --> 00:06:55.410
But it is greatly reduced
because of the fact that,

125
00:06:55.410 --> 00:06:58.880
again, each computer now is
on its own collision domain.

126
00:06:58.880 --> 00:07:02.420
But it doesn't mean that they're on their
own, they're still within a broadcast

127
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:05.670
domain, like we talked about in
the first episode, so do know that.

128
00:07:05.670 --> 00:07:09.440
Know that this is associated with 802.3,
remember,

129
00:07:09.440 --> 00:07:15.660
802.3 is the IEEE's formal standardization
for the Ethernet technology.

130
00:07:15.660 --> 00:07:20.176
And then all of its amendments and
derivatives thereafter, all right?

131
00:07:20.176 --> 00:07:22.580
So that's how we do it on a wired network,

132
00:07:22.580 --> 00:07:27.280
the next one we gotta talk about is
in a wireless communication, right?

133
00:07:27.280 --> 00:07:30.820
Wireless communications,
remember, are unbounded media,

134
00:07:30.820 --> 00:07:33.810
we do not have the bounds of
a physical cable, all right?

135
00:07:33.810 --> 00:07:36.683
So we have some good things and
we have some bad things, right.

136
00:07:36.683 --> 00:07:39.835
One of the good things is when you have
the limitations of your physical cable,

137
00:07:39.835 --> 00:07:41.960
and you can go to wireless,
you can get around that.

138
00:07:43.120 --> 00:07:47.110
One of the bad things is that
when a collision happens,

139
00:07:47.110 --> 00:07:52.512
it doesn't bounce back to the source,
it's not a shared cable, right?

140
00:07:52.512 --> 00:07:56.736
So we can't really detect whether
a collision has happened.

141
00:07:56.736 --> 00:08:03.528
So CSMA CD, or collision detection
Doesn't work in a wireless network.

142
00:08:03.528 --> 00:08:07.920
So what they did is they came
up with another type of CSMA.

143
00:08:07.920 --> 00:08:09.770
Still the same thing on the first part,
guys and

144
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:13.600
gals out there, don't let that fool you,
carrier sense multiple access.

145
00:08:13.600 --> 00:08:17.890
But now it's CA,
it's collision avoidance, all right?

146
00:08:17.890 --> 00:08:19.700
Now, be very clear on this one.

147
00:08:19.700 --> 00:08:22.260
The goal is collision avoidance, right?

148
00:08:22.260 --> 00:08:25.840
That's how we, Zack and I, drive to work
in the morning trying to get here to our

149
00:08:25.840 --> 00:08:30.280
job where our goal is to
try to avoid a collision.

150
00:08:30.280 --> 00:08:31.830
But on the way into work,

151
00:08:31.830 --> 00:08:34.050
you see people that have
unfortunately have collided, right?

152
00:08:34.050 --> 00:08:37.670
So the goal is to avoid collisions, right?

153
00:08:37.670 --> 00:08:40.631
So let's talk a little bit about CSMACA,

154
00:08:40.631 --> 00:08:43.941
CSMACA you make sure I
get that acronym right.

155
00:08:43.941 --> 00:08:46.840
Carrier Sense Multiple
Access Collision Avoidance.

156
00:08:46.840 --> 00:08:49.480
Let's go ahead and
take a look at our diagram here.

157
00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:51.560
Now, it's a little bit different here,
all right.

158
00:08:51.560 --> 00:08:55.020
So we still have a carrier sense,
and I could say that,

159
00:08:55.020 --> 00:08:56.840
hey, is the media present, right?

160
00:08:56.840 --> 00:08:59.085
You see, you still have that
carrier sense that has to go on.

161
00:08:59.085 --> 00:09:00.045
Is the network there?

162
00:09:00.045 --> 00:09:00.930
Is the media present?

163
00:09:00.930 --> 00:09:04.700
In this case, the media is
unbounded radiated energy, but

164
00:09:04.700 --> 00:09:06.770
the network is there, right?

165
00:09:06.770 --> 00:09:12.110
And when a device senses that media and
senses that it's there, it signals

166
00:09:12.110 --> 00:09:16.790
its intent to the rest of the network and
says I've got information to send.

167
00:09:16.790 --> 00:09:20.000
That's in the form of what's
known as a jam signal, all right?

168
00:09:20.000 --> 00:09:23.330
And the other computer that's within
ear shot says, yeah, I heard that.

169
00:09:23.330 --> 00:09:25.940
You've got data to send me,
like Zach saying,

170
00:09:25.940 --> 00:09:28.480
raising his hand in class if
we were in class together.

171
00:09:28.480 --> 00:09:32.000
Yeah, Zach, okya, you've got something to
say, everybody else hold off for a second,

172
00:09:32.000 --> 00:09:34.940
including the teacher or whoever is in
the front of the class at that time,

173
00:09:34.940 --> 00:09:35.940
just hold on.

174
00:09:35.940 --> 00:09:37.120
Zach has the floor, right?

175
00:09:37.120 --> 00:09:39.800
That's kind of how the jam signal works,
right?

176
00:09:39.800 --> 00:09:44.170
And then the data is going to
be transmitted, all right?

177
00:09:45.370 --> 00:09:49.040
Now, here is the thing that can happen,
all right?

178
00:09:49.040 --> 00:09:56.306
Here's one of the reasons I say the goal
is collision avoidance, all right?

179
00:09:56.306 --> 00:09:59.650
I tell you what,
we're gonna use this analogy.

180
00:09:59.650 --> 00:10:04.170
Zach, you and I, we go out to Ben Griffon
Stadium here in Gainesville, right, and

181
00:10:04.170 --> 00:10:07.480
we're standing literally on
the football field, right?

182
00:10:07.480 --> 00:10:10.800
I'm on one side of the 100 yards,
you're on the other side of the 100 yards,

183
00:10:10.800 --> 00:10:14.200
we're both in the end zones or whatever
on the opposite sides of the field.

184
00:10:14.200 --> 00:10:17.110
I want you to image that we have somebody
right in the middle of the field.

185
00:10:18.350 --> 00:10:23.240
We represent these devices here,
Client 1 and Client 2, all right?

186
00:10:23.240 --> 00:10:28.700
The person that's in the middle of the
field represent's the access point, okay?

187
00:10:28.700 --> 00:10:34.300
Now, there is a good chance that if I
was one side of the field and Zach was

188
00:10:34.300 --> 00:10:39.360
on the other side field, and I said hey
Zach I've got information I gotta send.

189
00:10:39.360 --> 00:10:45.170
That Zach wouldn't be in ear shot and
couldn't hear me say I have data to send.

190
00:10:45.170 --> 00:10:50.270
Just like on the other side of the field I
didn't hear Zach say I have data to send.

191
00:10:50.270 --> 00:10:51.950
Nobody seen us raise our hands, right?

192
00:10:51.950 --> 00:10:55.050
We're too far away from
each other to hear that.

193
00:10:55.050 --> 00:11:00.210
So we both send information at the same
time, and a collision happens.

194
00:11:00.210 --> 00:11:01.620
But here's the problem.

195
00:11:01.620 --> 00:11:02.810
There's no way to detect it.

196
00:11:02.810 --> 00:11:06.370
It doesn't bounce back,
it just, whatever it does,

197
00:11:06.370 --> 00:11:08.600
goes off into electrical limbo, right?

198
00:11:08.600 --> 00:11:09.440
It's gone.

199
00:11:09.440 --> 00:11:10.780
So we're having collisions.

200
00:11:10.780 --> 00:11:13.690
Again, the goal is to avoid collisions,
but

201
00:11:13.690 --> 00:11:15.760
it doesn't mean that it wouldn't happen.

202
00:11:15.760 --> 00:11:17.840
So they knew that,
they knew that there was a potential.

203
00:11:17.840 --> 00:11:21.050
What this does is create what's
known as the hidden node phenomenon,

204
00:11:21.050 --> 00:11:25.320
and that's where there's a node out
there saying I've got information.

205
00:11:25.320 --> 00:11:27.460
Sending a jam signal, nobody can hear him.

206
00:11:27.460 --> 00:11:29.320
Or her whatever, all right?

207
00:11:29.320 --> 00:11:31.670
Nobody can hear that device, all right?

208
00:11:31.670 --> 00:11:35.540
So what they did is they came up,
say again no detection of a collision,

209
00:11:35.540 --> 00:11:37.410
we think everything's good, right?

210
00:11:37.410 --> 00:11:38.250
We can't detect it.

211
00:11:38.250 --> 00:11:39.840
We think everything's good.

212
00:11:39.840 --> 00:11:44.440
And so they came up with a kind of

213
00:11:44.440 --> 00:11:47.100
a way to try to get away around
this hidden node syndrome.

214
00:11:47.100 --> 00:11:52.200
And that's something know as
a RTS CTS signal, all right?

215
00:11:52.200 --> 00:11:55.150
Now, again, I know another acronym, and
I'm not sure if they're going to ask you

216
00:11:55.150 --> 00:11:58.040
this on the exam, but if they do,
you'll be prepared for it, right?

217
00:11:58.040 --> 00:12:01.480
So what does a RTS CTS signal stand for?

218
00:12:01.480 --> 00:12:04.330
Well, RTS is request to send.

219
00:12:04.330 --> 00:12:08.590
Let's go back to the analogy of being
on the 100 yard on a football field,

220
00:12:08.590 --> 00:12:09.850
all right?

221
00:12:09.850 --> 00:12:13.505
Now, imagine Zach can't hear
me communicating saying

222
00:12:13.505 --> 00:12:16.845
hey Zach I've got data to send, or
hey network I've got data to send.

223
00:12:16.845 --> 00:12:17.535
And I can't, for

224
00:12:17.535 --> 00:12:22.315
whatever reason, I can't hear Zach saying
hey network I've got data to send.

225
00:12:22.315 --> 00:12:25.355
But wouldn't it be nice if we could talk
to the person that's sitting right in

226
00:12:25.355 --> 00:12:30.450
the middle of the field and
say hey anybody else sending information?

227
00:12:30.450 --> 00:12:31.970
I need to send some information.

228
00:12:31.970 --> 00:12:34.560
Because the person in the middle
of the field can hear Zach.

229
00:12:34.560 --> 00:12:36.426
And the person in the middle
of the field can hear me.

230
00:12:36.426 --> 00:12:38.590
We can't hear each other.

231
00:12:38.590 --> 00:12:43.040
But if I ask that person, hey can I talk?

232
00:12:43.040 --> 00:12:46.860
And that person says Zach
is talking right now.

233
00:12:46.860 --> 00:12:50.460
Okay, I'm not clear to send,
I got to hold off for a sec.

234
00:12:50.460 --> 00:12:53.090
And then I request to transmit again,
right?

235
00:12:53.090 --> 00:12:55.540
And then finally, the access point
of the person in the middle says,

236
00:12:55.540 --> 00:12:57.900
yeah, I can hear Zach and Zach is okay.

237
00:12:57.900 --> 00:13:00.150
The network is quiet, go ahead and send.

238
00:13:00.150 --> 00:13:05.773
And what it does is it says hey Zach,
Wes is sending information.

239
00:13:05.773 --> 00:13:08.810
You need to stop right now,
just hold off, all right?

240
00:13:08.810 --> 00:13:11.010
He's got his hand raised in the classroom.

241
00:13:11.010 --> 00:13:15.030
And it sends me back the CTS
signal that says clear to send,

242
00:13:15.030 --> 00:13:16.900
you're clear to transmit your information.

243
00:13:16.900 --> 00:13:19.930
So request to send, clear to send, or

244
00:13:19.930 --> 00:13:24.930
request to send, hold your horses somebody
else is sending, however it might work.

245
00:13:24.930 --> 00:13:29.940
And that kind of helps to eliminate or
to to combat that hidden node syndrome.

246
00:13:29.940 --> 00:13:34.020
That is Carrier Sense Multiple
Access Collision Avoidance.

247
00:13:34.020 --> 00:13:36.840

add its bit of information

So it receives, from an upper layer,

And what it's gonna do

Now when the network, and you can kinda

Now that the service data unit,
