472
00:26:52.780 --> 00:26:56.430
excuse me, being delivered back to you,
and it hits the connectivity device and

473
00:26:56.430 --> 00:26:57.700
it's like the airport.

474
00:26:59.190 --> 00:27:02.450
You got extra bags, you're not paying for
them, guess what we're gonna do,

475
00:27:02.450 --> 00:27:04.290
we're gonna throw it out.

476
00:27:04.290 --> 00:27:06.280
So you need to understand what the MTU is.

477
00:27:06.280 --> 00:27:08.340
Now I will tell you,
in fact, let's go ahead and

478
00:27:08.340 --> 00:27:10.470
dive back into our Windows machine here.

479
00:27:10.470 --> 00:27:14.690
And let me log back in, it looks like I
timed out, and you can actually see this,

480
00:27:14.690 --> 00:27:18.390
another command and I don't see this
command much in the objectives.

481
00:27:18.390 --> 00:27:20.960
But I will throw it out there
just in case they ask you about,

482
00:27:20.960 --> 00:27:24.700
it's called network shell,
we call it netsh, net shell.

483
00:27:24.700 --> 00:27:27.710
It's the way you can interact with
a network stack inside of Windows.

484
00:27:27.710 --> 00:27:32.906
So you can do netsh, you do interface, and

485
00:27:32.906 --> 00:27:39.570
ipv4 show interface and

486
00:27:39.570 --> 00:27:43.320
we can actually see that the operating
system is setting the MTU right?

487
00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:47.320
So the MTU is set by the operating system
and then it's peaked and tweaked according

488
00:27:47.320 --> 00:27:51.750
to whatever the administrator wants across
the switch or across that link itself.

489
00:27:51.750 --> 00:27:55.720
So there are other occasions
where you might exceed,

490
00:27:55.720 --> 00:27:59.250
as far as the connectivity device goes.

491
00:27:59.250 --> 00:28:02.160
In your networks you might
exceed the 1,500 byte MTU, and

492
00:28:02.160 --> 00:28:05.400
that's when we talk about VLANs,
cuz VLANs adds a tagging unit

493
00:28:05.400 --> 00:28:08.930
to it that could potentially grow
that just beyond 1,500 bytes.

494
00:28:08.930 --> 00:28:11.890
You'll learn more about that as you
go onto things like CISCO training.

495
00:28:11.890 --> 00:28:13.190
There's another way that
you can look at it.

496
00:28:13.190 --> 00:28:16.350
You can run that also and instead of doing
interface, if you wanted you could do

497
00:28:16.350 --> 00:28:20.760
subinterface and it just kinda rearranges
it a little bit different, but

498
00:28:20.760 --> 00:28:22.770
you can see that it's 1,500 bytes, right?

499
00:28:22.770 --> 00:28:25.090
I'll tell you what,
we'll do another one here.

500
00:28:25.090 --> 00:28:28.310
Let me go ahead and
bring up my terminal on the Mac OS here.

501
00:28:28.310 --> 00:28:31.350
And you all could see
that one likewise too.

502
00:28:31.350 --> 00:28:36.830
So, if we do an ifconfig, all right,

503
00:28:36.830 --> 00:28:42.230
and I'll just do a -a you can see that
if I scroll back up here we've got 1,500

504
00:28:42.230 --> 00:28:47.510
bytes right there, so
you can see there's the empty use 1500.

505
00:28:47.510 --> 00:28:52.520
Some of these different wireless networks,
and even this P to P here,

506
00:28:52.520 --> 00:28:56.360
you can see sets it a little bit
different, but for the main part,

507
00:28:56.360 --> 00:29:01.330
your ethernet based adapters,
they're gonna have your 1,500 bytes.

508
00:29:01.330 --> 00:29:05.050
So you can see that that's something that
is set inside of the operating system, but

509
00:29:05.050 --> 00:29:09.340
then ultimately across that lake it
will be something that is controlled

510
00:29:09.340 --> 00:29:10.990
by the network administrator themselves.

511
00:29:10.990 --> 00:29:13.670
So these are some of the properties of
our network traffic that you need to

512
00:29:13.670 --> 00:29:14.570
be aware of.

513
00:29:14.570 --> 00:29:16.560
And as you can see,
as we've gone through a couple of parts,

514
00:29:16.560 --> 00:29:20.910
it's not really just about what's on the
exam, it's really about knowing the DNA

515
00:29:20.910 --> 00:29:25.400
of the communications as they
traverse your networks, and

516
00:29:25.400 --> 00:29:26.760
where you might see some of these.

517
00:29:26.760 --> 00:29:29.870
And in the scenarios that you might
want to eliminate these like broadcast

518
00:29:29.870 --> 00:29:33.160
communications Reducing
collisions on your network,

519
00:29:33.160 --> 00:29:37.460
shortening collision domains by using
switches, getting the hubs off there.

520
00:29:37.460 --> 00:29:41.260
So not only for
the network plus exam but also for

521
00:29:41.260 --> 00:29:44.280
your own experience in
networking in the real world.

522
00:29:44.280 --> 00:29:45.370
>> Great job as usual, Wes.

523
00:29:45.370 --> 00:29:46.130
Thank you very much.

524
00:29:46.130 --> 00:29:50.250
Network Traffic Properties part two,
there was a part one, see them both and

525
00:29:50.250 --> 00:29:53.937
see everything inside the Comp Series
that Wes has put together for you.

526
00:29:53.937 --> 00:29:55.285
He's done such a fantastic job.

527
00:29:55.285 --> 00:29:58.420
[INAUDIBLE] all the information we
need for those exams and so forth.

528
00:29:58.420 --> 00:30:02.181
And by the way, when you're inside
the core there's hundreds of other videos.

529
00:30:02.181 --> 00:30:05.017
They're all designed to help you
go further, so check those out.

530
00:30:05.017 --> 00:30:08.310
And ITProTV, they'll be very glad you did.

531
00:30:08.310 --> 00:30:10.537
Thanks for watching, I'm Zack
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

532
00:30:10.537 --> 00:30:12.934
>> And we'll see you soon.

533
00:30:12.934 --> 00:30:18.838
[MUSIC]

534
00:30:18.838 --> 00:30:21.368
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the various characteristics and attributes of switching technologies. They look at concepts like unicast, multicast, broadcast domains and more.
episodes.title: Switching Technologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.300
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.300 --> 00:00:04.298
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.298 --> 00:00:09.366
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:09.366 --> 00:00:13.750
>> Hello and thank you for
watching IT Pro TV,

5
00:00:13.750 --> 00:00:16.760
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:20.350
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we
continue on with Comp G and Net Plus.

7
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:23.520
Switching Technologies is
the name of this episode and

8
00:00:23.520 --> 00:00:25.690
Wes Bryan is here to help us
out because he's a great guy.

9
00:00:25.690 --> 00:00:26.908
Wes, nice to see you sir.

10
00:00:26.908 --> 00:00:29.433
>> Hey,
you telling all those lies about me again.

11
00:00:29.433 --> 00:00:30.540
Thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:30.540 --> 00:00:32.480
It's always good to be here with ITProtV.

13
00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:38.270
That is right, we are moving through, if
you're following along with us out there,

14
00:00:38.270 --> 00:00:41.640
we're moving through the objective 1.3,
which is routing and switching, and

15
00:00:41.640 --> 00:00:44.170
in this episode we're gonna be
looking at some of the switching

16
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:47.342
technologies that you need to be
aware of when you sit that exam.

17
00:00:47.342 --> 00:00:49.587
Now we're going to talk about
some of the basics as well.

18
00:00:49.587 --> 00:00:54.048
We need to know things like, you know,
how do switches make decisions, and

19
00:00:54.048 --> 00:00:57.535
what is some of the information
that is stored within them,

20
00:00:57.535 --> 00:01:01.369
as well as defining some of the basic
concepts that can get a little

21
00:01:01.369 --> 00:01:04.812
bit confusing if you've never
seen some of these before.

22
00:01:04.812 --> 00:01:07.390
So if it's the first time
you're getting into Net plus,

23
00:01:07.390 --> 00:01:11.045
maybe first time you're getting into
networks, these will be some fundamental

24
00:01:11.045 --> 00:01:14.430
technologies that you're gonna need to
be aware of, and again not just for

25
00:01:14.430 --> 00:01:17.250
the exam but
as you launch into your networking career.

26
00:01:17.250 --> 00:01:20.258
>> And you know some of the episodes
we've actually worked on together,

27
00:01:20.258 --> 00:01:23.440
you mentioned packet switched and
circuits.

28
00:01:23.440 --> 00:01:24.330
So what's the difference?

29
00:01:24.330 --> 00:01:25.580
I guess that's what
we're leading into here.

30
00:01:25.580 --> 00:01:27.500
>> Absolutely, that's a great concept.

31
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:33.030
One of the most prevalent
ways that we move information

32
00:01:33.030 --> 00:01:36.925
across networks is through what is known
as a packing switching technology.

33
00:01:36.925 --> 00:01:40.125
In fact, our switches that we talk about,
they work with data packets.

34
00:01:40.125 --> 00:01:43.585
Now, it's kind of interesting that we
call it packet switching network, right?

35
00:01:43.585 --> 00:01:47.430
And when we talk about IP, that's
technically where are our packets, right.

36
00:01:47.430 --> 00:01:51.300
We talked about protocol data units,
and IP, the IP layer if you will,

37
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:55.110
the internet layer, the network layer
at least where we have packets, but

38
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:57.770
then when we talk about switches,
we always talk about the fact

39
00:01:57.770 --> 00:02:01.020
that well switches deal with frames,
they don't deal with packets so.

40
00:02:01.020 --> 00:02:02.400
What the heck is it that we mean?

41
00:02:02.400 --> 00:02:05.310
So in this context, what we mean when
we talk about packet switch networks,

42
00:02:05.310 --> 00:02:10.170
what we mean is that,
it's a unit of measurement if you will.

43
00:02:10.170 --> 00:02:12.760
A packet is a variable length size.

44
00:02:12.760 --> 00:02:15.090
It can change the links.

45
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:18.230
And one of the things that's great
about packet switching networks is that

46
00:02:18.230 --> 00:02:22.800
the way they have it set up is that
packets can take different routes across

47
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:26.390
networks to find their ways at
the endpoints and that's great.

48
00:02:26.390 --> 00:02:31.600
In some of the earlier implementation of
this, it's kinda like a military thing

49
00:02:31.600 --> 00:02:35.740
where they wanted, during war time and
stuff, portions of a network that could

50
00:02:35.740 --> 00:02:41.020
unfortunately be destroyed, right, and
they wanted a way these packets could be

51
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:44.830
basically routed around the failed network
and still make their way to the endpoints.

52
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:48.000
So with a packet switching network, a
couple of the characteristics that I want

53
00:02:48.000 --> 00:02:51.360
you to be aware of is that
the packets are variable length.

54
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:53.040
There isn't any predictability, right?

55
00:02:53.040 --> 00:02:56.420
We have different of technologies out
there like cell switching networks for

56
00:02:56.420 --> 00:02:59.580
the asynchronous transfer mode ATM, right?

57
00:02:59.580 --> 00:03:05.950
And that ATM, if you will, it uses these
cells that are 53 bytes in size, and

58
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:09.210
if your data isn't 53 bytes, well, guess
what, you have some padding on there,

59
00:03:09.210 --> 00:03:12.340
we're gonna make sure,
the technology is, not us.

60
00:03:12.340 --> 00:03:15.510
[LAUGH] But the technology's gonna make
sure that it's always 53 bytes that

61
00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:19.380
traverses the wire within those networks,
and that offers a predictability and

62
00:03:19.380 --> 00:03:25.540
we don't really have to calculate things
like the cyclic redundancy checks and

63
00:03:25.540 --> 00:03:30.060
stuff, so it's less prone to errors, but
it's also more of expensive technology.

64
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:32.180
And ethernet,
when we talk about ethernet, right,

65
00:03:32.180 --> 00:03:35.300
that's essentially packet
switching type communication.

66
00:03:35.300 --> 00:03:38.800
Now, the other thing to keep in mind to is
that packets will take different routes.

67
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:40.760
They don't take the same dedicated path.

68
00:03:40.760 --> 00:03:42.820
They don't have a dedicated
path if you will.

69
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:45.760
The connectivity devices will
check some information and

70
00:03:45.760 --> 00:03:49.300
they'll determine where that information
needs to go and send it along its way.

71
00:03:49.300 --> 00:03:53.730
And then even in the same data stream you
can have multiple packets that are taking

72
00:03:53.730 --> 00:03:56.920
different routes, and that's a little bit
different than circuit switching networks.

73
00:03:56.920 --> 00:03:58.730
Now you mentioned circuits, right?

74
00:03:58.730 --> 00:04:01.460
Well we also have circuit switching
networks and circuit switching networks

75
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:03.980
honestly are some of the oldest
network communications that we have.

76
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:05.530
It's really one of the reasons you and

77
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:09.890
I were talking about it at some
point off camera before the episode.

78
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:14.550
We talked about how why was computing
even really started, right?

79
00:04:14.550 --> 00:04:15.680
Why do we use binary?

80
00:04:15.680 --> 00:04:18.710
Well, if you go back into some of
the earliest days when they decided,

81
00:04:18.710 --> 00:04:22.480
hey, we need a way to
control these circuits,

82
00:04:22.480 --> 00:04:24.870
these logical gates if you will,
and binary was perfect.

83
00:04:24.870 --> 00:04:27.070
Because what you would have in
circuit switching networks,

84
00:04:27.070 --> 00:04:29.770
you probably remember some of the old
black and white commercials where you have

85
00:04:29.770 --> 00:04:31.090
the ladies in there and
they work the switchboard.

86
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:32.540
>> I was just gonna say like
operators at a switchboard-

87
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:33.080
>> That's right,

88
00:04:33.080 --> 00:04:35.340
they were our connectivity devices, right.

89
00:04:35.340 --> 00:04:37.340
If you look back,
going back a hundred years or

90
00:04:37.340 --> 00:04:39.930
so, those were our connectivity devices.

91
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:42.815
They would recieve a single on one and
say let me go ahead and connect you.

92
00:04:42.815 --> 00:04:47.200
Now, I want you to keep that in mind,
the reason I use that analogy os because,

93
00:04:47.200 --> 00:04:48.310
what were they doing?

94
00:04:48.310 --> 00:04:51.520
They were establishing a dedicated
communication path, and

95
00:04:51.520 --> 00:04:53.540
that's what's a little bit
different with circuit switching.

96
00:04:53.540 --> 00:04:57.840
See, with circuit switching networks like
your PSTN lines, publics, or what is it?

97
00:04:57.840 --> 00:04:59.900
The public telephone switch network.

98
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:03.450
Although sometimes they
call it POTS lines.

99
00:05:03.450 --> 00:05:05.490
You have a dedicated connection, right?

100
00:05:05.490 --> 00:05:09.160
When you make a communication
across the circuit switch network,

101
00:05:09.160 --> 00:05:14.090
what you have is you have a circuit
that is brought online and

102
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:17.990
it is a dedicated pathway
between source and destination.

103
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:23.750
And that portion of that network resource
is actually temporarily used and

104
00:05:23.750 --> 00:05:24.990
other people can't use it, right?

105
00:05:24.990 --> 00:05:28.220
So it's a little bit different than packet
switching where you can have one data

106
00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:31.080
stream that goes across the wire
taking different routes.

107
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:32.120
Circuit switching network,

108
00:05:32.120 --> 00:05:36.590
you build a dedicated point to point
communication between the endpoints.

109
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:41.340
Now, I say point to point, it doesn't have
to be a physical, they also have logical,

110
00:05:41.340 --> 00:05:43.310
virtual circuits, too.

111
00:05:43.310 --> 00:05:47.670
But keep in mind with a circuit switching
network you have a dedicated path

112
00:05:47.670 --> 00:05:51.430
in between source and destination,
unlike the package switching network.

113
00:05:51.430 --> 00:05:54.780
So circuit switching network
are still out there as well,

114
00:05:54.780 --> 00:05:57.880
again that's what you have things like
dialup is a circuit which type network.

115
00:05:57.880 --> 00:06:01.640
You have, for instance,
again those PSTN lines too.

116
00:06:01.640 --> 00:06:05.950
So that's a little it about
package switching networks versus

117
00:06:05.950 --> 00:06:07.100
circuit switching networks.

118
00:06:07.100 --> 00:06:10.060
Also, I went ahead and just mentioned
the other one, cell switching network,

119
00:06:10.060 --> 00:06:12.990
even though it's not really
relevant to our content here.

120
00:06:12.990 --> 00:06:15.160
It is relevant to understand
the three different types.

121
00:06:15.160 --> 00:06:19.160
Cell switching network is a fixed
length and it's predictable, right.

122
00:06:19.160 --> 00:06:22.300
Predictability means we know
exactly what to expect every time,

123
00:06:22.300 --> 00:06:23.190
less error correction.

124
00:06:23.190 --> 00:06:26.180
Now, one of the great things about packet
switching network is that if there

125
00:06:26.180 --> 00:06:30.710
are errors and errors do make are present,
well we just discard the packet and

126
00:06:30.710 --> 00:06:33.745
we do a request for retransmission
depending on if we're using connection

127
00:06:33.745 --> 00:06:36.670
oriented services or
if were using connectionless services.

128
00:06:36.670 --> 00:06:40.408
If it's connectionless services, we just
throw the packet away and that's right,

129
00:06:40.408 --> 00:06:42.770
it goes off and do electrical in both.

130
00:06:42.770 --> 00:06:46.620
All right, so that'll move us into some of
the other topics that we need to discuss.

131
00:06:46.620 --> 00:06:49.160
One of the things I want
to start out with is, and

132
00:06:49.160 --> 00:06:54.090
we've kind of talked about this in
other episodes, is how do switches

133
00:06:54.090 --> 00:07:00.320
make decisions on where to send
information when they are communicating?

134
00:07:00.320 --> 00:07:04.030
Well they do that with
something called a mack table.

135
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:05.110
That's how switches communicate.

136
00:07:05.110 --> 00:07:09.410
And we talked about switches, you know,
the switch communication in an earlier

137
00:07:09.410 --> 00:07:14.220
episode, but I do want you to kinda
understand that the Mac table

138
00:07:14.220 --> 00:07:20.090
essentially is a set of a Mac
addresses related to the porch that

139
00:07:20.090 --> 00:07:25.500
devices are on, and
when a frame comes into the switch,

140
00:07:25.500 --> 00:07:29.257
you have inside of that switch,
you have basically

141
00:07:29.257 --> 00:07:33.500
the database that is built up and
again it is port two MAC address mapping.

142
00:07:33.500 --> 00:07:37.950
So if I have a communication that comes
in on Port 1, well the switch looks and

143
00:07:37.950 --> 00:07:38.725
it says okay.

144
00:07:38.725 --> 00:07:40.620
What's the destination MAC address?

145
00:07:40.620 --> 00:07:41.790
Where is it supposed to be going?

146
00:07:41.790 --> 00:07:45.140
And then it looks at that destination MAC
address and compares it to its MAC table.

147
00:07:45.140 --> 00:07:47.920
And it says okay, I see,
just figuratively speaking,

148
00:07:47.920 --> 00:07:51.214
that this computer with this
destination MAC address, let's say,

149
00:07:51.214 --> 00:07:54.477
is on port 22, and it forwards
that information appropriately.

150
00:07:54.477 --> 00:07:58.958
Now I want you to remember that when
it comes to switches, not only do they

151
00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:03.669
have MAC tables, But just like our
computers they also have ARP tables too.

152
00:08:03.669 --> 00:08:08.030
And the ARP table, remember, is an IP
address mapped to its MAC address.

153
00:08:08.030 --> 00:08:09.727
In fact,
we've kinda looked at this before,

154
00:08:09.727 --> 00:08:11.257
I've got our Windows 10 machine here.

155
00:08:11.257 --> 00:08:14.641
And if you wanna see like on a computer
what the MAC table looks like, all you

156
00:08:14.641 --> 00:08:18.430
have to do is drop down to your command
prompt, and you can do an arp, right?

157
00:08:18.430 --> 00:08:21.390
If you run arp by itself,
it's just gonna say, hey,

158
00:08:21.390 --> 00:08:24.600
you needed to have some kind of
parameter option assigned to it,

159
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:27.780
you can see that we've got
a few different options here.

160
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:31.990
Let me go ahead and clear the screen and
we're gonna do our arp -a,

161
00:08:31.990 --> 00:08:36.000
and what that does is it shows us
the ARP table that this computer has.

162
00:08:36.000 --> 00:08:38.570
Now switches do the same exact thing.

163
00:08:38.570 --> 00:08:39.870
They have ARP tables, too.

164
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:43.290
And again, that's just your IP
addresses mapped to your MAC addresses.

165
00:08:43.290 --> 00:08:48.376
Remember that your switch
is making communication or

166
00:08:48.376 --> 00:08:54.714
delivering or forwarding information
based on that MAC address.

167
00:08:54.714 --> 00:08:58.369
So know a little bit about
the ARP table and what it is and

168
00:08:58.369 --> 00:09:01.972
what would be in there,
as well as your MAC table too.

169
00:09:01.972 --> 00:09:06.252
All right, some of the other concepts
that we need to look at, all right?

170
00:09:06.252 --> 00:09:10.673
One of the things that they talk
about are how do you control,

171
00:09:10.673 --> 00:09:15.540
what devices can communicate and
how and where they communicate.

172
00:09:15.540 --> 00:09:18.660
Well, that's through
something known as an ACL.

173
00:09:18.660 --> 00:09:22.410
Just like in Windows,
those of you that are coming over from A+

174
00:09:22.410 --> 00:09:24.440
probably have heard about permissions,
right?

175
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:27.590
And I can say okay, Zack,
you are our IT manager,

176
00:09:27.590 --> 00:09:31.649
I want you to have full control
over this file or folder, right?

177
00:09:31.649 --> 00:09:35.976
And that means Zack has a certain level of
things that he can do over that file or

178
00:09:35.976 --> 00:09:36.790
folder.

179
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:37.570
Well, believe it or not,

180
00:09:37.570 --> 00:09:40.470
you have access control lists
inside of your switches as well.

181
00:09:40.470 --> 00:09:44.640
And switches,
you can control how the traffic and

182
00:09:44.640 --> 00:09:49.050
who can communicate, what devices can
communicate, through access control lists.

183
00:09:49.050 --> 00:09:53.690
So understand that an ACL is just
a way to an access control method that

184
00:09:53.690 --> 00:09:58.270
allows an administrator to configure the
switch, put rules in there and dictate.

185
00:09:58.270 --> 00:10:02.120
How traffic can move,
where it can move inside of the switch.

186
00:10:02.120 --> 00:10:05.670
Now, those of you who are going on to
more advanced technologies or training,

187
00:10:05.670 --> 00:10:09.170
if you will, might get into the Cisco
world where they're gonan show

188
00:10:09.170 --> 00:10:11.980
you how to inspect an ACL and
do the configurations.

189
00:10:11.980 --> 00:10:14.670
But just know that an access
control list inside of a switch

190
00:10:14.670 --> 00:10:19.500
really isn't much different in a concept,
as it would be permissions inside

191
00:10:19.500 --> 00:10:24.390
of your operating system in Windows or
if you look at firewalls.

192
00:10:24.390 --> 00:10:25.360
Firewalls do what?

193
00:10:25.360 --> 00:10:29.310
They use a series of rules that either
allows or denies traffic going in and

194
00:10:29.310 --> 00:10:30.220
out of an interface.

195
00:10:30.220 --> 00:10:33.200
Well, your ports are interfaces
on switches as well and

196
00:10:33.200 --> 00:10:36.110
you use ACLs to control
who can communicate and

197
00:10:36.110 --> 00:10:40.640
who cannot communicate
on the switch itself.

198
00:10:40.640 --> 00:10:44.440
So that is something to keep in mind.

199
00:10:44.440 --> 00:10:47.770
Some of the other things that you need
to be aware of too that they call out.

200
00:10:47.770 --> 00:10:51.670
They call out things for
instance port mirroring, all right?

201
00:10:51.670 --> 00:10:54.392
Now port mirroring,
why would we do port mirroring?

202
00:10:54.392 --> 00:10:56.570
All right,
well I got a little diagram here and

203
00:10:56.570 --> 00:10:58.215
I wanna kind of show you what I mean here.

204
00:10:58.215 --> 00:11:01.530
So imagine these numbers by
the way these port numbers,

205
00:11:01.530 --> 00:11:03.640
I just kind of randomly through
them out there all right.

206
00:11:03.640 --> 00:11:07.612
So they are arbitrary just
imagine we got a 48 port switch.

207
00:11:07.612 --> 00:11:11.850
And we've got a couple of devices that are
connected to it that are in question here.

208
00:11:11.850 --> 00:11:16.980
Now, port mirroring is a great
way that you can see the traffic,

209
00:11:16.980 --> 00:11:20.750
you can duplicate traffic that's
going into one port, on another port.

210
00:11:20.750 --> 00:11:22.320
Now, why might I do this?

211
00:11:22.320 --> 00:11:24.260
Well, you can do it for
a few reasons, right?

212
00:11:24.260 --> 00:11:28.880
So, notice that the source of the
communication here and the destination.

213
00:11:28.880 --> 00:11:29.663
All right, now,

214
00:11:29.663 --> 00:11:32.662
I want you to keep in mind that we
also a management station here too.

215
00:11:32.662 --> 00:11:36.784
All right, and when we look at this,
notice that the source computer

216
00:11:36.784 --> 00:11:41.122
sends information into Port 2 and
the switch looks at it's MAC table and

217
00:11:41.122 --> 00:11:45.697
says okay, I see the destination MAC
address is bound for this server here.

218
00:11:45.697 --> 00:11:50.340
In this case, and that is on Port 22,
let me send it out that port.

219
00:11:50.340 --> 00:11:53.270
But what's interesting is when you do
a port mirroring, what you're saying

220
00:11:53.270 --> 00:11:58.780
is that, this computer let's say,
we're gonna mirror Port 2 with Port 10.

221
00:11:58.780 --> 00:12:02.115
Now what happens is, even though
the source of the communication and

222
00:12:02.115 --> 00:12:05.120
the destination of the communication
are actually talking.

223
00:12:05.120 --> 00:12:07.342
All the traffic that goes in and

224
00:12:07.342 --> 00:12:12.080
out of Port 2 is now going to be
also duplicated over to Port 10.

225
00:12:12.080 --> 00:12:15.030
Now, like I said,
why would we do something like that?

226
00:12:15.030 --> 00:12:16.700
We do it for
a couple of different reasons, right?

227
00:12:16.700 --> 00:12:18.660
One of the reasons you can do it,
is for security purposes.

228
00:12:18.660 --> 00:12:20.410
Maybe you're doing some
kind of security auditing.

229
00:12:20.410 --> 00:12:23.100
Maybe you've got
an administrative station that

230
00:12:23.100 --> 00:12:26.370
you just want to see what they're doing,
right?

231
00:12:26.370 --> 00:12:29.595
Maybe you've got somebody
on your network that again,

232
00:12:29.595 --> 00:12:32.855
it doesn't always have to be bad right,
that you wanna just kinda

233
00:12:32.855 --> 00:12:37.415
audit what it is that they're doing
while they're at work, I'm not sure.

234
00:12:37.415 --> 00:12:41.965
But you can inspect and
grab that information.

235
00:12:41.965 --> 00:12:44.284
So you can also do it as
a way to just basically,

236
00:12:44.284 --> 00:12:47.863
kind of like sniff traffic without
having to have a protocol analyzer.

237
00:12:47.863 --> 00:12:52.689
But you can also do it for diagnostic
purposes to maybe you wanna see a certain,

238
00:12:52.689 --> 00:12:55.323
for instance if the roles
were reversed and

239
00:12:55.323 --> 00:12:58.128
this server is what you
were port mirroring.

240
00:12:58.128 --> 00:13:01.360
Maybe you wanna see the traffic that's
coming in and out of the server, so

241
00:13:01.360 --> 00:13:05.300
you can get a better understanding
of the utilization of that server.

242
00:13:05.300 --> 00:13:07.790
Maybe the over [LAUGH]
utilization of that server.

243
00:13:07.790 --> 00:13:10.060
Maybe you have to beef
up the network adapter.

244
00:13:10.060 --> 00:13:11.810
Maybe a 1 gig length isn't good enough.

245
00:13:11.810 --> 00:13:13.560
You need a 10 gig length, so again,

246
00:13:13.560 --> 00:13:17.650
you can do it for the purposes just of
inspecting and diagnosing the information.

247
00:13:17.650 --> 00:13:21.990
We can also do this with things like IDSs
too and Trojan detection systems, so

248
00:13:21.990 --> 00:13:23.120
it's really up to you.

249
00:13:23.120 --> 00:13:27.090
Just understand basically, for the exam,
the port mirroring is a way that you can

250
00:13:27.090 --> 00:13:31.870
map traffic across or
duplicate the traffic across ports, right?

251
00:13:31.870 --> 00:13:35.060
We could do it for, again,
diagnostic purposes, auditing purposes,

252
00:13:35.060 --> 00:13:37.950
network logging information that's
coming to and from a server.

253
00:13:37.950 --> 00:13:41.250
And again, we wanna get some
idea of what information,

254
00:13:41.250 --> 00:13:44.460
what is being sent in and
out of that server.

255
00:13:44.460 --> 00:13:48.286
We can do that as well, so
it's a good handy thing to have.

256
00:13:48.286 --> 00:13:50.140
All right, so that's port mirroring.

257
00:13:50.140 --> 00:13:54.900
That's some of the properties of
the interface, if you will, but

258
00:13:54.900 --> 00:13:57.240
there's also other things
that you can do too.

259
00:13:57.240 --> 00:13:57.940
For instance,

260
00:13:57.940 --> 00:14:03.520
one of the things that we can do is
something known as port security.

261
00:14:03.520 --> 00:14:09.390
Now, port security is a way that we can
define exactly who or, as I say who but

262
00:14:09.390 --> 00:14:13.350
it's not us as the humans,
it's the device if you will, the node.

263
00:14:13.350 --> 00:14:15.780
I know I keep saying who can communicate,

264
00:14:15.780 --> 00:14:19.160
but what devices can communicate
on a single port, right?

265
00:14:19.160 --> 00:14:20.337
So for security,

266
00:14:20.337 --> 00:14:22.715
imagine that port security but,
>> [LAUGH]

267
00:14:22.715 --> 00:14:24.158
>> For security purposes,

268
00:14:24.158 --> 00:14:28.211
we wanna ensure that somebody can't
just randomly plug into a port and

269
00:14:28.211 --> 00:14:30.420
send their communications, right?

270
00:14:30.420 --> 00:14:34.210
Now physical security is one of
your second lines of defense,

271
00:14:34.210 --> 00:14:37.280
only preceded by policies,
procedure and awareness.

272
00:14:37.280 --> 00:14:38.800
But we do need physical security.

273
00:14:38.800 --> 00:14:41.910
So port security is a good way
to physically, you can say,

274
00:14:41.910 --> 00:14:47.330
hey, I'm gonna only allow this computer
to send information into that port.

275
00:14:47.330 --> 00:14:50.530
All right, so let's go ahead and
check and see what that looks like.

276
00:14:50.530 --> 00:14:53.400
So Zach, what we've got here is
we've got a series of computers.

277
00:14:53.400 --> 00:14:55.850
And again, like I said,
their names are kinda arbitrary here.

278
00:14:55.850 --> 00:14:58.280
But what I really care about
is the MAC address, right?

279
00:14:58.280 --> 00:15:02.300
And again, these are just kinda made
up on the fly MAC addresses still

280
00:15:02.300 --> 00:15:03.795
within the same format, right, so.

281
00:15:03.795 --> 00:15:08.329
Client01 has its MAC address,
that's part of an Ethernet based network.

282
00:15:08.329 --> 00:15:11.149
We'll all had MAC addresses and
remember that's what the switch is

283
00:15:11.149 --> 00:15:13.520
already using to determine
where to forward traffic.

284
00:15:13.520 --> 00:15:17.481
Right, I'm look into that destination MAC
address compare it to the MAC table inside

285
00:15:17.481 --> 00:15:18.204
of the switch.

286
00:15:18.204 --> 00:15:22.546
Well, when you do port security,
all you're saying is that on this

287
00:15:22.546 --> 00:15:26.966
port that the Client01 is connected to,
the only traffic that I'm

288
00:15:26.966 --> 00:15:31.010
going to allow into that port
is something that's sourced.

289
00:15:31.010 --> 00:15:35.917
Right, now we're looking
at the source MAC address.

290
00:15:35.917 --> 00:15:42.183
A source MAC address of this right here,
00-01-22-33-44-55, right?

291
00:15:42.183 --> 00:15:44.137
Same thing with Clientt02.

292
00:15:44.137 --> 00:15:46.470
Client02 is connected to the switch.

293
00:15:46.470 --> 00:15:51.405
The only inbound communication that we're
gonna allow on that port is going to

294
00:15:51.405 --> 00:15:53.287
be Client02s MAC address.

295
00:15:53.287 --> 00:15:55.473
Right, against inspecting that source and

296
00:15:55.473 --> 00:15:58.494
that destination MAC address
inside of the Ethernet frame.

297
00:15:58.494 --> 00:16:02.640
Same thing here likewise with Client03,
no different.

298
00:16:02.640 --> 00:16:04.332
Right?
We got a MAC address,

299
00:16:04.332 --> 00:16:06.432
and that's all we wanna see.

300
00:16:06.432 --> 00:16:08.730
Again, coming in to that port, right?

301
00:16:08.730 --> 00:16:13.250
So we've already got that MAC address
there, right from these computers.

302
00:16:13.250 --> 00:16:17.380
And it is in that database,
right and the switch says, okay,

303
00:16:17.380 --> 00:16:19.890
I see it again,
just arbitrary portal numbers here.

304
00:16:19.890 --> 00:16:22.912
Port 2, I see MAC address for client 1.

305
00:16:22.912 --> 00:16:24.862
All right, port 10, I see the MAC address.

306
00:16:24.862 --> 00:16:28.310
We configure MAC address and
port security for client 2.

307
00:16:28.310 --> 00:16:31.510
Let's say port 23 has client 03 on it,
right?

308
00:16:31.510 --> 00:16:33.800
That MAC address is there, likewise too.

309
00:16:33.800 --> 00:16:35.420
So now what happens, all right?

310
00:16:35.420 --> 00:16:40.760
Well, it's inspecting the source of the
communication as it comes into the switch.

311
00:16:40.760 --> 00:16:42.610
And here's what happens, all right?

312
00:16:42.610 --> 00:16:44.920
So we've got our bad guy, right?

313
00:16:44.920 --> 00:16:47.580
And you can tell he's a bad guy
by the way he's dressed, right?

314
00:16:47.580 --> 00:16:50.006
He's dressed like
Frank Sinatra with sunglasses,

315
00:16:50.006 --> 00:16:51.720
apparently that makes you a bad guy.

316
00:16:51.720 --> 00:16:52.649
>> An evil Frank Sinatra.

317
00:16:52.649 --> 00:16:54.774
>> That's right,
that's an evil Frank Sinatra.

318
00:16:54.774 --> 00:16:59.089
[LAUGH] So what we end up having here is,
and I'm sure you're not paying attention

319
00:16:59.089 --> 00:17:01.700
to the MAC addresses out there and
that's okay.

320
00:17:01.700 --> 00:17:07.725
So let me explain that this MAC address
that was actually set in the database,

321
00:17:07.725 --> 00:17:08.378
right?

322
00:17:08.378 --> 00:17:12.557
So when this switch receives
communication on port 2 and

323
00:17:12.557 --> 00:17:17.171
it inspects the MAC address just
like it's gonna do anyways and

324
00:17:17.171 --> 00:17:20.827
let's fix that there
aren't semicolons there,

325
00:17:20.827 --> 00:17:25.200
it looks at the MAC address and
says, let me see who that is.

326
00:17:25.200 --> 00:17:28.070
All right, let me look at my database.

327
00:17:28.070 --> 00:17:32.800
Yeah on port 2, I don't see that MAC
address, that's not the right MAC address,

328
00:17:32.800 --> 00:17:34.125
so what does it do?

329
00:17:34.125 --> 00:17:37.535
It doesn't allow the communication
it completely discards it,

330
00:17:37.535 --> 00:17:39.555
right that's part of port security.

331
00:17:39.555 --> 00:17:42.968
Now there are other port security too that
we could talk about as well and we'll talk

332
00:17:42.968 --> 00:17:45.963
a little bit more in depth as well
because I don't want to just stop here.

333
00:17:45.963 --> 00:17:50.155
But there's also 802.1X,
right that's port based authentication.

334
00:17:50.155 --> 00:17:51.635
Switches can actually and

335
00:17:51.635 --> 00:17:56.750
wireless access points if they're set up
in an enterprise mode, what you can do is

336
00:17:56.750 --> 00:18:00.492
physically shut the port down as
an authentication request comes in.

337
00:18:00.492 --> 00:18:05.330
All right, what the switch does is
pass that authentication through to

338
00:18:05.330 --> 00:18:07.840
some kind of authentication
server like a Radius server, and

339
00:18:07.840 --> 00:18:12.630
shut the port down while the Radius
server is doing the authentication,

340
00:18:12.630 --> 00:18:14.900
verifying that that
person should be there.

341
00:18:14.900 --> 00:18:18.120
And if the person or, again,
the device, I keep saying person,

342
00:18:18.120 --> 00:18:21.640
if the device should be
connected to the network, and

343
00:18:21.640 --> 00:18:25.730
the authentication is successful,
it turns around an it opens the port.

344
00:18:25.730 --> 00:18:27.330
So there's a couple of
different ways you can do it.

345
00:18:27.330 --> 00:18:30.570
One of the ways you can do it,
port security, there, is through, kind

346
00:18:30.570 --> 00:18:34.420
of like we do with our wireless network,
as well, through MAC filtering, right?

347
00:18:34.420 --> 00:18:37.470
We can say only the MAC address

348
00:18:37.470 --> 00:18:40.970
from this computer can send
information into that switch, right.

349
00:18:40.970 --> 00:18:45.560
We do it a little bit different, for
different purposes on wireless networks,

350
00:18:45.560 --> 00:18:50.070
we can say allow or deny,
we can put a MAC address in a list, right?

351
00:18:50.070 --> 00:18:52.712
This is doing it on a port by port basis.

352
00:18:52.712 --> 00:18:54.800
All right,

353
00:18:54.800 --> 00:18:58.860
so those are some of the other interface
properties that we need to be aware of.

354
00:18:58.860 --> 00:19:03.150
I would say, probably the next thing that
we should be aware of is what is known as

355
00:19:03.150 --> 00:19:03.660
VLANs.

356
00:19:03.660 --> 00:19:04.880
All right, what is a VLAN?

357
00:19:04.880 --> 00:19:07.710
A VLAN is a virtual local area network.

358
00:19:07.710 --> 00:19:12.520
It's a layer to technology that allows you
to essentially, logically if you will,

359
00:19:12.520 --> 00:19:15.150
divide up a switch in to
more than one switch.

360
00:19:15.150 --> 00:19:18.420
See, if I've got 48 ports on a switch,
what do I have?

361
00:19:18.420 --> 00:19:21.380
I have one big huge broadcast domain,
right?

362
00:19:21.380 --> 00:19:23.110
We talked about broadcast domains.

363
00:19:23.110 --> 00:19:25.750
>> Yep.
>> Well, if I want to maybe logically

364
00:19:25.750 --> 00:19:30.340
divide some of those ports up then
what I can do is create these logical

365
00:19:30.340 --> 00:19:35.170
software if you will,
based local area networks.

366
00:19:35.170 --> 00:19:36.920
And let me show you what I mean here.

367
00:19:36.920 --> 00:19:43.040
So I've got just an example of a VLAN
that you might see, VLAN diagram, right?

368
00:19:43.040 --> 00:19:45.900
So I've got one switch, right?

369
00:19:45.900 --> 00:19:48.950
Remember, switches are only aware
of what is connected to them.

370
00:19:48.950 --> 00:19:51.660
So these computers have to
be plugged into the switch.

371
00:19:51.660 --> 00:19:55.200
And then what we can do
inside of the software,

372
00:19:55.200 --> 00:19:58.070
the switch is that we can configure and
we can logically

373
00:19:58.070 --> 00:20:01.280
group these computers together so
that only they can communicate.

374
00:20:01.280 --> 00:20:04.580
That's why they call it
a virtual local area network.

375
00:20:04.580 --> 00:20:05.580
That's what a VLAN is.

376
00:20:05.580 --> 00:20:08.170
It's a software defined
local area network.

377
00:20:08.170 --> 00:20:10.550
Now don't confuse that with
software defined networking.

378
00:20:10.550 --> 00:20:11.820
We'll talk about SDN later.

379
00:20:11.820 --> 00:20:15.410
But what this is,
is it's logically defined in software.

380
00:20:15.410 --> 00:20:19.770
All right, so
that means that PC1, PC4 and 5.

381
00:20:19.770 --> 00:20:22.490
They're on their same virtual network,
right?

382
00:20:22.490 --> 00:20:25.590
And they can't communicate with,
if they are on VLAN10,

383
00:20:25.590 --> 00:20:28.370
they cannot communicate with VLAN20.

384
00:20:28.370 --> 00:20:32.720
These servers, I can segment them,
I can separate them from the rest of

385
00:20:32.720 --> 00:20:39.310
the computers that are on separate VLANs,
isolating their communication just for

386
00:20:39.310 --> 00:20:44.370

00:28:38.800 --> 00:28:40.570
And I tell you what,

00:28:41.920 --> 00:28:45.940
Let's talk about how we can,

if we get too many broadcasts we can

And it causes what's known as

00:28:53.000 --> 00:28:57.990
In order to stop this, we use something

00:28:57.990 --> 00:28:59.510
So, I want you to take a scenario, right,

00:28:59.510 --> 00:29:03.650
where this switch sends a broadcast

00:29:03.650 --> 00:29:06.267
Remember, we're talking

00:29:06.267 --> 00:29:10.650

00:29:10.650 --> 00:29:14.570

00:29:14.570 --> 00:29:18.150
That's where we send a broadcast

00:29:18.150 --> 00:29:19.840
because we need everybody to hear it.

00:29:19.840 --> 00:29:22.630
Well, the problem with

00:29:22.630 --> 00:29:25.070
this switch sends a broadcast
communication, right?

541
00:29:25.070 --> 00:29:30.390
It is sending a communication out to all

00:29:30.390 --> 00:29:33.140

00:29:33.140 --> 00:29:37.027
Well, what happens when this

00:29:37.027 --> 00:29:40.875
Well, it says okay,

00:29:40.875 --> 00:29:44.640

00:29:44.640 --> 00:29:47.830
And then what happened's again well

00:29:47.830 --> 00:29:50.630

00:29:50.630 --> 00:29:52.670

00:29:52.670 --> 00:29:55.710
Well it's send's it out all of

00:29:55.710 --> 00:29:59.970
This switch and this switch just

00:29:59.970 --> 00:30:03.250
even though it was this switch that

00:30:03.250 --> 00:30:06.280
this switch will receive it,
this switch will receive it.

00:30:06.280 --> 00:30:08.150
And then we're back to the same thing.

00:30:08.150 --> 00:30:11.988
Notice that again we've got,

00:30:11.988 --> 00:30:13.870
It's just those broadcast communication,

00:30:13.870 --> 00:30:17.050
every switch is receiving a portion

00:30:22.070 --> 00:30:24.366
And then you see what's going on here.

00:30:24.366 --> 00:30:28.113
The cycle just kind of repeats itself and

00:30:28.113 --> 00:30:32.900
communications are just ending up in these

561
00:30:32.900 --> 00:30:38.640
So what we do with spanning
tree protocol uses

562
00:30:38.640 --> 00:30:43.120
an algorithm called STA, spanning tree
algorithm, sorry about the acronyms there.

563
00:30:43.120 --> 00:30:44.020
It gets confusing.

564
00:30:44.020 --> 00:30:46.470
STP uses STA, class dismissed.

565
00:30:46.470 --> 00:30:51.560
No, spanning tree protocol uses an
algorithm called spanning tree in order to

566
00:30:51.560 --> 00:30:53.010
do a few things, all right?

567
00:30:53.010 --> 00:30:58.060
So I want you to know, it's a loop
prevention mechanism at layer two, right?

568
00:30:58.060 --> 00:31:02.730
What it does is the algorithm
takes all of these switches, and

569
00:31:02.730 --> 00:31:04.390
we can go look at our slide here.

570
00:31:04.390 --> 00:31:08.140
All of these switches are gonna go through
what's know as an election process.

571
00:31:08.140 --> 00:31:16.220
And the election process what it does is
it's determining the main switch, right?

572
00:31:16.220 --> 00:31:19.620
Who is the king of all the switches,
right?

573
00:31:19.620 --> 00:31:23.370
That's what becomes the root switch,
root bridge as they call it.

574
00:31:23.370 --> 00:31:26.231
They call it a root bridge
because bridging technologies,

575
00:31:26.231 --> 00:31:28.700
switching technologies
are pretty much the same.

576
00:31:28.700 --> 00:31:32.213
So this goes back from the early
days when we had bridges but

577
00:31:32.213 --> 00:31:34.727
they still call it a root bridge, right.

578
00:31:34.727 --> 00:31:39.517
What the root bridge is, is the root
bridge is the top part of the tree, right,

579
00:31:39.517 --> 00:31:42.855
it's going to start to try to
form this tree topology so

580
00:31:42.855 --> 00:31:45.370
there aren't any loops right.

581
00:31:45.370 --> 00:31:48.720
And the top part of the tree
is called that root bridge.

582
00:31:48.720 --> 00:31:52.188
And the root bridge's ports
are always in forwarding mode,

583
00:31:52.188 --> 00:31:54.505
all their ports are in forwarding mode.

584
00:31:54.505 --> 00:31:57.517
Now the root bridge is
determined by priority and

585
00:31:57.517 --> 00:32:01.407
it uses a MAC address all right,
a MAC address and a priority and

586
00:32:01.407 --> 00:32:04.566
by default all switches
have The same priority, so

587
00:32:04.566 --> 00:32:09.047
a lot of times what will happen is,
if you let spanning tree protocol go,

588
00:32:09.047 --> 00:32:13.260
is that it's going to choose the MAC
address with the lowest value.

589
00:32:13.260 --> 00:32:15.630
That will be the highest priority,
it will become the root bridge.

590
00:32:15.630 --> 00:32:18.250
And there are going to be problems with
that as well, because a lot of times,

591
00:32:18.250 --> 00:32:22.380
what you have is your oldest switches
have the lowest priority, or

592
00:32:22.380 --> 00:32:24.040
the lowest MAC addresses.

593
00:32:24.040 --> 00:32:26.930
And a lot of times, your oldest switches
are the slowest switches, right.

594
00:32:26.930 --> 00:32:28.240
They're the oldest technology.

595
00:32:28.240 --> 00:32:30.890
So a lot of your administrators
like in Cisco and

596
00:32:30.890 --> 00:32:35.360
stuff will manually define
what the route bridge is.

597
00:32:35.360 --> 00:32:39.150
But you can let FTP do this as well.

598
00:32:39.150 --> 00:32:42.110
Now, once the root bridge
has been elected, now,

599
00:32:42.110 --> 00:32:44.020
we gotta go through another process,
right?

600
00:32:44.020 --> 00:32:47.950
And that's determining which port you're
gonna actually be forwarding information,

601
00:32:47.950 --> 00:32:50.368
so that's another part of this, right?

602
00:32:50.368 --> 00:32:53.420
It determines, are loops present, and

603
00:32:53.420 --> 00:32:55.590
if loops are present,
we gotta start blocking ports.

604
00:32:55.590 --> 00:32:56.940
So, what we're doing here is,

605
00:32:56.940 --> 00:33:00.464
we're determining which
ports will be root ports.

606
00:33:00.464 --> 00:33:03.340
And root ports are gonna
forward information

607
00:33:03.340 --> 00:33:08.420
always back to the highest part of the
hierarchy, back towards the root bridge.

608
00:33:08.420 --> 00:33:10.080
And then you have designated ports,

609
00:33:10.080 --> 00:33:14.920
which can forward to other switches,
not to the root, but to other switches.

610
00:33:14.920 --> 00:33:16.685
And then you have non-designated ports,

611
00:33:16.685 --> 00:33:19.940
and non-designated ports
are those ones that we close down.

612
00:33:19.940 --> 00:33:25.970
And what it's trying to do is make sure
that it creates this loop-free topology.

613
00:33:25.970 --> 00:33:29.430
And then finally, what you have,
you'll see that the root ports,

614
00:33:29.430 --> 00:33:31.640
right, they're only
going in one direction.

615
00:33:31.640 --> 00:33:35.790
They're only forwarding traffic to one
direction, and that's back to the root.

616
00:33:35.790 --> 00:33:36.440
Right?

617
00:33:36.440 --> 00:33:40.880
So remember, you have root ports,
you have designated ports and

618
00:33:40.880 --> 00:33:42.670
you have non-designated ports.

619
00:33:42.670 --> 00:33:44.820
Root ports means these are the shortest,

620
00:33:44.820 --> 00:33:48.110
if this was determined that it's
the shortest path back to the root, and

621
00:33:48.110 --> 00:33:51.190
the designated ports
are forwarding to other switches.

622
00:33:51.190 --> 00:33:52.870
So, do keep that in mind.

623
00:33:52.870 --> 00:33:55.930
Any kind of loop that is detected,
those ports will be shut down and

624
00:33:55.930 --> 00:33:58.310
those are non-designated ports.

625
00:33:58.310 --> 00:34:00.770
All right, so a little bit
about spanning tree algorithm.

626
00:34:00.770 --> 00:34:04.410
Again, as you go on to
more advanced training,

627
00:34:04.410 --> 00:34:08.060
you'll learn how to configure this, and
you'll learn it in much greater detail.

628
00:34:08.060 --> 00:34:11.480
I would say on the Net+ exam,
know the process that's happening, right?

629
00:34:11.480 --> 00:34:12.620
Know that it's a priority and

630
00:34:12.620 --> 00:34:15.510
a MAC address that determines
the route bridge election.

631
00:34:15.510 --> 00:34:19.400
Know that it's root ports,
designated ports and non-designated ports.

632
00:34:19.400 --> 00:34:24.270
Essentially, the root ports are that
shortest path between that switch and

633
00:34:24.270 --> 00:34:26.570
the root bridge if you will,
or the root switch.

634
00:34:26.570 --> 00:34:30.960
And then, designated ports forward
just to that segment and then last but

635
00:34:30.960 --> 00:34:34.370
not least,
non-designated ports are blocked.

636
00:34:34.370 --> 00:34:36.170
That takes me to one other topic.

637
00:34:36.170 --> 00:34:40.630
I guess we got a couple of other
topics here, and we will finish up.

638
00:34:40.630 --> 00:34:44.720
The next thing I want to talk about is
what's known as a DMZ, and you might

639
00:34:44.720 --> 00:34:48.640
have heard this in our security section,
where we talked about demilitarized zone.

640
00:34:48.640 --> 00:34:52.420
There are a couple of different ways that
they define this in other technologies,

641
00:34:52.420 --> 00:34:55.880
more vendor-specific terms, you might
hear screen subnet perimeter network,

642
00:34:55.880 --> 00:34:56.520
edge network.

643
00:34:56.520 --> 00:35:01.740
But if we can look here,
our DMZ is typically

644
00:35:01.740 --> 00:35:05.650
any resource that is publicly
accessible from the internet.

645
00:35:05.650 --> 00:35:07.320
So I want you to think about this.

646
00:35:07.320 --> 00:35:11.930
We don't want people out on the internet
being able to connect back into our local

647
00:35:11.930 --> 00:35:14.500
area network, right,
that would be a security vulnerability.

648
00:35:14.500 --> 00:35:17.410
But what we might have is we
might have a web server for

649
00:35:17.410 --> 00:35:20.950
a company that needs to sell our product,
right?

650
00:35:20.950 --> 00:35:22.200
Well, we might have a web server, but

651
00:35:22.200 --> 00:35:25.050
we need customers from
the Internet to be able to get to.

652
00:35:25.050 --> 00:35:30.140
So how do we allow access public
access into that resource

653
00:35:30.140 --> 00:35:35.320
without actually allowing them access back
into our private network, or our LAN?

654
00:35:35.320 --> 00:35:38.338
Well, that's where a DMZ comes in.

655
00:35:38.338 --> 00:35:43.465
A DMZ, a demilitarized zone,
essentially, is a subnet.

656
00:35:43.465 --> 00:35:47.860
It's usually placed in between two
firewalls where the external firewall

657
00:35:47.860 --> 00:35:49.530
allows communication in.

658
00:35:49.530 --> 00:35:51.400
You can communicate with the web server,
but

659
00:35:51.400 --> 00:35:55.580
it doesn't allow public access back
into the local area network, right.

660
00:35:55.580 --> 00:35:59.090
So it is a, basically a network
that sits between the public side,

661
00:35:59.090 --> 00:36:02.460
public facing side,
which would be the internet, and

662
00:36:02.460 --> 00:36:05.980
the private network which would
be your local area network.

663
00:36:05.980 --> 00:36:08.970
All right, last but not least, I say last,

664
00:36:08.970 --> 00:36:11.245
it does look like I've
got two more topics here.

665
00:36:11.245 --> 00:36:14.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know we're running short on time.

666
00:36:14.210 --> 00:36:17.320
But I also wanna talk about, briefly,
about distributed switching, just so

667
00:36:17.320 --> 00:36:19.340
you can understand what that means.

668
00:36:19.340 --> 00:36:19.880
And again,

669
00:36:19.880 --> 00:36:23.550
this is something that you'll see in some
of the vendor-specific training as well.

670
00:36:23.550 --> 00:36:28.176
And what this does is,
this actually just breaks up and

671
00:36:28.176 --> 00:36:33.480
puts a hierarchical
implementation to switching.

672
00:36:33.480 --> 00:36:35.670
Essentially a hierarchical
model with multiple layers,

673
00:36:35.670 --> 00:36:37.940
and what you have are these three layers.

674
00:36:37.940 --> 00:36:40.880
You have an access layer,
a distribution layer, and a core layer.

675
00:36:40.880 --> 00:36:44.660
The access layer connects the clients
directly to the network, if you will.

676
00:36:44.660 --> 00:36:47.680
The distribution network can be
things like LAN-based routers,

677
00:36:47.680 --> 00:36:52.850
layer three switches, and it moves
the data like, for instance, across VLANs.

678
00:36:52.850 --> 00:36:56.846
The last is the core layer, and
the core layer are high-end switches with

679
00:36:56.846 --> 00:36:59.620
high-speed cabling,
like fiber optic communications.

680
00:36:59.620 --> 00:37:01.270
Think of it as the backbone.

681
00:37:01.270 --> 00:37:04.010
They're gonna handle
the traffic from everything.

682
00:37:04.010 --> 00:37:07.250
So lot of bandwidth,
basically, high-speed cable,

683
00:37:07.250 --> 00:37:09.330
compromising the backbone of a network.

684
00:37:09.330 --> 00:37:10.700
And that's just those abstract,

685
00:37:10.700 --> 00:37:13.480
that hierarchical model that
they apply to switching.

686
00:37:13.480 --> 00:37:17.560
They call it distributed swishing,
distributed switching.

687
00:37:17.560 --> 00:37:18.420
I'm not swishing.

688
00:37:18.420 --> 00:37:20.138
We're not teaching you
how to brush your teeth.

689
00:37:20.138 --> 00:37:21.680
[LAUGH] That's right.

690
00:37:21.680 --> 00:37:24.640
And right, last but not the least and
I'll quit saying that, sound

691
00:37:24.640 --> 00:37:28.858
like Colombo episode here is something
known as power over ethernet, POE.

692
00:37:28.858 --> 00:37:32.520
All right, POE is exactly what it
sounds like, ladies and gentlemen.

693
00:37:32.520 --> 00:37:36.840
It means that we've got ethernet cables,
and we inject power onto them so

694
00:37:36.840 --> 00:37:38.130
that we can power devices.

695
00:37:38.130 --> 00:37:39.280
Now, where do we see this?

696
00:37:39.280 --> 00:37:40.370
Where would this come in handy?

697
00:37:40.370 --> 00:37:41.920
I want you to think about of any kind of,

698
00:37:41.920 --> 00:37:46.340
like, an access point, that you can't
run an external AC adapter to, right?

699
00:37:46.340 --> 00:37:48.280
An IP camera, right?

700
00:37:48.280 --> 00:37:50.360
You have some kind of security camera, and

701
00:37:50.360 --> 00:37:53.310
you want to be able to send data to it and
from it.

702
00:37:53.310 --> 00:37:57.620
But you don't have a place to
mount an external AC adaptor.

703
00:37:57.620 --> 00:38:01.800
Well, you can plug your ethernet cable
into it, connect it to a POE injector.

704
00:38:01.800 --> 00:38:05.680
It puts power in to the ethernet cable,
and powers the device.

705
00:38:05.680 --> 00:38:09.350
There are two different POE technologies
that I want you to be aware of for

706
00:38:09.350 --> 00:38:10.130
the exam, right?

707
00:38:10.130 --> 00:38:12.370
There's POE and POE+.

708
00:38:12.370 --> 00:38:16.896
POE is 802.3af, alpha foxtrot, there.

709
00:38:16.896 --> 00:38:19.623
POE+ is 802.at, alpha tango.

710
00:38:19.623 --> 00:38:24.030
So what's the difference
between these two?

711
00:38:24.030 --> 00:38:29.030
Basically the output of wattage, right,
one's got a higher wattage output.

712
00:38:29.030 --> 00:38:32.081
The first POE or 802.3af,

713
00:38:32.081 --> 00:38:37.110
let me make sure I say that right,
would give you 15.4 watts.

714
00:38:37.110 --> 00:38:43.380
If you're talking about POE+, it increased
the wattage output up to about 25.5 watts.

715
00:38:43.380 --> 00:38:49.970
So POE+, or 802.at,
is going to be 25.5 watt output.

716
00:38:49.970 --> 00:38:53.690
So, just more of those specifications
that you have to know for your Net+ exam.

717
00:38:53.690 --> 00:38:56.480
Remember some of these technologies,
remember some of the fundamentals, and

718
00:38:56.480 --> 00:38:59.260
you'll be doing well the next
time you sit in that exam booth.

719
00:38:59.260 --> 00:39:00.540
>> Awesome job, Wes.

720
00:39:00.540 --> 00:39:04.023
Another essential episode,
switching technologies, and

721
00:39:04.023 --> 00:39:06.565
that's a part of the Comptia Net+ series.

722
00:39:06.565 --> 00:39:08.450
Make sure you see every
single one of them, and

723
00:39:08.450 --> 00:39:11.610
that will be in the course library, where
you'll find hundreds of other videos,

724
00:39:11.610 --> 00:39:14.100
all designed to help you go so
much further.

725
00:39:14.100 --> 00:39:17.110
And tell everybody you know about
ITPro TV, it is binge worthy.

726
00:39:17.110 --> 00:39:18.540
Thank you for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

727
00:39:18.540 --> 00:39:19.380
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

728
00:39:19.380 --> 00:39:19.890
>> And we'll see you soon.

729
00:39:19.890 --> 00:39:27.964
[MUSIC]

730
00:39:27.964 --> 00:39:30.399
Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach Wes dive into the various characteristics and attributes of routing technologies. They will look routing protocols like difference between interior gateway routing protocols and exterior gateway routing protocols. They will talk about a distance-vector routing protocol known as RIP and RIPv2.
episodes.title: Routing Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode Zach Wes dive into the various characteristics and attributes of routing technologies. They look at distance-vector protocols like EIGRP, a link-state routing protocol called OSPF as well as a path-vector routing protocol called BGP. They will look at other concepts like NAT and PAT, routing types and port forwarding
episodes.title: Routing Technologies Part 2

WEBVTT

8

9

As we continue on with CompTIA Net plus.

10
00:00:20.570 --> 00:00:23.550
And this is routing technologies part two.

11
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:27.080
And once Brian is here to once

00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:28.112
Well, it's good to see you, sir.

00:00:28.112 --> 00:00:30.363
>> Hey, [CROSSTALK] Hopefully
if it's murky waters,

we can clear them up for you.

15
00:00:31.627 --> 00:00:32.160
>> Yes, we can.

16
00:00:32.160 --> 00:00:36.670
>> That's right, so we've been talking
about routing technologies, right?

17
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:38.890
And like Zach mentioned,
this is a part two.

18
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:39.740
Remember in the first part,

19
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:43.340
we kind of set the stage for,
just some of the basics, right?

20
00:00:43.340 --> 00:00:46.090
The difference between an IGP and and EGP,

21
00:00:46.090 --> 00:00:49.720
interior gateway versus
exterior gateway protocols.

22
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:54.220
And we really talked about
Distance Vector Routing Protocols, right.

23
00:00:54.220 --> 00:00:56.770
We were talking about Rip version 2.

24
00:00:56.770 --> 00:01:00.750
So as a real quick recap on that
just remember RIP version 2 is

25
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:02.380
a distance-vector routing protocol, and

26
00:01:02.380 --> 00:01:05.250
with distance-vector protocols
keep in mind that it is

27
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:09.560
the hop count that becomes the cost of the
metric or what determines the best path.

28
00:01:09.560 --> 00:01:13.880
>> Yeah, so you said there's two types
of IGPs, distance vector and link state.

29
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:15.600
Now can you tell us more about that?

30
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:19.560
>> Absolutely, so
with link state routing protocols,

31
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:24.230
it's another type of essentially
interior gateway protocol.

32
00:01:24.230 --> 00:01:29.245
And the, really the most common one
that we use is what is known as OSPF,

33
00:01:29.245 --> 00:01:30.110
all right?

34
00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:32.098
That's Open, Shortest Path First.

35
00:01:32.098 --> 00:01:34.890
And it's kinda interesting, in the name
you can kind of see what's going on.

36
00:01:34.890 --> 00:01:36.360
It's the basis of routing, right?

37
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:39.060
We want the best, or
the shortest path to get to a destination.

38
00:01:39.060 --> 00:01:43.480
Well, with open shortest path first and
link state routing, it's a little

39
00:01:43.480 --> 00:01:46.750
different in how we determine what
the cost of a route is, right?

40
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:53.590
The metric or the cost itself is going
to be based on not just distance.

41
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:56.030
And really it can be based
on a lot of things, right?

42
00:01:56.030 --> 00:02:00.090
So where distance vector uses
the destination and just distance

43
00:02:00.090 --> 00:02:04.210
when it comes to link state, I want you
to kind of change your mindset around it.

44
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:07.560
I've been teaching this for almost
a decade now, and one of the things that I

45
00:02:07.560 --> 00:02:12.130
tell students is that when you think
of link state, change it around.

46
00:02:12.130 --> 00:02:15.060
And I want you to think
of state of the link.

47
00:02:15.060 --> 00:02:18.870
If you think of state of the link routing,
you can kind of figure out

48
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:23.580
what a link state routing protocol
is using to determine the best path.

49
00:02:23.580 --> 00:02:26.062
How it determines the cost, right?

50
00:02:26.062 --> 00:02:30.160
And that is through the state of the link,
right?

51
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:36.280
So it can use things like, for
instance, it can use the bandwidth.

52
00:02:36.280 --> 00:02:38.860
What is the available bandwidth for
it, if you will?

53
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:43.380
What is the load utilization, what is the
link reliability, is it up, is it down.

54
00:02:43.380 --> 00:02:46.570
Again speed of the link,
the bandwidth is one that is very,

55
00:02:46.570 --> 00:02:48.540
very important and let me show you here.

56
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:53.800
So unlike remember our distance-vector
protocol that's using hop counts,

57
00:02:53.800 --> 00:02:58.010
right and the distance when it comes
to something like OSPF, OSPF can say,

58
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:01.490
hey should I send this over,
let's say, maybe.

59
00:03:01.490 --> 00:03:03.296
Oop, let me finish my diagram there again.

60
00:03:03.296 --> 00:03:07.280
Should I send this over 100 megabite link?

61
00:03:07.280 --> 00:03:11.030
Or 100 megabit link,
should I send this over 65k link?

62
00:03:11.030 --> 00:03:14.580
Should I send this over a 10 gig link,
right?

63
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:18.989
Well, you'll notice that 10 gig
is obviously gonna be faster than

64
00:03:18.989 --> 00:03:22.790
a 100 Meg link, so
the 10 gig link has more bandwidth,

65
00:03:22.790 --> 00:03:26.228
it's gonna be could
potentially be a better choice.

66
00:03:26.228 --> 00:03:29.980
So we look at the quality of the link,
the speed of the link.

67
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:32.890
Well, is that link up or
is that link down?

68
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:35.220
Again, so the reliability of the link.

69
00:03:35.220 --> 00:03:37.720
So and
administrators can actually set these.

70
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:40.480
They set them through what are known
ad administrative distances, right?

71
00:03:40.480 --> 00:03:44.170
And you can manually let
OSPF determine it and

72
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:48.530
there's a certain value or cost associated
with different transmission speeds.

73
00:03:48.530 --> 00:03:51.328
But then administrators can
override these if they want.

74
00:03:51.328 --> 00:03:54.648
If they wanna manually define what
the cost of the link is, they can and

75
00:03:54.648 --> 00:03:57.972
they do that by setting what are known
as administrative distances and

76
00:03:57.972 --> 00:04:00.115
different characteristics of those links,

77
00:04:00.115 --> 00:04:02.853
as you'll go on to more
advanced training we'll learn.

78
00:04:02.853 --> 00:04:08.000
But the administrative distances do
differ in what the overall cost is.

79
00:04:08.000 --> 00:04:11.409
Now, kinda understand
a little bit more about OSPF.

80
00:04:11.409 --> 00:04:14.530
OSPF is actually a pretty
amazing link state protocol.

81
00:04:14.530 --> 00:04:19.670
It's the most common interior gateway
protocol, much more so than RIP is today.

82
00:04:19.670 --> 00:04:22.080
And one of the reasons is,

83
00:04:22.080 --> 00:04:26.960
Is that it doesn't have a hop count
limitation, we don't have that limitation.

84
00:04:26.960 --> 00:04:28.961
It's very, very scalable.

85
00:04:28.961 --> 00:04:32.120
It has faster convergence times too.

86
00:04:32.120 --> 00:04:35.835
Now, initially, it doesn't,
all right and let me tell you why.

87
00:04:35.835 --> 00:04:38.985
If we go back to our diagram here, OSPF,

88
00:04:38.985 --> 00:04:42.985
when these routers first come online if
they're using OSPF then what they do is

89
00:04:42.985 --> 00:04:47.570
they actually broadcast their routing
tables to all routers within the network.

90
00:04:47.570 --> 00:04:52.203
And you're probably thinking maybe, maybe
you're thinking out there like I am well

91
00:04:52.203 --> 00:04:55.161
wait a second if Rip is only
talking to the neighbors and

92
00:04:55.161 --> 00:04:59.794
broadcasting that communication with that
me more efficient than OSPF flooding that

93
00:04:59.794 --> 00:05:02.469
information out to every
router on the network.

94
00:05:02.469 --> 00:05:07.553
The answer is yes at first OSPF is
gonna saturate your network with a lot

95
00:05:07.553 --> 00:05:13.259
of communications while all of these
routers on this network try to converge.

96
00:05:13.259 --> 00:05:17.789
Again, convergence remember that
process of us all agreeing that we have

97
00:05:17.789 --> 00:05:20.680
the updated routing information.

98
00:05:20.680 --> 00:05:23.580
Now here's where it
starts to out perform REV

99
00:05:23.580 --> 00:05:28.340
at first you get a lot of heavy traffic,
as these routers are learning.

100
00:05:29.810 --> 00:05:31.475
Once they are converge,

101
00:05:31.475 --> 00:05:35.680
once they all agree to have
the updated topology information,

102
00:05:35.680 --> 00:05:41.157
if a link fails unlike RIP which continues
to broadcast communicate it's routing

103
00:05:41.157 --> 00:05:46.660
tables whether anything changes or not

I'm looking at the destination network

00:18:09.120 --> 00:18:12.062

00:18:12.062 --> 00:18:14.556

00:18:14.556 --> 00:18:17.490

333
00:18:17.490 --> 00:18:22.695
This means if I search the routing table,

00:18:22.695 --> 00:18:26.400
I don't know where to send it, I'm gonna

00:18:26.400 --> 00:18:29.720

00:18:29.720 --> 00:18:32.990

00:18:32.990 --> 00:18:35.760

00:18:35.760 --> 00:18:40.390

339
00:18:40.390 --> 00:18:45.520
Use its routing table and it can send
information on its local network, but

340
00:18:45.520 --> 00:18:48.070

00:18:48.070 --> 00:18:52.230

00:18:52.230 --> 00:18:55.500

00:18:55.500 --> 00:18:58.570

00:18:58.570 --> 00:19:01.350
The router,
it's up to its job to sit there and

00:19:01.350 --> 00:19:03.760

346
00:19:03.760 --> 00:19:08.060
So that is the default route, and I want
you to be aware of it or for the exam.

409
00:22:16.670 --> 00:22:19.970
Public IP addresses are how we

410
00:22:19.970 --> 00:22:24.504
Unlike the private IP addresses,
which I believe is RFC1918, if you will,

411
00:22:24.504 --> 00:22:27.973
request for comment 1918,
these private IP addresses,

00:22:27.973 --> 00:22:30.727
they're just used

00:22:30.727 --> 00:22:34.129

00:22:34.129 --> 00:22:36.943
IM before that, said hey,

00:22:36.943 --> 00:22:41.840
And you can use them internally in

416
00:22:41.840 --> 00:22:45.840
But you're not gonna be able to

00:22:45.840 --> 00:22:48.510
So how is it that you can have

00:22:48.510 --> 00:22:49.900

00:23:20.510 --> 00:23:23.180
That's through network

00:23:23.180 --> 00:23:25.125

00:23:30.990 --> 00:23:35.905

00:23:35.905 --> 00:23:37.830

00:23:37.830 --> 00:23:42.690

00:23:42.690 --> 00:23:44.302

00:23:47.887 --> 00:23:52.220

You can see 172.16 and

00:23:55.565 --> 00:23:57.989
That's in that class

00:23:57.989 --> 00:24:00.121

00:24:05.470 --> 00:24:09.039
So how is it that I tell you that

00:24:09.039 --> 00:24:11.589

00:24:16.770 --> 00:24:21.150

00:24:21.150 --> 00:24:25.455

00:24:29.618 --> 00:24:32.913

00:24:37.444 --> 00:24:40.130

00:24:40.130 --> 00:24:43.730

00:24:43.730 --> 00:24:45.840

00:24:45.840 --> 00:24:48.348
All right,
now when it comes back into the network,

00:24:48.348 --> 00:24:51.490
what it does is it takes that public

00:24:51.490 --> 00:24:53.078
Oops, [LAUGH] it removes it,

00:24:53.078 --> 00:24:56.690

00:24:56.690 --> 00:25:00.790

00:25:00.790 --> 00:25:02.345

00:25:06.368 --> 00:25:08.613

00:25:45.610 --> 00:25:47.440
