00:29:45.680 --> 00:29:48.351
>> Thanks for watching,
we'll see you soon.

554
00:29:48.351 --> 00:29:54.261
[MUSIC]

555
00:29:54.261 --> 00:29:57.091
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the concepts surrounding performance of the network. They look at some of the ways networks can grant specific types of traffic more or less of the network resources to ensure quality-of-service.
episodes.title: Network Performance Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.310
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.310 --> 00:00:06.080
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.080 --> 00:00:08.529
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.529 --> 00:00:12.146
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.146 --> 00:00:14.306
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.306 --> 00:00:16.710
helping you learn everywhere you go.

7
00:00:16.710 --> 00:00:20.780
I'm Zach Memos, your host as we
continue on with CompT and NetPlus.

8
00:00:20.780 --> 00:00:24.830
This episode is network
performance concepts.

9
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:27.740
And Wes is right here to show us the way.

10
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:28.840
Wes, good to have you here.

11
00:00:28.840 --> 00:00:30.260
>> Hey, Zach, thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:30.260 --> 00:00:33.078
That's right,
we have been working through,

13
00:00:33.078 --> 00:00:37.104
essentially a few concepts when it
comes to routing and switching.

14
00:00:37.104 --> 00:00:40.211
Weve looked at things like
the characteristics of our traffic,

15
00:00:40.211 --> 00:00:42.596
some of the properties that
you have to be aware of,

16
00:00:42.596 --> 00:00:46.702
weve talked about things like broadcast
domains, the communication times, weve

17
00:00:46.702 --> 00:00:51.030
looked at switching technologies, we've
also looked at routing concepts, too.

18
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:54.695
And as we move through those different
shows, we've been looking really at that

19
00:00:54.695 --> 00:01:00.078
1.3 domain there if you're following
along at home with the objectives there.

20
00:01:00.078 --> 00:01:04.250
And it is basically understanding
the concepts of routing and switching, and

21
00:01:04.250 --> 00:01:08.880
we kind of divvied them up a little bit so
that we could group them together in

22
00:01:08.880 --> 00:01:12.490
what I feel is in the appropriate manner,
right?

23
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:15.402
Because when we're talking about switching
technologies we're talking about

24
00:01:15.402 --> 00:01:16.340
VLANs, right?

25
00:01:16.340 --> 00:01:18.360
Well, that should be grouped
together with the switches.

26
00:01:18.360 --> 00:01:22.800
And if we talk about something like
routing information protocol or OSPF,

27
00:01:22.800 --> 00:01:25.700
that should be part of our
routing technologies, right?

28
00:01:25.700 --> 00:01:28.520
So one of the last things
that we kind of want to,

29
00:01:28.520 --> 00:01:32.160
again if you've been following along with
us, one of the last things we kind of

30
00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:36.240
round off are some network performance
concepts just like Zach said here.

31
00:01:36.240 --> 00:01:40.280
And we're gonna look at how you can
manipulate your communications a little

32
00:01:40.280 --> 00:01:43.020
bit to ensure that
different types of traffic

33
00:01:43.020 --> 00:01:46.360
get the network resources they need,
because when you think about it,

34
00:01:46.360 --> 00:01:49.210
we've got a network,
we've got a certain amount of bandwidth.

35
00:01:49.210 --> 00:01:53.560
And we sometimes need to prioritize, what
types of traffic get to their end point,

36
00:01:53.560 --> 00:01:57.300
the closer to real time, if you will,
and maybe even like some traffic,

37
00:01:57.300 --> 00:02:01.580
like traditional and old traffic that we
can slow down a little bit to ensure that

38
00:02:01.580 --> 00:02:04.400
real time traffic gets to
where it needs to be on time.

39
00:02:04.400 --> 00:02:07.700
>> Well that sounds like
a network shaping, right?

40
00:02:08.970 --> 00:02:11.670
>> It's close, it's called
traffic shaping, all right, and

41
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:15.730
in fact what we're going to look at
is more of an umbrella term, right?

42
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:17.520
We call it quality of service, right?

43
00:02:17.520 --> 00:02:19.540
And quality of service really is,

44
00:02:19.540 --> 00:02:23.500
there's many different ways we
can achieve a quality of service.

45
00:02:23.500 --> 00:02:25.950
But imagine that you've got one,

46
00:02:25.950 --> 00:02:30.310
let's say one communication, and
it's hogging all of your bandwidth.

47
00:02:30.310 --> 00:02:34.308
Let's say for instance, somebody's on
your network viewing things like YouTube,

48
00:02:34.308 --> 00:02:36.540
right when maybe they should be working.

49
00:02:36.540 --> 00:02:40.510
And what's causing, it can cause problems
with things like voice over traffic,

50
00:02:40.510 --> 00:02:42.360
voice over IP communications, right?

51
00:02:42.360 --> 00:02:46.110
In which we need to kind
a ensure a faster delivery.

52
00:02:46.110 --> 00:02:49.130
Well if somebody is hogging all of
our bandwidth in a certain area,

53
00:02:49.130 --> 00:02:54.040
then what happens is those, the end
user experience starts to degrade right,

54
00:02:54.040 --> 00:02:58.120
and certain communications we start
to notice performance hindrances

55
00:02:58.120 --> 00:02:59.110
inside of our network.

56
00:02:59.110 --> 00:03:02.530
>> So traffic shaping can
affect our network performance.

57
00:03:02.530 --> 00:03:03.820
>> It can, it can.

58
00:03:03.820 --> 00:03:07.270
And we need to kind of understand
what's going on here when it comes to

59
00:03:07.270 --> 00:03:08.070
traffic shaping.

60
00:03:08.070 --> 00:03:11.770
Now traffic shaping can be broken down
into some categories as well, all right?

61
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:15.510
For instance, on your exam objectives,
they call out what is known as traffic

62
00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:20.380
shaping and they also mention a little
bit about what's known as policing.

63
00:03:20.380 --> 00:03:22.910
Actually, they just call
it traffic shaping, really.

64
00:03:22.910 --> 00:03:25.520
But again, I'm gonna break it down
into three different concepts.

65
00:03:25.520 --> 00:03:27.410
We're gonna talk about
traffic shaping itself.

66
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:29.940
We're gonna talk about
traffic policing and

67
00:03:29.940 --> 00:03:32.215
then last I wanna talk
about reservations too.

68
00:03:32.215 --> 00:03:33.640
Because really, again,

69
00:03:33.640 --> 00:03:37.100
in the context of the exam objectives
they just mention traffic shaping.

70
00:03:37.100 --> 00:03:38.550
So let's go ahead and

71
00:03:38.550 --> 00:03:42.740
let's first give you a scenario
where maybe I need traffic shaping.

72
00:03:42.740 --> 00:03:47.280
All right, again, you want to ensure
that certain types of traffic

73
00:03:47.280 --> 00:03:51.290
get the level of performance,
the level of your network communications

74
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:55.500
that they need in order to give
a better experience, right?

75
00:03:55.500 --> 00:03:58.840
We have older traffic types like
some of the most common ones and

76
00:03:58.840 --> 00:04:02.420
again classic traffic types,
things like FTP, file transfer protocol,

77
00:04:02.420 --> 00:04:05.650
things like HTTP, right, your web traffic.

78
00:04:05.650 --> 00:04:08.740
Well they can do a little bit
better with a little bit of delay,

79
00:04:08.740 --> 00:04:11.090
I mean HTTP might be
a little exception there.

80
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:12.360
You're talking about end users, right?

81
00:04:12.360 --> 00:04:14.360
Because end users want to
get to your website, and

82
00:04:14.360 --> 00:04:16.760
they want the fastest and
best experience possible.

83
00:04:16.760 --> 00:04:20.010
But if you look at stuff like
File Transfer Protocol, been around for

84
00:04:20.010 --> 00:04:23.480
a very long time, and it's not
necessary because it is optimized for

85
00:04:23.480 --> 00:04:27.290
a large file transfer that it consumes
all of your network bandwidth.

86
00:04:27.290 --> 00:04:29.730
But we can actually kinda
slow that traffic down.

87
00:04:29.730 --> 00:04:32.530
And if we look at our bandwidth,
it's more of a piece of pie, right?

88
00:04:32.530 --> 00:04:37.540
And we can give a greater piece of pie to
things like voice conferencing, right?

89
00:04:37.540 --> 00:04:40.690
Video conferencing,
voice over IP communications,

90
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:42.670
things that need to get there
a little bit faster, right?

91
00:04:42.670 --> 00:04:44.830
Because File Transfer Protocol,

92
00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:49.320
it can handle a little bit of a delay,
a moderate amount of delay, right?

93
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:54.770
Things like video, video conferencing,
it can't handle a lot of delay right?

94
00:04:54.770 --> 00:04:57.260
It needs to be closer to real time.

95
00:04:57.260 --> 00:05:00.125
But the other thing we
need to look at is video

96
00:05:00.125 --> 00:05:04.880
conferencing We can implement
a little bit of packet loss, right?

97
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:10.150
Because in video conferencing, I don't
need to rebuild and reassemble packets,

98
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:14.150
if you will, and cause a glitch inside
of the video stream that we're watching,

99
00:05:14.150 --> 00:05:19.050
right, versus something like FTP where
we really can't have packet loss.

100
00:05:19.050 --> 00:05:20.800
Packet loss leads to file corruption,
right?

101
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:25.540
So we need to be able to mix and match and
kinda put the pieces of our network

102
00:05:25.540 --> 00:05:29.190
communications bandwidth where we need
them and that's what traffic shaping.

103
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:33.300
One of the many components under
quality service traffic shaping allows

104
00:05:33.300 --> 00:05:34.260
us to do so.

105
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:38.280
Let's talk about a little bit
more about traffic shaping.

106
00:05:38.280 --> 00:05:40.700
I got a little diagram here and

107
00:05:40.700 --> 00:05:44.870
what we're gonna do is kind of do
this in 8-bit increments, right.

108
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:47.970
We're gonna say well if I
want to shape the traffic,

109
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:52.200
it essentially allows me the ability
to do bandwidth management.

110
00:05:53.930 --> 00:05:58.420
Manipulate the data in order to
get prioritization to certain

111
00:05:58.420 --> 00:06:03.560
traffic as well as reducing
the heavy impact or

112
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:07.110
the impact that heavy bandwidth users
would have on any one person's experience.

113
00:06:07.110 --> 00:06:10.590
It's like I said, we're watching
a lot of YouTube communications then

114
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:13.000
we've got unnecessary
traffic on our network and

115
00:06:13.000 --> 00:06:15.800
we need to make sure that we can
shape that a little bit more.

116
00:06:15.800 --> 00:06:18.740
So let's say that we're
working on a policy,

117
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:22.740
if you will that says hey,
you can only use 8 bits of bandwidth.

118
00:06:22.740 --> 00:06:25.650
Well if I'm doing traffic shaping,
how does that work for us?

119
00:06:25.650 --> 00:06:28.820
Well if we're talking about
just basic traffic shaping,

120
00:06:28.820 --> 00:06:34.058
we're saying there's 8 bits of information
and that's kind of our ceiling, our cap.

121
00:06:34.058 --> 00:06:37.410
Well notice that if I
have 6 bits of bandwidth,

122
00:06:37.410 --> 00:06:39.620
what does traffic shaping do for me?

123
00:06:39.620 --> 00:06:42.615
Absolutely nothing,
I don't even notice it., right?

124
00:06:42.615 --> 00:06:47.081
But how about this, how about if
we send 7 bits of traffic, right?

125
00:06:47.081 --> 00:06:51.642
Well, how does traffic shaping affect
me there on those communications?

126
00:06:51.642 --> 00:06:53.147
Well, it doesn't, right?

127
00:06:53.147 --> 00:06:56.748
If I'm sending less than whatever the cap
is, whatever the policy says, hey,

128
00:06:56.748 --> 00:06:59.814
you're gonna send this amount and
you're not gonna send anymore,

129
00:06:59.814 --> 00:07:02.050
it doesn't affect you if you send less,
right.

130
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:03.560
And we don't even know.

131
00:07:03.560 --> 00:07:07.100
But let's consider,
when we talk about traffic shaping,

132
00:07:07.100 --> 00:07:08.800
a random line in
the middle of the diagram.

133
00:07:08.800 --> 00:07:12.679
Let's go ahead and pull this over and
let's say hey, well what happens if you

134
00:07:12.679 --> 00:07:16.032
send 8 bits of information while
you are still within the policy?

135
00:07:16.032 --> 00:07:17.445
Nothing really happens.

136
00:07:17.445 --> 00:07:19.635
But here's where it
starts to come into play.

137
00:07:19.635 --> 00:07:22.815
I want you to notice that we
have this 9th bit, all right?

138
00:07:22.815 --> 00:07:26.362
We say hey, the cap is 8 bits.

139
00:07:26.362 --> 00:07:28.152
And again we're just using this for
theory purposes.

140
00:07:28.152 --> 00:07:30.532
8 bits, what happens to the 9th bit?

141
00:07:30.532 --> 00:07:34.292
Well, this is where you have to know
the difference between traffic shaping and

142
00:07:34.292 --> 00:07:38.732
traffic policing, again it's all really
part of adjusting your bandwidth.

143
00:07:38.732 --> 00:07:43.243
But what happens to this 9th bit is
really different when we talk about

144
00:07:43.243 --> 00:07:45.005
shaping versus policing.

145
00:07:45.005 --> 00:07:49.589
So Zach, if we look here our 9th bit,
what's gonna happen to that,

146
00:07:49.589 --> 00:07:53.461
well if we go over the cap,
it's gonna be put in a buffer and

147
00:07:53.461 --> 00:07:58.127
what's going to happen is- The network
adapter is gonna buffer it and

148
00:07:58.127 --> 00:08:02.620
says, you know what,
I can't send that 9th bit right now.

149
00:08:02.620 --> 00:08:06.050
So what we'll do is we'll put it in
a buffer, and we'll allow communication to

150
00:08:06.050 --> 00:08:10.480
keep happening, and when the network's
free, we'll send that 9th bit.

151
00:08:10.480 --> 00:08:13.310
That's traffic shaping,
and what it says is,

152
00:08:13.310 --> 00:08:17.820
you're not going to send any
more information than just this.

153
00:08:17.820 --> 00:08:20.370
Now there's a little bit more to that
cuz I want to talk about policing and

154
00:08:20.370 --> 00:08:21.370
then we'll compare the two.

155
00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:23.900
Because what happens to that extra traffic

156
00:08:23.900 --> 00:08:27.280
is polar opposite different when it
comes to the two different concepts.

157
00:08:27.280 --> 00:08:31.155
So lets go ahead and let's talk
a little bit about Traffic Policing.

158
00:08:31.155 --> 00:08:35.405
Now, remember what we said, Traffic
Policing we're saying 8 bits is the cap.

159
00:08:35.405 --> 00:08:39.205
So anything less than that,
if I say, okay, here's 8 bits,

160
00:08:39.205 --> 00:08:44.155
and I say, well, somebody sending, I don't
know, let's say 3 bits of information.

161
00:08:44.155 --> 00:08:46.175
Well, they don't really notice it, right?

162
00:08:46.175 --> 00:08:50.390
And if, let's say they send 7 bits,

163
00:08:50.390 --> 00:08:53.550
well just like traffic shaping
it really doesn't affect us.

164
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:57.120
But now what we're gonna do is we're gonna
play a little bit of devil's advocate and

165
00:08:57.120 --> 00:09:00.820
I'm gonna bring out that pesky
9th bit again, all right?

166
00:09:00.820 --> 00:09:02.590
So what happens to the 9th bit?

167
00:09:02.590 --> 00:09:04.850
You're over the cap.

168
00:09:04.850 --> 00:09:06.740
Now here's the big difference.

169
00:09:06.740 --> 00:09:11.550
Notice when I said traffic shaping, what
we do is we buffer the excess information.

170
00:09:11.550 --> 00:09:15.014
If it's over what the policy states,
or the rule states if you will,

171
00:09:15.014 --> 00:09:16.580
we're gonna buffer that bit.

172
00:09:16.580 --> 00:09:20.425
And when the line is free, we're gonna
try to keep sending that information, but

173
00:09:20.425 --> 00:09:23.300
we're gonna make sure
it's no more than 8 bits.

174
00:09:23.300 --> 00:09:26.880
Policing, it does a little bit different.

175
00:09:26.880 --> 00:09:30.100
And instead of doing a buffer if you will,

176
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:34.080
like we just did with shaping,
it doesn't do a buffer.

177
00:09:34.080 --> 00:09:39.830
In fact, it's called policing because
what it does is it takes that 9th bit and

178
00:09:39.830 --> 00:09:47.640
it essentially will send it directly to
the garbage, all right, electrical limbo.

179
00:09:47.640 --> 00:09:51.620
So what happens is with policing,
any extra information, it's thrown out.

180
00:09:52.860 --> 00:09:54.810
Sorry, you can't send any
more information on that.

181
00:09:54.810 --> 00:09:56.790
We're not shaping the traffic,
we're not saying, okay,

182
00:09:56.790 --> 00:10:00.820
I just want this steady rate and anything
extra will be buffered and then sent.

183
00:10:00.820 --> 00:10:04.000
No, policing says, you're gonna
send this amount of information,

184
00:10:04.000 --> 00:10:06.585
if you send more,
I'm just going to discard it.

185
00:10:06.585 --> 00:10:10.690
So that is something to understand

186
00:10:10.690 --> 00:10:15.220
when it comes to the difference between
traffic shaping and traffic policing.

187
00:10:15.220 --> 00:10:17.790
Now there's another one
too that we have and

188
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:20.260
that is something known as reservations,
all right.

189
00:10:20.260 --> 00:10:23.580
And what I want you to understand
with reservations is that is

190
00:10:23.580 --> 00:10:26.010
kind of like saying,
all right, well you know what,

191
00:10:26.010 --> 00:10:30.490
I've got one device that's very,
very important in my network.

192
00:10:30.490 --> 00:10:34.440
Very important, all right, and
what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna say that

193
00:10:34.440 --> 00:10:38.075
this device,
I'm gonna reserve that bandwidth.

194
00:10:38.075 --> 00:10:41.653
I'm going to say, 8 bits,
you're guaranteed 8 bits,

195
00:10:41.653 --> 00:10:45.304
I'm going to reserve a portion
of the network bandwidth for

196
00:10:45.304 --> 00:10:48.607
you to make sure you have
that 8 bits when you need it.

197
00:10:48.607 --> 00:10:51.929
That's reservation, it's still traffic
shaping, you're still manipulating

198
00:10:51.929 --> 00:10:54.885
the bandwidth, but there is, you can
do this in a couple of ways, right?

199
00:10:54.885 --> 00:10:58.320
I can say, Zach, you always are going
to have time to speak here.

200
00:10:58.320 --> 00:11:01.130
Now, he's been hosting with us for
a while now and

201
00:11:01.130 --> 00:11:04.366
he knows that if I'm talking nobody
is going to be able to talk.

202
00:11:04.366 --> 00:11:06.545
[LAUGH] But
might not be a good analogy here but-

203
00:11:06.545 --> 00:11:07.878
>> it's a hierarchy.

204
00:11:07.878 --> 00:11:10.589
>> That's right, that's right,
so I'm going to say, Zach,

205
00:11:10.589 --> 00:11:12.687
you know you are going to
be reserved this time.

206
00:11:12.687 --> 00:11:16.295
Now what do we do with that time,
what do we do with that bandwidth?

207
00:11:16.295 --> 00:11:19.480
Well here's where the two differences come
in, you can do a reservation that says,

208
00:11:19.480 --> 00:11:23.050
Zach, I'm going to reserve you
that time and it's set in stone.

209
00:11:23.050 --> 00:11:24.590
It's just going to be there, waiting for

210
00:11:24.590 --> 00:11:27.780
you and you know what, we're going to take
it away from the rest of the network.

211
00:11:27.780 --> 00:11:33.790
So if you have a very high priority
system that you need that bandwidth,

212
00:11:33.790 --> 00:11:36.652
you need to make sure that
it's always open, right?

213
00:11:36.652 --> 00:11:40.320
Just like we're reserving the bat phone,
we need to know that if Batman makes that

214
00:11:40.320 --> 00:11:43.530
call, he's got that bandwidth
when he needs it, or

215
00:11:43.530 --> 00:11:46.540
we could say same thing,
make a reservation.

216
00:11:46.540 --> 00:11:48.340
But what we're gonna do is
we're gonna go ahead and

217
00:11:48.340 --> 00:11:50.590
use that bandwidth while
you're not using it, right?

218
00:11:50.590 --> 00:11:54.620
So it's kind of like dinner reservations,
the table doesn't get reserved and

219
00:11:54.620 --> 00:11:57.350

00:24:00.610 --> 00:24:02.590
are streaming traffic, right?

444
00:24:02.590 --> 00:24:07.200
Because they were looking, and again,
I think I heard one statistic that said

445
00:24:07.200 --> 00:24:10.860
70 to 80% of all of the bandwidth was
being taken up by streaming media.

446
00:24:10.860 --> 00:24:12.072
So they're gonna say hey,

447
00:24:12.072 --> 00:24:15.877
we're gonna reduce the amount of bandwidth
that we allow people to stream media for.

448
00:24:15.877 --> 00:24:19.417
So they are not the heavy bandwidth
consumers over the other people that

449
00:24:19.417 --> 00:24:21.135
are maybe trying to get work done.

450
00:24:21.135 --> 00:24:24.792
So throttling again just like in
CPUs we say throttling those of you

451
00:24:24.792 --> 00:24:29.760
that are coming over from A+ we're slowing
the rate of the bandwidth down, right?

452
00:24:29.760 --> 00:24:32.188
Rate limiting is outbound of your network.

453
00:24:32.188 --> 00:24:35.090
From inbound to outbound if you will.

454
00:24:35.090 --> 00:24:37.810
And that's slowing down
the amount of traffic or

455
00:24:37.810 --> 00:24:42.230
the amount of bandwidth that any one
person or one device might be consumed.

456
00:24:42.230 --> 00:24:43.050
>> That's fantastic.

457
00:24:43.050 --> 00:24:46.090
Well Network Performance Concepts,
love this episode.

458

A lot of great information.

459

In fact, Wes has done a wonderful job with

They're all designed to

And tell everybody you know about ITPROTV,

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They look an IP address format and how to convert IP addresses from decimal format to binary format as well as base10 and base2 numbering systems.
episodes.title: IP Addressing

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.360 --> 00:00:02.738

Thanks-

This is going to be one of those topics
that if you're getting into networks for

if you're coming into network plus, well,

As we go through this journey, we're gonna

us, all right here in this episode

IP addressing is how we determine

19

When we talk about IP, the internet

22

26

27

hey, what network do I send this to,

39

What end system do we

So let's go ahead and let's look at

Let's dive in to where our

give us a little bit

What I'm going to do is

We'll just run this very basically.

Ipconfig, I want you to remember

cuz we're going to use it and

a lot throughout this entire net

It's an important one to

And then, here is our the status

we're gonna talk about because we have

We also have the next generation too,

talk a little bit about in IP addressing,

Maybe not in this episode,

Now, I wanna look a little

and I kinda wanna talk about,

only does it, not just what does it

77

You have to kinda understand how

So you can see that I have an IPv4

Be familiar with this output on the exam,

They don't even tell

They just scroll past it and you have

But you can see, I have an IPv4 address.

What do these components do?

What's going on here?

>> Okay well, the subnet mask,
that's interesting,

I am glad you asked that, okay?

So the subnet mask, what it is responsible

the makeup of a IP address,
what it actually is,

00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:04.750
the subnet mask defines what

97
00:05:04.750 --> 00:05:09.250
And let's understand that the IPv4

us humans here in what's known

99
00:05:13.540 --> 00:05:14.426
>> Mm.

100
00:05:14.426 --> 00:05:19.098
>> A dotted, you can see here that we
have four individual blocks of numbers,

101
00:05:19.098 --> 00:05:20.592
four decimal numbers.

102

And we actually pronounce the dots,
believe it or not, when you're gonna

pronounce this in networking, you don't
say 10 period 0 period 14 period 20, 120.

104
00:05:30.982 --> 00:05:33.053
Actually, you pronounced them as dot,
right?

105
00:05:33.053 --> 00:05:38.614
10 dot zero dot 14 dot 120.

106
00:05:38.614 --> 00:05:41.610
Well that's how we see it as humans,

107
00:05:41.610 --> 00:05:44.920
But as far as the computer is concerned,

108
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:47.550
the computer doesn't deal
with this decimal values.

109
00:05:47.550 --> 00:05:49.302
Computers deal in binary.

110
00:05:49.302 --> 00:05:52.820
Binary is just ones and zeros, right?

111
00:05:52.820 --> 00:05:56.700
There's only two possible values,
there's a zero and there's a one, right?

112
00:05:56.700 --> 00:05:57.850
Binary zero, binary one.

113
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:00.100
It's what we call a base
two numbering system.

114
00:06:00.100 --> 00:06:05.500
Unlike a decimal notation, which we're
used to, this is what we're familiar with.

115
00:06:05.500 --> 00:06:07.780
Decimal value is just for us humans.

116
00:06:07.780 --> 00:06:13.592
Now, underneath, there's actually
32 binary bits that represent what

117
00:06:13.592 --> 00:06:19.336
the computer sees in an IP address,
it's actually a 32 bit identifier.

118
00:06:19.336 --> 00:06:21.915
Now, back to your question,
the subnet mask.

119
00:06:21.915 --> 00:06:26.231
The subnet mask, when applied to
this 32 bit identifier, and again,

120
00:06:26.231 --> 00:06:32.278
it's also expressed in dot and decimal
notation, you'll see 255.255.255.0.0.

121
00:06:32.278 --> 00:06:35.903
But when we look at binder,
which we gonna show you coming up,

122
00:06:35.903 --> 00:06:40.500
when a subnet mask is applied to an IP
address, it actually divides it up.

123
00:06:40.500 --> 00:06:44.640
The subnet mask tells us what
network this computer is on.

124
00:06:44.640 --> 00:06:49.400
It also tells us what portion of this IP
address is unique to the actual host.

125
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:54.160
In this case, this host, this computer
here, that has the IP address, right?.

126
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:59.330
So the subnet mask, primarily,
is applied to your IP address.

127
00:06:59.330 --> 00:07:01.840
And it defines what the network is.

128
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:04.150
And we'll show you how that

129
00:07:04.150 --> 00:07:06.270
just to kind of understand
it going forward.

130
00:07:06.270 --> 00:07:10.320
The default gateway,
what is the default gateway?

131
00:07:10.320 --> 00:07:11.780
Well, when we look at the default gateway,

132
00:07:11.780 --> 00:07:17.210
the default gateway is the IP
address of the router.

133
00:07:17.210 --> 00:07:21.390
When I need to send my traffic

134
00:07:22.470 --> 00:07:26.050
my computer doesn't understand routing,
that's not what it does.

135
00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:29.330
So it's gonna look at, it's interesting,
it will look at something internally,

136

it will look at a routing table that
we'll talk about in another episode.

137
00:07:32.910 --> 00:07:35.790
And it says, hey,
I recognize the local network,

138
00:07:35.790 --> 00:07:40.670
cuz I can apply my subnet mask to my
address, the computer can do that.

139
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:42.338
And it says, I know what that word on.

140
00:07:42.338 --> 00:07:46.661
And if I look at the destination IP
address and I apply that subnet mask,

141
00:07:46.661 --> 00:07:50.839
the same one I have, to it, and
we go through a process that, again,

142
00:07:50.839 --> 00:07:54.082
we'll look at coming up,
I can identify that, hey,

143
00:07:54.082 --> 00:07:58.330
this information is destined for
the network that I'm on.

144
00:07:58.330 --> 00:07:59.418
All right, I don't need the router.

145
00:07:59.418 --> 00:08:03.063
However, if I apply my subnet
mask the destination IP address,

146
00:08:03.063 --> 00:08:06.920
and I don't get my network,
I don't know what network that's on.

147
00:08:06.920 --> 00:08:11.173
So I need to get it to a device, if you
will, that can get that off of this local

148
00:08:11.173 --> 00:08:14.780
network can route that traffic
to another network, all right?

149
00:08:14.780 --> 00:08:16.580
And that's the job of the router.

150
00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:21.670
So the default gateway inside of
the TCP/IP communication protocol stack,

151
00:08:21.670 --> 00:08:25.720
if you will, is nothing more than really
the IP address of the router, all right?.

152
00:08:25.720 --> 00:08:28.300
Or as you'll learn in other
episodes that we've done,

153
00:08:28.300 --> 00:08:33.530
a layer three switch that also
understands the IP information, right?.

154
00:08:33.530 --> 00:08:35.350
So the default gateway is,

155
00:08:35.350 --> 00:08:38.120
think of it this way, it's the doorway
off of your local network, right?

156
00:08:38.120 --> 00:08:44.550
If I am gonna leave my house and I'm
gonna go, how do I get to the next house?

157
00:08:44.550 --> 00:08:46.220
Well, I got to go out the doorway, right?

158
00:08:46.220 --> 00:08:49.905
I got to go out the front door to be able
to go into the door of another house.

159
00:08:49.905 --> 00:08:53.620
Your default gateway as the gateway of
the door, off of your local network.

160
00:08:54.620 --> 00:08:58.778
Now, one of the things that I did mention
is that I said that an IP address, right,

161
00:08:58.778 --> 00:09:00.967
it is, there are four blocks, all right?

162
00:09:00.967 --> 00:09:04.210
Well, these blocks are actually
called octets, right?

163
00:09:05.510 --> 00:09:10.989
Because remember, an IP address underneath
is actually binary information.

164
00:09:10.989 --> 00:09:13.710
It's 32 ones and zeros, right?

165
00:09:13.710 --> 00:09:17.158
And I don't know if they're ones or zeros,
and we'll show you how you find that out

166
00:09:17.158 --> 00:09:20.818
as well cuz that's important to understand
what we call decimal to binary conversion.

167
00:09:20.818 --> 00:09:24.363
And we can kinda show you what
the computer is doing when it applies

168
00:09:24.363 --> 00:09:25.550
a subnet mask.

169
00:09:25.550 --> 00:09:27.233
And it determines what
network we're on and

170
00:09:27.233 --> 00:09:29.060
we'll also look at these components,
right?

171
00:09:29.060 --> 00:09:31.260
But these are called octets.

172
00:09:31.260 --> 00:09:35.450
And from the left to the right,
you have what's known as the first octet,

173
00:09:35.450 --> 00:09:39.024
second octet, third and
fourth octets, right?

174
00:09:39.024 --> 00:09:41.486
And it is important to understand that,
right,

175
00:09:41.486 --> 00:09:43.476
understand what the octet is, right?

176
00:09:43.476 --> 00:09:47.348
Even though we're seeing it
in decimal representation,

177
00:09:47.348 --> 00:09:51.810
each block is eight bits,
eight bits wide, hence the term octet.

178
00:09:51.810 --> 00:09:56.420
Now it is important to understand
how we do the conversion, right?

179
00:09:56.420 --> 00:09:59.714
And this is gonna be important so
you get a basis for

180
00:09:59.714 --> 00:10:03.335
what is going on when a subnet
mask is applied, right?

181
00:10:03.335 --> 00:10:06.533
We have to be able to determine
what network we're on, and

182
00:10:06.533 --> 00:10:10.646
in order to do that, sometimes we actually
have to see those binary ones and

183
00:10:10.646 --> 00:10:12.170
zeros to be able to do that.

184
00:10:12.170 --> 00:10:14.050
So that's the next thing
that we are gonna do.

185
00:10:14.050 --> 00:10:17.770
We are gonna go ahead, all right, and
we are gonna take a couple of examples of

186
00:10:17.770 --> 00:10:22.070
IP addresses and we are gonna
kind of convert them to binary.

187
00:10:22.070 --> 00:10:25.621
Cuz I do want you to see
an example of the octet,

188
00:10:25.621 --> 00:10:29.550
the bits that are within an IP address,
all right?

189
00:10:29.550 --> 00:10:34.844
So i've got a couple of examples here of
IP addresses that were gonna go ahead and

190
00:10:34.844 --> 00:10:36.460
were gonna convert.

191
00:10:36.460 --> 00:10:40.804
Were gonna use these three IP addresses,
and what were gonna do is we're gonna

192
00:10:40.804 --> 00:10:44.777
take them from the dotted decimal
notation, and were gonna transfer, or

193
00:10:44.777 --> 00:10:48.462
convert them over, if you will,
into the binary format, all right?

194
00:10:48.462 --> 00:10:49.990
So lets go ahead and do that.

195
00:10:49.990 --> 00:10:52.850
And the first thing that we have to do,
is we kinda have to understand

196

the difference between the base-2 and

there's your eight bits of binary.

423
00:22:53.120 --> 00:22:58.030
And that's what 208 looks like, not in

424
00:22:58.030 --> 00:22:58.820
>> Pretty cool.

425

Now, I know we're running a little bit

And then we'll come back,

we'll do a couple more examples as we

All right, so next one is 119.

The question is can I take 119 and

No negatives, remember we can't do that.

So that would be-

Now, I'm gonna ask

The answer is yes.

00:23:44.310 --> 00:23:50.740
I can subtract 64 from 119, and if I mark

00:23:50.740 --> 00:23:51.610

00:23:51.610 --> 00:23:52.436

444

Okay, so I've got a remainder of 55,
and I'm gonna take that and move it

00:23:56.503 --> 00:24:00.790
to the next bit position within this

446
00:24:00.790 --> 00:24:06.013
So now I got 55 The question is can

00:24:06.013 --> 00:24:08.300
And the answer is true, right?

00:24:08.300 --> 00:24:10.354
So because it's true

00:24:10.354 --> 00:24:15.288
And if I subtract 55 from 32,

00:24:15.288 --> 00:24:15.946

Answer is yes, right,

Thank you for the help Zach,

455
00:24:27.318 --> 00:24:31.270
That's gonna become a binary 1, all right?

And what that does is hopefully

457
00:24:35.036 --> 00:24:36.558
>> Yeah.
>> All right, very good, and

458
00:24:36.558 --> 00:24:38.306
we're gonna move into [CROSSTALK]

00:24:38.306 --> 00:24:38.819
just for the heck of it.

00:24:41.310 --> 00:24:45.393
So now that I've got 7 left,
can I take 7 and

00:24:50.559 --> 00:24:52.173

That becomes a binary 0, and
we just take that remainder,

467
00:24:58.400 --> 00:25:00.600
Now I've got 7 left, right?

468
00:25:00.600 --> 00:25:03.797
Can I subtract 4 from my remainder of 7?

00:25:03.797 --> 00:25:06.020
And the answer is yes I can, right?

470
00:25:06.020 --> 00:25:09.210
So that becomes a binary 1 in

471
00:25:09.210 --> 00:25:13.490
We move our remainder of 3

472
00:25:13.490 --> 00:25:15.170
Now, can I ask the same question?

00:25:15.170 --> 00:25:18.190
Can I take my remainder of 3 and

474
00:25:18.190 --> 00:25:19.170
The answer is yes, right?

475
00:25:19.170 --> 00:25:20.762
It's true, so that becomes a binary 1.

476
00:25:20.762 --> 00:25:24.690
That leaves me with a remainder so

477
00:25:24.690 --> 00:25:25.950
Remember, I said no remainders.

478
00:25:25.950 --> 00:25:30.139
Well, thank goodness, I have a remainder
of 1, 1 place value left that's 1, so

00:25:30.139 --> 00:25:31.465
I can subtract 1 from 1.

480
00:25:31.465 --> 00:25:33.340
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right, that becomes a binary 1.

481
00:25:33.340 --> 00:25:35.160
And I have no remainders.

482
00:25:35.160 --> 00:25:39.595
Now, all I do is take this 8-bit
value out of this chart and

00:25:39.595 --> 00:25:42.627
I can write it down right next to 119.

484
00:25:42.627 --> 00:25:49.670
And we now have the binary representation

485
00:25:49.670 --> 00:25:50.646
So we're on our way.
We're almost there.

486
00:25:50.646 --> 00:25:53.090
I know we're running

Let's go ahead and do two more
examples here and we'll go ahead and

00:26:00.580 --> 00:26:02.061
Or long, I guess you would say.

490
00:26:02.061 --> 00:26:02.561
[LAUGH] All right?
>> [LAUGH]

491
00:26:02.561 --> 00:26:04.919
>> So next one is 38, all right?

492
00:26:04.919 --> 00:26:05.730
Now this one's kinda

We're gonna have a bunch

Well, at least a couple of them, right?

00:26:16.040 --> 00:26:17.984

00:26:17.984 --> 00:26:18.975

00:26:21.590 --> 00:26:22.226
I can't take 64, right?

503
00:26:22.226 --> 00:26:24.910
>> So that's gonna become 0.

But once I get to the 32-bit,

00:26:28.884 --> 00:26:31.203
I can take 38 and I can subtract 32.

00:26:31.203 --> 00:26:33.482

00:26:33.482 --> 00:26:40.953
All right, now, if I'm subtracting 32

00:26:40.953 --> 00:26:42.180

I can't take 6 and

00:26:52.460 --> 00:26:56.610
I can't take 6 and subtract 8 from it.

00:26:56.610 --> 00:26:58.172
No negative values, right?

But once I get to 4, I can take the 6.

00:27:00.331 --> 00:27:00.915

00:27:01.752 --> 00:27:05.855
I can take the 6, and I can subtract 4

00:27:05.855 --> 00:27:08.130

And what do we have?

We have 4 from 6 is gonna leave me with 2.

Well guess what,

00:27:16.270 --> 00:27:18.140
So I can subtract 2 from 2, right?

And that gives me a binary

So anywhere in this list

I could just whatever place

From decimal to binary,

We still got 8 more to go and then we've

So let's do this one last time and

So you guys can really,

All right, so we got 100, right, last 100.

00:28:02.116 --> 00:28:02.830

head of the game there, but I can take 64.

I can take 100 and

00:28:13.043 --> 00:28:14.162

now I've got a position right here

So 36, and I take and

00:28:19.717 --> 00:28:20.539

00:28:20.539 --> 00:28:23.360

And that leaves me with the,

We had 36 from 32,

00:28:29.547 --> 00:28:31.600

[LAUGH]

That's false because I only have 4 left,

00:28:40.746 --> 00:28:43.517
I cannot take 4 and
thensubtract 8 from it.

00:28:43.517 --> 00:28:44.950
>> No.
>> That becomes a 0.

559

But in that place value where 4 is,

00:28:48.835 --> 00:28:52.850
So in that bit position that becomes a 1,

561
00:28:52.850 --> 00:28:58.900
So any remaining place values also become
0s and Zach, that is our last octet.

00:28:58.900 --> 00:29:01.090
And why they call them octets, by the way?

00:29:01.090 --> 00:29:04.030
Because there's 8 bits that
actually make up the binary

00:29:06.730 --> 00:29:08.410

address from left to right.

I enjoy all the episodes inside

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They continue their look at subnet masks and decimal to binary conversion. They explain subnet masks.

So Ronnie and I, we were talking

he is gonna jump in here and he'll have

Because as you all have seen

No, just kidding, it's just like my

So let's go ahead and

If you remember in the first part,

We had 208.119.38.100, and we gave you

Remember, we talked about

We're used to that base ten numbering

And that's what we are used

48
00:02:29.440 --> 00:02:30.470
Remember the place values.

49
00:02:30.470 --> 00:02:32.440
I said if there's one thing
that you can memorize,

50
00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:36.690
if you can remember these 8 bits by their

51

good inside of networking when it

52
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:42.810
So we're gonna go ahead and we are gonna

00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:45.410

And let's go ahead and let's work octet

55
00:02:50.040 --> 00:02:52.320
All right, so we're gonna go ahead and

56

Ronnie, if you can help me out here,

because I always have to have

58
00:02:57.270 --> 00:03:00.060
We're gonna start, remember,
that like we said,

if I can use a place value with the number

that would be a true statement,

61
00:03:07.610 --> 00:03:11.370
If I can't use it, it becomes, remember

62
00:03:11.370 --> 00:03:15.830
That becomes a binary 0 and we take that
number, or the remainder and we work our

63

way through each bit position until we get

64
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:23.094
We don't have any remainders in this

So we're gonna start from our left to

I'm looking at the 16 place value.

291
00:15:12.699 --> 00:15:15.308
I can subtract 16 from 31, right?

292
00:15:15.308 --> 00:15:18.314
So we're gonna go ahead,
we'll put a binary 1 there, and

293
00:15:18.314 --> 00:15:19.890
we'll move to the next octet.

294
00:15:19.890 --> 00:15:24.850
Now, if I take 31 and I subtract 16,
I should have a remainder of 15, right?

295
00:15:24.850 --> 00:15:29.140
And we're gonna do that, so we move to
the next place value and guess what?

296
00:15:29.140 --> 00:15:33.922
I can subtract 8 from 15, so
that means that is a binary 1 as well.

297
00:15:33.922 --> 00:15:38.400
We take our remainder of 7 and
we move to the next place value, right?

298
00:15:38.400 --> 00:15:41.210
And I could subtract 4 from 7,
so that becomes a binary 1.

299
00:15:41.210 --> 00:15:44.080
You're gonna start to see
that pattern again, right?

300
00:15:44.080 --> 00:15:47.074
And if I subtract 4 from 7,
that gives me 3 left.

301
00:15:47.074 --> 00:15:47.697
Well guess what?

302
00:15:47.697 --> 00:15:52.570
I can subtract 2 from 3, so
that also becomes a binary 1.

303
00:15:52.570 --> 00:15:53.978
Leaves me with 1 left, right?

304
00:15:53.978 --> 00:15:56.870
That's my remainder, and look,
I can subtract 1 from 1.

305
00:15:56.870 --> 00:15:59.245
Now I want you to notice something here.

306
00:15:59.245 --> 00:16:04.578
255 is the largest number you can
get in an 8 bit octet, all right?

307
00:16:04.578 --> 00:16:10.218
Notice also, that every one of
these place values has a 1 in it.

308
00:16:10.218 --> 00:16:12.080
Now notice the 0s here?

309
00:16:12.080 --> 00:16:15.660
0s are very easy,
those aren't too complicated, right?

310
00:16:15.660 --> 00:16:19.486
Yeah, that just means every place
value is gonna be a 0, right?

311
00:16:19.486 --> 00:16:23.210
And I could probably fill
these out a little bit easier.

312
00:16:23.210 --> 00:16:25.410
But we'll go ahead and
do it just cell by cell here.

313
00:16:25.410 --> 00:16:29.940
Now, the question is, if I were to lay
these all out, 32 bits left to right,

314
00:16:29.940 --> 00:16:32.350
do we have contiguous 1 bits, right?

315
00:16:32.350 --> 00:16:37.209
Do I have any 0s in between,
a break in the 1s, a 0 and then another 1?

316
00:16:37.209 --> 00:16:38.775
And the answer is no.

317
00:16:38.775 --> 00:16:42.185
And that's something to
understand about a subnet mask.

318
00:16:42.185 --> 00:16:49.141
A subnet mask must be contiguous 1s, there
cannot be any 0s in between these 1s.

319
00:16:49.141 --> 00:16:53.400
And we're gonna come back and we're gonna
see how that applies to our IP address,

320
00:16:53.400 --> 00:16:56.310
and why that's so
important here in a second.

321
00:16:56.310 --> 00:17:01.627
Now, if we just do the same thing here,
you're gonna notice that 255.255.0.0.

322
00:17:01.627 --> 00:17:03.500
Well, let's just go ahead and
we'll make it easy.

323
00:17:03.500 --> 00:17:08.120
We'll just fill these in cuz we
already know that they are 1s, right?

324
00:17:08.120 --> 00:17:13.100
And I know that those last two octets are
all 0s, and the question would be, well,

325
00:17:13.100 --> 00:17:16.300
do I have contiguous 1 bits here, right?

326
00:17:16.300 --> 00:17:19.546
Do I have, if I were to lay
this out all 32 bits wide,

327
00:17:19.546 --> 00:17:24.100
do I have 1s that are contiguous and
the 1s stop and the 0s begin?

328
00:17:24.100 --> 00:17:25.900
The answer is correct, right?

329
00:17:25.900 --> 00:17:30.950
I have two contiguous blocks,
or octets of 1s.

330
00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:34.552
Same thing goes here,
if you will for the last set, right?

331
00:17:34.552 --> 00:17:35.489
We can do the same thing here.

332
00:17:35.489 --> 00:17:41.600
And if you will notice we
have now 255.255.255.0.

333
00:17:41.600 --> 00:17:47.114
Notice that we now have contiguous
1 bits in the first three octets.

334
00:17:47.114 --> 00:17:51.520
And the last octet of course being 0,
all 0s, right?

335
00:17:51.520 --> 00:17:52.940
Now that is important, right?

336
00:17:52.940 --> 00:17:57.450
Because I want you to remember what
a subnet mask looks like in the binary cuz

337
00:17:57.450 --> 00:18:01.140
we're gonna come back to that and
we're gonna define why that's important.

338
00:18:01.140 --> 00:18:02.740
For now, at this point,

339
00:18:02.740 --> 00:18:07.660
all I want you to remember is that
a subnet mask has to be contiguous 1 bits.

340
00:18:07.660 --> 00:18:10.776
You have to have 1s, no 0s in between and

341
00:18:10.776 --> 00:18:16.860
at some point within these four octets,
the 1s will stop and the 0s will begin.

342
00:18:16.860 --> 00:18:23.340
All right, now,
let's go ahead now and go farther.

343
00:18:23.340 --> 00:18:28.450
Now that we've seen the majority
of our decimal to binary.

344
00:18:28.450 --> 00:18:32.480
Let me go ahead and tell you how you would
reverse this if you needed to, all right?

345
00:18:32.480 --> 00:18:35.170
Let's go back real quick
if we could to the diagram.

346
00:18:35.170 --> 00:18:41.910
If you ever have an 8-bit
binary number on the exam, and

347
00:18:41.910 --> 00:18:47.630
your answers are the decimal values, these
8 bits of binary, what is that in decimal?

348
00:18:47.630 --> 00:18:52.440
If you can remember these place values
that I'm kind of harping on here,

349
00:18:52.440 --> 00:18:53.580
you can remember them.

350
00:18:53.580 --> 00:18:58.740
All you got to do is make this chart,
put those binary numbers in this chart and

351
00:18:58.740 --> 00:19:00.280
add up all the 1s.

352
00:19:00.280 --> 00:19:04.820
And what I mean by that is take every
place value that you see has a 1 in it and

353
00:19:04.820 --> 00:19:07.460
add it up and
you will get your answer, right?

354
00:19:07.460 --> 00:19:14.990
If I look at, if I add let's see,
16 and 64, I get 80, right?

355
00:19:14.990 --> 00:19:16.933
Excuse me, let me try that again.

356
00:19:16.933 --> 00:19:19.920
16 and 64, yeah, I get 80.

357
00:19:19.920 --> 00:19:23.750
And then from 80 to 128, I get 208, right?

358
00:19:23.750 --> 00:19:26.310
So it's easy to do the conversion from

359
00:19:26.310 --> 00:19:32.000
binary to decimal once you know
these place values, all right?

360
00:19:32.000 --> 00:19:34.590
So, I wanted to not skip over that.

361
00:19:34.590 --> 00:19:38.010
Make sure that we do show
you that just in case.

362
00:19:38.010 --> 00:19:39.954
Now let's kind of look at an IP address.

363
00:19:39.954 --> 00:19:43.790
Now we've talked about these IP addresses,
we wanted you to kind of understand that

364
00:19:43.790 --> 00:19:48.540
it's a 32-bit identifier and it uniquely
identifies a node within a network.

365
00:19:48.540 --> 00:19:53.610
But we're gonna give you an analogy that
maybe you're familiar with already, right?

366
00:19:53.610 --> 00:19:56.905
Because if it's the first
time you've seen networking,

367
00:19:56.905 --> 00:19:58.932
maybe this is just all fresh to you.

368
00:19:58.932 --> 00:20:02.910
And you're like, what do you mean
that it's a unique identifier.

369
00:20:02.910 --> 00:20:06.290
Let's compare that back to something else.

370
00:20:06.290 --> 00:20:09.460
So, I want you to think about mail, right?

371
00:20:09.460 --> 00:20:11.210
When your mail is delivered.

372
00:20:11.210 --> 00:20:13.910
All right, you have a street address.

373
00:20:13.910 --> 00:20:17.094
Street addresses, and I'm not talking
about the whole entire thing with

374
00:20:17.094 --> 00:20:20.495
ZIP code and all, I'm just talking
about the street address itself, right?

375
00:20:20.495 --> 00:20:22.253
Not the whole mailing address.

376
00:20:22.253 --> 00:20:25.020
But what is a street address comprised of?

377
00:20:25.020 --> 00:20:26.990
Well, it's comprised of what?

378
00:20:26.990 --> 00:20:31.933
A house number and it's comprised of a
street number or street name, if you will,

379
00:20:31.933 --> 00:20:32.446
right?

380
00:20:32.446 --> 00:20:35.961
It doesn't necessarily have to be
a number, it could be a name, all right?

381
00:20:35.961 --> 00:20:40.021
And when a mail truck needs to
deliver to your address, well,

382
00:20:40.021 --> 00:20:42.390
what do they first have to know?

383
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:43.940
They first have to know
what street your on.

384
00:20:43.940 --> 00:20:45.260
So they gotta locate the street.

385
00:20:45.260 --> 00:20:48.650
And then once they locate the street,
now they have to differentiate your house.

386
00:20:48.650 --> 00:20:51.650
Let's say if Ronnie's my neighbor,
from Ronnie's house, right?

387
00:20:51.650 --> 00:20:53.940
So, what does that street
address have to have?

388
00:20:55.050 --> 00:20:57.040
Well, it's got to have a street name.

389
00:20:57.040 --> 00:21:01.560
But on that street, it has to
have a unique identifier as well.

390
00:21:01.560 --> 00:21:04.265
It has to have a unique house number.

391
00:21:04.265 --> 00:21:06.730
And that's how we differentiate,

392
00:21:06.730 --> 00:21:10.240
first of all, houses that are on
that are on the same street.

393
00:21:10.240 --> 00:21:12.410
And then the uniqueness of
the house within that street.

394
00:21:12.410 --> 00:21:14.550
Now, don't throw duplexes or
triplexes at me.

395
00:21:14.550 --> 00:21:15.330
We're not going there.

396
00:21:15.330 --> 00:21:18.120
We're just talking about
individual houses.

397
00:21:18.120 --> 00:21:24.099
Now, how would that analogy, how can
we bring that over to our networking?

398
00:21:24.099 --> 00:21:27.530
All right, well, I want you to
think of a network, all right?

399
00:21:27.530 --> 00:21:32.200
And I want you to think of your IP
addresses as street names, all right?

400
00:21:32.200 --> 00:21:37.090
If I look,
I know that a computer is going to

401
00:21:37.090 --> 00:21:41.900
have to have a unique network identifier,
right?

402
00:21:41.900 --> 00:21:45.580
If two computers are going to be
considered to be on the same network.

403
00:21:45.580 --> 00:21:50.310
Then like the houses that have to have
unique identifiers and I need to identify

404
00:21:50.310 --> 00:21:55.170
them on the same street, they have
to have the same street name, right?

405
00:21:55.170 --> 00:21:56.660
And that's gonna be important.

406
00:21:56.660 --> 00:22:01.260
So I want you to think of the two
components within an IP address or

407
00:22:01.260 --> 00:22:05.120
what's known as a network ID and
a node ID.

408
00:22:05.120 --> 00:22:08.050
And I want you to think of your
network ID as kind of like

409
00:22:08.050 --> 00:22:09.960
being your street name, all right?

410
00:22:09.960 --> 00:22:16.455
If two computers are gonna be considered
to be on the same network like our houses,

411
00:22:16.455 --> 00:22:22.401
they have to share the same network
identifier, all right, street name.

412
00:22:22.401 --> 00:22:29.909
But how do we uniquely identify two of
these computers within that same network?

413
00:22:29.909 --> 00:22:32.420
Well, let's go back to our house numbers,
right?

414
00:22:32.420 --> 00:22:36.840
Just like a house, sets of houses have
to have unique house numbers to be

415
00:22:36.840 --> 00:22:39.390
differentiated on the same street.

416
00:22:39.390 --> 00:22:41.570
Your nodes, in this case, computers,

417
00:22:41.570 --> 00:22:44.610
but understand that many
things can have IP addresses.

418
00:22:44.610 --> 00:22:50.070
This host or node on this network must
have a unique identifier as well.

419
00:22:50.070 --> 00:22:54.290
So, like our house identifiers,
that's what's known as a node ID.

420
00:22:54.290 --> 00:22:59.730
So when IP address is comprised of
two different things, all right?

421
00:22:59.730 --> 00:23:05.940
It's comprised of a network identifier,
network ID and a host ID, all right?

422
00:23:05.940 --> 00:23:11.070
So how do we get to this point, right?

423
00:23:11.070 --> 00:23:13.980
Well, we do that by a couple of things,

424
00:23:13.980 --> 00:23:16.460
couple of rules you need to be aware of,
all right?

425
00:23:16.460 --> 00:23:21.900
In order for two computers to be
consider on the same network, all right?

426
00:23:21.900 --> 00:23:28.440
They have to have the same network ID and
they also have to be uniquely identified.

427
00:23:28.440 --> 00:23:30.840
Let me make sure that I put that
they have to be uniquely identified.

428
00:23:30.840 --> 00:23:32.640
They can't have the same house number.

429
00:23:32.640 --> 00:23:34.890
They can't have the same node identifier,
right?

430
00:23:34.890 --> 00:23:38.580
So, let's say for instance, I'm a
maliciously, Ronny and I are neighbors and

431
00:23:38.580 --> 00:23:42.680
I maliciously go out to his mailbox and
I peel off the stickers on his mailbox.

432
00:23:42.680 --> 00:23:44.912
I wouldn't do that,
I don't wanna go to jail.

433
00:23:44.912 --> 00:23:47.920
[LAUGH] And
I put the same address as my house.

434
00:23:47.920 --> 00:23:49.850
Well, I want you to go back and
think about it.

435
00:23:49.850 --> 00:23:55.000
What would happen if somebody was trying
to deliver mail to our street and

436
00:23:55.000 --> 00:23:58.710
they delivered mail to me, and
then they come to the next mailbox and

437
00:23:58.710 --> 00:24:00.380
it's got the same house number?

438
00:24:00.380 --> 00:24:02.354
Well, your mail carrier is gonna
get a little confused, right?

439
00:24:02.354 --> 00:24:03.940
We're gonna have a conflict.

440
00:24:03.940 --> 00:24:05.980
Well, you have to understand
that in networks,

441
00:24:05.980 --> 00:24:08.840
your nodes have to have those
unique identifiers as well.

442
00:24:08.840 --> 00:24:14.405
They cannot have the same node ID, or
host ID, as it's called, all right?

443
00:24:14.405 --> 00:24:17.340
They, in order to be considered
on the same network,

444
00:24:17.340 --> 00:24:19.420
there's another thing
that they have to have.

445
00:24:19.420 --> 00:24:22.258
They both must share
the same subnet mask and

446
00:24:22.258 --> 00:24:26.100
that's where the subnet mask
comes into play, all right?

447
00:24:26.100 --> 00:24:28.570
The subnet mask, we're gonna get into,

448
00:24:28.570 --> 00:24:31.910
it looks like we're running a little
bit short on time on this episode.

449
00:24:31.910 --> 00:24:35.310
But when we come back on a part three,
we're gonna tell you

450
00:24:35.310 --> 00:24:39.280
exactly how to apply that subnet mask so
you can identify what network you're on.

451
00:24:40.410 --> 00:24:43.660
>> All right, Wes, well, thank you for
helping us to at least get started with

452
00:24:43.660 --> 00:24:46.680
the idea of binary and
decimal conversions.

453
00:24:46.680 --> 00:24:49.590
It is a skill that we have to
get ready for as we prepare for

454
00:24:49.590 --> 00:24:52.830
the Network+ exam and
you do need to practice this so

455
00:24:52.830 --> 00:24:55.710
that you get quicker at it for
the exam as well.

456
00:24:55.710 --> 00:25:00.050
And then of course we broke into the
concept of what an IP address actually is

457
00:25:00.050 --> 00:25:03.360
and where it actually does
break those 32 bits apart.

458
00:25:03.360 --> 00:25:05.531
And a portion of it is gonna
be your network ID, and

459
00:25:05.531 --> 00:25:07.257
a portion of it is gonna be your node ID.

460
00:25:07.257 --> 00:25:10.858
And we still need to see how that's gonna
be accomplished inside of the computer

461
00:25:10.858 --> 00:25:14.710
world as well, and that will be coming
up on part three that Wes mentioned.

462
00:25:14.710 --> 00:25:17.470
But this is a great place for
us to sign-off then.

463
00:25:17.470 --> 00:25:21.670
So for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

464
00:25:21.670 --> 00:25:22.620
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

465
00:25:22.620 --> 00:25:29.445
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the CompTIA Network+ shows.

466
00:25:29.445 --> 00:25:32.966
[MUSIC]

467
00:25:32.966 --> 00:25:35.654
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They explain in more detail how subnet masks apply to ip addresses, as well as how to identify the network versus node portions of an IP address.
episodes.title: IP Addressing Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They look at topics like classful vs. classless addressing, subnet masks, subnetting and IP address assignments.

that's right.

00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:42.597
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We got

17

a few things that we gotta

18
00:00:44.622 --> 00:00:49.356
Over the last three episodes the trilogy

19
00:00:49.356 --> 00:00:52.823
the DNA, the characteristics
properties of an IP address and

20
00:00:52.823 --> 00:00:55.856
kinda broke down that

21
00:00:55.856 --> 00:01:00.059
And we kinda shown you how a subnet masks

addresses so that you could divide net

you might actually even have

26
00:01:12.608 --> 00:01:16.576
So, if you're not familiar with those,

28

And who knows, it might be part
4,000 by the time we're done.

29
00:01:21.237 --> 00:01:23.685

30
00:01:23.685 --> 00:01:27.793
I was talking with Ronnie before
we started this part four here,

31
00:01:27.793 --> 00:01:31.916
and one of the things that I didn't
mention in the last episode.

32
00:01:31.916 --> 00:01:36.440
I didn't mention the host identifier,
right, we owe the node portion, right.

33
00:01:36.440 --> 00:01:39.370
We showed you how to find the network ID,
but

34
00:01:39.370 --> 00:01:42.390
remember that's only half
of your IP address, right.

35
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:45.639
One part of the IP address uniquely
identifies the network that these

36
00:01:45.639 --> 00:01:46.543
computers are on.

37
00:01:46.543 --> 00:01:50.065
And the other portion uniquely
identifies the node itself, right?

38
00:01:50.065 --> 00:01:52.830
The house number back to our analogy.

39
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:55.255
So let me just go ahead and
just double back real quick so

40
00:01:55.255 --> 00:01:57.121
we don't leave any stone unturned here.

41
00:01:57.121 --> 00:02:02.467
And if we can look here, you'll see that

484
00:29:25.263 --> 00:29:26.627
when it comes to Network+ exam.

485
00:29:26.627 --> 00:29:30.864
But it also is basic skills, fundamental
skills that you'll need as you advance

486
00:29:30.864 --> 00:29:33.120
forward towards your networking career.

487
00:29:33.120 --> 00:29:36.353
Without these fundamental skills,
you will be lost.

488
00:29:36.353 --> 00:29:40.582
So make sure you pay attention to the idea
of the IP addresses themselves, and

489
00:29:40.582 --> 00:29:44.049
these ranges, and where they're used and
how they're used.

490
00:29:44.049 --> 00:29:46.905
Because it's gonna be essential
as you continue to move forward.

491
00:29:46.905 --> 00:29:49.765
But this is a great place for
us to end this episode then.

492
00:29:49.765 --> 00:29:53.863
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

493
00:29:53.863 --> 00:29:54.943
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

494
00:29:54.943 --> 00:29:59.107
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the CompTIA Network+ Show.

495
00:29:59.107 --> 00:30:05.129
[MUSIC]

496
00:30:05.129 --> 00:30:08.643
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They look at classless subnet masks and the valid subnet mask ranges as well as some tips for the exam.
episodes.title: Classless IPv4 Addressing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.138 --> 00:00:02.762
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.762 --> 00:00:07.351
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.351 --> 00:00:08.570
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.570 --> 00:00:11.915
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.915 --> 00:00:14.075
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.075 --> 00:00:16.658
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.658 --> 00:00:21.559
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with CompTIA NET+ and

8
00:00:21.559 --> 00:00:24.490
this is Classless IPv4 Addressing.

9
00:00:24.490 --> 00:00:25.770
Mm, interesting?

10
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:27.880
And Wes Bryant is here to
tell us all about that.

11
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:28.700
Wes, good to see you sir.

12
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:30.137
>> Hey Zach, thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:30.137 --> 00:00:33.802
That's right, we have been moving
through things like IP Addressing and

14
00:00:33.802 --> 00:00:37.600
IP structure and we've really been
talking about IP before the whole time.

15
00:00:37.600 --> 00:00:41.200
But now we're gonna get into
kinda breaking the rules, right?

16
00:00:41.200 --> 00:00:42.075
In other episodes,

17
00:00:42.075 --> 00:00:44.965
we talked about the classes,
we kinda identified those classes.

18
00:00:44.965 --> 00:00:49.646
And in this episode, we're gonna look
at some of the concepts behind how

19
00:00:49.646 --> 00:00:53.882
we kind of break the rules and
we go with classless IP addressing.

20
00:00:53.882 --> 00:00:55.535
All coming up here in this episode.

21
00:00:55.535 --> 00:00:59.895
>> So Wes, why would we need
classless IPv4 addressing?

22
00:00:59.895 --> 00:01:03.745
>> Well they came up with a classful
system at a time that basically

23
00:01:03.745 --> 00:01:07.565
the Internet or back in the days of
the ARPANET when it first started out.

24
00:01:07.565 --> 00:01:12.283
They came up with a classful system, and
it had a set of clearly defined walls,

25
00:01:12.283 --> 00:01:13.690
if you will.

26
00:01:13.690 --> 00:01:17.923
The problem is with the classiful system,
the system was very wasteful.

27
00:01:17.923 --> 00:01:22.156
And it's just because they really didn't
know at the time that they came up with

28
00:01:22.156 --> 00:01:22.920
that system.

29
00:01:22.920 --> 00:01:27.745
That there was gonna be an exponential
growth of devices, nodes if you will,

30
00:01:27.745 --> 00:01:33.170
computers that wouldl be out there, on
this thing that would eventually become.

31
00:01:33.170 --> 00:01:35.738
The Internet,
we go through the dot com boom.

32
00:01:35.738 --> 00:01:40.800
What they noticed is that we were
having with that exponential increase.

33
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:45.637
We were also having an exponential
depletion of the available addresses

34
00:01:45.637 --> 00:01:48.266
that we had within this 32 bit space.

35
00:01:48.266 --> 00:01:49.678
>> That's exactly right.

36
00:01:49.678 --> 00:01:54.647
Back in the day, the old days,
we used to think that an IP address

37
00:01:54.647 --> 00:01:58.530
was assigned to a house,
a unit or an enterprise.

38
00:01:58.530 --> 00:02:00.780
But not the case, it's per unit.

39
00:02:00.780 --> 00:02:04.180
>> It usually is,
it's per host, any host, right?

40
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:08.357
Any node that wants to actually
communicate across the Internet

41
00:02:08.357 --> 00:02:11.928
in those days would have to
have an IP address, right?

42
00:02:11.928 --> 00:02:13.912
Well, as they started to see that, hey,

43
00:02:13.912 --> 00:02:17.020
we were going to eventually run
out of the available addresses.

44
00:02:17.020 --> 00:02:21.420
They said hey we've got to put some stop
gaps in place to kinda stall, if you will,

45
00:02:21.420 --> 00:02:24.190
not to really eliminate it because
it was still gonna happen.

46
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:26.270
But can we put some kind
of governor on it, right?

47
00:02:26.270 --> 00:02:28.852
Can we push the clutch in and
kinda ghost for

48
00:02:28.852 --> 00:02:33.095
a while if you will and try to stall
the inevitable depletion, right?

49
00:02:33.095 --> 00:02:38.470
In other episodes, we told you
a little bit about that RFC 1918.

50
00:02:38.470 --> 00:02:43.402
Which is the Internet engineering
task forces request for comments for

51
00:02:43.402 --> 00:02:46.950
implementing private IP address ranges,
right?

52
00:02:46.950 --> 00:02:50.650
Private IP address ranges were set
aside because they said, you know what?

53
00:02:50.650 --> 00:02:52.026
This is gonna help a lot of people.

54
00:02:52.026 --> 00:02:53.610
If you don't need to connect
out to the Internet,

55
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:57.930
then what we'll do is we'll
reserve in each of those classes.

56
00:02:57.930 --> 00:02:59.395
In fact let me kinda show you here.

57
00:02:59.395 --> 00:03:02.401
If you remember our classes that we
were talking about in other episodes and

58
00:03:02.401 --> 00:03:04.130
if not, go back and watch those episodes.

59
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:06.603
>> Yeah, we do.
>> Remember we have our classes and

60
00:03:06.603 --> 00:03:12.167
then there's you know, there's only so
many addresses within class A, B, and C.

61
00:03:12.167 --> 00:03:15.357
And then they put the private range
in there, and they said okay,

62
00:03:15.357 --> 00:03:19.132
we're gonna make the private range here,
and we're gonna set these aside.

63
00:03:19.132 --> 00:03:23.213
And they don't have to be unique across
the Internet, but there is a stipulation,

64
00:03:23.213 --> 00:03:26.090
you can't route traffic across
the Internet with these.

65
00:03:26.090 --> 00:03:30.059
But you can use these internally, on your
own networks, behind your routers, and

66
00:03:30.059 --> 00:03:31.829
not communicate with the Internet.

67
00:03:31.829 --> 00:03:34.609
Now, they also put into play,
some technologies,

68
00:03:34.609 --> 00:03:37.016
like network address translation, right.

69
00:03:37.016 --> 00:03:39.998
And that allows us to take an internal,
private IP address, and

70
00:03:39.998 --> 00:03:41.820
kinda do some packet mangling.

71
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:45.380
And replace a single public IP address

72
00:03:45.380 --> 00:03:47.950
still using multiple internal
private IP addresses.

73
00:03:47.950 --> 00:03:53.160
So that also helped to kinda stall
the depletion of that classical system.

74
00:03:53.160 --> 00:03:57.320
Well, they kind of figured out, that we
got to go a little bit farther than that,

75
00:03:57.320 --> 00:03:59.605
we can't just reserve a private range.

76
00:03:59.605 --> 00:04:03.300
We've got to make it to
where there's less waste.

77
00:04:03.300 --> 00:04:04.617
And let me show you what I mean here.

78
00:04:04.617 --> 00:04:08.826
Now, if we go back to the classful system,
let's say that this is all that we had,

79
00:04:08.826 --> 00:04:10.351
was the classful system, and

80
00:04:10.351 --> 00:04:13.480
let's say that you got a network
within this range, right?

81
00:04:13.480 --> 00:04:16.940
And let's go ahead, and I tell you what,
I'll just kind of bump this

82
00:04:16.940 --> 00:04:20.860
font up here a little bit and
make this a little bit bolder.

83
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:26.400
And let's say, I don't know,
you've got the 3.0.0.0 network, right?

84
00:04:26.400 --> 00:04:29.383
Well you would have this
subnet mask right away, right?

85
00:04:29.383 --> 00:04:33.724
255.0.0.0 and remember in other
episodes we said that those

86
00:04:33.724 --> 00:04:38.591
255s represent one bits in the binary and
above that's where your IP sits.

87
00:04:38.591 --> 00:04:42.139
That means that that block or
that octet is a part of the network range.

88
00:04:42.139 --> 00:04:44.835
Well, you can see that with a default or

89
00:04:44.835 --> 00:04:50.233
classical subnet mask of 255.0.0.0
applied to this IP address means

90
00:04:50.233 --> 00:04:56.170
that we're gonna have three octets that
are reserved all for our nodes, right?

91
00:04:56.170 --> 00:05:00.675
Well three octets is 24 bits, and
if you do two to the power of 24,

92
00:05:00.675 --> 00:05:04.498
you come up with just under
17 million potential nodes.

93
00:05:04.498 --> 00:05:05.404
>> Well that's a few.

94
00:05:05.404 --> 00:05:06.418
>> That's right, right?

95
00:05:06.418 --> 00:05:10.027
Well here's the thing,
what if you only needed 10 million, right?

96
00:05:10.027 --> 00:05:13.280
Well, you couldn't get one
of these Class B ranges,

97
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:16.590
right, cuz the Class B
range reserves two octets.

98
00:05:16.590 --> 00:05:18.780
Remember the 0s are our node bits.

99
00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:20.940
Reserves two octets for the host,

100
00:05:20.940 --> 00:05:25.890
which means it's 65,534 hosts
you can get on a network, right?

101
00:05:25.890 --> 00:05:28.974
So if I needed 10 million,
I would have to go into that A range and

102
00:05:28.974 --> 00:05:31.679
I would have to lease from
an Internet service provider.

103
00:05:31.679 --> 00:05:33.729
I'd have to get one of
those class A ranges.

104
00:05:33.729 --> 00:05:39.706
But the problem is, what happens to
the other 6,777,214 nodes or addresses?

105
00:05:39.706 --> 00:05:43.723
Well, you can't lease
those out to anybody else.

106
00:05:43.723 --> 00:05:46.522
So if you were a company
that was big enough and

107
00:05:46.522 --> 00:05:49.181
happened to need 10 million addresses.

108
00:05:49.181 --> 00:05:52.900
We just wasted 6 million because we
can't just release these over to anybody

109
00:05:52.900 --> 00:05:53.650
else, right?

110
00:05:53.650 --> 00:05:54.835
So that was a problem.

111
00:05:54.835 --> 00:06:01.487
Or what if you are a company that
may be needed 3,000 addresses?

112
00:06:01.487 --> 00:06:04.150
All right, well you had a couple
of things you could do.

113
00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:06.766
You could get one Class B network,
right and

114
00:06:06.766 --> 00:06:10.522
that would give you the potential
to have 65,533 nodes.

115
00:06:10.522 --> 00:06:14.162
But the problem is that
you only needed 3,000.

116
00:06:14.162 --> 00:06:17.577
What do you do with
the other 62,000 addresses?

117
00:06:17.577 --> 00:06:18.823
>> Give to my Aunt Gert.

118
00:06:18.823 --> 00:06:20.930
>> You can't give them,
you can't gift them, right.

119
00:06:20.930 --> 00:06:23.362
It's not like the fruit cake,
you can't regift it, right?

120
00:06:23.362 --> 00:06:25.633
And I know you like fruit cakes,
so I'm picking on Zach, right?

121
00:06:25.633 --> 00:06:26.774
>> I like them, I'm sorry.

122
00:06:26.774 --> 00:06:28.484
>> You can't regift it, right?

123
00:06:28.484 --> 00:06:31.191
So those just become unused addresses.

124
00:06:31.191 --> 00:06:33.762
So what they were noticing is
with this classful system,

125
00:06:33.762 --> 00:06:36.454
well what would you do if
you needed 3,000 addresses?

126
00:06:36.454 --> 00:06:41.469
Well, if I did a Class B,
I'm wasting around 62,000 addresses or so.

127
00:06:41.469 --> 00:06:44.879
In a Class C,
well in order to get that 3,00,

128
00:06:44.879 --> 00:06:48.136
remember that Class C
only has a single octet.

129
00:06:48.136 --> 00:06:50.131
The 0s are reserved for
the host bits, right?

130
00:06:50.131 --> 00:06:54.595
So at 8 bits, that only gives
you 254 potential nodes, and

131
00:06:54.595 --> 00:06:58.737
we'll talk about why that number
is 4 at the end of there.

132
00:06:58.737 --> 00:07:03.648
Well, 254 nodes, if I needed 3,000,
that means I would have to get, what,

133
00:07:03.648 --> 00:07:04.956
6 of those networks?

134
00:07:04.956 --> 00:07:09.259
I'd have to have at lease 6 of those
networks to try to achieve my goal of

135
00:07:09.259 --> 00:07:13.511
having 3,000 nodes, so
that isn't necessarily a lot of waste.

136
00:07:13.511 --> 00:07:15.972
It's more wasted money-
>> Right.

137
00:07:15.972 --> 00:07:20.053
>> For the employer or for the person that
needs to lease those IP addresses from

138
00:07:20.053 --> 00:07:21.859
the Internet service provider.

139
00:07:21.859 --> 00:07:26.415
So again you had a rapid depletion of
C networks because of the fact that,

140
00:07:26.415 --> 00:07:30.090
yeah they're smaller but
you'd have to get more of them.

141
00:07:30.090 --> 00:07:32.026
So there really was no in between.

142
00:07:32.026 --> 00:07:35.521
So the classful system again,
it implemented a lot of waste, right, or

143
00:07:35.521 --> 00:07:38.408
it brought about a lot of waste
because of those addresses.

144
00:07:38.408 --> 00:07:41.986
They said well what if, right,
what if we break the rules?

145
00:07:41.986 --> 00:07:43.607
What if we say you know what?

146
00:07:43.607 --> 00:07:47.393
We're gonna come up with
a system called classless.

147
00:07:47.393 --> 00:07:53.630
And we're going to allow you to manipulate
this subnet mask any way you need it,

148
00:07:53.630 --> 00:07:58.470
in order to Create the networks
that you need with the amount of

149
00:07:58.470 --> 00:08:02.307
nodes you need,
with the least amount of waste.

150
00:08:02.307 --> 00:08:04.432
All right?
Or at least to reduced the waste.

151
00:08:04.432 --> 00:08:05.080
>> Right.

152
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:08.200
>> And that's where the classPAL system
comes up, and there are some components

153
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:11.090
within a classPAL system that
you're gonna have to be aware of.

154
00:08:11.090 --> 00:08:15.619
So when we talk about classless system, I
wanna start with a default subnet mask and

155
00:08:15.619 --> 00:08:19.891
kinda recap where we were when we were
talking about some things like decimal to

156
00:08:19.891 --> 00:08:21.071
binary conversion.

157
00:08:21.071 --> 00:08:23.804
If you remember,
we said decimal to binary conversion.

158
00:08:23.804 --> 00:08:30.065
If you're not familiar with that,
Show, definitely go back and watch it.

159
00:08:30.065 --> 00:08:33.543
Because we're just basically using
the exact same information that we we're

160
00:08:33.543 --> 00:08:34.235
using before.

161
00:08:34.235 --> 00:08:38.915
But if you remember, I told you that
the default subnet masks right,

162
00:08:38.915 --> 00:08:42.800
that would be a single octet of 255 or
1 bits, right?

163
00:08:42.800 --> 00:08:45.720
So we have the network portion of your

164
00:08:45.720 --> 00:08:48.890
address would be any octet
that's above those 1's.

165
00:08:48.890 --> 00:08:53.380
Notice that in the class B default
subnet mask we would end up having well,

166
00:08:53.380 --> 00:08:53.990
what would it be?

167
00:08:53.990 --> 00:08:59.220
It'd be two octets of 1 bits would be
reserved for our network portion, and half

168
00:08:59.220 --> 00:09:04.170
of those, the other 16 bits if you will,
would be reserved for the node portion.

169
00:09:04.170 --> 00:09:09.720
And then last but not least,
we have the class B default subnet mass,

170
00:09:09.720 --> 00:09:15.324
which would be a set of 24 1 bits,
right, on that side, right,

171
00:09:15.324 --> 00:09:21.650
255.255.255.0, with only a single
octet reserved for the node portion.

172
00:09:21.650 --> 00:09:25.901
So I want you to understand,
when we start talking about this,

173
00:09:25.901 --> 00:09:29.992
I want you to keep in mind that
however many host bits we have,

174
00:09:29.992 --> 00:09:34.565
the more host bits we increase,
the more host we have available, or

175
00:09:34.565 --> 00:09:38.039
host addresses we have
available on that network.

176
00:09:38.039 --> 00:09:43.596
Well, with these fixed links, right, these
fixed walls, there was no manipulation.

177
00:09:43.596 --> 00:09:50.176
If you had a 255.0.0.0 subnet mask on
your Class A address, that means fixed.

178
00:09:50.176 --> 00:09:53.000
You would have all of these
24 bits reserved for hosts.

179
00:09:53.000 --> 00:09:54.480
And there was no way to manipulate them.

180
00:09:54.480 --> 00:09:57.606
Again, If we only needed 10 million,
we needed 1 million.

181
00:09:57.606 --> 00:10:01.878
That would leave 15 million or more
that would be completely wasted, right,

182
00:10:01.878 --> 00:10:04.770
how would you get up to
that million any other way?

183
00:10:04.770 --> 00:10:07.950
Well it would just be economically
infeasible for the company because they'd

184
00:10:07.950 --> 00:10:12.610
have to get multiple, and I wouldn't
even begin to do the math right there,

185
00:10:12.610 --> 00:10:16.380
to adding up 65,000, 65,000,
till you get up to 1 million, right?

186
00:10:16.380 --> 00:10:17.390
That's just not feasible.

187
00:10:17.390 --> 00:10:19.341
So again, it was a lot of waste.

188
00:10:19.341 --> 00:10:22.864
So when we start talking about
the classless system, all right,

189
00:10:22.864 --> 00:10:24.090
I wanna go back again.

190
00:10:24.090 --> 00:10:25.690
I want you guys to keep in mind that,

191
00:10:25.690 --> 00:10:30.140
remember, that when we talk
about anywhere these 255's are,

192
00:10:30.140 --> 00:10:34.580
just keep that in mind that, hey, those
are part of your network bits, right?

193
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:37.834
Those are your network bits, and that's
why I'm kinda keeping the same color

194
00:10:37.834 --> 00:10:40.065
coordination that we were
going along with, right?

195
00:10:40.065 --> 00:10:43.089
So and that's gonna come into play
because that's gonna make it easier for

196
00:10:43.089 --> 00:10:46.065
some of the other things that we have
to talk about in the classPAL system or

197
00:10:46.065 --> 00:10:47.508
the classless system, excuse me.

198
00:10:47.508 --> 00:10:53.101
So notice that 255.0.0.0 is
essentially one octet of 255's right?

199
00:10:53.101 --> 00:10:57.685
And that first octet and then your last
three octets, the second, the third, and

200
00:10:57.685 --> 00:10:59.621
the fourth are all 0's, right?

201
00:10:59.621 --> 00:11:02.775
We've got 255.255.0.0,

202
00:11:02.775 --> 00:11:08.135
again that is the first octet of 1's,
the second octet of 1's.

203
00:11:08.135 --> 00:11:11.383
And then the last, if you will,
the last two octets, the third and

204
00:11:11.383 --> 00:11:13.070
the fourth are all 0's, right?

205
00:11:13.070 --> 00:11:18.340
Well, and then the last one being 255
here, and if we look at 255, or I'm sorry,

206
00:11:18.340 --> 00:11:23.620
class C subnet mass, if we look at
255.255.255, you can now see that

207
00:11:23.620 --> 00:11:28.220
we've got what, one octet, two, three,
all the way up to the third octet of 1's.

208

So notice that I got, even in just

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the basic concepts of IP addressing. They look at classless subnet masks and the valid subnet mask ranges as well as some tips for the exam.
episodes.title: Classless IPv4 Addressing Part 2

So we also look at this chart because

IP address or networks with their subnet

it comes easy, it's kind of like

All right, well,

Well, now I have two octects of one bits,

16, so rather than say 255.255.255 or

But instead, I'm doing it shorthand and

00:04:55.210 --> 00:04:58.810
I'm saying 16 one bits in

00:04:58.810 --> 00:05:01.690
All right, now, let's do and

let me change this back to

00:05:04.820 --> 00:05:05.915
Let's do that same thing.

00:05:05.915 --> 00:05:10.140

And we do the same thing,

255.255.255.0, that's 8 + 8 + 8 or

97
00:05:23.600 --> 00:05:24.810

>> Right?

00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:27.770
So this is going to be a /24.

00:05:27.770 --> 00:05:34.870
Now, I could, if I was writing down and

00:05:36.580 --> 00:05:41.170

00:05:41.170 --> 00:05:44.090
And you have a subnet

00:05:44.090 --> 00:05:48.860
I could just write it out this way.

00:05:48.860 --> 00:05:49.928
I could say /24.

00:05:49.928 --> 00:05:52.931
And what we're saying is pretty

00:05:52.931 --> 00:05:54.900
it's easier, it's a shorthand.

00:05:54.900 --> 00:05:57.219
It's just saying how many

Now, here's where this

Class A default, class C or

that's because we still use

I still say, hey, Zach,

Well, if Zach knows what the B range is,

That would be between that 128 and

So, we still use them as weigh markers.

And I want you to use your CIDR notations,

system as a way marker, right?

00:06:44.550 --> 00:06:45.480
And here's why I say that.

00:06:45.480 --> 00:06:47.810
Because if we take something like,
I don't know,

>> Mm-hm.
