00:31:38.970 --> 00:31:42.194
>> Well what is this number if you will,

581
00:31:42.194 --> 00:31:46.150
taken out of the binary and
put into decimal?

582
00:31:46.150 --> 00:31:49.609
Well, it is 192.168.0.127.

583
00:31:49.609 --> 00:31:56.930
So that becomes the broadcast ID.

584
00:31:56.930 --> 00:31:59.607
So now we have what's
known as the network ID.

585
00:31:59.607 --> 00:32:01.520
I can't give the network ID out.

586
00:32:01.520 --> 00:32:04.401
Right?
The network ID is defined as all zeros.

587
00:32:04.401 --> 00:32:05.152
>> Right.

588
00:32:05.152 --> 00:32:07.007
>> In the host portion.

589
00:32:07.007 --> 00:32:12.171
Take that same network, same thing,
but turn the host portion into all 1s,

590
00:32:12.171 --> 00:32:16.180
and it tells me what the broadcast
address is, all right?

591
00:32:16.180 --> 00:32:18.980
And if I pull that out of
the binary back into the decimal,

592
00:32:18.980 --> 00:32:26.120
I can see that the broadcast address for
this network is 192.168.0.127.

593
00:32:26.120 --> 00:32:29.950
Well, remember, the second network I told
you though the two possibilities was a 0

594
00:32:29.950 --> 00:32:30.770
or a 1.

595
00:32:30.770 --> 00:32:32.200
That's part of the network.

596
00:32:32.200 --> 00:32:36.770
So all 0's in the host portion or
node portion becomes our network ID,

597
00:32:36.770 --> 00:32:41.210
and that would be a 128, right,
a 1 followed by all 0's.

598
00:32:41.210 --> 00:32:45.450
But if I turn this into all 1's in
the node portion, that now gives me what

599
00:32:45.450 --> 00:32:49.270
the broadcast ID is or
the broadcast address is for that network.

600
00:32:49.270 --> 00:32:52.621
Well, that tells me that
the broadcast ID or

601
00:32:52.621 --> 00:32:55.985
address, if you will, is going to be what?

602
00:32:55.985 --> 00:32:59.651
Well, what's all 1's in an octet,

603
00:32:59.651 --> 00:33:04.252
it's gonna be 192.168.0.255.

604
00:33:04.252 --> 00:33:09.449
All right, so
what we end up having here is

605
00:33:09.449 --> 00:33:15.250
we have our Network ID's on one side,
right?

606
00:33:15.250 --> 00:33:18.067
These are our network IDs.

607
00:33:18.067 --> 00:33:23.914
And on this side what we end up having is
what is known as our broadcast address,

608
00:33:23.914 --> 00:33:24.544
right?

609
00:33:24.544 --> 00:33:27.645
So we can say,
our Broadcast Address, all right?

610
00:33:27.645 --> 00:33:30.380
And you have to know that, right?

611
00:33:30.380 --> 00:33:33.052
When you start with this
process of subnetting,

612
00:33:33.052 --> 00:33:35.079
I have to know what is the network ID?

613
00:33:35.079 --> 00:33:38.685
If they give you an IP address
with this slash notation,

614
00:33:38.685 --> 00:33:43.447
they give you something
like 192.168.0.1.28/125,

615
00:33:43.447 --> 00:33:47.920
they say is this a valid IP
address within that network?

616
00:33:47.920 --> 00:33:50.720
Well, you would have to know
by doing the binary here that,

617
00:33:50.720 --> 00:33:53.530
no, that cannot be a valid IP address.

618
00:33:53.530 --> 00:33:57.030
Because if I put it in the binary,
and I do the division here,

619
00:33:57.030 --> 00:34:01.650
basically drawing that line between
the network portion and the node portion.

620
00:34:01.650 --> 00:34:07.623
I notice that there are all
0's in the node portion,

621
00:34:07.623 --> 00:34:14.960
that can't be an IP address,
that has to be a network ID, right?

622
00:34:14.960 --> 00:34:18.959
Just like looking at 127,
if I look at 192.168.0.127 and

623
00:34:18.959 --> 00:34:23.537
it has a /25 on it, and they say, is this
a valid IP address for that network range?

624
00:34:23.537 --> 00:34:27.844
Well, no, because if I look, 127,
after I've done my subnetting,

625
00:34:27.844 --> 00:34:32.420
is all 1's in the host bit, that means
it has to be the broadcast address.

626
00:34:32.420 --> 00:34:35.110
I cannot allocate that to a computer.

627
00:34:35.110 --> 00:34:39.160
So what we know now is that
in between these ranges

628
00:34:39.160 --> 00:34:42.040
are where our IP addresses stand.

629
00:34:42.040 --> 00:34:45.420
And what that means for me is that,
within this network here,

630
00:34:46.450 --> 00:34:51.330
what I'm gonna end up having
is an addressable range.

631
00:34:51.330 --> 00:34:53.500
And we'll just look at that last octet,
right?

632
00:34:55.000 --> 00:34:59.380
Looking at that last octet, that I know
that I can't use the first address, so

633
00:34:59.380 --> 00:35:05.360
I can use .1, through, can't use the 127,
that's the broadcast address, right?

634
00:35:05.360 --> 00:35:08.485
So I can use .1 to .126.

635
00:35:08.485 --> 00:35:15.560
And for this network, I can use what, I
can use, well, I can't use the 128, right?

636
00:35:15.560 --> 00:35:19.923
The 128 is going to be our network ID, so

637
00:35:19.923 --> 00:35:23.935
that means I can use .129, right?

638
00:35:23.935 --> 00:35:27.040
That's the first valid IP address.

639
00:35:27.040 --> 00:35:32.561
I can't use 255, right,
because 255 is the broadcast address,

640
00:35:32.561 --> 00:35:35.510
so I have to use .254, all right.

641
00:35:35.510 --> 00:35:40.360
So that essentially is where
we're getting the 126 computers.

642
00:35:40.360 --> 00:35:45.922
So the question would be, if I do this,
what is actually happening, all right?

643
00:35:45.922 --> 00:35:49.030
Well, let's go ahead, and
I know we're well out of time here,

644
00:35:49.030 --> 00:35:50.230
we'll come back in part 3.

645
00:35:50.230 --> 00:35:52.910
But what I've done with this is,
I've essentially said okay,

646
00:35:52.910 --> 00:35:58.600
I've created two networks now, right?

647
00:35:58.600 --> 00:36:02.025
So now we've got two subnets, right?

648
00:36:02.025 --> 00:36:04.900
Cuz we're subnetting here.

649
00:36:04.900 --> 00:36:08.626
And Network A is,

650
00:36:08.626 --> 00:36:14.092
this is the network ID, so

651
00:36:14.092 --> 00:36:20.061
Network A here, all right?

652
00:36:20.061 --> 00:36:28.580
And Network B, or subnet B,
if you will, Is, well, what?

653
00:36:28.580 --> 00:36:32.762
It is,
remember what we said 192.168.0.128?

654
00:36:32.762 --> 00:36:35.930
I've essentially created two subnets.

655
00:36:35.930 --> 00:36:40.060
We've got subnet or
Network A and Network B, and

656
00:36:40.060 --> 00:36:44.709
now we have two broadcast domains as well,
all right?

657
00:36:44.709 --> 00:36:49.901
And essentially, I can now put 126
computers on this network, and

658
00:36:49.901 --> 00:36:55.711
I could put 100, [SOUND] I can put 126
computers on this Network B as well.

659
00:36:55.711 --> 00:36:59.555
And then I also, with inside of each
of those networks, if I'm only using,

660
00:36:59.555 --> 00:37:03.701
let's say 50 computers, well,
I still have 50 something extra addresses,

661
00:37:03.701 --> 00:37:07.032
60 something extra addresses that
I can use for future growth.

662
00:37:07.032 --> 00:37:10.990
Now that's only one example, we got some
more examples that we wanna show you.

663
00:37:10.990 --> 00:37:13.230
Maybe we wanna go even further, right?

664
00:37:13.230 --> 00:37:15.456
Maybe we wanna make four networks.

665
00:37:15.456 --> 00:37:19.600
We wanna put 4 networks and we wanna
have 50 computers on each network.

666
00:37:19.600 --> 00:37:22.360
Or maybe we want three networks,
right, and

667
00:37:22.360 --> 00:37:26.380
we wanna have an extra network
just left over for future growth.

668
00:37:26.380 --> 00:37:28.120
Well, we're gonna show you how to do that,

669
00:37:28.120 --> 00:37:30.950
but we don't have time to
do it in this episode.

670
00:37:30.950 --> 00:37:34.291
>> Classless IPv4 Addressing Part
3 coming your way.

671
00:37:34.291 --> 00:37:36.760
This has been Part 2, there is a Part 1.

672
00:37:36.760 --> 00:37:38.366
I tell you what,
it's valuable information.

673
00:37:38.366 --> 00:37:41.820
If I were you, I'd be watching
all three of them many times.

674
00:37:41.820 --> 00:37:44.156
And in fact,
see everything that Wes' put together for

675
00:37:44.156 --> 00:37:45.810
you in the CompTIA Net+ series.

676
00:37:45.810 --> 00:37:48.760
And inside that course library
there's hundreds of other videos,

677
00:37:48.760 --> 00:37:51.160
all designed to help you go further.

678
00:37:51.160 --> 00:37:54.000
And tell everybody you
know about ITPro.TV.

679
00:37:54.000 --> 00:37:55.770
ITPro.TV is binge worthy.

680
00:37:55.770 --> 00:37:56.350
I'm Zach Memos.

681
00:37:56.350 --> 00:37:57.340
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

682
00:37:57.340 --> 00:37:58.117
>> And we'll see you soon.

683
00:37:58.117 --> 00:38:05.589
[MUSIC]

684
00:38:05.589 --> 00:38:07.886
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes continue their exploration on  the basic concepts of subnetting. They look applying classless subnet masks to networks to create smaller networks. They demonstate the concepts with examples.
episodes.title: Classless IPv4 Addressing Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.805
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.805 --> 00:00:03.143
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.143 --> 00:00:06.346
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.346 --> 00:00:07.207
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.207 --> 00:00:12.212
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.212 --> 00:00:14.270
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

7
00:00:14.270 --> 00:00:16.610
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

8
00:00:16.610 --> 00:00:20.560
I'm Zach Memos, your host,
as we continue on with CompTIA Net+.

9
00:00:20.560 --> 00:00:25.460
And this is Classes IPv4 Addressing,
part three.

10
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:29.940
More interesting information coming your
way from Wes Bryan, Wes Bryan, Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:32.290
>> All right, well, hey, Zach,
thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:32.290 --> 00:00:33.290
That's right, it's been fun.

13
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:35.620
And we are going to move on, right?

14
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:38.320
We're gonna move along and we're gonna
pick up right where we left off.

15
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:41.260
Remember, in the last episode
we ended with showing you

16
00:00:41.260 --> 00:00:45.930
how to basically take a single larger
network and subnet it into, or

17
00:00:45.930 --> 00:00:49.440
divide it into, two smaller networks.

18
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:50.470
But we're gonna go a little bit farther.

19
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:52.560
We didn't wanna just leave
you with one example.

20
00:00:52.560 --> 00:00:54.200
We wanna give you a couple of examples so

21
00:00:54.200 --> 00:00:57.350
that you will be prepared if they
ask you to do this on a Net+ exam.

22
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:01.170
So let's go ahead and let's dive right in,
and we'll pick up right where we left off.

23
00:01:01.170 --> 00:01:03.330
If you aren't aware of where we left off,

24
00:01:03.330 --> 00:01:07.550
go back and see part two and
then come back here and see part three.

25
00:01:07.550 --> 00:01:12.847
All right, so if we look at our sheet,
the last thing that we did, right,

26
00:01:12.847 --> 00:01:17.891
is we took a larger network
of 192.168.0.0 with a /24 or

27
00:01:17.891 --> 00:01:24.920
a classical subnet mask of 255.255.255.0,
right, and we divided it up, right?

28
00:01:24.920 --> 00:01:28.418
We said that hey, if I put a /25,

29
00:01:28.418 --> 00:01:33.410
that 25 adds one extra
bit in the 4th octet.

30
00:01:33.410 --> 00:01:38.775
And when we turn that bit on, we found
that these were our two network IDs.

31
00:01:38.775 --> 00:01:40.380
Oop, this is not a network ID.

32
00:01:40.380 --> 00:01:43.050
Let me go ahead and
change this around here just a little bit.

33
00:01:43.050 --> 00:01:45.400
Remember we said that all zeroes in

34
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:49.050
the host portion would be
your network IDs, right?

35
00:01:49.050 --> 00:01:52.420
So these network IDs would be all zeros.

36
00:01:52.420 --> 00:01:57.415
Well, that's easy enough,
that would be 192.168.0.0.

37
00:01:57.415 --> 00:02:02.380
The second possibility that we had here,
all right, was a binary 1, right?

38
00:02:02.380 --> 00:02:05.651
So if we take that out of the binary,

39
00:02:05.651 --> 00:02:11.226
that would be a network
ID of 192.168.0.128.

40
00:02:11.226 --> 00:02:14.140
Again /25, cuz we have that extra bit.

41
00:02:14.140 --> 00:02:18.640
Now remember we also said that to find
out what the broadcast address was for

42
00:02:18.640 --> 00:02:24.780
any given network, would be all 1 bits,
right, in the host portion.

43
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:28.590
So since we know that we took that one
bit and added it to the network portion,

44
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:31.540
if we put all ones in the host portion,

45
00:02:31.540 --> 00:02:37.260
these two binary numbers end up
becoming our broadcast addresses.

46
00:02:37.260 --> 00:02:41.570
So if I take this out of binary and
I convert it back to the decimal.

47
00:02:41.570 --> 00:02:43.105
And if you're not familiar with that,

48
00:02:43.105 --> 00:02:46.001
go back and look at some of the episodes
in which we've done this, right?

49
00:02:46.001 --> 00:02:49.411
I can see that that is
actually going to be 127.

50
00:02:49.411 --> 00:02:53.864
So I know that the broadcast address,
if you will, for this network here,

51
00:02:53.864 --> 00:02:57.930
the very first one we created,
was 192.168.0.127.

52
00:02:57.930 --> 00:03:01.940
Remember, all 1 bits in the host
portion for the second network as well.

53
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:05.310
That's gonna be the broadcast address for
the second network we created.

54
00:03:05.310 --> 00:03:09.120
And, well, all 1s we've already seen,
just like our subnet mask, right?

55
00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:11.565
All 1s in 8 bits is 255.

56
00:03:11.565 --> 00:03:15.000
The largest decimal value
can have an 8-bit octet.

57
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:16.697
So that means the broadcast address for

58
00:03:16.697 --> 00:03:19.844
the second network is also
192.168.0.255 with a /25.

59
00:03:19.844 --> 00:03:25.244
Now because we can't use
these two addresses,

60
00:03:25.244 --> 00:03:30.509
I want you to remember
that that takes off two of

61
00:03:30.509 --> 00:03:35.865
the addresses for the overall pool, right?

62
00:03:35.865 --> 00:03:39.145
When I need to figure out how
many possibilities do I have,

63
00:03:39.145 --> 00:03:40.660
I said 2 to the power of 8.

64
00:03:40.660 --> 00:03:45.100
You have 8 bits in an octet
that you can work with, is 256.

65
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:48.010
But as I've been kind of going back and
forth telling you,

66
00:03:48.010 --> 00:03:53.580
I said that gives you 254 available IP
addresses, and we kind of told you why.

67
00:03:53.580 --> 00:03:57.940
I can't give the network ID
to any individual computer,

68
00:03:57.940 --> 00:04:00.562
cuz all computers share the network ID,
right?

69
00:04:00.562 --> 00:04:03.810
I cannot give them the broadcast address.

70
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:07.030
I can't give that IP address
to Zach's computer, why?

71
00:04:07.030 --> 00:04:08.530
Well, cuz if I'm on that same network,

72
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:12.530
my computer uses that as well to send
broadcast communications, right?

73
00:04:12.530 --> 00:04:15.330
So all computers use
the broadcast address.

74
00:04:15.330 --> 00:04:19.420
So these two addresses,
the first address or

75
00:04:19.420 --> 00:04:22.230
the first possibility,
it's not really address, be careful.

76
00:04:22.230 --> 00:04:25.530
The first possibility within
a network range is the network ID.

77
00:04:25.530 --> 00:04:27.310
All zeroes in the host portion.

78
00:04:27.310 --> 00:04:32.462
The last possibility, all ones in the host
portion or node portion of an IP address,

79
00:04:32.462 --> 00:04:36.610
is going to be your broadcast,
and that can't be given out.

80
00:04:36.610 --> 00:04:39.180
So even though 2 to the power of 8 is 256,

81
00:04:39.180 --> 00:04:44.310
if we take off those two unusable
possibilities, that gives us 254 nodes.

82
00:04:45.890 --> 00:04:50.610
Now because we've now divided this
right down the dividing line,

83
00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:53.050
I don't have 254 possibilities.

84
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:54.580
What do I have, right?

85
00:04:54.580 --> 00:04:59.320
Well, if you look at it,
I now have what, 1 to 126.

86
00:04:59.320 --> 00:05:02.140
Essentially, I had 128, right,

87
00:05:02.140 --> 00:05:06.731
128 possibilities if we divide
that 256 right in half.

88
00:05:06.731 --> 00:05:08.567
But now that we've got 128,

89
00:05:08.567 --> 00:05:12.190
we've gotta keep in mind can't
give the first address out.

90
00:05:12.190 --> 00:05:13.870
Can't give the last address out.

91
00:05:13.870 --> 00:05:16.790
So technically I've got 126.

92
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:21.506
So that means the very first host,
right, within this network,

93
00:05:21.506 --> 00:05:24.953
is gonna be 192.168.0.1, right?

94
00:05:24.953 --> 00:05:29.780
That's the first host within that range,
the addressable range.

95
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:35.598
That means since I can't give the very
last possibility, the 192.168.01.127,

96
00:05:35.598 --> 00:05:40.870
cuz that's the broadcast address, it means
last one is one less than that, right?

97
00:05:40.870 --> 00:05:43.481
So it's .126.

98
00:05:43.481 --> 00:05:48.040
So this what we know as
the addressable range, all right?

99
00:05:48.040 --> 00:05:50.680
I called it the host range here,
but it's the addressable range.

100
00:05:50.680 --> 00:05:56.057
We can give out 192.168.0.1.2.3.4,

101
00:05:56.057 --> 00:05:59.428
all the way up to .126, right?

102
00:05:59.428 --> 00:06:05.150
But that .126 is the last address
we can use within that range,

103
00:06:05.150 --> 00:06:08.280
cuz then,
127 becomes your broadcast address.

104
00:06:08.280 --> 00:06:11.079
We move over into the second
network that we've created.

105
00:06:11.079 --> 00:06:16.558
128, I can't give that out, that's
the network ID, so that means 1.129.

106
00:06:16.558 --> 00:06:21.395
So 192.168.0.129, .128, .129,

107
00:06:21.395 --> 00:06:25.370
.130, .131 all the way up to .254.

108
00:06:25.370 --> 00:06:28.248
That gives me another.

109
00:06:28.248 --> 00:06:32.420
Well, it's overall 128 possibilities,

110
00:06:32.420 --> 00:06:36.390
but again,
it's another 126 potential IP addresses.

111
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:42.450
So what we did essentially is we
took all of this work in subnetting,

112
00:06:42.450 --> 00:06:45.690
went from a single,
larger network, of Network A.

113
00:06:45.690 --> 00:06:49.020
Now we have Subnet A and
Subnet B, all right?

114
00:06:49.020 --> 00:06:55.170
Well, maybe you want to eliminate
some more of the waste, right?

115
00:06:55.170 --> 00:07:00.510
Because what if I have only 50
computers on that one network, right?

116
00:07:00.510 --> 00:07:04.770
Or maybe I need only 50
computers on two networks.

117
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:06.460
Well, this isn't gonna work, right?

118
00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:09.390
And what they might ask
you is they want you

119
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:12.835
to waste the least amount of addresses,
right?

120

00:33:03.930 --> 00:33:08.150
Now what I need to do is I need
to figure one, two, three, four,

575
00:33:08.150 --> 00:33:09.430
five bits, all right.

576
00:33:09.430 --> 00:33:15.023
With five bits can I get,
what was the question again?

577
00:33:15.023 --> 00:33:16.227
Can I get 28 nodes?

578
00:33:16.227 --> 00:33:20.551
All right, well if you have a /27 and

579
00:33:20.551 --> 00:33:24.088
you have 5 bits for your nodes,

580
00:33:24.088 --> 00:33:29.740
that gives you essentially
30 nodes available.

581
00:33:29.740 --> 00:33:32.470
32 is your number, right,
32 is how many you get.

582
00:33:32.470 --> 00:33:35.910
But you can't use the first and
you can't use the last, so

583
00:33:35.910 --> 00:33:37.980
I don't get 32, I actually get 30.

584
00:33:37.980 --> 00:33:41.670
At this point right here,
I know that's the right answer.

585
00:33:41.670 --> 00:33:47.212
I don't have to go any
father in the subnetting

586
00:33:47.212 --> 00:33:53.322
because I now know that
a /27 gives me 8 networks

587
00:33:53.322 --> 00:33:58.320
with 30 nodes per network, all right.

588
00:33:58.320 --> 00:34:02.750
And, essentially,
the question was 5 networks,

589
00:34:02.750 --> 00:34:08.110
28 nodes per network, you need to provide
additional networks for the future.

590
00:34:08.110 --> 00:34:11.680
So I get my five networks,

591
00:34:11.680 --> 00:34:15.740
I've got three additional networks,
eight total for the future.

592
00:34:15.740 --> 00:34:20.915
And looking at the node portion,
I can see that I have enough bits,

593
00:34:20.915 --> 00:34:25.655
5 bits for the nodes gives
mean 32 total possibilities,

594
00:34:25.655 --> 00:34:30.705
take away the first and the last,
I get my 30 nodes in my addressable range.

595
00:34:30.705 --> 00:34:33.241
So, it meets the 20 nodes for
the question.

596
00:34:33.241 --> 00:34:37.988
So, I can tell right away that this
can't be the right answer either

597
00:34:37.988 --> 00:34:43.000
because of the fact that well,
29 would give me 2 bits less, right.

598
00:34:43.000 --> 00:34:46.500
And if that's two bits less that would
be three bits total for the node.

599
00:34:46.500 --> 00:34:48.560
And if we're talking about three bits,

600
00:34:48.560 --> 00:34:50.990
then you know what you get,
you get four hosts.

601
00:34:50.990 --> 00:34:54.570
And as you start to do this more and more,
you'll see where those numbers come up.

602
00:34:54.570 --> 00:34:58.500
So just keep that in mind that
this is another example, but

603
00:34:58.500 --> 00:35:02.540
I tell you what,
we got to do [LAUGH] a lot more, right?

604
00:35:02.540 --> 00:35:04.150
>> [LAUGH]
>> We need to get into things like

605
00:35:04.150 --> 00:35:08.820
variable length subnet masking,
or variable length subnet masks.

606
00:35:08.820 --> 00:35:12.460
So we're probably gonna have to go
into a part four on this one, and

607
00:35:12.460 --> 00:35:15.460
we'll come back in that part four and
we'll wrap up some

608
00:35:15.460 --> 00:35:19.030
of the additional concepts that we
couldn't take care of in the trilogy.

609
00:35:19.030 --> 00:35:20.260
>> Well you've done a wonderful job, Wes.

610
00:35:20.260 --> 00:35:22.810
And the more we do this,
the better it's gonna become for us and

611
00:35:22.810 --> 00:35:26.250
then it'll be ingrained IPv4, and

612
00:35:26.250 --> 00:35:30.420
his classless IPv4 addressing
part four coming your way.

613
00:35:30.420 --> 00:35:32.220
Make sure you watch parts one,
two, and three, and

614
00:35:32.220 --> 00:35:34.710
see everything in the CompTIA Net+ series.

615
00:35:34.710 --> 00:35:37.610
And when you're in that course library,
there's hundreds of other videos,

616
00:35:37.610 --> 00:35:40.000
they're all designed to
help you go further.

617
00:35:40.000 --> 00:35:43.850
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be mighty glad you did.

618
00:35:43.850 --> 00:35:44.540
I'm Zach Memos.

619
00:35:44.540 --> 00:35:45.420
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

620
00:35:45.420 --> 00:35:46.910
>> Thanks for watching, see you soon.

621
00:35:46.910 --> 00:35:53.150
[MUSIC]

622
00:35:53.150 --> 00:35:55.835
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: n this episode Zach and Wes continue their exploration on the basic concepts of subnetting. They look applying classless subnet masks to a larger network to create smaller networks. They continue their demonstatation of the concepts with additional examples inluding VLSM
episodes.title: Classless IPv4 Addressing Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

7
00:00:16.560 --> 00:00:20.220

00:00:20.220 --> 00:00:24.400
This episode is classless

And Wes Bryan,

10
00:00:27.000 --> 00:00:28.600

Yeah, this is the never ending episode.

But there's a lot of concepts

Especially when it comes

We talk about things like classless

00:00:41.131 --> 00:00:42.168

So we've actually looked at a lot of

So if you're not aware of some of those

And then, come back here and

22

Because this is really
gonna be a continuation.

23
00:00:56.950 --> 00:00:59.090
And we're picking up

24
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:03.640
In fact, if you remember in the last part,
the last episode right at the end,

25
00:01:03.640 --> 00:01:05.951
if we could take a look at the question.

26
00:01:05.951 --> 00:01:10.213
We were looking at a couple of a few
answers that you could potentially see on

27
00:01:10.213 --> 00:01:11.160
the exam.

28
00:01:11.160 --> 00:01:15.896
And we noted it down to this being the
right answer that if we needed 5 networks,

29
00:01:15.896 --> 00:01:17.886
20 hosts per network, right?

30
00:01:17.886 --> 00:01:24.989
What kind of slash notation or subnet masK
would we need with the base information if

31
00:01:24.989 --> 00:01:30.473
209.123.221.0, and
we provided that, right?

32
00:01:30.473 --> 00:01:36.591
We found out that a subnet
mask 255.255.255.224 or

33
00:01:36.591 --> 00:01:44.620
just a /27 would give us, and we went
back over to our trusty Excel sheet here.

34
00:01:44.620 --> 00:01:49.030
And we looked at borrowing those
three bits right, 224 is in that

35
00:01:49.030 --> 00:01:54.030
last octet would give us 8 networks and
then we counted the host bits up, right?

36
00:01:54.030 --> 00:01:56.720
We said, okay if we've got a certain
amount of host bits, right?

37
00:01:56.720 --> 00:02:00.670
Five of those host bits if we
did the math on that, right?

38
00:02:00.670 --> 00:02:04.500
We come out here to our calculator, and
let me go ahead and just change this to

39
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:08.760
a scientific calculator, and
we do a two to the power of five.

40
00:02:08.760 --> 00:02:11.110
We see that that gives

41
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:13.620
Remember, we cannot we cannot give

42
00:02:13.620 --> 00:02:19.480
that's 30 overall hosts that would be on

43
00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:21.950
So, we did accomplish our goal, right?

44
00:02:21.950 --> 00:02:24.190
We have two extra addresses per network,

45
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:25.970
28 hosts is what we needed.

46
00:02:25.970 --> 00:02:29.250
We got 30, so we have done

47
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:34.161
Now, I kind of added onto this question
because there might be some other things

48
00:02:34.161 --> 00:02:38.483
that they ask you in the context of
just general sub netting to see if you

49
00:02:38.483 --> 00:02:42.171
understand where the broadcast and
the network IDs stand.

50
00:02:42.171 --> 00:02:45.984
And then you can find out if an address
is actually addressable within a certain

51
00:02:45.984 --> 00:02:49.530
network, so we want to go ahead and
we kind of want to move into that next.

52
00:02:49.530 --> 00:02:54.440
So, the next part of the question,
we're gonna ask here is well what

53
00:02:54.440 --> 00:02:58.800
are the individual network, or
excuse me, what are the network ids for

54
00:02:58.800 --> 00:03:00.730
the individual networks that
we've created, all right?

55
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:03.480
And then, we'll come back and
we're gonna look at a couple other things.

56
00:03:03.480 --> 00:03:05.200
We're gonna look at
the broadcast addresses.

57

And then finally, the last thing that

58

59
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:15.370
These are all types that

60

So we want you to be prepared, and we want

61
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:22.833
So, remember that we said if we needed
to find out what network IDs are,

62
00:03:22.833 --> 00:03:26.470
all we have to do is take these

63
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:32.140
Remember, we can go ahead and we are
working with this, oops, sorry about that.

64
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:37.648
This side are notation right here, right?

65
00:03:37.648 --> 00:03:41.315
209.123.221.0/27 and
that gave us these networks right here.

66
00:03:41.315 --> 00:03:44.373
And remember that I told you that once
you know what your network bits are.

67
00:03:44.373 --> 00:03:47.675
You've got a certain amount of network
bits that are just going to stay the same.

68
00:03:47.675 --> 00:03:50.285
Like I know the first 3255's all ones.

69
00:03:50.285 --> 00:03:52.555
I don't have to worry about
anything within that range.

70
00:03:52.555 --> 00:03:53.923
I just have to focus on that 224.

71
00:03:53.923 --> 00:03:57.732
Well, once I've established that
those three bits are now part of

72
00:03:57.732 --> 00:03:59.024
the network portion,

73
00:03:59.024 --> 00:04:03.900
now all I have to do is come back here to

74
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:09.490
And just basically put 0's in

75
00:04:09.490 --> 00:04:15.570
what that'll do is that will show
me what our network IDs are, right?

76
00:04:15.570 --> 00:04:18.440
And then we take these out of binary,
which we're gonna do.

77
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:20.709
We're gonna do this for
every one of the networks here again.

78
00:04:20.709 --> 00:04:24.549
I'll give you multiple examples and
then what we want you to do here is,

79
00:04:24.549 --> 00:04:27.749
as you are practising this,
in getting ready for the exam,

80
00:04:27.749 --> 00:04:31.250
we definitely want you to be

81
00:04:31.250 --> 00:04:34.830
But this should give you plenty of

82
00:04:34.830 --> 00:04:38.020
and again like I said,
should make it easier for

83
00:04:38.020 --> 00:04:39.710
you should they ask you on the exam.

84
00:04:39.710 --> 00:04:46.040
So, now that we've got our 0's in
the host or known portion filled out.

85
00:04:46.040 --> 00:04:49.080
Remember, that it's just a matter
of taking these numbers and

86
00:04:49.080 --> 00:04:53.580
putting them back in decimal form, and
then attaching them to that last octet.

87
00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:56.520
Because that last octet is really
where's the actions at, right?

88
00:04:56.520 --> 00:04:59.323
Octet isolation,
if I'm worried about subnetting,

89
00:04:59.323 --> 00:05:03.680
I'm only gonna focus on the octet that
we're actually borrowing bits, right?

90
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:08.700
So, we can take this out and we can see
that the first network ID, if you will,

91
00:05:08.700 --> 00:05:14.280
is going to be, what is it gonna be?

92
00:05:14.280 --> 00:05:20.161
It's gonna be 209.123.0,
I missed one octet,

93
00:05:20.161 --> 00:05:24.782
sorry, 123.221.0 /27, right?

94
00:05:24.782 --> 00:05:27.800
So that's always gonna be the first start,
right?

95
00:05:27.800 --> 00:05:32.130
That is essentially where you
start with any kind of subnetting,

96
00:05:32.130 --> 00:05:36.855
you're gonna at least have that very
first base address, which is 0.

97
00:05:36.855 --> 00:05:37.610
>> Mm-hm.

98
00:05:37.610 --> 00:05:41.170
>> Then we're gonna go ahead, and
we're gonna move to the next octet, right?

99
00:05:41.170 --> 00:05:42.200
And we have to figure out.

100
00:05:42.200 --> 00:05:44.600
Well, what is this next octet?

101
00:05:44.600 --> 00:05:49.272
Well, I can kinda see that since there's
only a 1 in the 32 bit position,

102
00:05:49.272 --> 00:05:52.560
that place value,
well that's gonna be the number.

103
00:05:52.560 --> 00:05:57.440
Cuz to take it out from the binary to
the decimal we just add up all the 1s.

104
00:05:57.440 --> 00:06:01.170
Well I've got 1,
1 bit right in the 32 place value, right?

105
00:06:01.170 --> 00:06:05.930
So that's gonna be 209.123.221.32,
and /27.

106
00:06:05.930 --> 00:06:10.613
All right,
now we're gonna go to the next octet,

107
00:06:10.613 --> 00:06:16.318
we're gonna say,
well what's the network ID for this one?

108
00:06:16.318 --> 00:06:20.190
Remember, all 0's in the host bit,
take this out of the binary,

109
00:06:20.190 --> 00:06:25.940
put it back into the decimal,
and when we have 209.123.221 and

110
00:06:25.940 --> 00:06:30.680
in this case it is .64/, again, 27.

111
00:06:30.680 --> 00:06:33.763
Just to keep with our notation.

112
00:06:33.763 --> 00:06:36.770
All right, so then the next one
that we have here is going to be,

113
00:06:36.770 --> 00:06:39.540
well, notice that there are two bits,
right?

114
00:06:39.540 --> 00:06:42.300
We have the 64 and we have the 32.

115
00:06:42.300 --> 00:06:47.430
So, if you need to,
you can always get out the calculator.

116
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:51.030
Remember, that even on
the exam by the way.

117
00:06:51.030 --> 00:06:54.600
Let me let you know that they
will bring you a calculator out.

118
00:06:54.600 --> 00:06:57.930
So, if you don't know to have
that calculator ready to go

119
00:06:57.930 --> 00:07:01.020
then you can add your 64 and
your 32 we get 96.

120
00:07:01.020 --> 00:07:03.826
So I can see the next octet, or

121
00:07:03.826 --> 00:07:08.654
the next network if you
will is gonna be 209, and

122
00:07:08.654 --> 00:07:15.080
this'll be 123.221, and
again .96, and then /27.

123
00:07:15.080 --> 00:07:19.478
All right,
moving down to the next network, right,

124
00:07:19.478 --> 00:07:23.690
we're gonna do a 209.123.221.0.

125
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:27.960
Notice that there is only a single
0 in the very first bit position

126
00:07:27.960 --> 00:07:33.750
making that 128 for
that network's network ID, if you will.

127
00:07:33.750 --> 00:07:36.901
Now again, following down,
notice that there is a pattern here,

128
00:07:36.901 --> 00:07:38.714
nothing is really changing, right?

129
00:07:38.714 --> 00:07:41.924
Now we have got a 128 and a 32.

130
00:07:41.924 --> 00:07:45.833
And I'm not even going to prove
to you how bad my math is.

131
00:07:45.833 --> 00:07:49.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we are doing 128 + 32 and

132
00:07:49.540 --> 00:07:51.345
that give us 160.

133
00:07:51.345 --> 00:07:57.553
So we tell the network ID for
the next network is 209.123.221 And

134
00:07:57.553 --> 00:08:01.145
again, let me just double-check myself.

135
00:08:01.145 --> 00:08:02.301
As a-
>> 160.

136
00:08:02.301 --> 00:08:04.273
>> 160, thank you there, Mr. Zach.

137
00:08:04.273 --> 00:08:04.898
Appreciate it.

138
00:08:04.898 --> 00:08:07.110
And again a /27.

139
00:08:07.110 --> 00:08:10.840
All right, now, moving on down,
we've got two bits.

140
00:08:10.840 --> 00:08:14.000
You should recognize these if you've
been following along with us.

141
00:08:14.000 --> 00:08:17.350
You should recognize these as one of
the those valid subnet mask ranges, right?

142
00:08:17.350 --> 00:08:19.533
Because there's two one-bits here.

143
00:08:19.533 --> 00:08:21.563
Remember, 128, 192.

144
00:08:21.563 --> 00:08:23.078
So I don't even have
to count this one out.

145
00:08:23.078 --> 00:08:31.083
I can see that this is
192.209.123.221.192/27.

146
00:08:31.083 --> 00:08:33.905
And then the last one is,
well, three bits, all right?

147
00:08:33.905 --> 00:08:35.353
We look at the three bits there.

148
00:08:35.353 --> 00:08:37.028
Well, I can tell that that's 224.

149
00:08:37.028 --> 00:08:40.582
Again, because counting those
consecutive bits, those continuous bits,

150
00:08:40.582 --> 00:08:42.558
you'll start to see that pattern come up.

151
00:08:42.558 --> 00:08:43.850
>> Back to the chart that you made.

152
00:08:43.850 --> 00:08:45.849
>> That's right, absolutely.

153
00:08:45.849 --> 00:08:53.897
So it's 209.123.221.224/27.

154
00:08:53.897 --> 00:08:58.441
All right, so we've got, one, two,
three, four, five, six, seven,

155
00:08:58.441 --> 00:09:02.140
eight networks,
remember there's eight possibilities.

156
00:09:02.140 --> 00:09:04.220
And how did we come up with
those eight possibilities?

157
00:09:04.220 --> 00:09:06.700
Well, you can do the math,
if you want, on that one as well.

158
00:09:06.700 --> 00:09:09.970
And if we bring back our calculator and
we clear this out,

159
00:09:09.970 --> 00:09:14.790
we could do 2 to the power of 3,
those 4 bits.

160
00:09:14.790 --> 00:09:16.556
And notice that we have 8 right there.

161
00:09:16.556 --> 00:09:17.831
>> There it is.
>> So you can see it's always

162
00:09:17.831 --> 00:09:18.720
an exponential value.

163
00:09:18.720 --> 00:09:21.160
Just 2 to the power of how
ever many bits you have.

164
00:09:21.160 --> 00:09:24.120
If you're talking about network bits,
that's how many networks you have.

165
00:09:24.120 --> 00:09:25.870
Two to the power of how ever many bits.

166
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:30.100
If you're talking hosts, that's how many
hosts you have, and then minus the two.

167
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:33.746
One of those two being the network
IDs that we're working on right now.

168
00:09:33.746 --> 00:09:36.722
Now we also have to look at the next
part of the question, all right?

169
00:09:36.722 --> 00:09:39.615
If we know now what the network IDs are,

170
00:09:39.615 --> 00:09:44.360
the next part of this would be
what are the broadcast addresses?

171
00:09:44.360 --> 00:09:45.220
And let me go ahead and

172
00:09:45.220 --> 00:09:48.840

00:37:10.320 --> 00:37:11.950
We do a /28, all right?

613
00:37:11.950 --> 00:37:16.150
And well,
that ends up giving us our last network.

614
00:37:16.150 --> 00:37:18.360
And that puts, what'd we say?

615
00:37:18.360 --> 00:37:20.170
We said that's 16 nodes.

616
00:37:20.170 --> 00:37:23.510
So if I wanna figure out what
the broadcast address is with a /28,

617
00:37:23.510 --> 00:37:27.434
I'm just gonna go ahead and
do a 24, right?

618
00:37:27.434 --> 00:37:32.449
Plus, I can't use 16,
cuz 224 is one of those possibilities,

619
00:37:32.449 --> 00:37:36.093
so plus 15, oops,
you gotta do the rest, Wes.

620
00:37:36.093 --> 00:37:40.360
[LAUGH] 224 plus 15 equals 239.

621
00:37:40.360 --> 00:37:44.978
So, I can see that on this network,
the broadcast address is

622
00:37:44.978 --> 00:37:50.500
168.0., what did I say?

623
00:37:50.500 --> 00:37:53.170
I said it was 239.

624
00:37:53.170 --> 00:37:57.490
All right, now the reason I was showing
you how to figure out the broadcast IDs.

625
00:37:57.490 --> 00:38:00.950
And we were showing you
as well the network IDs.

626
00:38:00.950 --> 00:38:03.390
Is in order to do variable
length subnet masking,

627
00:38:03.390 --> 00:38:05.250
I gotta make sure that there's no overlap.

628
00:38:05.250 --> 00:38:09.260
So I need to know what the broadcast
address is in that network that I created,

629
00:38:09.260 --> 00:38:12.420
so I know what the network ID is
in the adjacent network that we're

630
00:38:12.420 --> 00:38:15.120
gonna create with the next set of bits.

631
00:38:15.120 --> 00:38:18.020
All right, so that is our 16.

632
00:38:18.020 --> 00:38:23.670
Not a lot of waste there but
what we've done is essentially we've used,

633
00:38:23.670 --> 00:38:27.610
if you noticed,
we've used a variable link subnet mask.

634
00:38:27.610 --> 00:38:35.206
And let me fill this one in for
completeness, 192.168.1 and

635
00:38:35.206 --> 00:38:40.440
that as 0.127, all right and a /25.

636
00:38:40.440 --> 00:38:43.420
All right,
notice what we've done here, right?

637
00:38:43.420 --> 00:38:45.800
We've varied the length
of the subnet masks.

638
00:38:45.800 --> 00:38:50.330
There's four different subnet masks on
this network now, other than the /24.

639
00:38:50.330 --> 00:38:55.490
And what we've done is we've tailored
them down to specifically what we need so

640
00:38:55.490 --> 00:38:58.330
that we don't have any of
the waste within our network.

641
00:38:58.330 --> 00:39:03.460
And that's what VLSM does, it allows
you to shorten the amount of waste to,

642
00:39:03.460 --> 00:39:07.770
and to more efficiently design
your networks the way you need to.

643
00:39:07.770 --> 00:39:10.430
And that's one of the reasons
that they implemented VLSM.

644
00:39:10.430 --> 00:39:14.240
Now, one of the things that I also want
you to keep in mind is that you have to

645
00:39:14.240 --> 00:39:16.000
have a routing protocol.

646
00:39:16.000 --> 00:39:18.620
Back to our routing protocols,
cuz remember our routing protocols

647
00:39:18.620 --> 00:39:19.820
are responsible-
>> Yeah.

648
00:39:19.820 --> 00:39:20.770
>> For handling IP.

649
00:39:20.770 --> 00:39:24.390
You have to have a routing protocol
that supports VLSM, right?

650
00:39:24.390 --> 00:39:29.150
RIP version 2, ISIS, EIGRP, BGP, OSPF,

651
00:39:29.150 --> 00:39:31.540
all of those routing protocols
that we've talked about.

652
00:39:31.540 --> 00:39:33.380
They support VLSM.

653
00:39:33.380 --> 00:39:34.411
Keep that in mind, right?

654
00:39:34.411 --> 00:39:35.800
Something early, very early,

655
00:39:35.800 --> 00:39:40.700
probably outdated by now protocols that
we would have might not support VLSM.

656
00:39:40.700 --> 00:39:46.090
This has been around since the 90s so
by now, most of our routing protocols do.

657
00:39:46.090 --> 00:39:48.460
But again,
just make sure that on the exam,

658
00:39:48.460 --> 00:39:52.340
if they ask you about variable length
subnet masks that you do know,

659
00:39:52.340 --> 00:39:55.470
which of those routing
protocols support that feature?

660
00:39:55.470 --> 00:39:56.950
>> Great job Wes, thank you very much.

661
00:39:56.950 --> 00:40:00.510
Classless iPv4 addressing part four.

662
00:40:00.510 --> 00:40:03.795
Make sure you watch all four parts,
cuz it's very important.

663
00:40:03.795 --> 00:40:06.855
And in fact, watch everything in the
CompTIA Net+ series while you're in that

664
00:40:06.855 --> 00:40:10.775
course library, hundreds of other
videos to help you go further.

665
00:40:10.775 --> 00:40:15.005
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
ITProTV is binge worthy.

666
00:40:15.005 --> 00:40:15.705
I'm Zach Memos.

667
00:40:15.705 --> 00:40:16.395
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

668
00:40:16.395 --> 00:40:17.675
>> Thank you for watching,
we'll see you soon.

669
00:40:17.675 --> 00:40:24.710
[MUSIC]

670
00:40:24.710 --> 00:40:27.535
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into how IP addresses are configured on nodes inside of modern networks. The look at concepts like DHCP, static assignments, EUI-64 and more
episodes.title: IP Address Assignments

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the basic concepts of IPv6 addressing. They look at topics like tunneling, dual stack, router advertisements and neighbor discovery
episodes.title: IPv6 Addressing

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the basic concepts of IPv6 addressing. They look at topics like tunneling, dual stack, router advertisements and neighbor discovery
episodes.title: IPv6 Addressing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes discuss different network topologies. They will look at the different network types like LANs, WANs and WLANs. They will also look at various concepts surrounding Internet of Things or IoT
episodes.title: Network Topologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.702
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.702 --> 00:00:04.176
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.176 --> 00:00:08.354
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.354 --> 00:00:10.909
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.909 --> 00:00:13.637
>> Hallo and thank you for
choosing ITPRO.TV,

6
00:00:13.637 --> 00:00:16.740
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:21.220
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA Net+ And

8
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:24.590
this episode is Network Topologies.

9
00:00:24.590 --> 00:00:25.450
What is that all about?

10
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:28.020
Well, Wes Bryan is here
to show us the way.

11
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:29.200
Wes, glad to have you.

12
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:30.740
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Zach.

13
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:34.070
That is right, we are gonna be talking
about, well, Zach already said it,

14
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:35.370
network topologies.

15
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:40.370
And let's go ahead and we'll waste no
time, dive in, what is a topology?

16
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:46.470
Well a topology basically describes the
layout of the network and the relationship

17
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:50.700
to connectivity devices and
the nodes that we have within the network.

18
00:00:50.700 --> 00:00:53.712
The end system, so the end systems,
end points if you will.

19
00:00:53.712 --> 00:00:59.410
In other episodes, we talked about source
and destination of the communication.

20
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:00.675
Those are our end points.

21
00:01:00.675 --> 00:01:04.630
And there's some different topologies
that we have to be aware of.

22
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:08.752
I do want you to understand, though,
when it comes to topologies,

23
00:01:08.752 --> 00:01:11.592
you have two different theories.

24
00:01:11.592 --> 00:01:16.590
Not eally theories, but you have what's
known as a physical topology, and

25
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:18.940
you have what's known
as a logical topology.

26
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:21.850
When we talk about the physical topology,
we talk about, again,

27
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:23.370
the physical characteristics,

28
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:28.210
the layout of the network, and the
relationship of the nodes to one another.

29
00:01:28.210 --> 00:01:34.720
But the logical topology describes how
the data flows across the network.

30
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:38.300
And what I'll do is, I'll show you
here in a second what I mean by that.

31
00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:42.990
But understand there is a physical
topology, which means you can actually see

32
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:45.540
all the wires and the cables,
and if you were to zoom out and

33
00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:49.090
look down on top of this network,
that's what it would look like.

34
00:01:49.090 --> 00:01:50.780
But just because the network
looks like that,

35
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:53.680
doesn't necessarily mean that's
how the data is gonna travel.

36
00:01:53.680 --> 00:01:57.470
The data could travel in
a completely deterministic manner.

37
00:01:57.470 --> 00:02:03.320
So we have to know, logically,
the logical topology as well too.

38
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:06.660
All right, so let's go ahead and
let's dive into our first one and

39
00:02:06.660 --> 00:02:09.990
the first one I wanna talk
about is an oldie but goodie.

40
00:02:09.990 --> 00:02:12.820
And this is what's known as a bus network.

41
00:02:12.820 --> 00:02:15.640
Now when I say oldie but
goodie in communication networks,

42
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:19.240
primarily we don't use a lot
of bus topologies anymore.

43
00:02:19.240 --> 00:02:23.560
However, there are plenty of buses,
and I don't mean the yellow buses that

44
00:02:23.560 --> 00:02:27.330
are taking your kids to and from school or
transporting you all across the city.

45
00:02:27.330 --> 00:02:31.220
What I'm talking about is, there are buses
all over our computing environment today.

46
00:02:31.220 --> 00:02:35.450
We have essentially electrical
copper conductors that

47
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:38.950
are sending information to and
from components on our motherboards.

48
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:40.190
Those are buses.

49
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:41.340
So when I say oldie but goodie,

50
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:45.370
understand that we're talking in the
strict form of a network communication.

51
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:48.720
Let me give you an example of what
a bus topology would look like.

52
00:02:48.720 --> 00:02:50.545
What you end up having is,
you end up having this,

53
00:02:50.545 --> 00:02:56.805
almost like this central conductor,
this central communication cable.

54
00:02:56.805 --> 00:03:01.585
It really forms what's known as
the backbone for the entire network.

55
00:03:01.585 --> 00:03:05.665
In the earlier days, these were the type
of networks that we were using commonly.

56
00:03:05.665 --> 00:03:09.818
The very first Ethernet networks,
802.3, the 10BASE2 and

57
00:03:09.818 --> 00:03:12.117
10BASE5, Thinnet and Thicknet.

58
00:03:12.117 --> 00:03:13.419
These were bus-based networks.

59
00:03:13.419 --> 00:03:18.271
Now some of the advantages you have to
the bus based networks is the fact that

60
00:03:18.271 --> 00:03:22.210
it was relatively easy to attach
a new device to the network.

61
00:03:23.300 --> 00:03:24.660
So it was very simplistic.

62
00:03:24.660 --> 00:03:28.050
And because of the fact that you
had this centralized bus and

63
00:03:28.050 --> 00:03:33.080
you're only attaching a single
node to the backbone cable,

64
00:03:33.080 --> 00:03:37.055
it was relatively easy and simplistic
when it comes to the physical cabling.

65
00:03:37.055 --> 00:03:41.044
Here's the problem with
the bus-based network.

66
00:03:41.044 --> 00:03:45.990
It's that bus networks are what
are known as contention-based networks.

67
00:03:45.990 --> 00:03:48.280
And the reason I say that,
a contention-based network,

68
00:03:48.280 --> 00:03:54.240
understand that your communication type
means that everybody is contending for

69
00:03:54.240 --> 00:03:55.430
access to the media.

70
00:03:55.430 --> 00:03:59.640
In the earlier bus-based network what
we'd be using, especially in Ethernet,

71
00:03:59.640 --> 00:04:03.240
was something known as Carrier-Sense
Multiple Access Collision Detection.

72
00:04:03.240 --> 00:04:07.260
And what this means is, again,
contention-based media, it just means that

73
00:04:07.260 --> 00:04:11.550
if this computer right here sent out
communications, well guess what?

74
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:18.490
Every single node connected to this
entire bus would receive the signal.

75
00:04:18.490 --> 00:04:21.350
Now that doesn't mean that they would
process it, because they would look at

76
00:04:21.350 --> 00:04:24.940
that information in the normal,
as we've talked about in other episodes.

77
00:04:24.940 --> 00:04:29.260
OSI model would apply, so we would look
at that data and see the MAC address and

78
00:04:29.260 --> 00:04:32.560
then the computer would say, well wait
a second here, that's not my MAC address.

79
00:04:32.560 --> 00:04:35.730
So even though I received it,
I didn't process the information.

80
00:04:36.730 --> 00:04:40.700
So what that means for
us is that we've got a lotta extra

81
00:04:40.700 --> 00:04:45.290
communications that are going on our
network that we don't necessarily need.

82
00:04:45.290 --> 00:04:47.880
So a lot of contention on these networks.

83
00:04:47.880 --> 00:04:52.200
Which means they weren't very scable,
and that's a problem,

84
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:55.650
because as we add additional computers,

85
00:04:55.650 --> 00:04:59.387
even though we add additional computers to
these networks and it becomes fairly easy

86
00:04:59.387 --> 00:05:03.360
to add additional computers,
we're increasing the contention.

87
00:05:03.360 --> 00:05:06.580
Because now, when this one
computer sends communications,

88
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:11.720
it doesn't just go now to the four
other computers on this network.

89
00:05:11.720 --> 00:05:14.320
Now, it also goes to
these computers as well.

90
00:05:14.320 --> 00:05:16.736
There's another problem with these
kind of networks likewise, too.

91
00:05:16.736 --> 00:05:22.220
It's the fact that a single break in
the cable, so let's say if we had a break

92
00:05:22.220 --> 00:05:27.440
in these cables, anywhere,
would bring the entire network down.

93
00:05:27.440 --> 00:05:29.370
Bring the entire network down.

94
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:33.730
One break in the cable and everybody
is looking up over their cubicles,

95
00:05:33.730 --> 00:05:35.660
wondering why the network is down.

96
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:38.340
Alright, the other thing about these
networks, the bus-based networks,

97
00:05:38.340 --> 00:05:41.290
too, is you had to basically

98
00:05:41.290 --> 00:05:44.220
match the electrical characteristics
of the cable that you were using.

99
00:05:44.220 --> 00:05:46.840
So you would use what
are known as terminators.

100
00:05:46.840 --> 00:05:48.530
Now when we're talking about
terminators in this sense,

101
00:05:48.530 --> 00:05:51.548
we're not talking about a machine sent
back in time to destroy Sean Conners.

102
00:05:51.548 --> 00:05:53.170
>> [LAUGH] I was just going to ask you.

103
00:05:53.170 --> 00:05:58.080
>> What we're talking about is basically,
it's a resistor, really, is what it is.

104
00:05:58.080 --> 00:06:01.030
And again, you would have 50 and
75 ohm resistors,

105
00:06:01.030 --> 00:06:04.090
one of the most common
was the 50 ohm resistor.

106
00:06:04.090 --> 00:06:07.102
And it would terminate the end of
the cable, because one of the things about

107
00:06:07.102 --> 00:06:13.460
this bus-based cable is that if you send
an electrical communication down it and

108
00:06:13.460 --> 00:06:17.370
it met an abrupt change in impedance,
it would cause signal reflection.

109
00:06:17.370 --> 00:06:18.190
It would bounce back.

110
00:06:18.190 --> 00:06:19.010
So what we'd have is,

111
00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:21.730
we'd have a bunch of electrical
signals bouncing back and forth.

112
00:06:21.730 --> 00:06:24.020
And if every computer is
sending these signals out,

113
00:06:24.020 --> 00:06:27.520
eventually what you would have, it would
just bring down the network completely.

114
00:06:27.520 --> 00:06:30.780
So you would terminate the ends
of each side of the bus.

115
00:06:30.780 --> 00:06:32.390
And that was again important.

116
00:06:32.390 --> 00:06:37.445
So again, keep in mind that they were
relatively simplistic to add an additional

117
00:06:37.445 --> 00:06:42.050
node, but they were not very good for
very large environments.

118
00:06:42.050 --> 00:06:43.240
So it is important.

119
00:06:43.240 --> 00:06:45.880
Now what do we use today
in very large environments?

120
00:06:45.880 --> 00:06:49.330
Well, we use something
known as a star topology.

121
00:06:49.330 --> 00:06:51.452
And I got an example of
a star topology right here.

122
00:06:51.452 --> 00:06:55.760
So your star topology is just one where
you have the devices that are connected in

123
00:06:55.760 --> 00:06:58.790
a star formation around
a central connectivity device.

124
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:01.840
Now this has its benefits too, and

125
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:05.500
this is the most common type
of implementation today.

126
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:09.990
Well, one of the things that it has
a really good benefit, is the fact

127
00:07:09.990 --> 00:07:15.110
that if one of the cables breaks here,
It only takes that node offline.

128
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:19.670
It doesn't bring down
the entirety of the network.

129
00:07:19.670 --> 00:07:21.320
So please keep that in mind.

130
00:07:21.320 --> 00:07:26.600
Now remember that I told you
that this is physical topology.

131
00:07:26.600 --> 00:07:34.110
Logical topology dictates the way the data
actually moves across the network.

132
00:07:34.110 --> 00:07:36.490
The logical topology does.

133
00:07:36.490 --> 00:07:40.570
Well, how could we have a connectivity
device that, even though this is

134
00:07:40.570 --> 00:07:45.290
a physical star topology,
logically would make it act like a bus.

135
00:07:45.290 --> 00:07:49.167
Well if it's a hub, if this central
connectivity device is a hub, and

136
00:07:49.167 --> 00:07:51.940
I send a signal from
this device into the hub.

137
00:07:51.940 --> 00:07:54.790
Remember when I told you about a hub and
we were talking about the OSI model?

138
00:07:54.790 --> 00:07:56.380
If not, you need to go back and watch.

139
00:07:56.380 --> 00:07:59.698
Is the hub is hard coded to
broadcast out all other ports,

140
00:07:59.698 --> 00:08:03.020
to the devices that
are connected to the hub.

141
00:08:03.020 --> 00:08:03.607
Well, guess what?

142
00:08:03.607 --> 00:08:04.798
That's a lot of contention.

143
00:08:04.798 --> 00:08:07.970
So now, even though physically
we have a star topology,

144
00:08:07.970 --> 00:08:09.555
if you look at it logically,

145
00:08:09.555 --> 00:08:14.690
we have a communication that goes right
back to our contention based physical bus.

146
00:08:14.690 --> 00:08:17.670
So that's what we mean when we say the
difference between a logical topology and

147
00:08:17.670 --> 00:08:19.300
physical topology.

148
00:08:19.300 --> 00:08:23.170
If this is a switch, it's a physical star.

149
00:08:23.170 --> 00:08:26.030
All right, it isn't a logical bus.

150
00:08:26.030 --> 00:08:29.970
All right, because the switch is basically
connecting ports together, all right.

151
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:32.690
The other benefit of this
is it's relatively easy

152
00:08:32.690 --> 00:08:35.000
to add another device, right.

153
00:08:35.000 --> 00:08:36.789
We just add another device, and

154
00:08:36.789 --> 00:08:41.308
we can just essentially hook a cable from
that device essentially to the switch.

155
00:08:42.546 --> 00:08:44.724
So, good benefit in a star topology,

156
00:08:44.724 --> 00:08:49.360
again one of the most common
implementations that you have today.

157
00:08:49.360 --> 00:08:53.190
Now, there are some other ones that
are kind of blurring the lines between

158
00:08:53.190 --> 00:08:57.230
oldies but goodies but some of them
that are topology is still unused today.

159
00:08:57.230 --> 00:08:59.460
And it's really one of
the fastest networks today.

160
00:08:59.460 --> 00:09:01.200
So what do I mean by that?

161
00:09:01.200 --> 00:09:05.390
Well again, let's go ahead and take a trip
back in time, let's go back to the 80s.

162
00:09:05.390 --> 00:09:08.350
February 1980, when the IEEE came
together and they said, you know what,

163

controlling the wireless devices.

387
00:21:48.930 --> 00:21:53.110
But there might be let's say a situation
where you might have to use something

00:21:53.110 --> 00:21:56.900
known as ad hoc mode because I
don't have a wireless access point.

389
00:21:56.900 --> 00:22:01.170
So if your network adaptors and your
laptop will support it, so for instance,

00:22:01.170 --> 00:22:05.520
maybe Zach and I, we have to go to
a location where we can't have access for

00:22:05.520 --> 00:22:07.170
whatever, let's say security reasons.

We can't have access to their wireless
network, it's for them but Zach and

I have to give a presentation.

He's got some PowerPoint slides on his

computer and unfortunately we've

396

Well we can set our computers

397
00:22:21.964 --> 00:22:24.470
we don't have to go

398
00:22:24.470 --> 00:22:27.480
This is where your wireless mesh comes in,
because now we're not going through

399
00:22:27.480 --> 00:22:30.730
infrastructure mode cuz the access
point isn't controlling this.

400
00:22:30.730 --> 00:22:34.070
My computer is acting like
an access point, I can send and

00:22:34.070 --> 00:22:35.980
receive signals at will.

402
00:22:35.980 --> 00:22:37.840
Zach can send information back to me,

403
00:22:37.840 --> 00:22:39.780
doesn't have to go
through the access point.

404
00:22:39.780 --> 00:22:42.557
So the difference between ad hoc mode and
infrastructure mode.

405
00:22:42.557 --> 00:22:46.139
Infrastructure mode,
managing wireless access point,

406
00:22:46.139 --> 00:22:48.696
ad hoc mode eliminate the access point and

407
00:22:48.696 --> 00:22:53.160
our computers will talk to each
other without that access point.

408
00:22:53.160 --> 00:22:55.124
That is important to understand.

409
00:22:55.124 --> 00:22:59.305
All right, so
those are some of the topologies, right?

Those are some of the topologies

So the next thing that we're gonna have to

But I want you to think about it based

That's what we're gonna go ahead and

And here's one of the very first ones,

00:23:19.849 --> 00:23:23.017
This is what's known as a LAN, and

00:23:23.017 --> 00:23:23.540

418
00:23:23.540 --> 00:23:29.925
Local area network essentially is a series

422
00:23:42.452 --> 00:23:45.720
It's connected with a typically
short range media and

00:23:45.720 --> 00:23:49.310
you as the administrator

424
00:23:49.310 --> 00:23:53.830
Now if you have bigger company
that has multiple LANs,

425
00:23:53.830 --> 00:23:58.030
multiple local area networks,
the single geographical locations but

426

they might wanna allow them to

427

So maybe the company,

428

Maybe they have a LAN in New York,

So it's a massive for

It could be an international company,

Well then what we end up having is

See a wide area network is comprised

And a wide area network spans

437
00:24:41.633 --> 00:24:43.735
Again, that's the wide area network,

438

You can essentially say like the Internet

439

I mean it's a bunch of local

442

Now a WAN let's get a little

443

When we talk about a WAN,

a WAN is typically under control

445

You go to Internet service provider to get

those multiple geographical locations,

447
00:25:11.184 --> 00:25:14.334
So we have a local area network, right?

448
00:25:14.334 --> 00:25:19.200
The local area network is comprised

449
00:25:19.200 --> 00:25:25.490
It's typical in control under a single

450
00:25:25.490 --> 00:25:28.910
When you have multiple

And even the wide area network, typically,

453
00:25:36.940 --> 00:25:39.450
typically like a single company,

454

So, those are some of

455

keep in mind as geographical location.

But I'm looking at our list and it looks

episodes.description: In this episode Justin and Wes discuss different network topologies. They will look at the different network types like LANs, WANs and WLANs. They will also look at various concepts surrounding Internet of Things or IoT

local I don't know what they are but

In other episodes, we talked about

We talked about 802.11 standards,

Well here we wanna talk about

Now, they get a little technical jargon-y

When I talk about an STA,

That's essentially what

All right, well I just want you to

So that's why you'll see it just

That's important because

00:04:30.190 --> 00:04:33.590

00:04:37.750 --> 00:04:40.820
If we take a look the distribution system

00:04:40.820 --> 00:04:43.030

00:04:43.030 --> 00:04:45.680
The DS,

Because remember in IT,

we always have to have acronyms.

We don't speak in English.

Whatever language you might

It's interesting.

When you look at a wireless access

It's a wired device.

00:05:10.140 --> 00:05:15.070
The wireless access point, what its job

00:05:15.070 --> 00:05:18.650

00:05:18.650 --> 00:05:20.150
That's all it really is.

Now when you have a single

We're not talking BFF that's

We're talking about a basic service set.

00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:37.330
All right, now sometimes you

00:05:37.330 --> 00:05:38.590
Right?
So what can you have?

00:05:38.590 --> 00:05:41.800
Well, we can actually put two of

00:05:41.800 --> 00:05:48.980

00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:50.810
All right.

at you and we didn't explain what it is.

What's an SSID?

The SSID is an alphanumeric string that

122
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:00.320
It's called the Service Set Identifier.

123
00:06:00.320 --> 00:06:02.255
And when you look at your Computers.

In fact,
just right here on my computer, Justin,

I've got tons of SSIDs

00:06:08.425 --> 00:06:11.835
We just call them,
generically we call them network names.

127
00:06:11.835 --> 00:06:19.079
Well, if you have a single access point,
that is managed by, again, a single SSID.

128
00:06:19.079 --> 00:06:22.620
It's broadcasting a single SSID and
that's the only access point.

129
00:06:22.620 --> 00:06:24.210
You have a basic service set.

130
00:06:24.210 --> 00:06:29.620
The great thing is you can expand the
coverage area by two Putting two access

131
00:06:29.620 --> 00:06:35.080
points on the same network essentially,

132
00:06:35.080 --> 00:06:39.570
When they're joined together and both

134
00:06:44.760 --> 00:06:47.260
Think about it as extending

135
00:06:47.260 --> 00:06:49.450
this is where things like WiFi and
roaming come in.

136
00:06:49.450 --> 00:06:53.270
When I leave the proximity of one
access point we have something knwn as

the relative signal strength indicator

138
00:06:57.615 --> 00:07:00.375
I'm getting too far from this
one axis point it starts

139
00:07:00.375 --> 00:07:03.345

guess what.

140
00:07:03.345 --> 00:07:07.105
The next access point says yeah I
see you're part of the same network.

141
00:07:07.105 --> 00:07:11.215
I can see that you are part of the same
extended service set identifiers so

142
00:07:11.215 --> 00:07:12.995
it starts to manage these devices.

00:07:12.995 --> 00:07:16.815
And that's essentially what

00:07:18.100 --> 00:07:20.060

00:07:20.060 --> 00:07:22.630

00:07:22.630 --> 00:07:25.100

00:07:25.100 --> 00:07:28.740

00:07:28.740 --> 00:07:34.090

00:07:34.090 --> 00:07:39.820
Now the other thing that we also have to

00:07:44.070 --> 00:07:45.800

00:07:52.150 --> 00:07:53.835

00:07:53.835 --> 00:07:59.030
