00:19:36.491 --> 00:19:40.620
all devices will be interoperable,
and that's one of the great things.

370
00:19:40.620 --> 00:19:43.850
Remember that's one of reasons
that we kind of stress standards.

371
00:19:43.850 --> 00:19:49.009
Standards aren't put in place to make
Comptia candidates just blow their minds

372
00:19:49.009 --> 00:19:54.566
with all these different specifications,
but it's about that interoperability.

373
00:19:54.566 --> 00:19:59.169
Now understand that it's a low latency
transmission, and we're talking very,

374
00:19:59.169 --> 00:20:00.645
very small data packets.

375
00:20:00.645 --> 00:20:04.225
It also operates in the ISM band as well.

376
00:20:04.225 --> 00:20:10.810
It operates at right around
908.42 MHz here in North America.

377
00:20:10.810 --> 00:20:13.340
In Europe and other countries,
it's gonna be slightly different.

378
00:20:13.340 --> 00:20:16.204
It's got a 30 meter range.

379
00:20:16.204 --> 00:20:20.334
All right, so be aware of that too, and
one of the cool things that I really like

380
00:20:20.334 --> 00:20:24.714
about this, and I know that when it comes
to things like Internet of things, cuz all

381
00:20:24.714 --> 00:20:29.535
of these technologies, that's essentially
what they're supporting, and I know Justin

382
00:20:29.535 --> 00:20:33.690
that you've worked pretty heavily
with things like razzpies and stuff.

383
00:20:33.690 --> 00:20:38.497
And one of the things I really like about
Z-Wave devices is that, even though we

384
00:20:38.497 --> 00:20:42.899
have a 30 meter range, the messages
can actually hop up to four nodes.

385
00:20:42.899 --> 00:20:45.240
So they can daisy chain
across multiple devices.

386
00:20:45.240 --> 00:20:46.510
Really cool technology.

387
00:20:48.440 --> 00:20:49.920
Here's the drawback.

388
00:20:49.920 --> 00:20:51.794
It competes with cordless phones.

389
00:20:51.794 --> 00:20:56.914
It doesn't compete with Wi-Fi or
Bluetooth, but it does compete with other

390
00:20:56.914 --> 00:21:01.969
small devices to as well, but mainly
with things like the cordless phones.

391
00:21:01.969 --> 00:21:05.874
>> Now Wes I do have a clarifying
question, I think I understand, so

392
00:21:05.874 --> 00:21:10.489
if I can jump four nodes does that mean,
if I have enough Z-Wave components,

393
00:21:10.489 --> 00:21:15.370
at exactly 30 meters, than my effective
distance can be up to 120 meters?

394
00:21:15.370 --> 00:21:18.657
>> You can extend it, and that's why, and
then one of the reasons they did the whole

395
00:21:18.657 --> 00:21:24.190
four node hop is they thought,
well that should be adequate for

396
00:21:24.190 --> 00:21:27.640
anybody's house, as big as the house is.

397
00:21:27.640 --> 00:21:31.600
Now, if you're an athlete and
you make a lot of money,

398
00:21:31.600 --> 00:21:35.120
maybe you need five or [LAUGH] six hops,
maybe you need to pair them together, but

399
00:21:35.120 --> 00:21:40.840
for the most part, they figure that that
would be adequate for the average house.

400
00:21:40.840 --> 00:21:42.619
All right, so let's see what else now.

401
00:21:42.619 --> 00:21:44.955
Okay, so the next one we have in here,

402
00:21:44.955 --> 00:21:48.701
it looks like we're going to
the study of bugs here, Ant+.

403
00:21:48.701 --> 00:21:52.090
Ant+ is another wireless
communication protocol, and

404
00:21:52.090 --> 00:21:54.380
this one's used all over the place,
believe it or not.

405
00:21:54.380 --> 00:21:58.484
It's used in things like the medical
field, heart rate monitors,

406
00:21:58.484 --> 00:22:01.148
monitoring your vital signs and stuff, and

407
00:22:01.148 --> 00:22:06.416
reporting that information over a wireless
communication to a central nerve system.

408
00:22:06.416 --> 00:22:07.841
Not your nervous system, but

409
00:22:07.841 --> 00:22:11.920
a central like nerve device that would
be monitoring all the sensors and stuff.

410
00:22:11.920 --> 00:22:16.867
Things like your tires in your cars,
things like tire pressure.

411
00:22:16.867 --> 00:22:22.663
Home devices, I know fitness monitors
are a real big thing right now,

412
00:22:22.663 --> 00:22:25.423
so Ant+ is also in there as well.

413
00:22:25.423 --> 00:22:29.056
It also has its own
inoperability layer too.

414
00:22:29.056 --> 00:22:34.780
So, if, like Z-Wave,
if these devices are developed and

415
00:22:34.780 --> 00:22:39.230
made according to the Ant+ standard,
then they should be interoperable

416
00:22:39.230 --> 00:22:42.130
regardless of the vender
that you are working with.

417
00:22:42.130 --> 00:22:47.020
One of the things that it does is it
uses asynchronous communication, and

418
00:22:47.020 --> 00:22:50.170
the reason for
the asynchronous communication, remember,

419
00:22:50.170 --> 00:22:54.160
we say asynchronous, so A, against,

420
00:22:54.160 --> 00:22:59.870
synchronization, so it's against timing,
chronos, if you will, timing.

421
00:22:59.870 --> 00:23:03.570
Why is it against timings,
any kind of synchronize timing?

422
00:23:03.570 --> 00:23:06.640
Well that's because what
the designers wanted is,

423
00:23:06.640 --> 00:23:10.380
let's say that I have to send
a communication out to, I don't know,

424
00:23:10.380 --> 00:23:15.220
like any kind of device,
any kind of application.

425
00:23:15.220 --> 00:23:18.664
We want it to be able to
send at any time it wants.

426
00:23:18.664 --> 00:23:22.988
We basically only make an over
the air transmission when

427
00:23:22.988 --> 00:23:25.430
required by the application.

428
00:23:25.430 --> 00:23:27.639
So it's one of the reasons
they're asynchronous.

429
00:23:27.639 --> 00:23:30.486
It operates as well,
in the 2.4 GHz spectrum, and

430
00:23:30.486 --> 00:23:33.660
it uses something that we talked
about in another episode.

431
00:23:33.660 --> 00:23:37.261
Remember we talked about code
divisional multiple access, and

432
00:23:37.261 --> 00:23:40.328
we talked about time divisional
multiple access, and

433
00:23:40.328 --> 00:23:43.878
frequency divisional multiple access,
this just uses TDMA.

434
00:23:43.878 --> 00:23:47.755
So in order to spread that communication,
if you will,

435
00:23:47.755 --> 00:23:52.620
across the 2.4 GHz spectrum it uses
those discrete time slots, and

436
00:23:52.620 --> 00:23:57.333
it just reuses the time slots,
if you will, across that spectrum.

437
00:23:57.333 --> 00:23:58.880
All right, what else have we got, Justin?

438
00:23:58.880 --> 00:24:01.815
>> Now, I do have a quick
question about this AMP Plus.

439
00:24:01.815 --> 00:24:04.259
Because I think I've actually
seen a device like this,

440
00:24:04.259 --> 00:24:07.077
where it gathers a bunch of information,
like a heart monitor.

441
00:24:07.077 --> 00:24:12.035
And then when it regains connectivity,
it transmits all of this information,

442
00:24:12.035 --> 00:24:14.480
asynchronous transmission.

443
00:24:14.480 --> 00:24:17.690
The one question, though, are there
limitations to these end devices.

444
00:24:17.690 --> 00:24:19.739
Let's say I collect a lot of data.

445
00:24:19.739 --> 00:24:24.710
Is there a bandwidth limit or
do you just have to wait until it's done?

446
00:24:24.710 --> 00:24:25.602
Do you know?

447
00:24:25.602 --> 00:24:27.470
>> No, honestly, I'm not really sure.

448
00:24:27.470 --> 00:24:32.021
I haven't really studied on it that
much if we had any kind of bugging down,

449
00:24:32.021 --> 00:24:35.721
basically, chewing through all
the bandwidth on that one.

450
00:24:35.721 --> 00:24:40.070
All right,
let's see what is next that we have here?

451
00:24:40.070 --> 00:24:41.550
I guess we got a couple more,

452
00:24:41.550 --> 00:24:46.009
we've got one that's been around for a
while there, and that one's IR, infrared.

453
00:24:46.009 --> 00:24:49.304
Infrared is used in quite
a few different products.

454
00:24:49.304 --> 00:24:52.818
One of the products I can think
of right now that it's used for,

455
00:24:52.818 --> 00:24:56.610
is things like remote controls and
any kind of IRDA-based device.

456
00:24:56.610 --> 00:25:00.134
Now IRDA, just understand that the IRDA,
the infrared data association,

457
00:25:00.134 --> 00:25:04.061
they're essentially the consortium or
group that oversee the standards, right.

458
00:25:04.061 --> 00:25:08.080
With the one common one that we use today,
I always call it vFIR.

459
00:25:08.080 --> 00:25:09.420
Little v, FIR.

460
00:25:09.420 --> 00:25:13.454
Its very fast infrared, and
it operates at 6 megabits per second.

461
00:25:13.454 --> 00:25:19.210
And essentially, what it does is it
uses an LED to admit infrared radiation.

462
00:25:19.210 --> 00:25:19.940
And then it goes and

463
00:25:19.940 --> 00:25:24.990
it shoots through a plastic lens that
really focuses it into a very narrow beam.

464
00:25:24.990 --> 00:25:29.294
The wavelengths are akin to some of
the fiberoptic communications that we talk

465
00:25:29.294 --> 00:25:30.214
about, right.

466
00:25:30.214 --> 00:25:37.598
When we talk about signal mode, fiberoptic
communications, the wavelengths are 1330.

467
00:25:37.598 --> 00:25:42.491
So 1,330 nanometers or
the one that has the extremely long

468
00:25:42.491 --> 00:25:47.970
range fiber-optic communication,
the 1550 nanometers.

469
00:25:47.970 --> 00:25:51.760
Again, I'm not sure if they're
going to ask you that on the exam,

470
00:25:51.760 --> 00:25:53.080
you just never know.

471
00:25:53.080 --> 00:25:55.647
They might ask you a characteristic,
and if they do,

472
00:25:55.647 --> 00:25:57.823
hopefully you're gonna be prepared for it.

473
00:25:57.823 --> 00:26:02.694
All right, we've got two more that we need
to talk about, and I will go ahead and

474
00:26:02.694 --> 00:26:05.800
mention the first one here, NFC.

475
00:26:05.800 --> 00:26:07.890
We're looking at NFC,
that's Near Field Communication.

476
00:26:07.890 --> 00:26:11.570
A Near Field Communication essentially
enables your portable devices

477
00:26:11.570 --> 00:26:13.440
to establish a communication.

478
00:26:13.440 --> 00:26:16.740
And all you have to do is bring them
within a few centimeters of each other.

479
00:26:16.740 --> 00:26:20.833
I believe the standard normally,
calls out like four centimeters, but

480
00:26:20.833 --> 00:26:22.748
very, very close to each other.

481
00:26:22.748 --> 00:26:27.710
And also operates in the ISM band
at around 13.56 megahertz and

482
00:26:27.710 --> 00:26:31.590
the data rates here very small packages

483
00:26:31.590 --> 00:26:36.550
bout 106k on up to about
424 kilobits per second, so

484
00:26:36.550 --> 00:26:42.840
really really small data packets, and
again I say small by todays standards.

485
00:26:42.840 --> 00:26:47.978
All right, last one, last one we need
to talk about is RFID, and again, RFID

486
00:26:47.978 --> 00:26:53.614
uses electromagnetic fields to identify,
and track, and tag different objects.

487
00:26:53.614 --> 00:26:55.491
It operates at, it depends,

488
00:26:55.491 --> 00:27:00.894
it's gotta couple of different ranges that
it operates in, give an example of some,

489
00:27:00.894 --> 00:27:06.597
you can, they'll operate at an around 120
K, all the way really up to 10 gigahertz,

490
00:27:06.597 --> 00:27:11.550
so you can see there's a pretty wide
spectrum that RFID will operate in.

491
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:14.490
Some of the common uses of it
are like your smart cards for

492
00:27:14.490 --> 00:27:17.810
smart card authentication,
that's the 1356 that it operates at.

493
00:27:17.810 --> 00:27:24.250
Just in the same range,
if you will, and frequency as NFC.

494
00:27:24.250 --> 00:27:28.732
You can do things like for
instance, tracking animals, goods,

495
00:27:28.732 --> 00:27:30.340
people, if you want.

496
00:27:30.340 --> 00:27:32.650
[LAUGH] Things like your contact list,
payment systems,

497
00:27:32.650 --> 00:27:36.110
if you've ever used those, where you've
touched your phone to a payment system.

498
00:27:36.110 --> 00:27:39.890
Android Pay, Apple Pay, I think are some
of the kinds that we have out there

499
00:27:39.890 --> 00:27:45.480
as well as even your travel documents
have RFID chips built into them too.

500
00:27:45.480 --> 00:27:49.480
Now, there is one that is mentioned,
but I don't have on the list.

501
00:27:49.480 --> 00:27:53.142
And why is that, because we've talked
heavily about it in other episodes, and

502
00:27:53.142 --> 00:27:54.302
that's 802.11.

503
00:27:54.302 --> 00:27:58.738
Go back and watch our episodes where
we talk about each one of the 802.11

504
00:27:58.738 --> 00:28:03.652
standards just in case they ask you a
question on it, but remember the 802.11 is

505
00:28:03.652 --> 00:28:08.940
technically the IEEE's implementation
of a wireless local area network.

506
00:28:08.940 --> 00:28:13.880
>> Well, Wes, you've definitely helped
us kind of ease through these variety

507
00:28:13.880 --> 00:28:16.920
network biologies and
associated technologies.

508
00:28:16.920 --> 00:28:19.080
But before we get out of here for
this part two,

509
00:28:19.080 --> 00:28:22.240
are there any parting words that
you'd like to leave us with?

510
00:28:22.240 --> 00:28:26.860
>> Yeah, Justin, I got so excited with all
the different ANs, the LAN, WAN, WLANs,

511
00:28:26.860 --> 00:28:30.880
that I forgot a couple that are important
enough, we've got to mention them here.

512
00:28:30.880 --> 00:28:32.120
So we want you to be aware of them.

513
00:28:32.120 --> 00:28:35.935
In fact, one of them, I've actually
got pulled up on my screen and

514
00:28:35.935 --> 00:28:39.087
that is what is known as
a Storage Area Network, a SAN.

515
00:28:39.087 --> 00:28:43.722
Understand that a SAN essentially is
a way to aggregate drives together, and

516
00:28:43.722 --> 00:28:47.997
typically, what happens is you'll
have these, they call them SANs,

517
00:28:47.997 --> 00:28:51.878
the SAN device, right, and
it will have a bunch of hard drives.

518
00:28:51.878 --> 00:28:54.610
Now, where are these hard
drives are located is,

519
00:28:54.610 --> 00:28:59.200
it really could be all across the network
hence, the term storage area network.

520
00:28:59.200 --> 00:29:02.906
And that what you'll have depending
on how you want to implement this,

521
00:29:02.906 --> 00:29:07.359
usually, they're fairly expensive
implementations, we're talking starting at

522
00:29:07.359 --> 00:29:11.216
around anyone worth their weight
about 50 to $70,000, right?

523
00:29:11.216 --> 00:29:13.744
So very, very expensive,
high speed fiber optic

524
00:29:13.744 --> 00:29:17.840
communications that's where we get
terms like fiber channel, right?

525
00:29:17.840 --> 00:29:21.781
What you'll have is, you'll have things
like your servers will have what are known

526
00:29:21.781 --> 00:29:25.568
as HBA's, host bus adapters, and then
that will connect into fiber switches.

527
00:29:25.568 --> 00:29:30.066
And you can see there is a whole bunch
of spaghetti all over this diagram,

528
00:29:30.066 --> 00:29:32.965
because they want high speed and
redundancy.

529
00:29:32.965 --> 00:29:37.125
So you'll end up seeing that you have
these fiber channel switches, and then you

530
00:29:37.125 --> 00:29:41.467
have what's known as you switch fabric and
you can see enough lines there that almost

531
00:29:41.467 --> 00:29:45.843
makes some fabric, and then you typically
have redundancy into the storage array.

532
00:29:45.843 --> 00:29:49.337
And that's essentially what
these storage network is.

533
00:29:49.337 --> 00:29:55.748
It's a way that you can give access to
network or network disks, if you will.

534
00:29:55.748 --> 00:30:00.528
Hard drives that are in systems that
can be distributed across the entire

535
00:30:00.528 --> 00:30:04.780
network or in a single enclosure,
depending on how you have it set up.

536
00:30:04.780 --> 00:30:08.331
Now, one of the other ones that we need
to be aware of is what is known as a MAN,

537
00:30:08.331 --> 00:30:08.897
all right.

538
00:30:08.897 --> 00:30:12.411
Now, a MAN is a Metropolitan Area Network,
all right.

539
00:30:12.411 --> 00:30:17.908
And a metropolitan area network I want you
to think of it as really the geographical

540
00:30:17.908 --> 00:30:22.380
coverage area there is going to be
kind of like a city, if you will.

541
00:30:22.380 --> 00:30:24.610
That's why they call it
a metropolitan area network and

542
00:30:24.610 --> 00:30:28.310
I've got an example of a couple
of different technologies here.

543
00:30:28.310 --> 00:30:31.160
Nothing really fancy here
as far as the diagram goes.

544
00:30:31.160 --> 00:30:36.188
But metro Ethernet is one,
because metro Ethernet is a cheap

545
00:30:36.188 --> 00:30:42.904
implementation that ISPs can provide
a service to business users, if you will.

546
00:30:42.904 --> 00:30:46.508
The other one is WiMAX,
now, I will say WiMAX,

547
00:30:46.508 --> 00:30:51.480
WiMAX was part of that whole 4G
technology long term evolution.

548
00:30:51.480 --> 00:30:54.940
LTE is the one that actually won out,
and that's what everybody uses today.

549
00:30:54.940 --> 00:30:57.905
But the wireless interoperability for
microwave access or

550
00:30:57.905 --> 00:31:02.210
802.16 was one of those
competing technologies, and

551
00:31:02.210 --> 00:31:07.866
it literally is what they call
a wireless metropolitan area network.

552
00:31:07.866 --> 00:31:10.970
Now, a WMAN isn't called out on the exam,

553
00:31:10.970 --> 00:31:14.170
but if you're gonna talk about
a metropolitan area network,

554
00:31:14.170 --> 00:31:17.620
you'll almost have to talk about WiMAX,
and WiMAX technically,

555
00:31:17.620 --> 00:31:22.990
even though it is a metropolitan
area network, type if you will.

556
00:31:22.990 --> 00:31:24.724
It is a wireless communication.

557
00:31:24.724 --> 00:31:28.594
Right now, the last one that we have to
talk about real quick and is one that I

558
00:31:28.594 --> 00:31:32.711
don't have a diagram and I know that
you've worked for colleges before, so you

559
00:31:32.711 --> 00:31:37.216
probably understand this one really well,
and that's campus area network, right?

560
00:31:37.216 --> 00:31:39.980
Here in Gainesville,
we have the University of Florida.

561
00:31:39.980 --> 00:31:43.225
University of Florida has buildings
all over Gainesville, and

562
00:31:43.225 --> 00:31:46.963
their buildings are interconnected
together their on network, right?

563
00:31:46.963 --> 00:31:51.816
So, a campus area network is typically
one of these networks that can span

564
00:31:51.816 --> 00:31:53.330
across the city.

565
00:31:53.330 --> 00:31:58.299
But it's under the control of a single,
you know academic institution, right, and

566
00:31:58.299 --> 00:32:00.585
hence, the term campus area network.

567
00:32:00.585 --> 00:32:04.955
UF, again, is a classic example of one
of these cans, cuz they have, again,

568
00:32:04.955 --> 00:32:08.145
buildings everywhere and they have one
massive network that they're connected to.

569
00:32:08.145 --> 00:32:11.585
So just a few things there,
Justin, that we had to wrap up.

570
00:32:11.585 --> 00:32:16.510
Do keep in mind, though, for
your exam know these different networks,

571
00:32:16.510 --> 00:32:17.730
know the different network types.

572
00:32:17.730 --> 00:32:22.350
Know the technologies that support IoT,
Internet of things.

573
00:32:22.350 --> 00:32:26.537
Again, things like your Z-wave,
Amp Plus, right, Bluetooth.

574
00:32:26.537 --> 00:32:30.884
We've talked about 802.11 as well,
and you should be doing good for

575
00:32:30.884 --> 00:32:32.930
your next Net+ exam.

576
00:32:32.930 --> 00:32:34.980
>> Well, Wes, you definitely
have some added value there.

577
00:32:34.980 --> 00:32:39.643
Leaving no stone unturned as we continue
our venture into CompTIA's Network+.

578
00:32:39.643 --> 00:32:43.129
Wow, I messed that up, but
we are done with this episode, but

579
00:32:43.129 --> 00:32:45.290
we do have more on Net+ coming at you.

580
00:32:45.290 --> 00:32:46.930
So definitely stay tuned, so

581
00:32:46.930 --> 00:32:49.890
signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I have been your host Justin Dennison.

582
00:32:49.890 --> 00:32:50.676
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

583
00:32:50.676 --> 00:32:52.730
>> And we'll see you next time.

584

446
00:25:38.650 --> 00:25:41.820
So, that's time-divisional multiplexing.

447
00:25:41.820 --> 00:25:46.260
The other one is CDMA, and
CDMA is interesting, all right?

448
00:25:46.260 --> 00:25:52.444
It uses what's known as a spread
spectrum technologies as well.

449
00:25:52.444 --> 00:25:57.105
Again spreading that information that,
those communications, if you will,

450
00:25:57.105 --> 00:25:59.480
amongst all those different channels.

451
00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:01.220
But it does it a little different, right?

452
00:26:01.220 --> 00:26:05.280
It doesn't use time slots, right,
like time divisional multiplexing does.

453
00:26:05.280 --> 00:26:06.400
This uses codes.

454
00:26:07.680 --> 00:26:11.960
And a code I want you to think
of as a language, all right?

455
00:26:11.960 --> 00:26:13.430
The sender and receiver,

456
00:26:13.430 --> 00:26:16.950
they have to be speaking the same language
in order to understand the communication.

457
00:26:16.950 --> 00:26:20.020
So if I assign a code to Zach and
assign that same code to myself, and

458
00:26:20.020 --> 00:26:21.580
again it's the underlying technology.

459
00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:22.800
I'm not gonna do anything here, right?

460
00:26:22.800 --> 00:26:24.860
It's built-in to the technology and
Zach and

461
00:26:24.860 --> 00:26:28.060
I can communicate within that spectrum,
right?

462
00:26:28.060 --> 00:26:32.144
If somebody else, I give you an example,
I love Mexican food,

463
00:26:32.144 --> 00:26:35.856
absolutely love me some guacamole now,
let me tell you.

464
00:26:35.856 --> 00:26:37.729
But if I'm sitting down
in a restaurant and

465
00:26:37.729 --> 00:26:41.109
we have a family that's sitting next to
me, and I wish I could speak Spanish,

466
00:26:41.109 --> 00:26:45.540
I'm still wanna learn beautiful language,
but I don't speak Spanish, right?

467
00:26:45.540 --> 00:26:49.284
So if they're sitting next to me, and
let's say they're communicating, right?

468
00:26:49.284 --> 00:26:51.470
They're speaking in a different language.

469
00:26:51.470 --> 00:26:52.590
It's not meant for me.

470
00:26:52.590 --> 00:26:53.920
And because I don't know that language

471
00:26:53.920 --> 00:26:56.980
I can't partake in that communication,
right?

472
00:26:56.980 --> 00:26:57.890
That's what a code is.

473
00:26:57.890 --> 00:27:00.270
All right, so when we say code
divisional multiple access,

474
00:27:00.270 --> 00:27:02.860
your codes have to match
from the sender or receiver.

475
00:27:02.860 --> 00:27:06.200
All right and we can use multiple codes
within that bandwidth, right, and

476
00:27:06.200 --> 00:27:09.390
spread those different communication
channels based on the codes,

477
00:27:09.390 --> 00:27:11.550
provided the sender and
receiver have the same code.

478
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:13.630
That's code divisional multiple access.

479
00:27:13.630 --> 00:27:15.970
I'm just gonna throw one out here for
you guys and gals.

480
00:27:15.970 --> 00:27:18.930
Cuz I don't like leaving
this one this way.

481
00:27:18.930 --> 00:27:23.620
Cuz there's another one there, and
that's something known as frequency

482
00:27:25.130 --> 00:27:28.330
FDMA, frequency divisional
multiple access.

483
00:27:28.330 --> 00:27:31.150
I said multiplexing, let me back up here.

484
00:27:31.150 --> 00:27:33.220
Time divisional multiple access,

485
00:27:33.220 --> 00:27:37.940
that's the A part there is no I
don't know why I said multiplexing.

486
00:27:37.940 --> 00:27:39.460
Multiplexing in general says hey,

487
00:27:39.460 --> 00:27:44.550
how can I take more than one signal and
combine it over the same medium?

488
00:27:44.550 --> 00:27:49.160
Again, with time divisional multiple
access, it's discrete time slots.

489
00:27:49.160 --> 00:27:52.520
Code divisional multiple access,
its codes, languages,

490
00:27:52.520 --> 00:27:54.770
if you think about them codes or
languages right?

491
00:27:54.770 --> 00:27:59.700
The best way I can think of how to explain
it, you don't understand the language?

492
00:27:59.700 --> 00:28:00.990
You're not a part of the communication.

493
00:28:00.990 --> 00:28:01.680
You don't have the code?

494
00:28:01.680 --> 00:28:03.280
You are not a part of that communication.

495
00:28:03.280 --> 00:28:08.440
But the last one I do wanna kinda
mention even though it's not in the exam

496
00:28:08.440 --> 00:28:14.116
objectives and that's FDMA,
frequency division multiple access, right.

497
00:28:14.116 --> 00:28:17.332
So if I have one person,
in fact let's go back to my diagram,

498
00:28:17.332 --> 00:28:20.730
let's say we've got all these
individual frequencies.

499
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:27.561
It means I can have somebody, it's also
called frequency hopping spread spectrum.

500
00:28:27.561 --> 00:28:31.916
And this means that the transceiver, or
not the transceiver the transmitter and

501
00:28:31.916 --> 00:28:36.290
the receiver have to know beforehand
just like codes, just like time slots.

502
00:28:36.290 --> 00:28:38.980
They have to know what the frequency
is as they're gonna change.

503
00:28:38.980 --> 00:28:41.345
This goes all the way
back to the late1800s.

504
00:28:41.345 --> 00:28:44.075
And this would be where,

505
00:28:44.075 --> 00:28:47.165
let's say that Zach and
I are communicating at this point.

506
00:28:47.165 --> 00:28:52.858
We're communicating on channel
one at 2,412 megahertz.

507
00:28:52.858 --> 00:28:55.475
He has to be on 4,012 megahertz as well.

508
00:28:55.475 --> 00:28:58.835
But then we jump up,
all right, and we jump up.

509
00:28:58.835 --> 00:29:04.680
Now, we're operating on 4,000 or
excuse me, 2,417 megahertz.

510
00:29:04.680 --> 00:29:07.510
And we hop through the spectrum.

511
00:29:07.510 --> 00:29:10.860
That means once we hop to two or
we hop to three or

512
00:29:10.860 --> 00:29:12.360
in this, case non-overlapping channels,

513
00:29:12.360 --> 00:29:16.900
I go from one and I go to six, well that
means in somebody else can use one, right.

514
00:29:16.900 --> 00:29:18.220
Why can they use one?

515
00:29:18.220 --> 00:29:19.820
I'm not using it anymore.

516
00:29:19.820 --> 00:29:21.970
And we can keep hopping through
the different channels.

517
00:29:21.970 --> 00:29:27.010
And that's how you can have multiple,
independent communications within the same

518
00:29:27.010 --> 00:29:30.830
domain like that, cuz you're hopping
through the different channels, all right?

519
00:29:30.830 --> 00:29:32.200
So those are some of the things and

520
00:29:32.200 --> 00:29:36.270
some of the technologies that we want you
to be aware of when it comes to the exam.

521
00:29:36.270 --> 00:29:38.110
Remember, I know it's a lot of standards.

522
00:29:38.110 --> 00:29:39.480
I know it's a lot of specifications.

523
00:29:39.480 --> 00:29:42.660
But if you can get these under your belts
now, you're gonna be doing great for

524
00:29:42.660 --> 00:29:44.170
the next Network+ exam.

525
00:29:44.170 --> 00:29:47.650
>> And you're very fortunate, because this
is a video that you can watch again, and

526
00:29:47.650 --> 00:29:50.940
again, and again when it's finally
mounted to our course library.

527
00:29:50.940 --> 00:29:54.730
So this has been Wireless Technologies,
great episode.

528
00:29:54.730 --> 00:29:57.730
In fact, in the CompTia Net+ series,
watch them all.

529
00:29:57.730 --> 00:29:59.210
They're all fantastic.

530
00:29:59.210 --> 00:30:00.490
Wes did a great job.

531
00:30:00.490 --> 00:30:03.580
And in that course library, you're
gonna find hundreds of other videos.

532
00:30:03.580 --> 00:30:07.240
They're all created for one purpose,
to help you go further.

533
00:30:07.240 --> 00:30:10.470
And thank you for watching ITProTV,
tell everybody you know about ITProTV!

534
00:30:10.470 --> 00:30:11.780
They'll be glad you did.

535
00:30:11.780 --> 00:30:12.580
I'm Zach Memos.

536
00:30:12.580 --> 00:30:13.390
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

537
00:30:13.390 --> 00:30:14.979
>> And we will see you soon.

538
00:30:14.979 --> 00:30:21.945
[MUSIC]

539
00:30:21.945 --> 00:30:24.984
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Justin and Wes explore technologies that help to support the cloud. They look at the different services offered by cloud providers such as SaaS, PaaS and IaaS as well as the delivery models.
episodes.title: Cloud Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:02.390
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.390 --> 00:00:05.230
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.230 --> 00:00:08.276
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.276 --> 00:00:11.810
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.810 --> 00:00:15.744
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.744 --> 00:00:20.950
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
we're back in CompTia Network Plus LAN.

7
00:00:20.950 --> 00:00:23.670
More specifically, we're gonna be
looking at some cloud concepts today.

8
00:00:23.670 --> 00:00:28.663
And luckily, we have a very special
individual in the studio today to lead us,

9
00:00:28.663 --> 00:00:32.005
to guide us to be, our one and
only, Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:32.005 --> 00:00:32.830
How are you doing today, Wes?

11
00:00:32.830 --> 00:00:35.610
>> Hey, I'm doing great, Justin,
thanks for having me back here.

12
00:00:35.610 --> 00:00:38.790
And that is right, we're gonna put
our heads in the clouds, right?

13
00:00:38.790 --> 00:00:42.140
[LAUGH] But more importantly,
what is the cloud?

14
00:00:42.140 --> 00:00:43.990
Well, the cloud,
it's an interesting thing.

15
00:00:43.990 --> 00:00:45.510
You say, well,
where does the cloud reside?

16
00:00:45.510 --> 00:00:48.720
Well, the cloud resides a little here,
a little there, and really,

17
00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:50.280
just a bit of everywhere.

18
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:53.170
Essentially what you're doing is,
you're paying a provider.

19
00:00:53.170 --> 00:00:57.500
And you're using some form
of their resources, right?

20
00:00:57.500 --> 00:00:59.445
Whether it be maybe network components,

21
00:00:59.445 --> 00:01:03.150
maybe a way it'd be development
environments, right, firewalls.

22
00:01:03.150 --> 00:01:06.150
You're essentially paying
another provider, and

23
00:01:06.150 --> 00:01:08.280
they provide you with a service.

24
00:01:08.280 --> 00:01:12.400
>> So as a real quick question about
those service, when you say service,

25
00:01:12.400 --> 00:01:13.800
that seems like a very broad term.

26
00:01:13.800 --> 00:01:17.150
What are some services, that if I am
paying a provider, what am I getting back?

27
00:01:17.150 --> 00:01:19.440
>> Well, that's a great question, Justin.

28
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:22.740
The fact, I guess it really just
depends on what you need, all right?

29
00:01:22.740 --> 00:01:26.000
When it boils down, we typically have
three different kinds of services.

30
00:01:26.000 --> 00:01:30.540
Three of the common services, I want you
to understand that there are more and

31
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:34.960
more services being added probably,
as we speak right now [LAUGH] and

32
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:35.800
we don't even know it.

33
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:41.306
But they call out on the exam three of
the main services offerings if you will,

34
00:01:41.306 --> 00:01:43.773
that have been around for awhile.

35
00:01:43.773 --> 00:01:47.257
The very first one up we're gonna talk
about, you probably use and have used for

36
00:01:47.257 --> 00:01:49.130
a while and maybe you didn't even know it.

37
00:01:49.130 --> 00:01:51.600
Maybe you didn't even know that
that's what you were doing, right?

38
00:01:51.600 --> 00:01:55.110
I want you to think of your email service,
all right?

39
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:59.370
I haven't really paid for
an email service in a very long time,

40
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:03.020
but I do get the ability
of sending emails.

41
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:05.050
Well, who is it that manages and
maintains that?

42
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:07.860
Well, it depends on which provider
you're talking about, but for

43
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:09.720
the most part I use Gmail, right?

44
00:02:09.720 --> 00:02:12.000
Gmail, Google's Gmail if you will.

45
00:02:12.000 --> 00:02:15.850
But we have things like Hotmail that are
out, I know it's Outlook.com today, right?

46
00:02:15.850 --> 00:02:19.380
You have things like Ymail or
you just call it Yahoo Mail, right?

47
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:23.775
But these providers are essentially
giving you a service basically

48
00:02:23.775 --> 00:02:26.404
allowing you to use their application.

49
00:02:26.404 --> 00:02:27.980
And thats one of the fist offerings.

50
00:02:27.980 --> 00:02:31.430
In fact, Ive got a little slide here or
a diagram here and

51
00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:34.300
its whats know as software as a service,
right?

52
00:02:34.300 --> 00:02:40.060
Software as a service, you probably
seen it abbreviated before, SaaS, right?

53
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:45.780
This is where you have a provider and
they are essentially going to manage and

54
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:51.290
maintain applications, and they're gonna
let you access their applications.

55
00:02:51.290 --> 00:02:52.560
Again, provided as a service.

56
00:02:52.560 --> 00:02:54.790
Now sometimes you get a free services.

57
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:56.060
Sometimes you don't have to pay.

58
00:02:56.060 --> 00:02:58.010
But on the business side of things,

59
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:02.030
if you're going like what we use here
at ITProTV, we use Office 365, right?

60
00:03:02.030 --> 00:03:05.216
Microsoft's software as a service
offering, or a portion of it.

61
00:03:05.216 --> 00:03:08.500
Right, they have got a lot of different
services that they provide but

62
00:03:08.500 --> 00:03:09.680
it gives you an example, right?

63
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:12.710
So for instance,
I can log into a web interface and

64
00:03:12.710 --> 00:03:16.180
that's one of the great things
about the software as a service,

65
00:03:16.180 --> 00:03:20.840
is that a lot of times with software as
a service if we're using an application.

66
00:03:20.840 --> 00:03:23.490
We access it through a web browser,
and that's great.

67
00:03:23.490 --> 00:03:27.010
Why, cuz the web browser is
commonly built into your devices.

68
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:31.203
Most of your devices that you use will
have some form of web browser build right

69
00:03:31.203 --> 00:03:31.858
into them.

70
00:03:31.858 --> 00:03:34.826
Now, that doesn't mean that I'm
using software as a service that

71
00:03:34.826 --> 00:03:36.920
you're only gonna go
through a web browser.

72
00:03:36.920 --> 00:03:40.568
A lot of times they have stand alone apps
too that allow you to perform the same

73
00:03:40.568 --> 00:03:41.595
functionality, but

74
00:03:41.595 --> 00:03:45.375
at least it allows you that functionality
without additional applications.

75
00:03:45.375 --> 00:03:50.676
The one of the great things about this too
is that, if you are using an application,

76
00:03:50.676 --> 00:03:55.320
again software as a service,
they're maintaining the updates.

77
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:59.980
They maintain things like
as the platform develops,

78
00:03:59.980 --> 00:04:01.910
you don't have to worry about that.

79
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:06.100
They maintain it,
they give you things like redundancy and

80
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:09.190
for the most part, a lot of times,
you don't even see outages, right?

81
00:04:09.190 --> 00:04:13.971
So that's a great thing and as a company,
sometimes it's inconvenient if you

82
00:04:13.971 --> 00:04:17.534
have a very very small IT staff
which a lot of companies do.

83
00:04:17.534 --> 00:04:21.513
And maybe you don't want to
maintain an on-premise server.

84
00:04:21.513 --> 00:04:23.801
All right,
that's what we call a local resource and

85
00:04:23.801 --> 00:04:27.703
that relationship between local resources
and cloud resources just essentially says,

86
00:04:27.703 --> 00:04:29.900
if I have local resources,
we're gonna have to.

87
00:04:29.900 --> 00:04:31.980
My company's gonna have to manage and
maintain them.

88
00:04:31.980 --> 00:04:35.000
If I have an email server, and
I want access to an email platform?

89
00:04:35.000 --> 00:04:39.370
Well guess what,
we've got to deploy or install,

90
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:43.360
if you will, that email client
across every one of our devices.

91
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:46.360
That's gonna connect back to our email
server, and then we're gonna have

92
00:04:46.360 --> 00:04:49.970
a system administrator that manages and
maintains that server.

93
00:04:49.970 --> 00:04:52.520
Which means there's a potential
something could have down time,

94
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:55.160
if something on that server fails,
all right?

95
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:58.030
So that's another one of the benefits
that you are offloading that

96
00:04:58.030 --> 00:05:00.290
basically to the service provider.

97
00:05:00.290 --> 00:05:03.200
And they provide that service for
whatever the fee might be.

98
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:08.890
So that is one of the very first services
that I want you to be aware of, and again,

99
00:05:08.890 --> 00:05:12.850
like I said, you've probably used it
before and maybe didn't even know it.

100
00:05:12.850 --> 00:05:18.370
Now, the next service that we have
is what is known as infrastructure.

101
00:05:18.370 --> 00:05:20.030
Infrastructure as a service, right?

102
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:22.240
Now, with infrastructure as a service,

103
00:05:22.240 --> 00:05:27.350
I got a little diagram here just to
kinda show what IaaS does, right?

104
00:05:27.350 --> 00:05:29.105
This provides things
like your computation,

105
00:05:29.105 --> 00:05:30.590
your computer resources, all right?

106
00:05:31.610 --> 00:05:34.920
Things for instance,
your memory, your storage.

107
00:05:34.920 --> 00:05:38.330
Things like network and communications,
your operating systems, your servers.

108
00:05:38.330 --> 00:05:41.500
And you might be saying,
they give you a physical server?

109
00:05:41.500 --> 00:05:44.900
No, not really, because one of
the things you have to keep in mind

110
00:05:44.900 --> 00:05:47.940
that almost go hand in hand is
virtualization technologies which we'll

111
00:05:47.940 --> 00:05:50.490
talk about in other episodes,
and cloud based technologies.

112
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:55.470
Right, I want you to think about
the ability to, or maybe you require.

113
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:58.739
You require setting up a web server,
right?

114
00:05:58.739 --> 00:06:02.490
For redundancy,
you wanna set up maybe a web server farm.

115
00:06:02.490 --> 00:06:04.240
So you wanna have multiple web servers.

116
00:06:04.240 --> 00:06:08.677
Well, that takes a lot of money,
a lot of time, a lot of resources.

117
00:06:08.677 --> 00:06:13.050
A lot of money has to be invested into
those devices, a lot of power concerns,

118
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:14.220
if you will.

119
00:06:14.220 --> 00:06:18.570
Imagine the ability to offload
that service to somebody else,

120
00:06:18.570 --> 00:06:22.970
to another provider and they,
in the background, have the servers,

121
00:06:22.970 --> 00:06:26.450
have the networking cable,
have the memory.

122
00:06:26.450 --> 00:06:30.300
The storage and
they maintain that for you, right?

123
00:06:30.300 --> 00:06:33.020
The other great thing about things
like infrastructure as a service,

124
00:06:33.020 --> 00:06:34.940
is rapid deployment.

125
00:06:34.940 --> 00:06:39.564
Right, I don't have to wait for a server
to come in, sit it in the server closet,

126
00:06:39.564 --> 00:06:43.780
still in the box and let it acclimate
itself to the server room temperature

127
00:06:43.780 --> 00:06:47.020
before I take it out and
then we install it, right?

128
00:06:47.020 --> 00:06:48.690
Once we install it in the rack mounts,

129
00:06:48.690 --> 00:06:52.670
then we install the operating system,
just for a single server.

130
00:06:52.670 --> 00:06:53.860
It can be a lot.

131
00:06:53.860 --> 00:06:57.510
But imagine the ability just to spin
up an instance of a device and say,

132
00:06:57.510 --> 00:07:00.080
I want this amount of memory,

00:19:07.350 --> 00:19:09.830
You could be, but
you might not be aware of it.

361
00:19:09.830 --> 00:19:13.367
Scheduled updates and maintenance,
we've kind of already talked about.

362
00:19:13.367 --> 00:19:15.580
Expense allocation, all right?

363
00:19:15.580 --> 00:19:20.500
This is a great way to say hey,
I needed ten servers for whatever,

364
00:19:20.500 --> 00:19:22.630
24 hours, and
then we scale it back down, all right?

365
00:19:22.630 --> 00:19:26.700
Then we can do charge back, and
we know we could do metering,

366
00:19:26.700 --> 00:19:29.320
if you will, charge metering a lot easier.

367
00:19:29.320 --> 00:19:34.170
And then, last but not least is,
well, environmental impact, right?

368
00:19:34.170 --> 00:19:37.660
Think about the extra power it takes to
maintain those servers in a server closet,

369
00:19:37.660 --> 00:19:40.890
that you would have on constantly, right?

370
00:19:40.890 --> 00:19:42.180
So if that's something that you're into,

371
00:19:42.180 --> 00:19:46.230
you can think about reducing your
overall carbon footprint, too.

372
00:19:46.230 --> 00:19:49.060
Now, there are some security
implementations, or

373
00:19:49.060 --> 00:19:51.792
implications I should say,
things that you have to consider.

374
00:19:51.792 --> 00:19:54.920
Any time you're using
a public cloud solution,

375
00:19:54.920 --> 00:19:57.010
you have what's known as multitenancy.

376
00:19:57.010 --> 00:20:01.560
Multitenancy just means that you know
that you have more than one company

377
00:20:01.560 --> 00:20:05.310
that is going to use that provider, right?

378
00:20:05.310 --> 00:20:07.907
I couldn't tell you how many,
as big as Amazon or AWS is,

379
00:20:07.907 --> 00:20:11.861
I couldn't tell you how many thousands and
thousands if not hundreds of thousands, or

380
00:20:11.861 --> 00:20:13.595
millions of customers they have, but

381
00:20:13.595 --> 00:20:17.577
there are multiple customers within a
single platform, it's called multitenancy.

382
00:20:17.577 --> 00:20:22.390
So you have to pay attention to
how they handle that, right?

383
00:20:22.390 --> 00:20:25.470
Because you don't have to worry
about virtual environment

384
00:20:25.470 --> 00:20:27.320
escaping techniques, right?

385
00:20:27.320 --> 00:20:30.650
So there are security concerns
that we have to be aware of.

386
00:20:30.650 --> 00:20:31.640
Privacy, right?

387
00:20:31.640 --> 00:20:35.040
You have to pay attention to the privacy
in the service level agreements, right?

388
00:20:35.040 --> 00:20:38.020
Data location could be another thing
that might be important to you as well.

389
00:20:38.020 --> 00:20:40.930
Especially if you're talking
about data standards, right?

390
00:20:40.930 --> 00:20:45.752
What is customer data versus
the company data, PII,

391
00:20:45.752 --> 00:20:48.660
if we have personally
identifiable information.

392
00:20:48.660 --> 00:20:50.830
If we're worried about things like PCI,
DSS, or

393
00:20:50.830 --> 00:20:54.220
the payment card information,
data security standards, right?

394
00:20:54.220 --> 00:20:56.940
Do we have to follow under
things like HIPAA compliance?

395
00:20:56.940 --> 00:20:59.030
Well then, we have to look, and
we have to read those laws.

396
00:20:59.030 --> 00:21:02.510
We have to be aware of the information
security standards and

397
00:21:02.510 --> 00:21:05.080
make sure that if you
are using a cloud provider,

398
00:21:05.080 --> 00:21:10.470
and you used the example of backing
that information up to the cloud.

399
00:21:10.470 --> 00:21:11.630
Where is it stored?

400
00:21:11.630 --> 00:21:13.090
Is it stored in a secure location?

401
00:21:13.090 --> 00:21:14.610
Who has access to it?

402
00:21:14.610 --> 00:21:15.660
You don't know.

403
00:21:15.660 --> 00:21:17.030
That's things that you need find out.

404
00:21:17.030 --> 00:21:20.261
And that's also things that you need to
secure before you decide what you're gonna

405
00:21:20.261 --> 00:21:23.472
store in the cloud and what you're
not gonna store in the cloud, right?

406
00:21:23.472 --> 00:21:26.436
If they're local resources, they're
on-prem, you mentioned that term, on-prem,

407
00:21:26.436 --> 00:21:28.667
on premise, that means you're managing,
you're maintaining.

408
00:21:28.667 --> 00:21:31.767
I mean you can secure them a little bit
better when you move them up to the cloud

409
00:21:31.767 --> 00:21:33.522
and they become a cloud-based resource.

410
00:21:33.522 --> 00:21:36.734
It's up to you to read the documentation,
to make sure that

411
00:21:36.734 --> 00:21:41.540
the data that you put up in the cloud
does maintain its level of security.

412
00:21:41.540 --> 00:21:43.470
These are just a few of
the topics when it comes, and

413
00:21:43.470 --> 00:21:45.260
we really just scratched
the surface with the cloud.

414
00:21:45.260 --> 00:21:50.638
Keep in mind that they are adding all
different types of as a services,

415
00:21:50.638 --> 00:21:53.760
storage-as-a-service,
security-as-a-service, right?

416
00:21:53.760 --> 00:21:55.105
Many more database-as-a-service.

417
00:21:55.105 --> 00:21:58.811
So these are just three of
the most common ones that

418
00:21:58.811 --> 00:22:03.790
we want you to be aware of on
the Network+ exam and so does CompTIA.

419
00:22:03.790 --> 00:22:05.960
>> Well Wes, you've definitely
illuminated some of the things that

420
00:22:05.960 --> 00:22:10.760
we need to consider when using cloud-based
technology, so thank you so much for that.

421
00:22:10.760 --> 00:22:13.140
Now before we depart from this episode,

422
00:22:13.140 --> 00:22:17.110
are there any final parting
words of wisdom from you?

423
00:22:17.110 --> 00:22:19.520
>> Yeah, just get the jargon,
I think that's the big thing.

424
00:22:19.520 --> 00:22:25.270
Is just get the jargon under your belt
when it comes to taking this exam or

425
00:22:25.270 --> 00:22:26.880
when you prepare for this exam.

426
00:22:26.880 --> 00:22:29.685
And just be aware of some scenarios
that they might ask you and

427
00:22:29.685 --> 00:22:31.830
ask you which services is this,
all right?.

428
00:22:33.110 --> 00:22:35.940
If company A can access
that information but

429
00:22:35.940 --> 00:22:37.910
no other company can
access the information,

430
00:22:37.910 --> 00:22:42.160
is this an example of a private cloud,
or a public cloud, or a hybrid cloud?

431
00:22:42.160 --> 00:22:44.660
Be able to know these different models,
these different services, so

432
00:22:44.660 --> 00:22:47.950
that next time,
when you sit that Net+ exam and

433
00:22:47.950 --> 00:22:51.020
they come up with a question,
you'll be able to answer every one.

434
00:22:51.020 --> 00:22:54.720
>> Well, Wes, thank you for illuminating
those wonderful words of wisdom,

435
00:22:54.720 --> 00:22:58.290
those little nuggets that we can take
away as we prepare for ComptTIA Network+.

436
00:22:58.290 --> 00:23:00.690
But we're continuing on,
so definitely stay tuned.

437
00:23:00.690 --> 00:23:03.000
But for this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

438
00:23:03.000 --> 00:23:05.980
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

439
00:23:05.980 --> 00:23:06.548
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

440
00:23:06.548 --> 00:23:07.892
>> And we'll see you next time.

441
00:23:07.892 --> 00:23:10.364
[MUSIC]

442
00:23:10.364 --> 00:23:15.255
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes take a look into various network services functions. THey will look at characteristics of the domain name system \(DNS\)and the dynamic host configuration protocol \(DHCP\).
episodes.title: Network Service Functions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.620 --> 00:00:01.320
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.320 --> 00:00:02.345
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.345 --> 00:00:08.302
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.302 --> 00:00:11.871
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:11.871 --> 00:00:15.890
>> Hello, and thank you for choosing ITPRO
TV, helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.890 --> 00:00:20.090
I'm your host, Zach Memos as we
continue on with CompTIA Net+.

7
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:24.760
And this is network service functions,
great title for an episode.

8
00:00:24.760 --> 00:00:26.770
There should be some DNS in our future,
I think.

9
00:00:26.770 --> 00:00:30.020
And Wes Bryan is here to help us out
with all the information we need.

10
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:30.740
Wes, good to see you.

11
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:32.369
>> Absolutely, it's great to be here Zach.

12
00:00:32.369 --> 00:00:35.924
That's right, when they talk about
network service functions, well,

13
00:00:35.924 --> 00:00:38.171
we technically got a lot
of network services.

14
00:00:38.171 --> 00:00:42.025
But Zach already kinda let
the cat out of the bag.

15
00:00:42.025 --> 00:00:44.800
>> Uh-oh.
>> Because there are two services that we

16
00:00:44.800 --> 00:00:45.650
need to worry about.

17
00:00:45.650 --> 00:00:50.050
And two services, really,
that make up really important protocols.

18
00:00:50.050 --> 00:00:55.330
It's what allows us to either obtain IP
addresses or to find computers out there,

19
00:00:55.330 --> 00:00:58.862
whether in our local networks or
across the Internet.

20
00:00:58.862 --> 00:01:03.746
And they really are, when it comes to
network services, two services that you

21
00:01:03.746 --> 00:01:08.271
really should know, not only from
a certification, exam standpoint.

22
00:01:08.271 --> 00:01:12.102
Obviously, that's one of the reasons you
wanna know it because you might be going

23
00:01:12.102 --> 00:01:16.154
into the Network+ exam and, boy, wouldn't
it be nice just to have these questions or

24
00:01:16.154 --> 00:01:18.400
answers ready to go when
the ask you scenarios?

25
00:01:18.400 --> 00:01:22.275
But even more so, because they're so
important to your networking career,

26
00:01:22.275 --> 00:01:25.688
here at the Network+ level,
it's good to get a solid foundation.

27
00:01:25.688 --> 00:01:29.930
Because you're gonna be dealing with
these almost sometimes on a daily basis.

28
00:01:29.930 --> 00:01:33.990
And they really form a lot
of the major foundation

29
00:01:33.990 --> 00:01:39.200
communications that we have
on the network, in general.

30
00:01:39.200 --> 00:01:41.603
>> So, Wes, could you tell us
a little bit about the DNS service?

31
00:01:41.603 --> 00:01:43.078
>> Yes, great question.

32
00:01:43.078 --> 00:01:45.540
We talk about the DNS service in general,
right.

33
00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:46.840
What is it responsible for?

34
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:50.900
I want you to think about how we
talked about how routers communicate

35
00:01:50.900 --> 00:01:52.430
with other computers across the Internet.

36
00:01:52.430 --> 00:01:56.790
Cuz essentially when you visit a website,
you're asking a server for a webpage,

37
00:01:56.790 --> 00:01:58.690
like we talked about those protocols.

38
00:01:58.690 --> 00:02:02.220
So I have to know where
to find that web server.

39
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:05.610
Well, remember that when we talked about
routers, for instance, in our OSI models,

40
00:02:05.610 --> 00:02:10.410
we said that the routers allow us to
communicate via IP address, right.

41
00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:11.520
They look at routing tables.

42
00:02:11.520 --> 00:02:13.044
They look at the network.

43
00:02:13.044 --> 00:02:16.580
They break down the network ID to try
to find out where the network is.

44
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:19.830
And, if not, they pass it on based on
the destination IP address, right.

45
00:02:19.830 --> 00:02:24.102
So in our layer three data packet, right,
we have a destination IP address and

46
00:02:24.102 --> 00:02:25.281
a source IP address.

47
00:02:25.281 --> 00:02:28.440
And that's how the routers
make their decisions, right.

48
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:30.820
What we don't have are things like names,
right.

49
00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:32.960
And if you think about it,
Domain Name System,

50
00:02:32.960 --> 00:02:37.050
there has to be names involved cuz
it's right there in the name, right.

51
00:02:37.050 --> 00:02:39.624
That's good for routers,
that's great for computers, right.

52
00:02:39.624 --> 00:02:41.708
But it's not so good for us humans, right.

53
00:02:41.708 --> 00:02:43.980
I don't know about you, Zach,
but I can't remember yesterday.

54
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:47.960
Sometimes I wouldn't even remember my head
if it wasn't attached at the neck, right.

55
00:02:47.960 --> 00:02:51.014
So I want you to think about every website
that you were gonna visit out there.

56
00:02:51.014 --> 00:02:53.330
Do you know its IP address?

57
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:57.170
Did you wake up when you went to Facebook
this morning, maybe on your computer, and

58
00:02:57.170 --> 00:03:01.790
type the IP address of one of the Facebook
servers, one of the Google servers?

59
00:03:01.790 --> 00:03:03.608
Did you go out there to
Microsoft's website?

60
00:03:03.608 --> 00:03:06.615
Those of you that are maybe studying
some Microsoft exams, and you went up to

61
00:03:06.615 --> 00:03:12.240
TechNet, did you type in the web browser
the IP address of the TechNet web server?

62
00:03:12.240 --> 00:03:14.530
No, you didn't, right, you typed a name.

63
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:17.032
And a lot of times, what we do is
we type a name in a search engine.

64
00:03:17.032 --> 00:03:19.418
That's why I always say search
engine is first, right.

65
00:03:19.418 --> 00:03:23.559
But, still, when you go to a search
engine, you're going to a server, and

66
00:03:23.559 --> 00:03:25.850
you're saying I need to find something.

67
00:03:25.850 --> 00:03:28.795
And you type in and
you interact with that search engine.

68
00:03:28.795 --> 00:03:31.470
But your computer found
it on an IP address.

69
00:03:31.470 --> 00:03:36.600
But when you typed it in, you typed
it in by name, right, www.google.com.

70
00:03:36.600 --> 00:03:40.870
Or if you're using Microsoft,
www.bing.com, right.

71
00:03:40.870 --> 00:03:43.760
Those are names, they're not IP addresses.

72
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:48.760
So if computers use IP addresses, and
it's easier for us to remember names,

73
00:03:48.760 --> 00:03:52.230
then how is that working in
the background where I type a name, and

74
00:03:52.230 --> 00:03:54.613
in the background it
connects to the IP address?

75
00:03:54.613 --> 00:03:56.550
Magic, [LAUGH] not really.

76
00:03:56.550 --> 00:03:59.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's where the DNS service comes in.

77
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:01.420
See, the DNS service is responsible.

78
00:04:01.420 --> 00:04:06.008
When my computer and the programs or
the applications, if you will, need to

79
00:04:06.008 --> 00:04:11.110
communicate across the network, right,
they need to communicate via IP address.

80
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:15.087
But when my computer doesn't
know what the IP address is,

81
00:04:15.087 --> 00:04:19.970
and all I have is a name, we go through
a process using that DNS service.

82
00:04:19.970 --> 00:04:24.149
And that DNS service, with some
components that we're gonna show you,

83
00:04:24.149 --> 00:04:27.027
is going to go out there,
search some databases,

84
00:04:27.027 --> 00:04:30.110
take that name,
associate it with an IP address, and

85
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:34.454
return back to your computer the actual
IP address so that you can connect.

86
00:04:34.454 --> 00:04:39.691
And making it easier for
us humans, we can remember names,

87
00:04:39.691 --> 00:04:45.660
which can be a lot more user friendly,
then a four octet IP address,

88
00:04:45.660 --> 00:04:50.621
or even more so,
an eight block IPv6 address, right.

89
00:04:50.621 --> 00:04:53.100
And that's a beauty of
the Domain Name System.

90
00:04:53.100 --> 00:04:56.530
Domain Name System says
when I type in something,

91
00:04:56.530 --> 00:05:01.898
like www.google.com, or www.itpro.tv,

92
00:05:01.898 --> 00:05:07.400
right, www.practice-labs.com,
and it associates,

93
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:11.080
goes out there, goes through the process,
takes that IP address, maps it to it,

94
00:05:11.080 --> 00:05:15.300
returns the answer back to my computer,
my computer says, now I can connect.

95
00:05:15.300 --> 00:05:17.530
I don't know what this name is,
but now I have an IP address, and

96
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:19.370
I can get there, all right.

97
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:20.490
But it is a hierarchy.

98
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:22.082
DNS works through this hierarchy,

99
00:05:22.082 --> 00:05:24.425
and we have to know a little
bit about the hierarchy.

100
00:05:24.425 --> 00:05:26.670
So let's go ahead and
take a look at the DNS hierarchy.

101
00:05:26.670 --> 00:05:30.801
And understand that hierarchy,
you gotta kinda understand the make up,

102
00:05:30.801 --> 00:05:33.341
the DNA if you will,
of the name, all right.

103
00:05:33.341 --> 00:05:38.073
The name that we resolve is what's known
as a fully qualified domain name, right.

104
00:05:38.073 --> 00:05:42.920
DNS, Domain Name System,
works on fully qualified domain names.

105
00:05:42.920 --> 00:05:44.637
So what is a fully qualified domain name?

106
00:05:44.637 --> 00:05:47.045
All right, well,
I've got an example of one right here.

107
00:05:47.045 --> 00:05:49.340
They're called FQDNs for short.

108
00:05:49.340 --> 00:05:51.265
But let's go ahead and
define the acronym [LAUGH].

109
00:05:51.265 --> 00:05:52.179
>> [LAUGH]
>> You ladies and

110
00:05:52.179 --> 00:05:54.814
gentlemen have enough acronyms
out there under your belt.

111
00:05:54.814 --> 00:05:57.911
I'll throw another one here at you.

112
00:05:57.911 --> 00:05:59.310
>> FYI.
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

113
00:05:59.310 --> 00:06:01.850
So when we're talking about
fully qualified domain names,

114
00:06:01.850 --> 00:06:04.130
that consists of what's
known as a hostname.

115
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:06.680
It's a single label name, all right.

116
00:06:06.680 --> 00:06:09.210
And sometimes in the Microsoft world,

117
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.540
they call it a computer name, as well,
all right, as well as a domain name.

118
00:06:13.540 --> 00:06:16.350
See, a host name, let's say, for instance,

119
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:21.300
server 01, let's say it's computer name,
it's host name, is SRV01.

120
00:06:22.760 --> 00:06:29.064
Well, when we attach that to the end
of a domain name like demo.itpro.tv,

121
00:06:29.064 --> 00:06:34.320
the whole thing together becomes what's
known as the fully qualified domain name.

122
00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:40.890
So remember that, that that is
hostname plus domain name equals FQDN.

123
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:42.720
Now that sounds like a lot of algebra.

124
00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:46.840
When you start putting letters in math,
I mean, I'm out, all right.

125
00:06:46.840 --> 00:06:51.700
But it is important to understand this
name and how the resolution process works.

126
00:06:51.700 --> 00:06:53.070
We call it resolving the name.

127
00:06:53.070 --> 00:06:55.380
Resolution, resolving the name, all right,

128
00:06:55.380 --> 00:06:59.790
Because well here in
the states we read what?

129
00:06:59.790 --> 00:07:00.670
Left to right.

130
00:07:00.670 --> 00:07:04.420
Now I know that we've
got viewers all around.

131
00:07:04.420 --> 00:07:05.990
The world right.

132
00:07:05.990 --> 00:07:09.160
And some languages, obviously,
don't read that way.

133
00:07:09.160 --> 00:07:11.040
They read right to left, right.

134
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:15.750
But when we're reading here, here in
the States, right, we read left to right.

135
00:07:15.750 --> 00:07:18.770
And you would think that we would start on
this side of the tracks to resolve a name.

136
00:07:20.030 --> 00:07:22.030
But DNS doesn't work that way.

137
00:07:22.030 --> 00:07:26.970
DNS actually works from the right,
and resolves back to the left.

138
00:07:26.970 --> 00:07:32.561
See, a hierarchical name space is one
that's broken up into different levels.

139
00:07:32.561 --> 00:07:37.466
And the levels are distinguished, if you
will, by the little punctuation mark,

140
00:07:37.466 --> 00:07:39.010

that says when this computer,
