00:20:24.456 --> 00:20:29.239
let's say just take anyone of this
computers needs to find another computer.

366
00:20:29.239 --> 00:20:33.537
Within this network,
via its fully qualified domain name,

367
00:20:33.537 --> 00:20:37.890
I sent it to the internal DNS server,
all right?

368
00:20:37.890 --> 00:20:43.320
Now the internal DNS server, we got to be
careful because the internal DNS server

369
00:20:43.320 --> 00:20:48.166
isn't the authority of anything that's
out there across the Internet, all right?

370
00:20:48.166 --> 00:20:52.440
We have the Internet corporation for
assigning names and

371
00:20:52.440 --> 00:20:53.810
numbers, I can't right.

372
00:20:53.810 --> 00:20:56.920
Then they are responsible things
like the unique names out there,

373
00:20:56.920 --> 00:21:01.340
I know if you will,
the Internet Assign Numbers Authority.

374
00:21:01.340 --> 00:21:03.620
All of these different standard bodies,
and

375
00:21:03.620 --> 00:21:08.540
the standards bodies are the ones
that oversee public DNS servers.

376
00:21:08.540 --> 00:21:12.360
Now a public DNS server is
also an external DNS server.

377
00:21:12.360 --> 00:21:15.206
Okay so, I wanna kind of clarify,
understand that,

378
00:21:15.206 --> 00:21:17.725
cuz you'll hear different terms.

379
00:21:17.725 --> 00:21:21.650
Is a very good job keeping
it vendor neutral, right?

380
00:21:21.650 --> 00:21:23.570
But you could hear internal and external.

381
00:21:23.570 --> 00:21:26.090
You could hear private and public, right?

382
00:21:26.090 --> 00:21:26.845
And let me tell you why.

383
00:21:26.845 --> 00:21:31.250
Cuz if Zach in no way knows nothing,

384
00:21:31.250 --> 00:21:36.410
doesn't know anything about my internal
infrastructure within my network.

385
00:21:36.410 --> 00:21:39.653
His DNS server is not gonna know anything
about the computers that are in my network

386
00:21:39.653 --> 00:21:41.299
just like my DNS server is not gonna know.

387
00:21:41.299 --> 00:21:45.620
And know how to resolve the names to IP
addresses of the computers that are within

388
00:21:45.620 --> 00:21:46.403
his network.

389
00:21:46.403 --> 00:21:49.440
So they're called private,
they're internal servers.

390
00:21:49.440 --> 00:21:52.520
They resolve internal addresses,
all right?

391
00:21:53.660 --> 00:21:56.130
External DNS servers, what do they do?

392
00:21:56.130 --> 00:21:57.260
So if we could take a look here.

393
00:21:57.260 --> 00:22:01.350
You could have, and this is why
I keep saying an ISP, all right?

394
00:22:01.350 --> 00:22:03.940
When I need to resolve a name
out there across the Internet,

395
00:22:03.940 --> 00:22:06.629
I'm going to send that DNS
request to an external server.

396
00:22:08.300 --> 00:22:09.485
And what are we gonna do?

397
00:22:09.485 --> 00:22:12.065
In this case, probably gonna be
your Internet service provider.

398
00:22:12.065 --> 00:22:14.940
And your Internet service provider's is
gonna go through that process for you.

399
00:22:14.940 --> 00:22:16.740
Somebody else is gonna do
the heavy lifting, right?

400
00:22:16.740 --> 00:22:19.510
Or the public or
external DNS servers, right?

401
00:22:19.510 --> 00:22:21.610
Now you also have things like well,
Google.

402
00:22:21.610 --> 00:22:26.710
Now, be careful with Google because
Google has their own DNS servers, right?

403
00:22:26.710 --> 00:22:29.560
So understand that, yes they're are top
level, or second level domain, but

404
00:22:29.560 --> 00:22:34.030
they also have public DNS servers,
external DNS servers that you can send

405
00:22:34.030 --> 00:22:38.260
information or request to,
and get responses back.

406
00:22:38.260 --> 00:22:44.590
IP addresses just happen to be 8.8.8.8 and
8.8.4.4.

407
00:22:44.590 --> 00:22:46.010
All right, level 3.

408
00:22:46.010 --> 00:22:49.970
Level 3, is one of what's known as
an Internet backbone provider, all right?

409
00:22:49.970 --> 00:22:51.910
They have external DNS servers and
by the way,

410
00:22:51.910 --> 00:22:56.570
they also control some of
the servers as well, right?

411
00:22:56.570 --> 00:22:58.600
So these are big guys, all right?

412
00:22:58.600 --> 00:22:59.460
And that's the difference.

413
00:22:59.460 --> 00:23:02.900
Now, I don't want you to think when I say
and let me make a clarifying statement so

414
00:23:02.900 --> 00:23:04.260
there's no confusion here.

415
00:23:04.260 --> 00:23:08.700
Yes, my internal DNS server it
can resolve names that are out

416
00:23:08.700 --> 00:23:12.660
there across the Internet, but what it's
doing is what's known as a forward, right.

417
00:23:12.660 --> 00:23:17.620
My local DNS server, my internal DNS
server can resolve those names those fully

418
00:23:17.620 --> 00:23:22.340
qualified domain names to IP
addresses on my local network.

419
00:23:22.340 --> 00:23:25.730
And then what we can do is,
just like your mail forwarder,

420
00:23:25.730 --> 00:23:30.710
I can forward a request for
an external name resolution lookup,

421
00:23:30.710 --> 00:23:34.460
may be I'm looking for
Microsoft, www.microsoft.com.

422
00:23:34.460 --> 00:23:37.486
Well, we can take a look
at here at My Computer,

423
00:23:37.486 --> 00:23:43.027
we can ask that internal DNS server, hey,
do you know where www.microsoft.com is?

424
00:23:43.027 --> 00:23:47.267
And a lot of times what the admins will do
is, configure a forwarder that says, no,

425
00:23:47.267 --> 00:23:50.310
I'm not the authority,
I don't have that in my database.

426
00:23:50.310 --> 00:23:54.489
But I tell you what, let me go ahead and
I'll forward that out the router.

427
00:23:54.489 --> 00:23:58.105
And I'll forward that question
over to the ISP's DNS server.

428
00:23:58.105 --> 00:24:01.623
Cuz guess what, the ISP's DNS server's
gonna go through the process of

429
00:24:01.623 --> 00:24:03.758
the external name resolution part of that,

430
00:24:03.758 --> 00:24:07.507
gonna return an answer through that
process back to my internal DNS server and

431
00:24:07.507 --> 00:24:09.780
guess what my internal
DNS server is gonna do?

432
00:24:09.780 --> 00:24:11.820
It's gonna cache it.

433
00:24:11.820 --> 00:24:15.730
So the next time I'm looking for
Microsoft's website, www.Microsoft.com,

434
00:24:15.730 --> 00:24:19.930
now my internal DNS server says let
me look at my local resolver cache.

435
00:24:19.930 --> 00:24:22.630
Okay it's there, here's your answer.

436
00:24:22.630 --> 00:24:25.690
So part of the name resolution process,
do I already have the answer?

437
00:24:25.690 --> 00:24:27.970
No I don't or I do and you return it and

438
00:24:27.970 --> 00:24:29.840
I don't have to go through
the name resolution process.

439
00:24:29.840 --> 00:24:31.330
Let's say no I don't.

440
00:24:31.330 --> 00:24:33.540
All right, am I the authority?

441
00:24:33.540 --> 00:24:35.180
The second step, am I the authority?

442
00:24:36.890 --> 00:24:41.170
My internal DNS server is not the
authority over Microsoft's DNS servers.

443
00:24:41.170 --> 00:24:42.420
No it's not.

444
00:24:42.420 --> 00:24:44.000
All right, so I need to talk to somebody.

445
00:24:44.000 --> 00:24:45.100
Do I have a forwarder?

446
00:24:45.100 --> 00:24:47.820
If I have a forwarder, just send it out
to whatever that DNS server that is.

447
00:24:47.820 --> 00:24:52.145
If not, let me look at the IP
addresses of the root hint server.

448
00:24:52.145 --> 00:24:54.830
Okay I've got the IP addresses
of the root hint server.

449
00:24:54.830 --> 00:24:57.550
Go talk to root and
then that process goes.

450
00:24:58.630 --> 00:25:01.390
All right, so
do keep that in mind, all right.

451
00:25:01.390 --> 00:25:07.150
Now you'll also have things like
your third party DNS servers and

452
00:25:07.150 --> 00:25:09.490
cloud hosted servers, all right.

453
00:25:09.490 --> 00:25:13.363
So for instance,
you can pay somebody like GoDaddy,

454
00:25:13.363 --> 00:25:16.303
GoDaddy is a domain registrar, right.

455
00:25:16.303 --> 00:25:19.708
If I want to have a domain name out there,
and I want it to be publicly accessible,

456
00:25:19.708 --> 00:25:21.326
I've got to go to a domain registrar.

457
00:25:21.326 --> 00:25:25.052
And I've got to register with them, and
they're gonna be licensed bonded and

458
00:25:25.052 --> 00:25:27.660
insured just in case there
is any malicious activity.

459
00:25:27.660 --> 00:25:31.750
You'll still be held accountable, but
any time it's a publicly resolvable name,

460
00:25:31.750 --> 00:25:33.740
there has to be accountability.

461
00:25:33.740 --> 00:25:36.500
So I could go to somebody
like godaddy.com and

462
00:25:36.500 --> 00:25:41.650
I could say I wanna bring up my domain and
I want you to host the DNS records.

463
00:25:41.650 --> 00:25:43.560
Third party, right?

464
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:48.310
Now, they are providing the name
resolution worldwide across the worldwide

465
00:25:48.310 --> 00:25:53.030
DNS system for my domain and
I don't have to manage the DNS servers.

466
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:54.640
So that for small businesses works.

467
00:25:55.970 --> 00:25:57.960
The second one that I
mentioned is cloud hosting and

468
00:25:57.960 --> 00:26:00.680
that's what we use here by the way.

469
00:26:00.680 --> 00:26:02.888
We don't have internal DNS servers.

470
00:26:02.888 --> 00:26:06.140
We send ours either up to AWS or,
I believe it's AWS but

471
00:26:06.140 --> 00:26:09.340
it might be Azure or could be both.

472
00:26:09.340 --> 00:26:11.970
I know that some of the people that are
behind designing our network here don't

473
00:26:11.970 --> 00:26:13.280
put all their eggs in one basket.

474
00:26:13.280 --> 00:26:15.900
They might use two cloud providers
just to provide redundancy, but

475
00:26:15.900 --> 00:26:19.130
it's very hard to get more redundant
than the AWS infrastructure.

476
00:26:19.130 --> 00:26:21.090
They've got the biggest
infrastructure in the world.

477
00:26:21.090 --> 00:26:24.260
But either way,
Amazon's managing it, right?

478
00:26:24.260 --> 00:26:26.780
And they're giving us
the virtual DNS servers.

479
00:26:28.290 --> 00:26:33.540
And they provide it per service,
kinda like GoDaddy does, all right.

480
00:26:33.540 --> 00:26:36.660
So that's the difference between
a third-party and the cloud host.

481
00:26:36.660 --> 00:26:42.010
>> Now Wes, you're talking about names,
like me Zach you Wes, names, names.

482
00:26:42.010 --> 00:26:44.740
Can you tell us a little bit
more what do you mean by names?

483
00:26:44.740 --> 00:26:46.090
>> You know.
>> Name management.

484
00:26:46.090 --> 00:26:50.920
>> That's right so names are an
interesting thing but you know what Zach?

485
00:26:50.920 --> 00:26:55.450
I think what a such a big topic like that
we might have to go into a part two.

486
00:26:55.450 --> 00:26:56.190
>> Cliffhanger.

487
00:26:56.190 --> 00:26:56.780
>> Cliffhanger.

488
00:26:57.790 --> 00:26:59.320
>> Boy.
Network service functions pat

489
00:26:59.320 --> 00:27:00.470
two coming your way.

490
00:27:00.470 --> 00:27:04.027
This has been network service functions
part one into the CompTIA Net+ series.

491
00:27:04.027 --> 00:27:05.840
Wes, wonderful job as always.

492
00:27:05.840 --> 00:27:09.740
And you wanna make sure you watch every
single episode in the CompTIA Net+ series.

493
00:27:09.740 --> 00:27:12.310
And check out all the other videos
we have in our course library.

494
00:27:12.310 --> 00:27:15.340
They're all designed to do one thing,
help you go further.

495
00:27:15.340 --> 00:27:16.690
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

496
00:27:16.690 --> 00:27:18.040
They'll be glad you did.

497
00:27:18.040 --> 00:27:19.555
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

498
00:27:19.555 --> 00:27:22.083
>> And I'm Wes Bryan
>> And we will see you soon

499
00:27:22.083 --> 00:27:28.986
[MUSIC]

500
00:27:28.986 --> 00:27:33.409
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes take a look into various network services functions. THey will look at characteristics of the domain name system \(DNS\)and the dynamic host configuration protocol \(DHCP\).
episodes.title: Network Service Functions Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.091 --> 00:00:01.158
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.158 --> 00:00:02.139
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.139 --> 00:00:08.211
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.211 --> 00:00:11.897
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:11.897 --> 00:00:13.998
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing IT Pro TV,

6
00:00:13.998 --> 00:00:16.610
engaging the world through
the power of learning.

7
00:00:16.610 --> 00:00:20.510
I'm your host Zack Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA and

8
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:23.270
Net+ Network Service Functions Part 2.

9
00:00:23.270 --> 00:00:24.692
We had a part 1,
make sure you see that too.

10
00:00:24.692 --> 00:00:28.010
And Wes Bryan is back again
to complete this thought.

11
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:29.710
Wes, good to see you,
thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:29.710 --> 00:00:30.885
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Zach.

13
00:00:30.885 --> 00:00:33.817
Yeah, these network services
that we're be talking about over

14
00:00:33.817 --> 00:00:36.980
the next couple of episodes,
they're really, really important.

15
00:00:36.980 --> 00:00:44.120
I mean, they really form the foundation
for how we communicate across a network.

16
00:00:44.120 --> 00:00:47.208
Remember that in the first part
we basically said with DNS,

17
00:00:47.208 --> 00:00:51.595
domain name system, the service that is
associated with it, it's responsible for

18
00:00:51.595 --> 00:00:54.097
taking names and
mapping them to IP addresses.

19
00:00:54.097 --> 00:00:57.475
Remember, fully qualified domain names,
or FQDN's, and

20
00:00:57.475 --> 00:00:59.406
mapping them to our IP addresses.

21
00:00:59.406 --> 00:01:02.912
And it's a very, very important
service because, yeah, I tell you,

22
00:01:02.912 --> 00:01:04.848
I can't remember a single IP address.

23
00:01:04.848 --> 00:01:08.230
If you think about us humans, right?

24
00:01:08.230 --> 00:01:10.990
Today a lot of us don't even
know telephone numbers.

25
00:01:10.990 --> 00:01:15.634
We associate a name and maybe even a photo
of a friend that we've got on our contacts

26
00:01:15.634 --> 00:01:17.465
list, and we push that button.

27
00:01:17.465 --> 00:01:22.340
And it maps it to a cell phone number and
it contacts them, right?

28
00:01:22.340 --> 00:01:25.358
Well, different kind of number,
different kind of name, but

29
00:01:25.358 --> 00:01:27.215
the theory's the same thing, right?

30
00:01:27.215 --> 00:01:29.631
It's easier for us to remember
names than it is IP addresses.

31
00:01:29.631 --> 00:01:34.345
And DNS makes it so we can remember
the names and not the IP addresses.

32
00:01:34.345 --> 00:01:39.042
>> And we left you with a cliffhanger,
and that was my question of naming.

33
00:01:39.042 --> 00:01:40.750
You know, like I'm Zach, that's Wes.

34
00:01:40.750 --> 00:01:43.708
[LAUGH] But there's names, there's all
these names we were talking about.

35
00:01:43.708 --> 00:01:46.660
What exactly are we talking about?

36
00:01:46.660 --> 00:01:48.410
Where do we find them, where are they for?

37
00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:49.730
>> Well I'll tell you what,
let's go ahead and

38
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:51.540
see if we can help you out on that one.

39
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:53.708
Now I've got a little
bit of a diagram here.

40
00:01:53.708 --> 00:01:55.261
We'll go back back to that real quick and

41
00:01:55.261 --> 00:01:58.010
we'll talk about that they're what
are known as records, all right?

42
00:01:58.010 --> 00:02:01.410
DNS records are actually
stored on a DNS server, right,

43
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:02.670
on a little database, if you will.

44
00:02:02.670 --> 00:02:04.660
It's really just a text file, all right?

45
00:02:04.660 --> 00:02:08.330
And what you'll see here is
that I've got FQDN, all right?

46
00:02:08.330 --> 00:02:11.285
And it's mapped to an IP address.

47
00:02:11.285 --> 00:02:14.794
Now the server, and in fact let me go
ahead and for the sake of consistency,

48
00:02:14.794 --> 00:02:17.484
I noticed that this IP address
is a little bit different.

49
00:02:17.484 --> 00:02:21.562
And it might confuse people because I'm
gonna use a different, private IP address,

50
00:02:21.562 --> 00:02:22.575
all right?

51
00:02:22.575 --> 00:02:26.225
Now it takes the name,
maps it to the IP address.

52
00:02:26.225 --> 00:02:29.646
Well that name to IP address,
pp4 specifically,

53
00:02:29.646 --> 00:02:31.804
is what's known as an A record.

54
00:02:31.804 --> 00:02:35.170
And the A record gets stored in
what's known as a DNS zone file.

55
00:02:35.170 --> 00:02:39.619
Again, the zone file, database, it's
really just a text file, it's a listing.

56
00:02:39.619 --> 00:02:42.790
Now that is what's known as a DNS record.

57
00:02:42.790 --> 00:02:45.470
But it's only one example of a DNS record.

58
00:02:45.470 --> 00:02:47.295
We've got quite a few, all right?

59
00:02:47.295 --> 00:02:49.130
And we've gotta talk about them,
all right?

60
00:02:49.130 --> 00:02:54.180
So understand that these are the type of
DNS records that we need to be aware of,

61
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:54.952
all right?

62
00:02:54.952 --> 00:02:58.260
The very first one we have is an A record,
all right?

63
00:02:58.260 --> 00:03:01.733
An A record, sometimes called
an address record, all right?

64
00:03:01.733 --> 00:03:06.361
It takes that host name, I'm just gonna
say host here, but host name, and

65
00:03:06.361 --> 00:03:08.650
maps it to an IP address, all right?

66
00:03:10.080 --> 00:03:14.160
Now IPv4 isn't the only internet
protocol we have, right?

67
00:03:14.160 --> 00:03:17.080
In other episodes we talk about IPv4 and
we also talked about IPv6, right,

68
00:03:17.080 --> 00:03:22.680
that eight-block, hexadecimal,
crazy long IP address.

69
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:25.195
Well those aren't A records now, right?

70
00:03:25.195 --> 00:03:28.382
The designers of DNS got
a little crafty here and

71
00:03:28.382 --> 00:03:33.006
they said since an IPv6 address
has four times the numbers, right,

72
00:03:33.006 --> 00:03:36.850
or four times the bits,
we'll call it a quad-A record.

73
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:41.360
You see four As, sometimes they
called it quad-A record, all right?

74
00:03:41.360 --> 00:03:46.875
A quad-A record, AAAA record if you want,
it's called quad-A,

75
00:03:46.875 --> 00:03:52.120
takes that name, and
it maps it to an IPv6 address, all right?

76
00:03:52.120 --> 00:03:56.070
So we still have name
mapped to IP address.

77
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:59.960
But an A is an IPv4 and
a quad-A is an IPv6 address.

78
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:08.550
Now remember, DNS is not only responsible
for mapping just names to IP addresses.

79
00:04:08.550 --> 00:04:11.770
The cool thing is it can also
take services on your net.

80
00:04:11.770 --> 00:04:12.794
It is a service in and of itself.

81
00:04:12.794 --> 00:04:15.544
But it can take services
that are on your network so

82
00:04:15.544 --> 00:04:19.100
you know where to find those services and
the IP address.

83
00:04:19.100 --> 00:04:22.260
So, for instance, let's say in a Windows
domain I need to log on to the Windows

84
00:04:22.260 --> 00:04:25.230
domain, right, over the Kerberos protocol.

85
00:04:25.230 --> 00:04:26.990
Well, I gotta find the domain controller.

86
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:29.300
My computer has to know where's
the domain controller so

87
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:32.170
that I can send these credentials
over to it and talk to it.

88
00:04:32.170 --> 00:04:37.410
So it talks to DNS and it says,
I need an LDAP server.

89
00:04:37.410 --> 00:04:40.920
Where do I find a service out there,

90
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:43.058
a lightweight directory
access protocol service?

91

00:31:51.560 --> 00:31:55.660
there will be a Network Service
Functions Part 3, where we look at DHCP.

542
00:31:55.660 --> 00:31:57.246
So you don't wanna miss that and

543
00:31:57.246 --> 00:32:00.260
you don't wanna miss anything
in the CompTIA Net+ series.

544
00:32:00.260 --> 00:32:02.440
Wes is doing a wonderful job,
he always does.

545
00:32:02.440 --> 00:32:04.555
And in fact,
check out the rest of the course library.

546
00:32:04.555 --> 00:32:07.810
There's so many videos and
they're all there to do one thing.

547
00:32:07.810 --> 00:32:09.310
Help you go further.

548
00:32:09.310 --> 00:32:10.937
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

549
00:32:10.937 --> 00:32:12.198
They'll be very glad you did.

550
00:32:12.198 --> 00:32:13.650
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

551
00:32:13.650 --> 00:32:14.540
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

552
00:32:14.540 --> 00:32:17.160
>> And we will see you soon.

553
00:32:17.160 --> 00:32:23.104
[MUSIC]

554
00:32:23.104 --> 00:32:27.130
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes take a look into various network services functions. THey will look at characteristics of the domain name system \(DNS\)and the dynamic host configuration protocol \(DHCP\).
episodes.title: Network Service Functions Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.607
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your host,
Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.607 --> 00:00:06.642
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.642 --> 00:00:08.297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:11.925
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.925 --> 00:00:14.063
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.063 --> 00:00:15.760
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:15.760 --> 00:00:16.890
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

8
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:21.700
as we continue on with
CompTIA Net+ Network Service Functions,

9
00:00:21.700 --> 00:00:23.480
this is part three.

10
00:00:23.480 --> 00:00:26.650
And that's right, and in fact,
we left off with DHCP.

11
00:00:26.650 --> 00:00:29.040
But before we get there I have to
introduce this fellow right here.

12
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:31.390
This is Wes Bryan, he knows everything.

13
00:00:31.390 --> 00:00:32.383
Wes, thanks for being here.

14
00:00:32.383 --> 00:00:33.375
>> Yeah, hey, it's good.

15
00:00:33.375 --> 00:00:34.960
Boy, you set that bar high.

16
00:00:34.960 --> 00:00:36.043
Hopefully you're gonna-
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:36.043 --> 00:00:37.474
>> Stick around and help me hold that bar.

18
00:00:37.474 --> 00:00:40.020
But that's right,
I don't know a little bit.

19
00:00:40.020 --> 00:00:43.690
What we wanna show you is enough,
hopefully, and hopefully so

20
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:45.780
that you'll pass that Net+ exam.

21
00:00:45.780 --> 00:00:49.428
Keep in mind that we try to give
a good comprehensive overview of some

22
00:00:49.428 --> 00:00:51.739
of the objectives that you're gonna see.

23
00:00:51.739 --> 00:00:56.670
But you can always learn more and
you can always study, study, study.

24
00:00:56.670 --> 00:00:57.750
So let's go ahead.

25
00:00:57.750 --> 00:01:00.900
We're gonna look at DHCP
inside of this episode.

26
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:04.747
>> And I was just gonna ask you that maybe
give us a recap, too, where we've been and

27
00:01:04.747 --> 00:01:06.920
where we're going, but DHCP, certainly.

28
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:09.200
>> Yeah, and in the first couple of parts,
we'll start with the recap.

29
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:11.649
Remember in the first couple of
parts we talked about a very,

30
00:01:11.649 --> 00:01:13.438
very important service that's out there.

31
00:01:13.438 --> 00:01:17.915
And it really revolves around
name resolution, right?

32
00:01:17.915 --> 00:01:21.407
Again, it is mapping names to
IP Addresses, if you will, so

33
00:01:21.407 --> 00:01:23.880
that we could find things like computers.

34
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:28.300
We can find services,
we can find an email server for a domain.

35
00:01:28.300 --> 00:01:29.918
And you know what's kinda interesting?

36
00:01:29.918 --> 00:01:33.070
One of the things, Zach, that I didn't
mention in there that I do have to.

37
00:01:33.070 --> 00:01:36.848
We talked about in other episodes,
we mentioned the record types, right?

38
00:01:36.848 --> 00:01:40.568
And we went through all the various
records, A records, quad A records,

39
00:01:40.568 --> 00:01:45.110
MX records, PTI records, canonical
names or C_Names, aliases, if you will.

40
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:48.313
One of the ones that I didn't mention,
and I wanna go ahead and

41
00:01:48.313 --> 00:01:52.210
mention now is an NS record because we
wanna be complete to the objectives.

42
00:01:52.210 --> 00:01:58.904
And the NS record is essentially
nothing more than a Name Server record.

43
00:01:58.904 --> 00:02:06.900
If you want a DNS Server basically
to know where a Name Server is for

44
00:02:06.900 --> 00:02:11.270
another domain, what you can do is you
can put NS record up in the DNS server.

45
00:02:11.270 --> 00:02:13.450
And what that will do is
when you are looking for

46
00:02:13.450 --> 00:02:19.690
a name that correlates with this name
server's domain name space, if you will.

47
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:24.090
Basically DNS can say, hey, well,
let me return you the IP address of

48
00:02:24.090 --> 00:02:28.180
the name server, and then you can go just
talk directly to that DNS server and

49
00:02:28.180 --> 00:02:30.160
you can get your resolution there.

50
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:34.040
So that was one of the records that I
didn't mention when it comes to DNS.

51
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:36.875
So if you're not aware of some of
the records that we're talking about, or

52
00:02:36.875 --> 00:02:39.862
that doesn't make sense to you, please
go back and watch the first two parts.

53
00:02:39.862 --> 00:02:41.239
>> Please do.

54
00:02:41.239 --> 00:02:48.587
>> We're gonna move on into part three,
talking about the DHCP service.

55
00:02:48.587 --> 00:02:52.690
In other episodes, we talked
about how we obtain IP addresses.

56
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:56.663
We talked about things like static IP
addressing where we have to manually

57
00:02:56.663 --> 00:02:59.300
configure IP addresses
on all of our computers.

58
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:02.790
And that does run the risk for not only
being an administrative complexity,

59
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:04.660
the fact that you have to
do this multiple times.

60
00:03:04.660 --> 00:03:06.280
If you have 1,000
computers in your network,

61
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:10.860
if you're doing everything statically,
yeah, you got to do this 1,000 times.

62
00:03:10.860 --> 00:03:14.190
You have to configure things like
subnet mask, default gateways,

63
00:03:14.190 --> 00:03:17.350
the DNS servers and
that also leads to configuration errors.

64
00:03:17.350 --> 00:03:20.250
Remember that one of things that we
can do is that we can set that DHCP

65
00:03:20.250 --> 00:03:22.100
server out on our network.

66
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:24.640
And we can set our clients up to use DHCP.

67
00:03:24.640 --> 00:03:27.790
And they call out to the network when
they need an IP address and say,

68
00:03:27.790 --> 00:03:29.290
hey, anybody out there got an IP address.

69
00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:30.120
I could really use one.

70
00:03:30.120 --> 00:03:34.641
And the DHCP service, if it's configured
to respond will respond with an offer and

71
00:03:34.641 --> 00:03:36.590
some additional configurations.

72
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:41.360
We're going to look a little bit more
at the DHCP server side of it itself.

73
00:03:41.360 --> 00:03:46.000
If you're not aware of what the DHCP or
the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

74
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:48.400
I hate doing that, especially to
our CompTIA viewers down there.

75
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:50.120
I've said an acronym four or
five terms and

76
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:52.170
I haven't once mentioned
what that acronym is.

77
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:54.140
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol,
right?

78
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:56.439
We're gonna look a little bit,

79
00:03:56.439 --> 00:03:59.270
more at the service than some of
the components inside of the service.

80
00:03:59.270 --> 00:04:02.850
So I tell you what, without further ado,
let's just go ahead and

81
00:04:02.850 --> 00:04:06.240
rather than just speak about
everything that we have to talk about,

82
00:04:06.240 --> 00:04:07.850
let's go ahead and
do both at the same time.

83
00:04:07.850 --> 00:04:11.140
We'll kinda show you, and talk about
some of the things that we're saying.

84
00:04:11.140 --> 00:04:15.190
So I'm back on the same Windows Server
here that we had in the last episode.

85
00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:19.590
You might remember that we looked at
Tools and we went to the Roles, and

86
00:04:19.590 --> 00:04:23.190
if you remember,
we pulled up the DNS console, all right?

87
00:04:23.190 --> 00:04:25.010
Well, I've got DHCP here too.

88
00:04:25.010 --> 00:04:27.570
Now this role, I've installed it.

89
00:04:27.570 --> 00:04:30.490
But I haven't done any configurations
on it because the great thing about

90
00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:36.030
configuring it is the wizard that I
really like that Microsoft has here kind

91
00:04:36.030 --> 00:04:40.690
of points you through some of the topics
that we need to look at for the exam here.

92
00:04:40.690 --> 00:04:46.860
So what a great way, if you haven't
seen bringing a DHCP server online and

93
00:04:46.860 --> 00:04:50.100
configuring it for the first time to
start handing out IP addresses and

94
00:04:50.100 --> 00:04:54.640
some of the components that make up
the DHCP service that can also help

95
00:04:54.640 --> 00:04:56.730
to assist the computers
that are on your network.

96
00:04:56.730 --> 00:05:03.330
So you'll see here if I go up to
the little action event flag here.

97
00:05:03.330 --> 00:05:07.000
Notice it does say we need
a post-deployment configuration here for

98
00:05:07.000 --> 00:05:11.000
me and what that means is that I need
to complete the DHCP configuration.

99
00:05:11.000 --> 00:05:14.710
Now I will tell you, when I click this
link, there's one thing that I'm going to

100
00:05:14.710 --> 00:05:20.178
have to do here that is really kind of
unique, if you will, to the Windows world.

101
00:05:20.178 --> 00:05:23.770
I understand that this is not on the exam,
but

102
00:05:23.770 --> 00:05:27.070
I just don't want you
guys to be confused here.

103
00:05:27.070 --> 00:05:33.142
What this is gonna do is this is gonna
create the computers, the security groups,

104
00:05:33.142 --> 00:05:37.894
inside of our Active Directory so
that they can not only use, but

105
00:05:37.894 --> 00:05:42.300
also configure DHCP, and
then authorize the DHCP server.

106
00:05:42.300 --> 00:05:47.020
Because it says, if domain joined, this
DHCP server, this is domain joined and

107
00:05:47.020 --> 00:05:50.250
authorizing that server just means it's
allowed to hand out IP addresses on

108
00:05:50.250 --> 00:05:51.180
our network.

109
00:05:51.180 --> 00:05:54.487
Understand that's a Microsoft,
that's a Windows Domain thing.

110
00:05:54.487 --> 00:05:56.780
That's a Windows DHCP server.

111
00:05:56.780 --> 00:05:59.220
That's not something that's
gonna be on the exam objectives,

112
00:05:59.220 --> 00:06:00.850
but we have to do it to go ahead and
start.

113
00:06:00.850 --> 00:06:04.650
So I'll go ahead, commit this,
we'll bring this server online basically

114
00:06:04.650 --> 00:06:07.870
creating the security groups and
authorizing the DHCP server and

115
00:06:07.870 --> 00:06:10.425
Active Directory so
that we can hand out IP addresses.

116
00:06:10.425 --> 00:06:13.060
Let me make sure that I close that.

117
00:06:13.060 --> 00:06:16.710
And now that that's done,
we can launch our DHCP console.

118
00:06:16.710 --> 00:06:21.069
Now DHCP console looks a lot like our
DNS manager, management consoles.

119
00:06:21.069 --> 00:06:23.580
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> It doesn't look much different, right?

120
00:06:23.580 --> 00:06:27.760
And we can see that this is our, this
just happens to be our DHCP server here.

121
00:06:27.760 --> 00:06:31.340
And if I expand this out, I'll see that we
have two protocols, because remember like

122
00:06:31.340 --> 00:06:36.090
we talked about, IP addresses in other
episodes, the DHCP service, remember that?

123
00:06:36.090 --> 00:06:41.048
Not only can we hand out IPv4 addresses,
we can also hand out IPv6 addresses,

124
00:06:41.048 --> 00:06:41.793
all right?

125
00:06:41.793 --> 00:06:46.218
So what we're gonna focus on right now, is
we're just kind of drill down into IPv4,

126
00:06:46.218 --> 00:06:46.850
all right?

127
00:06:46.850 --> 00:06:50.675
Now IPv4, to get this up and running,
right, so that we can start handing

128
00:06:50.675 --> 00:06:53.852
out IP addresses,
we need to create what's known as a scope.

129
00:06:53.852 --> 00:06:56.300
All right, now scope, we're not
talking about mouthwash here, right?

130
00:06:56.300 --> 00:07:01.136
But what we're talking about here when
we say scope is a range of addresses

131
00:07:01.136 --> 00:07:05.582
that we wanna hand out to clients
when they call out to the network and

132
00:07:05.582 --> 00:07:08.873
they say, I need an IP address,
anybody got one?

133
00:07:08.873 --> 00:07:13.899
Well, for us to offer an IP address,
we have to have a scope.

134
00:07:13.899 --> 00:07:15.227
That's where it starts.

135
00:07:15.227 --> 00:07:20.711
So let's go ahead and
what we'll do is we'll right-click

136
00:07:20.711 --> 00:07:25.769
on our IPv4 here, and
we're gonna choose New Scope.

137
00:07:25.769 --> 00:07:27.100
So that's the very first part.

138
00:07:27.100 --> 00:07:28.841
We'll choose New Scope, and

139
00:07:28.841 --> 00:07:32.676
this will bring us in to our New Scope
wizard which is what we want.

140
00:07:32.676 --> 00:07:35.000
I love these wizards
cuz they're very easy.

141
00:07:35.000 --> 00:07:37.100
They kinda walk you through
everything that you need to know.

142
00:07:37.100 --> 00:07:39.100
And you can name the scope,
the name is arbitrary.

143
00:07:39.100 --> 00:07:42.281
It's for identification
purposes on your side, right?

144
00:07:42.281 --> 00:07:46.075
So I might just say,
I don't know, clients maybe.

145
00:07:46.075 --> 00:07:48.750
Maybe I just wanna say
this is the client scope.

146
00:07:48.750 --> 00:07:50.100
Again, this is up to you.

147
00:07:50.100 --> 00:07:55.786
It's all up to how you do
the architecture in your network.

148
00:07:55.786 --> 00:08:00.071
All right, now the next thing
that we need to do is we need to

149
00:08:00.071 --> 00:08:02.702
configure a range of IP addresses.

150
00:08:02.702 --> 00:08:09.552
So I'm gonna give out this from
this IP address to this IP address.

151
00:08:09.552 --> 00:08:12.803
Now when doing that,
what that's gonna do is it's gonna give us

152
00:08:12.803 --> 00:08:15.770
a certain amount of IP addresses
that we have to lease out.

153
00:08:15.770 --> 00:08:18.802
So let's go ahead and let's say,
I'm gonna do 192.168.

154
00:08:18.802 --> 00:08:21.277
We're doing private IP addresses here.

155
00:08:21.277 --> 00:08:26.506
And instead of doing 1.1,
I'm not going to do 1.1 all right.

156
00:08:26.506 --> 00:08:30.229
Why, well, a lot of times and
it doesn't have to be, but

157
00:08:30.229 --> 00:08:35.582
your very first address within a network
range a lot of times it's not reserved but

158
00:08:35.582 --> 00:08:39.088
admins like to reserve it for
their default gateway.

159
00:08:39.088 --> 00:08:43.587
So the router, so now everybody
knows that 1.1 the very first

160
00:08:43.587 --> 00:08:48.100
network address within that network
range is gonna be a router.

161
00:08:48.100 --> 00:08:52.040
So we're gonna go ahead and
what we're not gonna do is 1.1.

162
00:08:52.040 --> 00:08:56.380
We're actually gonna start
here from 192.168.1.2.

163
00:08:56.380 --> 00:08:57.578
And then from here,

164
00:08:57.578 --> 00:09:01.960
we'll say what's the last address in
this range that we want to give out?

165
00:09:01.960 --> 00:09:05.460
How many addresses are we gonna have?

166
00:09:05.460 --> 00:09:07.853
What I'm gonna do here other than 1.1,

167
00:09:07.853 --> 00:09:11.254
I'm gonna do the entire
class C network of 192.1.0.

168
00:09:11.254 --> 00:09:16.102
We'll do the entire network range,
so what we're gonna

169
00:09:16.102 --> 00:09:21.080
do here is we're gonna do 192.168.1.254.

170
00:09:21.080 --> 00:09:24.421
Remember, those of you have looked
at some of our other episodes,

171
00:09:24.421 --> 00:09:25.741
I can't give out 255.

172
00:09:25.741 --> 00:09:26.914
That's the broadcast address.

173
00:09:26.914 --> 00:09:30.810
All computers use that to receive
broadcast communications.

174
00:09:30.810 --> 00:09:32.239
That's why it's not 255, but it's 254.

175
00:09:32.239 --> 00:09:37.000
That's the last usable IP address
essentially within this network.

176
00:09:38.860 --> 00:09:42.232
Now the next thing that we do is we
configure things like the subnet mask.

177
00:09:42.232 --> 00:09:43.830
And I can modify this.

178
00:09:43.830 --> 00:09:44.484
I can do this couple of different ways.

179
00:09:44.484 --> 00:09:47.808
I can decide [INAUDIBLE] if we happen
to be doing class listener domain

180
00:09:47.808 --> 00:09:48.754
routing, right.

181
00:09:48.754 --> 00:09:52.820
And I can do a variable link subnet mask,
VLSM.

182
00:09:52.820 --> 00:09:58.004
But I'm gonna ahead and
I'll just leave it classful.

183
00:09:58.004 --> 00:10:01.573
So we're gonna use a /24,
24 bit subnet mask, or

184
00:10:01.573 --> 00:10:05.310
a 255.255.255.0 and we'll choose Next.

185
00:10:05.310 --> 00:10:08.872
Now, we also have what
are known as exclusions.

186
00:10:08.872 --> 00:10:11.220
I'm gonna come back to exclusions here,

187
00:10:11.220 --> 00:10:13.780
cuz I want to show you
setting up exclusions.

188
00:10:13.780 --> 00:10:17.610
But, it's going to give you
what the definitions are.

189
00:10:17.610 --> 00:10:22.246
An exclusion says if you've got within
this range that you just created,

190
00:10:22.246 --> 00:10:25.848
if we go back to My Computer
within this range right here.

191
00:10:25.848 --> 00:10:29.544
You've got a certain set
of addresses that you

192
00:10:29.544 --> 00:10:33.130
don't want this DHCP server to hand out.

193
00:10:33.130 --> 00:10:35.838
Maybe you got things like
voice over IP phones.

194
00:10:35.838 --> 00:10:38.355
They're statically mapped.

195
00:10:38.355 --> 00:10:41.524
Theyre not changing,
they don't rely on a dynamic address.

196
00:10:41.524 --> 00:10:42.669
You statically map those.

197
00:10:42.669 --> 00:10:47.546
Well, if I want, I could put a range.

198
00:10:47.546 --> 00:10:51.190
I could do let's say maybe 192.168.1.

199
00:10:51.190 --> 00:10:55.749
And I don't know,
maybe I've got a few addresses,

200
00:10:55.749 --> 00:10:59.076
150, and I can do 192, maybe.

201
00:10:59.076 --> 00:11:02.100
No, 192.168.1 and I can do maybe 200.

202
00:11:02.100 --> 00:11:05.855
And I say that, it's kind of hard for
me to type apparently.

203
00:11:05.855 --> 00:11:10.167
And then what I could do,
is I could add that, and that says those,

204
00:11:10.167 --> 00:11:13.550
50 address will not be
handed out to anybody.

205
00:11:13.550 --> 00:11:16.838
I don't care, if you call out on
the network and say hey got an IP address,

206
00:11:16.838 --> 00:11:18.600
your not going to get these addresses.

207
00:11:18.600 --> 00:11:22.995
And then if we had 50 voice over IP phones
that were statically mapped, guess what?

208
00:11:22.995 --> 00:11:25.160
They're excluded from that entire range

00:34:59.230 --> 00:35:04.050
Sometimes when you get, and
apparently it's active.

658
00:35:04.050 --> 00:35:04.810
Notice this here.

659
00:35:04.810 --> 00:35:08.770
192.168.1.250.

660
00:35:08.770 --> 00:35:13.190
All right, so l have a active reservation
that this computer is now utilizing.

661
00:35:13.190 --> 00:35:16.455
Let me see, l might have just
jumped the gun on that too fast.

662
00:35:16.455 --> 00:35:18.850
Let me try that one more time.

663
00:35:18.850 --> 00:35:20.670
And it did finally, it did.

664
00:35:20.670 --> 00:35:22.605
I was a little bit
faster than the refresh.

665
00:35:22.605 --> 00:35:26.439
[LAUGH] And that doesn't easily happen,
usually I'm two steps behind.

666
00:35:26.439 --> 00:35:28.251
But now you notice here, right?

667
00:35:28.251 --> 00:35:34.550
192.168.1.250, there is the reservation,
all right?

668
00:35:34.550 --> 00:35:37.030
And that means every time this computer,
if it looks and

669
00:35:37.030 --> 00:35:41.360
it's got a lease that's expired, and
it calls back out to the network and

670
00:35:41.360 --> 00:35:45.180
says DCHP I need an IP address,
it's gonna get that same one every time.

671
00:35:45.180 --> 00:35:48.310
That's what's known as a MAC reservation,
or a reservation, if you will.

672
00:35:49.670 --> 00:35:52.170
Now, I mentioned a couple of concepts,

673
00:35:52.170 --> 00:35:55.350
last thing I know I'm
running way late on this one.

674
00:35:55.350 --> 00:35:56.971
Zach's letting me know we
gotta wrap this one up.

675
00:35:56.971 --> 00:35:57.734
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

676
00:35:57.734 --> 00:36:01.370
there are just a couple more things
that I wanna put into this episode,

677
00:36:01.370 --> 00:36:03.760
especially because two
of them relate to DHCP.

678
00:36:03.760 --> 00:36:07.440
One of them also relates to DNS.

679
00:36:07.440 --> 00:36:11.325
And that is something known as
a DHCP relay agent or an IP helper.

680
00:36:11.325 --> 00:36:13.132
Now, IP helper is essentially,

681
00:36:13.132 --> 00:36:16.748
you gotta understand that broadcast
communications, routers do

682
00:36:16.748 --> 00:36:20.958
not allow broadcast communications
to traverse their interfaces, right?

683
00:36:20.958 --> 00:36:26.260
So if a router receives a broadcast
communication on one network adapter,

684
00:36:26.260 --> 00:36:30.479
it's not gonna pass that over
to the next network, right?

685
00:36:30.479 --> 00:36:32.538
It filters that and throws it away.

686
00:36:32.538 --> 00:36:36.168
But sometimes you'll have a DHCP
server that's on one network, and

687
00:36:36.168 --> 00:36:40.050
you'll have a client that's on
a completely different subnet.

688
00:36:40.050 --> 00:36:44.515
And you want it to be able to communicate
with the DHCP server by broadcasting,

689
00:36:44.515 --> 00:36:46.590
right, the door process discovery.

690
00:36:46.590 --> 00:36:48.290
But how do I do that?

691
00:36:48.290 --> 00:36:51.950
If the discovery packet's a broadcast,
how do I get that across the router's

692
00:36:51.950 --> 00:36:55.450
interface when it's being picky and
it's discarding broadcast?

693
00:36:55.450 --> 00:36:58.500
Well, that's where the DHCP
relay agent comes in.

694
00:36:58.500 --> 00:37:04.500
The router will see this
UDP Broadcast DHCP request, and it'll

695
00:37:04.500 --> 00:37:10.250
wrap it a unicast transmission, it'll
convert it into a unicast transmission.

696
00:37:10.250 --> 00:37:15.050
And it'll send it directly to the other
network, directly to the DHCP server.

697
00:37:15.050 --> 00:37:17.550
That will pass the router's interface.

698
00:37:17.550 --> 00:37:22.142
Because then after that process, it's a
unicast address, and now the communication

699
00:37:22.142 --> 00:37:28.245
with a DHCP relay agent, it can relay
that information in between, all right?

700
00:37:28.245 --> 00:37:31.700
Now, doesn't necessary mean
that it has to be a router.

701
00:37:31.700 --> 00:37:38.030
You can have, where the client is, you can
configure it to use the DHCP relay agent.

702
00:37:38.030 --> 00:37:42.990
The DHCP relay agent can wrap in
a unicast, send it directly to the router,

703
00:37:42.990 --> 00:37:44.620
and the router passes unicast anyways.

704
00:37:44.620 --> 00:37:46.460
So to the router it would be
transparent at that point.

705
00:37:47.480 --> 00:37:54.680
IP helper, that just means when you
have some kind of UDP broadcast service

706
00:37:54.680 --> 00:37:58.750
request like that, the router's gonna drop
it cuz it's a broadcast communication.

707
00:37:58.750 --> 00:38:00.510
So what does an IP helper do?

708
00:38:00.510 --> 00:38:03.510
It just takes that broadcast
communication, wraps it into a unicast,

709
00:38:03.510 --> 00:38:05.690
and directs it over to
where the service is.

710
00:38:05.690 --> 00:38:09.750
And they're kinda using these
together because that's exact

711
00:38:09.750 --> 00:38:12.340
what a DHCP relay agent does.

712
00:38:12.340 --> 00:38:15.790
It takes that broadcast communication,
wraps it into a unicast, and

713
00:38:15.790 --> 00:38:19.770
sends it directly to the DHCP server so
that it can finish the door process.

714
00:38:21.150 --> 00:38:27.370
Now, I showed you one example of where DNS
and DHCP can kind of communicate together,

715
00:38:27.370 --> 00:38:30.800
and they could make each other aware,
right, through dynamic registration.

716
00:38:30.800 --> 00:38:31.570
That's okay.

717
00:38:31.570 --> 00:38:35.940
What if you have 5, 000 computers
across all these different subnets?

718
00:38:35.940 --> 00:38:36.930
Different DNS servers.

719
00:38:36.930 --> 00:38:42.300
And you want to be able to allow
the coordination between DHCP and DNS?

720
00:38:42.300 --> 00:38:46.730
Well, that's where the Internet Protocol
Address Management technology comes in.

721
00:38:46.730 --> 00:38:47.640
IPAM as they call it.

722
00:38:47.640 --> 00:38:52.355
It allows you to coordinate on a large
scale, too, up to a large scale.

723
00:38:52.355 --> 00:38:58.310
The communication between DHCP and
DNS so that we agree.

724
00:38:58.310 --> 00:39:00.320
Last but
not least is network time protocol.

725
00:39:00.320 --> 00:39:02.290
I'm not going to go into that one
too much because, Zach, you and

726
00:39:02.290 --> 00:39:04.150
I talked about that in
the protocol episodes.

727
00:39:04.150 --> 00:39:06.780
Remember, synchronization is important.

728
00:39:06.780 --> 00:39:07.500
Time is important.

729
00:39:07.500 --> 00:39:09.035
Especially on a Windows domain.

730
00:39:09.035 --> 00:39:12.990
So, NTP is a service that, hey,
I need time synchronization.

731
00:39:12.990 --> 00:39:14.080
What do I do?

732
00:39:14.080 --> 00:39:16.570
I send a request to update my time clock.

733
00:39:16.570 --> 00:39:17.370
In a Windows domain,

734
00:39:17.370 --> 00:39:21.360
it just happens to be the master time
clock's whats known as the PDC emulator.

735
00:39:21.360 --> 00:39:25.420
One of the domain controllers,
depending on how you've got it set up.

736
00:39:25.420 --> 00:39:27.840
I need to synchronize my time clock.

737
00:39:27.840 --> 00:39:29.980
Well, I'm gonna use NTP to do that.

738
00:39:29.980 --> 00:39:35.325
So these are some very, very important
network services and how they function.

739
00:39:35.325 --> 00:39:40.345
Know DNS, know DHCP, be aware of it for
the exam because they're gonna put

740
00:39:40.345 --> 00:39:44.715
you potentially into multiple scenarios,
and you might know A plus B equals C.

741
00:39:44.715 --> 00:39:48.889
But what if I take out B?

742
00:39:48.889 --> 00:39:50.123
Do you know how we got C?

743
00:39:50.123 --> 00:39:52.025
So you're gonna have to
know all the pieces so

744
00:39:52.025 --> 00:39:55.356
that you can know what the answer is the
next time they ask you on the Net + exam.

745
00:39:55.356 --> 00:39:56.674
>> And fortunately, Wes,

746
00:39:56.674 --> 00:40:00.831
you do provide us all the pieces This is
Network Service Functions part three.

747
00:40:00.831 --> 00:40:02.712
Make sure you see parts one and two.

748
00:40:02.712 --> 00:40:05.861
And make sure you see everything
in the COMPTIA Net + series.

749
00:40:05.861 --> 00:40:09.401
While you're at it, check out the other
videos in the course library,

750
00:40:09.401 --> 00:40:10.352
hundreds of them.

751
00:40:10.352 --> 00:40:12.107
All designed to take your further.

752
00:40:12.107 --> 00:40:15.410
And tell everybody you know about
ITPRO.TV, they'll be very glad you did.

753
00:40:15.410 --> 00:40:17.165
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

754
00:40:17.165 --> 00:40:17.886
>> And I'm Wes Brian.

755
00:40:17.886 --> 00:40:20.211
>> And we will see you soon

756
00:40:20.211 --> 00:40:26.281
[MUSIC]

757
00:40:26.281 --> 00:40:29.600
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.787 --> 00:00:07.123
Welcome to ITPro TV I'm
your host Don Pezet

2
00:00:07.123 --> 00:00:12.412
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:12.412 --> 00:00:15.890
>> Thank you for choosing ITPRO.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

4
00:00:15.890 --> 00:00:19.310
I'm Zach Memos, your host for
this episode of Net Plus.

5
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:24.530
And we're gonna be looking at the TCP/IP
model with the one and only, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:24.530 --> 00:00:26.110
Wes, glad to have you here, thanks.

7
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:27.613
>> Thanks, Zach,
thanks for having me here.

8
00:00:27.613 --> 00:00:31.565
That's right, we were going through the
objectives and we like to be thorough, and

9
00:00:31.565 --> 00:00:33.681
I just happened to look
into the objectives,

10
00:00:33.681 --> 00:00:35.865
and see in the OSI model, right?

11
00:00:35.865 --> 00:00:37.285
And we've talked about in other episode,

12
00:00:37.285 --> 00:00:39.865
we've talked about the Open
Systems Interconnection model that

13
00:00:39.865 --> 00:00:41.605
really goes back to.

14
00:00:41.605 --> 00:00:44.725
They say the 80's is when they
started standardizing this, but

15
00:00:44.725 --> 00:00:48.825
I believe the model actually goes back
a little further like 1977 or so, right?

16
00:00:48.825 --> 00:00:53.084
So, we've talked about that model,
and we had mentioned,

17
00:00:53.084 --> 00:00:56.508
well I should say I've mentioned,
in passing,

18
00:00:56.508 --> 00:01:00.704
I've mentioned TCP/IP through
the whole entire course.

19
00:01:00.704 --> 00:01:03.754
But we haven't really defined
what TCP/IP is, right?

20
00:01:03.754 --> 00:01:04.460
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

21
00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:06.190
>> So, even though it's not actually

22
00:01:06.190 --> 00:01:09.996
called out by the exam objectives,
you better believe you're gonna see stuff

23
00:01:09.996 --> 00:01:13.760
about TCP/IP on the exam, and it is one
of those things that kind of implied.

24
00:01:13.760 --> 00:01:16.610
So, in this episode what we'd like to do,

25
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:19.235
since we've already
recorded out OSI model,

26
00:01:19.235 --> 00:01:22.715
if you're not familiar with that, by all
means, go back and check it out, right?

27
00:01:22.715 --> 00:01:27.255
Watch the OSI model there for
more in depth on the OSI itself.

28
00:01:28.495 --> 00:01:31.985
In this episode, we're gonna talk about
the Transmission Control Protocol,

29
00:01:31.985 --> 00:01:33.510
Internet Protocol suite, right?

30
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:35.030
The protocol stack or

31
00:01:35.030 --> 00:01:40.590
the abstract model that really is
the most common model that's used today.

32
00:01:40.590 --> 00:01:44.590
And then at the end what we'd like to do,
in this episode,

33
00:01:44.590 --> 00:01:47.940
we'd like to kind of come back and
tie it all together, right?

34
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:50.300
Look at the OSI model,
and then look at TCP/IP,

35
00:01:50.300 --> 00:01:54.500
kinda put them side-by-side, and,
let's see what they're doing, right?

36
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:55.830
Do they agree on certain things?

37
00:01:55.830 --> 00:01:57.490
Do they disagree on other things?

38
00:01:57.490 --> 00:02:01.410
So that you can have a little bit
more thorough understanding of

39
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:03.660
why do we say layer one?

40
00:02:03.660 --> 00:02:09.200
And that means the physical layer and
then other terminology, layer one actually

41
00:02:09.200 --> 00:02:14.290
defines the characteristics of let's say
Mac addressing and the physical media.

42
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:16.070
Well, wait a second, what's going on here?

43
00:02:16.070 --> 00:02:19.380
So, that's one of the things that we're
gonna do right here in this episode.

44
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:20.510
>> Let's do it.

45
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:23.360
>> All right, so let's go ahead,
TCP/IP basics, all right?

46
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:27.271
Transmission Control Protocol,
Internet Protocol suite,

47
00:02:27.271 --> 00:02:29.889
even though they are two
protocols in the name, all right?

48
00:02:29.889 --> 00:02:35.561
It's actually a family of technology,
an entire suite of technologies here,

49
00:02:35.561 --> 00:02:41.249
that also are formed kinda like OSI,
in an abstract layered model, all right?

50
00:02:41.249 --> 00:02:46.048
And in fact, let's go ahead and look at,
I've got a little diagram here, and

51
00:02:46.048 --> 00:02:48.973
these are the layers
within the TCP/IP model.

52
00:02:48.973 --> 00:02:54.200
Now, this goes way back to the 60s when
the United States Department of Defense,

53
00:02:54.200 --> 00:02:58.906
and more specifically DARPA,
Defense Advance Research Project Agency,

54
00:02:58.906 --> 00:03:04.528
was developing communication protocols for
what was back then called ARPANET, right?

55
00:03:04.528 --> 00:03:07.540
We've kinda mentioned that,
that was the predecessor to our Internet.

56
00:03:07.540 --> 00:03:11.540
And then at a certain point
ARPANET kinda split if you will,

57
00:03:11.540 --> 00:03:15.180
while the military went to MILNET and
that's their lockdown military network.

58
00:03:15.180 --> 00:03:20.190
And ARPANET was released into the public
domain, would later become the Internet.

59
00:03:20.190 --> 00:03:25.130
Well, this protocol stack, this actually
goes back to those earliest days when

60
00:03:25.130 --> 00:03:28.513
they were trying to route
traffic across the ARPANET.

61
00:03:28.513 --> 00:03:31.754
And the one big thing that
they wanted to do is,

62
00:03:31.754 --> 00:03:35.913
they wanted to be able to route
traffic across ARPANET, and

63
00:03:35.913 --> 00:03:40.424
the individual local area
networks connection technologies.

64
00:03:40.424 --> 00:03:43.560
TCB/IP would be independent of that,
right?

65
00:03:43.560 --> 00:03:46.050
So it's been around for a very long time.

66
00:03:46.050 --> 00:03:50.740
It is the most common network
communication implementation

67
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:52.760
used by the internet today, right?

68
00:03:52.760 --> 00:03:53.710
When we say internet, right?

69
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:56.180
I want you to think of IP,
Internet Protocol.

70
00:03:56.180 --> 00:04:00.178
That's the most common addressing
protocol out there today.

71
00:04:00.178 --> 00:04:02.270
Now, by all means,
it's not the only one, right?

72
00:04:02.270 --> 00:04:03.060
We've had others as well.

73
00:04:03.060 --> 00:04:04.877
We've had things like Novell,

74
00:04:04.877 --> 00:04:10.020
had the IPX/SPX the Inter Packet
Exchange/Sequenced Packet Exchange.

75
00:04:10.020 --> 00:04:12.560
And it's not as common,
it kinda went by the wayside.

76
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:17.320
Proprietary, and for
whatever reason it never took off.

77
00:04:17.320 --> 00:04:22.416
Apple was another player,
a big competitor in technologies,

78
00:04:22.416 --> 00:04:24.828
they had Appletalk, right?

79
00:04:24.828 --> 00:04:26.205
Appletalk was another protocol out there.

80
00:04:26.205 --> 00:04:30.265
But again ultimately what it came
down to is the most commonly

81
00:04:30.265 --> 00:04:33.465
vendor distributed protocol
suite would be TCP/IP.

82
00:04:33.465 --> 00:04:36.275
And it would become
later on what we use and

83
00:04:36.275 --> 00:04:39.755
what we use today for
internet communications.

84
00:04:39.755 --> 00:04:40.865
Now it has other names.

85
00:04:40.865 --> 00:04:44.555
You might hear it referred to
as not as common as TCP/IP,

86
00:04:44.555 --> 00:04:48.590
that is by far what everybody
recognizes once in that working, right?

87
00:04:48.590 --> 00:04:49.710
But it has other names, too.

88
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:52.230
Like for instance,
it was called the DARPA model,

89
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:54.370
hence because DARPA was the one
that invented it, right?

90
00:04:54.370 --> 00:04:58.619
Imagine that, or sometimes you might even
hear it called the DoD model, right?

91
00:04:58.619 --> 00:05:00.841
The Department of Defense model, too.

92
00:05:00.841 --> 00:05:06.509
All right, so we do have to be aware
of Transmission Control Protocol,

93
00:05:06.509 --> 00:05:09.200
Internet Protocol suite.

94
00:05:09.200 --> 00:05:15.180
Again, the two protocols that perform
a lot of the major functions are TCP/IP,

95
00:05:15.180 --> 00:05:17.390
hence why it's in the name,
but it's not the only one.

96
00:05:17.390 --> 00:05:20.970
So, let's go ahead and
let's look at our slide here, and

97
00:05:20.970 --> 00:05:23.190
let's talk about some of
the services that we can see.

98
00:05:23.190 --> 00:05:27.035
And then what we'll also do is go a little
bit in to some of the protocols that you

99
00:05:27.035 --> 00:05:29.215
can see in each of these layers,
all right?

100
00:05:29.215 --> 00:05:30.765
When we look at the application layer,
all right?

101
00:05:30.765 --> 00:05:35.370
The application layer, it provides things
like network resource access, right?

102
00:05:35.370 --> 00:05:39.240
If we've got an application
that we need to exchange data,

103
00:05:39.240 --> 00:05:41.810
some kinda application data exchange,
well, guess what?

104
00:05:41.810 --> 00:05:46.330
The application layer is the one
that gives network services to those

105
00:05:46.330 --> 00:05:47.170
applications, right?

106
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:49.602
It provides those resources.

107
00:05:49.602 --> 00:05:51.658
Provides things like name resolution,
right?

108
00:05:51.658 --> 00:05:52.911
When we need to take those names and

109
00:05:52.911 --> 00:05:55.260
resolve them to the lower level
IP addresses, well guess what?

110
00:05:55.260 --> 00:05:59.272
The application layer is the one
that provides that functionality and

111
00:05:59.272 --> 00:06:00.498
that service for us.

112
00:06:00.498 --> 00:06:02.585
It also does things like data encoding,
all right?

113
00:06:02.585 --> 00:06:03.770
You say encoding, decoding, all right?

114
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:06.550
Think about just formatting or syntaxed.

115
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:11.510
Now, it also has the syntax functionality
inside of the application layer as well.

116
00:06:11.510 --> 00:06:16.682
It provides things like, for instance,
encryption and compression, all right?

117
00:06:16.682 --> 00:06:19.178
That all happens right here
at the application layer 1,

118
00:06:19.178 --> 00:06:21.367
as well as things like network management,
too.

119
00:06:21.367 --> 00:06:23.598
And we'll come back and
we'll look at some of the protocols, too.

120
00:06:23.598 --> 00:06:27.814
So this'll make it hopefully a little bit
more added sense to some of the services

121
00:06:27.814 --> 00:06:29.000
that it'll provide.

122
00:06:29.000 --> 00:06:31.813
And if those of you who have
already been studying OSI model,

123
00:06:31.813 --> 00:06:34.580
when I start saying things
like name recognition.

124
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:37.866
You probably got in the back of your
head maybe one of the protocols that I'm

125
00:06:37.866 --> 00:06:38.606
talking about.

126
00:06:38.606 --> 00:06:41.768

00:11:10.490 --> 00:11:13.670

The Transmission Control Protocol says,

LAN communications, LAN technologies,

Clearly defined.

In context I gotta figure out

Busy.
We're talking about OSI and

Keep saying Internet so

So you have for instance here,

But then we can see other information,

Well, SMB is server message block,

Now, I didn't mention it, but SMB, Samba,

But notice that we have we've

We have right here,

00:22:47.160 --> 00:22:50.040

Right.
And

that's another thing to keep in

Inside of the application layer in TCP IP.

I can see DNS and we'll see a little bit

00:23:27.390 --> 00:23:29.490

That's kinda built right into

00:23:37.650 --> 00:23:38.720

So what do I have right here?

00:23:40.800 --> 00:23:42.900
Remember we said the transmission
control protocol,

00:23:42.900 --> 00:23:44.950
TCP is a connection oriented service.

471
00:23:44.950 --> 00:23:46.980
How does it happen?

472
00:23:46.980 --> 00:23:47.521
Right?
Well,

473
00:23:47.521 --> 00:23:51.340
it happens through what's known as
a TCP three-way handshake, all right?

474
00:23:51.340 --> 00:23:52.678
Hey, I need something.

475
00:23:52.678 --> 00:23:55.989
Okay, I acknowledge the other side,
I acknowledge that you need something.

476
00:23:55.989 --> 00:23:59.535
Hey, Now we're connected and
we can set up a communication.

477
00:23:59.535 --> 00:24:00.585
Three-way handshake.

478
00:24:00.585 --> 00:24:04.090
What we have is a syncronization
request packet.

479
00:24:04.090 --> 00:24:06.550
This is kinda cool when you get
down into the protocol analyze.

480
00:24:06.550 --> 00:24:09.480
You're like wow that's the protocol
doing what it's supposed to be doing.

481
00:24:09.480 --> 00:24:13.640
It's setting up that
connection oriented session.

482
00:24:13.640 --> 00:24:15.820
It's saying hey I need
to syncronize with you.

483
00:24:15.820 --> 00:24:16.885
And then the end party.

484
00:24:16.885 --> 00:24:19.316
The other system calls back and
says okay, I acknowledge it.

485
00:24:19.316 --> 00:24:21.780
It's called a SynAck,
synchronization acknowledgement packet.

486
00:24:21.780 --> 00:24:23.740
I acknowledge that you
want to synchronize.

487
00:24:23.740 --> 00:24:25.550
And then finally to set
up that connection.

488
00:24:25.550 --> 00:24:30.212
It sends back the acknowledgement, right?

489
00:24:30.212 --> 00:24:31.195
So that's the last one.

490
00:24:31.195 --> 00:24:33.720
So you have the TCP three
way handshake going on here.

491
00:24:33.720 --> 00:24:37.790
And we could see that information Right
here in the protocol stack, right?

492
00:24:37.790 --> 00:24:40.020
And let me go ahead and select this one.

493
00:24:40.020 --> 00:24:41.590
Now, here's another thing to keep in mind.

00:24:41.590 --> 00:24:44.840
Some people believe that in every
single communication you do.

00:24:44.840 --> 00:24:48.724
You're gonna work down the application
to the network interface.

496
00:24:48.724 --> 00:24:51.330
Back up the network interface
all the way to the application.

497
00:24:52.430 --> 00:24:54.730
That isn't necessarily true, all right?

498
00:24:54.730 --> 00:24:58.040
Because sometimes transmission control
protocol is just communicating, right?

499
00:24:58.040 --> 00:25:01.000
Hey Hold on application, you need to stop.

500
00:25:01.000 --> 00:25:02.490
Don't send me your information yet.

501
00:25:02.490 --> 00:25:04.253
You need a connection oriented service,

00:25:04.253 --> 00:25:05.677
That's what you're telling me?

503
00:25:05.677 --> 00:25:07.240
Hold the horses.

504
00:25:07.240 --> 00:25:10.840
Let me go ahead and set that up with

505
00:25:10.840 --> 00:25:13.830
That's why we don't that many

00:25:13.830 --> 00:25:16.070
This is the very first

00:25:16.070 --> 00:25:18.180

508
00:25:18.180 --> 00:25:22.510
I see you're trying to give me this SDU,

509
00:25:22.510 --> 00:25:23.870

510
00:25:23.870 --> 00:25:25.400
Let me go ahead and
pick up the phone call and

I'll get that phone call started for

00:25:27.460 --> 00:25:29.890
And then you can pull

What we see after that,

00:25:33.210 --> 00:25:36.060

00:25:36.060 --> 00:25:41.380
These three packets that I've captured

00:25:41.380 --> 00:25:44.170
But notice what happens

00:25:44.170 --> 00:25:45.950

We hit the first SMB, and

And in between the application layer

Like I said,

521
00:25:57.540 --> 00:26:00.291
But at the application layer it

523
00:26:03.970 --> 00:26:05.998
But you can see that there it is.

00:26:05.998 --> 00:26:09.673
There is SMB sitting right
on that transport Protocol,

525
00:26:09.673 --> 00:26:12.026
which is sitting right on top of IP.

526
00:26:12.026 --> 00:26:15.030
Which is then finally encapsulated

527
00:26:17.800 --> 00:26:20.420
And then,
it's turned into an electrical current and

00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:23.200

529
00:26:23.200 --> 00:26:25.960
So those are some of the things that you
can see in transmission control protocol,

530
00:26:25.960 --> 00:26:27.990
