00:13:59.030 --> 00:14:02.210
All right, if they ask you about
the layers, I'm gonna go ahead and

267
00:14:02.210 --> 00:14:07.790
move back one slide here, because I do
want you to keep in mind, all right.

268
00:14:07.790 --> 00:14:10.670
I've done this myself when I was
communicating with somebody else and

269
00:14:10.670 --> 00:14:14.680
they were asking me about, they said
layer two, I need to route the traffic.

270
00:14:14.680 --> 00:14:19.070
You can't route traffic with layer two.

271
00:14:19.070 --> 00:14:23.240
Yes, you can, no, you can't, and
then we found out we were both right.

272
00:14:23.240 --> 00:14:27.220
I was talking about OSI and
he was talking about the TCP/IP model.

273
00:14:27.220 --> 00:14:28.332
We were both right.

274
00:14:28.332 --> 00:14:29.872
When he said layer two,

275
00:14:29.872 --> 00:14:34.600
what he was talking about was that
Internet layer where IP sits, right?

276
00:14:34.600 --> 00:14:39.754
Versus the network layer which is what I
was talking about, which I'm also right.

277
00:14:39.754 --> 00:14:41.570
[LAUGH] So we were both right, all right?

278
00:14:41.570 --> 00:14:43.660
I want you to keep that
in mind on an exam.

279
00:14:43.660 --> 00:14:49.020
What layer of the such and
such model does a switch operate at?

280
00:14:49.020 --> 00:14:51.000
Well, layer 1 or layer 2?

281
00:14:51.000 --> 00:14:53.650
Well, there again, depends on
what model you're talking about.

282
00:14:53.650 --> 00:14:56.110
If you're talking OSI model,
switching happens at layer 2.

283
00:14:56.110 --> 00:14:59.164
If you're talking about TCP/IP model,
it happens at layer 1.

284
00:15:00.420 --> 00:15:02.220
It can get a little confusing.

285
00:15:02.220 --> 00:15:04.860
So know your numbers,
that is an important thing.

286
00:15:04.860 --> 00:15:09.580
Know the comparisons, know where some of
the protocols sit and also always, always,

287
00:15:09.580 --> 00:15:11.950
always, always, pay attention to keywords.

288
00:15:11.950 --> 00:15:16.980
Because if you miss a keyword, just like
I did, had I been listening to a friend

289
00:15:16.980 --> 00:15:22.630
of mine that we were discussing
switching or it was routing, right?

290
00:15:22.630 --> 00:15:26.545
Had I listened to the keywords I would've
heard that maybe he was talking about

291
00:15:26.545 --> 00:15:27.600
TCP/IP.

292
00:15:27.600 --> 00:15:31.103
Or maybe if he had listened to me,
I was talking about OSI model.

293
00:15:31.103 --> 00:15:34.456
But since we both thought
we knew we were both right,

294
00:15:34.456 --> 00:15:36.754
which technically we kind of were.

295
00:15:36.754 --> 00:15:39.800
We didn't even agree to disagree,
I guess, right?

296
00:15:39.800 --> 00:15:43.600
That little miss,

297
00:15:43.600 --> 00:15:49.640
right, not only does it happen within
just communicating amongst people.

298
00:15:49.640 --> 00:15:52.650
It could also happen if you don't
read the question thoroughly,

299
00:15:52.650 --> 00:15:53.930
read that question thoroughly.

300
00:15:53.930 --> 00:15:57.660
Pay attention to what model they're
talking about, know both of the models.

301
00:15:57.660 --> 00:16:04.340
Know the OSI model, know the TCP/IP model,
know the comparisons between the two.

302
00:16:04.340 --> 00:16:07.319
So just in case, all right,
they ask you on the exam.

303
00:16:07.319 --> 00:16:11.982
But you also need to know this too
because as you go on to more higher level

304
00:16:11.982 --> 00:16:15.963
networking certifications,
OSI model's gonna be there.

305
00:16:15.963 --> 00:16:20.206
But you can believe the Transmission
Control Protocol Internet, Protocol Model,

306
00:16:20.206 --> 00:16:22.130
TCP/IP model, is going to be there.

307
00:16:22.130 --> 00:16:26.927
Because it is the most common technology
that we use to route traffic across

308
00:16:26.927 --> 00:16:30.176
the Internet today.
>> Well said Wes, very well done and

309
00:16:30.176 --> 00:16:33.044
TCP/IP model Part 2,
make sure you see part 1 and

310
00:16:33.044 --> 00:16:35.790
see everything inside
the Net+ series as well.

311
00:16:35.790 --> 00:16:38.569
Because Wes has done a great job
putting that all together for you and

312
00:16:38.569 --> 00:16:41.712
you're in the course library so
there's thousands of other videos there.

313
00:16:41.712 --> 00:16:45.104
Take a look at them, they're great for
you, and they'll help you move forward,

314
00:16:45.104 --> 00:16:46.984
and tell everyone you know about ITPro.TV.

315
00:16:46.984 --> 00:16:50.100
ITPro.TV is bingeworthy, thanks for
watching I'm Zach Memos.

316
00:16:50.100 --> 00:16:50.894
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

317
00:16:50.894 --> 00:16:53.342
>> And we will see you soon.

318
00:16:53.342 --> 00:16:58.531
[MUSIC]

319
00:16:58.531 --> 00:17:01.963
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes dive into different cabling solutions avaiable in today's modern networks. They will talk about copper-based media as well as the various connectors associated with these cable types.
episodes.title: Cabling Solutions-Copper
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:02.592
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.592 --> 00:00:08.251
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.251 --> 00:00:12.190
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.190 --> 00:00:13.040
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:13.040 --> 00:00:15.970
watching ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.970 --> 00:00:20.690
My name is Zach Memos, and I'm your host
as we continue on with CompTIA Net +,

7
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:22.800
cabling solutions copper.

8
00:00:22.800 --> 00:00:24.468
That's the name of this episode and

9
00:00:24.468 --> 00:00:28.795
Wes Bryan is just the fellow we need
to tell us, what we need to know.

10
00:00:28.795 --> 00:00:29.764
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right and-

11
00:00:29.764 --> 00:00:30.317
>> He's the guy.

12
00:00:30.317 --> 00:00:34.186
>> It's interesting Zach, when we
talked about copper it's like well,

13
00:00:34.186 --> 00:00:36.904
are they just gonna be
talking about colors here.

14
00:00:36.904 --> 00:00:40.140
But no we're talking about copper media,
right.

15
00:00:40.140 --> 00:00:43.297
When we talk about cabling solutions,
we have two,

16
00:00:43.297 --> 00:00:46.820
it really boils down to two
major cabling solutions.

17
00:00:46.820 --> 00:00:51.230
We've got copper, and in another
episode we're gonna talk about fiber.

18
00:00:51.230 --> 00:00:55.600
Copper is one of the most prevalent cable
solutions that we have in our local area

19
00:00:55.600 --> 00:00:56.970
networks today.

20
00:00:56.970 --> 00:00:59.840
That's what we're gonna be taking
a look at here in this episode.

21
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:02.555
>> So Wes, right off the bat,
and obvious question,

22
00:01:02.555 --> 00:01:04.905
what are some copper media types?

23
00:01:04.905 --> 00:01:06.455
>> There's two major ones, and

24
00:01:06.455 --> 00:01:10.245
one has kinda gone by the wayside when
it comes to more data communications.

25
00:01:10.245 --> 00:01:15.325
And then one literally is the most popular
local area network implementation.

26
00:01:15.325 --> 00:01:19.950
And what I'm talking about is twisted
pair implementation and coaxial.

27
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:23.763
Now twisted pair implementations
are how we deploy things like Ethernet.

28
00:01:23.763 --> 00:01:26.843
Ethernet uses twisted pair
implementations, and there's a couple of

29
00:01:26.843 --> 00:01:30.400
varieties that we have to look out when
it comes to twisted pair implementations.

30
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:34.840
Now the next one, coaxial, we have
to be careful with that one because

31
00:01:34.840 --> 00:01:38.780
it really form the basis for
our very early networks, right.

32
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:41.930
The networks in the mid 80s,

33
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:46.185
we talk about things like our very first
Ethernet deployments in other episodes.

34
00:01:46.185 --> 00:01:49.640
Zach, you and I we've talked about
bus based networks, right, and

35
00:01:49.640 --> 00:01:53.820
those earlier bus based networks
had a backbone cable, right.

36
00:01:53.820 --> 00:01:58.030
Just a single centralized backbone cable
that all the nodes were attached to.

37
00:01:58.030 --> 00:02:02.110
Well that would have been coaxial
implementations, those were the ten based

38
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:07.070
five and ten based two in those days,
it would've been thick net and Ethernet.

39
00:02:07.070 --> 00:02:11.660
Thick net used to have the name of well
the frozen yellow garden hose is what

40
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:16.140
it was called, because it was a big
yellow cable and it was really,

41
00:02:16.140 --> 00:02:17.700
really hard to work with.

42
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:19.598
And then the other one thin net or

43
00:02:19.598 --> 00:02:22.911
thin wire Ethernet as it might
have been called as well.

44
00:02:22.911 --> 00:02:26.758
It was about half the diameter
of the earlier one, so

45
00:02:26.758 --> 00:02:31.790
those have really gone,
those are legacy technologies today.

46
00:02:31.790 --> 00:02:36.520
And I'm really too sure that I don't
know if you will see them on the exam,

47
00:02:36.520 --> 00:02:39.270
we'll kinda mention them
a little bit briefly here.

48
00:02:39.270 --> 00:02:43.006
But we will talk about the coaxial
standards that they do require you to

49
00:02:43.006 --> 00:02:47.502
know, because even though coaxial isn't
really used too much in our Ethernet based

50
00:02:47.502 --> 00:02:51.268
implementation as a copper media
solution it's still heavily used.

51
00:02:51.268 --> 00:02:52.376
It's used in audio and

52
00:02:52.376 --> 00:02:55.930
video communications, in fact some
of the directors here that we have,

53
00:02:55.930 --> 00:02:59.487
the director that's behind the scenes
right now helping us produce this

54
00:02:59.487 --> 00:03:03.128
episode's probably seen more coaxial
cables in her life than she wants.

55
00:03:03.128 --> 00:03:07.823
We got boxes of coaxial cables back there,
and what we use them for is audio and

56
00:03:07.823 --> 00:03:12.030
visual, or video, excuse me,
audio and video equipment, right.

57
00:03:12.030 --> 00:03:14.626
Very prevalent in using coaxial media.

58
00:03:14.626 --> 00:03:17.295
So, understand that coaxial
is heavily used, but

59
00:03:17.295 --> 00:03:20.088
when it comes to your
internal land communications,

60
00:03:20.088 --> 00:03:23.513
the most common one is gonna be
the twisted pair implementation.

61
00:03:23.513 --> 00:03:26.460
And we'll talk a little bit more
about twisted pair coming up.

62
00:03:26.460 --> 00:03:29.120
Now when we do mention twisted pair,
all right,

63
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:34.010
well they really boil down to a couple
different types that we need to look at.

64
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:38.100
But let's go ahead and just take
a basic look at what twisted pair and

65
00:03:38.100 --> 00:03:39.950
coaxial look, at least from the outside.

66
00:03:39.950 --> 00:03:43.880
See, these are two types, right, and they
don't real look like anything special.

67
00:03:43.880 --> 00:03:48.193
In fact, this side here we've what's
known as twisted pair implementation, and

68
00:03:48.193 --> 00:03:50.610
we've got here what's
known as the coaxial.

69
00:03:50.610 --> 00:03:53.641
And again, from the outside,
other than the connectors looking

70
00:03:53.641 --> 00:03:56.452
a little bit different,
if I was to cover up the connectors,

71
00:03:56.452 --> 00:03:59.060
the cables don't really
look much different, right.

72
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:04.140
So we gotta kinda understand,
kinda looking at the anatomy

73
00:04:04.140 --> 00:04:07.810
of the cable to really understand what
is the difference between these two.

74
00:04:07.810 --> 00:04:10.952
So what we're gonna do is we're
gonna pull the coaxial cable, and

75
00:04:10.952 --> 00:04:12.928
we'll kinda set that to the side for now.

76
00:04:12.928 --> 00:04:16.318
And we're gonna focus in on
the characteristics of a twisted pair

77
00:04:16.318 --> 00:04:19.831
implementation first, and
then we'll pull coaxial back there and

78
00:04:19.831 --> 00:04:21.640
we won't make coaxial so lonely.

79
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:24.600
Now if I was to cut these connectors, and

80
00:04:24.600 --> 00:04:26.550
we're gonna talk more about
the connectors coming up.

81
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:29.176
But if I was to cut the connectors off,
and

82
00:04:29.176 --> 00:04:33.978
I was to pull the ends of the cable off
and just kinda pull the outside sheath,

83
00:04:33.978 --> 00:04:39.331
protective coating off, you'd see here's
why they call it twisted pair, right.

84
00:04:39.331 --> 00:04:44.261
Now don't worry about this plastic piece
that's right here, that plastic piece is

85
00:04:44.261 --> 00:04:49.070
a separator piece and these actually sit
down in almost like a cross hair, right.

86
00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:53.030
They sit in the four positions right here,
so we really don't need that right now cuz

87
00:04:53.030 --> 00:04:55.480
not all of these cables
necessary are gonna have that.

88
00:04:55.480 --> 00:05:00.105
But what all twisted pair implementations
have are twisted pairs, right.

89
00:05:00.105 --> 00:05:02.175
>> [LAUGH]
>> If they didn't I guess we would

90
00:05:02.175 --> 00:05:07.150
just call them cables [LAUGH] but notice
that we four twisted pairs, all right.

91
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:13.390
Inside of a twisted pair you have eight
copper conductors twisted into four pairs.

92
00:05:13.390 --> 00:05:16.810
Be very, very careful on
the exam with your wording.

93
00:05:16.810 --> 00:05:20.522
I will tell you guys and
gals out there that wording, keywords,

94
00:05:20.522 --> 00:05:21.911
keywords, keywords.

95
00:05:21.911 --> 00:05:27.727
And here's what I mean, all right,
on the exam they might say,

96
00:05:27.727 --> 00:05:31.839
how many copper conductors
are in the cable.

97
00:05:31.839 --> 00:05:35.809
And you're gonna have to
know that it's eight, but

98
00:05:35.809 --> 00:05:40.606
they might say, how may copper
pairs are inside of this cable.

99
00:05:40.606 --> 00:05:42.980
And then at that point,
you're gonna have to know that it's four.

100
00:05:42.980 --> 00:05:47.080
So just pay attention to your keyword,
very easy questions to come across.

101
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:48.210
Easy to get right,

102
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:51.570
also easy to kinda over look if
you're not paying attention, right.

103
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:54.340
So if we were to take these and
untwist these, and

104
00:05:54.340 --> 00:05:56.020
I can tell you that sometimes is a bear.

105
00:05:56.020 --> 00:05:58.850
So I went ahead and
did that before hand here.

106
00:05:58.850 --> 00:06:03.405
If we look at untwisting these,
you can now see that we have well,

107
00:06:03.405 --> 00:06:07.537
we have the eight copper pairs, or I'm
sorry the eight copper conductors here.

108
00:06:07.537 --> 00:06:09.270
I gotta be careful with
my verbage as well.

109
00:06:09.270 --> 00:06:13.395
[LAUGH] But you notice if we look across,
and they're all color coded and

110
00:06:13.395 --> 00:06:16.162
we'll come back to why
that is here in a second.

111
00:06:16.162 --> 00:06:20.565
But you'll notice we got one, two, three,
four, five, six, seven, eight, right.

112
00:06:20.565 --> 00:06:24.335
So that is your twisted
pair implementation.

113
00:06:24.335 --> 00:06:26.696
Now these twist within the cable,

114
00:06:26.696 --> 00:06:32.571
what they do is they help to increase its
immunity to electromagnetic interference.

115
00:06:32.571 --> 00:06:38.080
Now, the better quality of the cable,
and also the faster the speed

116
00:06:38.080 --> 00:06:42.924
requirements, the more twists
have to be in these cables.

117
00:06:42.924 --> 00:06:46.300
And again we'll come back to some
of those concepts coming up.

118
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:49.490
So that is your twisted
pair implementation,

119
00:06:49.490 --> 00:06:52.950
now there are also a couple of different

120
00:06:52.950 --> 00:06:56.900
media types that we need to worry about
when it comes to the twisted pair.

121
00:06:56.900 --> 00:07:01.697
Now the twisted pair implementations,
please understand ladies and gentlemen,

122
00:07:01.697 --> 00:07:06.287
that yeah, the twisted pairs, the more
twists that are in them help to increase

123
00:07:06.287 --> 00:07:09.806
it's immunity to electromagnetic
interference, right.

124
00:07:09.806 --> 00:07:13.074
But we can also go a little
bit further than that,

125
00:07:13.074 --> 00:07:17.505
what you see right here is what is
known as a UTP cable, excuse me.

126
00:07:17.505 --> 00:07:24.680
A UTP cable is an unshielded twisted pair
right, and this one doesn't have a shield.

127
00:07:24.680 --> 00:07:26.210
And really what do I mean by that?

128
00:07:26.210 --> 00:07:27.844
Well let's go ahead,

129
00:07:27.844 --> 00:07:33.524
I've got here I'll pull out here from
the side I'll have a STP cable, right.

130
00:07:33.524 --> 00:07:36.523
Now we're not talking about a motor oil
here, right, [LAUGH] we're not talking

131
00:07:36.523 --> 00:07:39.182
about a company that old Richard Petty
used to drive for, for a while.

132
00:07:39.182 --> 00:07:40.220
>> An additive for my oil.

133
00:07:40.220 --> 00:07:41.781
>> Right, that's exactly it, but

134
00:07:41.781 --> 00:07:45.330
when you look on the outside they
really don't look much different.

135
00:07:45.330 --> 00:07:48.720
Now one of the telltale signs you can tell
that this one is a shielded twisted pair

136
00:07:48.720 --> 00:07:52.510
is because, Zach can you see
the difference between those connectors?

137
00:07:52.510 --> 00:07:54.878
Especially this one here that
I'm kinda moving in the light?

138
00:07:54.878 --> 00:07:58.170
>> Yeah, the shielded looks like it's
got a metal finish or some metal to it.

139
00:07:58.170 --> 00:08:03.231
>> That's exactly it, that's exactly it,
and what this does is the shielding.

140
00:08:03.231 --> 00:08:07.426
Helps to further increase its immunity
to electromagnetic interference.

141
00:08:07.426 --> 00:08:11.200
So that's one of the telltale signs
that this is a shielded twisted pair.

142
00:08:11.200 --> 00:08:17.112
However, again, if we were to strip off
the outside insulating jacket here,

143
00:08:17.112 --> 00:08:22.053
one of the things that we would notice,
if I could peel this back.

144
00:08:22.053 --> 00:08:25.960
I kinda don't wanna break it,
I want you guys to be able to see it.

145
00:08:25.960 --> 00:08:26.730
Look at the foil, right?

146
00:08:26.730 --> 00:08:27.690
>> Metal foil shielding.

147
00:08:27.690 --> 00:08:32.255
>> And that is exactly it,
nail right on the head there, Zach,

148
00:08:32.255 --> 00:08:34.232
that is a foil shielding.

149
00:08:34.232 --> 00:08:39.995
And what it does is it wraps around
these conductors here to increase,

150
00:08:39.995 --> 00:08:45.210
to further increase its immunity to
electromagnetic interference, right?

151
00:08:45.210 --> 00:08:50.217
So that is the difference between
what's known as a UTP cable, right?

152
00:08:50.217 --> 00:08:54.830
An unshielded twisted pair and
a STP cable.

153
00:08:54.830 --> 00:08:58.850
Again, now if I was to pull
this shield off, right?

154
00:08:58.850 --> 00:09:02.440
And you can see there's
quite a bit of coating here.

155
00:09:02.440 --> 00:09:05.730
You can see that there's actually
those twisted pairs in here.

156
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:09.850
And again, they wrap these up pretty
good because you pay a good cost, right?

157
00:09:09.850 --> 00:09:12.455
Shielded twisted pair's more expensive,
>> Mm-hm.

158
00:09:12.455 --> 00:09:14.710
>> Than unshielded twisted pair.

159
00:09:14.710 --> 00:09:17.410
Unshielded twisted pair is really,
really one of the most common.

160
00:09:17.410 --> 00:09:21.510
But there are some times when you
need to increase the resistance, or

161
00:09:21.510 --> 00:09:24.900
the immunity, I should say,
to electromagnetic interference.

162
00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:29.525
So for instance,
STP is gonna be run in areas where

163
00:09:29.525 --> 00:09:32.722
maybe your running HVAC systems,

164
00:09:32.722 --> 00:09:37.917
you're running your copper
media next to an elevator.

165
00:09:37.917 --> 00:09:42.730
They give off a lot of electromagnetic

00:21:51.373 --> 00:21:54.660
But what these stand for,
they're actually NEC,

387
00:21:54.660 --> 00:21:59.020
National Electronic Code or
electrical code specifications, and

388
00:21:59.020 --> 00:22:03.600
they're published by
the National Fire Protection Agency.

389
00:22:03.600 --> 00:22:06.710
And they're the ones that certify these.

390
00:22:06.710 --> 00:22:09.120
Hey, if it's plenum grade then
it can be used in plenum.

391
00:22:09.120 --> 00:22:11.612
Obviously if it's not
it's not it's non plenum.

392
00:22:11.612 --> 00:22:17.265
But most of them will have some kind
of basic UL listing even if it's basic,

393
00:22:17.265 --> 00:22:21.342
and you can see there's
a UL listing right here.

394
00:22:21.342 --> 00:22:26.220
But CM if you will,
these are the cables that are used for

395
00:22:26.220 --> 00:22:28.340
general wiring purposes, all right.

396
00:22:28.340 --> 00:22:31.256
These are used basically connecting and

397
00:22:31.256 --> 00:22:35.969
running through your drop ceilings
if you will on a single floor,

398
00:22:35.969 --> 00:22:41.554
they're used essentially in area other
than plenum and risers, all right.

399
00:22:41.554 --> 00:22:42.313
Now the CMR,

400
00:22:42.313 --> 00:22:46.540
let's just focus on the single letters
here that are different from CM.

401
00:22:46.540 --> 00:22:48.140
R means riser, all right,

402
00:22:48.140 --> 00:22:51.280
when we say riser I want you to
think floor to floor, all right.

403
00:22:51.280 --> 00:22:54.737
So if I've got a multi-floor building,

404
00:22:54.737 --> 00:22:59.790
well I can't use the CM to run
vertical runs between floors.

405
00:22:59.790 --> 00:23:05.150
I have to use a CMR, or
CM riser grade cable,

406
00:23:05.150 --> 00:23:11.100
because what it does is it's engineered to
prevent floor to floor fire spread, right.

407
00:23:11.100 --> 00:23:14.707
And that's what that is, they're used
basically in vertical shaft applications.

408
00:23:14.707 --> 00:23:16.740
>> So does CMR then mean that it's plenum?

409
00:23:16.740 --> 00:23:18.526
>> It is, it's not plenum, but

410
00:23:18.526 --> 00:23:20.403
it does share some of-
>> Okay.

411
00:23:20.403 --> 00:23:22.390
>> That's a great question, Zach.

412
00:23:22.390 --> 00:23:26.410
It's not plenum,
which is a little confusing, but it does

413
00:23:26.410 --> 00:23:31.073
have fire resistant properties, right,
so it can be used in vertical shafts.

414
00:23:31.073 --> 00:23:37.250
Now, all right, let's go ahead kinda put
the cart in front of the horse there.

415
00:23:37.250 --> 00:23:38.430
Guess what the next one is?

416
00:23:38.430 --> 00:23:44.903
So if CMR stands for riser,
what do you think the CMP stands for?

417
00:23:44.903 --> 00:23:45.899
>> Plenum!

418
00:23:45.899 --> 00:23:47.578
>> That's right, and that's what that is.

419
00:23:47.578 --> 00:23:49.390
The P stands for plenum.

420
00:23:49.390 --> 00:23:52.989
So if this would have a mark right here it
would let me know that that actually is,

421
00:23:52.989 --> 00:23:56.882
even though it doesn't say plenum on it,
that it's a plenum grade cabling, right.

422
00:23:56.882 --> 00:24:00.232
And these cables essentially
are engineered for fire resistant,

423
00:24:00.232 --> 00:24:02.120
low smoke, if you will.

424
00:24:02.120 --> 00:24:04.082
Toxin producing character.

425
00:24:04.082 --> 00:24:08.330
You know, again, low smoke,
low toxin, producing characteristics.

426
00:24:08.330 --> 00:24:09.180
And they're used for

427
00:24:09.180 --> 00:24:14.100
duct work, plenum applications without
the use of any kind of conduit.

428
00:24:14.100 --> 00:24:18.480
So that would be another way but
we can see a plenum grade cable being

429
00:24:18.480 --> 00:24:22.330
marked right there and honestly I
can't remember for the life of me.

430
00:24:22.330 --> 00:24:25.320
These aren't gonna be on the exam but
at least you kinda have an idea.

431
00:24:25.320 --> 00:24:27.310
If you are taking this exam and

432
00:24:27.310 --> 00:24:29.520
turn around maybe you're
gonna be a cable layer right?

433
00:24:29.520 --> 00:24:32.010
Maybe you need to know
this is part of your job.

434
00:24:32.010 --> 00:24:35.100
It's definitely going to help you
out in the real world as well.

435
00:24:35.100 --> 00:24:38.130
Now the AWG, you might see that a lot,

436
00:24:38.130 --> 00:24:41.880
in fact you will see that a lot, that's
what's known, it's another standard.

437
00:24:41.880 --> 00:24:46.600
It's called American Wire Gauge and 23.

438
00:24:46.600 --> 00:24:51.280
So the number the numerical
value that's before it

439
00:24:51.280 --> 00:24:55.960
they start all the way from like
triple lot zero to a four zeros.

440
00:24:55.960 --> 00:25:00.630
The three zeros we've got any of you
out there that in the body piercing.

441
00:25:00.630 --> 00:25:05.328
It's interesting [LAUGH] that the body
piercing gauges also follow the American

442
00:25:05.328 --> 00:25:07.480
wire gauge standard, right?

443
00:25:07.480 --> 00:25:12.220
So the higher the gauge, and I probably
just catered to an audience that now knows

444
00:25:12.220 --> 00:25:16.080
right away if I've got
a 23 gauge ear piercing,

445
00:25:16.080 --> 00:25:20.030
that's gonna be a smaller diameter
than a ten gauge piercing.

446
00:25:20.030 --> 00:25:24.020
[LAUGH] So another way that you can
look at it, the higher the number

447
00:25:24.020 --> 00:25:28.140
basically saying, you know, it denotes
a decrease in the wire gauge side.

448
00:25:28.140 --> 00:25:33.300
So that's a little bit about
the twisted pair implementations and

449
00:25:33.300 --> 00:25:36.570
it is important to know
some of these standards.

450
00:25:36.570 --> 00:25:40.320
You know, it comes down to what our
standards are very very important.

451
00:25:40.320 --> 00:25:43.490
We've got to know what's
going on with these Cables.

452
00:25:43.490 --> 00:25:46.150
The last one that I might
just kind of throw in here.

453
00:25:46.150 --> 00:25:50.400
Well you will see here kind of
moving in the background here.

454
00:25:50.400 --> 00:25:52.910
What we've got,
this is co-axial cable right?

455
00:25:52.910 --> 00:25:56.610
And it's just coming in on a spool and
it's kind of hard to see.

456
00:25:56.610 --> 00:26:00.910
And I'm not going to try to
make you guys blind out there.

457
00:26:00.910 --> 00:26:05.870
But what you could see on the side
here is it tells you about the cable,

458
00:26:05.870 --> 00:26:09.970
it tells you what the cable is and we're

459
00:26:09.970 --> 00:26:14.420
But this is, essentially, the spool and
they all differ a little bit, right?

460
00:26:14.420 --> 00:26:17.300
I've got another coaxial cable spool

00:26:17.300 --> 00:26:22.130
next to our server closet that's

00:26:22.130 --> 00:26:24.540
And it has another set of stickers

00:26:24.540 --> 00:26:27.240
it lets you know what the cable types are.

464
00:26:27.240 --> 00:26:33.270
So very, very good way that we

465
00:26:33.270 --> 00:26:37.490
Well you can look on the side f the box,
so you know what choices to make, and

466
00:26:37.490 --> 00:26:42.090
again, you can see here that this is

00:26:42.090 --> 00:26:45.780
It doesn't say CMR, but

00:26:45.780 --> 00:26:50.100
I know that it is a CMR grade cable, and

469
00:26:50.100 --> 00:26:56.170
basically floor to floor structured
cabling, so very easy way to

00:26:56.170 --> 00:27:01.920

471
00:27:01.920 --> 00:27:04.665
>> So Wes, as we move on here,
I have one question.

472
00:27:04.665 --> 00:27:05.925
PVC vs plenum.

473
00:27:05.925 --> 00:27:10.185
Is it plenum cable stiffer,
maybe harder to work with?

474
00:27:10.185 --> 00:27:11.005
Am I wrong?

475
00:27:11.005 --> 00:27:13.805
>> No you are absolutely right and
I'm glad you mentioned it cuz I would

476
00:27:13.805 --> 00:27:17.025
have forgot because when we were comparing
PVC to plenum one of the things that I

00:27:17.025 --> 00:27:19.582
said is that
>> with that PVC cable I could

00:27:19.582 --> 00:27:20.912
have bent the cable to the side and

00:27:20.912 --> 00:27:23.092
I showed you there was a little

480
00:27:23.092 --> 00:27:29.992
Well not only does the Plenum grade

00:27:29.992 --> 00:27:35.530
low low smoke,
the other thing too is that outer jacket

00:27:35.530 --> 00:27:40.430
Tightly conformed tightly wraps around
those central copper conductors so

00:27:40.430 --> 00:27:44.370
it doesn't air to pass through,
it doesn't allow air to travel through it.

00:27:44.370 --> 00:27:49.120
Which prevents or
increases the fire resistance right?

485
00:27:49.120 --> 00:27:53.700
Like you said fire retarding if you will.

Decreases its ability to allow fire

00:27:58.840 --> 00:28:01.720
>> Like the PVC ones will as well.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into different cabling solutions avaiable in today's modern networks. They will talk about copper-based media as well as the various connectors associated with these cable types.

This is definitely a good things like

Now, the other one that we have

So this is the registered jack 45,

Because one of the connector types

67
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:52.315
Well DB-9 sub miniature,

00:03:52.315 --> 00:03:55.460

69
00:03:55.460 --> 00:03:57.985
This is actually goes back

00:04:01.555 --> 00:04:03.475
I'll show you the other

74
00:04:06.205 --> 00:04:10.695
This is really,

This would be things like, what is it?

76

The RS-232 null modem cables.

77
00:04:19.531 --> 00:04:23.778
And these were for making point-to-point

00:04:23.778 --> 00:04:25.760

00:04:25.760 --> 00:04:27.100
I know it's a little redundant.

80
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:31.983
When you needed to do a point-to-point

81

83
00:04:42.610 --> 00:04:46.873
And then you could configure it and

84
00:04:46.873 --> 00:04:51.546
Like I said this is actually a connection

85
00:04:51.546 --> 00:04:55.939

00:04:55.939 --> 00:04:57.084

So I've actually seen this

00:05:08.170 --> 00:05:10.790
And the earlier days,

What they actually have is a 25

93
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:18.820

00:05:18.820 --> 00:05:23.670
>> Right and in fact, you know, I don't

Unfortunately because it is

I think one of the oldest cable I've got

00:05:40.700 --> 00:05:42.790
But I've actually got a picture

00:05:42.790 --> 00:05:45.260

00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:04.900

>> And

Straight post, single post, and

Again, the F-type connector that

00:08:22.586 --> 00:08:24.910
And some of you've probably

00:08:28.690 --> 00:08:31.110

00:08:37.710 --> 00:08:41.570
Especially in disaster recovery sites

00:08:42.940 --> 00:08:47.441
And I certainly don't want to

00:08:47.441 --> 00:08:49.866

00:08:49.866 --> 00:08:54.183
And we've had a couple of pretty bad

00:08:54.183 --> 00:08:59.150

00:08:59.150 --> 00:09:01.788
And these people are in bad

00:09:01.788 --> 00:09:03.923

00:09:03.923 --> 00:09:07.771
You might have large portions

168
00:09:07.771 --> 00:09:10.350
like switched networks, that will fail.

169
00:09:10.350 --> 00:09:14.880
But there's a lot of PSTN lines out there,

00:09:14.880 --> 00:09:17.890

they've been around since, what,

171
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:19.490
the late 1800s.

172
00:09:19.490 --> 00:09:21.050
So they're well established.

00:09:21.050 --> 00:09:24.810

But if you're a field technician,

177
00:09:33.287 --> 00:09:37.301
disaster recovery sites, you might be

00:09:37.301 --> 00:09:42.325
So know that dial-up [LAUGH] isn't dead,

00:09:42.325 --> 00:09:46.947

You leave for a day, and come back, and

00:09:52.017 --> 00:09:56.159
So dial-up is something that

184
00:09:56.159 --> 00:10:00.990

00:10:06.860 --> 00:10:10.580

00:10:10.580 --> 00:10:12.930

00:10:12.930 --> 00:10:13.433

00:10:13.433 --> 00:10:17.067
If there weren't, like we've talked
about in other episodes where we were

191
00:10:17.067 --> 00:10:19.072

00:10:19.072 --> 00:10:20.455
We mentioned the OSI model.

00:10:20.455 --> 00:10:23.104
And I know it's a lot of theory,
ladies and gentlemen, out there.

194
00:10:23.104 --> 00:10:26.756
But keep in mind that one of the reasons
we want standardization is so

195
00:10:26.756 --> 00:10:29.142
that we get things like interoperability.

196
00:10:29.142 --> 00:10:32.805
One of the reasons the OSI model came
out by the International Organization of

197
00:10:32.805 --> 00:10:36.016
Standardization back in 84 was because,
in those earlier days,

198
00:10:36.016 --> 00:10:38.520
everybody had the latest and
greatest technology.

199
00:10:38.520 --> 00:10:41.826
Everybody was using a little bit of this,
a little bit of that.

200
00:10:41.826 --> 00:10:45.339
And the problem was if you were
using a certain networking type,

201
00:10:45.339 --> 00:10:47.300
you'd get vendor locked, right.

202
00:10:47.300 --> 00:10:52.204
So the IEEE sits down, and they say,
hey, we're gonna standardize or

203
00:10:52.204 --> 00:10:55.903
provide some kind of abstract model for
networking.

204
00:10:55.903 --> 00:10:56.860
Well, guess what?

205
00:10:56.860 --> 00:10:58.860
We also have copper standards out there.

206
00:10:58.860 --> 00:11:01.630
The copper standards
basically do the same thing.

207
00:11:01.630 --> 00:11:05.550
They ensure that if you've got
the standard, vendors follow the standard,

208
00:11:05.550 --> 00:11:07.220
then it doesn't matter what.

209
00:11:07.220 --> 00:11:10.990
If I buy a cable, all I really do,
have to do, is just pick which

210
00:11:10.990 --> 00:11:14.410
vendor makes maybe a better cable or
maybe gives me a better price, right.

211
00:11:14.410 --> 00:11:18.950
But we essentially don't get the Wild West
mentality with everybody just doing

212
00:11:18.950 --> 00:11:21.530
everything a little bit different.

213
00:11:21.530 --> 00:11:24.480
There's no interoperability, and
we don't have communications.

214
00:11:24.480 --> 00:11:28.930
So let's go ahead and look at some of the
copper standards that we need to be aware

215
00:11:28.930 --> 00:11:32.130
of, the copper cable
standards more specifically.

216
00:11:32.130 --> 00:11:35.010
And what we have here are some Cat cables.

217
00:11:35.010 --> 00:11:37.610
I'm sure some of you probably
have heard this term.

00:11:37.610 --> 00:11:39.490
If you haven't, well,
that's why you're here.

219
00:11:39.490 --> 00:11:40.605
So what is a category?

220
00:11:40.605 --> 00:11:43.570
And that's what Cat, by the way,
is short for, category.

221
00:11:43.570 --> 00:11:47.550
Well, category defines things like
its transmission speed, right,

222
00:11:47.550 --> 00:11:49.880
the quality of the cable.

00:11:49.880 --> 00:11:53.840
And this is actually defined and
standardized by what's known as TIA/EIA.

224
00:11:53.840 --> 00:11:57.990
See, here in the States, we have
the American National Standards Institute.

225
00:11:57.990 --> 00:11:59.403
And I believe in Europe,

226
00:11:59.403 --> 00:12:03.050
I know they have the International
Telecommunications Union.

227
00:12:03.050 --> 00:12:05.934
They have the European,
I can't remember, it's CEPT, and

228
00:12:05.934 --> 00:12:08.159
I can't remember what
the acronym stands for.

229
00:12:08.159 --> 00:12:10.385
But I know the ITU is also
in the European nation's

230
00:12:10.385 --> 00:12:12.400
International Telecommunications Union.

231
00:12:12.400 --> 00:12:17.082
Well, here in the States, ANSI,
American National Standards Institute,

232
00:12:17.082 --> 00:12:20.899
promoted another organization
called TIA/EIA, all right,

233
00:12:20.899 --> 00:12:26.029
Telecommunication Industry Association
Electronic Industry Alliance, right.

234
00:12:26.029 --> 00:12:31.362
And TIA/EIA is the one that they
promote telecommunication standards.

235
00:12:31.362 --> 00:12:36.340
And they're the ones that basically
standardize the different levels,

236
00:12:36.340 --> 00:12:40.490
if you will, of quality of the cable and
these Cat types, all right.

237
00:12:40.490 --> 00:12:41.970
Now, you might also be asking yourself,
well,

00:12:41.970 --> 00:12:44.680
wait a second,
what happened to Cat 1 and 2?

239
00:12:44.680 --> 00:12:49.240
[LAUGH] Well, unofficially there was

00:12:49.240 --> 00:12:53.800
But that was by Nixter, and
that was Nixter cables if you will, and

241
00:12:53.800 --> 00:12:56.130
those weren't data grade cables.

242
00:12:56.130 --> 00:12:57.780
Those were your earlier phone line cables.

243
00:12:57.780 --> 00:13:02.830
So TIA/EIA doesn't formally endorse or
standardize anything below three.

244
00:13:02.830 --> 00:13:05.730
Three is where it starts, so
that's why we started with three.

245
00:13:05.730 --> 00:13:09.530
I don't want you guys and gals out there
to think, you forgot a couple, Wes, right.

00:13:09.530 --> 00:13:12.560

00:13:12.560 --> 00:13:14.558

00:13:14.558 --> 00:13:16.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But not counting, okay,

249
00:13:16.540 --> 00:13:18.530
so [LAUGH], and I digress.

250
00:13:18.530 --> 00:13:21.760
Let's talk a little bit about Cat 3,

251
00:13:21.760 --> 00:13:25.120
All right, there are some things,
attributes of these cables,

252
00:13:25.120 --> 00:13:26.662
that I want you to be aware for the exam.

253
00:13:26.662 --> 00:13:28.360
All right, get them under your belt.

254
00:13:28.360 --> 00:13:29.440
I know it's memorization.

255
00:13:29.440 --> 00:13:31.730
The great thing is it's really not theory.

256
00:13:31.730 --> 00:13:33.010
You can actually look at the cable.

257
00:13:33.010 --> 00:13:33.660
You can see it.

258
00:13:33.660 --> 00:13:34.310
You can test it.

259
00:13:34.310 --> 00:13:35.450
You can see what's going on.

260
00:13:35.450 --> 00:13:42.560
And you can actually find out a little
bit more about these cables, as well.

261
00:13:42.560 --> 00:13:44.908
So Cat 3 cable, what is it?

262
00:13:44.908 --> 00:13:49.820
Cat 3 cable was the very first twisted
pair implementation that would be utilized

263
00:13:49.820 --> 00:13:52.180
in Ethernet, all right.

264
00:13:52.180 --> 00:13:57.380
Ethernet, up until these points, would be
using your coaxial cables, right, on thin

265
00:13:57.380 --> 00:14:02.350
wire or thin net, as it was called, thick
net or thick wire Ethernet in those days.

266
00:14:02.350 --> 00:14:05.500
But when we moved into
the twisted pair implementations,

267
00:14:05.500 --> 00:14:08.840
which would basically just throw
those other two by the wayside and

268
00:14:08.840 --> 00:14:11.850
leave them in the dark, right,
that's what we use today.

269
00:14:11.850 --> 00:14:14.500
It was the very first standard
that was using twisted pair.

270
00:14:14.500 --> 00:14:17.300
So we call it Ethernet, all right.

271
00:14:17.300 --> 00:14:22.230
Now, this cable has a transmission
speed that I want you to be aware of,

272
00:14:22.230 --> 00:14:23.710
10 megabits.

273
00:14:23.710 --> 00:14:25.650
All right, it's a 10 megabit standard.

274
00:14:25.650 --> 00:14:30.643
So if you have a Cat 3 cable, and
it's verified TIA/EIA compliant,

275
00:14:30.643 --> 00:14:35.160
then that means it has to
support 10 meg speeds.

276
00:14:35.160 --> 00:14:39.260
Now, you also have to worry about
transmission distance, okay.

277
00:14:39.260 --> 00:14:44.590
There's a reason they set standards as
well on the distance of different cables.

278
00:14:44.590 --> 00:14:46.430
I don't care what cable
you're talking about,

279
00:14:46.430 --> 00:14:48.500
this isn't something
that's specific to copper.

280
00:14:48.500 --> 00:14:50.790
It applies to coaxial implementations.

281
00:14:50.790 --> 00:14:54.410
All we gotta do is go back there and
ask some of our directors and

282
00:14:54.410 --> 00:14:57.985
our production staff that are behind
the scenes about how long

283
00:14:57.985 --> 00:15:01.670
a cable could be run for video, and
what kind of a cable do you need?

284
00:15:01.670 --> 00:15:04.430
Every cable has a maximum
transmission distance.

285
00:15:04.430 --> 00:15:09.790
And what the maximum transmission
distance, if you follow it, does, it tries

286
00:15:09.790 --> 00:15:15.990
to ensure that you don't get corruption
of a signal or signal attenuation, right.

287
00:15:15.990 --> 00:15:18.530
Attenuation, it sounds technical.

288
00:15:18.530 --> 00:15:21.360
All it just means is I send a signal.

289
00:15:21.360 --> 00:15:25.410
And the farther that signal travels
down that media, gets farther and

290
00:15:25.410 --> 00:15:29.130
farther away from its source,
it starts to degrade, it starts to weaken.

291
00:15:29.130 --> 00:15:30.650
That's signal attenuation.

292
00:15:30.650 --> 00:15:34.320
There are transmission distances
set by the standard so

293
00:15:34.320 --> 00:15:38.350
that you know if you follow the standard,
back to why we have the standards,

294
00:15:38.350 --> 00:15:43.280
that you're going to get the performance
of that cable out to its maximum distance.

295
00:15:43.280 --> 00:15:46.730
Anything beyond that, you run the risk
of corruption, damage of the signal,

296
00:15:46.730 --> 00:15:48.570
signal attenuation.

297
00:15:48.570 --> 00:15:50.250
So Cat cables.

298
00:15:50.250 --> 00:15:52.060
If we look at the list here,
we've got what?

299
00:15:52.060 --> 00:15:56.950
One, two, three, four, five, six, right,
six Cat cables that are in this list.

300
00:15:56.950 --> 00:15:58.103
Make it easy.

301
00:15:58.103 --> 00:16:03.292
Every one of these cables has a maximum
transmission distance of 100 meters or

302
00:16:03.292 --> 00:16:04.216
328 feet.

303
00:16:04.216 --> 00:16:06.691
I don't know which one they're
gonna show you on the exam.

304
00:16:06.691 --> 00:16:10.829
Don't think up in my brain here that I
can convert that fast between metric and

305
00:16:10.829 --> 00:16:12.050
the imperial system.

306
00:16:12.050 --> 00:16:15.000
It's just there's a commonality
that you kind of find.

307
00:16:15.000 --> 00:16:17.860
You find one meter, ten meter,
a hundred meter, right?

308
00:16:17.860 --> 00:16:20.630
I don't know why, but in networking
you find a lot of that, right?

309
00:16:20.630 --> 00:16:22.620
So one meter's gonna be 3.28 feet.

310
00:16:22.620 --> 00:16:24.390
We're moving the decimal point.

311
00:16:24.390 --> 00:16:29.240
Ten meters, 32.8 feet and
finally 100 meters is 328 feet.

312
00:16:29.240 --> 00:16:30.470
I'm telling you both.

313
00:16:30.470 --> 00:16:32.390
So if they ask you how
many feed on the exam,

314
00:16:32.390 --> 00:16:34.610
whatever's closest to 128's gonna win out.

315
00:16:34.610 --> 00:16:36.630
Another little exam tip, there.

316
00:16:36.630 --> 00:16:39.630
Every one of these is 100 meters
when it comes to the Cat cables.

317
00:16:39.630 --> 00:16:41.730
Now let's move down in to Cat 5.

318
00:16:41.730 --> 00:16:45.230
So the next one on the list,
Cat 5 here, Cat 5 comes down and

319
00:16:45.230 --> 00:16:48.230
this is what's known as fast ethernet.

320
00:16:48.230 --> 00:16:51.460
Now maybe not fast by today's standards,
but fast ethernet, if you will,

321
00:16:51.460 --> 00:16:54.630
is going to be 100 megabit
transmission speed.

322
00:16:54.630 --> 00:16:57.470
When we talk about 100
megabit transmission speeds,

323
00:16:57.470 --> 00:17:00.840
you have to know that for
the exam, know the names too.

324
00:17:00.840 --> 00:17:05.180
Cat 3 is ethernet, Cat 5 fast ethernet.

325
00:17:05.180 --> 00:17:09.150
Now moving down on the list,
you are going to see now we have Cat 5e.

326
00:17:09.150 --> 00:17:13.110
What does the E mean?

327
00:17:13.110 --> 00:17:15.670
The E actually stands for enhanced.

328
00:17:15.670 --> 00:17:19.715
What happens here is now

episodes.title: Cabling Solutions-Copper Part 3

The blue they reversed themselves right.

We get the in positions 7,

Because if you'll notice,

But what I can do is I

Is that when you're looking

Well, in position six,

Now in order for

Positions three and six are the green

it just happens to be Ethernet, right.

450
00:25:34.540 --> 00:25:39.640
In broadband, you use multiple channels,
right, multiple frequencies, right.

451
00:25:39.640 --> 00:25:43.050
We use things like frequency divisional
multiplexing in order to take more than

452
00:25:43.050 --> 00:25:46.280
one signal and cross the wire, right.

453
00:25:46.280 --> 00:25:48.314
In Ethernet, it's baseband signaling,

454
00:25:48.314 --> 00:25:51.317
there's a single signal going
across that medium at any time.

455
00:25:51.317 --> 00:25:54.458
And we use discrete time slots,
that's the TDMA,

456
00:25:54.458 --> 00:25:57.537
the time divisional multiplexing for
Ethernet.

457
00:25:57.537 --> 00:26:00.918
Now that's the base,
what's that alphabet character,

458
00:26:00.918 --> 00:26:04.250
that alphabetic character
at the end right?

459
00:26:04.250 --> 00:26:09.970
Or alphabetical if you will, [LAUGH] T,
well, it tells you what the media type is.

460
00:26:09.970 --> 00:26:12.190
And in this case,
T stands for twisted pair.

461
00:26:12.190 --> 00:26:16.060
So we've got transmission speed,
signaling type, media code.

462
00:26:16.060 --> 00:26:20.320
Any time you see T, it's twisted
pair implementations, all right.

463
00:26:20.320 --> 00:26:24.535
Now, I'm gonna go ahead, and
even though I've got LX and

464
00:26:24.535 --> 00:26:27.490
BaseSX here,
we're gonna leave those for our fiber.

465
00:26:27.490 --> 00:26:31.430
We'll come back to those, you get
a taste of them, go study, go Google it.

466
00:26:31.430 --> 00:26:33.053
Come back with our fiber-
>> It's a tease if you will.

467
00:26:33.053 --> 00:26:36.030
>> That's right, but I only wanna
look at the T standards right now.

468
00:26:36.030 --> 00:26:36.948
>> Right.

469
00:26:36.948 --> 00:26:42.103
>> So 100 megabits in the 100BaseT,
same thing on the last part of it,

470
00:26:42.103 --> 00:26:46.464
it's baseband signaling,
twisted pair implementations.

471
00:26:46.464 --> 00:26:51.917
1000BaseT, guess what,
it's gigabit Ethernet, 1000 megabits,

472
00:26:51.917 --> 00:26:56.475
right, baseband signalling,
twisted pair implementations.

473
00:26:56.475 --> 00:27:01.240
And if I remember right the TX that's
gonna be a pair of twisted pairs

474
00:27:01.240 --> 00:27:03.592
more than one cable, all right.

475
00:27:03.592 --> 00:27:07.981
The last one that I'll talk about,
like I said I'll save the LX and SX,

476
00:27:07.981 --> 00:27:09.737
those are fiber standards,

477
00:27:09.737 --> 00:27:15.310
we'll come back to those in our fiber
cabling solutions show, is 10GBaseT.

478
00:27:15.310 --> 00:27:21.875
We look at 10GBaseT, I'm also so
used to always saying 10BaseT.

479
00:27:21.875 --> 00:27:25.925
Now we're talking about
as Ethernet evolves,

480
00:27:25.925 --> 00:27:28.825
we go to 10 gigabit Ethernet networks.

481
00:27:28.825 --> 00:27:31.401
Right, over twisted pair,
that's what it means.

482
00:27:31.401 --> 00:27:38.045
10G is a 10 gigabit speed baseband
signaling with Ethernet as its media type.

483
00:27:38.045 --> 00:27:41.280
All right, so it is important
that you know these standards.

484
00:27:41.280 --> 00:27:46.360
Now, I've also talked about Ethernet as
being 802.3 standard in other episodes and

485
00:27:46.360 --> 00:27:48.550
I think I might have mentioned
it a little bit in here.

486
00:27:48.550 --> 00:27:51.920
Ethernet also has an IEEE 802 standard,
and

487
00:27:51.920 --> 00:27:56.570
I want you to be aware of those
associated standards, right,

488
00:27:56.570 --> 00:28:00.390
the IEEE standard, and how these
base standards, where do they apply.

489
00:28:00.390 --> 00:28:05.085
So if you will remember this for
the exam, all right, your 100BaseT,

490
00:28:05.085 --> 00:28:10.710
I'm gonna throw a couple extra at you,
is actually an 802.3j Ethernet standard.

491
00:28:10.710 --> 00:28:15.628
1000BaseT is 802.3ab,
and then the last one,

492
00:28:15.628 --> 00:28:20.545
10GBaseT is a newer one,
relatively newer one I know by

493
00:28:20.545 --> 00:28:25.720
now it's been around for
a bit, is 802.3an.

494
00:28:25.720 --> 00:28:29.960
Know these Ethernet deployments so that if
they ask you these questions on the exam,

495
00:28:29.960 --> 00:28:32.140
you will be able to get them right.

496
00:28:32.140 --> 00:28:35.130
>> Wes, is there standards for
termination points?

497
00:28:35.130 --> 00:28:38.200
>> There are and termination points
when we talk about these standards,

498
00:28:38.200 --> 00:28:43.220
I want you to think about,
I have a whole bunch of copper conductors

499
00:28:43.220 --> 00:28:48.260
that I need to terminate in a small space,
all right.

500
00:28:48.260 --> 00:28:53.650
And that is where we get what are known
as the different block types.

501
00:28:53.650 --> 00:28:56.702
When we look at the different block types,
I've got a few up here,

502
00:28:56.702 --> 00:28:59.441
the first one they call out is
what's known as a 66 block.

503
00:28:59.441 --> 00:29:03.515
You might've seen these if you've
ever been in a commercial building,

504
00:29:03.515 --> 00:29:08.060
you probably seen that there was a piece
of plywood somewhere in a back room.

505
00:29:08.060 --> 00:29:11.613
And then you would see all of these
telephone cables coming in, snaking, and

506
00:29:11.613 --> 00:29:13.210
being punched down to it, right.

507
00:29:13.210 --> 00:29:15.578
All right, they call them punch down tool,

508
00:29:15.578 --> 00:29:19.820
a little tool that what you do is it
strips, embeds, and trims off the excess.

509
00:29:19.820 --> 00:29:23.490
And these are called punch down blocks
essentially, and this is a 66 block.

510
00:29:23.490 --> 00:29:26.770
There are two different kinds that
they ask you about on the exam,

511
00:29:26.770 --> 00:29:28.850
a 66 block and a 110 block.

512
00:29:28.850 --> 00:29:32.530
Please do not think that that has anything
to do with how many devices can be

513
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:34.700
connected to it, it does not.

514
00:29:34.700 --> 00:29:38.550
It has to do with the electrical
characteristics of the block

515
00:29:38.550 --> 00:29:39.505
itself, right.

516
00:29:39.505 --> 00:29:42.950
So even though it's called a 66 block,
typically used for phone cables,

517
00:29:42.950 --> 00:29:47.690
you can have 12 four-pair cables, or

518
00:29:47.690 --> 00:29:51.430
50 pairs that are punched down
to this single block, right.

519
00:29:51.430 --> 00:29:56.080
So again, don't think that it's the amount
of devices that are connected or

520
00:29:56.080 --> 00:30:00.520
the amount of connection,
it defines the electrical characteristics.

521
00:30:00.520 --> 00:30:03.210
And it is typically mounted vertically,

522
00:30:03.210 --> 00:30:05.680
notice the vertical
mounting position here.

523
00:30:05.680 --> 00:30:11.190
Now the other one that they call out
is what is known as the 110 block.

524
00:30:11.190 --> 00:30:15.640
Now you can see that there's a lot of
difference here in this 110 block.

525
00:30:15.640 --> 00:30:17.140
It's mounted horizontally and

526
00:30:17.140 --> 00:30:19.820
look how many connections
are being terminated here.

527
00:30:19.820 --> 00:30:20.320
>> Wow.

528
00:30:20.320 --> 00:30:24.488
>> Again, mounted horizontally this one,
if you will,

529
00:30:24.488 --> 00:30:29.576
the 110, has greater electrical
capabilities, if you will.

530
00:30:29.576 --> 00:30:32.542
And this is usually to terminate
structured cabling, and

531
00:30:32.542 --> 00:30:34.606
you can see that here in the background.

532
00:30:34.606 --> 00:30:39.368
All of these cables that
are coming in to it,

533
00:30:39.368 --> 00:30:43.746
now what we're talking about a 100,

534
00:30:43.746 --> 00:30:48.895
200, 300 pairs right, and it could be,

535
00:30:48.895 --> 00:30:53.142
or I'm sorry, it is 100, 200 or

536
00:30:53.142 --> 00:30:57.760
300 with rows of 50 pairs a piece.

537
00:30:57.760 --> 00:31:00.250
See how many they are, I had to make
sure I get my numbers right here,

538
00:31:00.250 --> 00:31:02.940
and I don't know if they're gonna ask you
about the numbers on the exam, right.

539
00:31:02.940 --> 00:31:06.400
I just want you to know that it's about
the electrical capabilities, right.

540
00:31:06.400 --> 00:31:09.950
I can have all of those pairs 100,
200 and 300,

541
00:31:09.950 --> 00:31:14.870
right, total on a single 110
block at 50 pairs per row,

542
00:31:14.870 --> 00:31:20.210
versus a max of about 50 pairs in
a single, one of those 66 blocks.

543
00:31:20.210 --> 00:31:22.795
So, definitely know about them.

544
00:31:22.795 --> 00:31:27.720
But the last things that I wanna talk
about is what is known as a patch panel.

545
00:31:27.720 --> 00:31:31.310
Now when we look at a patch panel,
we've talked a lot about our cabling and

546
00:31:31.310 --> 00:31:36.720
our termination of twisted pair
implementations, all right.

547
00:31:36.720 --> 00:31:41.320
Now when all of your twisted pair
implementations essentially go

548
00:31:41.320 --> 00:31:44.950
down across all of the different
connections you have in a building.

549
00:31:44.950 --> 00:31:47.190
They come down the vertical runs and

550
00:31:47.190 --> 00:31:50.985
they come into like a telecommunications
closet like a server closet.

551
00:31:50.985 --> 00:31:51.980
Well, where do they terminate at?

552
00:31:51.980 --> 00:31:54.570
And that's where the patch panel comes up,
and

553
00:31:54.570 --> 00:31:59.490
I can actually show you a patch panel
here and let's see if we can find one.

554
00:31:59.490 --> 00:32:01.596
There we go,
the first one in the list there.

555
00:32:01.596 --> 00:32:07.440
Looks like it's gonna correct me here, and
yeah there we go Wikipedia's got one here.

556
00:32:07.440 --> 00:32:10.830
Make sure that we find a good one,
there we go perfect.

557
00:32:10.830 --> 00:32:15.630
All right so this is a patch panel and
what is happening here essentially is

558
00:32:15.630 --> 00:32:20.320
all of your structured,
twisted pair implementations.

559
00:32:20.320 --> 00:32:23.407
You could have 500 computers,
a 1,000 computers in a building,

560
00:32:23.407 --> 00:32:25.250
where do all those cables run?

561
00:32:25.250 --> 00:32:28.390
Well they run vertically and
then horizontally through the building.

562
00:32:28.390 --> 00:32:32.040
They go down vertical shafts,
usually into a telecommunications closet.

563
00:32:32.040 --> 00:32:36.764
Sometimes on the first floor,
if you're multi high rise building,

564
00:32:36.764 --> 00:32:38.920
it might be upper floor.

565
00:32:38.920 --> 00:32:42.460
But for the most part, what they do and
what they will do is basically terminate

566
00:32:42.460 --> 00:32:45.150
into a single point, and
that's what the patch panel is.

567
00:32:45.150 --> 00:32:46.390
On the back of the patch panel,

568
00:32:46.390 --> 00:32:50.600
this is where you're going to strip
off all the outer jackets, right.

569
00:32:50.600 --> 00:32:54.870
You're gonna spread out all the individual
conductors and just like, one of those 66

570
00:32:54.870 --> 00:32:59.110
blocks you're gonna punch each individual
cable to the back of the patch panel.

571
00:32:59.110 --> 00:33:01.380
And then what you can
do as an administrator,

572
00:33:01.380 --> 00:33:05.120
rather than having to strip anymore
cables, you use patch cable, all right.

573
00:33:05.120 --> 00:33:08.038
And you connect a pair of drops by
just moving the patch panel cables,

574
00:33:08.038 --> 00:33:09.914
kinda like the old switchboard operators.

575
00:33:09.914 --> 00:33:10.807
>> Right, that's what I was thinking.

576
00:33:10.807 --> 00:33:14.136
>> They didn't rewire
the communications closet, right.

577
00:33:14.136 --> 00:33:17.131
What they would do is they would
just move the plugs, right,

578
00:33:17.131 --> 00:33:18.490
from one plug to the next.

579
00:33:18.490 --> 00:33:22.610
Well, that's essentially what a patch
panel is, a patch panel is like the old

580
00:33:22.610 --> 00:33:27.053
operator switchboard for your twisted
pair, or Ethernet implementations today.

581
00:33:27.053 --> 00:33:30.813
So know some of these copper standards
that we've been talking about,

582
00:33:30.813 --> 00:33:34.071
so that if they ask you,
they put you in scenarios on the exam,

583
00:33:34.071 --> 00:33:37.157
pay attention to the keywords so
that you can get it right.

584
00:33:37.157 --> 00:33:39.029
So that next time you
set that Network + exam,

585
00:33:39.029 --> 00:33:41.205
you're going to get those answers right.

586
00:33:41.205 --> 00:33:46.165
>> And all you have to do is pay attention
to Wes, because he's got the answers in

587
00:33:46.165 --> 00:33:49.345
cabling solutions-copper parts one,
two, and three.

588
00:33:49.345 --> 00:33:52.195
Review them, you'll be glad you did,
and take a look at all the other

589
00:33:52.195 --> 00:33:56.735
hundreds of videos available in our course
library that will all help you go further.

590
00:33:56.735 --> 00:34:00.085
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be very glad you did.

591
00:34:00.085 --> 00:34:01.455
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

592
00:34:01.455 --> 00:34:02.195
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

593
00:34:02.195 --> 00:34:03.867
>> And we will see you soon.

594
00:34:03.867 --> 00:34:09.876
[MUSIC]

595
00:34:09.876 --> 00:34:15.080
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into different cabling solutions available in today's modern networks. They will talk about fiber optics and the various connectors associated with these cable types.
episodes.title: Cabling Solutions-Fiber
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:02.882
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.882 --> 00:00:08.500
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.500 --> 00:00:12.088
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:14.236
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.236 --> 00:00:16.240
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.240 --> 00:00:20.070
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Comp TIA Net +,

7
00:00:20.070 --> 00:00:22.920
this episode is Cabling Solutions-Fiber.

8
00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:24.600
And we've asked our IT expert and

9
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:27.160
all around great guy Wes Bryan
back to help us out.

10
00:00:27.160 --> 00:00:29.030
Wes, good to see you again sir thanks for
coming.

11
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:32.650
>> Absolutely Zach thanks for having me
back, yep, it's always fun to be here.

12
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:35.730
That's right we are talking,
just like Zach said, about fiber.

13
00:00:35.730 --> 00:00:39.379
Keep in mind that we've really
talked about a couple of different,

14
00:00:39.379 --> 00:00:41.650
I would say, media types, right.

15
00:00:41.650 --> 00:00:44.460
In general when we boil it down
we have copper and we have fiber.

16
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:47.560
Now if you're not aware of all
the copper standards, go back and

17
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:48.700
watch those episodes.

18
00:00:48.700 --> 00:00:51.720
And if you happen to be studying
right now for your Net + exam, and

19
00:00:51.720 --> 00:00:54.940
you're just looking for fiber,
well you've come to the right place.

20
00:00:54.940 --> 00:00:58.900
Because fiber is what we're gonna be
talking about in this episode here.

21
00:00:58.900 --> 00:01:00.870
>> And I just have a question
right off the bat, Wes.

22
00:01:00.870 --> 00:01:05.410
When it comes to the copper and the fiber,
I know there's different applications.

23
00:01:05.410 --> 00:01:08.410
Is there any one better than
the other what do you think?

24
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:12.238
>> It really is always gonna be one
of those ones, I'll say it depends,

25
00:01:12.238 --> 00:01:13.758
what a great answer right.

26
00:01:13.758 --> 00:01:15.819
[LAUGH] It doesn't really
give you an answer,

27
00:01:15.819 --> 00:01:18.532
it's almost like answering
an answer with a question, but

28
00:01:18.532 --> 00:01:21.424
let's talk about what I mean when
I say it depends, all right.

29
00:01:21.424 --> 00:01:22.882
So if you have money,

30
00:01:22.882 --> 00:01:27.930
if you are one these companies that
can throw money at any problem.

31
00:01:27.930 --> 00:01:31.635
And money is not an option,
you really should be running fiber.

32
00:01:31.635 --> 00:01:35.550
Hands down, you should be running fiber
again, because if you don't have to worry

33
00:01:35.550 --> 00:01:40.470
about the advanced training that
it takes on your technicians to

34
00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:45.280
make fiber optic cables, to terminate
them and stuff, then you are doing good.

35
00:01:45.280 --> 00:01:49.020
However, copper is a little bit more
prevalent because it's less expensive

36
00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:49.770
than fiber.

37
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:53.420
Now, they both have their goods and
they both have their bads, right.

38
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:58.230
Again copper, one of the good things would
be that it's less expensive than fiber is.

39
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:01.870
However, it does have some
drawbacks because the expense

40
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:05.260
can start to really creep up towards
fiber if you're worried about things like

41
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:07.308
electromagnetic interference,
right, that's a big thing.

42
00:02:07.308 --> 00:02:10.451
And Zach we've talked about that
pretty heavily in that other episode

43
00:02:10.451 --> 00:02:13.070
on the cabling solutions when
it comes to copper, right.

44
00:02:13.070 --> 00:02:17.520
Because I have electromagnetic energy that
is sent down copper conductors, right,

45
00:02:17.520 --> 00:02:20.609
and if we're near things like
high voltage power sources,

46
00:02:20.609 --> 00:02:24.220
right, HVPs and throw a whole bunch
of acronyms here right up front.

47
00:02:24.220 --> 00:02:28.840
HVAC systems, heating, ventilation,
and AC, if we're worried about things

48
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:32.130
like plenums we talked about,
that could run a problem, right.

49
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:36.514
So we definitely have things to consider,
but the main thing really boils down to

50
00:02:36.514 --> 00:02:40.322
I would say, in my opinion, and
you might disagree with me out there.

51
00:02:40.322 --> 00:02:46.424
And some of you probably laid cabling and
have seen this before, but copper again,

52
00:02:46.424 --> 00:02:51.410
its benefit, it can be a lot less
expensive than fiber optic media.

53
00:02:51.410 --> 00:02:54.340
However, it's typically a shorter
range unless you're talking

54
00:02:54.340 --> 00:02:58.680
about the traditional PST inlines, those
public switch telephone network lines.

55
00:02:58.680 --> 00:03:02.756
But it's susceptible to
electromagnetic interference, right.

56
00:03:02.756 --> 00:03:07.623
On the other hand fiber, fiber
solutions now they're more expensive,

57
00:03:07.623 --> 00:03:11.470
right out the gate we gotta
throw that out there, right.

58
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:15.030
But if again, you're one of these
companies that can throw money at any

59
00:03:15.030 --> 00:03:18.429
problem, and that's not a problem
then definitely go with fiber.

60
00:03:18.429 --> 00:03:22.120
Because you have an immunity
to electromagnetic interfere.

61
00:03:22.120 --> 00:03:24.136
Now let's be careful when I say that,

62
00:03:24.136 --> 00:03:27.097
you're immune to electromagnetic
interference, but

63
00:03:27.097 --> 00:03:31.138
it doesn't mean that you can just treat
the cables any way you want, right.

64
00:03:31.138 --> 00:03:35.080
You do have things that you have to worry
about when it comes to fiber optic cables.

65
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:39.779
Because you are sending a highly
concentrated light source down

66
00:03:39.779 --> 00:03:42.570
a highly concentrated core, right.

67
00:03:42.570 --> 00:03:46.452
These cores are microns of an inch, and
millionths of a meter, all right, or

68
00:03:46.452 --> 00:03:50.005
microns, millionths of a meter,
mixed two systems there together.

69
00:03:50.005 --> 00:03:54.337
And a bend in the cable could disrupt
the signal, right, just a bend,

70
00:03:54.337 --> 00:03:56.550
all right, so that's a drawback.

71
00:03:56.550 --> 00:03:57.930
However, speed,

72
00:03:57.930 --> 00:04:01.440
it's pretty much the fastest
transmission medium we have, right.

73
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:05.752
In fact, we've got technologies that
really can't saturate the full potential

00:16:09.444 --> 00:16:10.418
And what do I mean by that?

301
00:16:10.418 --> 00:16:16.540
All right, singlemode, my guess,
it's a single light source, all right?

302
00:16:16.540 --> 00:16:20.595
And the light source is typically
a high intensity laser.

303
00:16:20.595 --> 00:16:25.483
And that laser is fired like

00:16:25.483 --> 00:16:30.186

ultra concentrated core.

305
00:16:30.186 --> 00:16:33.574
Which is why single mode is the largest,

306
00:16:33.574 --> 00:16:37.669
longest transmission
distance bounded media.

307
00:16:37.669 --> 00:16:41.300
Or the longest bounded media we

308

And when I say concentrated, I want

309
00:16:45.317 --> 00:16:46.260

310

nine millionths of a meter, all right?

00:16:51.625 --> 00:16:55.423
Very hard to tell these from

Now, when it comes to your singlemode

00:17:13.795 --> 00:17:19.097

200 kilometers, depending on, again,

Because I have singlemode

The communication device that you're using

00:17:51.629 --> 00:17:53.860
or whether it's going to be singlemode.

Now we could take a look

00:17:56.709 --> 00:17:59.590
We've got a couple of

And Zach, without looking at

00:18:06.821 --> 00:18:08.946
Other than the fact that I just told you.

you need to get in the field

We've got some technicians that

00:18:27.090 --> 00:18:30.363
again, all joking aside,
that's absolutely correct, right?

00:18:30.363 --> 00:18:32.807
We don't know which ones are which,

00:18:32.807 --> 00:18:35.076
And we'll get back to that

This fiber optic cables are inside

Or two fibers if we're about talking

I'm not gonna leave you guys and

00:18:52.422 --> 00:18:55.848

00:18:55.848 --> 00:18:58.400
But if you look here, we've got a cable.

00:18:58.400 --> 00:19:02.477
And I don't know if this cable's got,

00:19:02.477 --> 00:19:04.961

00:19:04.961 --> 00:19:06.423
This is our fiber optic cable, and

00:19:10.100 --> 00:19:14.915
All right, and we'll just give that

00:19:14.915 --> 00:19:18.348

And again,
what we have here is a multimode cable.

00:19:26.878 --> 00:19:28.896

00:19:28.896 --> 00:19:30.289

00:19:30.289 --> 00:19:34.511

And what that means is that we can

00:19:45.253 --> 00:19:48.591
It means that the jacket that's on
the outside of this, if I was to, and

00:19:48.591 --> 00:19:52.225

Some people would be like, wow,

00:19:54.465 --> 00:19:56.066
I've actually kind of
spliced this already.

00:19:56.066 --> 00:19:57.018

00:19:57.018 --> 00:19:58.290
>> That's right, [LAUGH].

373
00:19:58.290 --> 00:20:01.590
>> [LAUGH]
>> And this jacket here is made of plenum

00:20:01.590 --> 00:20:06.591
grade cabling, which means,
again, it's really stiff cable.

00:20:06.591 --> 00:20:10.053
It's very hard to work with, and I don't
want to go into too much bending these

00:20:10.053 --> 00:20:12.159
cables, and,
we'll tell you why in a second.

377
00:20:12.159 --> 00:20:15.280
But that just means that
in a plenum grade cabling,

378
00:20:15.280 --> 00:20:19.723
I don't have to worry about this when
it's burnt giving off a toxic gas.

379
00:20:19.723 --> 00:20:23.743
Very, very low toxins,
and very low smoke, and

00:20:23.743 --> 00:20:27.285
it doesn't allow fire to pass through it.

381
00:20:27.285 --> 00:20:31.480
But if I strip off the outside,
the outside protecting jacket, right?

00:20:31.480 --> 00:20:35.956
We'll take that off, so that's what's

00:20:35.956 --> 00:20:43.175
But if we look here, and I take, see these

00:20:43.175 --> 00:20:44.880
>> Mm-hm.
>> And you can see the little fibers that

00:20:44.880 --> 00:20:45.570

And a lot of times, when we're running

And, again, because your technicians are

00:20:57.840 --> 00:21:02.621
All right, so what we have here, Zach,

00:21:02.621 --> 00:21:03.521

>> Even though it

00:21:05.835 --> 00:21:09.858
This is actually a bundle of fibers, so

00:21:09.858 --> 00:21:14.002
And I'm not even going to attempt to

00:21:14.002 --> 00:21:15.604

Because ultimately the glass is going

00:21:19.982 --> 00:21:21.540

I mean, that little thing,

00:21:24.367 --> 00:21:27.209

00:21:27.209 --> 00:21:31.610
So, this is what you end up seeing inside,

00:21:31.610 --> 00:21:36.250
And you have the protective shielding,

00:21:36.250 --> 00:21:38.865
that's gonna be 120, 125 microns.

00:21:38.865 --> 00:21:42.430
Inside these cores, and
you're just gonna have to take my word for

Because I don't have something

00:21:48.028 --> 00:21:51.220
So these are going to be 50 microns thick.

00:21:51.220 --> 00:21:56.330
Now we can tell that, again, by the side

just like we've showed you guys

00:22:00.127 --> 00:22:03.877
It lets you know what type of cable it is.

And again, if you can remember

00:22:07.218 --> 00:22:09.660
I don't even have to

00:22:09.660 --> 00:22:13.159
I can tell that this that this

00:22:13.159 --> 00:22:17.632
Now, if I look at this cable, and

00:22:17.632 --> 00:22:20.810

Turn it the right way,

00:22:23.117 --> 00:22:24.908
I see that it's an optical fiber cable.

00:22:24.908 --> 00:22:28.851
Corning Glass is the one that makes this,

00:22:28.851 --> 00:22:29.954

That says 9, 9 forward slash 125, right?

00:22:35.530 --> 00:22:38.576
So I know that at nine microns this is,

00:22:42.303 --> 00:22:46.315
And it doesn't really tell us, if we

00:22:46.315 --> 00:22:47.570

00:22:47.570 --> 00:22:48.350

And I'll just kind see if I can't

In here, it will tell you

All right, so,

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into different cabling solutions available in today's modern networks. They will talk about fiber optics and the various connectors associated with these cable types.
