40
00:02:15.285 --> 00:02:17.455
please don't think it's just a slice and
dice.

41
00:02:17.455 --> 00:02:20.595
>> You need what's known
as a field fusion splicer.

42
00:02:20.595 --> 00:02:23.132
And a field fusion splicer,
they do have some rough and

43
00:02:23.132 --> 00:02:26.673
dirty ones that'll at least give you
the ability to get the cable repaired.

44
00:02:26.673 --> 00:02:28.073
But you've gotta do polishing,

45
00:02:28.073 --> 00:02:30.425
you gotta make sure that
the ends are polished, right.

46
00:02:30.425 --> 00:02:33.497
Because any bend in the light
can cause signal loss and

47
00:02:33.497 --> 00:02:37.603
you're always getting signal
loss in fiber optic cables.

48
00:02:37.603 --> 00:02:40.863
So, there's not a lot of tolerances there,
so do keep that in mind.

49
00:02:40.863 --> 00:02:44.263
And we'll talk a little bit more about
some of the things that you could see that

50
00:02:44.263 --> 00:02:47.083
might be problematic when it
comes to fiber optic solutions,

51
00:02:47.083 --> 00:02:48.623
when we get into some of
the troubleshooting shows.

52
00:02:48.623 --> 00:02:49.738
But I want you to know,

53
00:02:49.738 --> 00:02:53.500
[LAUGH] it typically takes
a highly trained technician.

54
00:02:53.500 --> 00:02:56.140
A field technician doesn't go
out there and gonna fix and

55
00:02:56.140 --> 00:02:57.900
terminate the fiber-optic cables.

56
00:02:57.900 --> 00:03:01.920
They usually have fusion splicers and
fusion splicers can get very,

57
00:03:01.920 --> 00:03:02.648
very expensive.

58
00:03:02.648 --> 00:03:06.110
They could be a few hundred dollars up to
a few hundreds of thousands of dollars

59
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:11.550
depending, right, so definitely not
something to take lightly for sure.

60
00:03:11.550 --> 00:03:14.330
So, now back to your question,
the connector types.

61
00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:16.940
We've got three that we really
have to worry about and

62
00:03:16.940 --> 00:03:20.145
then slight variations of those
three that we need to talk about.

63
00:03:20.145 --> 00:03:23.651
And yes, that's right,
back with acronyms [LAUGH]

64
00:03:23.651 --> 00:03:28.560
as always here in anything Net + or
well really CompTIA exams, right.

65
00:03:28.560 --> 00:03:31.420
The first ones that they call out are ST,

66
00:03:31.420 --> 00:03:35.860
well actually the ones I called out,
ST, [LAUGH] SC, and LC.

67
00:03:35.860 --> 00:03:39.640
All right now [LAUGH] what do
we even mean by that right?

68
00:03:39.640 --> 00:03:40.958
Make sense of that all right,

69
00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.606
well let's talk about the very
first one that I mentioned.

70
00:03:43.606 --> 00:03:46.610
And that is something
known as straight tip,

71
00:03:46.610 --> 00:03:51.900
all right, ST standard tipped,
straight tip as you might hear it called.

72
00:03:51.900 --> 00:03:55.310
This is a slightly older fiber
optic cable, still in use today.

73
00:03:55.310 --> 00:03:58.622
Now it's not as old as things like
the Biconic, which is pretty much largely

74
00:03:58.622 --> 00:04:01.170
obsolete it was on the very
first fiber optic connectors.

75
00:04:01.170 --> 00:04:06.190
And kinda got a picture of it, we've seen
something that almost looks like this.

76
00:04:06.190 --> 00:04:10.120
Notice the fiber connector at the end
there, and it's interesting Zach,

77
00:04:10.120 --> 00:04:12.570
you were with me in
the copper shows right?

78
00:04:12.570 --> 00:04:15.495
If you remember we talked about BNC, so

79
00:04:15.495 --> 00:04:19.405
this straight tip connector
has a BNC twist to lock.

80
00:04:19.405 --> 00:04:22.558
So it really looks like that Bayonet
right Neill-Concelman connector that

81
00:04:22.558 --> 00:04:23.900
we're talking about.

82
00:04:23.900 --> 00:04:28.580
And that's hence, the reason they
call it a straight tip connector.

83
00:04:28.580 --> 00:04:31.130
But it's not the only one that you
need to be aware of for the exam,

84
00:04:31.130 --> 00:04:32.290
we've got a couple more.

85
00:04:32.290 --> 00:04:35.900
And I wanna talk about LC and
I wanna talk about SC.

86
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:40.160
But let's go ahead and
let's dive in to the SC connector first.

87
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:44.340
This is what's known as standard
connector or subscriber connector.

88
00:04:44.340 --> 00:04:46.574
And again,
depends on where you're looking at,

89
00:04:46.574 --> 00:04:48.977
you could call it subscriber connector,
all right.

90
00:04:48.977 --> 00:04:52.675
And the subscriber connector,
this one again, is still used today, but

91
00:04:52.675 --> 00:04:56.029
again it's kinda been replaced by
the next one we'll talk about.

92
00:04:56.029 --> 00:05:01.060
And you can see that what we have is we
have two interlocking connectors here.

93
00:05:01.060 --> 00:05:04.840
They could be a single connector,
they could be a pair.

94
00:05:04.840 --> 00:05:08.231
A lot of times what you'll find
is these are paired together, and

95
00:05:08.231 --> 00:05:12.870
the reason they're paired together is for
what's known as a duplexing configuration.

96
00:05:12.870 --> 00:05:16.977
In fact, I tell you what, let's talk
about the next one here coming up and

97
00:05:16.977 --> 00:05:18.243
then we'll show you.

98
00:05:18.243 --> 00:05:21.507
Rather than just show you the pictures,
we've actually got some of these cables

99
00:05:21.507 --> 00:05:24.620
that really utilizes both, and
we'll go to them here in a second.

100
00:05:24.620 --> 00:05:25.880
Let's talk about the next one, and

101
00:05:25.880 --> 00:05:29.180
the next one is what is known
as a Lucient connector.

102
00:05:29.180 --> 00:05:31.260
And here's a picture of
the Lucent connector,

103
00:05:31.260 --> 00:05:35.670
you might hear it called local contact,
I've also heard it called.

104
00:05:35.670 --> 00:05:40.890
A characteristic of this connector
that I want you to remember for

105
00:05:40.890 --> 00:05:44.460
the exam to help you memorize it,
might help you, little connector.

106
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:49.005
That's how I remembered it for
the exam because when you look at it,

107
00:05:49.005 --> 00:05:51.797
it has most of the same characteristics,

108
00:05:51.797 --> 00:05:57.411
really all of the same characteristics
of it's older and larger brother, right.

109
00:05:57.411 --> 00:06:00.413
If you'll notice that the subscriber

110
00:06:00.413 --> 00:06:04.360
connector has a lot of
the same look to it, right.

111
00:06:04.360 --> 00:06:06.530
This one happens to have
the locking connector there for

112
00:06:06.530 --> 00:06:08.670
two of them to kinda pair them up.

113
00:06:08.670 --> 00:06:12.640
All right, and then you can see kinda
like the core is kind of exposed there.

114
00:06:12.640 --> 00:06:15.930
Sometimes you might find a little plastic
cap on the end of them as well, and

115
00:06:15.930 --> 00:06:17.250
we'll see that coming up.

116
00:06:17.250 --> 00:06:20.380
But the local contact, or

117
00:06:20.380 --> 00:06:24.540
Lucent connector as it's also called,
notice it's pretty much the same thing.

118
00:06:24.540 --> 00:06:28.000
It's really close to the same thing,
so what's the difference,

119
00:06:28.000 --> 00:06:32.680
why do we have one that is a larger
connector versus a smaller connector?

120
00:06:32.680 --> 00:06:39.530
And that really comes down to age
of the technology, all right.

121
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:43.932
Fiber optic connectors at one point, and
still today, are very, very expensive,

122
00:06:43.932 --> 00:06:45.483
all right, very expensive.

123
00:06:45.483 --> 00:06:49.741
And the fact that in some of the earlier
things like switches, right,

124
00:06:49.741 --> 00:06:52.860
you wouldn't have as many
ports on a switch right.

125
00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:57.240
Be very expensive just to put a fiber
optic blade in a switch let alone adding

126
00:06:57.240 --> 00:06:58.950
more and more ports, right.

127
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:03.160
So, the subscriber connector is
the older connector, right, and

128
00:07:03.160 --> 00:07:06.690
it didn't allow for a great port density.

129
00:07:06.690 --> 00:07:08.070
And what I mean by that port density,

130
00:07:08.070 --> 00:07:12.760
is how many ports do you have
on the switch, all right.

131
00:07:12.760 --> 00:07:18.380
Well if we can cut that connector in half,
we get a greater port density right?

132
00:07:18.380 --> 00:07:20.950
Which means that if I have
the subscriber connector, and

133
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:24.460
I put them side by side with
the Lucent connect or the little guy.

134
00:07:24.460 --> 00:07:27.010
I always say little connector cuz it
helped me remember to get it right on

135
00:07:27.010 --> 00:07:29.550
the exam, it's literally half the size.

136
00:07:29.550 --> 00:07:35.306
So I can get two of the LC connectors
into the space of a single SC connector.

137
00:07:35.306 --> 00:07:39.323
So from the perspective of the switch I
get a greater port density, all right.

138
00:07:39.323 --> 00:07:43.704
And again as price come down, and again
I say down, that's relative, if you guys

139
00:07:43.704 --> 00:07:48.291
are like us maybe watching from home, we
live on working men's salary here, right.

140
00:07:48.291 --> 00:07:53.768
[LAUGH] You need greater a port density,
right, today.

141
00:07:53.768 --> 00:07:58.628
We can put more of these connections
into a single switch if we're using

142
00:07:58.628 --> 00:08:02.190
a connector that is half the size, right.

143
00:08:02.190 --> 00:08:03.197
And that's important to understand.

144
00:08:03.197 --> 00:08:05.332
In fact, we've got some examples of one.

145
00:08:05.332 --> 00:08:09.506
In fact, earlier when we were talking
about it, if we can take a look at these,

146
00:08:09.506 --> 00:08:10.962
you'll see that this one,

147
00:08:10.962 --> 00:08:14.530
I like this cable because it's
really easy to see that it has both.

148
00:08:14.530 --> 00:08:17.748
And if we can kind of zoom
into that just a little bit,

149
00:08:17.748 --> 00:08:22.229
you're gonna notice that they're
really not much different, right?

150
00:08:22.229 --> 00:08:28.000
I mean, aesthetically on the outside, the
plastic might look a little bit different.

151
00:08:28.000 --> 00:08:31.096
But notice, Zach,
the size difference, right?

152
00:08:31.096 --> 00:08:32.806
So this is two fibers, right?

153
00:08:32.806 --> 00:08:36.354
This is in what's known as
a duplexing configuration, right?

154
00:08:36.354 --> 00:08:41.239
You could, if you wanted to, you could
find these where they weren't paired

155
00:08:41.239 --> 00:08:45.290
up together and it would just
be a single fiber strand, right?

156
00:08:45.290 --> 00:08:49.930
But they don't, a lot of times they do
what's known as a duplexing arrangement.

157
00:08:49.930 --> 00:08:53.260
And with the duplexing arrangement,
what that gives us the ability to do

158
00:08:53.260 --> 00:08:58.550
essentially is we can have a send
fiber and a receive fiber.

159
00:08:58.550 --> 00:09:00.247
So we're sending and
receiving at the same time.

160
00:09:00.247 --> 00:09:01.954
So these are typically
in a duplex arrangement.

161
00:09:01.954 --> 00:09:06.934
And the communication type on
this would be what's known as

162
00:09:06.934 --> 00:09:12.016
a full duplex communication,
simultaneous communication

163
00:09:12.016 --> 00:09:15.814
in both directions, same time, all right?

164
00:09:15.814 --> 00:09:19.030
And again, you can see here that,
same thing, right?

165
00:09:19.030 --> 00:09:23.210
We have two different fiber strands here,
and I'm be careful not to break this.

166
00:09:23.210 --> 00:09:25.300
And at the same time, we've got our caps.

167
00:09:25.300 --> 00:09:26.420
This isn't the core,

168
00:09:26.420 --> 00:09:30.250
this is actually a cap that you can
see is protecting the core, right?

169
00:09:30.250 --> 00:09:31.980
So we get a greater port density, and

170
00:09:31.980 --> 00:09:35.900
we'll talk about what these
devices are here coming up.

171
00:09:35.900 --> 00:09:41.640
But again, if you look, this actually
takes two of the LC connectors, right?

172
00:09:41.640 --> 00:09:46.515
I couldn't even maybe fit,
side-by-side, maybe one, maybe,

173
00:09:46.515 --> 00:09:51.810
one of these SC connectors into
a single interface card on the switch.

174
00:09:51.810 --> 00:09:54.460
So again,
you get that greater port density, right?

175
00:09:54.460 --> 00:09:58.050
So, and these cables, honestly, this cable
here is for backwards compatibility.

176
00:09:58.050 --> 00:10:01.830
You might have a switch that
has the older connector, right,

177
00:10:01.830 --> 00:10:03.120
versus the newer connector.

178
00:10:03.120 --> 00:10:04.490
Well, this cable is interoperability,
right?

179
00:10:04.490 --> 00:10:10.305
It allows you to use these
interchangeably if you have one device or

180
00:10:10.305 --> 00:10:15.050
module that is using newer LC connectors
versus the older SC connector,

181
00:10:15.050 --> 00:10:17.740
you get the transition,
you get that interoperability.

182
00:10:17.740 --> 00:10:21.910
However, you'll see you don't get
that one with this multi-mode cable.

183
00:10:21.910 --> 00:10:23.980
Or again, if you were paying
attention to the first episode,

184
00:10:23.980 --> 00:10:26.905
this is a single-mode cable and
this is a multi-mode cable.

185
00:10:26.905 --> 00:10:30.364
And notice that single-mode, multi-mode,

186
00:10:30.364 --> 00:10:34.518
it's irrelevant to what
the connector type is, right?

187
00:10:34.518 --> 00:10:39.332
Because this has two of the LC connectors

188
00:10:39.332 --> 00:10:43.870
on each side of our fiber optic cable.

189
00:10:43.870 --> 00:10:49.290
So you can see there that we have
single mode taking LC connector.

190
00:10:49.290 --> 00:10:54.190
We have multi-mode,
also taking SC connectors likewise.

191
00:10:54.190 --> 00:10:58.770
Now, with the connectors, we do have
to be careful with them because there

192
00:10:58.770 --> 00:11:01.900
is another thing that you need
to be aware of, all right?

193
00:11:01.900 --> 00:11:06.049
But we have, and they call it out on the
exam objectives, what's known as UPC, and

194
00:11:06.049 --> 00:11:07.785
what's known as APC, all right?

195
00:11:07.785 --> 00:11:12.768
And to really understand the difference
is to understand that we always

196
00:11:12.768 --> 00:11:16.680
have signal loss happening
inside a fiber optic cable.

197
00:11:17.770 --> 00:11:18.910
It's just gonna happen, right?

198
00:11:18.910 --> 00:11:22.540
Even the best manufacturers are gonna be
impurities, imperfections in the glass,

199
00:11:22.540 --> 00:11:24.940
because were talking about
a millionth of a meter.

200
00:11:24.940 --> 00:11:28.130
Bubbles in the glass,
that's gonna cause signal loss.

201
00:11:28.130 --> 00:11:29.130
That's gonna end up happening.

202
00:11:29.130 --> 00:11:36.720
When signal loss happens, we get a
degrading, or performance degrades, right?

203
00:11:36.720 --> 00:11:40.600
Now, when we end up attaching
the connectors to the end, when we do

204
00:11:40.600 --> 00:11:44.620
terminate these connectors, or terminate
these cables with these connector types,

205
00:11:45.700 --> 00:11:50.538
the UPC versus the APC really
comes down to a couple of things.

206
00:11:50.538 --> 00:11:55.270
How much signal loss can you tolerate,
all right?

207
00:11:55.270 --> 00:12:00.430
And as well is how much
reflection is going to happen,

208
00:12:00.430 --> 00:12:02.850
or where, I should say,
the reflection's gonna happen.

209
00:12:02.850 --> 00:12:04.840
So I got a little diagram here.

210
00:12:04.840 --> 00:12:07.510
And when we look at UPC, all right?

211
00:12:07.510 --> 00:12:09.890
Again, imagine the cable.

212
00:12:09.890 --> 00:12:12.950
We have, right, we've got
the fiber optic cable, all right?

213
00:12:12.950 --> 00:12:17.120
Notice that we have multiple light sources
coming down the center of this cable,

214
00:12:17.120 --> 00:12:18.260
right, this UPC.

215
00:12:18.260 --> 00:12:23.249
UPC, by the way, ladies and gentlemen,
make sure that we define that for you,

216
00:12:23.249 --> 00:12:25.569
that's an Ultra Physical Contact.

217
00:12:25.569 --> 00:12:30.456
Versus APC, for the acronyms, those of
you guys that are keeping track of your

218
00:12:30.456 --> 00:12:34.760
jargon out there,
that's the Angled Physical Connector.

219
00:12:34.760 --> 00:12:40.690
Now, when we look at
the Ultra Physical Connector,

220
00:12:40.690 --> 00:12:46.320
or contact if you will,
notice that a portion of this fiber,

221
00:12:46.320 --> 00:12:51.280
or the signal coming down this fiber, when
it's terminated some of it reflects back.

222
00:12:51.280 --> 00:12:53.360
That just happens, we're going
to get signal reflection, right?

223
00:12:54.790 --> 00:12:59.340
Versus Angled Physical Connector.

224
00:12:59.340 --> 00:13:02.624
Notice that what we end up having here is,
notice the angle.

225
00:13:02.624 --> 00:13:03.910
Oops let me get that out of there.

226
00:13:03.910 --> 00:13:05.030
Notice the angle here.

227
00:13:06.530 --> 00:13:10.920
APC, make sure that if,
when the connector's applied to the end of

228
00:13:10.920 --> 00:13:16.280
the cable, that we get an eight degree
angle on the reflection, all right?

229
00:13:16.280 --> 00:13:19.860
Now, why do we have to worry about that,
all right?

230
00:13:19.860 --> 00:13:23.520
Again, keep in mind,
every time a fiber optic cable

231
00:13:23.520 --> 00:13:27.260
has a connector attached to it, a portion
of the light is going to be lost, right?

232
00:13:27.260 --> 00:13:29.230
It's called light loss, all right?

233
00:13:29.230 --> 00:13:32.312
Light loss is essentially due
to the reflection that occurs

234
00:13:32.312 --> 00:13:36.813
when the connector's applied, essentially
causing a damaged or disrupted signal,

235
00:13:36.813 --> 00:13:37.442
all right?

236
00:13:37.442 --> 00:13:42.501
You can see that there's more
reflection going on in the UPC when

237
00:13:42.501 --> 00:13:47.193
it reflects straight back to
its light source, all right?

238
00:13:47.193 --> 00:13:52.177
Now, to understand that,
and UPC is used in systems

239
00:13:52.177 --> 00:13:56.830
that require less precision, all right?

240
00:13:56.830 --> 00:14:00.570
Essentially, they can tolerate
a little bit more light loss, right?

241
00:14:00.570 --> 00:14:04.561
So if you have a signal or a system
that isn't sensitive to light loss,

242
00:14:04.561 --> 00:14:08.502
extremely sensitive to light loss,
you can use the UPC, all right?

243
00:14:08.502 --> 00:14:10.470
The Ultra Physical Contact.

244
00:14:10.470 --> 00:14:11.952
Now, it's a polished connector.

245
00:14:11.952 --> 00:14:14.580
You always have to have
polished connectors, all right?

246
00:14:14.580 --> 00:14:17.260
When you are connecting them.

247
00:14:17.260 --> 00:14:19.893
They're usually color coded blue, and

248
00:14:19.893 --> 00:14:23.543
they have a return loss of
about 50 decibel or higher.

249
00:14:23.543 --> 00:14:24.648
You don't have to worry,

250
00:14:24.648 --> 00:14:27.020
I put that out there just in
case they ask you on the exam.

251
00:14:27.020 --> 00:14:28.190
I don't think they're going to ask you.

252
00:14:28.190 --> 00:14:34.730
However, you do have systems that
need precision fiber signaling.

253
00:14:34.730 --> 00:14:37.780
They cannot handle light loss, right?

254
00:14:37.780 --> 00:14:39.670
They are too sensitive, right?

255
00:14:39.670 --> 00:14:42.690
And that's where the APC
is gonna come in handy.

256
00:14:42.690 --> 00:14:44.700
A little bit more expensive, right?

257
00:14:44.700 --> 00:14:51.219
But when it comes down to it, if you are
requiring precision fiber connectivity,

258
00:14:51.219 --> 00:14:57.276
and cannot deal with light loss,
use the APC, the Angle Physical Contact.

259
00:14:57.276 --> 00:14:59.990
And again, that's going to be one,
a return loss if you will,

260
00:14:59.990 --> 00:15:01.490
of about 60 decibels or higher.

261
00:15:01.490 --> 00:15:04.060
And again, it's color-coded green,
all right?

262
00:15:04.060 --> 00:15:06.920
So I'm not sure if they'll show
you an exhibit on the exam, but

263
00:15:06.920 --> 00:15:08.940
if they do, they color-code these.

264

we might not get anything couples,

487
00:28:12.020 --> 00:28:15.610
we're trying to talk at the same time,
but we could communicate and

488
00:28:15.610 --> 00:28:18.320
we could talk at the same time and
hear each other at the same time.

489
00:28:18.320 --> 00:28:20.921
That is a bi-directional communication.

490
00:28:20.921 --> 00:28:24.260
Each direction can happen simultaneously.

491
00:28:24.260 --> 00:28:28.980
So be aware of that and that's why we
see these fibers again where there's two

492
00:28:28.980 --> 00:28:32.420
fibers at once because you can send on one
fiber and you can receive on the other.

493
00:28:32.420 --> 00:28:35.980
You get that full duplex
communication as it's known.

494
00:28:35.980 --> 00:28:40.410
Last but no the least is what's known
as a fiber distribution panel, right?

495
00:28:40.410 --> 00:28:45.227
Well a fiber distribution panel
is a lot like a copper based or

496
00:28:45.227 --> 00:28:47.883
twisted pair based patchville.

497
00:28:47.883 --> 00:28:52.150
Right, we need a place to terminate
all these fiber connections, right?

498
00:28:52.150 --> 00:28:52.930
How do we do that?

499
00:28:52.930 --> 00:28:56.180
Well, I've actually got a picture
of one pulled up here and

500
00:28:56.180 --> 00:28:59.150
you can kind of see that
this is a combination.

501
00:28:59.150 --> 00:29:02.430
I like this one because it kinda
harkens back to what we said before,

502
00:29:02.430 --> 00:29:04.060
this is actually you can see.

503
00:29:04.060 --> 00:29:07.890
Why don't we try that again if I
know how to work a web browser.

504
00:29:07.890 --> 00:29:11.020
Notice that we've got our
copper media right here,

505
00:29:11.020 --> 00:29:13.560
these are RJ-45 jacks that we see.

506
00:29:13.560 --> 00:29:19.078
But then we also if we scroll up,
we can see that we have some GBex.

507
00:29:19.078 --> 00:29:22.700
Now this is an older standard here.

508
00:29:22.700 --> 00:29:25.700
Because if you look up these
are the SC connectors.

509
00:29:25.700 --> 00:29:29.580
But notice that we have our fiber optics
cables that are actually kinda terminating

510
00:29:29.580 --> 00:29:33.960
right here into this fiber optic
distribution or fiber distribution panel.

511
00:29:33.960 --> 00:29:37.190
So, that's what you've got and you
typically have these inside of your server

512
00:29:37.190 --> 00:29:39.680
closet, this happens to be
a floor patch panel if you will.

513
00:29:39.680 --> 00:29:41.620
And this is kind of mixing both, right.

514
00:29:41.620 --> 00:29:45.769
It's mixing fiber optic communications
along with you have your copper

515
00:29:45.769 --> 00:29:48.837
connections or
your twisted pair implementations.

516
00:29:48.837 --> 00:29:52.561
So probably both of these are for some
kind of Ethernet communication if I had

517
00:29:52.561 --> 00:29:56.920
to take a guess here, but that essentially
is your fiber distribution panel.

518
00:29:56.920 --> 00:29:58.350
Lot of different technologies, right?

519
00:29:58.350 --> 00:29:59.130
Keep that in mind,

520
00:29:59.130 --> 00:30:03.160
a lot of different standards, completely
understand it don't let it scare you.

521
00:30:03.160 --> 00:30:06.630
Get these specifications under your belt
so that if they put you in a scenario on

522
00:30:06.630 --> 00:30:11.250
the exam you'll be able to answer this,
answer these questions.

523
00:30:11.250 --> 00:30:13.770
Keep in mind,
another great thing about going ahead and

524
00:30:13.770 --> 00:30:17.950
doing the memorization is that, in doing
the memorization, sometimes it's very

525
00:30:17.950 --> 00:30:22.290
easy to write a question that says, okay,
you've got a single mode cable, and

526
00:30:22.290 --> 00:30:25.740
you need to, I don't know,
operate at 2,000 meters.

527
00:30:25.740 --> 00:30:28.390
Or maybe they're asking, they're putting
you in a scenario that says, hey,

528
00:30:28.390 --> 00:30:30.630
this business has to connect
to this business, and

529
00:30:30.630 --> 00:30:33.860
it's 1,000 meters away, which of
these standards are you gonna use?

530
00:30:33.860 --> 00:30:40.930
Well if you know, again,
that 1000BASE-SX is only multimode?

531
00:30:40.930 --> 00:30:41.999
You're not gonna use it, right?

532
00:30:41.999 --> 00:30:45.857
You're not gonna be able to use that
standard in order to go a 1000 meters,

533
00:30:45.857 --> 00:30:47.902
right, because the maximum distance for

534
00:30:47.902 --> 00:30:50.777
multimode in this application
is gonna be 550 meters.

535
00:30:50.777 --> 00:30:55.918
These are easy questions to get to
wrong if you're not paying to keywords,

536
00:30:55.918 --> 00:30:58.455
but they're also easy to get right.

537
00:30:58.455 --> 00:31:02.815
So definitely, know the facts and
specifications here.

538
00:31:02.815 --> 00:31:06.370
Do your memorization so on the exam
any scenario that they give you,

539
00:31:06.370 --> 00:31:08.930
you're gonna be doing well and
not only pass that exam.

540
00:31:08.930 --> 00:31:10.880
We want you to knock it
out of the ballpark.

541
00:31:10.880 --> 00:31:12.570
>> And
with your help Wes I'm sure they will.

542
00:31:12.570 --> 00:31:14.010
This is awesome stuff.

543
00:31:14.010 --> 00:31:15.420
Cabling solutions fiber part two.

544
00:31:15.420 --> 00:31:16.560
Make sure you see part one and

545
00:31:16.560 --> 00:31:20.700
see everything in the CompTIA net plus
series that Wes is creating for you.

546
00:31:20.700 --> 00:31:21.330
It will help you.

547
00:31:21.330 --> 00:31:24.210
It really will and while you're in
the course library hundreds of other

548
00:31:24.210 --> 00:31:26.730
videos and
they're all designed to do one thing.

549
00:31:26.730 --> 00:31:28.250
Help you go further and

550
00:31:28.250 --> 00:31:31.540
tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be very happy that you did.

551
00:31:31.540 --> 00:31:32.940
Thanks for watching I'm Zach Memos.

552
00:31:32.940 --> 00:31:33.790
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

553
00:31:33.790 --> 00:31:36.280
>> And we will see you soon.

554
00:31:36.280 --> 00:31:42.291
[MUSIC]

555
00:31:42.291 --> 00:31:45.367
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Justin and Wes explore the different devices inside of modern networks such as firewall, routers, switches.....etc.
episodes.title: Network Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:02.684
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.684 --> 00:00:05.985
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.985 --> 00:00:08.312
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.312 --> 00:00:11.865
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.865 --> 00:00:15.477
>> Greetings and welcome back to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.477 --> 00:00:17.058
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and

7
00:00:17.058 --> 00:00:20.683
while we're continuing on with our
CompTIA Network+ adventure, particularly,

8
00:00:20.683 --> 00:00:23.100
we're gonna be looking at
network devices today.

9
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:25.970
And here to help us in that very endeavor,
is Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:26.830
How are you doing today, Wes?

11
00:00:26.830 --> 00:00:28.880
>> I'm doing okay, thanks for
having me back, Justin.

12
00:00:28.880 --> 00:00:32.690
That's right, we will be looking
at various network devices,

13
00:00:32.690 --> 00:00:37.507
as well as determining where we need to
place these devices within our networks.

14
00:00:37.507 --> 00:00:40.642
And one of the very first ones
that we are gonna jump in and

15
00:00:40.642 --> 00:00:44.210
talk about in this episode,
is the good old firewall.

16
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:48.070
All right, now maybe some of you guys and
gals out there are aware of the firewall

17
00:00:48.070 --> 00:00:50.670
that maybe is currently
running on your machine.

18
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:53.560
All right,
maybe on your Windows machine out there,

19
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:58.780
maybe you got a firewall like IPtables,
if you will, inside our firewall CMD,

20
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:02.430
I believe, inside of Linux systems, right?

21
00:01:02.430 --> 00:01:05.140
But those, are what are known
as host-based firewalls, right?

22
00:01:05.140 --> 00:01:07.996
And the reason they call them
host-based firewalls, or

23
00:01:07.996 --> 00:01:11.032
even sometimes software-based firewalls,
is, for one,

24
00:01:11.032 --> 00:01:15.018
they are screening the traffic that is
coming in and out of the network adaptor,

25
00:01:15.018 --> 00:01:17.364
on the host that they're running on,
right?

26
00:01:17.364 --> 00:01:21.377
They're called software-based firewalls
because typically they don't have

27
00:01:21.377 --> 00:01:25.461
a hardware appliance associated with them,
unlike a network-based firewall.

28
00:01:25.461 --> 00:01:27.086
In fact, I kinda have got a diagram,

29
00:01:27.086 --> 00:01:30.030
little diagram here of the difference
between these two, right?

30
00:01:30.030 --> 00:01:30.945
So if you look at,

31
00:01:30.945 --> 00:01:35.155
like for instance, we'll just take
the traditional Windows Firewall, right?

32
00:01:35.155 --> 00:01:37.888
Let's say software-based
firewall that works inside of

33
00:01:37.888 --> 00:01:39.400
the Windows operating system.

34
00:01:39.400 --> 00:01:43.220
And again, it is just screening
traffic that's coming to and

35
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:48.350
from the network adapter, the NIC if
you will, inside of a specific host.

36
00:01:48.350 --> 00:01:52.261
All right, and
that's unlike the network-based firewall.

37
00:01:52.261 --> 00:01:55.915
When we look at the network-based
firewall, notice where the position of

38
00:01:55.915 --> 00:01:59.518
the network-based firewall is in
relationship to the network, right?

39
00:01:59.518 --> 00:02:03.067
Now, I will tell you that some routers
might even have firewalls built right

40
00:02:03.067 --> 00:02:03.630
into them.

41
00:02:03.630 --> 00:02:07.240
So abstractly, you could have
multi-functional device that is doing

42
00:02:07.240 --> 00:02:09.930
all of this,
built into a single device, right?

43
00:02:09.930 --> 00:02:14.650
But the firewall, the network-based
firewall, what traffic is it screening?

44
00:02:14.650 --> 00:02:17.340
Well, if you look,
based on its position within the diagram,

45
00:02:17.340 --> 00:02:22.032
it's actually screening every bit of
traffic that comes into your network,

46
00:02:22.032 --> 00:02:23.655
or is leaving your network.

47
00:02:23.655 --> 00:02:25.709
Unlike the host-based firewall, right?

48
00:02:25.709 --> 00:02:29.810
The host based firewall, again, is just
screening traffic that is coming in and

49
00:02:29.810 --> 00:02:32.372
out of the network adapter,
on that one machine.

50
00:02:32.372 --> 00:02:37.332
The network-based firewall,
it goes farther and it screens all traffic

51
00:02:37.332 --> 00:02:42.621
going to everybody within your networks,
as well as out of your networks too.

52
00:02:42.621 --> 00:02:47.030
All right, and these firewalls,
they can be very complex.

53
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:50.101
In fact, with the next generation
of firewalls that we have,

54
00:02:50.101 --> 00:02:52.004
you might hear the term NGFW, right?

55
00:02:52.004 --> 00:02:53.368
Next generation firewall,

56
00:02:53.368 --> 00:02:56.620
they can go all the way,
if we're looking at the OSI model, right?

57
00:02:56.620 --> 00:02:58.849
They can go all the way
up to the application,

58
00:02:58.849 --> 00:03:00.559
the application layer firewall.

59
00:03:00.559 --> 00:03:04.053
All right, firewalls, again, one of
the things that traditionally they do,

60
00:03:04.053 --> 00:03:07.183
the network-based firewalls, and
really the host based firewalls,

61
00:03:07.183 --> 00:03:10.260
is they block all
unsolicited inbound traffic.

62
00:03:10.260 --> 00:03:13.380
Now, what do I mean by
blocking unsolicited traffic?

63
00:03:13.380 --> 00:03:16.880
Which means you don't ask for
that traffic to come into your network,

64
00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:19.210
it's going to be blocked by default.

65
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:22.280
Now, you can make an exception of that,
we call it exceptions,

66
00:03:22.280 --> 00:03:25.320
the exceptions of the rule is block
everything that comes into the network,

67
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:30.490
except for this type of traffic
that I put a rule there, right?

68
00:03:30.490 --> 00:03:32.843
Outbound traffic however,
is typically allowed.

69
00:03:32.843 --> 00:03:38.790
Cuz it's typically inside of your network,
being sent out to some source, right?

70
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:45.126
Now, I do want you to keep in mind
that if you're looking at a firewall,

71
00:03:45.126 --> 00:03:49.000
in relation to l the OSI model that
we've talked about in other episodes,

72
00:03:49.000 --> 00:03:52.760
firewalls can do things like
inspecting IP addresses, right?

73
00:03:52.760 --> 00:03:56.670
If they're inspecting IP addresses, then
what they're basically doing is operating

74
00:03:56.670 --> 00:03:58.910
at layer three of the OSI model, right?

75
00:03:58.910 --> 00:04:00.320
The network layer.

76
00:04:00.320 --> 00:04:05.050
But sometimes what they do is they
monitor the state of a connection.

77
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:06.580
Well, where's the state of a connection?

78
00:04:06.580 --> 00:04:08.920
And we talk about transmission
control protocol.

79
00:04:08.920 --> 00:04:12.380
That sits at the transport and
the session layer of the OSI model.

80
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:17.070
When we talk about the TCP/IP session
identifiers, like sockets and ports, well,

81
00:04:17.070 --> 00:04:22.550
sometimes you can do port-based
rules that say hey, block this port.

82
00:04:22.550 --> 00:04:24.860
Well, that's gonna be
at the session layer.

83
00:04:24.860 --> 00:04:28.860
But then sometimes, these firewalls
are smart enough that it says,

84
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:31.890
hey, I can peel back that encapsulation.

85
00:04:31.890 --> 00:04:34.311
I can look down in that packet,
and you know what?

86
00:04:34.311 --> 00:04:38.200
I'm blocking unencrypted web traffic,
right?

87
00:04:38.200 --> 00:04:40.840
Well, just because you change
that port number to 443,

88
00:04:40.840 --> 00:04:44.810
doesn't mean that you're gonna fool
the application layer firewall.

89
00:04:44.810 --> 00:04:49.430
Cuz it can look and say hey, you're
telling me that this is encrypted traffic,

90
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:52.100
but I can plainly see this
is just basic HTTP traffic.

91
00:04:52.100 --> 00:04:56.508
So it's aware of those protocols and
they can be very very smart, all right?

92
00:04:56.508 --> 00:04:59.204
That's a network-based firewall.

93
00:04:59.204 --> 00:05:03.596
Now, generically the objectives just say
firewall, so that's why we went ahead and

94
00:05:03.596 --> 00:05:05.210
we told you about both.

95
00:05:05.210 --> 00:05:07.370
Remember, just like a host-based firewall,

96
00:05:07.370 --> 00:05:11.220
sometimes it's called a software-based
firewall, a network-based firewall,

97
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:14.010
sometimes is also called
a hardware-based firewall, right?

98
00:05:14.010 --> 00:05:15.530
Now, that gets a little confusing,

99
00:05:15.530 --> 00:05:17.700
cuz, honestly, to me,
that was always confusing.

100
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:22.220
Cuz if I think about it, Justin,
you've got a small piece of software

101
00:05:22.220 --> 00:05:24.690
that's actually running within
a hardware-based firewall.

102
00:05:24.690 --> 00:05:28.080
But just understand generically,
that's where those terms come from.

103
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:31.842
Software-based firewall running on
your host, host-based firewall.

104
00:05:31.842 --> 00:05:35.990
Your hardware-based firewalls are a
dedicated appliance that has the software,

105
00:05:35.990 --> 00:05:38.760
essentially, that's performing
the firewall functionality, within them.

106
00:05:40.210 --> 00:05:43.440
All right, now the next thing we're gonna
talk about are a series of connectivity

107
00:05:43.440 --> 00:05:44.060
devices.

108
00:05:44.060 --> 00:05:47.450
And I'm gonna do this in a little bit
different order than what you would see,

109
00:05:47.450 --> 00:05:50.770
if you're following along at home
with the objectives, all right?

110
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:53.807
And the reason I wanna do
this in a different order,

111
00:05:53.807 --> 00:05:56.492
is because I wanna do them,
historically and

112
00:05:56.492 --> 00:06:00.893
as well kinda related to their
intelligence within the network, right?

113
00:06:00.893 --> 00:06:04.134
If you're gonna understand a network
device, you have to kinda understand

114
00:06:04.134 --> 00:06:07.740
what's going on within, inside of that
device, just like we mentioned firewall.

115
00:06:07.740 --> 00:06:11.080
So the very first one that I wanna
start with is what is known as a hub.

116
00:06:11.080 --> 00:06:12.303
Hubs have been around for a while.

117
00:06:12.303 --> 00:06:16.287
And I've gotta, generically, a little
diagram here, of a hub, all right?

118
00:06:16.287 --> 00:06:19.210
Now, why did I start with a hub?

119
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:25.390
Hubs are probably the dumbest,
if you will, of all networking devices.

120
00:06:25.390 --> 00:06:28.910
In fact, Justin, you and
I were talking about,

121
00:06:28.910 --> 00:06:31.440
and you made a good point about that hub.

122
00:06:31.440 --> 00:06:34.030
That hub,
it doesn't have any logic in it, right?

123
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:37.415
So it is hardwired,
electrically hardwired,

124
00:06:37.415 --> 00:06:40.381
to receive bits of information, right?

125
00:06:40.381 --> 00:06:43.994
So this computer, if it's sending
information into the hub, all it's doing

126
00:06:43.994 --> 00:06:47.240
is it's sending those raw bits down
that physical layer into the hub.

127
00:06:47.240 --> 00:06:48.720
And the hub is hardwired to say,

128
00:06:48.720 --> 00:06:53.680
you know what, just broadcast this
information out all of our other ports.

129
00:06:53.680 --> 00:06:57.350
Do not make a logical decision,
don't worry about MAC addresses, right,

130
00:06:57.350 --> 00:06:58.260
at the data link layer.

131
00:06:58.260 --> 00:07:02.790
Don't worry about the IP addresses at
the network layer, I couldn't care less.

132
00:07:02.790 --> 00:07:04.600
I don't know anything about that.

133
00:07:04.600 --> 00:07:06.363
I take this information, and

134
00:07:06.363 --> 00:07:10.818
my wires are soldered in a way [LAUGH]
that I broadcast it out all other ports.

135
00:07:10.818 --> 00:07:13.790
All right, now there's an issue with hubs.

136
00:07:13.790 --> 00:07:16.978
All right, not only the fact
[LAUGH] that they're, well,

137
00:07:16.978 --> 00:07:21.535
pretty unintelligent, is the fact that
they also crease contention, increase,

138
00:07:21.535 --> 00:07:23.636
excuse me, contention, all right?

139
00:07:23.636 --> 00:07:26.640
Within already contention-based
networks right?

140
00:07:26.640 --> 00:07:28.730
So for instance,
we talked about in other episodes,

141
00:07:28.730 --> 00:07:31.300
how if we had a bus topology, right?

142
00:07:31.300 --> 00:07:35.190
We talked about that ethernet, the earlier
ethernet networks where bus topologies,

143
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:37.190
and the more nodes you would put on them,
right?

144
00:07:37.190 --> 00:07:43.840
It would increase the contention
within that network topology.

145
00:07:43.840 --> 00:07:44.860
Well, hubs do the same thing.

146
00:07:44.860 --> 00:07:46.820
The more devices that you add to a hub,

147
00:07:46.820 --> 00:07:49.712
the more broadcast communications
you are gonna have.

148
00:07:49.712 --> 00:07:52.118
The other thing to keep in
mind too is that with a hub,

149
00:07:52.118 --> 00:07:53.945
it's a half-duplex communication.

150
00:07:53.945 --> 00:07:57.315
Now, we haven't really talked about
the duplexing types here, but

151
00:07:57.315 --> 00:08:00.105
half-duplex means It is
a two-way communication, but

152
00:08:00.105 --> 00:08:03.490
just in one direction at a time,
because I want you to think about it.

153
00:08:03.490 --> 00:08:06.990
If we go back to the diagram here, if I've
got this computer as sending information

154
00:08:06.990 --> 00:08:12.090
into the Hub, and it's going to
broadcast it out all other ports,

155
00:08:12.090 --> 00:08:16.490
then what must all other devices be
doing if this computer is communicating?

156
00:08:16.490 --> 00:08:19.611
They gotta wait, just wait.

157
00:08:19.611 --> 00:08:23.809
You've got data to send but I'm already
sending data, right, and we can't send and

158
00:08:23.809 --> 00:08:25.967
receive data on the same electrical cable,

159
00:08:25.967 --> 00:08:30.250
because we're gonna get electrical
collisions, right, and that's a bad thing.

160
00:08:30.250 --> 00:08:32.988
So the more devices,
just like on the bus based network,

161
00:08:32.988 --> 00:08:35.680
the more devices you add to a hub,
the more contention.

162
00:08:35.680 --> 00:08:40.299
The more competition for communications,
increase the more wasted communication,

163
00:08:40.299 --> 00:08:44.347
excess communications that don't
necessarily need to be on your network,

164
00:08:44.347 --> 00:08:45.000
all right.

165
00:08:45.000 --> 00:08:47.100
So the hub's where it started, all right.

166
00:08:47.100 --> 00:08:51.700
Then, we moved into what was
known as the bridge, all right.

167
00:08:51.700 --> 00:08:54.430
Now, there's a couple of different types
of bridges, there's wired bridge and

168
00:08:54.430 --> 00:08:55.320
a wireless bridge too.

00:08:55.320 --> 00:08:56.624
I wanna kind of tackle both.

170
00:08:56.624 --> 00:09:00.692
Now again,understand that when we look

00:09:00.692 --> 00:09:02.440
they're just saying a bridge.

172
00:09:02.440 --> 00:09:04.890
But again, I want you to kinda know the
difference between the wired bridge and

173
00:09:04.890 --> 00:09:07.010

174
00:09:07.010 --> 00:09:09.280
So the wired bridge, what would you have?

175
00:09:09.280 --> 00:09:12.770
Well, within a local area network,
all right, understand that that's where

176
00:09:12.770 --> 00:09:16.260
they're positioned, they're inside to

177
00:09:16.260 --> 00:09:19.820
You could have two physical segments,

178
00:09:19.820 --> 00:09:23.910
Segments, just a physical
grouping of computers together.

179
00:09:23.910 --> 00:09:27.320
And essentially what you have here
when you look at LAN segment 1 and

180
00:09:27.320 --> 00:09:32.090
LAN segment 2, it really got two

181
00:09:32.090 --> 00:09:37.416
There's no way for LAN segment 1
to communicate with LAN segment 2,

182
00:09:37.416 --> 00:09:43.465
so if you wanna take two of these segments

183
00:09:43.465 --> 00:09:48.363
then you bridge the two smaller
networks together, all right?

184
00:09:48.363 --> 00:09:52.314
Now, the bridge, what it does,

00:09:52.314 --> 00:09:54.661
If a communication, let me go ahead and

00:09:54.661 --> 00:09:57.920
just kinda move our little
box here out of the way.

187
00:09:57.920 --> 00:10:02.930
If this computer wants to speak with
this computer, does it make sense to

00:10:02.930 --> 00:10:08.480

189
00:10:08.480 --> 00:10:12.870
Not really, if this was the hub,

190
00:10:12.870 --> 00:10:14.704
Hub doesn't understand anything.

00:10:14.704 --> 00:10:23.190
So now we start to see logical

00:10:23.190 --> 00:10:24.380
And what's being made?

193
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:30.390
Well, when workstation 1 sends
information to workstation 2, we're

194
00:10:30.390 --> 00:10:34.310
probably still gonna have a bridge in
here, or a bus based network of some type.

195
00:10:34.310 --> 00:10:37.466
So that means, this computer's gonna
hear it, this computer's gonna hear it,

196
00:10:37.466 --> 00:10:39.080
this computer's gonna hear it.

197
00:10:39.080 --> 00:10:42.904
And the network adapter on this side
of the bridge is gonna hear it as well.

198
00:10:42.904 --> 00:10:44.860
But the bridge, in this case,

199
00:10:44.860 --> 00:10:50.000
isn't gonna pass the communication to
its next interface on this next segment.

200
00:10:50.000 --> 00:10:54.352
Because what it's gonna do is it's gonna

201
00:10:54.352 --> 00:10:59.200
And it's gonna look at a table that
it has, and the table will say,

202
00:10:59.200 --> 00:11:03.113
hey, work station 3,

203
00:11:03.113 --> 00:11:05.862
The MAC address lets me know

00:11:05.862 --> 00:11:08.070
to this network this side of the bridge.

205
00:11:08.070 --> 00:11:11.920
So rather than allow all of that

00:11:11.920 --> 00:11:13.490
it isolates it.

207
00:11:13.490 --> 00:11:16.950
All right, so that is one of

208
00:11:16.950 --> 00:11:21.063
Yes, you can take two LAN segments,

209
00:11:21.063 --> 00:11:27.050
But then you can also isolate them down

210
00:11:27.050 --> 00:11:33.110
Because any electrical collisions that
happen for communications on computer 1,

211
00:11:33.110 --> 00:11:38.840
2, and 3, only affect 1, 2, and 3 because
the Mac addresses are being inspected.

212
00:11:38.840 --> 00:11:44.401
Now let say that workstation 1 wanted
to send communication to workstation 4.

213
00:11:44.401 --> 00:11:48.653
Well, the same process still applies
because they're on LAN segment 1

214
00:11:48.653 --> 00:11:53.640
station 2, station 3, and the bridge
are gonna receive that information.

215
00:11:53.640 --> 00:11:58.450
But this time what's gonna happen is,
the bridge is gonna say, wait a second,

216
00:11:58.450 --> 00:12:01.490
let me inspect the destination
Mac address, all right.

217
00:12:01.490 --> 00:12:03.620
I'll look at a table here, all right.

218
00:12:03.620 --> 00:12:07.070
So I see that that information
isn't bound for LAN segment 1, but

00:12:07.070 --> 00:12:11.690
according to my Mac table here that
I have, I can actually send that

220
00:12:11.690 --> 00:12:16.970
directly over to LAN segment 2 with
a destination MAC address is, all right?

221
00:12:16.970 --> 00:12:21.040
So now, we start to see that some logical
decisions are being made, all right?

222
00:12:21.040 --> 00:12:26.400
Well, notice that we gotta kind of
a limitation on how many devices or

223
00:12:26.400 --> 00:12:29.940
really how many connections

224
00:12:29.940 --> 00:12:31.800
And if you look in this case,

00:12:31.800 --> 00:12:36.340
what's gonna happen here was we're gonna

00:12:36.340 --> 00:12:39.905
Or we're gonna have some kind of

00:12:39.905 --> 00:12:40.620
communication.

00:12:40.620 --> 00:12:45.650
So the bridges still didn't

229
00:12:45.650 --> 00:12:46.930
So what can we do?

00:12:46.930 --> 00:12:51.535
All right, one of the things that you can

00:12:51.535 --> 00:12:52.266

00:12:52.266 --> 00:12:56.670
Multiport bridging, we'll go into

00:13:01.610 --> 00:13:03.490
We'll come back to the switches

00:13:03.490 --> 00:13:06.860
I want you to understand
that a multiport bridge,

00:13:06.860 --> 00:13:08.780
you could technically call the switch.

00:13:08.780 --> 00:13:13.508
All right, and we'll come back to
that here in a second cuzI also

00:13:13.508 --> 00:13:18.030
want to touch base on the wireless bridge,

239
00:13:18.030 --> 00:13:23.860
Now wireless bridges also work
by taking two segments and

00:13:23.860 --> 00:13:28.020
allowing communication to travel
between those two sections,

00:13:28.020 --> 00:13:31.210
those two segments essentially

242
00:13:31.210 --> 00:13:36.780
So for instance, this would be good in
scenarios where maybe you had a wired

243
00:13:36.780 --> 00:13:41.450
network here, that needs to
communicate across the wireless

244
00:13:41.450 --> 00:13:46.480
communication with wired network B but
there's a problem, right.

245
00:13:46.480 --> 00:13:48.420
Maybe we don't have wires running,

246
00:13:48.420 --> 00:13:51.520
we don't have the ability to run
a cable in between these two.

247
00:13:51.520 --> 00:13:55.730
So what we can have here is we
can have the wired computers and

248
00:13:55.730 --> 00:13:59.040
the wireless computers talk
to the access point, right?

249
00:13:59.040 --> 00:14:03.190
Do the wired connection for the wireless
devices, or the wire devices, excuse me.

250
00:14:03.190 --> 00:14:06.640
And they can communicate
across the wireless bridge

251
00:14:06.640 --> 00:14:08.220
to the other computers
on the other segment.

252
00:14:08.220 --> 00:14:09.950
So concept still the same.

253
00:14:09.950 --> 00:14:13.238
In fact, we've talked about it
in one of our other episodes,

254
00:14:13.238 --> 00:14:17.114
we talked about topologies where you
had a wireless local area network.

255
00:14:17.114 --> 00:14:22.582
And you had a single basic service set and
we bridged two basic service

256
00:14:22.582 --> 00:14:28.830
sets together and essentially what we
now have is an extended service set.

257
00:14:28.830 --> 00:14:32.959
An extended service set is almost

258
00:14:32.959 --> 00:14:35.630
So do be aware of that as well.

259
00:14:35.630 --> 00:14:38.650
Now there might be times where you
just need to extend the range of your

00:14:38.650 --> 00:14:40.060

00:14:40.060 --> 00:14:45.730
And maybe you don't need an entire AP,
a network,

00:14:45.730 --> 00:14:49.770
an access point doing all the management,
all the beckoning information and

263
00:14:49.770 --> 00:14:53.230
you just want to extend the range

264
00:14:53.230 --> 00:14:56.972
Well inside of your wireless networks,

00:14:56.972 --> 00:14:59.364
you can also do wireless
range extenders as well.

00:14:59.364 --> 00:15:01.170
And that's really common

00:15:01.170 --> 00:15:05.468
It makes it fairly easy to extend your

268
00:15:05.468 --> 00:15:10.180
your home, where you realize that

00:15:10.180 --> 00:15:11.430
The performance isn't that best, or

00:15:11.430 --> 00:15:15.330

00:15:15.330 --> 00:15:19.050
All right, so that is a little

00:15:19.050 --> 00:15:22.700
Now, we've talked about wireless

00:15:22.700 --> 00:15:24.310

00:15:24.310 --> 00:15:31.521
Remember that the wireless access point,

00:15:31.521 --> 00:15:36.482
A wireless access point is nothing
more than a device that gives your

wireless devices within your networks

277
00:15:41.980 --> 00:15:44.100
So our access point here, right?

00:15:44.100 --> 00:15:46.610
It is connected to our wired network here,

00:15:46.610 --> 00:15:49.271
in this case I'll just
take wired network A.

280
00:15:49.271 --> 00:15:52.937
And I have wireless devices
that are in this network A.

281
00:15:52.937 --> 00:15:56.908
They need access to these wired computers,

282
00:15:56.908 --> 00:16:00.444
Hence the term Wireless Access Point.

00:16:00.444 --> 00:16:05.976
Your Wireless Access Point actually
gives your wireless devices [LAUGH],

00:16:05.976 --> 00:16:10.279
if you can remember that,
access to your wired network.

00:16:10.279 --> 00:16:10.930
All right.

00:16:10.930 --> 00:16:12.230
So that's a little bit about the bridge.

00:16:12.230 --> 00:16:17.030
Now I do wanna go back to this concept

00:16:17.030 --> 00:16:19.780
Right.
I said that forms the basis for

00:16:19.780 --> 00:16:23.270
switching technologies and
switches that we have, right?

00:16:23.270 --> 00:16:27.440
Because if I can take
these six computers and

00:16:27.440 --> 00:16:33.280
then connect all of those computers

00:16:33.280 --> 00:16:34.900
we get a little bit better

00:16:34.900 --> 00:16:36.540
And I'll talk about that here in a second.

00:16:36.540 --> 00:16:39.400
This is where we get
what's known as a switch.

295
00:16:39.400 --> 00:16:43.230
A switch, really,
is nothing more than a multi-port bridge.

296
00:16:43.230 --> 00:16:47.240
The difference is your devices
have a direct connection,

297
00:16:47.240 --> 00:16:49.990
every single one of them, into the switch.

298
00:16:49.990 --> 00:16:54.350
Versus just one network adapter with
a bunch of devices connected to a hub and

299
00:16:54.350 --> 00:16:58.230
a single connection into
one side of the bridge.

300
00:16:58.230 --> 00:17:00.920
Now, what's the benefit here?

301
00:17:00.920 --> 00:17:06.490
The benefit here is that when
a switch inspects the information,

302
00:17:06.490 --> 00:17:11.400
it also does a lookup in the MAC table,
just like a bridge does, right?

303
00:17:11.400 --> 00:17:15.190
And then, let's say that Client1 wants
to send information, I don't know,

304
00:17:15.190 --> 00:17:17.000
to Client4, all right?

305
00:17:17.000 --> 00:17:18.010
So what does the switch do?

306
00:17:19.090 --> 00:17:23.320
Well, the switch is going
to inspect its MAC table.

307
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:26.430
All right, and it's gonna look at
the ethernet frame in this case.

308
00:17:26.430 --> 00:17:29.470
It will look at the ethernet frame,
and what it's gonna look at,

309
00:17:29.470 --> 00:17:32.790
is it's gonna look and say, hmm,
where do I need to send this?

310
00:17:32.790 --> 00:17:34.760
Well, let me find out.

311
00:17:34.760 --> 00:17:38.850
And inside of my MAC table,
it will store the source and

312
00:17:38.850 --> 00:17:42.870
destination MAC addresses through
constant communication with the devices,

313
00:17:42.870 --> 00:17:44.730
the devices that are communicating
with the switch.

314
00:17:44.730 --> 00:17:48.190
And it will build up this
database of MAC addresses.

315
00:17:48.190 --> 00:17:53.270
And, in this case, once it says, okay,
I know where that MAC address is.

316
00:17:53.270 --> 00:17:57.690
It's connected to, let's say,
I don't know, port 10 on the switch.

317
00:17:57.690 --> 00:17:59.250
More importantly,

318
00:17:59.250 --> 00:18:04.810
it knows how to forward the traffic
between those ports out to the right

319
00:18:04.810 --> 00:18:10.120
machine that's connected to that port
with that same MAC address, all right.

320
00:18:10.120 --> 00:18:13.520
Now, one of the great things
also about switches is,

321
00:18:13.520 --> 00:18:17.890
remember we said that in a hub we're
talking about half duplex, right?

322
00:18:17.890 --> 00:18:21.470
Well, in a switch you essentially
get a full duplex communication.

323
00:18:21.470 --> 00:18:26.400
I could send and receive out
the same port, right, because Client

324
00:18:26.400 --> 00:18:31.220
1 can send information, and internally
the switch is doing that forwarding.

325
00:18:31.220 --> 00:18:36.060
At the same time, Client 5 can be
communicating to me back to Client O1.

326
00:18:36.060 --> 00:18:40.700
All right, and essentially, too,
what happens is each one of

327
00:18:40.700 --> 00:18:45.690
these computers now becomes their
own individual collision domain.

328
00:18:45.690 --> 00:18:49.480
We've isolated those collisions
because we don't have two

329
00:18:49.480 --> 00:18:53.730
computers necessarily sending
traffic at the same time.

330
00:18:53.730 --> 00:18:55.740
With one exception.

331
00:18:55.740 --> 00:18:59.000
Broadcast communications,
if it is labeled for

332
00:18:59.000 --> 00:19:02.860
the broadcast MAC address,
that still goes out all ports.

333
00:19:02.860 --> 00:19:06.810
And there is a potential that two machines
could do a broadcast at the same time.

334
00:19:06.810 --> 00:19:13.410
So you could still see some type of
performance hit there, but for the most

335
00:19:13.410 --> 00:19:19.610
part, switches allow you a lot better
performance than the earlier hubs will.

336
00:19:19.610 --> 00:19:22.720
And even more so
than the bridge, likewise.

337
00:19:24.050 --> 00:19:25.010
All right, so

00:19:25.010 --> 00:19:28.560
we're gonna go more into some of the

00:19:28.560 --> 00:19:32.860

And again, the next one, and

I didn't mention the intelligence

This is the middle ground

>> No that's a great question.

00:20:32.790 --> 00:20:36.740
So really, from that standpoint,
it's what decisions are being made.

00:20:36.740 --> 00:20:38.920
And great question, too.

So, that's the switch.

The switch is kinda middle ground.

And if we wanna kinda recap too, with

00:20:45.500 --> 00:20:51.290

Because they know raw bits.

That's the physical layer.

Your switches operate for the most part,

00:21:00.088 --> 00:21:03.910
All right, now the next one

modulator demodulator.

381
00:21:38.630 --> 00:21:42.280
All right, so what is going on here?

382
00:21:42.280 --> 00:21:42.920
All right, well,

383
00:21:42.920 --> 00:21:46.200
you have digital signals, essentially
they're coming from your computer.

384
00:21:46.200 --> 00:21:47.540
And they're going into the modem.

385
00:21:47.540 --> 00:21:50.170
And then you have these
converter chips right,

386
00:21:50.170 --> 00:21:52.545
you have analogs to
digital converter chips.

387
00:21:52.545 --> 00:21:56.610
Digital-analog converter chips and they
run them through modulation schemes that

388
00:21:56.610 --> 00:21:59.680
turns that digital communication
into an analog signal, and

389
00:21:59.680 --> 00:22:03.670
places it on your public switch
telephone network lines, the PSTN lines.

390
00:22:03.670 --> 00:22:08.500
And then, on the other end, that analog
signal comes back off of the wire,

391
00:22:08.500 --> 00:22:12.590
goes into the modem, and
they basically run it through

392
00:22:12.590 --> 00:22:16.730
the analog-to-digital conversion chips,
if you will.

393
00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:20.106
And then it's delivered to the computer,
and the computer processes it.

394
00:22:20.106 --> 00:22:21.921
Yes, we're talking dialup.

395
00:22:21.921 --> 00:22:27.350
Yes, we're talking about a whopping 56K
transmission speed, way back in time.

396
00:22:27.350 --> 00:22:30.130
And like I said,
if you think that we don't use those,

397
00:22:30.130 --> 00:22:33.510
all you have to do is look at
some of the areas, in fact,

398
00:22:33.510 --> 00:22:37.370
at the time of this recording, that have
been affected by things like hurricanes.

399
00:22:37.370 --> 00:22:42.700
When your satellite communications fail,
when things like your,

400
00:22:42.700 --> 00:22:48.500
just regular ethernet-based networks fail,
when they get completely eliminated,

401
00:22:48.500 --> 00:22:55.870
there's so much distribution of the public
switch telephone network lines that,

402
00:22:55.870 --> 00:22:59.036
a lot of times, we're gonna use it in
things like disaster recovery situations.

403
00:22:59.036 --> 00:23:01.870
Where you'll have things like
insurance companies, you'll have

404
00:23:01.870 --> 00:23:05.490
emergency support companies come in and
they'll come in with banks of modems, so

405
00:23:05.490 --> 00:23:11.500
that somebody can maintain or reestablish
even the most basic communications.

406
00:23:11.500 --> 00:23:14.020
As well as things like backups, right?

407
00:23:14.020 --> 00:23:17.130
So don't think that the days of
dial-up are completely gone.

408
00:23:17.130 --> 00:23:20.670
We still see it,
we still see modems in today's networks.

409
00:23:22.170 --> 00:23:24.550
All right, couple more that
we wanna kinda talk about.

410
00:23:24.550 --> 00:23:28.510
We're gonna talk about
what is known really as

411
00:23:28.510 --> 00:23:34.360
a VOIP, a VOIP end point.

412
00:23:34.360 --> 00:23:35.770
What's a VOIP endpoint?

413
00:23:35.770 --> 00:23:36.920
What's VOIP to begin with?

414
00:23:36.920 --> 00:23:38.950
Well, this is Voice Over IP.

415
00:23:38.950 --> 00:23:42.750
And when we talk about a VOIP end point,
a lot of times it's gonna be a VOIP phone.

416
00:23:42.750 --> 00:23:43.530
Doesn't have to be.

417
00:23:43.530 --> 00:23:46.811
It could be a device that has a VoIP
client on it, but let's go ahead and

418
00:23:46.811 --> 00:23:47.825
kinda show you here.

419
00:23:47.825 --> 00:23:49.864
You'll have these VoIP endpoints,

420
00:23:49.864 --> 00:23:53.809
in this case I'm just using things
like the traditional voice over IP,

421
00:23:53.809 --> 00:23:56.782
which is what VoIP stands for,
voice over IP phones.

422
00:23:56.782 --> 00:24:01.210
All right, and they send neither
that H323 communication or

423
00:24:01.210 --> 00:24:04.660
session initiation protocols,
zip if you will.

424
00:24:04.660 --> 00:24:06.360
Sometimes you might even
hear them called zip and

425
00:24:06.360 --> 00:24:10.130
points, if they're using the zip protocol,
but remember voice over IP isn't

426
00:24:10.130 --> 00:24:14.300
just restricted to the session
initiation protocol, all right?

427
00:24:14.300 --> 00:24:15.620
And that's essentially what they are.

428
00:24:15.620 --> 00:24:17.240
You have your VoIP end points.

429
00:24:17.240 --> 00:24:20.240
You have VoIP server, and
it is responsible for

430
00:24:20.240 --> 00:24:24.010
handling the communications and
distributing it to the endpoints.

431
00:24:25.400 --> 00:24:28.820
All right, let's see, a couple other
ones that we wanna end up talking about.

432
00:24:28.820 --> 00:24:32.320
One of the ones I wanna talk about is
something known as media converters.

433
00:24:32.320 --> 00:24:36.690
Now remember media converters,
this is more about interoperability

434
00:24:36.690 --> 00:24:40.040
between two dissimilar
communication types, right?

435
00:24:40.040 --> 00:24:43.480
One of the ones that we have
that's real common are the fact,

436
00:24:43.480 --> 00:24:44.890
like we've talked about in other episodes,

437
00:24:44.890 --> 00:24:48.340
we've mentioned fiber-optic communication
and the two mode types, right?

438
00:24:48.340 --> 00:24:50.080
We have single mode and multi-mode.

439
00:24:50.080 --> 00:24:54.840
Well, if you need to communicate from a
multi-mode to a single mode communication

440
00:24:54.840 --> 00:24:57.700
mechanism, they don't work together,
right?

441
00:24:57.700 --> 00:24:58.970
They don't play nice.

442
00:24:58.970 --> 00:25:02.430
They're completely different
types of communications.

443
00:25:02.430 --> 00:25:05.530
When you talk multi-mode, remember we're
talking about multiple light sources

444
00:25:05.530 --> 00:25:09.750
versus a single mode, which basically
takes a single laser and fires it down

445
00:25:09.750 --> 00:25:15.245
a highly optimized and concentrated core
and can do it up to 40,0000 kilometers.

446
00:25:15.245 --> 00:25:17.174
So they're completely different signals.

447
00:25:17.174 --> 00:25:22.870
And you put a media converter, and
it takes one protocol gateways.

448
00:25:22.870 --> 00:25:26.270
Gateways sometimes are media converters,
and the fact that they take dissimilar

449
00:25:26.270 --> 00:25:29.826
protocols and allow them to communicate
across to each other for interoperability.

450
00:25:29.826 --> 00:25:34.052
And you can put something like a single
mode to multi-mode media converter, so

451
00:25:34.052 --> 00:25:38.370
that you can have those communication
types between dissimilar systems.

452
00:25:38.370 --> 00:25:42.370
You also have things like, for instance,
multi-mode to Ethernet, right?

453
00:25:42.370 --> 00:25:45.441
Internally, our local area
networks most probably

454
00:25:45.441 --> 00:25:48.470
are Ethernet-based communication types.

455
00:25:48.470 --> 00:25:51.330
You can even say single mode
to Ethernet too, right?

456
00:25:51.330 --> 00:25:54.991
Because single mode communications can
be used from your ISP coming from your

457
00:25:54.991 --> 00:25:58.711
internet service provider into your
building through your demarcation point

458
00:25:58.711 --> 00:25:59.853
and they hit Ethernet.

459
00:26:00.870 --> 00:26:02.080
What do we do?

460
00:26:02.080 --> 00:26:03.770
They don't play nice together, right?

461
00:26:03.770 --> 00:26:07.380
So you put the media converter in there
and again it does the conversion for you.

462
00:26:07.380 --> 00:26:12.910
Now, I put coaxial in here, just because
in the earlier days, you might see fiber

463
00:26:12.910 --> 00:26:19.700
optic to the old Ethernet coaxial
implementations, but they are there.

464
00:26:19.700 --> 00:26:21.460
And I think that's pretty much it, right?

465
00:26:21.460 --> 00:26:26.490
So when it boils down to,
one of the popular ones is a,

466
00:26:26.490 --> 00:26:31.580
and I didn't even mention that, copper
media versus a fiber optic light source.

467
00:26:31.580 --> 00:26:37.300
Those don't jive well without anything in
the middle, again, to do the conversion,

468
00:26:37.300 --> 00:26:43.460
so definitely know those conversion, know
a little bit about the media converters.

469
00:26:43.460 --> 00:26:48.470
The last one we have to talk about is
probably one of the smartest network

470
00:26:48.470 --> 00:26:53.510
devices that we have within
our modern networks today, and

471
00:26:53.510 --> 00:26:54.865
that's something known as a router.

472
00:26:54.865 --> 00:26:57.160
Let's go ahead and take a look at that.

473
00:26:57.160 --> 00:26:59.660
And Justin, let me go ahead and
explain why I say,

474
00:26:59.660 --> 00:27:02.910
why the router is probably
the smartest device.

475
00:27:02.910 --> 00:27:08.910
And that's because a router, unlike
a switch, doesn't have to be connected

476
00:27:08.910 --> 00:27:13.440
to the network in order to
get traffic to that network.

477
00:27:13.440 --> 00:27:16.400
All right, and what I mean by
that is a switch is only aware of

478
00:27:16.400 --> 00:27:19.126
the devices that are directly
connected to its ports,

479
00:27:19.126 --> 00:27:22.340
If you're not connected to a portal
on the switch, guess what?

480
00:27:22.340 --> 00:27:24.570
It says, I don't know who you are.

481
00:27:24.570 --> 00:27:28.140
I got a MAC table, and I build up the MAC
table based on the devices that connect to

482
00:27:28.140 --> 00:27:30.410
the ports and communicate with me, right?

483
00:27:30.410 --> 00:27:31.810
Routers are different.

484
00:27:31.810 --> 00:27:35.380
Routers can actually build
databases of networks

485
00:27:35.380 --> 00:27:38.120
that they're not connected to, all right?

486
00:27:38.120 --> 00:27:40.200
So if Justin and
I are both routers, right?

487
00:27:40.200 --> 00:27:41.780
I can communicate with Justin and
say, hey,

488
00:27:41.780 --> 00:27:45.510
Justin, I need to send
traffic to this network.

489
00:27:45.510 --> 00:27:46.490
Do you know where it is?

490
00:27:46.490 --> 00:27:47.720
Cuz I don't know where it is.

491
00:27:47.720 --> 00:27:52.409
And Justin, as router can look in his
routing table and say, you know what,

492
00:27:52.409 --> 00:27:56.790
I don't know exactly where that network
is, but I do have an entry here that tells

493
00:27:56.790 --> 00:28:01.100
me if you send it to me, I can forward it
to the next person in the line that does.

494
00:28:01.100 --> 00:28:06.370
So they can communicate with each other,
and build up these network topologies.

495
00:28:06.370 --> 00:28:09.010
And another thing, too,
is they can connect

496
00:28:09.010 --> 00:28:12.840
you to these networks when they're not
directly connected themselves, right.

497
00:28:12.840 --> 00:28:16.400
So routers are great connectivity devices.

498
00:28:16.400 --> 00:28:18.760
They are the smartest connectivity device.

499
00:28:18.760 --> 00:28:22.590
And again with the communications
between router to router, you could

500
00:28:22.590 --> 00:28:25.840
have something here where you have one
router connected to three networks,

501
00:28:25.840 --> 00:28:28.180
let's say, just theoretically.

502
00:28:28.180 --> 00:28:31.390
And you can have all these other
routers that are communicating and

503
00:28:31.390 --> 00:28:37.791
they could build up what essentially
becomes these large humongous topologies,

504
00:28:37.791 --> 00:28:43.590
and networks that this first router didn't
even know, doesn't even understand.

505
00:28:43.590 --> 00:28:48.030
Cuz all it has to know is that, hey,
back to the analogy of Justin and I.

506
00:28:48.030 --> 00:28:52.940
I talk to Justin, Justin says,
well, I don't exactly know where

507
00:28:52.940 --> 00:28:57.290
that network is way out here, but
you know what, I've talked to this guy.

508
00:28:57.290 --> 00:29:01.210
And this guy said, well, if you send it
to me, I can get it to the next person in

509
00:29:01.210 --> 00:29:06.120
line, and again, finally, it will,
through these communication processes,

510
00:29:06.120 --> 00:29:10.270
they will get that information to
the right endpoint, all right?

511
00:29:10.270 --> 00:29:14.500
To the right network, and then,
by association, to the right endpoint.

512
00:29:14.500 --> 00:29:20.510
Routers are what make up the communication
across the entire Internet.

513
00:29:20.510 --> 00:29:21.170
If it wasn't for

514
00:29:21.170 --> 00:29:26.150
routers, we'd be stuck with local
area communications, in general.

515
00:29:26.150 --> 00:29:27.390
And that would be all that we have.

516
00:29:27.390 --> 00:29:30.840
So understand that the routers
are the smartest devices,

517
00:29:30.840 --> 00:29:34.960
as a recap on your OSI model,
remember they operate at layer three.

518
00:29:34.960 --> 00:29:37.480
They deal with IP addresses.

519
00:29:37.480 --> 00:29:40.738
Now to round this one off, I know Justin's
telling me, he's giving me an eye saying,

520
00:29:40.738 --> 00:29:42.852
it's getting a little close
to the end of this episode.

521
00:29:42.852 --> 00:29:46.637
Let's go ahead and wrap all this up and
put some of these devices in our networks,

522
00:29:46.637 --> 00:29:48.696
so you know where they
would be positioned,

523
00:29:48.696 --> 00:29:51.540
should you have to uninstall and
configure them.

524
00:29:51.540 --> 00:29:53.010
All right.
So I got a little diagram here.

525
00:29:53.010 --> 00:29:55.280
Right?
We've got our endpoints here.

526
00:29:55.280 --> 00:29:55.992
We've got our switches.

527
00:29:55.992 --> 00:30:00.320
Remember, our switches are our
single network, local area networks.

528
00:30:00.320 --> 00:30:04.270
They're only aware of the devices
that are connected to them,

529
00:30:04.270 --> 00:30:09.650
if a computer has to send information
to a computer on another network.

530
00:30:09.650 --> 00:30:13.550
Well, if it's not connected to the switch,
the switch isn't gonna know how to do it.

531
00:30:13.550 --> 00:30:16.170
But guess what,
we can send it to the router.

532
00:30:16.170 --> 00:30:18.340
The router can say, hey, you know what?

533
00:30:18.340 --> 00:30:22.290
I know where that network is, and
I can help you get that information there.

534
00:30:22.290 --> 00:30:25.970
Remember that the firewall typically,
in the network-based firewall,

535
00:30:25.970 --> 00:30:31.080
is going to be screening all traffic
coming in and out of your network.

536
00:30:31.080 --> 00:30:36.320
So we could say, if these networks
are owned by two different people,

537
00:30:36.320 --> 00:30:37.924
let's say, two different companies, right?

538
00:30:37.924 --> 00:30:43.090
I could do something like this, and we
might have a couple of firewalls, right?

539
00:30:43.090 --> 00:30:46.560
So understand that your firewalls
can be strategically placed.

540
00:30:46.560 --> 00:30:50.210
But if this was a heavily routed
environment, where maybe, this,

541
00:30:50.210 --> 00:30:54.170
a single company owned both of
these networks, well, maybe,

542
00:30:54.170 --> 00:30:58.648
outbound to the Internet,
we only have one inbound and one outbound,

543
00:30:58.648 --> 00:31:01.820
and we put our network
firewall right there.

544
00:31:01.820 --> 00:31:05.830
So do keep that in mind that the network
firewall screens all traffic coming in and

545
00:31:05.830 --> 00:31:07.110
leaving your network.

546
00:31:07.110 --> 00:31:10.850
But that kind of gives you an idea of
the placement of these devices within

547
00:31:10.850 --> 00:31:13.750
your modern networks for
your Net Plus exam.

548
00:31:13.750 --> 00:31:15.123
>> Well, Wes, thanks for

549
00:31:15.123 --> 00:31:19.930
definitely seeing how those pieces of
the puzzle come together to provide, well,

550
00:31:19.930 --> 00:31:24.410
incredibly complex, admittedly so,
a lot more complex than I even feared.

551
00:31:24.410 --> 00:31:26.288
But definitely thank you so much and

552
00:31:26.288 --> 00:31:29.800
hopefully you stay tuned as we got
more network plus coming at you.

553
00:31:29.800 --> 00:31:32.290
But for this episode we're
gonna go ahead and wrap it up.

554
00:31:32.290 --> 00:31:35.370
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

555
00:31:35.370 --> 00:31:39.099
>> And I'm Wes Bryan
>> And we'll see you next time.

556
00:31:39.099 --> 00:31:45.029
[MUSIC]

557
00:31:45.029 --> 00:31:49.840
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the different advanced devices inside of modern networks such as  NGFW firewalls, load balancers, multilayer switches, IPSs and IDSs, UTM appliances.....etc.
episodes.title: Advanced Networking Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:03.040
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.040 --> 00:00:07.938
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.938 --> 00:00:10.934
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:10.934 --> 00:00:12.946
>> Hello again.

5
00:00:12.946 --> 00:00:14.546
Thank you for choosing ITPROTV.

6
00:00:14.546 --> 00:00:17.370
Empowering the world
though engaging learning.

7
00:00:17.370 --> 00:00:20.390
I'm your host Zach Memos as
we continue on with CONTI and

8
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:26.020
Net Plus and this episode is
advanced networking devices.

9
00:00:26.020 --> 00:00:27.710
This is not mediocre networking,

10
00:00:27.710 --> 00:00:30.740
this is advanced networking devices,
with Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:31.460
Wes, good to see you.

12
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:32.130
Thanks for joining us.

13
00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:33.440
>> Hey, thanks for having me here Zach.

14
00:00:33.440 --> 00:00:37.320
That's right, we're going to be talking
about a lot of devices here that have

15
00:00:37.320 --> 00:00:40.770
a little bit more functionality than just
the traditional networking devices that

16
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:42.400
we've looked at in other episodes.

17
00:00:42.400 --> 00:00:45.020
What do you say we just go ahead and
we'll dive right in and

18
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:46.285
we'll start with the very first one?

19
00:00:46.285 --> 00:00:47.990
>> Mm-hm.
>> The very first ones that they call out

20
00:00:47.990 --> 00:00:50.680
is what is known as a multilayer switch.

21
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:52.540
Now why would they call
it a multilayer switch?

22
00:00:52.540 --> 00:00:55.400
Are we talking about a switch that really
when it's put together looks like one of

23
00:00:55.400 --> 00:00:57.120
those vanilla wafers?

24
00:00:57.120 --> 00:00:59.830
No, that's not really the layers
that we're talking about.

25
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:02.060
We have to harken back to our OSI model.

26
00:01:02.060 --> 00:01:05.360
Remember the OSI models, that seven
layer model that we talked about?

27
00:01:05.360 --> 00:01:06.840
>> Yep.
>> You know and it different layers,

28
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:10.050
there's different functionalities,
right, different services being provided

29
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:15.030
that help move our data from source
to destination across our networks.

30
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:19.010
Well this is where the multilayer switch
comes in or the term multi layer comes in.

31
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:20.330
Now when we look at switches,

32
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:23.750
we've talked about in other episodes
about how switching functionality right.

33
00:01:23.750 --> 00:01:27.890
The switch receives a frame,
right, in one of it's ports.

34
00:01:27.890 --> 00:01:30.820
It receives an ethernet frame and
then it does a couple things.

35
00:01:30.820 --> 00:01:35.130
One of the first things it does is it
inspects the addressing information,

36
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:35.860
the Mac address.

37
00:01:35.860 --> 00:01:37.230
That six byte address.

38
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:39.790
We talked about on other episodes and
it says, okay,

39
00:01:39.790 --> 00:01:44.470
I see the destination MAC address and
then it references a database, right?

40
00:01:44.470 --> 00:01:46.650
It's database is what's
known as a MAC table, right?

41
00:01:46.650 --> 00:01:50.690
And in that MAC table, if the switch
is already communicated with the device

42
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:55.140
that is That the destination is bound for,
that package is destined for.

43
00:01:55.140 --> 00:01:58.420
Then it will have that
information inside of the switch.

44
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:01.720
If it hasn't, for whatever reason,
talk to that device.

45
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:03.390
Then it'll flood, you know, and

46
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:07.410
it'll send out a broadcast communication
out all of its ports except for that one.

47
00:02:07.410 --> 00:02:10.220
That it received that
communication in on and

48

00:22:39.390 --> 00:22:42.152
just kind of recap the VPN,
Virtual Private Network.

423
00:22:42.152 --> 00:22:47.930
Remember that the VPN technology
allows me to take my client

424
00:22:47.930 --> 00:22:51.960
and a VPN based device,
and what I can do is I can

425
00:22:53.760 --> 00:22:58.510
communicate over a public
network in a private manner.

426
00:22:58.510 --> 00:23:02.664
I could communicate over a public network
in a way that we create a tunnel,

427
00:23:02.664 --> 00:23:05.310
we encapsulate the information,
we also encrypt it.

428
00:23:06.390 --> 00:23:10.606
But you have to understand that when
a device does encrypt tunneling,

429
00:23:10.606 --> 00:23:14.537
an encryption sends that information
over that public network so

430
00:23:14.537 --> 00:23:18.397
that it can't be eavesdropped on
when it hits the other device,

431
00:23:18.397 --> 00:23:22.201
the endpoint, whether if
a client's a little bit different.

432
00:23:22.201 --> 00:23:25.433
Either way,
if you're doing site-to-site VPN,

433
00:23:25.433 --> 00:23:30.287
you've got two site to site routers,
VPN gateway routers, well guess what?

434
00:23:30.287 --> 00:23:35.268
For every one of those communications that
goes through a tunnel is then encapsulated

435
00:23:35.268 --> 00:23:39.556
and decapsulated, encrypted and
unencrypted just for that one tunnel,

436
00:23:39.556 --> 00:23:42.200
there's a lot of that computational power.

437
00:23:43.210 --> 00:23:47.935
Remember, any time you encrypt information
at CPU and you're taking resources,

438
00:23:47.935 --> 00:23:52.392
it takes CPU resources of the network
device that is doing the encapsulation,

439
00:23:52.392 --> 00:23:55.044
decapsulation, encryption, decryption.

440
00:23:55.044 --> 00:23:59.031
It's one of the reasons we use such high
encryption levels and other technologies,

441
00:23:59.031 --> 00:24:02.459
security technologies, because it
increases the computational power

442
00:24:02.459 --> 00:24:04.440
that it takes to break that information.

443
00:24:04.440 --> 00:24:06.829
Well guess what?
Even if nobody's trying to break that

444
00:24:06.829 --> 00:24:10.916
information, we also have computational
power that it takes to encapsulate,

445
00:24:10.916 --> 00:24:13.790
decapsulate, encrypt and decrypt.

446
00:24:13.790 --> 00:24:16.800
So let me show you what
the VPN Concentrator's all about.

00:24:16.800 --> 00:24:18.850
So I've gotta a diagram here.

448
00:24:18.850 --> 00:24:24.980
VPN Concentrator basically allows you
to have a device that can do multiple,

00:24:24.980 --> 00:24:29.620
aggregate, multiple simultaneous
