00:24:29.620 --> 00:24:32.440

00:24:32.440 --> 00:24:36.080
Now depending on the scalability
of the device will dictate what

00:24:36.080 --> 00:24:37.650

00:24:37.650 --> 00:24:42.230
I mean really today, I know there's plenty

00:24:42.230 --> 00:24:44.200

00:24:44.200 --> 00:24:47.235
But a lot of times what you have today or

00:24:51.450 --> 00:24:53.709
I've got, I need a firewall, so

00:24:53.709 --> 00:24:57.333

00:24:57.333 --> 00:24:59.919
it performs additional functionalities.

00:25:00.960 --> 00:25:03.170

00:25:03.170 --> 00:25:04.790
It's a firewall,
it does packet inspection,

00:25:04.790 --> 00:25:08.210

00:25:08.210 --> 00:25:09.730

00:25:09.730 --> 00:25:13.820
I almost said concentration, but
VPN Concentrator functionality, and

00:25:13.820 --> 00:25:18.000
the fact that it can handle

466
00:25:18.000 --> 00:25:20.620
So a lot of times, what you seeing
today is again things like those

467
00:25:20.620 --> 00:25:22.737
next generation firewalls
that we talk about.

468
00:25:22.737 --> 00:25:25.876
Next-generation firewall,
which is in the list as well,

469
00:25:25.876 --> 00:25:30.145
is nothing more than a firewall, that
understands not only the network layer but

470
00:25:30.145 --> 00:25:33.067
all the way up,
more importantly to the application.

471
00:25:33.067 --> 00:25:36.390
You might hear the term,
application layer firewall.

472
00:25:36.390 --> 00:25:37.430
They're smart.

473
00:25:37.430 --> 00:25:41.960
They can peel all the layers of the onion
that we say is the OSI model all

474
00:25:41.960 --> 00:25:45.280
the way back and look down in the data and
say, I know what the data is.

475
00:25:45.280 --> 00:25:50.240
Just because you changed the port
from 80 to 443 and you're trying to

476
00:25:50.240 --> 00:25:55.010
pawn it off to me as encrypted traffic,
I can see those upper layers.

477
00:25:55.010 --> 00:25:57.490
I know that's not encrypted traffic.

478
00:25:57.490 --> 00:26:00.960
I know that's not HTTP or
HTTPS like it's supposed to be.

479
00:26:00.960 --> 00:26:02.360
I know it's HTTP.

480
00:26:02.360 --> 00:26:02.860
Why?

481
00:26:04.400 --> 00:26:08.530
Because it understands
application layer services.

482
00:26:08.530 --> 00:26:12.330
And again, you'll hear the term,
next-generation firewall.

483
00:26:12.330 --> 00:26:15.160
Say it over and over so
you know that it's NGFW.

484
00:26:16.720 --> 00:26:20.450
That's what it means, when you see NGFW,
next-generation firewall.

485
00:26:20.450 --> 00:26:22.380
We're talking about a layer 7 firewall,

486
00:26:22.380 --> 00:26:27.310
an application layer firewall that not
only understands the network layer being

487
00:26:27.310 --> 00:26:32.250
able to do packet inspection,
source and destination IP address.

488
00:26:32.250 --> 00:26:37.078
Also understands things like session layer
information, transport layer information,

489
00:26:37.078 --> 00:26:40.337
understanding TCP,
can see the state of the TCP connection,

490
00:26:40.337 --> 00:26:42.483
can stop things like SYN flood attacks.

491
00:26:42.483 --> 00:26:46.492
But it goes further than that, and goes
all the way up to the application layer

492
00:26:46.492 --> 00:26:48.600
knowing what protocols are being used.

493
00:26:48.600 --> 00:26:53.040
And even potentially the context,
if you will, of the data.

494
00:26:54.370 --> 00:26:58.620
So back to the VPN Concentrator, again
keep in mind that is a way that you can

495
00:26:58.620 --> 00:27:04.140

00:27:04.140 --> 00:27:08.300
in a single device,

Again, because as you start to add more
and more of these VPNs on each other,

00:27:13.240 --> 00:27:16.960
that's a lot of computational power that
a network device has to be performing.

499
00:27:18.170 --> 00:27:22.890
So, if you can get a device that has
a dedicated functionality and can bond, or

00:27:22.890 --> 00:27:24.360
not bond, it's not like bonding, but

501
00:27:24.360 --> 00:27:27.900
can perform multiple
tunnels together like that.

502
00:27:27.900 --> 00:27:31.501
Then you're gonna get a much better
performance out of your VPN communications

503
00:27:31.501 --> 00:27:33.768
rather than watching your
throughput just tank.

504
00:27:33.768 --> 00:27:39.317
Because you do have a throughput that
kind of degrades performance wise

505
00:27:39.317 --> 00:27:45.538
because of the encryption, decryption,
encapsulation and decapsulation.

506
00:27:45.538 --> 00:27:49.262
All right, and
that takes us to another concept, but

507
00:27:49.262 --> 00:27:52.317
I'm looking at that clock Zach,
looks like I talked a lot on this one.

508
00:27:52.317 --> 00:27:53.825
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it does look like we're gonna have

509
00:27:53.825 --> 00:27:55.616
to come in back to a part two.

510
00:27:55.616 --> 00:27:58.566
>> Wow, Advanced Networking Devices,
Part-2 coming your way.

511
00:27:58.566 --> 00:27:59.486
This has been Part-1.

512

Make sure you watch both of them, and

Wes does a wonderful job.

514

And while you're in the course library
there's hundreds of other videos.

They're all designed to
help you go further.

Check those out too.

517

And tell everybody you

They'll be glad you did.

519

Thanks for watching.

520

I'm Zach Memos.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the different advanced devices inside of modern networks such as load balancers, IPSs and IDSs, UTM appliances and more.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.320 --> 00:00:02.800
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.229 --> 00:00:07.585
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.585 --> 00:00:08.347
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.347 --> 00:00:11.615
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.615 --> 00:00:16.035
>> Hello, and thank for choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.035 --> 00:00:20.175
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with CompTIA Net Plus,

7
00:00:20.175 --> 00:00:22.751
Advanced Networking Devices part two.

8
00:00:22.751 --> 00:00:25.285
That means there was a part one,
make sure you see that one too.

9
00:00:25.285 --> 00:00:28.085
Bringing us all the information we
need is the one and only, Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:28.085 --> 00:00:29.015
Wes, good to see you.

11
00:00:29.015 --> 00:00:31.575
>> Hey Zach, thanks for having me back,
as always, great to be here.

12
00:00:31.575 --> 00:00:35.012
That's right, part two, which means
Wes talked way too much in part one.

13
00:00:35.012 --> 00:00:35.830
>> That's right.

14
00:00:35.830 --> 00:00:38.410
So we're coming back with a,
well, the sequel here.

15
00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:42.050
In the first part, we talked about
a couple of the advance devices, right?

16
00:00:42.050 --> 00:00:45.044
We talked about multi-layer switches,
proxy servers, right,

17
00:00:45.044 --> 00:00:47.640
difference between forward and
reverse proxy.

18
00:00:47.640 --> 00:00:52.380
Talked about that wireless local area
network, or wireless LAN controller,

19
00:00:52.380 --> 00:00:56.660
WLC, likewise with the VPN concentrator.

20
00:00:56.660 --> 00:00:58.420
Now the next one that
we're gonna go ahead and

21
00:00:58.420 --> 00:01:02.500
just kinda dive right into is gonna be
what's known as load balancer, all right?

22
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:09.424
Now a load balancer really has to do
with high availability, all right?

23
00:01:09.424 --> 00:01:14.448
High availability, it could be done for
performance, could be done for,

24
00:01:14.448 --> 00:01:19.093
well, I'd say availability,
fault tolerance, and redundancy.

25
00:01:19.093 --> 00:01:22.550
To ensure that one device
doesn't get overwhelmed, right?

26
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:26.730
So let's face it, if you have a series,
a couple of servers,

27
00:01:26.730 --> 00:01:31.733
right, and or maybe bank of servers right,
you got a web farm, right?

28
00:01:31.733 --> 00:01:36.720
You wanna make sure that one server,
within that whole entire group

29
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:40.560
of other servers isn't completely
getting overwhelmed, right?

30
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:44.250
So if you only have a couple servers or
one server, right?

31
00:01:44.250 --> 00:01:47.100
That one server goes offline,
what happens to your website?

32
00:01:48.530 --> 00:01:50.070
It goes down, right?

33
00:01:50.070 --> 00:01:54.066
Load balancing is a great way to ensure
that you get that high availability and

34
00:01:54.066 --> 00:01:58.323
redundancy by making sure that whatever
service is being provided by the device.

35
00:01:58.323 --> 00:02:01.766
It sits behind the load balancer,
all right,

36
00:02:01.766 --> 00:02:06.730
van have that service evenly spread
out across multiple devices.

37
00:02:06.730 --> 00:02:08.790
Let me give you an example
what I mean here.

38
00:02:08.790 --> 00:02:13.714
So I got kind of a just generic diagram
here of your load balancers, right,

39
00:02:13.714 --> 00:02:16.227
and we've got a couple here, right?

40
00:02:16.227 --> 00:02:18.524
We got LB 1, low balancer one and
low balancer two and

41
00:02:18.524 --> 00:02:20.480
we have here is kinda
like a server farm here.

42
00:02:20.480 --> 00:02:22.930
We got a cluster of servers behind it,
right?

43
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:26.130
And these servers might be
serving up web pages, all right.

44
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:30.409
Now one of the things that we want
to ensure is that we get even

45
00:02:30.409 --> 00:02:33.590
distribution of the workload, all right.

46
00:02:33.590 --> 00:02:37.147
Again we could be doing this for
the benefit of performance or

47
00:02:37.147 --> 00:02:41.100
we could be doing this for
the benefit of fault tolerance.

48
00:02:41.100 --> 00:02:44.670
If we're doing this for the performance
than what we're making sure is that let's

49
00:02:44.670 --> 00:02:48.570
say these two servers don't get
all of the web requests right?

50
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:54.010
Because not only from the vantage
point of the end user but

51
00:02:54.010 --> 00:02:56.630
also from the vantage
point of the servers,

52
00:02:56.630 --> 00:03:01.800
we can get performance degrading, right?

53
00:03:01.800 --> 00:03:06.180
So how many of you out there and I'm gonna
be the first one to raise my hand, so

54
00:03:06.180 --> 00:03:09.570
you guys don't have to feel
guilty about it, if this is you.

55
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:14.240
How many of you today, when you go to buy
something maybe out there on the Internet,

56
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:20.200
if it takes a little bit too long you're
moving onto the next product, right?

57
00:03:20.200 --> 00:03:23.252
I've done that before,right, the faster
computers get, the more impatient I get.

58
00:03:23.252 --> 00:03:26.780
All right, I don't want it now,
I wanted it yesterday, all right.

59
00:03:26.780 --> 00:03:31.286
And there are times when that every little
bit of that performance of a web page

60
00:03:31.286 --> 00:03:32.964
coming back and rendering.

61
00:03:32.964 --> 00:03:38.744
And opening up that page and seeing
the results of whatever that search are,

62
00:03:38.744 --> 00:03:43.270
it takes a little bit too,
and I'm gone, right?

63
00:03:43.270 --> 00:03:45.480
In our fast paced society we're gone,

64
00:03:45.480 --> 00:03:48.820
we're gonna go completely
to a different customer.

65
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:51.100
We that's not really too good for
business, right?

66
00:03:51.100 --> 00:03:53.886
So from a performance standpoint,
any user experience.

67
00:03:53.886 --> 00:03:58.687
When I have somebody hit my website I
want them to be able to get to it pretty

68
00:03:58.687 --> 00:04:00.120
darn quick, right?

69
00:04:00.120 --> 00:04:03.980
I want that website to open up and
when they do a search result for

70
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:08.830
whatever it is that they're buying, a game
or something or a gaming console, right.

71
00:04:08.830 --> 00:04:12.820
I want it to open up right away, right,
I want the performance to be good, right.

72
00:04:12.820 --> 00:04:15.430
So if we look back at my diagram here,

73
00:04:15.430 --> 00:04:19.860
I want to make sure that maybe this server
here is getting a little overwhelmed.

74
00:04:19.860 --> 00:04:23.840
Well, if we've got a load balancer, we can
push some of the workload off onto this

75
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:27.390
server, and then maybe push some of
the workload off onto this server.

76
00:04:27.390 --> 00:04:31.230
Or maybe we've got it literally
where it goes sequentially, and

77
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:34.250
it doesn't have to, right,
you can set it up the way you want.

78
00:04:34.250 --> 00:04:39.290
But the great thing is that not
only does it make it better for

79
00:04:39.290 --> 00:04:43.120
the end user, but
it's also transparent to the end user.

80
00:04:43.120 --> 00:04:46.510
I don't want to have to
maintain two websites,

81
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:49.760
that's not the way things are going
to work, right, that's horrible.

82
00:04:49.760 --> 00:04:53.720
So it's transparent to the end user and
you get that performance gain if you will.

83
00:04:55.110 --> 00:04:58.240
But then you can also be doing it for
fault tolerance, all right.

84
00:04:58.240 --> 00:05:03.650
If I have a load balancer, and
let's say this one server gone offline, or

85
00:05:03.650 --> 00:05:07.780
maybe we happen to lose another server,
okay, offline, all right.

86
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:10.670
Well, if I didn't have
the load balancing going on,

87
00:05:10.670 --> 00:05:14.548
right I could have potentially
just lost my site right?

88
00:05:14.548 --> 00:05:18.350
Because if everybody was hitting that one
web server those two web servers right

89
00:05:18.350 --> 00:05:21.090
there and they just went offline,
guess what?

90
00:05:21.090 --> 00:05:23.870
No food for you, no purchase,
no gaming console.

91
00:05:24.890 --> 00:05:25.550
So what we do,

92
00:05:25.550 --> 00:05:30.320
we get the benefit is that we can put
things like our network adapters.

93
00:05:30.320 --> 00:05:34.620
Let me go ahead and kindamove these over
and you can see what's going on here.

94
00:05:34.620 --> 00:05:37.650
We can put these in a performance mode,

95
00:05:37.650 --> 00:05:43.352
where we have what's known
as Active-Active, all right.

96
00:05:43.352 --> 00:05:47.480
So Active-Active says that every
request that comes in, I want it,

97
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:50.345
it's gonna hit each one
of the load balancers.

98
00:05:50.345 --> 00:05:53.700
Then they're gonna work together, and
they're gonna spread the information out

99
00:05:53.700 --> 00:05:57.530
like a multi-tasker across
the whole entire web server farm.

100
00:05:58.670 --> 00:06:00.470
That's for performance.

101
00:06:00.470 --> 00:06:02.260
Now we could change this around right.

102
00:06:02.260 --> 00:06:07.070
We could go from Active-Passive,and
this will be for

103
00:06:07.070 --> 00:06:09.320
things like fault tolerance and
redundancy.

104
00:06:09.320 --> 00:06:12.050
Well we already have the redundancy
because we have two, right?

105
00:06:12.050 --> 00:06:14.199
Just because you have two of something
doesn't mean that you're fault

106
00:06:14.199 --> 00:06:15.260
tolerant, right?

107
00:06:15.260 --> 00:06:18.320
Because if I have two of something,
and one's completely turned off,

108
00:06:18.320 --> 00:06:21.060
yeah I've got redundancy,
I've got two but it's not fault tolerant.

109
00:06:21.060 --> 00:06:22.690
>> So Wes, depending upon the application,

110
00:06:22.690 --> 00:06:24.730
you can have multiples of load balancers,
right?

111
00:06:24.730 --> 00:06:25.940
>> Yes you can, absolutely,

112
00:06:25.940 --> 00:06:29.190
it depends on how much of the workload
you need to distribute right?

113
00:06:29.190 --> 00:06:33.410
And a lot of times it's relevant to how
big is the pipeline coming in, right?

114
00:06:33.410 --> 00:06:37.732
If the pipeline coming in has the
potential to be bigger than the pipeline

115
00:06:37.732 --> 00:06:41.510
that it's going to,
you might have to spread it out, right.

116
00:06:41.510 --> 00:06:47.320
So Active-Passive what this says is we'll
just let this load balancer do the work.

117
00:06:47.320 --> 00:06:50.170
It's gonna and
you see that we got connection,

118
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:54.174
it's got a connection to every
server within the web server farm.

119
00:06:54.174 --> 00:06:59.385
And it'll just spread the information
out to each server where it needs to go.

120
00:06:59.385 --> 00:07:00.660
But if this web,

121
00:07:00.660 --> 00:07:06.690
this basically what happens if this
load balancer goes offline, guess what?

122
00:07:06.690 --> 00:07:11.740
This goes from a passive state,
to an active state, right?

123
00:07:11.740 --> 00:07:13.660
Now we've got fault tolerance.

124
00:07:13.660 --> 00:07:15.810
Like I said,
redundancy means more than one,

125
00:07:15.810 --> 00:07:17.920
that doesn't mean that you're
fault tolerant, right?

126
00:07:17.920 --> 00:07:22.210
If I have two of something and one's
turned off, yeah I've got redundancy, but

127
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:24.080
I certainly don't have fault tolerance.

128
00:07:24.080 --> 00:07:27.300
So, understand that while they
do kinda work hand in hand,

129
00:07:27.300 --> 00:07:29.650
technically they're not
the same exact concept.

130
00:07:29.650 --> 00:07:33.067
Redundancy allows for
fault tolerance,all right.

131
00:07:33.067 --> 00:07:37.510
And then what happens is,
when I bring, if you will, that load

132
00:07:37.510 --> 00:07:43.320
balancer back online this might go from
an active state back to a passive state.

133
00:07:43.320 --> 00:07:45.170
All right, and we'll shut it back down.

134
00:07:45.170 --> 00:07:48.608
Or maybe this does stay active, right and

135
00:07:48.608 --> 00:07:54.024
it changes this one to passive,
right, so we flip flopped them.

136
00:07:54.024 --> 00:07:57.631
So one's back online, it's ready to go,
but the one that took over,

137
00:07:57.631 --> 00:07:59.173
we don't wanna mess with it.

138
00:07:59.173 --> 00:08:02.880
We don't want to change things up and
stuff, so we'll just let it keep running.

139
00:08:02.880 --> 00:08:06.523
All right, and that's the great
thing about load balancers,

140
00:08:06.523 --> 00:08:09.210
being able to control
the flow of the data too.

141
00:08:09.210 --> 00:08:15.113
Right, because one of the great things
is if you're hitting a load balancer,

142
00:08:15.113 --> 00:08:18.790
right, you're still
providing the services.

143
00:08:18.790 --> 00:08:23.030
But what's behind the load
balancer is transparent.

144
00:08:24.440 --> 00:08:26.500
You can't see, you don't even know
it's there, that it's masked,

145
00:08:26.500 --> 00:08:28.220
I guess you could say.

146
00:08:28.220 --> 00:08:31.210
So there are a lot of benefits,
like I said, redundancy, fault tolerance,

147
00:08:31.210 --> 00:08:31.790
performance.

148
00:08:31.790 --> 00:08:34.090
Being able to and
when you talk about a load balance or

149
00:08:34.090 --> 00:08:38.370
it performs load balancing in the very
basics, taken any jargon out of it.

150
00:08:38.370 --> 00:08:40.890
I have a service that we're providing and

151
00:08:40.890 --> 00:08:46.060
what we need to do is evenly distribute
that service across multiple devices.

152
00:08:46.060 --> 00:08:49.555
We load balance, right,
great technology, great thing to have.

153
00:08:49.555 --> 00:08:50.570
>> Mm-hm.

154
00:08:50.570 --> 00:08:54.850
>> Now the next thing that we have is
what is known as a RADIUS or AAA server.

155
00:08:54.850 --> 00:08:58.150
All right, now when we talk about RADIUS,
let's mention the term RADIUS.

156
00:08:58.150 --> 00:09:02.250
Alright well, actually, I'm gonna go
ahead and talk about AAA first, right?

157
00:09:02.250 --> 00:09:08.054
We talk about authorization,
authentication and auditing, right?

158
00:09:08.054 --> 00:09:12.960
So basically, I did it a little backwards
here, right, let's try that again.

159
00:09:12.960 --> 00:09:16.510
Authentication, authorization and
accounting, right?

160
00:09:16.510 --> 00:09:20.780
The ability to prove who you say you are,
right?

161
00:09:20.780 --> 00:09:24.725
So for instance this morning, right, we
had a little authentication challenge that

162
00:09:24.725 --> 00:09:27.211
was going on to Zach, and
he didn't even realize it.

163
00:09:27.211 --> 00:09:30.490
Well, he knows it, but
maybe not in this context.

164
00:09:30.490 --> 00:09:32.060
He was challenged this morning.

165
00:09:32.060 --> 00:09:34.830
I'm Zach, I'm a host here at ITProTV,
and I should be here.

166
00:09:34.830 --> 00:09:38.816
Our front door said prove it.

167
00:09:38.816 --> 00:09:39.872
So what did he do?

168
00:09:39.872 --> 00:09:41.800
Right, what did you do
to get in that door?

169
00:09:41.800 --> 00:09:44.365
>> I had a smoke bomb, and I no, [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

170
00:09:44.365 --> 00:09:46.570
>> I used my magnetic card.

171
00:09:46.570 --> 00:09:48.203
>> Don't tell them about the explosives.

172
00:09:48.203 --> 00:09:50.238
That's right,
you've got your key card, right.

173
00:09:50.238 --> 00:09:51.741
>> Key card.
>> So essentially what's happening is

174
00:09:51.741 --> 00:09:52.910
the door is challenging it.

175
00:09:52.910 --> 00:09:56.362
And saying, and it's funny,
I didn't say challenging something, right?

176
00:09:56.362 --> 00:09:58.292
>> [LAUGH]
>> You might have said it that way, but

177
00:09:58.292 --> 00:09:59.580
it challenged him, right?

178
00:09:59.580 --> 00:10:00.530
Because it's a locked door.

179
00:10:01.560 --> 00:10:03.590
He supposed to be here, all right?

180
00:10:03.590 --> 00:10:07.840
That locked door says prove it,
well security system that we have.

181
00:10:07.840 --> 00:10:10.580
He says, here's my authentication.

182
00:10:10.580 --> 00:10:14.373
[SOUND] He touches it to the door,
he's allowed in here.

183
00:10:14.373 --> 00:10:18.385
Now let's talk about, we saw
authentication, how about authorization,

184
00:10:18.385 --> 00:10:19.920
all right?

185
00:10:19.920 --> 00:10:23.860
Now with us as the host and
the subject matter experts, it's maybe not

186
00:10:23.860 --> 00:10:28.440
a good example because we have access
to a pretty wide range if things.

187
00:10:28.440 --> 00:10:29.780
I'll give you an example here.

188
00:10:29.780 --> 00:10:32.570
It will be a good example, I promise.

189
00:10:32.570 --> 00:10:33.230
By the time, I get
>> [LAUGH]

190
00:10:33.230 --> 00:10:34.607
>> Done with it, all right.

191
00:10:34.607 --> 00:10:36.310
We've got multiple businesses here.

192
00:10:36.310 --> 00:10:36.950
Not just ITProTV-
>> Yup.

193
00:10:36.950 --> 00:10:39.575
>> And that's where I thought,
this might be a-

194
00:10:39.575 --> 00:10:40.340
>> It's true.

195
00:10:40.340 --> 00:10:41.520
>> Good example, right?

196
00:10:41.520 --> 00:10:44.240
So we've got more than one
business that actually is under

197
00:10:44.240 --> 00:10:47.110
the umbrella building that we
have here at ITProTV, right?

198
00:10:47.110 --> 00:10:51.583
We've got a great media place that's back
there, got a development academy, just

199
00:10:51.583 --> 00:10:55.128
absolutely amazing other businesses here-
>> Even we're at.

200
00:10:55.128 --> 00:10:58.961

we were talking about,

When we say Unified Threat Management.

That is not, and let me try,

But you see the term a lot, and

00:25:20.890 --> 00:25:22.785
It just means Unified Security Management.

455
00:25:22.785 --> 00:25:23.430
>> Mm-hm.

>> It's the same concept.

We want you to just blow

And you start typing in UTM,

They're the same thing,

463
00:25:46.900 --> 00:25:48.320
Unified Threat Management.

464
00:25:48.320 --> 00:25:49.490
Unified Security Management.

00:25:49.490 --> 00:25:53.840
The ability that I could get

Well imagine all of the little security

00:26:32.580 --> 00:26:34.410
Little bit simplified administration,

So it's a great thing, right?

It's a good thing to have.

Last but not least,

And I don't have any diagram for

Just like the next generation firewall,

And a content filter can be a hardware

00:26:59.010 --> 00:27:04.090
a content filter allows

491
00:27:04.090 --> 00:27:05.452

492

>> Wow.
[LAUGH] What it allows you to is,

Think about content.

Now, there are obvious things we know

especially when you're surfing the web,

You guys know the risque stuff,

Has a few x's in the term, all right?

But there are other things

Maybe social media,

maybe your company doesn't want YouTube

504

You filter that content out.

505

Drop it.

506
00:27:42.530 --> 00:27:43.900
Right?
Netflix.

507

Netflix is one of the reasons,
I don't know,

that maybe a little of opinionated there,

>> [LAUGH]
>> But all these media streaming

companies out there.

Now we need neutrality because there's
75% of all the traffic in the world is

513

Wouldn't it be nice to save that content

00:28:01.740 --> 00:28:04.450
I don't even want it on my network.

515

I don't want 75% of the bandwidth,
that I'm having to pay somebody else so

that my business functions,
being utilized for YouTube.

And again,
not a dig on YouTube by any means.

>> Please don't think that.

519

I love my Netflix, I fall asleep

520
00:28:19.240 --> 00:28:20.650
All right?

521

But the point is,
here's other things, right, gambling.

522
00:28:24.240 --> 00:28:27.740
I don't care if you gamble,

But in some states, and

working in the news industry,

525

So now not only does it become

because people shouldn't be

00:28:50.595 --> 00:28:53.445
So we don't allow you
to get to that content.

531

Content filtering.

And you can do it in a lot of ways.

You can do it things on ratings,
you can do it things on, like for

instance, URL filtering allows
you to do content filtering.

535
00:29:03.800 --> 00:29:07.290
And I can do it on keywords, I can say
these keywords are not allowed to be

searched for, you can't have information
that's coming into our network that way.

537
00:29:11.080 --> 00:29:14.360
So content filtering is also another one,
content filter.

538

All right?
You could put it on your web server,

your proxy servers are a good place.

00:29:17.760 --> 00:29:21.417
You talked about, when we were
mentioning proxies, Zach, you mentioned-

541

>> [CROSSTALK]

542
00:29:22.261 --> 00:29:23.171
>> Access, right?

543
00:29:23.171 --> 00:29:27.951
Well I can say, not only can't this
series of computers connect outbound to

00:29:27.951 --> 00:29:30.579
the Internet, but these three that can?

545
00:29:30.579 --> 00:29:32.477
They're not gonna see
that information come in,

because the moment it hits

547
00:29:35.360 --> 00:29:39.090
It's a great way to get the control of the

548
00:29:39.090 --> 00:29:42.160
when it's you that owns the network and

the stuff that's on that network.

As well as, helping to increase

All right?

And there's your business sense for

But I will tell you,
know some of these devices,

be able to explain in your own mind,

If you can do that, you're going to

Advanced networking devices part two.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.652
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.652 --> 00:00:11.947
[SOUND]
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:11.947 --> 00:00:13.086
>> Hello and thank you for

4
00:00:13.086 --> 00:00:16.690
choosing ITPRO.TV empowering
the world through engaging learning.

5
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:19.881
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with CompTIA Net+,

6
00:00:19.881 --> 00:00:21.687
>> This is going to be virtualization and

7
00:00:21.687 --> 00:00:25.243
network storage, and we've asked our
IT expert and all around great guy,

8
00:00:25.243 --> 00:00:26.895
Wes Bryan to help us out with that.

9
00:00:26.895 --> 00:00:27.801
Wes, good to see you.

10

>> Exact.

11
00:00:28.341 --> 00:00:29.201
Thanks for having me here.

12
00:00:29.201 --> 00:00:29.741
That's right.

13
00:00:29.741 --> 00:00:32.580
We are looking at some pretty
interesting concepts and

14
00:00:32.580 --> 00:00:34.181
pretty popular concepts for the most part.

15
00:00:34.181 --> 00:00:36.950
We're going to be looking at,
well, virtualization technologies.

16
00:00:36.950 --> 00:00:40.600
And it's interesting because
here at network plus, we don't

17
00:00:40.600 --> 00:00:45.210
talk a lot about some of the other
portions of the virtualization technology.

18
00:00:45.210 --> 00:00:47.000
So we're gonna kind of touch on both.

19
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:50.111
We'll definitely talk about
things like virtual machines.

20
00:00:50.111 --> 00:00:54.200
We'll talk about things like host and
guest operating systems.

21
00:00:54.200 --> 00:00:58.030
Then, we're gonna get in to some of
the vitalize networking components that we

22
00:00:58.030 --> 00:01:01.610
need to be aware of since
it is a network plus exam.

23
00:01:01.610 --> 00:01:04.480
And we're also gonna look at different
components within that work storage.

24
00:01:04.480 --> 00:01:06.410
So let's go ahead and let's dive right in.

25
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:10.430
And we're gonna talk about some of
the virtual networking components.

26
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:13.330
And what I wanna talk about, with the
slide that we got here, the, the little

27
00:01:13.330 --> 00:01:17.180
diagram we got here, I want us to know and
understand what virtualization is.

28
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:20.660
See without virtualization,
you know we have these abstract layers.

29
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:21.820
Right, when it comes to computing.

30
00:01:21.820 --> 00:01:22.810
We've got our hardware.

31
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:25.123
Right?
And just above our hardware.

32
00:01:25.123 --> 00:01:29.122
Well, let's talk about our hardware,
we've got our computational resources.

33
00:01:29.122 --> 00:01:30.890
We've got things like our CPU, right.

34
00:01:30.890 --> 00:01:31.571
We have our memory.

35
00:01:31.571 --> 00:01:32.542
We have our storage.

36
00:01:32.542 --> 00:01:35.330
We have our networking communications,
right.

37
00:01:35.330 --> 00:01:38.970
And then traditionally, without any
kind of of virtualization technology,

38
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:42.650
if we look we have an operating system
that's installed on our hardware, right.

39
00:01:42.650 --> 00:01:45.880
Right, and then above that,
the next layer is gonna be,

40
00:01:45.880 --> 00:01:49.240
well, not necessarily like the OSI
model when I say application layer.

41
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:52.450
But that's gonna be the software that
runs within the operating system.

42
00:01:52.450 --> 00:01:53.650
Now, that's all fine and good.

43
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:56.700
But one of the things I want you
to understand is that when we

44
00:01:56.700 --> 00:01:58.010
have something like this, right?

45
00:01:58.010 --> 00:02:03.016
When we have our operating system running
on our hardware, but one thing to keep

46
00:02:03.016 --> 00:02:07.741
in mind is that if we have a little
lot of computational resources, right?

47
00:02:07.741 --> 00:02:10.911
We have a very,
very strong multi-core process.

48
00:02:10.911 --> 00:02:13.721
We've got a lot of RAM at 64 gigs of RAM.

49
00:02:13.721 --> 00:02:19.141
We've got just terabytes of storage and
we've got a pretty good network adapter.

50
00:02:19.141 --> 00:02:23.605
What we've got is a single operating
system that is utilizing all of these

51
00:02:23.605 --> 00:02:28.429
resources and some of those resources
might just get pushed by the wayside, and

52
00:02:28.429 --> 00:02:34.280
not fully or adequately used, efficiently
used by that single operating system.

53
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:37.210
Or the applications that are running
within the operating system.

54
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:40.420
We might have some wasted resources.

55
00:02:40.420 --> 00:02:45.114
Wouldn't it be nice if we could find
a way that we could more efficiently

56
00:02:45.114 --> 00:02:49.969
allocate resources not just to a single
operating system that's running

57
00:02:49.969 --> 00:02:53.960
on a physical machine or
not just to a handful of applications

58
00:02:53.960 --> 00:02:58.372
that's running in a single operating
system on a single machine?

59
00:02:58.372 --> 00:03:02.078
Would it be nicer if we take those
resources and we could have more

60
00:03:02.078 --> 00:03:06.818
than one operating system running side by
side in its own isolated environment and

61
00:03:06.818 --> 00:03:10.387
we can allocate a portion of the CPU,
a portion of the memory,

62
00:03:10.387 --> 00:03:14.670
a portion of the storage and a portion
of the networking communications?

63
00:03:14.670 --> 00:03:16.910
Just that single operating system and

64
00:03:16.910 --> 00:03:21.670
all of those other resources that don't
really efficiently get used, right?

65
00:03:21.670 --> 00:03:24.150
They're not used the way they could be.

66
00:03:24.150 --> 00:03:25.770
Now, they don't get wasted.

67
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:28.560
They don't just put in the side,
put in the closet close closet door.

68
00:03:28.560 --> 00:03:29.500
We can't use them anymore.

69
00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:30.180
But now,

70
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:36.110
we can do is we can show another operating
system on the same physical machine.

71
00:03:36.110 --> 00:03:38.790
And then we can take
that operating system,

72
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:40.490
that second operating system if you will.

73
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:44.734
And we can now locate some of those
unused resources that CPU to that second

74
00:03:44.734 --> 00:03:49.412
operating system a little bit more of its
memory to the second operating system.

75
00:03:49.412 --> 00:03:52.540
And then the storage right a hard
drive space whether it's a hard disk

76
00:03:52.540 --> 00:03:53.930
driver solid state storage and

77
00:03:53.930 --> 00:03:57.470
again that networking communication's
probably mentioned that twice right?

78
00:03:57.470 --> 00:04:00.020
So this is really about taking
those four horsemen right?

79
00:04:00.020 --> 00:04:04.089
I call him in the computing architecture,
right?

80
00:04:04.089 --> 00:04:06.420
And dividing them up a little bit better.

81
00:04:06.420 --> 00:04:10.097
Now, that's what virtualization
technology allows me to do,

82
00:04:10.097 --> 00:04:14.410
an what we don't see here is proper
utilization of our resources.

83
00:04:14.410 --> 00:04:16.070
Well, how do we do virtualization?

84
00:04:16.070 --> 00:04:19.542
Well, we do virtualization through
something known as hypervisor.

85
00:04:19.542 --> 00:04:25.690
All right and a hypervisor will do
is it will add another layer here.

86
00:04:25.690 --> 00:04:27.320
Well, it depends on
where the hypervisor is.

87
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:30.340
We're going to talk about a couple
different types of hypervisors.

88
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:34.910
But the goal here is to add another layer
so that we can install multiple different

89
00:04:34.910 --> 00:04:38.630
operating systems on it on a single

it's running in the virtual machine and

538
00:29:13.934 --> 00:29:16.234
it's only screening the information
that's coming to and

539
00:29:16.234 --> 00:29:19.495
from the virtual network adapter
that it is running inside of.

540
00:29:19.495 --> 00:29:22.655
All right, so those are some of the
components that you need to be aware of

541
00:29:22.655 --> 00:29:25.270
when it comes to virtual networking.

542
00:29:25.270 --> 00:29:28.680
But we've got more to go,
we don't have enough time.

543
00:29:28.680 --> 00:29:29.840
>> Great job as usual, Wes.

544
00:29:29.840 --> 00:29:32.920
In fact, I didn't say a word because
I was absolutely mesmerized by what

545
00:29:32.920 --> 00:29:33.740
you were saying.

546
00:29:33.740 --> 00:29:37.250
Virtualization in network storage part two
coming your way, this has been part one.

547
00:29:37.250 --> 00:29:39.845
Make sure that you watch everything
in the CompTIA net+ series,

548
00:29:39.845 --> 00:29:40.855
Wes does a wonderful job.

549
00:29:40.855 --> 00:29:42.495
And while you're in the course library,

550
00:29:42.495 --> 00:29:45.945
hundreds of videos all designed
to you help you go further.

551
00:29:45.945 --> 00:29:49.115
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be very glad you did.

552
00:29:49.115 --> 00:29:50.435
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

553
00:29:50.435 --> 00:29:51.195
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

554
00:29:51.195 --> 00:29:52.081
>> And we will see you soon.

555
00:29:53.706 --> 00:29:59.690
[MUSIC]

556
00:29:59.690 --> 00:30:02.799
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes dive into virutalization technologies like virtual routers, NAS and SANs devices as well as connection types associated with them.
episodes.title: Virtualization and Network Storage Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.066 --> 00:00:02.520
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.520 --> 00:00:08.281
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.281 --> 00:00:11.889
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.889 --> 00:00:14.186
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITPro.TV,

5
00:00:14.186 --> 00:00:16.430
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.430 --> 00:00:20.810
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on with CompTIA Net+ Virtualization and

7
00:00:20.810 --> 00:00:21.980
Network Storage Part 2.

8
00:00:21.980 --> 00:00:24.089
There was a Part 1,
hopefully you saw that.

9
00:00:24.089 --> 00:00:27.204
And the one and only IT expert Wes Bryan
brought us that information, and

10
00:00:27.204 --> 00:00:30.130
he's gonna give us even more
information right now, aren't you?

11
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:31.990
>> Absolutely Zach,
thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:31.990 --> 00:00:35.166
That's right we talked about, well, all
about virtualization in the first part.

13
00:00:35.166 --> 00:00:38.928
And, well, we probably could have
just named that one virtualization,

14
00:00:38.928 --> 00:00:41.840
cuz I didn't get to the network
storage side of things and

15
00:00:41.840 --> 00:00:44.040
that is what we're gonna talk about here.

16
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:48.486
Now Zach, you'd asked me before we started
this episode, hey, a little recap?

17
00:00:48.486 --> 00:00:51.938
And you know what I said, no, we don't
need a recap, but now I'm gonna do

18
00:00:51.938 --> 00:00:55.361
a double reversal on you, I'm gonna
keep this poor guy wondering here.

19
00:00:55.361 --> 00:00:57.351
But we'll go ahead and
just do a little recap here,

20
00:00:57.351 --> 00:01:00.150
remember we looked at some of
the virtualized networking components.

21
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:03.318
And even kinda set the stage for why we
would use those networking components,

22
00:01:03.318 --> 00:01:05.199
talking about things
like virtual machines.

23
00:01:05.199 --> 00:01:09.903
We talked about virtual machines,
hypervisors, virtual switches, routers,

24
00:01:09.903 --> 00:01:11.890
network adapters and firewalls.

25
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:16.257
So if those are a little foreign to you,
go back like Zach said, watch that Part 1.

26
00:01:16.257 --> 00:01:18.809
And then come back here and
join us in Part 2,

27
00:01:18.809 --> 00:01:22.110
because in this episode it's
all about network storage.

28
00:01:22.110 --> 00:01:23.239
>> And Wes, there's various or

29
00:01:23.239 --> 00:01:25.900
there's different network types,
network storage types?

30
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:26.990
>> Absolutely, there is,

31
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:30.700
now one of the most basic ones that they
call out, and it's always interesting.

32
00:01:30.700 --> 00:01:33.933
You look at the acronyms, and it's almost
like they reverse each other, right?

33
00:01:33.933 --> 00:01:41.310
So we got a NAS or a NAS device, N-A-S,
and then we have a SAN, which is S-A-N.

34
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:44.202
So here we go got,
it looks like the letters are reversed, so

35
00:01:44.202 --> 00:01:46.151
what is the difference between the two?

36
00:01:46.151 --> 00:01:50.827
Well the SAN is actually fairly complex,
so I'm gonna start with the NAS device.

37
00:01:50.827 --> 00:01:55.150
NAS, NOS, I've heard it called everything,
if you listen to R&B and

38
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:59.290
hip-hop, you might say NOS,
and NAS I've heard it as well.

39
00:01:59.290 --> 00:02:04.195
But either way it's N-A-S and it stands
for Network Attached Storage, all right?

40
00:02:04.195 --> 00:02:08.050
Now network attached storage
isn't really too complex,

41
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:13.980
it doesn't necessarily lend itself
to high speed or high performance,

42
00:02:13.980 --> 00:02:17.000
if you will, high performance computing.

43
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:19.865
Essentially it's nothing more
than a glorified file server,

44
00:02:19.865 --> 00:02:21.560
storage server, if you will.

45
00:02:21.560 --> 00:02:25.019
What you have is you have a device that
has multiple drive bays in it, so we can

46
00:02:25.019 --> 00:02:28.772
put our hard drives in there, it could be
solid state drives as well, depending.

47
00:02:28.772 --> 00:02:32.360
And I guess that would increase
the storage performance, right?

48
00:02:32.360 --> 00:02:34.175
But that's essentially all it is,

49
00:02:34.175 --> 00:02:37.682
it's got a very small slim line
operating system that runs on it, and

50
00:02:37.682 --> 00:02:41.688
it coordinates the communication,
typically a high speed network adapter.

51
00:02:41.688 --> 00:02:46.531
And that's really all it does, it's just
another device that sits like any other

52
00:02:46.531 --> 00:02:49.070
TCP/IP based node on your network.

53
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:54.250
And you can access the shared storage
medium over the network, right?

54
00:02:54.250 --> 00:02:58.100
That's a network attached storage device,
all right?

55
00:02:58.100 --> 00:03:01.812
When you purchase one of these, you can
purchase them for a few hundred dollars.

56
00:03:01.812 --> 00:03:04.910
They don't really cost all that much.

57
00:03:04.910 --> 00:03:10.210
Now they can, just like anything that you
buy, it can get very, very expensive.

58
00:03:10.210 --> 00:03:14.343
It can be relatively cheap depending
on how much money you wanna spend.

59
00:03:14.343 --> 00:03:18.349
In fact, let's go ahead, and again, I've
stole Zach's credit card one more time.

60
00:03:18.349 --> 00:03:19.739
We're gonna go out here to Newegg here.

61
00:03:19.739 --> 00:03:21.208
>> Wait a minute, you did?

62
00:03:21.208 --> 00:03:24.704
>> We're gonna go out to Newegg,
and we're gonna just go ahead and

63
00:03:24.704 --> 00:03:25.880
put NAS right there.

64
00:03:25.880 --> 00:03:30.353
So desktop NAS, there's also rack mounts,
that means if you're in the server

65
00:03:30.353 --> 00:03:33.374
closets, but
the concept is still the same, right?

66
00:03:33.374 --> 00:03:34.280
What do we have?

67
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:36.470
We've got a storage component,
and here's one, QNAP.

68
00:03:36.470 --> 00:03:39.790
In fact, we've got QNAPs and
we've had QNAPs on our own networks here.

69
00:03:39.790 --> 00:03:42.475
But I want you to kinda see
that if we look here, well,

70
00:03:42.475 --> 00:03:43.926
look at what we got, right?

71
00:03:43.926 --> 00:03:46.440
We've got some drive bays, right?

72
00:03:46.440 --> 00:03:49.403
And I like these, they've got the keys to
lock them down and kinda keep them secure,

73
00:03:49.403 --> 00:03:51.120
but you have a series of drive bays.

74
00:03:51.120 --> 00:03:55.998
You fill it up with your hard drives and
whatever the capacity might be.

75
00:03:55.998 --> 00:03:59.540
At $900 dollars, so
this one's fairly expensive.

76
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:02.299
And you can see that it's got
some small components in it.

77
00:04:02.299 --> 00:04:05.940
It's got a dual core processor,
4-Bay, it's an Intel i3.

78
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:09.100
So not bad,
it does 4000K video playback, right?

79
00:04:09.100 --> 00:04:12.132
It's got some memory in it,
nothing really crazy.

80
00:04:12.132 --> 00:04:15.079
This one's actually a little bit
better because, if you'll notice,

81
00:04:15.079 --> 00:04:16.909
this actually supports a 10 gig network.

82
00:04:16.909 --> 00:04:19.761
So I say it's not really high speed,
I guess I put my foot in my mouth on that

83
00:04:19.761 --> 00:04:21.360
one, because-
>> That's pretty good.

84
00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:23.262
>> Yeah, absolutely Zach.

85
00:04:23.262 --> 00:04:26.042
So they're definitely coming
up in the performance, right?

86
00:04:26.042 --> 00:04:30.867
However, the next one that w're gonna talk
about is something known as a storage area

87
00:04:30.867 --> 00:04:31.680
network.

88
00:04:31.680 --> 00:04:33.808
And that's separate than what we see here,
all right?

89
00:04:33.808 --> 00:04:37.669
When we get into a storage area network,
we're talking about

90
00:04:37.669 --> 00:04:42.220
a component that you use and the drives
can be located all over the place.

91
00:04:42.220 --> 00:04:46.070
In fact, let me go ahead and
get away from spending Zach's money.

92
00:04:46.070 --> 00:04:50.500
Kinda talk about the components
that you see inside of a SAN.

93
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:55.126
A SAN, again, is a drive array,
it's the same kind of drive array, right?

94
00:04:55.126 --> 00:04:59.158
But typically when you connect to it,
you don't necessarily connect to it.

95
00:04:59.158 --> 00:05:01.875
There's exceptions,
we're gonna talk about connections,

96
00:05:01.875 --> 00:05:03.576
we're not out of the woods on that one.

97
00:05:03.576 --> 00:05:06.980
But you typically don't connect to
it over things like a traditional

98
00:05:06.980 --> 00:05:10.030
IP based network, or
even over traditional ethernet.

99
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:12.846
There's exceptions to the rules, I know
some of you out there are probably saying,

100
00:05:12.846 --> 00:05:14.407
well, wait a second,
I know some protocols.

101
00:05:14.407 --> 00:05:17.209
We'll get back to those,
all right, and why is that?

102
00:05:17.209 --> 00:05:19.822
Well, because if you're
using a SAN device,

103
00:05:19.822 --> 00:05:24.648
you typically are gonna spend on a cheap
scale 70, $80,000 for a cheap one,

104
00:05:24.648 --> 00:05:29.120
$50,000 maybe,
maybe if it get's a little cheaper, right?

105
00:05:29.120 --> 00:05:30.790
And you could spend hundreds
of thousands of dollars.

106
00:05:30.790 --> 00:05:31.990
>> Let's go back to the NAS [LAUGH].

107
00:05:31.990 --> 00:05:33.090
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

108
00:05:33.090 --> 00:05:35.338
And so we don't wanna spend Zach's money.

109
00:05:35.338 --> 00:05:37.169
Zach's like, no man,
I'm taking my credit card back.

110
00:05:37.169 --> 00:05:39.170
But these are very expensive right?

111
00:05:39.170 --> 00:05:42.500
But the other thing about a storage are
network is you're typically connecting to

112
00:05:42.500 --> 00:05:45.420
it over high speed fiber
optic communications,

113
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:46.940
something known as fiber channel.

114
00:05:46.940 --> 00:05:48.358
And that's kind of what we've got,

115
00:05:48.358 --> 00:05:50.568
some of the components that
are mentioned here, right?

116
00:05:50.568 --> 00:05:54.515
Fiber channel uses what's known
as a switched fabric, right?

117
00:05:54.515 --> 00:05:57.204
And we talked about fiber
channel in other episodes, but

118
00:05:57.204 --> 00:06:00.689
since we're talking about network storage,
we'll kind of recap that.

119
00:06:00.689 --> 00:06:04.465
And we'll talk a little bit more about
the components that are in fiber channel.

120
00:06:04.465 --> 00:06:07.693
We have what are known as
host bus adapters, and

121
00:06:07.693 --> 00:06:11.175
a host bus adapter is kinda
like a network adapter.

122
00:06:11.175 --> 00:06:13.345
It's essentially like a network adapter or

123
00:06:13.345 --> 00:06:16.430
a network interface controller in
ethernet based networks, right?

124
00:06:16.430 --> 00:06:21.338
The difference is, you're gonna
connect to fiber channel fiber optic

125
00:06:21.338 --> 00:06:24.298
cable to the HBA, or the host bus adapter.

126
00:06:24.298 --> 00:06:27.167
And then it connects through
that fiber optic communication,

127
00:06:27.167 --> 00:06:29.830
to a fiber channel switch,
and these could be redundant.

128
00:06:29.830 --> 00:06:33.264
And a lot of times they are redundant,
cuz we are talking

129
00:06:33.264 --> 00:06:38.176
tens of thousands of dollars in cost for
the fiber cables, the fiber switches.

130
00:06:38.176 --> 00:06:41.233
And usually what you do is you
implement more than one, so

131
00:06:41.233 --> 00:06:45.769
that you have high speed access, you have
redundancy and fault tolerance, right?

132
00:06:45.769 --> 00:06:47.624
In other episodes we talk
about fault tolerance and

133
00:06:47.624 --> 00:06:48.968
redundancy though load balancers.

134
00:06:48.968 --> 00:06:50.680
One goes down,
the other one's still there.

135
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:53.980
Well, you can do the same thing
with the fiber channel switches.

136
00:06:53.980 --> 00:06:58.140
And then they connect,
in turn, into the SAN right?

137
00:06:58.140 --> 00:07:02.215
And again, in large arrays,
usually very, very expensive drives,

138
00:07:02.215 --> 00:07:06.790
high RPM drive, even solid state today,
but very high RPM drives right?

139
00:07:06.790 --> 00:07:11.559
In the NAS, I can put things like SATA
drives in there, and even at 4 terabytes

140
00:07:11.559 --> 00:07:16.709
in just a single drive, you're only
talking about $100, $200 per drive.

141
00:07:16.709 --> 00:07:19.320
These SAS drives, serial attached SCSI,

142
00:07:19.320 --> 00:07:24.505
these type of drives they can be $1,500,
so they're very, very expensive.

143
00:07:24.505 --> 00:07:27.190
They're for very, very fast reads and

144
00:07:27.190 --> 00:07:30.690
write performance over
fiber optic communication.

145
00:07:30.690 --> 00:07:33.219
That's a storage area network, all right?

146
00:07:33.219 --> 00:07:36.017
Now since we're mentioning fiber channel,
right?

147
00:07:36.017 --> 00:07:40.500
That's not the only way you connect
to a storage area network, right?

148
00:07:40.500 --> 00:07:44.400
I said there are exceptions to the rule,
because fiber channel, well,

149
00:07:44.400 --> 00:07:46.590
we'll stick with fiber channel for
a little bit more.

150
00:07:46.590 --> 00:07:49.619
Cuz I wanna talk about some of the
components that you might see on the exam.

151
00:07:49.619 --> 00:07:53.245
I'm not sure if you will, but you might,
so let's be aware of them, right?

152
00:07:53.245 --> 00:07:58.039
In network adapters,
in an ethernet based network, we use what?

153
00:07:58.039 --> 00:08:02.275
We use MAC addresses and then MAC
addresses identify That computer uniquely,

154
00:08:02.275 --> 00:08:06.560
and I know it's the network adapter,
but it's in the computer, right?

155
00:08:06.560 --> 00:08:09.020
Uniquely identify that
node on the network.

156
00:08:09.020 --> 00:08:12.490
Well, HBAs use a little bit
different convention, but

157
00:08:12.490 --> 00:08:13.910
the theory's the same, right.

158
00:08:13.910 --> 00:08:19.430
We're gonna uniquely identify a fibre
channel endpoint within the switch fabric.

159
00:08:19.430 --> 00:08:20.730
And what we do for

160
00:08:20.730 --> 00:08:25.940
that is use what's known as
a World Wide Node Name, right, a WWNN.

161
00:08:25.940 --> 00:08:28.640
This falls under a more
umbrella term they call a WWN.

162
00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:31.770
It's not the next latest and
greatest wrestling organization.

163
00:08:31.770 --> 00:08:33.610
It's World Wide Name, right.

164
00:08:33.610 --> 00:08:35.460
It's a unique identifier.

165
00:08:35.460 --> 00:08:40.070
It's what we uniquely identify devices or
entities within the network.

166
00:08:40.070 --> 00:08:43.710
And under that, one of the ways we do
this in fibre channels specifically,

167
00:08:43.710 --> 00:08:46.110
is with World Wide Node Names, right?

168
00:08:46.110 --> 00:08:49.540
It identifies the end point, all right?

169
00:08:49.540 --> 00:08:51.980
Now, we have to identify the ports, right,

170
00:08:51.980 --> 00:08:56.280
that the end point is
making a connection to.

171
00:08:56.280 --> 00:09:00.408
And that's where something
known as a WWPN comes in.

172
00:09:00.408 --> 00:09:03.950
Guys, world wide is the same,
but now instead of node name,

173
00:09:03.950 --> 00:09:05.465
we're saying port name.

174
00:09:05.465 --> 00:09:10.030
All right, and if I make a connection
via an HBA, I've got a port, and

175
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:14.120
you could actually just say, for instance,
you could have, you could say this is

176
00:09:14.120 --> 00:09:18.345
on both sides, a port number for
the HBA and on the switch itself.

177
00:09:18.345 --> 00:09:21.080
All right, so the World Wide Port Number

178
00:09:21.080 --> 00:09:24.820
uniquely identifies the port that's
associated with that switch.

179
00:09:24.820 --> 00:09:29.470
And you could say each HBA
has its own port number.

180
00:09:29.470 --> 00:09:31.970
Now I will tell you something
that can change here.

181
00:09:31.970 --> 00:09:35.960
And let's go ahead, I'm gonna modify my
slide on the fly, cuz that never fails,

182
00:09:35.960 --> 00:09:36.515
right, Zach?

183
00:09:36.515 --> 00:09:38.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Zach is going, god, here we go.

184
00:09:38.310 --> 00:09:43.000
So let's say that I take this HBA and
we've got a multi-homed,

185
00:09:43.000 --> 00:09:46.520
just like network adapters, right,
we've got a multi-homed end point.

186
00:09:46.520 --> 00:09:49.360
In this case it's a server
attached to the SAN.

187
00:09:49.360 --> 00:09:57.490
Well, guess what, now that I've got two
HBAs I now have two unique WWPNs, right.

188
00:09:57.490 --> 00:10:02.060
HBA1, it has World Wide Port Number
that it's connected to.

189
00:10:02.060 --> 00:10:07.179
HBA2, the second host bus
adapter has WWPN2, right.

190
00:10:07.179 --> 00:10:11.718
And again, you could rightfully just kinda
double these up cuz the connection is from

191
00:10:11.718 --> 00:10:15.230
the host bus adapter to
the port on the switch, right.

192
00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:18.270
But notice what didn't change,
the World Wide Node Name.

193
00:10:18.270 --> 00:10:21.972
The end point is still identified
as an endpoint but I could have,

194
00:10:21.972 --> 00:10:26.772
and sometimes you do, a lot of times with
redundancy I might do something like this.

195
00:10:26.772 --> 00:10:31.438
Where maybe I have a completely
separate switch and for

196
00:10:31.438 --> 00:10:34.989
high availability and fault tolerance,

197
00:10:34.989 --> 00:10:39.872
what we end up having is we
have one HBA that is connected.

198
00:10:39.872 --> 00:10:43.460
Oop, see, like I said, and
this is why you should never-

199
00:10:43.460 --> 00:10:44.078
>> Do it on the fly.

200

>> Do it on the fly, but

no more no less, if you transmit any more,

426
00:23:17.970 --> 00:23:21.460
the device the connectivity
device is gonna drop the frame.

427
00:23:21.460 --> 00:23:23.520
All right well what is ethernet's MTU?

428
00:23:24.700 --> 00:23:26.260
It's 1500 bytes.

429
00:23:26.260 --> 00:23:28.280
Now there are a little padding there.

430
00:23:28.280 --> 00:23:33.080
Most offer like Windows operating system
sets the maximum transmission unit at

431
00:23:33.080 --> 00:23:34.220
1500 bytes.

432
00:23:34.220 --> 00:23:39.026
But a lot of switches might have a little
bit extra for things like the 802.1q or

433
00:23:39.026 --> 00:23:43.766
the VLAN assignment, the VLAN tagging unit
cuz that adds a little bit more data but

434
00:23:43.766 --> 00:23:45.909
you don't have to worry about that.

435
00:23:45.909 --> 00:23:50.640
Know that ethernet maximum transmission
unit is 1500 bytes which means that if all

436
00:23:50.640 --> 00:23:53.427
your storage device or
your connectivity device,

437
00:23:53.427 --> 00:23:57.896
excuse me are set to 1500 bytes, and
a computer through error, corruption,

438
00:23:57.896 --> 00:24:02.495
or virus tries to send something down
that pathway, that's over 1500 bytes.

439
00:24:02.495 --> 00:24:04.838
>> Mm-hm.
>> Switch looks at it, and discards it.

440
00:24:04.838 --> 00:24:05.726
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right?

441
00:24:05.726 --> 00:24:08.261
Is where jumbo frame comes in.

442
00:24:08.261 --> 00:24:13.299
Jumbo frames allows you to grow

443
00:24:13.299 --> 00:24:19.703
the frame size up to 9,000 bytes.

444
00:24:19.703 --> 00:24:22.380
That's why they call it a jumbo frame,
all right.

445
00:24:22.380 --> 00:24:24.016
Now there are some things to keep in mind.

446
00:24:24.016 --> 00:24:26.742
It can perform or, excuse me, I'm sorry,

447
00:24:26.742 --> 00:24:30.146
it can improve your network performance,
all right?

448
00:24:30.146 --> 00:24:32.050
What are you doing?

449
00:24:32.050 --> 00:24:35.001
Putting more data into a frame,
right, more data,

450
00:24:35.001 --> 00:24:38.490
I'm sending more information
in a single frame.

451
00:24:38.490 --> 00:24:41.080
Sometimes you might say data packets,
but it's not packets.

452
00:24:41.080 --> 00:24:45.596
Remember packets,
are the PDU that happens at network,

453
00:24:45.596 --> 00:24:51.415
the protocol data unit that happens
at the layer 3 of the OSI model.

454
00:24:51.415 --> 00:24:54.675
Remember the data link layer,
the PDU or the protocol data unit,

455
00:24:54.675 --> 00:24:56.385
is what's known as a frame.

456
00:24:56.385 --> 00:25:01.260
So this allows you to grow
the frame up to 9,000 bytes but

457
00:25:01.260 --> 00:25:05.560
if your devices arent
configured to support a PDU,

458
00:25:05.560 --> 00:25:08.440
if you will, of 9,000 bytes.

459
00:25:08.440 --> 00:25:11.521
Well, they're gonna inspect it, and
they're gonna say, no, what, 9,000,

460
00:25:11.521 --> 00:25:12.550
what the heck is this stuff?

461
00:25:12.550 --> 00:25:16.450
We're set to 1,500, you know that,
and discards it, right?

462
00:25:16.450 --> 00:25:18.990
So you have to make sure that your
connectivity devices are setup, or

463
00:25:18.990 --> 00:25:20.590
that could be a problem, right?

464
00:25:20.590 --> 00:25:24.050
The good thing about putting
more data into the frame and

465
00:25:24.050 --> 00:25:27.810
where it could improve your performance,
is the fact that the CPU

466
00:25:27.810 --> 00:25:32.600
on the connectivity devices don't have
to process as many frames, right?

467
00:25:32.600 --> 00:25:36.110
Because we use stored forward technology,

468
00:25:36.110 --> 00:25:39.730
that's one of the most common
switching types today.

469
00:25:39.730 --> 00:25:45.280
And store means I receive the entire
frame, I calculate the CS at the end,

470
00:25:45.280 --> 00:25:48.330
the frame checks some sequence,
verifying that the frame is intact and

471
00:25:48.330 --> 00:25:55.620
it hasn't been corrupted in any way and
then I forward it on to the destination.

472
00:25:55.620 --> 00:26:00.480
If we find a corruption, we discard it,
we recall the frame back, right?

473
00:26:00.480 --> 00:26:05.120
It's part of what that data link layer is
doing, flow control and error detection.

474
00:26:06.180 --> 00:26:11.090
Now, if I have to do that on 1,500 bytes,
I'm gonna do a lot more than checking that

475
00:26:11.090 --> 00:26:16.400
frame checksum sequence
on a 9,000 byte frame.

476
00:26:16.400 --> 00:26:20.941
So it means that your CPUs have
less frames to process, all right?

477
00:26:22.570 --> 00:26:25.000
Here is where it comes to a problem.

478
00:26:25.000 --> 00:26:29.700
One of the things about
checking frames more often,

479
00:26:29.700 --> 00:26:32.810
is that you can detect errors quicker,
right?

480
00:26:32.810 --> 00:26:36.282
So, if I think about it,
1,500, 1,500 is 3, right?

481
00:26:36.282 --> 00:26:36.827
>> Mm-hm.

482
00:26:36.827 --> 00:26:37.651
>> So, what is that?

483
00:26:37.651 --> 00:26:43.886
So, two, that would be nine, that would be
three times, I have to check that frame.

484
00:26:43.886 --> 00:26:46.057
Let me make sure I get that,
one, two, three.

485
00:26:46.057 --> 00:26:50.629
Yeah, I'd have to check those
frames like nine times,

486
00:26:50.629 --> 00:26:53.270
my math is probably bad on that.

487
00:26:53.270 --> 00:26:57.330
But I'm having to calculate the frame
checksum sequence more often, all right.

488
00:26:58.410 --> 00:27:02.835
Yes, it puts a burden on the CPU, but
it means that I'm only having to discard

489
00:27:02.835 --> 00:27:07.100
1,500 bytes of data if I do find
a problem with the information.

490
00:27:08.290 --> 00:27:13.170
Yes, in a 9,000 byte jumbo frame,
I have to check and

491
00:27:13.170 --> 00:27:18.970
process less frames, but it means what
happens if the calculation is wrong or

492
00:27:18.970 --> 00:27:21.830
we calculate it and
there's an error in 9,000 bytes?

493
00:27:23.730 --> 00:27:26.600
We have to discard the entire 9000 bytes.

494
00:27:26.600 --> 00:27:31.939
So that means that your packet loss, or
frame loss, ratio rate could increase too.

495
00:27:31.939 --> 00:27:34.200
So that is one thing to keep in mind.

496
00:27:34.200 --> 00:27:36.919
Yes, you have to process less frames,
right, but

497
00:27:36.919 --> 00:27:40.966
it also means you have the potential for
damage to be there so you have to throw

498
00:27:40.966 --> 00:27:44.787
more data away when one of the frames
is discarded and we have to recall.

499
00:27:44.787 --> 00:27:49.171
So while it can have a benefit,
just like anything else in life,

500
00:27:49.171 --> 00:27:55.530
networking in general, is that it also can
potentially have its drawbacks as well.

501
00:27:55.530 --> 00:27:56.950
So do keep that in mind.

502
00:27:56.950 --> 00:27:59.695
And those are little bit about
the storage network technologies,

503
00:27:59.695 --> 00:28:01.910
network storage technologies
that we have to know.

504
00:28:01.910 --> 00:28:04.930
Know some of the specifications here,
know some of the components so

505
00:28:04.930 --> 00:28:08.720
that if they ask you on the Network Plus
exam, not only are you gonna get it right,

506
00:28:08.720 --> 00:28:10.780
but you're gonna knock
it out of the ballpark.

507
00:28:10.780 --> 00:28:13.370
>> Because of Wes, I'm telling you.

508
00:28:13.370 --> 00:28:16.250
Virtualization and Network Storage Part 2,
there is also a part one,

509
00:28:16.250 --> 00:28:18.740
make sure you see those both parts one and
part two.

510
00:28:18.740 --> 00:28:21.435
And by the way, see everything in
the CompTIA Plus series that Wes

511
00:28:21.435 --> 00:28:24.785
has put together for you and
our great course library.

512
00:28:24.785 --> 00:28:26.175
There's hundreds of videos there and

513
00:28:26.175 --> 00:28:29.845
they're all designed to help you
go further, check those out too.

514
00:28:29.845 --> 00:28:32.935
And tell everyone you know about ITProTV,
they'll be very glad you did.

515
00:28:32.935 --> 00:28:34.212
Thanks for watching, I'm Zack Memos.

516
00:28:34.212 --> 00:28:34.723
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

517
00:28:34.723 --> 00:28:36.083
>> And we will see you again very soon.

518
00:28:36.083 --> 00:28:43.328
[MUSIC]

519
00:28:43.328 --> 00:28:46.080
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore the many characteristics of wide area networks and associated technologies. They will look at services types, transmission mediums and termination
episodes.title: WAN Technologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.360 --> 00:00:01.317
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.317 --> 00:00:08.550
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.550 --> 00:00:12.129
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.129 --> 00:00:14.333
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.333 --> 00:00:16.836
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.836 --> 00:00:21.051
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTia Network+.

7
00:00:21.051 --> 00:00:25.339
This episode is When Technologies, and
we've asked Wes Bryan to help us up with

8
00:00:25.339 --> 00:00:27.651
that because he knows
what we need to hear.

9
00:00:27.651 --> 00:00:28.458
Don't you, Wes?

10
00:00:28.458 --> 00:00:29.678
>> Gosh, I hope so, Jack.

11
00:00:29.678 --> 00:00:31.184
Again, thanks for having me here.

12
00:00:31.184 --> 00:00:32.473
>> Thank you.
>> That's right,

13
00:00:32.473 --> 00:00:34.533
we are going to be walking
down that path and

14
00:00:34.533 --> 00:00:37.066
hopefully lead you to your
net plus certification.

15
00:00:37.066 --> 00:00:39.924
And like Zach said,
we're going to be looking at,

16
00:00:39.924 --> 00:00:44.377
well the other side of our networks we've
been focusing on the Lan facing side,

17
00:00:44.377 --> 00:00:46.716
talking about all the LAN technologies.

18
00:00:46.716 --> 00:00:50.772
But what we haven't talked about
is the side of the network that,

19
00:00:50.772 --> 00:00:54.017
unless you work for
a service provider, you work for

20
00:00:54.017 --> 00:00:58.776
ISP, Telco or telecommunications company,
a lot of times you don't see.

21
00:00:58.776 --> 00:01:01.307
But it is going to be important
of the net plus exam, so

22
00:01:01.307 --> 00:01:04.142
we have to understand what some
of these technologies are.

23
00:01:04.142 --> 00:01:06.415
And just like anything else that
we've been talking about or

24
00:01:06.415 --> 00:01:09.224
everything else I should say,
that we've been talking about through this

25
00:01:09.224 --> 00:01:11.697
net plus journey, there's going
to be a lot of specifications.

26
00:01:11.697 --> 00:01:16.039
All right, we're going to start learning
about channelized services, and

27
00:01:16.039 --> 00:01:18.710
when we talk about our
LAN based technologies,

28
00:01:18.710 --> 00:01:22.479
a lot of times we don't talk about
channelized services, right?

29
00:01:22.479 --> 00:01:24.226
We talk about things like
gigabit Ethernet, right?

30
00:01:24.226 --> 00:01:28.384
We talk about 10 gig Ethernet or
in some of the older networks,

31
00:01:28.384 --> 00:01:32.621
which we really don't use much today but
10 meg, 100 megs.

32
00:01:32.621 --> 00:01:36.038
But now we're gonna talk
about on the ISP side,

33
00:01:36.038 --> 00:01:40.398
how they actually divide up
the bandwidth that they have, so

34
00:01:40.398 --> 00:01:45.015
that multiple customers can
utilize the transmission media and

35
00:01:45.015 --> 00:01:48.454
the networks and
technologies that they have.

36
00:01:48.454 --> 00:01:51.214
So, we're going to start
right here by talking

37
00:01:51.214 --> 00:01:55.354
about some of the different service
types that you can see out there when

38
00:01:55.354 --> 00:01:58.738
we talk about the WAN side of
our network communications.

39
00:01:58.738 --> 00:02:03.682
Now, we have to understand that a lot
of the technologies that we're going

40
00:02:03.682 --> 00:02:08.705
to talk about really fall under what
is known as a Digital Signal Hierarchy,

41
00:02:08.705 --> 00:02:11.076
is what it's called, a DS system.

42
00:02:11.076 --> 00:02:16.505
And the Digital Signal Hierarchy, if you
will, is basically just a set of service

43
00:02:16.505 --> 00:02:21.716
levels and according to the different
levels will denote how much bandwidth.

44
00:02:21.716 --> 00:02:25.362
And we have different technologies that
allows us to hit these different service

45
00:02:25.362 --> 00:02:27.567
levels, and
in fact let me show what I mean here.

46
00:02:27.567 --> 00:02:31.235
In fact, we have here on my screen,
we have what's known as,

47
00:02:31.235 --> 00:02:35.204
a lot of times you'll see this
just called digital signal levels.

48
00:02:35.204 --> 00:02:39.669
You might see digital signal transmission
rates but it really falls under this,

49
00:02:39.669 --> 00:02:43.016
here in North America at least,
under what's known as DSH,

50
00:02:43.016 --> 00:02:44.806
the Digital Signal Hierarchy.

51
00:02:44.806 --> 00:02:47.853
And there's a whole bunch of
these levels of services, right?

52
00:02:47.853 --> 00:02:52.608
And they standardize these levels and they
say, hey, if you wanna provide this level,

53
00:02:52.608 --> 00:02:56.607
whatever technology you implement
must adhere to these service levels.

54
00:02:56.607 --> 00:02:59.859
All right, so there are a few
that I want you to be aware of.

55
00:02:59.859 --> 00:03:04.114
And the ones that really are going to
affect your understanding of some of

56
00:03:04.114 --> 00:03:07.601
the other technologies,
as we move into things like ISDN,

57
00:03:07.601 --> 00:03:09.505
that are heavily channelized.

58
00:03:09.505 --> 00:03:11.777
All right, so you are going to know,
have to know.

59
00:03:11.777 --> 00:03:17.021
Now, if we can look at the list here,
there are several out there and

60
00:03:17.021 --> 00:03:20.981
in fact this I need to fix
this here real quick here.

61
00:03:20.981 --> 00:03:24.385
What you end up having here is DS0,

62
00:03:24.385 --> 00:03:29.046
DS0 is the first transmission
rate if you will.

63
00:03:29.046 --> 00:03:31.507
And you're going to notice that channels,

64
00:03:31.507 --> 00:03:34.641
when we talk about broadband
communications, right?

65
00:03:34.641 --> 00:03:36.809
When we talk about
baseband communications,

66
00:03:36.809 --> 00:03:40.321
we talk about one signal goes over
the media at the same, one time, right?

67
00:03:40.321 --> 00:03:44.789
We can get multiple sources that
can use that bandwidth, but

68
00:03:44.789 --> 00:03:48.474
through time divisional multiplexing,
right?

69
00:03:48.474 --> 00:03:49.711
You can talk it this time,

70
00:03:49.711 --> 00:03:52.423
you are the only one using
that baseband communication.

71
00:03:52.423 --> 00:03:55.759
Now somebody else talks, you're
the only one using that communication.

72
00:03:55.759 --> 00:03:58.827
See, when we talk about
broadband communications,

73
00:03:58.827 --> 00:04:03.063
they actually divide the entire
bandwidth into this discrete channels.

74
00:04:03.063 --> 00:04:08.653
And one channel according to the Digital
Signal Hierarchy is equal to 64K,

75
00:04:08.653 --> 00:04:10.634
64 kilobyte per second.

76
00:04:10.634 --> 00:04:13.769
Now, you can see that we also have DS1,
all right.

77
00:04:13.769 --> 00:04:18.678
When we look at DS1 now,
DS1 we want you to understand that

78
00:04:18.678 --> 00:04:22.225
DS1 is 1.544 megabits, all right?

79
00:04:22.225 --> 00:04:26.788
And what that essentially means is
that we're taking 24 of those DS0's,

80
00:04:26.788 --> 00:04:31.294
which is a single channel, right,
and we're aggregating them together.

81
00:04:31.294 --> 00:04:34.631
Or basically we're going to squish
them to the, all together and

82
00:04:34.631 --> 00:04:38.589
if you want that kind of speed you're
going to use all 24 channels, right?

83
00:04:38.589 --> 00:04:40.803
So it's a multiplex communication and

84
00:04:40.803 --> 00:04:44.432
sends more than one signal going
down that transmission media.

85
00:04:44.432 --> 00:04:47.981
Whatever the media is that you use
in order to adhere to this standard,

86
00:04:47.981 --> 00:04:48.593
all right.

87
00:04:48.593 --> 00:04:53.756
So you're going to see that come up again
that one point five or four megabits.

88
00:04:53.756 --> 00:04:59.707
And again, it's just a 24 of these
DS0 channels together, all right.

89
00:04:59.707 --> 00:05:03.644
And then you've got and there's more,
there's some that I didn't put in here,

90
00:05:03.644 --> 00:05:07.695
there's zero, there's one two three four
and I didn't put them in the list because

91
00:05:07.695 --> 00:05:10.662
they're really not applicable
to the Network Plus exam, and

92
00:05:10.662 --> 00:05:12.624
we've got enough to learn, all right.

93
00:05:12.624 --> 00:05:17.356
So let's not put a lot of other stuff in
our minds that we really don't, aren't

94
00:05:17.356 --> 00:05:22.252
gonna help us for the exam, but you'll see
that we also have DS3 here on the list.

95
00:05:22.252 --> 00:05:25.944
Now that's 44.736 megabits and
that's a pretty big number, right?

96
00:05:25.944 --> 00:05:28.276
>> [LAUGH]
>> So when we look at that number,

97
00:05:28.276 --> 00:05:30.206
how do we come up with that number?

98
00:05:30.206 --> 00:05:35.058
Well, if you take 672 of
those DS0 services or

99
00:05:35.058 --> 00:05:39.574
channels, and
you squish them all together.

100
00:05:39.574 --> 00:05:44.136
And we use them as a single pipeline if
you will, multiplex all these signals

101
00:05:44.136 --> 00:05:47.858
together you're gonna to
come up with 44.76 megabits.

102
00:05:47.858 --> 00:05:52.878
All right, so understand that there
is a method to the madness, right?

103
00:05:52.878 --> 00:05:56.733
Understand that this isn't just
a crap shot across the board, right?

104
00:05:56.733 --> 00:06:00.921
And we hope we come up with
a certain number or number,

105
00:06:00.921 --> 00:06:05.205
these numbers are structured
this way because again,

106
00:06:05.205 --> 00:06:09.971
it's always that single channel
rate of 64K, all right.

107
00:06:09.971 --> 00:06:11.626
Now, in North America here,

108
00:06:11.626 --> 00:06:15.202
in order to adhere to these digital
signal standard we have, and

109
00:06:15.202 --> 00:06:20.057
all around the world really, we have what
are known as carrier designations, right?

110
00:06:20.057 --> 00:06:23.107
The carrier designations that we have
inside of North America are called

111
00:06:23.107 --> 00:06:25.213
T-carriers, you might
have heard them before.

112
00:06:25.213 --> 00:06:28.464
Maybe you've heard of the term T1 line,
T2 line, T3 line, right?

113
00:06:28.464 --> 00:06:29.238
>> Mm-hm.

114
00:06:29.238 --> 00:06:33.424
>> Well, these are the physical media, the
copper media, cuz our transmission mediums

115
00:06:33.424 --> 00:06:36.934
that we have are really no different
than what we have in our LAN, right?

116
00:06:36.934 --> 00:06:42.265
We have fiber optic communication,
long distances at high speeds copper,

117
00:06:42.265 --> 00:06:47.098
shorter distances, relatively
slower speeds relative to copper,

118
00:06:47.098 --> 00:06:50.868
and we also have fiber optic
communications as well.

119
00:06:50.868 --> 00:06:54.338
Well, the carrier systems
denote the copper cable and

120
00:06:54.338 --> 00:06:58.940
sometime you can see things like
traditional PSTN lines that are used for

121
00:06:58.940 --> 00:07:01.289
these T-carrier systems, right?

122
00:07:01.289 --> 00:07:03.645
So what is the carrier system going to do?

123
00:07:03.645 --> 00:07:05.878
Well, it's going to be something
known as dedicated bandwidth, right?

124
00:07:05.878 --> 00:07:09.681
When we look at other technologies,
that I'll elaborate a little bit more on,

125
00:07:09.681 --> 00:07:12.026
we look at things like cable broadband,
right?

126
00:07:12.026 --> 00:07:14.544
Maybe you have cable broadband

00:19:21.350 --> 00:19:26.030
You're not using the entire bandwidth
of what the T1 is capable of, so

352
00:19:26.030 --> 00:19:26.700
what do they do?

353
00:19:26.700 --> 00:19:29.380
They divide it up, and
you pay for what you need.

354
00:19:29.380 --> 00:19:31.980
You might need a few of these
fractional T1 lines, right?

355
00:19:31.980 --> 00:19:34.500
Whatever it is that you need to
aggregate together to get the bandwidth

356
00:19:34.500 --> 00:19:35.600
that you need.

357
00:19:35.600 --> 00:19:39.760
I just happened to show you that there is,
just for demonstration purposes,

358
00:19:39.760 --> 00:19:43.520
is overall channelized service,
we've got two here.

359
00:19:43.520 --> 00:19:46.830
Two completely different
service providers.

360
00:19:46.830 --> 00:19:51.040
But notice the delta channel,
16 kilobits delta channel, all right?

361
00:19:51.040 --> 00:19:52.475
That's why sometimes you
might see 144 kilobits.

362
00:19:52.475 --> 00:19:56.970
Not all of it is gonna be used for
your data.

363
00:19:56.970 --> 00:19:59.440
Some of it's used for signaling,
defining the parameters,

364
00:19:59.440 --> 00:20:01.450
maintaining the communication and
tearing it down.

365
00:20:02.678 --> 00:20:05.770
Now BRI-ISDN that we see here is
typically what you would see inside of

366
00:20:05.770 --> 00:20:10.740
things like residential areas and
even commercial businesses.

367
00:20:10.740 --> 00:20:12.070
Well what if you needed more bandwidth?

368
00:20:12.070 --> 00:20:14.890
Or you were the telecommunications
provider, we'll just say TELCO,

369
00:20:14.890 --> 00:20:18.830
if you're the telecommunications provider,
that's where something like primary rate

370
00:20:18.830 --> 00:20:23.130
interface comes in, and that's PRI-ISDN.

371
00:20:23.130 --> 00:20:27.870
Now I'll tell you, Zach,
I didn't take the time to sit out here and

372
00:20:27.870 --> 00:20:30.070
draw 24 individual lines, all right?

373
00:20:30.070 --> 00:20:34.540
I did not, I got a little
lazy on this one, all right?

374
00:20:34.540 --> 00:20:41.750
But know what I want you to know is that
notice that the PRI-ISDN is 23 B channels.

375
00:20:41.750 --> 00:20:46.400
So 23 channels carrying our data,
23 of those barer channels,

376
00:20:46.400 --> 00:20:50.600
at 64 kilobits per, all right?

377
00:20:50.600 --> 00:20:56.260
So when we look at that, that's
essentially equal to what the T1 line is.

378
00:20:56.260 --> 00:20:57.990
That's a full T1 line.

379
00:20:57.990 --> 00:21:02.670
Or if you're in Europe, and again, we're
gonna kind of tie this back together, and

380
00:21:02.670 --> 00:21:05.430
I did mention our Australian
viewers out there.

381
00:21:05.430 --> 00:21:06.640
We're not forgetting you.

382
00:21:06.640 --> 00:21:09.640
They also fall under the e
carrier system likewise too.

383
00:21:09.640 --> 00:21:12.000
So if you're in Europe or
you're in Australia.

384
00:21:12.000 --> 00:21:12.600
>> It's E.

385
00:21:12.600 --> 00:21:14.690
>> It's gonna be E1, right?

386
00:21:14.690 --> 00:21:17.160
That's the copper line
that you're gonna achieve

387
00:21:17.160 --> 00:21:19.550
this type of service I'm offering, right?

388
00:21:19.550 --> 00:21:20.850
Service level.

389
00:21:20.850 --> 00:21:23.230
Notice that the D channel
here has a little,

390
00:21:23.230 --> 00:21:26.780
gotta little bit more padding
in it than the earlier.

391
00:21:26.780 --> 00:21:31.635
PRI ISDN has a 16 kilo bit delta
channel here with pre or primary.

392
00:21:31.635 --> 00:21:33.895
Primary rate interface ISDN,

393
00:21:33.895 --> 00:21:37.705
you're looking at 64 kilobit
delta channels, all right?

394
00:21:37.705 --> 00:21:41.387
Then you can kind of see how we tied
together with the T-carrier systems, or

395
00:21:41.387 --> 00:21:44.195
E-carrier systems, or even,
I put in this just in case,

00:21:44.195 --> 00:21:45.945
you know, the J-carrier systems.

00:21:45.945 --> 00:21:49.495
I just put that in there for, just so

398
00:21:49.495 --> 00:21:53.460
I don't want you to worry about
J-carriers, if you will, for this exam.

399
00:21:53.460 --> 00:21:57.590
All right, so
that takes us through our ISDN.

400
00:21:57.590 --> 00:22:00.640
Now, there are other technologies
that we also have to consider, too.

401
00:22:00.640 --> 00:22:03.410
And by the way, these are all
