402
00:22:03.410 --> 00:22:04.090
>> Mm hm.

403
00:22:04.090 --> 00:22:05.160
>> All right?

404
00:22:05.160 --> 00:22:10.090
And that's something known as,
digital subscriber line, DSL, all right.

405
00:22:11.100 --> 00:22:13.220
Now when we talk about
digital subscriber line,

406
00:22:13.220 --> 00:22:16.630
this is another common service type
that we have out there that your

407
00:22:16.630 --> 00:22:20.280
service providers provide for
your WAN communication, right?

408
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:21.230
Your ISPs out there.

409
00:22:22.270 --> 00:22:27.261
Now digital subscriber line
is interesting, all right?

410
00:22:27.261 --> 00:22:31.906
It essentially can put voice and
data within the same communication line if

411
00:22:31.906 --> 00:22:35.529
you will, but
the frequencies are separate, all right?

412
00:22:35.529 --> 00:22:39.276
What you typically need is like
a DSL filter on the end of

413
00:22:39.276 --> 00:22:43.320
the connection there to

414
00:22:43.320 --> 00:22:47.880
But you could see here with the DSL, and
I would have had in a slide here and

415
00:22:47.880 --> 00:22:49.370
put a DSL.

416
00:22:49.370 --> 00:22:51.470
That's asymmetric digital subscriber line.

417
00:22:51.470 --> 00:22:54.050
The reason I did that is

418
00:22:54.050 --> 00:22:57.850
It just means your uploads and
your downloads are at different speeds.

419
00:22:57.850 --> 00:23:02.960
You also have symmetric DSL, but
it isn't the most common type.

420
00:23:02.960 --> 00:23:04.820
So I just went ahead and
put the most common type in here,

421
00:23:04.820 --> 00:23:08.650
because there's quite a few different

422
00:23:08.650 --> 00:23:13.120
And what you have is you have A DTE,

423
00:23:13.120 --> 00:23:15.440
A data termination equipment, right?

424
00:23:15.440 --> 00:23:20.000
That's something that's inside

425
00:23:20.000 --> 00:23:23.490
All right, typically a subscriber modem,
sometimes you can hear it called CPE,

00:23:23.490 --> 00:23:26.140
Customer Premise Equipment.

428
00:23:29.580 --> 00:23:31.450
And multiple, fi you will,

00:23:31.450 --> 00:23:35.790
multiple signals can be put across the
high speed backbone with something known

430
00:23:35.790 --> 00:23:41.230
as the digital subscriber
line access multiplexer.

431
00:23:41.230 --> 00:23:45.320
Understand that we have
channels here coming from, and

432
00:23:45.320 --> 00:23:47.900
signals coming from, more than one source.

433
00:23:47.900 --> 00:23:51.390
So when we have these devices it
doesn't matter if it's a copper based

434
00:23:51.390 --> 00:23:52.170
communication.

435
00:23:52.170 --> 00:23:55.680
Doesn't matter If it's
a fiber-optic communication,

436
00:23:55.680 --> 00:23:59.072
we'll talk about SONET coming up that also
uses something like this called an atom.

437
00:23:59.072 --> 00:24:03.770
All right, it takes multiple signals and
it combines it into one massive

438
00:24:03.770 --> 00:24:08.570
single signal and sends it over
a single physical medium, right?

439
00:24:08.570 --> 00:24:10.270
It's called multiplexing.

440
00:24:10.270 --> 00:24:12.540
It's a mux device, multiplexer.

441
00:24:12.540 --> 00:24:15.000
All right,
now on the other side of a communication,

442
00:24:15.000 --> 00:24:17.940
when you're receiving multiple
signals off of the ISP and

443
00:24:17.940 --> 00:24:22.324
it has to go to separate customers,
they call it de-multiplexing.

444
00:24:22.324 --> 00:24:23.330
A de-mux device.

445
00:24:23.330 --> 00:24:26.910
So, you have mux, multiplexing,
de-mux, de-multiplexing, right?

446
00:24:26.910 --> 00:24:28.770
So, it separates those signals.

447
00:24:28.770 --> 00:24:29.610
And, if we can look here,

448
00:24:29.610 --> 00:24:34.240
back at our diagram,
it would be de-multiplexed, if you will.

449
00:24:34.240 --> 00:24:39.540
So, you've got, going into the high speed
backbone, these signals are combined,

450
00:24:39.540 --> 00:24:43.590
and we offer the high speed backbone,
they're gonna be separated,

451
00:24:43.590 --> 00:24:47.830
so multiplex versus demultiplex,
all right?

452
00:24:47.830 --> 00:24:50.820
And that's a couple of the service
types that we have to look at.

453
00:24:50.820 --> 00:24:53.410
We've got a couple more
copper types to look at.

454
00:24:53.410 --> 00:24:56.060
And then we're gonna get into other
great things, things like satellite.

455
00:24:56.060 --> 00:25:00.650
We've gotta look at fiber fiber, one of

456
00:25:00.650 --> 00:25:04.010
But unfortunately it does look like we're

457

>> And we will watch part

So, you notice that you

Now, I didn't put any regional rings in

The local collector ring is what accepts

And that gets placed on

One of the connectivity devices that we

When we talk about an add-drop

It takes multiple subscriber data, right,

from multiple subscriber sources,
basically combines the signal and

sends that signal's signal across

54
00:03:08.640 --> 00:03:12.702
Well, the ADM here, the add drop
multiplexer essentially is one of the very

00:03:12.702 --> 00:03:16.147
important element inside of

56
00:03:16.147 --> 00:03:21.138
And basically it takes it and
multiplexes or combines, if you will,

57
00:03:21.138 --> 00:03:26.216
several lower bandwidth,
really we're dealing with wavelengths,

58
00:03:26.216 --> 00:03:29.071
if you will, streams, data streams.

59
00:03:29.071 --> 00:03:33.695
And then places them on a regional

60
00:03:33.695 --> 00:03:38.910

61
00:03:38.910 --> 00:03:41.994
The SONET backbone ring has
the highest bandwidth, and

00:03:41.994 --> 00:03:46.529
that's typically what you're going to

63
00:03:46.529 --> 00:03:52.001
All right, now one of the great

64
00:03:52.001 --> 00:03:58.760
the dual ring topology is that like we've

65

We talked about the fact that it's

00:04:02.438 --> 00:04:04.927
in the fact that,
since it's dual ring, right,

67
00:04:04.927 --> 00:04:06.785
when we have two we have redundancy.

68
00:04:06.785 --> 00:04:12.147
Anytime we have redundancy it helps us to
achieve fault tolerance if we want to,

69
00:04:12.147 --> 00:04:16.430
it's a very fault tolerant
type of communication.

70
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:20.332
Now, and this is all related to fiber,

71
00:04:20.332 --> 00:04:24.611
there're couple other topics that I wanna

72

And when we talk about fiber, we have

And when we talk about the cabling types

when we talked about T1 lines,
we talked about T2 lines, right?

What we also have fiber-optic lines that

but they called something

What they're called,
is optical carrier transmissions, right?

79
00:04:51.260 --> 00:04:56.103
OC for short, optical carriers,
and they also have a certain set

of specifications that are called
out on the exam, all right?

81

Now, in earlier episodes
here in WAN Technologies,

the first part we talked about T1,

00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:09.901
We also talked about the E
carriers as well, E1 and

E3 likewise in the European carriers.

00:05:12.805 --> 00:05:18.417
Well, when it comes to your optical
carriers, they call out two as well,

00:05:18.417 --> 00:05:24.409
OC-1 and excuse me I'm sorry,
not OC-1, OC-3, and OC-192.

00:05:24.409 --> 00:05:27.062
And again, OC is just short for
optical carrier, let's go ahead and

88
00:05:27.062 --> 00:05:28.176
take a look at that, right.

We talked about optical carrier 3,
we're talking about a transmission speed

91
00:05:38.036 --> 00:05:41.420
>> Mm-hm.
All right, now I definitely want you to

92
00:05:41.420 --> 00:05:47.191
know of OC-192 because we have 10

00:05:47.191 --> 00:05:52.504
we have 10G based T, if you will,

Now, that's your land based

96

Here's where our gateway device comes

We also have a 10G based offering

00:06:13.979 --> 00:06:15.800

100
00:06:15.800 --> 00:06:20.749
Now, we do need our gateway device,

00:06:20.749 --> 00:06:25.410
on the 10G base side we're running

00:06:25.410 --> 00:06:28.950
But on the WAN side, we're going to

331
00:19:36.827 --> 00:19:38.794
Like you said, you've got one
on the outside of your house.

332
00:19:38.794 --> 00:19:40.551
>> Do.
>> That little box, and again,

333
00:19:40.551 --> 00:19:43.356
what that's gonna lead back to is
like the cabling, if you will,

334
00:19:43.356 --> 00:19:46.325
that's inside of your house or
inside of your commercial building.

335
00:19:46.325 --> 00:19:46.910
And guess what?

336
00:19:46.910 --> 00:19:49.923
You're going to be responsible for
maintaining all of the cabling.

337
00:19:49.923 --> 00:19:51.602
If something happens there, right?

338
00:19:51.602 --> 00:19:55.653
If I decide that I wanna bust a wall
down inside of the house, and

339
00:19:55.653 --> 00:19:58.722
I cut one of the Cat cables
that are on that side.

340
00:19:58.722 --> 00:20:01.500
It's not gonna be the cable
company's responsibility, right?

341
00:20:01.500 --> 00:20:04.323
I don't call the cable company and
tell them that my TV's broke.

342
00:20:04.323 --> 00:20:07.813
I might, but there not gonna do anything
about it, it's my job to fix the TV,

343
00:20:07.813 --> 00:20:09.770
that's my point of responsibility.

344
00:20:09.770 --> 00:20:14.144
However, if something happens to their
cable on the outside that causes my cable

345
00:20:14.144 --> 00:20:17.502
television to go out,
I can call the cable provider, right?

346
00:20:17.502 --> 00:20:22.287
That's their point of responsibility, and
that's essentially what the d mark is,

347
00:20:22.287 --> 00:20:26.087
the demarcation point,
it is really the point of responsibility.

348
00:20:26.087 --> 00:20:27.998
Now, speaking of network interface device,

349
00:20:27.998 --> 00:20:31.140
we've got another one here that I need
to mention too, that's in the list.

350
00:20:31.140 --> 00:20:34.955
And that's called a network interface or
excuse me, I'm sorry,

351
00:20:34.955 --> 00:20:37.213
it's called a smart jack, all right?

352
00:20:37.213 --> 00:20:41.798
When you have things like for instance,
you might have something like a an ISDN

353
00:20:41.798 --> 00:20:46.520
line, you might have in fact, you could
see this one's right next to a 66 block

354
00:20:46.520 --> 00:20:49.460
that we've talked about
in other episodes here.

355
00:20:49.460 --> 00:20:54.438
But a smart jack essentially is a network
interface device that does signal,

356
00:20:54.438 --> 00:20:59.185
it does code and does protocol conversions
as well as a little bit more than

357
00:20:59.185 --> 00:21:03.112
just a simple jack, if you will,
that allows connections.

358
00:21:03.112 --> 00:21:05.695
It also does things like
diagnostics as well, and

359
00:21:05.695 --> 00:21:09.381
you can actually see there are three
cabinets here, the shelves as they

360
00:21:09.381 --> 00:21:12.776
call them, two shelves, excuse me,
and we'll get this right.

361
00:21:12.776 --> 00:21:15.242
Two shelves, three smart jacks, right?

362
00:21:15.242 --> 00:21:18.153
And you could see some of the lights
on here in the diagnostics telling you

363
00:21:18.153 --> 00:21:21.845
whether you've got connection, whether
something's up, whether something's down.

364
00:21:21.845 --> 00:21:24.854
Or again, whether you're running
just general diagnostics,

365
00:21:24.854 --> 00:21:26.257
that's called a smart jack.

366
00:21:26.257 --> 00:21:28.450
And again,
they call it a network interface unit.

367
00:21:28.450 --> 00:21:31.666
But again, it's just another
form of network interface, and

368
00:21:31.666 --> 00:21:33.920
it's something to be aware of for
the exam.

369
00:21:34.920 --> 00:21:39.575
Now that leads me to the last
concept that we have to understand

370
00:21:39.575 --> 00:21:44.245
a little bit about and
that's something known as a CSU/DSU.

371
00:21:44.245 --> 00:21:48.246
In the earlier days, these CSUs,
DSUs would be separate devices, right?

372
00:21:48.246 --> 00:21:52.409
And they're called channel service
unit and data service unit.

373
00:21:52.409 --> 00:21:55.184
And one side of it would
connect to your DTE,

374
00:21:55.184 --> 00:21:59.090
your data termination equipment,
like a router if you will.

375
00:21:59.090 --> 00:22:04.045
The other side would connect to
the DCE the data circuits equipment,

376
00:22:04.045 --> 00:22:07.043
that's inside of the carriers network.

377
00:22:07.043 --> 00:22:10.429
In fact, I can kinda show you
where the CSU/DSU would sit,

378
00:22:10.429 --> 00:22:13.017
If you're looking at the network topology.

379
00:22:13.017 --> 00:22:17.940
Today, and for a long time now,
you can see that the CSU/DSUs are built

380
00:22:17.940 --> 00:22:23.046
into one little module, if you will,
that can be put right into a switch.

381
00:22:23.046 --> 00:22:28.598
But here it is, all right, see the CSU/DSU
is behind the demarcation point.

382
00:22:28.598 --> 00:22:31.268
And that connects to the DTE,
the data termination equipment.

383
00:22:31.268 --> 00:22:34.203
In this case, a router, if you will,
and then the DSU again,

384
00:22:34.203 --> 00:22:37.872
this side is gonna connect to the DCE
inside of the carrier's network in, and

385
00:22:37.872 --> 00:22:39.974
that's the data circuit equipment again.

386
00:22:39.974 --> 00:22:43.942
So just realize what the DSU/CSU is,
it essentially takes that signal,

387
00:22:43.942 --> 00:22:47.273
if you will, that's coming off
of the customer's network.

388
00:22:47.273 --> 00:22:51.198
And converts it into a signal that can be
then placed onto the carrier's network and

389
00:22:51.198 --> 00:22:53.003
moved along the carrier's network.

390
00:22:53.003 --> 00:22:56.987
So that's one of the last little
components to definitely be aware of, and

391
00:22:56.987 --> 00:22:58.450
kinda know where it seats.

392
00:22:58.450 --> 00:23:03.629
If you were happen to give maybe
a network diagram on the exam,

393
00:23:03.629 --> 00:23:06.628
which one of these is the CSU/DSU?

394
00:23:06.628 --> 00:23:09.850
Just be able to point it out, like I
said in the earlier days, they would

395
00:23:09.850 --> 00:23:13.370
be separate devices today, and for
a long time now they're a single device.

396
00:23:13.370 --> 00:23:16.875
And even just a module that you could
put inside of your network connectivity

397
00:23:16.875 --> 00:23:18.362
devices in your server closet.

398
00:23:18.362 --> 00:23:21.654
So those are some of the WAN
technologies that we've been looking at.

399
00:23:21.654 --> 00:23:24.798
And some of the things that you will
need to know for the Network+ exam.

400
00:23:24.798 --> 00:23:28.674
And also it's good to know because a lot
of times we don't see what's on the other

401
00:23:28.674 --> 00:23:32.690
side of the street there when it comes
to your Internet service providers.

402
00:23:32.690 --> 00:23:34.195
Know some of the channelized services,

403
00:23:34.195 --> 00:23:37.393
know some of the technologies that we've
talked about over these past few episodes.

404
00:23:37.393 --> 00:23:41.448
So that you'll be doing good the next
time, you sit your Network+ exam.

405
00:23:41.448 --> 00:23:43.892
>> Well once again Wes,
thank you for being so complete.

406
00:23:43.892 --> 00:23:46.214
WAN Technologies,
parts one, two, and three.

407
00:23:46.214 --> 00:23:50.095
And also the entire series, of the CompTIA
Net+, that Wes has put together for you.

408
00:23:50.095 --> 00:23:53.582
See them all, enjoy them all, learn from
them all, through the course library check

409
00:23:53.582 --> 00:23:55.868
out the other hundreds of
videos that are there as well.

410
00:23:55.868 --> 00:23:58.780
And they're all designed
to help you go further.

411
00:23:58.780 --> 00:24:01.762
And tell everybody you know about
ITPro.TV, they'll be really glad you did.

412
00:24:01.762 --> 00:24:03.058
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

413
00:24:03.058 --> 00:24:03.994
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

414
00:24:03.994 --> 00:24:06.839
>> And we'll see you soon.

415
00:24:06.839 --> 00:24:12.783
[MUSIC]

416
00:24:12.783 --> 00:24:15.629
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes take a look at diagrams and different pieces of documentation. They dive into diagrams, change and inventory management documentation, labeling and more.
episodes.title: Network Diagrams and Documentation

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes dive into the realm of business continuity. They explore high availability, fault tolerance, battery backups as well as site types
episodes.title: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.770
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.770 --> 00:00:03.105
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.105 --> 00:00:06.468
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.468 --> 00:00:08.168
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.168 --> 00:00:11.950
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.950 --> 00:00:13.183
>> Hello, and thank you for

7
00:00:13.183 --> 00:00:16.080
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn where ever you go.

8
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:17.580
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

9
00:00:17.580 --> 00:00:21.291
As we continue on with CompTIA and
NetPlus in this episode,

10
00:00:21.291 --> 00:00:24.198
Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery.

11
00:00:24.198 --> 00:00:27.093
And the person bringing us the information
we need is the one and only Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:27.093 --> 00:00:28.190
Wes, good to see you, sir.

13
00:00:28.190 --> 00:00:29.493
>> Hey, Zach, thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:29.493 --> 00:00:34.025
That's right, this episode is gonna
be all about If we have a failure,

15
00:00:34.025 --> 00:00:39.590
all right, can our business, can it
maintain whatever its operations might be?

16
00:00:39.590 --> 00:00:40.890
And that's gonna be important.

17
00:00:40.890 --> 00:00:44.320
Or if we have some kind of disaster,
right?

18
00:00:44.320 --> 00:00:49.710
How can we take, if you will,
that area that maybe has been destroyed or

19
00:00:49.710 --> 00:00:53.590
components of it have been destroyed,
how do we maintain again our day-to-day

20
00:00:53.590 --> 00:00:56.520
operations should
something like that happen?

21
00:00:56.520 --> 00:00:59.064
>> So we're gonna be looking at
proactive and reactive, aren't we, Wes?

22
00:00:59.064 --> 00:01:03.650
>> Definitely, and some of the concepts
that we talk about is before hand, right?

23
00:01:03.650 --> 00:01:08.330
Just like you said proactive, but some of
them will be after something has happened

24
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:10.100
we gotta kinda figure out
where do we go from here?

25
00:01:10.100 --> 00:01:12.300
But regardless,
it all starts with planning.

26
00:01:12.300 --> 00:01:15.530
So I guess all of it's really proactive,
right?

27
00:01:15.530 --> 00:01:19.100
Again, when we implement it
sometimes might be reactive, right?

28
00:01:19.100 --> 00:01:20.250
But it all starts with planning.

29
00:01:20.250 --> 00:01:24.660
So let's go ahead and let's start out with
the very first concept that we need to be

30
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:25.390
aware of, right?

31
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:27.960
They talk about availability concepts.

32
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:32.550
Well, one of the very first things when it
comes to availability concepts is, well,

33
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:35.800
a couple of terms, right?

34
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:37.090
Redundancy and fault tolerance.

35
00:01:37.090 --> 00:01:40.860
Now fault tolerance is an exam objective,
but redundancy is not.

36
00:01:40.860 --> 00:01:45.070
But you do need to know that redundancy
is how we achieve fault tolerance, right?

37
00:01:45.070 --> 00:01:48.660
So when we talk about fault tolerance,
it's the ability of a system, the device,

38
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:52.910
a network, to continue the operations,
continue to operate,

39
00:01:52.910 --> 00:01:56.110
if you will,
in the event of some kind of failure.

40
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:59.780
Now when I say a system you could have a
whole bunch of systems that are providing

41
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:00.460
a service, right?

42
00:02:00.460 --> 00:02:02.390
So it could be just
a component within that system,

43
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:04.640
could be a component within a device.

44
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:10.055
Right, and we need to make sure that we
can again maintain or continue to operate.

45
00:02:10.055 --> 00:02:14.020
Now we achieve fault tolerance
through redundancy, all right?

46
00:02:14.020 --> 00:02:15.630
And what is redundancy?

47
00:02:15.630 --> 00:02:20.800
Redundancy is just having more than
one of a component or a system, right?

48
00:02:20.800 --> 00:02:24.370
So let me give you an example, because
I keep using component, system device.

49
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:25.830
Let me tell you want I mean, all right?

50
00:02:25.830 --> 00:02:29.570
For instance,
let's go back to our A+ training.

51
00:02:29.570 --> 00:02:32.459
Maybe some of you guys and
gals out there are coming over from A+.

52
00:02:32.459 --> 00:02:36.306
But if not, you need to know a little bit
about something called redundant array of

53
00:02:36.306 --> 00:02:38.390
independent disks, right, RAID arrays.

54
00:02:38.390 --> 00:02:39.910
Why do we use RAID arrays?

55
00:02:39.910 --> 00:02:42.935
Well, let's go ahead and just take
performance just out of the mix because

56
00:02:42.935 --> 00:02:45.633
that's one of the reasons that we do it,
but redundancy, right?

57
00:02:45.633 --> 00:02:49.073
We have more than one hard drive so
that in the event of a failure,

58
00:02:49.073 --> 00:02:51.966
with hard drives,
it's not a matter of if they fail.

59
00:02:51.966 --> 00:02:54.405
It's a matter of just
when they're gonna fail.

60
00:02:54.405 --> 00:02:58.452
So then if one of those drives fails we
still have access to the most important

61
00:02:58.452 --> 00:03:01.943
thing in information technology today,
information, right?

62
00:03:01.943 --> 00:03:03.560
We have more than one.

63
00:03:03.560 --> 00:03:08.590
If we have, let's say more than
one route leading into a network,

64
00:03:08.590 --> 00:03:11.160
why do we have more than one
route leading into a network?

65
00:03:11.160 --> 00:03:12.860
Isn't one route fine?

66
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:15.340
Yeah, it is, but what if that route fails?

67
00:03:15.340 --> 00:03:17.880
Now you can't communicate in and
out of that network, right?

68
00:03:19.070 --> 00:03:23.593
Redundancy in a device itself could be the
fact that maybe we have multiple routers.

69
00:03:23.593 --> 00:03:25.714
Maybe we have multiple firewalls, right?

70
00:03:25.714 --> 00:03:27.750
Why would we want more than one firewall?

71
00:03:27.750 --> 00:03:30.795
Well, if one firewall goes offline,
what happens?

72
00:03:30.795 --> 00:03:33.598
Your entire system is open to attack.

73
00:03:33.598 --> 00:03:38.320
But if we've got two firewalls, right,
redundancy gives us fault tolerance.

74
00:03:38.320 --> 00:03:39.420
>> Quick question for you, Wes.

75
00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:41.320
Are backups considered redundant?

76
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:42.930
Is that redundancy, having backups?

77
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:50.120
>> No, backups I would say are just
a protection in case of a failure, right?

78
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:54.307
It should be a part of system maintenance,
too, just normal system maintenance.

79
00:03:54.307 --> 00:03:57.951
But backups are a part of
business continuity, I could say.

80
00:03:57.951 --> 00:04:02.413
But what you need to understand, though,
is that I back my information up, right?

81
00:04:02.413 --> 00:04:05.255
We get a copy of the most
critical information so

82
00:04:05.255 --> 00:04:08.032
that if a system does fail,
we can restore it.

83
00:04:08.032 --> 00:04:11.231
All right, and we're gonna get in to
back ups here coming up because they

84
00:04:11.231 --> 00:04:14.482
are important and there are some things
that you have to know about backups

85
00:04:14.482 --> 00:04:16.382
including things like types, all right?

86
00:04:16.382 --> 00:04:18.548
So fault tolerance and
redundancy, remember that,

87
00:04:18.548 --> 00:04:21.110
they're not the same thing but
one is how we achieve the other.

88
00:04:21.110 --> 00:04:24.355
Redundancy having more than one
of something is how we achieve

89
00:04:24.355 --> 00:04:26.010
fault tolerance.

90
00:04:26.010 --> 00:04:28.793
Now we also got a term
known as high availability.

91
00:04:28.793 --> 00:04:31.677
I want you to be aware of
high availability, all right?

92
00:04:31.677 --> 00:04:35.839
So high availability is any system,if you
will, that can maintain continuity of

93
00:04:35.839 --> 00:04:39.470
operations without a failure for
a long duration of time.

94
00:04:39.470 --> 00:04:44.230
All right, these services are typically
tested for durability, if you will.

95
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:48.650
A lot of effort is made, if you will,
to ensure things like the redundancy,

96
00:04:48.650 --> 00:04:51.549
more than one, and
the fault tolerance that we can

97
00:04:51.549 --> 00:04:54.954
withstand a foreseeable component failure,
all right?

98
00:04:54.954 --> 00:04:58.321
Now depending on something
known as your SLA, all right,

99
00:04:58.321 --> 00:05:03.490
your service-level agreement, will dictate
how much availability you have, right?

100
00:05:03.490 --> 00:05:06.623
See, high availability is actually
a metric, if you will, all right?

101
00:05:06.623 --> 00:05:12.358
And that metric says,
how close can we get to 100% uptime?

102
00:05:12.358 --> 00:05:16.550
Now, if money's no object, well,
then you'd probably stay up 100% of

103
00:05:16.550 --> 00:05:20.770
the time when we talk about
availability to a service, right?

104
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:22.368
But it's very, very expensive.

105
00:05:22.368 --> 00:05:26.987
So it's not realistic to say
100% availability, all right?

106
00:05:26.987 --> 00:05:29.969
High availability again is
that metric that tells you

107
00:05:29.969 --> 00:05:32.496
how close to 100% availability you get.

108
00:05:32.496 --> 00:05:34.354
And there are different metrics,
all right?

109
00:05:34.354 --> 00:05:36.812
So I got a little chart here
that I wanna kinda talk about so

110
00:05:36.812 --> 00:05:39.905
you understand what we mean when we
say high availability, all right?

111
00:05:39.905 --> 00:05:44.377
We have what's known as the 99% all right,
or the 9s,

112
00:05:44.377 --> 00:05:47.766
if you will, as they might call it, right?

113
00:05:47.766 --> 00:05:54.047
And if we look we look at 99% uptime,
right, the two nine availability, right?

114
00:05:54.047 --> 00:06:00.840
This is again just your how
close to 100% complete uptime.

115
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:06.390
No interruptions, no, I can't say delays
but no interruptions of service at all.

116
00:06:06.390 --> 00:06:09.864
All right, well, your SLA,
your service level agreement.

117
00:06:09.864 --> 00:06:14.565
By the way, service level agreement,
real quick, is just the minimum level

118
00:06:14.565 --> 00:06:18.977
of acceptable performance that
a service provider an give you, again,

119
00:06:18.977 --> 00:06:20.590
according to a contract.

120
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:24.600
And then things like, what are the
requirements of that service provider

121
00:06:24.600 --> 00:06:29.140
should they fail to give you
that level of service, right?

122
00:06:29.140 --> 00:06:33.705
So if you have a 99 or
two nines, 99% uptime,

123
00:06:33.705 --> 00:06:41.010
then what you see is that downtime per
year Is around 3.65 days, all right?

124
00:06:41.010 --> 00:06:43.189
Now that's not acceptable for
a lot of people,

125
00:06:43.189 --> 00:06:46.964
cuz I want you to think of a company that
makes $1 million an hour on online sales.

126
00:06:46.964 --> 00:06:47.594
>> Like?

127
00:06:47.594 --> 00:06:49.375
>> All right, I will tell you.

128
00:06:49.375 --> 00:06:50.892
>> Starts with an A.

129
00:06:50.892 --> 00:06:51.720
>> Exactly, right?

130
00:06:51.720 --> 00:06:53.270
Like Amazon, absolutely.

131
00:06:53.270 --> 00:06:55.451
So let's take Amazon, right?

132
00:06:55.451 --> 00:07:02.764
So if Amazon is offline for three days,
millions of dollars that they've lost.

133
00:07:02.764 --> 00:07:03.542
>> Maybe more.

134
00:07:03.542 --> 00:07:07.130
>> Absolutely Zack, so
that's probably not acceptable.

135
00:07:07.130 --> 00:07:09.410
But you know the metric, right?

back up here, link aggregation

360
00:20:16.593 --> 00:20:21.632
is sometimes defined in
the Ethernet standard as 802.3ad.

361
00:20:21.632 --> 00:20:24.600
I want you to know that for
the exam, right?

362
00:20:24.600 --> 00:20:29.900
There's something known as
Link Aggregation Control Protocol.

363
00:20:29.900 --> 00:20:33.682
All right, that's what you're gonna see,
that's the IEEE standardization for

364
00:20:33.682 --> 00:20:34.610
link aggregation.

365
00:20:34.610 --> 00:20:36.530
So not sure if they're
gonna ask you on the exam.

366
00:20:36.530 --> 00:20:41.131
But if you're gonna be talking
about things like port aggregation,

367
00:20:41.131 --> 00:20:46.062
NIC teaming if you will,
again link aggregation, know the 802.3.

368
00:20:46.062 --> 00:20:53.853
All right, now that is a little bit
about some of the availability concepts.

369
00:20:53.853 --> 00:20:57.359
But we don't really stop there when
it comes to availability concepts.

370
00:20:57.359 --> 00:21:00.133
We've got some other things that
we need to keep in mind too.

371
00:21:00.133 --> 00:21:03.372
And they call out things like
power management, right?

372
00:21:03.372 --> 00:21:07.731
So power management,
we need some fault tolerance in our,

373
00:21:07.731 --> 00:21:12.017
basically the thing that runs
all of our devices, right?

374
00:21:12.017 --> 00:21:14.560
I could have NIC teaming, right?

375
00:21:14.560 --> 00:21:17.280
I could have port aggregation, right?

376
00:21:17.280 --> 00:21:18.560
I could have load balancing.

377
00:21:18.560 --> 00:21:20.900
I could have things like clustering.

378
00:21:20.900 --> 00:21:23.240
But what happens if the power goes off?

379
00:21:23.240 --> 00:21:24.232
Well, we have none of that.

380
00:21:24.232 --> 00:21:25.010
[LAUGH] Right?

381
00:21:25.010 --> 00:21:26.554
>> Get the gerbils on the wheels, quickly.

382
00:21:26.554 --> 00:21:28.493
>> [LAUGH] That's right, absolutely.

383
00:21:28.493 --> 00:21:32.170
Somebody's gonna be on their
fitness bike powering everything.

384
00:21:32.170 --> 00:21:36.180
Just kidding, so what we need is we also
need redundancy in our power, right?

385
00:21:36.180 --> 00:21:37.200
So power management,

386
00:21:37.200 --> 00:21:40.370
we have to implement some kind of
redundancy to get fault tolerance.

387
00:21:40.370 --> 00:21:42.820
And there's a few different ways
that you can do this, right?

388
00:21:42.820 --> 00:21:45.760
One of the things that they call
out is something known as battery

389
00:21:45.760 --> 00:21:46.840
backups, all right?

390
00:21:46.840 --> 00:21:50.560
More commonly we're gonna talk about UPSs,
all right?

391
00:21:50.560 --> 00:21:52.160
UPS, we're not talking
about a delivery service.

392
00:21:52.160 --> 00:21:57.010
What we're talking about here is something
known as an uninterruptible power supply.

393
00:21:57.010 --> 00:22:00.310
Uninterruptible power supply,
so what does that mean, right?

394
00:22:00.310 --> 00:22:03.590
Why would we need an uninterruptible
power supply, all right?

395
00:22:03.590 --> 00:22:08.430
Well, understand that when you turn
your systems off intentionally,

396
00:22:08.430 --> 00:22:10.180
those are called graceful shutdowns,
all right?

397
00:22:10.180 --> 00:22:13.690
And we've gotta kinda understand that to
understand what the UPS is actually doing

398
00:22:13.690 --> 00:22:14.409
for us, right?

399
00:22:15.410 --> 00:22:18.830
When you power a system down
under its own means, right?

400
00:22:18.830 --> 00:22:22.260
So for instance I go into a Windows
server and I shut it down.

401
00:22:22.260 --> 00:22:24.976
And I give whatever the reason is
that it requires me to shut down.

402
00:22:24.976 --> 00:22:29.610
I am doing what's known as
a graceful shutdown, all right?

403
00:22:29.610 --> 00:22:32.505
That's important because that
helps to protect my data,

404
00:22:32.505 --> 00:22:34.523
when we do graceful shutdowns, right?

405
00:22:34.523 --> 00:22:36.813
And you have things like journal
file systems, if you will.

406
00:22:36.813 --> 00:22:39.836
You have a database if you will
that has a lot of different logs,

407
00:22:39.836 --> 00:22:41.619
transaction logs that's going on.

408
00:22:41.619 --> 00:22:43.860
It's got the database,
don't wanna get it corrupted.

409
00:22:43.860 --> 00:22:48.546
When you shut it down gracefully, the
operating system says all right we need to

410
00:22:48.546 --> 00:22:52.845
stop all the writes that are going on
to this file, to this database, right?

411
00:22:52.845 --> 00:22:55.051
To the operating system, to the page file.

412
00:22:55.051 --> 00:22:56.949
We need to shut everything down, and

413
00:22:56.949 --> 00:23:00.760
when we do that we'll maintain
the integrity of all of that information.

414
00:23:02.470 --> 00:23:06.450
That is the polar opposite of what's known
as a kernel power failure, right, or

415
00:23:06.450 --> 00:23:07.610
any power failure really.

416
00:23:07.610 --> 00:23:10.440
When we're talking about operating
systems is critical kernel power failure.

417
00:23:10.440 --> 00:23:14.257
Cuz what happens is your device might be
in the middle of a write operation to

418
00:23:14.257 --> 00:23:16.147
the hard disk, hard drive, right?

419
00:23:16.147 --> 00:23:18.143
Or whatever the storage array
might be that you're using.

420
00:23:18.143 --> 00:23:20.930
And the problem with that is,
if we're writing.

421
00:23:22.754 --> 00:23:24.918
Boy, if we had left
that episode like this,

422
00:23:24.918 --> 00:23:27.460
it would be like the Sopranos ending,
right?

423
00:23:27.460 --> 00:23:28.860
We wouldn't know what's going on.

424
00:23:28.860 --> 00:23:33.550
But worse than that, is we'd end
up getting file corruption, right?

425
00:23:33.550 --> 00:23:35.680
Now, we don't want that.

426
00:23:35.680 --> 00:23:39.450
So an uninterruptible power supply
is a battery backup if you will,

427
00:23:39.450 --> 00:23:44.055
that allows your systems to perform
graceful shutdowns, all right.

428
00:23:44.055 --> 00:23:47.520
Here's what a UPS is not for, to

429
00:23:47.520 --> 00:23:52.220
power your systems until your electrical
company brings the power back online.

430
00:23:52.220 --> 00:23:54.421
It's not what it's for, all right?

431
00:23:54.421 --> 00:23:59.329
It is to maintain a great, or actually
just to when the power kicks over to

432
00:23:59.329 --> 00:24:04.076
give you a long enough A long enough
time span, I guess you'd save your

433
00:24:04.076 --> 00:24:08.521
power to perform a graceful shutdown,
to shut the devices down.

434
00:24:08.521 --> 00:24:11.445
And you might have some kind of
trigger event that says, hey,

435
00:24:11.445 --> 00:24:14.932
the moment I'm on a battery backup,
the moment I'm on a UPS, go ahead and

436
00:24:14.932 --> 00:24:18.950
start shutting these systems down and
whatever their volatility might be, right?

437
00:24:18.950 --> 00:24:21.400
Whatever is most crucial,
shut down, right?

438
00:24:21.400 --> 00:24:24.430
Perform the graceful shutdown, right?

439
00:24:24.430 --> 00:24:29.740
Now if you need a little bit more
time [LAUGH] as far as power goes,

440
00:24:29.740 --> 00:24:31.150
well you might go a little bit farther.

441
00:24:31.150 --> 00:24:33.130
UPS is not gonna be the way you go.

442
00:24:33.130 --> 00:24:34.300
You might need a power generator.

443
00:24:35.720 --> 00:24:41.220
Now power generators aren't so
much necessarily to do graceful shutdowns.

444
00:24:41.220 --> 00:24:43.510
They continue to power your devices and

445
00:24:43.510 --> 00:24:47.900
if you have mission critical systems that
might be something that your company has.

446
00:24:47.900 --> 00:24:51.870
For instance, take somebody as
big as Amazon, big as Azure,

447
00:24:51.870 --> 00:24:55.060
Microsoft Azure, all right.

448
00:24:56.100 --> 00:24:59.640
AWS has one of biggest if not
the biggest redundancy and

449
00:24:59.640 --> 00:25:01.360
fault tolerance system in the world.

450
00:25:01.360 --> 00:25:05.490
I mean they have entire geographical
regions that fail over to

451
00:25:05.490 --> 00:25:08.550
electrical grids right and
are well beyond that.

452
00:25:08.550 --> 00:25:11.650
Facebook is one that
Is pretty interesting.

453
00:25:11.650 --> 00:25:14.740
They have one of the most
redundant systems out there,

454
00:25:14.740 --> 00:25:18.740
because they add, gosh,
I don't know how much,

455
00:25:18.740 --> 00:25:22.430
thousands of servers a day, a day-
>> A day.

456
00:25:22.430 --> 00:25:25.110
>> Is how big they are expanding daily.

457
00:25:25.110 --> 00:25:28.920
All right, they have generators out there

458
00:25:28.920 --> 00:25:34.220
that are big enough that could power 700
houses for a month, just one of them.

459
00:25:34.220 --> 00:25:38.055
And there's 20 of them 30 of
them just on a single building.

460
00:25:38.055 --> 00:25:40.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right it's absolutely insane.

461
00:25:40.830 --> 00:25:42.100
>> They're not taking any chances.

462
00:25:42.100 --> 00:25:43.200
>> No they're definitely not.

463
00:25:43.200 --> 00:25:44.740
>> Mm.
>> Now there's a type of generator

464
00:25:44.740 --> 00:25:47.160
you wanna be careful about.

465
00:25:47.160 --> 00:25:49.710
Remember when we talked about computer
circuitry and this kind of goes back to

466
00:25:49.710 --> 00:25:52.198
your A+ training, right,
remember that your network devices,

467
00:25:52.198 --> 00:25:54.657
all your computing equipment
operates on direct current, right.

468
00:25:55.990 --> 00:26:00.320
Your computing components, they dont
do well with frequency variations.

469
00:26:00.320 --> 00:26:01.860
It's why we don't use alternating current.

470
00:26:01.860 --> 00:26:05.640
Well we do to bring the power source in
and then we run it through a converter and

471
00:26:05.640 --> 00:26:08.800
it converts it over to direct current,
right to DC.

472
00:26:08.800 --> 00:26:13.040
Now, you don't wanna be using things
like gasoline generators, all right?

473
00:26:13.040 --> 00:26:18.990
Why, well gasoline generators provide
a pretty big power fluctuation, right?

474
00:26:18.990 --> 00:26:20.540
And any of you that have
ever been around when,

475
00:26:20.540 --> 00:26:23.490
I know I used to be a commercial
painter before I got into IT.

476
00:26:23.490 --> 00:26:25.870
We'd go out to a job site
that didn't have any power.

477
00:26:25.870 --> 00:26:31.550
We still needed to run
an airless spray gun, right.

478
00:26:31.550 --> 00:26:35.710
Well, every time that the gasoline
generator would go on,

479
00:26:35.710 --> 00:26:39.610
if you had your hand on that trigger
that when you were spraying right,

480
00:26:39.610 --> 00:26:44.010
you could notice a very sizable
drop in the pressure sometimes.

481
00:26:44.010 --> 00:26:48.410
You would hear the gasoline generator bog
down and then it would kind of spin up and

482
00:26:48.410 --> 00:26:50.020
gain its power back right.

483
00:26:50.020 --> 00:26:53.600
Well, that's a frequency variation
that circuitry's not gonna do well.

484
00:26:53.600 --> 00:26:59.870
The airless might do just fine it'll build
up enough compression it'll tolerate that.

485
00:26:59.870 --> 00:27:03.380
So you don't wanna use
gasoline generators.

486
00:27:03.380 --> 00:27:06.920
Most often these are diesel generators
that they use so do keep that in mind.

487
00:27:06.920 --> 00:27:08.310
If they give you that option on the exam,

488
00:27:08.310 --> 00:27:10.690
which one are you gonna
use over the other?

489
00:27:10.690 --> 00:27:13.480
Gonna wanna use the diesel generator.

490
00:27:13.480 --> 00:27:17.860
Now the other thing is redundant circuits.

491
00:27:17.860 --> 00:27:21.120
Remember that we use that a lot in
things like server closets, right.

492
00:27:21.120 --> 00:27:25.120
And speaking of server closets,
redundant power supplies,

493
00:27:25.120 --> 00:27:31.560
in fact I've got a picture of
a redundant power adapter.

494
00:27:31.560 --> 00:27:34.080
You can see this one right here,
it's a quick change, right?

495
00:27:34.080 --> 00:27:36.570
Notice that there are two
power supplies here.

496
00:27:36.570 --> 00:27:38.720
>> Yeah!
>> Right, and they also have two plugs,

497
00:27:38.720 --> 00:27:42.440
and this is so you can daisy-chain, but
you might find that you have not only

498
00:27:42.440 --> 00:27:45.330
redundant power supplies or
dual power supplies.

499
00:27:45.330 --> 00:27:48.100
But not only do I have more
than one power supply,

500
00:27:48.100 --> 00:27:51.240
each one of these power supplies is
plugged into the separate circuit.

501
00:27:52.500 --> 00:27:54.220
Because here's what doesn't make sense.

502
00:27:56.160 --> 00:27:58.610
If I have two power supplies and

503
00:27:58.610 --> 00:28:03.020
I've spent the money to be redundant
to try to achieve full tolerance,

504
00:28:03.020 --> 00:28:07.290
and I plug both of those power supplies
into the same electrical circuit.

505
00:28:07.290 --> 00:28:08.750
What happens when that circuit goes bad?

506
00:28:09.905 --> 00:28:12.790
Doesn't matter that I have two power
supplies, if both power supplies.

507
00:28:12.790 --> 00:28:13.650
Thats right.

508
00:28:13.650 --> 00:28:14.270
So what do we do?

509
00:28:15.290 --> 00:28:17.570
We have redundant circuits.

510
00:28:17.570 --> 00:28:20.990
I plug one of the power
supplies into once circuit.

511
00:28:20.990 --> 00:28:24.110
I plug the other power supply
into the other circuit.

512
00:28:24.110 --> 00:28:27.880
So now,
I've achieved fault tolerance, right.

513
00:28:27.880 --> 00:28:31.941
Because, not only if one of those power
supplies goes bad, but, if one of

514
00:28:31.941 --> 00:28:36.550
the circuits behind that power supply
goes bad, we're still online, right?

515
00:28:36.550 --> 00:28:40.350
We still have our direct current
running into our devices.

516
00:28:40.350 --> 00:28:42.020
>> Makes perfect sense.

517
00:28:42.020 --> 00:28:43.140
>> And these are some of the things.

518
00:28:43.140 --> 00:28:46.203
And, you know, Zach,
I'm looking at the time.

519
00:28:46.203 --> 00:28:49.544
Zach's telling me might have to wrap this
one up here, but we've got a lot more to

520
00:28:49.544 --> 00:28:52.840
talk about when it comes to business
continuity and disaster recovery.

521
00:28:52.840 --> 00:28:55.990
But it does look like we're gonna
have to save that for another time.

522
00:28:55.990 --> 00:28:59.520
>> But awesome information as always
Wes I'm looking forward to part two of

523
00:28:59.520 --> 00:29:01.920
Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery.

524
00:29:01.920 --> 00:29:06.180
And see everything in the CompTIA Net+
series that Wes has put together for

525
00:29:06.180 --> 00:29:09.950
you and while you're in the course library
hundreds of other videos all designed to

526
00:29:09.950 --> 00:29:12.740
help you do one thing, go much further.

527
00:29:12.740 --> 00:29:14.170
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

528
00:29:14.170 --> 00:29:16.140
They'll be very glad you did.

529
00:29:16.140 --> 00:29:16.940
I'm Zach Memos.

530
00:29:16.940 --> 00:29:17.740
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

531
00:29:17.740 --> 00:29:20.370
>> Thanks for watching,
we'll see you soon.

532
00:29:20.370 --> 00:29:26.393
[MUSIC]

533
00:29:26.393 --> 00:29:29.685
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV.

helping you learn wherever you go.

7

I'm your host, Zach Memos,

And Wes Bryan has returned

Wes, great to have you here.

00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:33.786
That's right, we've got a lot of ways
that we can connect to our devices or

13
00:00:33.786 --> 00:00:34.803
our computers.

00:00:34.803 --> 00:00:37.503
And while we're not in the same
physical location as those computers,

00:00:37.503 --> 00:00:40.923
remember that's what we've been looking at
as we've been talking over the last, well,

16
00:00:40.923 --> 00:00:44.000
I guess we're working on a trilogy here,
the first couple of episodes, right?

17

We talked about VPN communication, showed
you a little bit about one of the oldies

that is still around out there, PPTP.

We also showed you L2TP, and IPSEC, and

21

Well, we got some other
remote access methods, right,

that we also need to talk about,
some additional protocols.

23
00:01:03.094 --> 00:01:05.940
And that's what we're gonna be
looking at here in this episode.

24
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:09.462
>> So remote access methods, Wes,
why wouldn't we be using Telnet?

25
00:01:09.462 --> 00:01:13.555
>> Yeah, Zach, we talked about Telnet
throughout this series, right?

26
00:01:13.555 --> 00:01:14.395
It's an oldie but goodie,.

27
00:01:14.395 --> 00:01:15.900
It's been around for a very long time.

28
00:01:15.900 --> 00:01:18.090
It goes all the way back
to the days of ARPANET.

29
00:01:18.090 --> 00:01:19.730
It had its heyday, right?

30
00:01:19.730 --> 00:01:23.525
And in those early days, we weren't really
worried about securing the communications

31
00:01:23.525 --> 00:01:26.200
cuz there weren't a lot of
communications going on, right?

32
00:01:26.200 --> 00:01:27.125
There was just a select few.

33
00:01:27.125 --> 00:01:27.949
>> It just wasn't as
important at that point.

34
00:01:27.949 --> 00:01:32.622
>> That's right, yeah, it wasn't after the
.com boom, right, where everybody was on

35
00:01:32.622 --> 00:01:35.922
this massive network, but
we have to worry about it, right?

36
00:01:35.922 --> 00:01:39.995
Even though it would allow your client
operating system to appear to a host

37
00:01:39.995 --> 00:01:43.479
centralized computing system
as being a dedicated terminal,

38
00:01:43.479 --> 00:01:44.940
it has problems, right?

39
00:01:44.940 --> 00:01:47.070
One of the problems is it doesn't
encrypt that information.

00:01:47.070 --> 00:01:49.000
And in fact, let's kind of show you why.

41
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:53.310
We've also talked about SSH, and
SSH is a remote access method, too.

42
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:56.790
So let's come up in our Ports and
Protocols episode, right,

43
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:00.840
cuz we gotta talk about the port and
the protocol and in general what it does.

44
00:02:00.840 --> 00:02:02.140
But let's see it in action, right?

45
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:05.100
And this also kind of ties together a lot
of things that we've talked about when

46
00:02:05.100 --> 00:02:06.380
it comes to security, right?

47
00:02:06.380 --> 00:02:08.840
We talk about mitigating some

00:25:58.730 --> 00:25:59.630
Here we go, right?

508
00:25:59.630 --> 00:26:04.140
We have our network interface layer
here with our ethernet, right?

509
00:26:04.140 --> 00:26:07.660
We have out internet
layer here with the IP.

510
00:26:07.660 --> 00:26:09.300
Transmission control protocol, right?

511
00:26:09.300 --> 00:26:11.392
That's the transport layer and

512
00:26:11.392 --> 00:26:15.274
part of the application layer
if you will in the TCIP model.

513
00:26:15.274 --> 00:26:17.730
And notice when I open up SSH.

514
00:26:19.310 --> 00:26:20.910
Notice that the encryption here.

515
00:26:20.910 --> 00:26:22.400
It's telling me what the encryption is.

516
00:26:23.510 --> 00:26:29.350
And if I open up the packet,
notice it's an encrypted packet.

517
00:26:29.350 --> 00:26:33.260
This is your encrypted information and
I can't tell what's going on here.

518
00:26:33.260 --> 00:26:35.780
And I can see it's got
a message authentication code

519
00:26:35.780 --> 00:26:38.800
to verify the integrity of
the information as well.

520
00:26:38.800 --> 00:26:40.560
So we're getting a confidentiality.

521
00:26:40.560 --> 00:26:42.370
We're getting the integrity and
the availability.

522
00:26:42.370 --> 00:26:43.500
That's CIA triad.

523
00:26:43.500 --> 00:26:47.000
So when I'm using something like SFTP,
I created a directory?

524
00:26:48.060 --> 00:26:51.300
Well, if you're not a part of
the communication, you don't know that.

525
00:26:51.300 --> 00:26:53.499
That's one of the beauties of
using something like SFTP.

526
00:26:53.499 --> 00:26:57.961
It's that you get the encrypted
communications between your client,

527
00:26:57.961 --> 00:27:00.550
your FTP client and the FTP server.

528
00:27:00.550 --> 00:27:04.100
And that encrypted tunnel makes to
where you don't even really know.

529
00:27:04.100 --> 00:27:04.724
Is it FTP?

530
00:27:04.724 --> 00:27:07.230
I don't see FTP in the list.

531
00:27:07.230 --> 00:27:10.890
Not a single thing tells me
that this is a FTP server.

532
00:27:10.890 --> 00:27:11.590
>> Right.

533
00:27:11.590 --> 00:27:13.010
>> And that's what we want.

534
00:27:13.010 --> 00:27:14.480
I don't want you to know what's going on.

535
00:27:14.480 --> 00:27:18.140
I don't want you to know that I'm creating
a directory called secret on an FTP

536
00:27:18.140 --> 00:27:20.080
server, right?

537
00:27:20.080 --> 00:27:22.130
So you can do that too.

538
00:27:22.130 --> 00:27:25.330
There's one more, and Zack, I know I've
completely run out of time on this one,

539
00:27:25.330 --> 00:27:28.690
but there is one last one remote access
method that I want to talk about, right?

540
00:27:28.690 --> 00:27:32.150
We've been mentioning FTP,
don't shy away from FTP.

541
00:27:32.150 --> 00:27:35.380
It's an excellent protocol for
large file transfers.

542
00:27:35.380 --> 00:27:37.750
One of the reasons it's still around,
it's been around, and

543
00:27:37.750 --> 00:27:40.190
it's going to stay around for a long time.

544
00:27:40.190 --> 00:27:41.460
Just secure it.

545
00:27:41.460 --> 00:27:44.980
You secure it, then the flaw that you
were worried about is gone, right?

546
00:27:44.980 --> 00:27:47.910
But there's also another type of FTP.

547
00:27:47.910 --> 00:27:52.929
If you don't need all the commands and
creating directories,

548
00:27:52.929 --> 00:27:57.096
traversing directories,
grabbing information,

549
00:27:57.096 --> 00:28:00.514
putting information up on the FTP server.

550
00:28:00.514 --> 00:28:04.185
Let's say you just need a little
firmware that needs to be downloaded or

551
00:28:04.185 --> 00:28:08.527
maybe you are a terminal and you connect
to a client and you connect to a server

552
00:28:08.527 --> 00:28:12.101
and you pull down and you pull down
your configuration information.

553
00:28:12.101 --> 00:28:16.725
Well i don't need a dedicated
connection-oriented servers like TCP

554
00:28:16.725 --> 00:28:18.460
handling that.

555
00:28:18.460 --> 00:28:21.950
Well, that's where something
known as TFTP comes in.

556
00:28:21.950 --> 00:28:24.961
The trivial file transfer protocol is

557
00:28:24.961 --> 00:28:29.582
basically FTP strip down center
over UDP for small files.

558
00:28:29.582 --> 00:28:31.777
You still did that file exchange, but

559
00:28:31.777 --> 00:28:35.758
you do not get all the added bonuses
of the commence structure that you

560
00:28:35.758 --> 00:28:40.900
get with FTP being able to do a lot of
stuff is just a need to pull down file.

561
00:28:40.900 --> 00:28:42.620
I need to pull down a config file.

562
00:28:42.620 --> 00:28:46.290
I need to pull down some configurations or
a firmware update, right?

563
00:28:46.290 --> 00:28:48.890
You might be doing that over your FTP.

564
00:28:48.890 --> 00:28:51.580
Or TFTP,
that's trivial file transfer protocol,

565
00:28:51.580 --> 00:28:55.280
stripped down version of
FTP that runs over UDP.

566
00:28:55.280 --> 00:28:58.504
Some of the remote access methods
that you have to be aware of,

567
00:28:58.504 --> 00:29:02.288
know some of the scenarios just in case
they ask you on that Net Plus exam.

568
00:29:02.288 --> 00:29:03.940
You're gonna be able to answer them.

569
00:29:03.940 --> 00:29:05.140
And not only answer them,

570
00:29:05.140 --> 00:29:08.090
you'll understand why the right
answer is the right answer.

571
00:29:08.090 --> 00:29:10.110
>> Fantastic job as always, Wes.

572
00:29:10.110 --> 00:29:12.784
And this is Remote Access Methods
part three, make sure you see

573
00:29:12.784 --> 00:29:15.811
Remote Access Methods part one and
two, and in fact see everything that

574
00:29:15.811 --> 00:29:18.897
will come to you in the Net Plus series
that Wes has put together for your.

575
00:29:18.897 --> 00:29:22.676
And the course library,
there's hundreds of other videos there and

576
00:29:22.676 --> 00:29:25.050
they are there to help you go further.

577
00:29:25.050 --> 00:29:27.560
To talk about you know about ITProTV,
love you.

578
00:29:27.560 --> 00:29:28.642
Very glad you did.

579
00:29:28.642 --> 00:29:29.497
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

580
00:29:29.497 --> 00:29:31.459
>> And I'm Wes Bryan, and
we will see you soon.

581
00:29:31.459 --> 00:29:38.975
[MUSIC]

582
00:29:38.975 --> 00:29:41.781
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes discuss various policy types such as NDAs, AUPs safety procedures, password policies....etc. They will also look at basic best practices.
episodes.title: Policies and Best Practices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:03.113
Welcome to ITPro.TV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.113 --> 00:00:08.530
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.530 --> 00:00:12.000
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.000 --> 00:00:14.179
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV,

5
00:00:14.179 --> 00:00:16.651
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.651 --> 00:00:18.150
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:18.150 --> 00:00:19.680
As we continue on with CompTee and

8
00:00:19.680 --> 00:00:23.310
NetPlus, the title of this episode
is policies and best practises.

9
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:26.290
And the person who's gonna tell
us all about that is Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:27.080
Wes good to have you.

11
00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:27.650
>> Hey Zach.

12
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:28.490
Thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:28.490 --> 00:00:30.920
That's right.
Now we get to get into more of the paper

14
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:31.630
work, right?

15
00:00:31.630 --> 00:00:35.840
When we talk about policies,
procedures, best practices, right?

16
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:38.877
So we are going to be looking at,
well, documentation, really,

17
00:00:38.877 --> 00:00:40.030
when it comes down to it.

18
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:41.730
When we talk about policies,

19
00:00:41.730 --> 00:00:47.240
in security we usually implement
some kind of layer defence system.

20
00:00:47.240 --> 00:00:49.660
We don't usually use
one type of technology.

21
00:00:49.660 --> 00:00:51.900
We use multiple technologies, right?

22
00:00:51.900 --> 00:00:56.160
And one of those layers,
the very first layer, if you will,

23
00:00:56.160 --> 00:00:59.720
is policies, procedure,
and awareness, right?

24
00:00:59.720 --> 00:01:04.969
So that's really a major point in
securing your infrastructure when

25
00:01:04.969 --> 00:01:10.410
we talk about networks, as well as
keeping things like your data safe.

26
00:01:10.410 --> 00:01:13.844
So we are going to be looking at
some best practices, and again,

27
00:01:13.844 --> 00:01:18.297
some common best practices, because keep
in mind that everything changes a little

28
00:01:18.297 --> 00:01:22.051
bit depending on what company you work for
and one policy that works for

29
00:01:22.051 --> 00:01:24.914
some companies might not work for
other companies and

30
00:01:24.914 --> 00:01:27.680
best practices again is
more of a generalization.

31
00:01:27.680 --> 00:01:30.310
So you need to be aware of these for
the exam.

32
00:01:30.310 --> 00:01:32.100
So one of the first things that
we're gonna dive in we're in,

33
00:01:32.100 --> 00:01:36.890
we're gonna talk about concept known
as privileged user management.

34
00:01:36.890 --> 00:01:39.620
And this is very, very important
inside of your infrastructure.

35
00:01:39.620 --> 00:01:42.850
>> And Wes, when you talk about
privileged user agreement here.

36
00:01:42.850 --> 00:01:46.150
Are you talking about a manager or are you
talking about a system administrator?

37
00:01:46.150 --> 00:01:47.120
Is that what we are talking about?

38
00:01:47.120 --> 00:01:47.810
>> That's right.
You know,

39
00:01:47.810 --> 00:01:50.140
when you talk about a privileges or
agreement you're talking,

40
00:01:50.140 --> 00:01:52.080
first of all, documentation, right?

41
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:55.250
Documentation that you have,
things like your systems administrators,

42
00:01:55.250 --> 00:01:57.250
that's exactly right, Zach.

43
00:01:57.250 --> 00:02:01.330
Systems administrators, people who have
essentially the keys to the kingdom,

44
00:02:01.330 --> 00:02:03.310
I have heard it put before, right?

45
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:07.100
If you have a powerful role, right,

46
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:11.820
there is a potential for
that role to get or the access level,

47
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:15.930
right, we talk in other episodes we talk
about things like authentication and

48
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:19.700
authorization, and with the privileged
users, they are typically authorized.

49
00:02:19.700 --> 00:02:23.370
They have the privileges,
they are authorized to do more

50
00:02:23.370 --> 00:02:27.460
things than just the average standard
end user within our networks, right.

51
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:33.750
And you've heard that saying, with great
power comes a lot of responsibility.

52
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:35.550
It's a great responsibility.

53
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:38.950
And they say absolute power
corrupts absolutely, right?

54
00:02:38.950 --> 00:02:39.860
>> Absolutely.

55
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:40.660
>> Absolutely, so

56
00:02:40.660 --> 00:02:44.750
we'll see how many times we can say that
word here inside of this episode today.

57
00:02:44.750 --> 00:02:47.030
So privileged user agreement,

58
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:51.270
this again is just a policy that is put
into place that somebody like a system

59
00:02:51.270 --> 00:02:55.160
administrator, maybe even a C
level employee has to sign, right?

60
00:02:55.160 --> 00:02:59.290
Because again, they have a level of access
that your standard users don't have.

61
00:02:59.290 --> 00:03:03.320
A level of access, too, so why might
you need a policy like that, right?

62
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:07.110
Well, when we look at it,
malicious insiders,

63
00:03:07.110 --> 00:03:12.470
we talk about threat actors in other
CompTee courses that we teach,

64
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:14.760
like for instance,
inside of security plus, right?

65
00:03:14.760 --> 00:03:18.880
We talk about the roles that different
actors, bad actors, if you will,

66
00:03:18.880 --> 00:03:22.170
that we talk about an app
within your company or

67
00:03:22.170 --> 00:03:24.250
we are just against your company,
if you will.

68
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:28.360
And one of them
are the malicious insiders.

69
00:03:28.360 --> 00:03:32.270
Malicious insiders are a major treat or

70
00:03:32.270 --> 00:03:35.460
can be a major threat to any organization,
right?

71
00:03:35.460 --> 00:03:40.830
Well, we have to worry about things like
system sabotage, things like data theft.

72
00:03:40.830 --> 00:03:42.640
Theft of your systems too.

73
00:03:42.640 --> 00:03:44.380
Introduction of bad code.

74
00:03:44.380 --> 00:03:47.520
You got somebody who says hey,
knows they're gonna be fired.

75
00:03:47.520 --> 00:03:51.016
Well, we also talk about on-boarding and
off-boarding procedures.

76
00:03:51.016 --> 00:03:54.190
On-boarding is that systematic
approach to hiring somebody and

77
00:03:54.190 --> 00:03:57.910
bringing him into your network, a lot of
the documentation that we're talking about

78
00:03:57.910 --> 00:04:00.640
they might have to sign as part
of the on-boarding process.

79
00:04:00.640 --> 00:04:03.460
Well part of the good off-boarding
process too is when you

80
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:08.280
have somebody like a privileged user, they
know or your company knows that they're

81
00:04:08.280 --> 00:04:11.920
gonna be terminated, then there has to be
an appropriate systematic off-boarding

82
00:04:11.920 --> 00:04:15.650
process to make sure that they can't do
things like sabotage your systems, right?

83
00:04:15.650 --> 00:04:19.690
Introduction, bad code, you've got
a developer that's on the way out and

84
00:04:19.690 --> 00:04:23.180
they slipstream in some bad code,
maybe in software that you're developing,

85
00:04:23.180 --> 00:04:27.190
causes some kind of undesired effect,
if you will, and

86
00:04:27.190 --> 00:04:32.880
maybe causes some kind of damage to
a product that you're working with.

87
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:38.140
Slip streaming things like malware into
your code or into your systems too, or

88
00:04:38.140 --> 00:04:42.260
just introducing things like unauthorized
hardware and unauthorized software, right?

89
00:04:42.260 --> 00:04:45.190
We also have a licensing restrictions
that we have to worry about too.

90
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:48.630
And if we put a piece
of software into play,

91
00:04:48.630 --> 00:04:50.180
company have the license for it right?

92
00:04:50.180 --> 00:04:54.030
So privileged users, again,
we have to manage them appropriately and

93
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:57.390
according to your
privileged user agreement.

94
00:04:57.390 --> 00:05:01.790
You might have things like certain
levels of responsibility and

95
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:05.590
ways that not only does that
person meet that agreement, but

96
00:05:05.590 --> 00:05:08.450
then what are some ways that we
enforce that agreement right?

97
00:05:08.450 --> 00:05:10.610
That's why we talk about things
like separation of duties, right?

98
00:05:10.610 --> 00:05:13.080
Two keys on the launchpad.

99
00:05:13.080 --> 00:05:16.090
Not anyone person has all that power.

100
00:05:16.090 --> 00:05:18.320
There is some kind of accountability,

101
00:05:18.320 --> 00:05:22.070
accountability could be things like
mandatory vacation, all right.

102
00:05:22.070 --> 00:05:24.340
You're gonna take a week off here Zach,

103
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:26.130
because we know you're
the systems administrator.

104
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:28.040
We just kinda want to
audit what you're doing.

105
00:05:28.040 --> 00:05:32.170
So auditing, we talked about auditing and
logging and other episodes too, and

106
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:34.930
that is tracking those events, right?

107
00:05:34.930 --> 00:05:36.070
Least privilege.

108
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:38.440
We talk about the principle
of least privilege, right?

109
00:05:38.440 --> 00:05:43.400
You give only the level of privilege
that a user needs to perform their job,

110
00:05:43.400 --> 00:05:44.390
no more, no less.

111
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:47.890
Now, there's also called
privilege bracketing, too.

112
00:05:47.890 --> 00:05:49.410
And that's another way
that you can do that.

113
00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:52.140
Which means if you need that privilege,
I give it to you so

114
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:53.300
you can accomplish your job.

115
00:05:53.300 --> 00:05:57.410
And then once that's done,
we end up taking that privilege from you.

116
00:05:57.410 --> 00:06:00.260
Privilege user agreement might even
be somebody as simple as a contract

117
00:06:00.260 --> 00:06:02.950
where they can get into a certain
area that normally people,

118
00:06:02.950 --> 00:06:05.390
the average public,
wouldn't have access to, right?

119
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:08.880
So privilege bracketing says hey,
while you are in this building,

120
00:06:08.880 --> 00:06:12.110
while you are contracting and
doing a job for us,

121
00:06:12.110 --> 00:06:15.940
you have this level of privilege that you
can get into this maybe restricted area.

122
00:06:15.940 --> 00:06:19.020
But then once that job is done,
privilege bracketing says yeah,

123
00:06:19.020 --> 00:06:23.450
I gave you those privileges but now
that it's done, we remove them from you.

124
00:06:23.450 --> 00:06:25.880
So job rotations are other
ways that you can do that.

125
00:06:25.880 --> 00:06:29.130
And the big thing is
tracking those activities.

126
00:06:29.130 --> 00:06:32.200
Now the next thing that they talk about
is what's known as a password policy.

127
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:36.202
And password policies are important
because passwords, a lot of time,

128
00:06:36.202 --> 00:06:40.793
are the very first line, attack vector,
if you will, the first line of attack that

129
00:06:40.793 --> 00:06:43.941
anybody that's on the outside
of your organization, or

130
00:06:43.941 --> 00:06:47.310
maybe inside your organization,
is going to try to attack.

131
00:06:47.310 --> 00:06:49.730
So password policies are important.

132
00:06:49.730 --> 00:06:54.550
You might have, and most likely will,
have some kind of documentation, that

133
00:06:54.550 --> 00:06:58.850
lays out what the password policy and how
that you are going to adhere to a policy,

134
00:06:58.850 --> 00:07:02.062
but what does a password
policy help us to do?

135
00:07:02.062 --> 00:07:06.080
All right, well it helps to increase the
resilience of our passwords to things like

136
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:07.550
password attacks.

137
00:07:07.550 --> 00:07:11.000
Now, you could see there's actually
inside of your Windows Operating System.

138
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:12.200
I'm on a server right here.

139
00:07:12.200 --> 00:07:14.930
Windows Server 2012 machine and

140
00:07:14.930 --> 00:07:18.670
we can say that we actually have
password policies in effect by default.

141
00:07:18.670 --> 00:07:22.470
So for instance if I just bring
up our server manager dashboard.

142
00:07:22.470 --> 00:07:26.040
We go over here to tools and when you
scroll down a little bit you're gonna see

143
00:07:26.040 --> 00:07:29.790
that well hey, there's Group Policy
Management Console, right, the GPMC.

144
00:07:29.790 --> 00:07:33.320
Now the Group Policy Management Console is
important because this is how we push out

145
00:07:33.320 --> 00:07:40.510
policies, but those polices define
what is the computing environment.

146
00:07:40.510 --> 00:07:42.791
How is it going to affect the users?

147
00:07:42.791 --> 00:07:46.369
Can be restrictive,
are we gonna not allow certain things,

148
00:07:46.369 --> 00:07:51.141
but in the context of a password policy,
we have what's known as a default domain

149
00:07:51.141 --> 00:07:54.605
policy over here in our group
policy management console.

150
00:07:54.605 --> 00:07:56.267
So let me go ahead and just show you.

151
00:07:56.267 --> 00:07:57.681
We take a look at this, right?

152
00:07:57.681 --> 00:08:01.598
And we can kind of define what makes
up the components that make up password

153
00:08:01.598 --> 00:08:02.112
policy.

154
00:08:02.112 --> 00:08:05.032
And if I basically just go ahead and

00:17:30.440 --> 00:17:31.787
And you couple that.

00:17:31.787 --> 00:17:34.530
And that's the other reason things like
digital is good because it's easy to do

time stamping.

00:17:36.200 --> 00:17:38.270
So, again, the other thing about digital,

00:17:38.270 --> 00:17:40.310
remember, we said that
better video quality?

00:17:40.310 --> 00:17:42.830
One of the things that you can get

00:17:42.830 --> 00:17:46.420
And that's good when you have

00:17:46.420 --> 00:17:50.960
When we talk about data forensics,
we talk about data forensics one of

00:17:50.960 --> 00:17:54.110
the methods of data forensics

00:17:54.110 --> 00:17:57.360
And when we say video surveillance
if somebody has broke into a certain

area we can scrutinize

00:18:01.160 --> 00:18:05.110

you said you didn't do it.

The camera doesn't lie.

00:18:06.170 --> 00:18:08.003
The camera's seeing that you did it,

So if we got high definition, good

00:18:12.497 --> 00:18:17.204

00:18:17.204 --> 00:18:20.958

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:23.947
>> [LAUGH]
>> The other cool thing about this too is

00:18:23.947 --> 00:18:28.270
you have the potential for wider viewing

336
00:18:28.270 --> 00:18:30.710
And the remote monitoring

00:18:30.710 --> 00:18:35.010
is fairly simplistic because all
you need is an Internet connection.

00:18:35.010 --> 00:18:38.270
We can put IP based cameras on there and
connect over an IP based network so

00:18:38.270 --> 00:18:40.690
the installation gets a little easier,

340
00:18:40.690 --> 00:18:42.660
Because you don't have to
run things like extra power.

00:18:42.660 --> 00:18:47.080
You can slap on your network a POE,

342
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:49.410
And I don't have to make sure
that I have AC adapters for

00:18:49.410 --> 00:18:51.170

344
00:18:51.170 --> 00:18:54.425
All I gotta do is run power

00:18:54.425 --> 00:18:56.126
And not only do I get the power, but

00:18:56.126 --> 00:18:59.210
I also get the remote

347
00:18:59.210 --> 00:19:00.950
Less cabling, easier installation.

00:19:02.370 --> 00:19:04.496
Analog is also a viable solution.

00:19:04.496 --> 00:19:11.221
But it's a little more costly equipment,

00:19:11.221 --> 00:19:16.588
Does have some of the downfalls but

00:19:16.588 --> 00:19:18.950
The next thing that we have

00:19:18.950 --> 00:19:20.011

All right, when we say tagging we're

00:19:35.840 --> 00:19:36.691
So for instance,

00:19:36.691 --> 00:19:40.568
if you have projectors that maybe you

00:19:40.568 --> 00:19:43.622

00:19:43.622 --> 00:19:46.771

00:19:46.771 --> 00:19:49.149

00:19:50.170 --> 00:19:52.220
Right, things like your laptops.

00:19:52.220 --> 00:19:55.740

00:19:55.740 --> 00:19:57.780

00:19:57.780 --> 00:20:00.620
Could be machinery,

00:20:00.620 --> 00:20:04.190
I know that our director team that

And we monitor and

You put an asset tag on that and you

00:20:19.350 --> 00:20:21.910

00:20:21.910 --> 00:20:23.280
When's the last time it was serviced?

Do we need to schedule for maintenance?

We've got five pieces of video equipment.

00:20:30.460 --> 00:20:31.670
One of them needs a repair.

377
00:20:32.790 --> 00:20:36.097
Well, wouldn't it be nice just to have
that tag and you have that, again,

378
00:20:36.097 --> 00:20:38.984
that centralized location that you
can see all of these things and

00:20:38.984 --> 00:20:41.040
it becomes visual for you, right?

00:20:41.040 --> 00:20:46.940
And you can acquiesce that data at any

00:20:46.940 --> 00:20:50.720
basically allowing your company,
if you will, to just easily gather data

382
00:20:50.720 --> 00:20:55.360

pinpoint things like their locations.

00:20:55.360 --> 00:20:57.716
All right, not only monitoring

00:20:57.716 --> 00:21:00.086
We can automate the inventory
side of things,

00:21:00.086 --> 00:21:03.917

as well as preventing the loss and

00:21:03.917 --> 00:21:07.600
regulate management and

00:21:07.600 --> 00:21:10.060
Why do we manage compliance,

00:21:10.060 --> 00:21:13.710
Well, if I've got a server that's storing

Where's the hard drive.

00:21:26.690 --> 00:21:28.670
So, again, this a good way to track.

All right, so Zach, one of the last

>> [LAUGH]
>> Three strikes you're out [LAUGH].

00:21:38.346 --> 00:21:41.295
As far as detection goes is
what's known as tamper detection.

00:21:41.295 --> 00:21:45.720
Now you've probably seen this before,
tamper detection.

00:21:45.720 --> 00:21:46.800
Now, tamper detection,

401
00:21:46.800 --> 00:21:51.360
one of the examples I have is like
if you've ever opened up a computer.

00:21:51.360 --> 00:21:52.760
And you've got a warranty on it, right?

403
00:21:52.760 --> 00:21:55.680
Maybe you've got a really good warranty on

404
00:21:55.680 --> 00:21:59.400

seal's broken, you void your warranty.

405
00:21:59.400 --> 00:22:02.700
Well, that's tamper detection, all right?

406
00:22:02.700 --> 00:22:05.975
You return that computer and
say, it's broke.

407
00:22:05.975 --> 00:22:07.595
So, well, did you fix it?

408
00:22:07.595 --> 00:22:09.625
No.
Well, yes you did according to what

00:22:09.625 --> 00:22:11.435
that sticker looks like it's broke.

410
00:22:11.435 --> 00:22:14.495
It looks like you removed it cuz

411
00:22:14.495 --> 00:22:16.945
When we do, we remove the sticker and
we replace it with a new one.

412
00:22:18.430 --> 00:22:21.300
Now, Zach, you have a good example
of tampered detection, right?

413
00:22:21.300 --> 00:22:23.768
>> Yeah, like the security tapes
on a gas pump for instance.

414
00:22:23.768 --> 00:22:25.460

00:22:25.460 --> 00:22:27.462

And that's one we see almost

00:22:33.182 --> 00:22:34.940

419
00:22:34.940 --> 00:22:35.954

00:22:35.954 --> 00:22:39.630
And how many times you been to the pump

00:22:39.630 --> 00:22:42.747
stamp that's across it that's
letting you know that hey,

00:22:42.747 --> 00:22:45.489

423
00:22:45.489 --> 00:22:50.595

424
00:22:50.595 --> 00:22:51.715
Great example right?

425
00:22:53.645 --> 00:22:54.426
There's other ones.

00:22:54.426 --> 00:22:58.521
But what it boils down to is it gives

00:22:58.521 --> 00:23:02.749

a compromise of any device, a system or

00:23:02.749 --> 00:23:07.523
like we're talking about hard drives the

Back in the day the emperor's seal, the

00:23:13.384 --> 00:23:15.204
I mean that's-

You better believe it,

00:23:22.153 --> 00:23:24.280
And again, wow, that's awesome, man.

00:23:24.280 --> 00:23:25.444
There's other cool things too.

00:23:25.444 --> 00:23:28.016
Like for

electrical systems,
they put certain sensors in there,

00:23:30.946 --> 00:23:34.020

00:23:34.020 --> 00:23:37.590
And if that variation,
if it's not constant or

00:23:37.590 --> 00:23:42.640
they see the variation they know that

00:23:42.640 --> 00:23:46.155
Or, if you're talking about networks,

00:23:46.155 --> 00:23:49.850

00:23:49.850 --> 00:23:51.835
there's a wave pattern, a waveform.

00:23:51.835 --> 00:23:56.315
Well, you can put a cable in there that
hooks to an alert system that monitors

447
00:23:56.315 --> 00:23:57.368
the wavelength.

448
00:23:57.368 --> 00:23:59.612
And if it sees a variation
in the wavelength,

449
00:23:59.612 --> 00:24:03.511
the passive cable that's on the outside
sends an alert, triggers a monitor,

450
00:24:03.511 --> 00:24:06.780
triggers an alert to a monitoring
system and lets you know, hey.

451
00:24:06.780 --> 00:24:09.879
Something's going on with
your fiber optic cable.

452
00:24:09.879 --> 00:24:14.365
Because fiber optic cables,
it's not so easy to splice-and-dice.

453
00:24:14.365 --> 00:24:15.718
You need a lot of equipment.

454
00:24:15.718 --> 00:24:17.990
You need some expensive
equipment to get in there.

455
00:24:17.990 --> 00:24:21.710
And if that waveform varies at all,
there's detecting,

456
00:24:21.710 --> 00:24:26.420
it allows you to detect
some tampering might go on.

457
00:24:26.420 --> 00:24:28.910
All right, basically,
disruption of the wave form.

00:24:28.910 --> 00:24:32.277
There's other things too, tamper

Other then the obvious sign of it,

All right, boy I can tell you,

And what we do is we touch it to
