546
00:28:27.400 --> 00:28:31.960
And the door either opens or
it prevents people from going in, right?

547
00:28:31.960 --> 00:28:34.220
Your door is one of your
first lines of defense.

548
00:28:34.220 --> 00:28:35.180
And I gotta be careful.

549
00:28:35.180 --> 00:28:40.252
That's why I went ahead and prefaced this
with defense indepth because policies and

550
00:28:40.252 --> 00:28:42.044
awareness are technically.

551
00:28:42.044 --> 00:28:44.935
The other thing is to get a lock.

552
00:28:44.935 --> 00:28:47.915
And in fact we couple this with locks too.

553
00:28:47.915 --> 00:28:51.805
Now we've got, and that's why I said,
some of these they shake hands with here.

554
00:28:51.805 --> 00:28:54.185
We're doing multiple
prevention techniques.

555
00:28:54.185 --> 00:28:55.575
We've got badge.

556
00:28:55.575 --> 00:28:58.352
We've got RFID key fob.

557
00:28:58.352 --> 00:29:04.547
And then we also got the doors that have
the locks on them that these trigger.

558
00:29:04.547 --> 00:29:08.498
But don't put it outside of just
the old traditional key and

559
00:29:08.498 --> 00:29:12.222
lock, lock and key, or
pinlock entries with a little.

560
00:29:12.222 --> 00:29:15.165
I worked for a restaurant that if you
wanted to get into the employee area,

561
00:29:15.165 --> 00:29:16.317
it had a little pin pad on it.

562
00:29:16.317 --> 00:29:19.670
You just dial the four digits and
you open the door.

563
00:29:19.670 --> 00:29:21.200
You make your way in.

564
00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:25.820
But if you really want to get fancy,
that's when you go with biometrics.

565
00:29:25.820 --> 00:29:28.740
Now biometrics is also
a prevention method.

566
00:29:28.740 --> 00:29:30.670
But this works on
the authentication factors,

567
00:29:30.670 --> 00:29:32.530
that we also talk about
in another episode.

568
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:37.421
But lets go ahead, review just those
three authentication factors, right?

569
00:29:37.421 --> 00:29:40.798
The most common three authentication
factors are something you know,

570
00:29:40.798 --> 00:29:43.450
something you have and something you are.

571
00:29:43.450 --> 00:29:46.920
Something you know is the username and
password, a pin, security question, right?

572
00:29:46.920 --> 00:29:51.840
Something you have is kinda like the card
that I have, right, or a key fob.

573
00:29:51.840 --> 00:29:55.710
Something you are is some physical or
sociological characteristic of yourself,

574
00:29:55.710 --> 00:29:59.197
a fingerprint, voice recognition,
retinal pattern, hand geometry.

575
00:29:59.197 --> 00:30:01.900
That's something that's unique to me,
right?

576
00:30:01.900 --> 00:30:04.520
Well, if you use that as
your form of authentication,

577
00:30:04.520 --> 00:30:06.720
that's where you get biometrics, right?

578
00:30:06.720 --> 00:30:09.970
That's biometrics,
is that something you are.

579
00:30:09.970 --> 00:30:14.340
And this, if you would have been asking
me when I started teaching about a decade

580
00:30:14.340 --> 00:30:19.020
ago, I would have said man,
this is mission impossible stuff.

581
00:30:19.020 --> 00:30:21.398
This is expensive as all get out.

582
00:30:21.398 --> 00:30:23.633
And well, it can still be.

583
00:30:23.633 --> 00:30:27.298
But they got these integrated into our
smartphones now and basic devices.

584
00:30:27.298 --> 00:30:32.835
An all out biometric security system
can get very expensive, right?

585
00:30:32.835 --> 00:30:36.507
And that's why you're typically only
gonna see this in highly secure areas or

586
00:30:36.507 --> 00:30:39.731
the companies that when they say there
is a problem we just throw money

587
00:30:39.731 --> 00:30:40.479
at it, right?

588
00:30:40.479 --> 00:30:43.290
If you just throw money at it
then you're just fine, right?

589
00:30:43.290 --> 00:30:48.022
So biometrics, again using some
kind of physical characteristic of

590
00:30:48.022 --> 00:30:51.693
yourself to prevent access
to some kind of restricted

591
00:30:51.693 --> 00:30:55.217
area that only authorized
personnel should be in.

592
00:30:55.217 --> 00:30:58.766
So these are a handful of the devices
that you should be aware of,

593
00:30:58.766 --> 00:31:00.620
the physical security devices.

594
00:31:00.620 --> 00:31:04.690
Understand that this is
the second line of defense.

595
00:31:04.690 --> 00:31:07.090
Make sure I get that right
in the defense indepth.

596
00:31:07.090 --> 00:31:09.940
Keep in mind that they break
down into a couple of concepts.

597
00:31:09.940 --> 00:31:13.220
Detection, prevention, right?

598
00:31:13.220 --> 00:31:16.270
Now I don't know which side
of the tracks you're on.

599
00:31:16.270 --> 00:31:18.610
You could say well,
shouldn't we prevent before we detect, or

600
00:31:18.610 --> 00:31:19.890
detect before we prevent.

601
00:31:19.890 --> 00:31:21.690
There's no right way or wrong way, right?

602
00:31:21.690 --> 00:31:25.010
There's never one way fits all,
one size fits all for security.

603
00:31:25.010 --> 00:31:29.006
Remember when it comes to security, it's
really never a destination to be reached.

604
00:31:29.006 --> 00:31:31.141
It's only a journey to be traveled upon.

605
00:31:31.141 --> 00:31:32.320
>> Fantastic, Wes.

606
00:31:32.320 --> 00:31:34.910
There's levels of security
we all need to be aware of.

607
00:31:34.910 --> 00:31:37.807
So, physical security devices
is the name of this episode.

608
00:31:37.807 --> 00:31:38.910
Hopefully you enjoyed that.

609
00:31:38.910 --> 00:31:39.960
I'm sure you did.

610
00:31:39.960 --> 00:31:43.152
Make sure you watch every single
episode of the CompTIA Net+ series

611
00:31:43.152 --> 00:31:45.880
that Wes has put together for
you, it will help you.

612
00:31:45.880 --> 00:31:47.350
And while you're in the course library,

613
00:31:47.350 --> 00:31:51.380
there's hundreds of other videos all
designed to help you go further.

614
00:31:51.380 --> 00:31:52.890
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

615
00:31:52.890 --> 00:31:54.440
They'll be very glad you did.

616
00:31:54.440 --> 00:31:55.930
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

617
00:31:55.930 --> 00:31:56.780
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

618
00:31:56.780 --> 00:32:05.041
>> And we will see you soon.

619
00:32:05.041 --> 00:32:07.185
[MUSIC]
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore various authentication technologies like RADIUS, SSO, LDAP, certificates.....etc. They will also look at different access control mechanisms such as RADIUS, TACACS+ and Kerberos.
episodes.title: Authentication and Access Control
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.627
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.627 --> 00:00:05.861
I'm your host, Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.861 --> 00:00:08.482
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.482 --> 00:00:10.642
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

5
00:00:10.642 --> 00:00:15.880
choosing To the ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:20.970
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with CompTIA Net+ Authentication and

7
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:23.520
Access Control, the name of this episode.

8
00:00:23.520 --> 00:00:26.089
And Wes Bryan is here to help us out,
show us the way.

9
00:00:26.089 --> 00:00:27.420
Wes, great to have you here, thanks.

10
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:28.820
>> Hey Zach, thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:31.790
That's right, we're gonna be looking at,
well Zach's already told you, right.

12
00:00:31.790 --> 00:00:34.710
We're gonna be looking at
authentication and access control, and

13
00:00:34.710 --> 00:00:36.920
some of the components
that you find within it.

14
00:00:36.920 --> 00:00:40.251
And we're definitely gonna be hitting
you with some more acronyms and

15
00:00:40.251 --> 00:00:42.745
some specifications
standardization if you will.

16
00:00:42.745 --> 00:00:44.545
And you're gonna need to know this for

17
00:00:44.545 --> 00:00:48.470
the Net+ exam when it comes to sitting
the hot seat, that's right, in the exam.

18
00:00:48.470 --> 00:00:51.804
So let's go ahead and let's dive
right into some of those topics.

19
00:00:51.804 --> 00:00:54.500
>> Yeah.
>> Now go under the exam objectives here,

20
00:00:54.500 --> 00:00:58.120
they talk about three concepts,
right and they mention authorization,

21
00:00:58.120 --> 00:00:59.480
authentication, and accounting.

22
00:01:00.610 --> 00:01:04.770
I'm gonna kinda move this around a little
bit here and describe what those are and

23
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:07.770
then talk about some of the technologies
that we have to perform

24
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:08.626
those three things.

25
00:01:08.626 --> 00:01:12.040
So, let's go ahead, and instead of
talking about authorization first,

26
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:14.470
let's talk about authentication,
all right?

27
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:17.670
Because with those three concepts,
you might hear a AAA, right?

28
00:01:17.670 --> 00:01:20.060
You might hear and
I'm not talking about insurance, right?

29
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:23.963
We're talking about AAAs and
authentication, authorization, and

30
00:01:23.963 --> 00:01:25.690
then accounting, all right?

31
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:29.350
Sometimes accounting you might even hear
it called auditing as well too, right?

32
00:01:29.350 --> 00:01:31.350
So what is authentication?

33
00:01:31.350 --> 00:01:35.110
Well, authentication is proving
you are who you say you are.

34
00:01:35.110 --> 00:01:36.550
Who are you, all right?

35
00:01:36.550 --> 00:01:42.510
And then we have well, authorization and
authorization is about what can you do,

36
00:01:42.510 --> 00:01:45.425
and then accounting is about
tracking those activities.

37
00:01:45.425 --> 00:01:48.048
And if you want a really
basic way to understand it,

38
00:01:48.048 --> 00:01:49.885
I wish I could take credit for this.

39
00:01:49.885 --> 00:01:54.623
But some another instructor that I was
sitting there watching one of the things

40
00:01:54.623 --> 00:01:59.072
that they were doing said, it really
boils down to these three concepts,

41
00:01:59.072 --> 00:02:03.060
who are you, what can you do,
and then, what did you do?

42
00:02:03.060 --> 00:02:05.360
If you look at right, authentication.

43
00:02:05.360 --> 00:02:06.150
Who are you, right?

44
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:07.300
Zach, I know it's Zach.

45
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:08.730
Well, how do I know it's Zach?

46
00:02:08.730 --> 00:02:13.964
Well, on the onboarding process,
he provided his identification, right?

47
00:02:13.964 --> 00:02:16.298
Once he had his identification proven and

48
00:02:16.298 --> 00:02:20.150
then came on the onboarding
process he was given a keycard.

49
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:24.050
That keycard is the way he authenticates,
he touches it to the door.

50
00:02:24.050 --> 00:02:26.780
We've got one, I've got one in my
back pocket right here, right,

51
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:29.690
we prove we are who we say we are.

52
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:33.230
Then, we have to determine what
level of access do you have?

53
00:02:33.230 --> 00:02:34.190
What can you do?

54
00:02:34.190 --> 00:02:35.770
That's the authorization part.

55
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:38.443
I can't authorize you to do something or

56
00:02:38.443 --> 00:02:42.147
even not do something until
we've authenticated you.

57
00:02:42.147 --> 00:02:45.236
And then once that's done, once we've
determined, well, Zach, you know what,

58
00:02:45.236 --> 00:02:47.990
you've got these seven, and
I'm just throwing these numbers out there.

59
00:02:47.990 --> 00:02:51.400
You've got these seven doors that
you're allowed to enter and access.

60
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:53.810
We've got some other tenants that
are within this building, and

61
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:58.740
here at ITProTV and those doors are for
those businesses, right?

62
00:02:58.740 --> 00:03:02.822
And if Zach touches his keycard to those
doors, it's gonna get an access denied,

63
00:03:02.822 --> 00:03:05.400
right, because he's not authorized.

64
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:07.893
That's not part of what
he's allowed to do.

65
00:03:07.893 --> 00:03:09.490
And same thing with me,
I mean I'm not picking.

66
00:03:09.490 --> 00:03:10.710
Thank you for
letting me pick on you, Zach.

67
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:12.706
But same thing for me as well, right.

68
00:03:12.706 --> 00:03:18.939
And then finally, we need a mechanism
that says, well Zach, what did you do?

69
00:03:18.939 --> 00:03:21.410
When you were in the building,
if I needed to check out,

70
00:03:21.410 --> 00:03:23.480
what doors did you go through?

71
00:03:23.480 --> 00:03:25.140
Well, I need a way to track that.

72
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:27.030
And that's accounting or
auditing, if you will.

73
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:31.290
It's tracking system-wide
events that happen, all right?

74
00:03:31.290 --> 00:03:35.880
So, who are you, what can you do,
and then what did you do?

75
00:03:35.880 --> 00:03:38.080
And you have to understand too,
that identification and

76
00:03:38.080 --> 00:03:39.520
authentication are a little bit different.

77
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:41.690
A lot of people say, well, identification.

78
00:03:41.690 --> 00:03:45.239
Now notice I said,
it didn't tell me the keycard, right.

79
00:03:45.239 --> 00:03:47.810
It doesn't tell me Zach
is who he says he is,

80
00:03:47.810 --> 00:03:50.610
it just means that he's got a keycard,
right.

81
00:03:50.610 --> 00:03:53.610
Authentication is actually
preceded by identification, right.

82
00:03:54.660 --> 00:04:00.400
That ensures that the person who they say
they are is truly who they say they are,

83
00:04:00.400 --> 00:04:02.060
that's identification and

84
00:04:02.060 --> 00:04:04.840
that's usually the predecessor
to being authenticated, right.

85
00:04:04.840 --> 00:04:07.997
I have to prove that I'm supposed
to be on this network, right?

86
00:04:07.997 --> 00:04:11.430
And one of the ways I do that is
part of the onboarding process.

87
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:16.635
I fill out my application for employment,
I provide my Social Security card and

88
00:04:16.635 --> 00:04:20.612
I provide my drivers license,
state issued id, all right.

89
00:04:20.612 --> 00:04:24.490
And then once that's done, now I get
a keycard and I can authenticate.

90
00:04:24.490 --> 00:04:27.990
Right, identification is about proving
that a person that has credentials

91
00:04:27.990 --> 00:04:29.870
is the person that should
own those credentials.

92
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:33.870
And then once that's done,
I can now be authorized.

93
00:04:33.870 --> 00:04:37.710
Now, the other thing too
is an unauthorized person,

94
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:39.560
they need to try to authenticate as well.

95
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:42.560
And let me tell you why then,
cuz authorization is after authentication,

96
00:04:42.560 --> 00:04:43.800
and let me give you an example.

97
00:04:43.800 --> 00:04:49.002
Let's say Zach, okay, you're gonna
go into the conference room, right.

98
00:04:49.002 --> 00:04:52.479
Your authentication is you touch
the key fob to the door or

99
00:04:52.479 --> 00:04:55.510
the card to the door and
it opens, all right.

100
00:04:55.510 --> 00:04:59.900
So that says, hey, we know it's Zach,
we know that he's authorized, right,

101
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:00.860
allowed to be in there.

102
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:03.370
And then we also have a system
that's tracking that fact that he

103
00:05:03.370 --> 00:05:06.090
did enter that room.

104
00:05:06.090 --> 00:05:09.710
But you're allowed in there, we also have
to determine what level of access you have

105
00:05:09.710 --> 00:05:11.460
to, right, what level of authorization.

106
00:05:11.460 --> 00:05:14.471
Because you might be able to sit in
the room but that doesn't necessarily mean

107
00:05:14.471 --> 00:05:17.640
that you can go over and you can adjust
the thermostat on the wall, right?

108
00:05:17.640 --> 00:05:21.940
I have to authenticate you before
I can even deny you access, right?

109
00:05:21.940 --> 00:05:22.670
How do we do that?

110
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:26.460
Well, if you're not
an employee here at ITProTV,

111
00:05:26.460 --> 00:05:29.370
you don't come back here on the floor.

112
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:32.726
Now, except for our members,
always stop by the Gainesville studios.

113
00:05:32.726 --> 00:05:33.650
>> Yeah.
>> But the point is,

114
00:05:33.650 --> 00:05:37.536
if you're unauthorized, you try to
authenticate, can't prove who you are,

115
00:05:37.536 --> 00:05:39.452
right, then you're not authorized.

116
00:05:39.452 --> 00:05:44.820
So you also have to authenticate
even to deny somebody authorization.

117
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:46.400
Right, what level of access do you have?

118
00:05:46.400 --> 00:05:48.910
You might not have
access to this resource,

119
00:05:48.910 --> 00:05:51.450
you might have access to that resource,
all right.

120
00:05:51.450 --> 00:05:55.820
So, authentication,
authorization, and accounting.

121
00:05:55.820 --> 00:05:59.790
Keep in mind that authentication is
always preceded by identification first.

122
00:05:59.790 --> 00:06:03.480
We have to make sure that
the person that has credentials

123
00:06:03.480 --> 00:06:04.745
is that person they say they are.

124
00:06:04.745 --> 00:06:06.520
>> Mm-hm.
>> All right, so let's dive in, and

125
00:06:06.520 --> 00:06:10.150
talk about some of the authentication
mechanisms that we have.

126
00:06:10.150 --> 00:06:14.910
The very first one they talk about is
the remote access dial-in user service.

127
00:06:14.910 --> 00:06:16.680
That's right, radius.

128
00:06:16.680 --> 00:06:22.180
Radius has long been a common standard for
authentication of remote access.

129
00:06:22.180 --> 00:06:23.770
All right, what we mean by remote access?

130
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:26.590
In fact, I've got a little diagram here,
and we've quite a few components here.

131
00:06:26.590 --> 00:06:30.785
But it's really the radius server and
this process that we're focusing on.

132
00:06:30.785 --> 00:06:34.310
Now understand,
this is an enterprise-level technology.

133
00:06:34.310 --> 00:06:38.490
This is typically something you don't
do in a normal home environment, right.

134
00:06:38.490 --> 00:06:40.634
You could see, because there's
a lot of infrastructure behind it.

135
00:06:40.634 --> 00:06:45.024
But if I've got somebody that, let's
say somebody's working from home, and

136
00:06:45.024 --> 00:06:47.860
they're on the outside of my network.

137
00:06:47.860 --> 00:06:54.230
I need a standardized way for
authenticating who they are, who are you.

138
00:06:54.230 --> 00:06:58.530
For determining what level of access
they have, their authorization, and

139
00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:00.690
then finally,
how we can track their activities.

140
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:02.100
Did you access something?

141
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:05.220
So again, who are you,
what can you do, what did you do?

142
00:07:05.220 --> 00:07:09.460
And radius is a standard mechanism for
doing that.

143
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:13.266
So when a remote access client needs to
make access over a public network back

144
00:07:13.266 --> 00:07:16.840
into our internal network,
they hit what are known as RAS, all right.

145
00:07:16.840 --> 00:07:20.948
And you might even hear it called RAS
Server but RAS Server's kinda redundant,

146
00:07:20.948 --> 00:07:24.700
it's Remote Access Services Server,
or Remote Access Server Server.

147
00:07:24.700 --> 00:07:25.756
Depending on- [LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK]

148
00:07:25.756 --> 00:07:27.580
>> Redundancy on that one, right?

149
00:07:27.580 --> 00:07:32.045
And then once they hit the remote access
servers, depending on the technology used

150
00:07:32.045 --> 00:07:37.945
whether it's a VPN server, dial-up server,
or an 802.1X wireless access point,

151
00:07:37.945 --> 00:07:41.285
these devices are what
are known as radius client.

152
00:07:41.285 --> 00:07:44.265
Now, be careful with that term cuz I
remember when I first started this,

153
00:07:44.265 --> 00:07:45.455
I said, well, okay,

154
00:07:45.455 --> 00:07:50.460
if I'm requesting this service of a radius
server, aren't I the client, right?

155
00:07:50.460 --> 00:07:52.748
We talked about the client-server
architecture, right?

156
00:07:52.748 --> 00:07:55.951
A client requests resources,
the server provides the resources.

157
00:07:55.951 --> 00:07:58.217
But RADIUS is interesting.

158
00:07:58.217 --> 00:08:04.120
Because a remote access client cannot
communicate directly with a RADIUS server.

159
00:08:04.120 --> 00:08:07.630
The reason they call these servers, and
this access point, a RADIUS client,

160
00:08:07.630 --> 00:08:11.440
is because what they do, is they become
kind of like the middle man, all right,

161
00:08:11.440 --> 00:08:12.950
or middle person, if you would.

162
00:08:12.950 --> 00:08:14.430
Don't forget the ladies out there, right?

163
00:08:14.430 --> 00:08:18.370
And what they do,
is when a remote access request is made,

164
00:08:18.370 --> 00:08:21.990
they take that authentication request,
and they wrap it into,

165
00:08:21.990 --> 00:08:25.530
encapsulate it if you will, wrap it up
into what's known as a RADIUS message.

166
00:08:25.530 --> 00:08:28.390
And the reason these devices
are called RADIUS clients is,

167
00:08:28.390 --> 00:08:30.500
they talk to the RADIUS server.

168
00:08:30.500 --> 00:08:35.160
They're making a request, a client,
on your behalf, all right?

169
00:08:35.160 --> 00:08:40.090
And betting on success or failure, what
they do is they take the RADIUS message,

170
00:08:40.090 --> 00:08:43.160
they receive it,
they decapsulate it, right?

171
00:08:43.160 --> 00:08:45.860
They remove the layer
of the onion off of it.

172
00:08:45.860 --> 00:08:49.570
What's left is the success or fail, and
they pass it off to the remote client.

173
00:08:49.570 --> 00:08:52.300
They're the doorway,
they're the gatekeepers, right?

174
00:08:52.300 --> 00:08:56.160
Ultimately, who says
you can have access or

175
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:58.760
can't have access against
the RADIUS server?

176
00:08:58.760 --> 00:09:00.560
And then,
a lot of times when they do this,

177
00:09:00.560 --> 00:09:02.450
they don't authenticate
on the RADIUS server.

178
00:09:02.450 --> 00:09:04.960
You can, in fact in Windows,
if you set it up in Windows server,

179
00:09:04.960 --> 00:09:08.640
you can authenticate right on the RADIUS
server, but sometimes what we do and a lot

180
00:09:08.640 --> 00:09:12.820
of times what we do is we use a directory
services, right, like Active Directory.

181
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:16.180
We let that be the centralized
management of your user accounts.

182
00:09:16.180 --> 00:09:20.600
So the RADIUS server says, all right, I
see the username and password, in fact I'm

183
00:09:20.600 --> 00:09:24.000
not even gonna authenticate this, I'll
hand this over to the Active Directory

184
00:09:24.000 --> 00:09:27.850
server, and it can say whether your
username and password is correct, right?

185
00:09:27.850 --> 00:09:31.052
So a lot of times we'll couple
it with an LDAP server.

186
00:09:31.052 --> 00:09:34.640
All right, now I want you to understand
that RADIUS combines the authentication.

187
00:09:34.640 --> 00:09:35.370
Who are you?

188
00:09:35.370 --> 00:09:38.120
With the authorization,
what level of access do you have?

189
00:09:38.120 --> 00:09:38.910
What can you do?

190
00:09:38.910 --> 00:09:40.710
And as well as the accounting side too.

191
00:09:40.710 --> 00:09:42.790
And it's been the common standard for

192
00:09:42.790 --> 00:09:46.982
a very long time for
doing remote access authentication.

193
00:09:46.982 --> 00:09:50.300
All right, now, I will tell you that
commonly today, what you're gonna see,

194
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:52.690
and we gotta mention some ports here,
right?

195
00:09:52.690 --> 00:09:55.690
Just like we talked about our ports and
protocols.

196
00:09:55.690 --> 00:09:58.310
Well, RADIUS protocol uses a specific or

197
00:09:58.310 --> 00:09:59.970
couple of them that we
want you to be aware of.

198
00:09:59.970 --> 00:10:04.730
And I'm actually going to do some retro

00:10:04.730 --> 00:10:05.760
we use UDP.

200
00:10:05.760 --> 00:10:09.980
And by the way, this uses a connection

that in your mind here because we're going

00:10:16.688 --> 00:10:23.240
So a NASS server, if you will,
again the Network Access Service Server,

204
00:10:23.240 --> 00:10:29.510
is going to use port 1812 for
the RADIUS authentication message, right?

205
00:10:29.510 --> 00:10:34.590
If we go back to the slide here,
when these RADIUS clients, when they go

206
00:10:34.590 --> 00:10:38.640
to encapsulate that authentication request
in a RADIUS message, and they pass it off

207
00:10:38.640 --> 00:10:43.090
to the RADIUS server, the RADIUS server
is listening out on UDP on port 1812.

208
00:10:43.090 --> 00:10:45.880
And now, for the accounting part.

209
00:10:45.880 --> 00:10:51.820
Where do we have the accounting messages,

00:10:51.820 --> 00:10:57.320
but for argument purposes, well,
that's actually over UDP port 1813.

211
00:10:57.320 --> 00:11:00.250
And let me make sure I got that
right because I think I said, 1812.

212
00:11:00.250 --> 00:11:03.490
It's 1812 and 1813.

213
00:11:03.490 --> 00:11:04.722
Got to make sure I get those right for
you.

214
00:11:04.722 --> 00:11:09.814
RADIUS authentication messages on
UDP Port 1812, the accounting messages,

215
00:11:09.814 --> 00:11:13.464
RADIUS accounting messages,
are going to be on 1813.

216
00:11:13.464 --> 00:11:17.564
Now, I'm going to go ahead and give you
some of the older ports that it used to

00:11:17.564 --> 00:11:21.299

00:11:21.299 --> 00:11:26.099
I'm not sure which one, but

servers might use UDP port 1645 for

And for the accounting messages 1646,

Again, these are some of the older ports,

225
00:11:48.760 --> 00:11:53.584
Now, the next one is also a way that

00:11:53.584 --> 00:11:58.050

00:11:58.050 --> 00:12:00.430
However, I will tell you

it actually separates into two components,

00:12:05.550 --> 00:12:08.010
That is something known as TACACS+.

00:12:08.010 --> 00:12:12.245
Now, TACACS, again, the acronym there,

00:12:12.245 --> 00:12:17.690
T-A-C-A-C-S, and its successor,
TACACS+ are Cisco proprietary.

232
00:12:17.690 --> 00:12:20.796
All right, so one is an industry-wide

233
00:12:20.796 --> 00:12:25.520
TACACS and TACACS+, however,

234
00:12:25.520 --> 00:12:29.420
close, because they're allowing

00:12:29.420 --> 00:12:34.900
And again, they separate the authorization

00:12:34.900 --> 00:12:37.980
It, on the other hand,

00:12:42.810 --> 00:12:45.620
Rather than UDP, all right?

So what's better about that?

00:12:47.340 --> 00:12:50.490
Well, remember what
Transmission Control Protocol is.

00:12:50.490 --> 00:12:52.960
It's a connection oriented service.

243
00:12:52.960 --> 00:12:54.750
It's a reliability protocol.

244
00:12:54.750 --> 00:12:57.830
It's reliable,
it's more reliable than UDP.

245
00:12:57.830 --> 00:13:02.490
So it's considered TACACS+,
the successor, right?

246
00:13:02.490 --> 00:13:07.210
The TACACS is the oldest rendition of it,

00:13:07.210 --> 00:13:10.549
Cisco, when they came and they did,
and they kinda manipulated it, and

248
00:13:10.549 --> 00:13:12.627
they made it, upgraded it,
if you will, and

249
00:13:12.627 --> 00:13:15.970
their not backwards compatible with
each other, TACACS and TACACS+,

00:13:15.970 --> 00:13:19.850
they're different enough that they're
not compatible with each other.

251
00:13:19.850 --> 00:13:24.030
That is what is the common standard today.

252
00:13:24.030 --> 00:13:32.264
TACACS+ is considered more

253
00:13:32.264 --> 00:13:36.598
It uses TCP Port 49, all right?

00:13:36.598 --> 00:13:38.741
Now, let's kinda look

And 802.1X by the way, this is the IEEEs

All right, what this means is that when

00:14:10.805 --> 00:14:15.290
it means that the wireless device or

00:14:15.290 --> 00:14:18.460
its not contingent on whether your wired
connection really make sure I say that.

00:14:18.460 --> 00:14:21.830
I know a lot of time in contacts that
use it with wireless, but its wired or

00:14:21.830 --> 00:14:22.846

00:14:22.846 --> 00:14:24.450
And it support 802.1X,

It means if that port can be

And it says, we shut the port down,

And I'll go send your RADIUS message on

802.1X is typically an umbrella

Like A, B, G, N, AC, and they don't want

So like a variable,

00:16:32.226 --> 00:16:35.915

That's the claim that's made, right?

00:16:57.953 --> 00:17:01.780
So the client says,
I'm supposed to be here.

00:17:01.780 --> 00:17:04.260
Well, then there's

00:17:04.260 --> 00:17:06.770
And what the server is doing is says,

323
00:17:08.420 --> 00:17:11.350
Prove it.

324
00:17:11.350 --> 00:17:13.910
That's what the server's gonna say,

325
00:17:13.910 --> 00:17:16.220
Sends a radius authentication challenge.

326
00:17:16.220 --> 00:17:18.250
You're saying, I'm supposed to be here.

00:17:18.250 --> 00:17:19.920
The server says, yeah, you are.

00:17:19.920 --> 00:17:20.910
Well, prove it to me.

329
00:17:20.910 --> 00:17:23.110
Prove it to me that you're

00:17:23.110 --> 00:17:24.790
And then what happens?

00:17:24.790 --> 00:17:30.385
Well, there's a proof to the challenge.

00:17:30.385 --> 00:17:33.890
The proof,
you claim that I'm supposed to be here.

333
00:17:33.890 --> 00:17:38.310
The server challenges you, and
you make good on that challenge.

334
00:17:38.310 --> 00:17:44.450
And you say I am, and

00:17:44.450 --> 00:17:46.020
All right, does that make sense?

00:17:46.020 --> 00:17:50.300
So far you say I am, and then again,
you provide the username and

00:17:50.300 --> 00:17:55.420
password, all of this is going back and
forth between the radius clients.

338
00:17:55.420 --> 00:17:57.550
And then the server does what?

339
00:17:57.550 --> 00:17:58.190
Authentication.

340
00:17:58.190 --> 00:18:01.950
It says, if you are who you say you are,

341
00:18:01.950 --> 00:18:04.390

password should match, right?

342
00:18:04.390 --> 00:18:06.920
And that's why I say

00:18:06.920 --> 00:18:09.350
Authentication success
is really contingent on.

00:18:10.550 --> 00:18:11.910
Do you know the username and password?

00:18:11.910 --> 00:18:12.910
Did you type it right?

00:18:12.910 --> 00:18:16.130
Because I could say, authentication is

347
00:18:16.130 --> 00:18:18.792
if it's like Wes on
the keyboard on Monday,

348
00:18:18.792 --> 00:18:21.940
might take me several [LAUGH]
authentication attempts, right?

349
00:18:21.940 --> 00:18:24.320
But notice that the authentication
is successful, and

350
00:18:24.320 --> 00:18:27.300

351
00:18:27.300 --> 00:18:30.250
That is a high level overview
of the radius process

352
00:18:30.250 --> 00:18:32.500
when you are making
a remote access request.

353
00:18:32.500 --> 00:18:35.580
Remember, this is about access control.

00:19:02.650 --> 00:19:04.610
It's guarding the access to Hades.

00:19:04.610 --> 00:19:05.830
Well guess what?

00:19:05.830 --> 00:19:09.240
Alright.
Kerberos is an authentication protocol

00:19:09.240 --> 00:19:11.850

It's a standard authentication mechanism

Massachusetts Institute for
Technology, and

00:19:19.770 --> 00:19:23.480

00:19:23.480 --> 00:19:28.240
Windows authentication mechanism is

well let's see if we can help you.

380
00:19:56.490 --> 00:20:01.570
I got a little, just basic diagram here
of what's going on with Kerberosl, okay?

381
00:20:01.570 --> 00:20:06.770
When you go to authenticate with Kerberos,
against a Kerberos server, right?

382
00:20:06.770 --> 00:20:09.730
If you're in a Windows domain your
Kerberos servers actually the active

383
00:20:09.730 --> 00:20:10.920
directory domain controller.

384
00:20:10.920 --> 00:20:13.520
When I type in my user name and password,

385
00:20:13.520 --> 00:20:19.230
I'm actually gonna send a Kerberos
authentication message up to that server.

386
00:20:19.230 --> 00:20:20.730
Here's what the server's gonna do.

387
00:20:20.730 --> 00:20:21.570
It's kind of interesting.

388
00:20:21.570 --> 00:20:23.060
It's going to inspect its database.

389
00:20:23.060 --> 00:20:25.300
It's got to have a database
of usernames and passwords,

390
00:20:25.300 --> 00:20:29.450
verifying you are who you say you are, at
least you have that balid credentials, but

391
00:20:29.450 --> 00:20:32.580
then instead of just granting
you access to the network,

392
00:20:32.580 --> 00:20:37.460
what it does is it issues
you a timestamped TGT.

393
00:20:37.460 --> 00:20:40.990
TGT is just short for
ticket granting ticket, all right.

394
00:20:40.990 --> 00:20:44.070
So what does that, get you access to?

395
00:20:44.070 --> 00:20:45.270
Nothing, [LAUGH] all right.

396
00:20:45.270 --> 00:20:48.810
What that does, cuz that's
actually stored on your computer.

397
00:20:48.810 --> 00:20:52.390
At least, I'll throw a caveat to that.

398
00:20:52.390 --> 00:20:56.890
The timestamped TGT, or ticket granted
ticket, is actually cast on your computer.

399
00:20:56.890 --> 00:20:59.490
And when your computer, or

400
00:20:59.490 --> 00:21:05.230
you go to browse across that Windows
domain, and you go to access a resource.

401
00:21:05.230 --> 00:21:06.950
Here's what's interesting.

402
00:21:06.950 --> 00:21:11.320
Instead of to the resource that
you are trying to gain access.

403
00:21:11.320 --> 00:21:13.730
Let's say it's a file share
out there on the network.

404
00:21:13.730 --> 00:21:16.300
Instead of taking the TGT, and

405
00:21:16.300 --> 00:21:20.460
presenting that to the resource server,
you actually take your TGT,

406
00:21:20.460 --> 00:21:25.020
your ticket granting ticket, and
pass it back to the Kerberos server.

407
00:21:25.020 --> 00:21:26.620
Now what is a Kerberos Server?

408
00:21:26.620 --> 00:21:28.120
Inspects the timestamp.

409
00:21:29.140 --> 00:21:32.820
We'll talk about why that timestamp
is important here in a second.

410
00:21:32.820 --> 00:21:36.870
Inspects the timestamp,
it inspects the validity of the ticket.

411
00:21:36.870 --> 00:21:40.790
And then, if it's valid it
issues you another ticket.

412
00:21:40.790 --> 00:21:43.200
That's why we said,
ticket granting system, right?

413
00:21:43.200 --> 00:21:45.500
It issues you a service ticket.

414
00:21:45.500 --> 00:21:49.290
And then when you access the resource
that resource server, let's say it's

415
00:21:49.290 --> 00:21:53.330
a file server within your domain,
is going to inspect the service ticket.

416
00:21:54.390 --> 00:21:57.440
Well, the service ticket
is automatically trusted.

417
00:21:57.440 --> 00:21:59.100
And why is it trusted?

418
00:21:59.100 --> 00:22:03.930
Because the resource server
trusts the Kerberos server.

419
00:22:03.930 --> 00:22:08.310
It trusts the service ticket,

420
00:22:08.310 --> 00:22:13.510
because the only entity on your network
that could have issued that service ticket

421
00:22:13.510 --> 00:22:16.920
was a Kerberos server that
beforehand validated your TGT.

422
00:22:16.920 --> 00:22:19.510
Pretty cool, right?

423
00:22:19.510 --> 00:22:21.170
So little bit of a process here.

424
00:22:21.170 --> 00:22:24.510
Now, why is the time stamping important?

425
00:22:24.510 --> 00:22:25.830
Well time-stamping is important,

426
00:22:25.830 --> 00:22:28.670
because it guards against
things like replay attacks.

427
00:22:28.670 --> 00:22:31.430
All right, if I can gain your information,

428
00:22:31.430 --> 00:22:34.260
if I can grab your information,
let's say with a protocol analyzer and

429
00:22:34.260 --> 00:22:37.810
if it was the TGT was all I needed,
then I could steal your TGT, and

430
00:22:37.810 --> 00:22:41.410
I could present it to the resource server,
and I could do a replay attack, right?

431
00:22:41.410 --> 00:22:45.700
Spoofing myself as hey, being Zach,
acting, you know, Zach's authorized,

432
00:22:45.700 --> 00:22:49.210
I'm the hacker here,
I just grab Zach's TGT and

433
00:22:49.210 --> 00:22:52.628
I present it to the resource server,
doing a man in the middle attack, and

434
00:22:52.628 --> 00:22:56.260
guess what,
I'm accessing your resources, right?

435
00:22:56.260 --> 00:22:57.750
But it doesn't work that way.

436
00:22:57.750 --> 00:22:58.260
All right?

437
00:22:58.260 --> 00:23:03.430
If I grab the TGT, all right,
and I let some time go by,

438
00:23:03.430 --> 00:23:07.050
then I present that back to the Kerberos
server, the Kerberos server says no.

439
00:23:07.050 --> 00:23:10.980
I don't know,
the timestamps varies by five minutes.

440
00:23:10.980 --> 00:23:12.630
You can actually lose your
trust with the domain.

441
00:23:12.630 --> 00:23:15.600
It says no, no, no,
that's not you and just discards it.

442
00:23:15.600 --> 00:23:16.830
Doesn't even consider it.

443
00:23:16.830 --> 00:23:19.650
And that's why your devices
don't consider it a TGT either,

444
00:23:19.650 --> 00:23:24.570
because it's the resource servers
responding to a service ticket, and

445
00:23:24.570 --> 00:23:28.100
only the Kerberos server
can issue a service ticket.

446
00:23:28.100 --> 00:23:31.680
So again, very, very complex yet
really cool process.

447
00:23:31.680 --> 00:23:34.760
So that is your Kerberos
authentication protocol.

448
00:23:34.760 --> 00:23:36.980
Now, be aware of what these are.

449
00:23:36.980 --> 00:23:38.120
Be aware of Radius.

450
00:23:38.120 --> 00:23:39.930
Be aware of the ports in Radius too.

451
00:23:39.930 --> 00:23:44.532
And again, as a recap, the major ones,
the newer ones 18-12 for

452
00:23:44.532 --> 00:23:47.574
Radius authentication mechanism messages,

453
00:23:47.574 --> 00:23:51.874
1813 for accounting messages,
I keep on saying mechanism.

454
00:23:51.874 --> 00:23:57.275
[LAUGH] And 1645 for radius,
the older radius authentication messages,

455
00:23:57.275 --> 00:24:01.100
1646 for the accounting messages.

456
00:24:01.100 --> 00:24:04.890
Keep in mind that it uses UDP,
and it's considered less reliable

457
00:24:04.890 --> 00:24:08.470
than tech X plus which is a Cisco
proprietary authentication and

458
00:24:08.470 --> 00:24:12.910
authorization mechanism,
that uses 49 over transmission

459
00:24:12.910 --> 00:24:17.120
control protocol in such it's
a connection or it's a service.

460
00:24:17.120 --> 00:24:21.270
And I didn't even mention the fact that
it could be an encrypted wide process.

461
00:24:21.270 --> 00:24:24.740
The whole authentication
process is encrypted, right?

462
00:24:24.740 --> 00:24:27.940
So the whole authentication process
beginning in the end could be encrypted.

463
00:24:27.940 --> 00:24:29.830
And again, because it's
transmission control protocol,

464
00:24:29.830 --> 00:24:31.500
it is considered more reliable.

465
00:24:32.580 --> 00:24:35.070
Also, know what Kerberos is, right?

466
00:24:35.070 --> 00:24:39.550
And again, it's used in your
active directory environments, and

467
00:24:39.550 --> 00:24:42.300
you can see UDP or TCP Port 88.

468
00:24:42.300 --> 00:24:47.080
And then again, an active directory
environment you might even see port 640 or

469
00:24:47.080 --> 00:24:48.560
464 just in case.

470
00:24:48.560 --> 00:24:51.770
These are some of the mechanisms
that you have to be aware of, but

471
00:24:51.770 --> 00:24:53.120
we've still got more to go.

472
00:24:53.120 --> 00:24:54.680
>> Great job as usual, Wes.

473
00:24:54.680 --> 00:24:57.930
Authentication and Access Control
part one, there will be a part two,

474
00:24:57.930 --> 00:24:58.960
watch them both.

475
00:24:58.960 --> 00:25:02.090
And watch everything in the CompTIA Net+
series that Wes is putting

476
00:25:02.090 --> 00:25:02.630
together for you.

477
00:25:02.630 --> 00:25:03.780
He's doing a wonderful job,

478
00:25:03.780 --> 00:25:06.540
and he wants to make sure that
no stone is left unturned.

479
00:25:06.540 --> 00:25:07.110
And you know something,

480
00:25:07.110 --> 00:25:10.090
when you're in that course library,
there's hundreds of other videos.

481
00:25:10.090 --> 00:25:11.760
They're all designed to
help you go further.

482
00:25:11.760 --> 00:25:12.680
Check them out.

483
00:25:12.680 --> 00:25:14.890
And tell everyone you know about ITPRO TV.

484
00:25:14.890 --> 00:25:16.600
ITPro TV is binge-worth.

485
00:25:16.600 --> 00:25:17.830
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

486
00:25:17.830 --> 00:25:18.820
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

487
00:25:18.820 --> 00:25:19.860
>> And we will see you soon.

488
00:25:19.860 --> 00:25:27.291
[MUSIC]

489
00:25:27.291 --> 00:25:32.198
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes explore various authentication technologies like RADIUS, SSO, LDAP, certificates.....etc. They will also look at different access control mechanisms such as NAC, 802.1X, port security and more.
episodes.title: Authentication and Access Control Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.197 --> 00:00:02.758
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.758 --> 00:00:06.327
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.327 --> 00:00:08.358
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.358 --> 00:00:12.110
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.110 --> 00:00:14.504
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.504 --> 00:00:16.520
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:17.880
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

8
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:22.420
As we continue on with and net plus,
this is going to be authentication and

9
00:00:22.420 --> 00:00:24.560
access control part two.

10
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:26.810
There is a part one,
make sure you see that.

11
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:29.850
And Wes Bryan is here to, once again,
take us through these waters.

12
00:00:29.850 --> 00:00:31.750
>> All right,
let's hope they're not too murky.

13
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:32.470
>> Let's go, Captain.

14
00:00:32.470 --> 00:00:34.180
>> That's right, ludicrous speed, go!

15
00:00:34.180 --> 00:00:35.880
>> That's right,
we're jumping in with a part two here.

16
00:00:35.880 --> 00:00:40.770
Remember in the first part we talked about
just the basics, again, of authentication,

17
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:42.430
authorization, and accounting.

18
00:00:42.430 --> 00:00:45.480
And we looked at things like radius and

19
00:00:45.480 --> 00:00:50.170
we also finished off with a Kerberos
protocol or a Kerberos, if you will.

20
00:00:50.170 --> 00:00:51.250
Remember, as a recap,

21
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:54.600
when we talk about authentication
that is proving who you are.

22
00:00:54.600 --> 00:01:00.750
Authorization is determining what level of
access you have, as well as accounting,

23
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:03.680
sometimes called auditing,
that's basically tracking activity.

24
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:09.130
So again, like I've heard it said before,
who are you, that's the authentication.

25
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:11.110
What can you do is the authorization.

26
00:01:11.110 --> 00:01:13.400
Last but not least, is, well,
what did you do, right?

27
00:01:13.400 --> 00:01:14.350
That's the accounting part.

28
00:01:14.350 --> 00:01:15.600
So those are-
>> Three A's.

29
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:19.030
>> Some basics, that's right,
the three A's that we need to be aware of.

30
00:01:19.030 --> 00:01:22.420
Now, one of the things that I didn't
mention when we were talking about

31
00:01:22.420 --> 00:01:23.160
Kerberos, right?

32
00:01:23.160 --> 00:01:26.397
We talked about that
being a ticket granting,

33
00:01:26.397 --> 00:01:29.800
time sensitive authentication protocol.

34
00:01:29.800 --> 00:01:31.040
What does it allow us to do?

35
00:01:31.040 --> 00:01:32.060
Well it's interesting,

36
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:35.360
what it allows us to do is perform
something known as a single sign on.

37
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:39.550
And what we mean by that is the fact that
I can enter a set of credentials one time,

38
00:01:39.550 --> 00:01:45.540
be authenticated, have my authorization
applied to my my user account, if

39
00:01:45.540 --> 00:01:51.300
you will, and I don't have to reenter my
credentials if you think about it, right.

40
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:53.840
Especially with today we got so
many different services out there.

41
00:01:53.840 --> 00:01:57.140
Can you imagine having to enter your
credentials every time you wanted to

42
00:01:57.140 --> 00:01:59.780
access an additional resource?

43
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:02.620
>> It would get a little bit tricky right?

44
00:02:02.620 --> 00:02:07.340
And one of the things good is that when
it comes to single sign on, and in fact,

45
00:02:07.340 --> 00:02:08.320
let me show you here.

46
00:02:08.320 --> 00:02:11.610
You've probably been using this and
maybe you didn't even notice.

47
00:02:11.610 --> 00:02:17.230
I use Google because they have such as
wide range of services that they offer,

48
00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:19.480
but no different than if
you're using Office 365.

49
00:02:19.480 --> 00:02:22.840
If you ever logged in with Facebook,
right.

50
00:02:22.840 --> 00:02:24.790
And it says log in with your
Facebook account, right.

51
00:02:24.790 --> 00:02:26.510
>> Yes.
>> I've already put in my Facebook

52
00:02:26.510 --> 00:02:27.100
credentials.

53
00:02:27.100 --> 00:02:28.310
So all I got to do is hit a button and

54
00:02:28.310 --> 00:02:31.860
I don't really have to enter
those credentials again.

55
00:02:31.860 --> 00:02:33.230
Now that goes a little bit farther.

56
00:02:33.230 --> 00:02:36.640
That's called federated services but
it allows us that single sign on.

57
00:02:36.640 --> 00:02:38.350
Entering credentials once and

58
00:02:38.350 --> 00:02:41.760
not having to enter them again
to access additional resources.

59
00:02:41.760 --> 00:02:43.640
So we have some basic stuff.

60
00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:46.120
Maybe you've used Google services before,
right?

61
00:02:46.120 --> 00:02:48.370
Maybe you use Hangout, Gmail, right?

62
00:02:48.370 --> 00:02:50.700
Google Drive or YouTube.

63
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:53.610
Log in one time, and
then you can access those resources and

64
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:56.730
you don't have to reenter that
user name and password, right?

65
00:02:56.730 --> 00:02:58.120
That's a great convenience.

66
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:00.940
It's convenience in a couple of ways,
right?

67
00:03:00.940 --> 00:03:02.820
Most of the times we're
talking about security, right.

68
00:03:02.820 --> 00:03:04.720
Access control a lot of
times is about security.

69
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:08.800
And when we say you increase security,
you usually decrease convenience,

70
00:03:08.800 --> 00:03:12.320
the more secure something is sometimes
it's harder to gain access to it right.

71
00:03:13.520 --> 00:03:15.890
Or the opposite side of the tracks right.

72
00:03:15.890 --> 00:03:19.210
If we say well that's a little too
difficult, you know you've got to enter

73
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:24.460
all these different passwords or we're
making the passwords astronomically huge.

74
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:30.340
Again as we're more secure, we're talking

75
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:35.150
about convenience starts to get a little
bit less, but if we say you know what,

76
00:03:35.150 --> 00:03:38.230
we don't want to make it so hard,
you don't have to have a big password.

77
00:03:38.230 --> 00:03:40.290
In fact,
you can have a really small password and

78
00:03:40.290 --> 00:03:41.530
we're not going to make you change it.

79
00:03:41.530 --> 00:03:44.060
Well, now we've introduced
a greater convenience but

80
00:03:44.060 --> 00:03:46.300
we've also decreased some of our security.

81
00:03:46.300 --> 00:03:49.913
And one of the great things about single
sign on is it kinda helps you kinda

82
00:03:49.913 --> 00:03:51.820
balance the middle of the road there.

83
00:03:51.820 --> 00:03:55.590
Now I'm not sure where, you know, the
middle of the road is because if you tell

84
00:03:55.590 --> 00:03:58.941
me to show you a secure network,
I'll show you one that doesn't exist.

85
00:03:58.941 --> 00:04:01.281
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the benefit is the user gets,

86
00:04:01.281 --> 00:04:05.680
from the end user experience is you get
the convenience of entering one set of

87
00:04:05.680 --> 00:04:10.330
credentials and you can access all the
resources that you are allowed to access,

88
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:12.070
that you have authorization for.

89
00:04:12.070 --> 00:04:15.610
That single sign on, we get that inside
things like active directory domains,

90
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:19.660
where I can logon to a domain
computer one time and then if I'm

91
00:04:19.660 --> 00:04:24.280
accessing a resource within the domain,
provided I have the permissions to, right,

92
00:04:24.280 --> 00:04:26.620
I mean you can't access something
you're not authorized to.

93
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:29.590
But provided I can,
I don't have to reenter my password.

94
00:04:29.590 --> 00:04:31.270
We'll show you an example
of that coming up.

95
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:36.630
And that actually leads us in to our
next concept, and that's known as LDAP.

96
00:04:36.630 --> 00:04:39.590
We look at LDAP, that's the lightweight
directory access protocol.

97
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:42.908
We talk about things like and I've been
mentioning Kerberos and active directory,

98
00:04:42.908 --> 00:04:47.590
well LDAP is essentially the way you
access a directory service's database.

99
00:04:47.590 --> 00:04:51.230
Well, why would I want something
like a directory service's database?

100
00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:54.230
What does that make,
what does that do for us?

101
00:04:54.230 --> 00:04:57.690
Well that's a centralized
authentication mechanism.

102
00:04:57.690 --> 00:05:00.100
I want you to think about local login,
right?

103
00:05:00.100 --> 00:05:01.050
Local access.

104
00:05:01.050 --> 00:05:05.480
If I've got a work group and
I want somebody to be able to access

105
00:05:05.480 --> 00:05:08.540
a resource across ten different
computers within a work group, then I

106
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:13.480
have to create them ten different user
accounts on each one of those computers.

107
00:05:13.480 --> 00:05:16.250
Because each one of those computers
are managing their own user account

108
00:05:16.250 --> 00:05:16.910
database, right?

109
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:21.120
And they don't trust each other's user
accounts across different computers.

110
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:23.070
But if I put them in
an active directory domain,

111
00:05:23.070 --> 00:05:27.502
if I put them in a directory service, then
what you do is you log on one time and

112
00:05:27.502 --> 00:05:32.440
provided you have the resources, you can
access all the different domain computers,

113
00:05:32.440 --> 00:05:34.360
if you will,
that are also a part of that domain.

114
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:38.120
So it also gives you the ability
to have single sign on as well.

115
00:05:38.120 --> 00:05:40.470
Let me go ahead and
show you what I mean by that.

116
00:05:40.470 --> 00:05:42.980
I've got a Windows 10 machine here,
and let's go ahead and

117
00:05:42.980 --> 00:05:45.250
let's log into this machine right now.

118
00:05:45.250 --> 00:05:48.090
This computer is not a part of a domain,
right?

119
00:05:48.090 --> 00:05:51.360
I want to kind of show you the protocol in
the background, so that you can see how

120
00:05:51.360 --> 00:05:55.290
this is actually kind of coming into play,
