335
00:15:50.280 --> 00:15:53.290
And when we look at a certificate
based authentication mechanism,

336
00:15:53.290 --> 00:15:54.253
what we mean by that.

337
00:15:54.253 --> 00:15:58.006
Is that you can use digital certificates.

338
00:15:58.006 --> 00:16:03.265
A digital certificate is really just
a little bit of information that

339
00:16:03.265 --> 00:16:08.720
associates an identity with that
digital stamp, if you will, right?

340
00:16:08.720 --> 00:16:10.270
The certificate, if you will,

341
00:16:10.270 --> 00:16:14.380
is one of the pretty much one of
the secure forms of authentication.

342
00:16:14.380 --> 00:16:17.070
So rather than using usernames and
passwords,

343
00:16:17.070 --> 00:16:22.170
we can go through a process of
actually assigning a certificate.

344
00:16:22.170 --> 00:16:25.410
And we can assign them not just to users,
we can assign them to computers,

345
00:16:25.410 --> 00:16:29.630
we can assign them,
if you will to our devices.

346
00:16:29.630 --> 00:16:31.750
So users, computers, and devices.

347
00:16:31.750 --> 00:16:33.610
Let me kind of show you the process.

348
00:16:33.610 --> 00:16:38.250
When you go for a certificate,
the first thing that happens is you

349
00:16:38.250 --> 00:16:42.170
have to identify who you are, that's
always part of your onboarding process.

350
00:16:42.170 --> 00:16:46.380
I'm providing my drivers license, my
Social Security card, I get hired, right?

351
00:16:46.380 --> 00:16:49.480
But then the next thing I have to do is I
have to go to a registration authority.

352
00:16:49.480 --> 00:16:52.650
And a registration authority
looks at my certificate request.

353
00:16:52.650 --> 00:16:54.430
I make a certificate request.

354
00:16:54.430 --> 00:16:55.850
I need a certificate, right?

355
00:16:55.850 --> 00:16:57.780
Registration authority says, okay.

356
00:16:57.780 --> 00:16:59.870
The request is valid.

357
00:16:59.870 --> 00:17:01.870
Let me turn around and
I'm gonna go ahead and

358
00:17:01.870 --> 00:17:06.630
I'm gonna send this off to what's
known as a certificate authority.

359
00:17:06.630 --> 00:17:10.680
All right, the certificate authority,
CAs if you will, they're responsible for

360
00:17:10.680 --> 00:17:13.980
issuing the CAs, or
the certificate, excuse me.

361
00:17:13.980 --> 00:17:15.410
But there's typically a hierarchy.

362
00:17:15.410 --> 00:17:17.190
You have what's known as
public infrastructure.

363
00:17:17.190 --> 00:17:20.320
That's where certificates come from,
from a public key infrastructure.

364
00:17:20.320 --> 00:17:24.880
And what you have is typically you have a
multi-level, you don't always have to, but

365
00:17:24.880 --> 00:17:29.190
you have what's known as a tiered
public key infrastructure.

366
00:17:29.190 --> 00:17:33.508
And you have what's known as the highest
portion of the certificate hierarchy,

367
00:17:33.508 --> 00:17:34.532
known as a root CA.

368
00:17:34.532 --> 00:17:40.190
And then what it does is it issues
a self signed certificate to itself.

369
00:17:40.190 --> 00:17:41.850
And what we mean by that is it says,

370
00:17:41.850 --> 00:17:45.000
hey, I'm the highest part
of this trust hierarchy.

371
00:17:45.000 --> 00:17:49.820
And then what it does is it endorses
lower level certificate authorities

372
00:17:49.820 --> 00:17:54.230
called issuing CAs, or subordinate CAs,
and they become the work horse.

373
00:17:54.230 --> 00:17:58.350
They're the ones that actually issue
the certificate to the user, all right?

374
00:17:59.500 --> 00:18:02.330
Or the device, or
the computer, if you will.

375
00:18:02.330 --> 00:18:08.070
And what the certificate does, is
the certificate actually has a key pair.

376
00:18:08.070 --> 00:18:11.330
Two keys, if you will,
that are associated with this certificate,

377
00:18:11.330 --> 00:18:15.580
and it's how we get asymmetric encryption,
all right?

378
00:18:15.580 --> 00:18:20.800
Now, that key pair with that certificate
is then installed on the local computer,

379
00:18:20.800 --> 00:18:23.050
or assigned to the end user.

380
00:18:23.050 --> 00:18:27.685
And now instead of having to type in
a user name or password when you go to

381
00:18:27.685 --> 00:18:33.344
authenticate against a resource instead of
again typing the user name and password,

382
00:18:33.344 --> 00:18:38.399
you're computer hands the certificate
to that resource, whatever it is.

383
00:18:38.399 --> 00:18:39.560
So I want you to think of it this way,
right?

384
00:18:39.560 --> 00:18:44.355
If I go into a bank and
I want to get access to my account, data,

385
00:18:44.355 --> 00:18:47.048
and my money, what do I have to do?

386
00:18:47.048 --> 00:18:49.072
Well, I have to present them with my ID.

387
00:18:49.072 --> 00:18:50.570
I have to give them my driver's license.

388
00:18:50.570 --> 00:18:53.050
Or if your military out there,
your CAC card.

389
00:18:53.050 --> 00:18:56.741
You military vets out there probably
know the Common Access Card that you

390
00:18:56.741 --> 00:18:57.719
present, right?

391
00:18:57.719 --> 00:19:00.080
And in that has all your
identifying information.

392
00:19:00.080 --> 00:19:02.580
Well, that's kind of
the way certificates work.

393
00:19:02.580 --> 00:19:04.590
It's like a digital identity, if you will.

394
00:19:04.590 --> 00:19:07.720
And in fact,
we can kinda see that in action here if,

395
00:19:07.720 --> 00:19:10.600
let's say, so for instance,
I'm on Google's website.

396
00:19:10.600 --> 00:19:12.450
This is a certificate
based authentication.

397
00:19:12.450 --> 00:19:13.220
Now the difference is,

398
00:19:13.220 --> 00:19:18.190
is when I connected to the web server,
the web server said here's my certificate.

399
00:19:18.190 --> 00:19:20.280
Here's my digital driver's license,
if you will.

400
00:19:20.280 --> 00:19:23.500
So you can prove I am who I say I am.

401
00:19:23.500 --> 00:19:26.645
We can actually see some of that
information and it lets me know your

402
00:19:26.645 --> 00:19:29.576
information is private when
it's sent to this site, right?

403
00:19:29.576 --> 00:19:33.726
It's the way that we can keep,
not only authentication but

404
00:19:33.726 --> 00:19:39.210
make it more stronger but it allows us
to do encryption between two end points.

405
00:19:39.210 --> 00:19:44.495
So, certificate based authentication
is a very good thing.

406
00:19:44.495 --> 00:19:50.096
Again, you end up having to put
a lot of infrastructure in place.

407
00:19:50.096 --> 00:19:53.626
In fact, let me go ahead and see if we can
look at some of the security information

408
00:19:53.626 --> 00:19:55.760
on this certificate here real quick.

409
00:19:55.760 --> 00:19:57.370
Okay.
So, notice it says its

410
00:19:57.370 --> 00:19:58.790
a valid certificate, right?

411
00:19:58.790 --> 00:20:04.810
And if I view the certificate,
we can see that this was issued to Google.

412
00:20:04.810 --> 00:20:09.020
And if Google server is presenting
this back to my web browser,

413
00:20:09.020 --> 00:20:12.020
it's saying here's my identifier,
you can trust me.

414
00:20:12.020 --> 00:20:12.990
So, why do we trust it?

415
00:20:14.020 --> 00:20:16.710
Well, remember the hierarchy
I told you about, right?

416
00:20:16.710 --> 00:20:19.480
A certificate is issued to a device or
a user and

417
00:20:19.480 --> 00:20:26.330
you can see that this has been issued
to google.com by an issuing CA.

418
00:20:26.330 --> 00:20:28.230
Now this is interesting
because Google is so big,

419
00:20:28.230 --> 00:20:30.990
that they're also a subordinate CA.

420
00:20:30.990 --> 00:20:32.780
So they've issued their own certificate,

421
00:20:32.780 --> 00:20:36.440
but their certificate was
endorsed by the root CA.

422
00:20:37.600 --> 00:20:41.130
And these are some of the roots CAs that
you can see out there on the Internet.

423
00:20:41.130 --> 00:20:45.760
And the roots CAs are essentially
public entities, they're businesses.

424
00:20:45.760 --> 00:20:49.231
They issue certificates to other CAs,
if you will.

425
00:20:49.231 --> 00:20:54.140
In this case, if they're a subordinate CA,
second in that chain, they'll issue it

426
00:20:54.140 --> 00:20:59.900
to servers or identities, and again,
that's part of that public key hierarchy.

427
00:20:59.900 --> 00:21:02.950
Keep in mind that these companies, again,

428
00:21:02.950 --> 00:21:06.290
are publicly endorsed and
it's all based on a trust model.

429
00:21:06.290 --> 00:21:09.281
So that's a little bit about
certificate authentication,

430
00:21:09.281 --> 00:21:13.031
certificate based authentication,
I do want you to know just for the exam,

431
00:21:13.031 --> 00:21:15.846
if you're gonna do certificate
based authentication,

432
00:21:15.846 --> 00:21:18.680
the authentication mechanism
that you use is EAP-TLS.

433
00:21:18.680 --> 00:21:22.706
That's the Extensible Authentication
Protocol with Transport Layer Security.

434
00:21:22.706 --> 00:21:26.699
As you go on a more advanced training, you
might learn a little bit more about that,

435
00:21:26.699 --> 00:21:30.353
but know that that's the way you do
certificate-based authentication out

436
00:21:30.353 --> 00:21:33.172
there when we're talking
about mutual authentication.

437
00:21:33.172 --> 00:21:34.833
And that's something that
we should mention too.

438
00:21:34.833 --> 00:21:37.610
Mutual authentication is both parties,
right?

439
00:21:37.610 --> 00:21:39.850
It's not single-ended authentication,
right?

440
00:21:39.850 --> 00:21:44.980
That's me saying Zach, here's who I am and
I present Zach with my driver's license.

441
00:21:44.980 --> 00:21:47.170
Well, Zach says, now I know who you are.

442
00:21:47.170 --> 00:21:49.150
Here, let me present you
with my driver's license.

443
00:21:49.150 --> 00:21:52.090
And we kinda now both
know who each other are.

444
00:21:52.090 --> 00:21:56.060
That's mutual authentication and it works
on both sides of that communication.

445
00:21:56.060 --> 00:21:58.570
>> And then I keep Wes's driver's
license because, why not.

446
00:21:58.570 --> 00:22:01.190
>> [LAUGH] That's right, because I've
spend a lot of your money through this

447
00:22:01.190 --> 00:22:03.450
episode on your credit cards, right?

448
00:22:03.450 --> 00:22:04.050
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

449
00:22:04.050 --> 00:22:05.460
Tit for tat there.

450
00:22:05.460 --> 00:22:06.800
>> That's right, all right.

451
00:22:06.800 --> 00:22:10.140
So a couple of the other things that
we wanna just kind of round off here.

452
00:22:10.140 --> 00:22:12.180
We talked about the accounting part.

453
00:22:12.180 --> 00:22:16.250
The accounting part is where we get
auditing, and auditing and logging.

454
00:22:16.250 --> 00:22:20.060
Logging is actually
the result of auditing,

455
00:22:20.060 --> 00:22:24.540
Auditing is tracking those system-wide
activities that produces logs, and

456
00:22:24.540 --> 00:22:29.250
then we can go back and we can scrutinize
the logs for just being able to track what

457
00:22:29.250 --> 00:22:33.130
people are doing within your networks or
on your devices.

458
00:22:33.130 --> 00:22:37.220
In fact, I can kinda show you that if we
dive down into our Windows 10 machine

459
00:22:37.220 --> 00:22:41.980
here, and we go back to Event Viewer, I'm
just right-clicking on the Windows charm,

460
00:22:41.980 --> 00:22:45.950
if I go to Event Viewer, and
we pull up Event Viewer.

461
00:22:45.950 --> 00:22:49.260
You're gonna see that Windows,
by default, has some logs.

462
00:22:49.260 --> 00:22:52.430
And one of the logs that we have is
the security log right here, and

463
00:22:52.430 --> 00:22:55.470
this security log is how we're
actually tracking events.

464
00:22:55.470 --> 00:23:02.040
And they're certain events, by default,
that are tracked, and some that are not.

465
00:23:02.040 --> 00:23:04.280
But you can always adjust this too.

466
00:23:04.280 --> 00:23:07.540
But notice we have the auditing going on.

467
00:23:07.540 --> 00:23:09.810
So audit success produced this log.

468
00:23:09.810 --> 00:23:13.310
It says the account was
successfully logged on, right.

469
00:23:13.310 --> 00:23:16.630
So the accounting,
we're auditing is tracking, right?

470
00:23:16.630 --> 00:23:20.525
The logs are what we can go back and
scrutinize as a,

471
00:23:20.525 --> 00:23:26.600
the after effect if you will, of auditing.

472
00:23:26.600 --> 00:23:27.310
Right now.

473
00:23:27.310 --> 00:23:28.810
I will tell you be careful with auditing,

474
00:23:28.810 --> 00:23:31.870
because you might say well why
don't we just track everything?

475
00:23:31.870 --> 00:23:36.213
Well, you can track everything, but if
you're not gonna be scrutinizing the logs,

476
00:23:36.213 --> 00:23:39.350
you really shouldn't be,
because in auditing everything,

477
00:23:39.350 --> 00:23:41.727
you can actually use up
a lot of storage space.

478
00:23:41.727 --> 00:23:42.297
>> I imagine you could.

479
00:23:42.297 --> 00:23:43.820
>> And it could cause performance issues.

480
00:23:43.820 --> 00:23:50.336
If you're not going to Check the logs,
dont audit it, right?

481
00:23:50.336 --> 00:23:52.670
So just make sure you dont
want to audit everything.

482
00:23:52.670 --> 00:23:56.515
Just audit the information specifically
that youre going to check the logs for,

483
00:23:56.515 --> 00:23:57.570
yeah that is important.

484
00:23:58.678 --> 00:24:02.820
All right, so a couple of the last
things that I kinda need to talk about,

485
00:24:02.820 --> 00:24:06.010
I need to talk about what is known
as a captive portal, all right?

486
00:24:06.010 --> 00:24:10.430
Captive portal is a great way to
stop somebody from just getting

487
00:24:10.430 --> 00:24:11.900
instant public access.

488
00:24:11.900 --> 00:24:16.416
You see this a lot of times in hotels and
stuff, and public hot spots, right?

489
00:24:16.416 --> 00:24:19.270
Like a Wi-Fi hot spot, where they've
got a coffee shop, if you will,

490
00:24:19.270 --> 00:24:21.330
that's going to allow you free and
public access.

491
00:24:21.330 --> 00:24:25.990
Let me go ahead and show you, I'm up
here on Wikimedia, Wiki commons here.

492
00:24:25.990 --> 00:24:29.340
And you've probably seen one of these
before if you've ever been to a hotel

493
00:24:29.340 --> 00:24:34.330
where they say, hey, you get free Wi-Fi,
but we'll give you a hotel user name,

494
00:24:34.330 --> 00:24:37.520
or a user name and
password a lot of times.

495
00:24:37.520 --> 00:24:40.970
User name will just be your room number
and whatever password they might have or

496
00:24:40.970 --> 00:24:42.680
maybe even an access code.

497
00:24:42.680 --> 00:24:45.809
And then what they do is they tell you,
hey, you've got an AUP, right?

498
00:24:45.809 --> 00:24:49.663
An acceptable use policy that says, hey,
if you're gonna connect to this network,

499
00:24:49.663 --> 00:24:52.552
guess what, you have certain things
that you need to abide by for

500
00:24:52.552 --> 00:24:54.556
the acceptable use of our network, right?

501
00:24:54.556 --> 00:24:55.360
That's a captive portal.

502
00:24:55.360 --> 00:25:00.050
What it means is that, yeah, we're gonna
allow potential public access to this

503
00:25:00.050 --> 00:25:02.800
network, but you're gonna have to come and
get some information for us.

504
00:25:02.800 --> 00:25:06.870
We're not going to just allow free
run-of-the-mill and anybody can access it.

505
00:25:06.870 --> 00:25:08.625
That's captive portal.

506
00:25:08.625 --> 00:25:10.860
So definitely be aware of that.

507
00:25:10.860 --> 00:25:14.740
The other thing that we also have to
mention are some authentication factors

508
00:25:14.740 --> 00:25:17.050
because we really haven't,
we talked about authentication but

509
00:25:17.050 --> 00:25:20.020
we really haven't talked about
the authentication factors, all right?

510
00:25:20.020 --> 00:25:21.770
And these are the authentication factors.

511
00:25:21.770 --> 00:25:22.915
I've got a little diagram here.

512
00:25:22.915 --> 00:25:25.460
And the ones that you need to know for
the exam, right?

513
00:25:25.460 --> 00:25:28.590
Now, the most common ones
are these three right here.

514
00:25:28.590 --> 00:25:30.360
All right,
these long have been the common ones.

515
00:25:30.360 --> 00:25:32.790
Something you know, something you have,
and something you are.

516
00:25:32.790 --> 00:25:34.880
All right, let's stop right there and
talk about those and

517
00:25:34.880 --> 00:25:37.550
then we'll come back to these that
are a little bit newer, right?

518
00:25:37.550 --> 00:25:40.690
Something you know,
a username and password, right?

519
00:25:40.690 --> 00:25:44.130
That's an authentication factor that you
probably use almost on a daily basis.

520
00:25:44.130 --> 00:25:49.301
Username and password, a PIN,
Personal Identification Number.

521
00:25:49.301 --> 00:25:52.300
If you've ever logged into your phone with
a four digit code, it's a PIN, right?

522
00:25:52.300 --> 00:25:53.540
That's something you know.

523
00:25:53.540 --> 00:25:54.530
A security question, right?

524
00:25:54.530 --> 00:25:56.410
If you've ever been challenged
with a security question.

525
00:25:56.410 --> 00:25:57.520
What's your mother's maiden name?

526
00:25:57.520 --> 00:25:59.020
What's your favorite pet?

527
00:25:59.020 --> 00:26:01.170
What high school did you go to?

528
00:26:01.170 --> 00:26:03.420
What, I don't know,
city did you meet your spouse?

529
00:26:03.420 --> 00:26:05.480
These are all things you know, right?

530
00:26:05.480 --> 00:26:07.670
Thats one of the authentication factors.

531
00:26:07.670 --> 00:26:09.450
The next one is,
something you have, all right?

532
00:26:09.450 --> 00:26:13.460
When we talk about something you have,
well, weve talked kind of about them,

533
00:26:13.460 --> 00:26:16.460
Ive been picking on Zach
about his ID badge for a bit.

534
00:26:16.460 --> 00:26:18.350
Well this is something you have, right?

535
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:21.000
This is a card,
its something that you possess, right?

536
00:26:21.000 --> 00:26:26.110
It could be a card, it could be a key fob,
that is something you have.

537
00:26:26.110 --> 00:26:29.170
Now, something you are boils down to
really one thing, that's biometrics.

538
00:26:29.170 --> 00:26:29.740
Something you are.

539
00:26:29.740 --> 00:26:31.350
Some physical characteristic of yourself.

540
00:26:31.350 --> 00:26:35.150
Like voice recognition system,
fingerprint, scanner,

541
00:26:35.150 --> 00:26:39.400
hand geometry scanner, retinal scanner,
if you will, maybe even more.

542
00:26:39.400 --> 00:26:42.904
Retinal scanners, now we're now
talking about some fancy technology.

543
00:26:42.904 --> 00:26:45.840
Even iris scanners, likewise, too.

544
00:26:45.840 --> 00:26:48.860
Again, biometrics is something you are.

545
00:26:48.860 --> 00:26:52.670
Now if you have ever heard of the term
geolocation and geofencing, right?

546
00:26:52.670 --> 00:26:53.620
Geofencing is,

547
00:26:53.620 --> 00:26:58.101
I could provide someone a level of access
based on where they are located, right?

548
00:26:58.101 --> 00:27:01.420
So if youre within our networks
you have this set of access,

549
00:27:01.420 --> 00:27:03.360
right, this set of authorization.

550
00:27:03.360 --> 00:27:08.010
You move outside of that, somewhere you
are, move outside of that location,

551
00:27:08.010 --> 00:27:11.560
now you have this level of access or
no access at all, right?

552
00:27:11.560 --> 00:27:13.670
That's somewhere you are.

553
00:27:13.670 --> 00:27:16.360
The last one here that we've in
the list is something you do.

554
00:27:16.360 --> 00:27:19.130
And again, this wasn't one that is newer.

555
00:27:19.130 --> 00:27:23.750
And I say just newer in relationship
to the CompTIA exams, right?

556
00:27:23.750 --> 00:27:25.710
The first three are the most common,
right?

557
00:27:25.710 --> 00:27:29.370
Something you do is keystroke patterns,
right?

558
00:27:29.370 --> 00:27:32.523
All they'd have to do is look at me and
how many times I hit the delete button or

559
00:27:32.523 --> 00:27:33.525
the backspace button.

560
00:27:33.525 --> 00:27:35.503
That's like my electronic whiteout, right?

561
00:27:35.503 --> 00:27:38.305
Because I can't spell worth a darn.

562
00:27:38.305 --> 00:27:41.210
Here's another one that and
you'll probably see this and

563
00:27:41.210 --> 00:27:43.646
I'm just kind of guessing here,
gait, right?

564
00:27:43.646 --> 00:27:44.910
How you walk.

565
00:27:44.910 --> 00:27:46.357
That's kind of interesting too.

566
00:27:46.357 --> 00:27:51.540
Looking at gate like how you stride,
right, and that can authenticate you.

567
00:27:51.540 --> 00:27:56.680
So something you do is some action that
you perform that uniquely identifies you.

568
00:27:56.680 --> 00:27:58.360
These are authentication factors.

569
00:27:58.360 --> 00:28:02.510
Now, I also want you to know what
a multi-factor authentication is, and

570
00:28:02.510 --> 00:28:07.330
it is more than one of any
of these factors, all right?

571
00:28:07.330 --> 00:28:09.910
Something you know with
something you have.

572
00:28:09.910 --> 00:28:12.390
I got my key card and I've got a PIN.

573
00:28:12.390 --> 00:28:15.696
I've gotta enter the PIN, the Personal
Identification Number or a password and

574
00:28:15.696 --> 00:28:16.828
I've gotta swipe my card.

575
00:28:16.828 --> 00:28:21.200
It's multi-factored, combine something I
know with something I have, all right?

576
00:28:21.200 --> 00:28:24.210
Or I've got a key fob or a key card.

577
00:28:24.210 --> 00:28:27.770
I swipe it across an electronic lock and
then I turn around and

578
00:28:27.770 --> 00:28:31.410
I put my finger on the finger
print scanner, right?

579
00:28:31.410 --> 00:28:33.630
That's combining something you
have with something you are.

580
00:28:33.630 --> 00:28:35.455
That's multi-factor, all right?

581
00:28:35.455 --> 00:28:38.337
Maybe it's geolocation and
a password, all right?

582
00:28:38.337 --> 00:28:41.705
Now you're in the building,
that's somewhere you are.

583
00:28:41.705 --> 00:28:42.945
Go ahead and enter your password.

584
00:28:42.945 --> 00:28:46.155
You still have to authenticate because we
don't somebody that just stole your device

585
00:28:46.155 --> 00:28:47.195
to walk into the building.

586
00:28:47.195 --> 00:28:51.325
And now that they're located inside of
the building, they gain access, right?

587
00:28:51.325 --> 00:28:53.380
That wouldn't really be safe.

588
00:28:53.380 --> 00:28:54.464
So what do we do?

589
00:28:54.464 --> 00:28:55.956
Your phone's locked with a PIN and

590
00:28:55.956 --> 00:28:58.590
you have to be inside of
the building to gain access, right?

591
00:28:58.590 --> 00:29:03.150
Now, we have something you know with the
PIN, and the location, somewhere you are.

592
00:29:03.150 --> 00:29:05.110
It's multi-factor authentication.

593
00:29:05.110 --> 00:29:06.757
Sometimes you'll hear
it called one factor,

594
00:29:06.757 --> 00:29:10.040
which isn't multi-factored,
it's just any one of these.

595
00:29:10.040 --> 00:29:13.010
Two, three, and even four factor
authentication, now that we've got so

596
00:29:13.010 --> 00:29:14.150
many options.

597
00:29:14.150 --> 00:29:16.130
These are some of the things
that I would keep in mind.

598
00:29:16.130 --> 00:29:19.240
A couple of the other things that they
talk about are more generic terms, for

599
00:29:19.240 --> 00:29:21.210
instance, Network Access Control.

600
00:29:21.210 --> 00:29:25.900
Network Access Control is really
just a set of policies, procedures,

601
00:29:25.900 --> 00:29:30.840
and technologies that you put together
in order to govern what devices and

602
00:29:30.840 --> 00:29:33.880
what level of access people
have on into your network.

603
00:29:33.880 --> 00:29:38.700
You have, for instance, inside of the
server, Windows Server operating system.

604
00:29:38.700 --> 00:29:42.840
You had Network Access Protection, that
had a lot of components in it, that would.

605
00:29:42.840 --> 00:29:45.080
You'd have a health
registration authority and

606
00:29:45.080 --> 00:29:48.050
when your computer joined to a network,
first thing that would happen,

607
00:29:48.050 --> 00:29:50.560
is it would take a system
health validator,

608
00:29:50.560 --> 00:29:55.860
like is your firewall on,
are your Windows updates installed?

609
00:29:55.860 --> 00:29:57.970
And you would take that
statement of health,

610
00:29:57.970 --> 00:30:01.570
right, and you'd hand it off to a health
registration authority and inspect it and

611
00:30:01.570 --> 00:30:05.940
say, all right policy says,
you have to have your firewall turned on,

612
00:30:05.940 --> 00:30:10.670
you have to have antivirus software turned
on, you have to have your updates done.

613
00:30:10.670 --> 00:30:14.400
If you meet the health requirement
based on your statement of health,

614
00:30:14.400 --> 00:30:15.880
then you gain access to the network.

615
00:30:15.880 --> 00:30:18.740
In fact,
let me show you what I mean here, right?

616
00:30:18.740 --> 00:30:20.430
And then if you don't,

617
00:30:20.430 --> 00:30:24.620
if you hand off that information, you
got a remote access client, if you will,

618
00:30:24.620 --> 00:30:27.500
hands off that information to
the Health Registration Authority and

619
00:30:27.500 --> 00:30:32.240
says, all right, well, I see that you
have a valid statement of health.

620
00:30:32.240 --> 00:30:34.230
Let's check against the policy server and
say,

621
00:30:34.230 --> 00:30:37.470
now that we know that you're okay,
what can you do?

622
00:30:37.470 --> 00:30:39.890
And they couple this in with
things like Active Directory.

623
00:30:39.890 --> 00:30:44.480
And if you meet the policy that the server
states, required by the administrator,

624
00:30:44.480 --> 00:30:46.830
then you gain access to
the resource server.

625
00:30:46.830 --> 00:30:48.880
If you don't meet the health policy,

626
00:30:48.880 --> 00:30:51.740
then what they do is they put
you onto an isolation network.

627
00:30:51.740 --> 00:30:54.840
And that isolation network is
where we have some kind of

628
00:30:54.840 --> 00:30:58.510
remediation server that says,
you're not up to date, but guess what?

629
00:30:58.510 --> 00:31:02.600
We got a WSUS server that's in
the isolation network that will allow you

630
00:31:02.600 --> 00:31:04.050
to update your computer.

631
00:31:04.050 --> 00:31:05.270
And when it's updated,

632
00:31:05.270 --> 00:31:07.950
just pass your statement of health back
off to the registration authority.

633
00:31:07.950 --> 00:31:09.192
We go through this process again.

634
00:31:09.192 --> 00:31:14.105
If you've met the network policy, now
you gain access to the resources, right?

635
00:31:14.105 --> 00:31:18.165
You also have CISCO has network access
control too, but again generically,

636
00:31:18.165 --> 00:31:20.755
network access control are those
technologies, policies and

637
00:31:20.755 --> 00:31:25.245
procedures that you implement in order
to govern and control what users or

638
00:31:25.245 --> 00:31:28.810
devices have access to your network.

639
00:31:28.810 --> 00:31:31.415
Last but not the least,
access control list.

640
00:31:31.415 --> 00:31:33.390
We've already talked about
these in other episodes.

641
00:31:33.390 --> 00:31:37.623
Keep in mind an ACL is just
a way that you can govern,

642
00:31:37.623 --> 00:31:42.653
based on identity,
what level of access that somebody has.

643
00:31:42.653 --> 00:31:45.950
MAC filtering, we've talked about
MAC filtering in other episodes too.

644
00:31:45.950 --> 00:31:50.640
Keep in mind this is just a list of
approved, or allowed, or denied MAC

645
00:31:50.640 --> 00:31:55.800
addresses to computers that are allowed
again or denied access to your network.

646
00:31:55.800 --> 00:31:58.528
Port security,
we've seen some examples of it, right,

647
00:31:58.528 --> 00:32:00.830
802.1X port based authentication.

648
00:32:00.830 --> 00:32:05.257
As well as port security based on a MAC
address too where the switch says, hey,

649
00:32:05.257 --> 00:32:09.550
I only expect to see a source MAC address
coming from this computer that I know

650
00:32:09.550 --> 00:32:12.055
is authorized to be
connected to that port.

651
00:32:12.055 --> 00:32:15.736
if I see any other Mac address,
sending information on that port,

652
00:32:15.736 --> 00:32:18.250
we close it down,
no access for that device.

653
00:32:18.250 --> 00:32:21.050
So few of the different things
that I would be aware of when it

654
00:32:21.050 --> 00:32:21.870
comes to this exam.

655
00:32:21.870 --> 00:32:25.334
So if they ask you about things
like RADIUS and TACACS plus,

656
00:32:25.334 --> 00:32:27.250
you're gonna be doing well.

657
00:32:27.250 --> 00:32:31.260
Know the ports, know the technologies for
the next time you sit the Net Plus exam.

658
00:32:31.260 --> 00:32:33.760
>> Awesome, authentication and
access control, part two.

659
00:32:33.760 --> 00:32:35.775
There was a part one,
make sure you watch them both.

660
00:32:35.775 --> 00:32:37.180
Wes is doing a wonderful job, and

661
00:32:37.180 --> 00:32:41.190
he's done a great job putting together
the CompTOIA Net Plus series of videos.

662
00:32:41.190 --> 00:32:42.140
Make sure you watch all of them,

663
00:32:42.140 --> 00:32:45.720
and when you're in that course library,
there's all kinds of other videos there.

664
00:32:45.720 --> 00:32:48.760
And they're all designed to do one thing,
help you go further.

665
00:32:48.760 --> 00:32:50.799
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

666
00:32:50.799 --> 00:32:52.690
ITProTV is binge-worthy.

667
00:32:52.690 --> 00:32:54.110
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

668
00:32:54.110 --> 00:32:54.930
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

669
00:32:54.930 --> 00:32:56.165
>> And we will see you very soon.

670
00:32:57.732 --> 00:33:03.650
[MUSIC]

671
00:33:03.650 --> 00:33:06.607
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes explore ways in which to secure basic wireless networks. They will look at topics like WPA, WPA2, TKIP, CCMP.....etc.
episodes.title: Basic Wireless Network Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:03.403
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host [INAUDIBLE]

2
00:00:03.403 --> 00:00:05.640
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:05.640 --> 00:00:13.670
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV.

4
00:00:13.670 --> 00:00:15.890
Helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:15.890 --> 00:00:17.050
I'm your host Zach Memos.

6
00:00:17.050 --> 00:00:19.990
As we continue on with compt and net+.

7
00:00:19.990 --> 00:00:23.770
In this episode,
basic wireless network security.

8
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:24.510
I want to hear about this.

9
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:26.770
I know you do too and
Wes Bryan is gonna help us out.

10
00:00:26.770 --> 00:00:27.650
Wes, good to see you, sir.

11
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:29.180
>> Hey, Zach, great to see you too.

12
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:31.200
That's right, good to be back and
that's right.

13
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:34.520
We are moving into well,
some basic wireless security.

14
00:00:34.520 --> 00:00:40.070
Like Zach already said, we will dive
right into the technologies that

15
00:00:40.070 --> 00:00:45.930
we need to be aware of to help secure,
well, those unbounded networks, right?

16
00:00:45.930 --> 00:00:49.890
And you might say well, why do we
need security in wireless networks?

17
00:00:49.890 --> 00:00:51.220
Well, it's exactly that.

18
00:00:51.220 --> 00:00:56.590
If you think about it, with a physical,
bounded media, right, transmission media.

19
00:00:56.590 --> 00:01:01.790
In order to gain access to it you have
to physically plug into the network and

20
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:03.930
that's certainly not to say
that it's impossible but

21
00:01:03.930 --> 00:01:06.740
it's where we get that
term wiretapping from.

22
00:01:06.740 --> 00:01:11.290
Maybe not so easy on our fiber optic
networks because of the fact what it

23
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:15.090
takes to terminate a fiber optic cable,
right?

24
00:01:15.090 --> 00:01:16.610
But with Copper Networks, right?

25
00:01:16.610 --> 00:01:20.650
Our twisted pair implementations,
cut the cable, put an RJ-45 jack on it,

26
00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:23.250
slap it right into the network adapter and
now you're in, right?

27
00:01:23.250 --> 00:01:25.302
And I know it's not quite that easy, but

28
00:01:25.302 --> 00:01:30.340
a lot easier when you're talking about
wireless communication and why is that?

29
00:01:30.340 --> 00:01:31.450
Well we have radios, right?

30
00:01:31.450 --> 00:01:34.600
We have antennas if you will,
they're giving off a signal.

31
00:01:34.600 --> 00:01:37.650
All we have to do, is we gotta
be in proximity of that signal,

32
00:01:37.650 --> 00:01:41.300
in order to gain access to it and
if the data isn't secure.

33
00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:44.720
Well, then we could
gain access to the data

34
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:48.190
that's traversing that network as well.

35
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:51.240
So we're gonna talk up a little
bit about some of the different,

36
00:01:51.240 --> 00:01:53.590
wireless Encryption technologies and

37
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:56.200
some of the components that
are surrounding them here in this episode.

38
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:01.720
All right so let's go ahead and I'm gonna
mention one, in fact let's look at some of

39
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:05.710
the cryptographic protocols that we
have here for wireless communications.

40
00:02:05.710 --> 00:02:07.350
Now I will tell you ladies and

41
00:02:07.350 --> 00:02:12.090
gentlemen one that isn't on the exam is
the very first one on the list, okay.

42
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:15.830
I went ahead and decided that it would be
beneficial to our viewers, whether this is

43
00:02:15.830 --> 00:02:20.000
on the exam or not, it would be beneficial
to our users to put it within the list.

44
00:02:20.000 --> 00:02:25.200
The reason I say that is I do believe
that it's good to know where the wireless

45
00:02:25.200 --> 00:02:29.010
securities technologies has come from
to kinda give you that timeline of

46
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:29.790
where we are now.

47
00:02:29.790 --> 00:02:33.440
And the very first one on the list
is what's know as WEP, all right?

48
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:35.950
Now, WEP we kinda wanna stay away from,
all right?

49
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:40.210
There's a reason maybe that it's
not in the objectives anymore but

50
00:02:40.210 --> 00:02:42.410
we wanna raise awareness nonetheless,
okay?

51
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:46.440
WEP is called Wired Equivalent Privacy,
alright?

52
00:02:46.440 --> 00:02:48.650
Now when we talk about
Wired Equivalent Privacy,

53
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:51.720
remember what I said
when we started the show?

54
00:02:51.720 --> 00:02:54.690
I said when you have a wireless network,
right?

55
00:02:54.690 --> 00:02:58.360
In order to gain access to that network or
a wired network.

56
00:02:58.360 --> 00:03:03.158
When you have a wired network, in order
to gain access to that wired network

57
00:03:03.158 --> 00:03:06.748
you have to be able to physically
plug into the network.

58
00:03:06.748 --> 00:03:12.023
When wireless networks first came out,
some of the very first 802.11 protocols,

59
00:03:12.023 --> 00:03:16.802
a and b, when they were released back
in 1999, understand that if we didn't

60
00:03:16.802 --> 00:03:21.233
have security, people could get to
the proximity of a wireless network and

61
00:03:21.233 --> 00:03:25.275
if they did some manipulations to
their network adapters, right.

62
00:03:25.275 --> 00:03:27.420
They put it in ad hoc mode or
promiscuous mode,

63
00:03:27.420 --> 00:03:31.240
they could start to read all
the information coming off that network.

64
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:36.010
All right, so the IEEE and a consortium
of people called the Wi-Fi Alliance,

65
00:03:36.010 --> 00:03:39.910
which is basically a consortium
of wireless manufacturers that

66
00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:43.080
promote their standards and
specifications, said you know what?

67
00:03:43.080 --> 00:03:47.475
We need to put some basic level
security on wireless network.

68
00:03:47.475 --> 00:03:48.810
So they came out with WEP.

69
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:50.658
Again, Wired Equivalent Privacy.

70
00:03:50.658 --> 00:03:55.760
Now you gotta understand that you don't
really have privacy on a wired network.

71
00:03:55.760 --> 00:03:59.040
The only way you have privacy on
a network is to make sure that, like

72
00:03:59.040 --> 00:04:03.170
we've talked about, you have encryption
protocols that encrypt the communications

73
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:06.580
as they transverse the network
between the source and destination.

74
00:04:06.580 --> 00:04:09.890
So essentially what wire equivalent
privacy did when it came out,

75
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:13.040
again we're talking about released
as a security standard back in 1999,

76
00:04:13.040 --> 00:04:17.330
is it basically pulled the blinds
down right, in the living room.

77
00:04:17.330 --> 00:04:18.630
I want you to think about that.

78
00:04:18.630 --> 00:04:23.270
What I mean by that is imagine if
somebody's just walking their dog at night

79
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:26.910
outside of your house, and
you have all the windows open.

80
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:33.110
People can see in but if you take
the blinds and you just close them up.

81
00:04:33.110 --> 00:04:34.530
You close the windows down.

82
00:04:34.530 --> 00:04:37.640
It's not so easy to see what's
going on in your network.

83
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:42.300
However, for a trained professional,
like a professional thief, if you will.

84
00:04:42.300 --> 00:04:44.300
What are those blinds,

85
00:04:44.300 --> 00:04:48.420
what are shutting those windows going
to do for the professional thief?

86
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:49.800
Not much.

87
00:04:49.800 --> 00:04:53.203
And that is the problem right there
with wired equivalent privacy.

88
00:04:53.203 --> 00:04:57.070
All right,
WEP gives you that wired privacy of

89
00:04:57.070 --> 00:05:00.490
I at least have to plug into the network,
but it doesn't go far enough.

90
00:05:00.490 --> 00:05:05.330
In fact, the initial release, at the time
that it was released to the public was

91
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:10.580
only 64 bit encryption, and
even in those days when it first came out

92
00:05:10.580 --> 00:05:13.510
even given the computational power of
computers that wasn't very strong.

93
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:15.760
There were some issues with
the government there, and

94
00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:19.860
it wasn't until later revisions that they
would bump up the key length, right?

95
00:05:19.860 --> 00:05:21.080
Remember what a key is.

96
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:23.930
We'll talk more about encryption and
stuff in other episodes but

97
00:05:23.930 --> 00:05:24.920
we're talking about it enough.

98
00:05:24.920 --> 00:05:29.743
Just remember encryption, that's
a mathematical operation that we apply to

99
00:05:29.743 --> 00:05:33.760
the data that makes sure that
it's scrambled all right?

100
00:05:33.760 --> 00:05:36.630
The other thing I want you to understand
is that the encryption algorithm

101
00:05:36.630 --> 00:05:39.680
again is just that mathematical operation.

102
00:05:39.680 --> 00:05:44.640
However we make it unique to you and
I right?

103
00:05:44.640 --> 00:05:47.530
I can tell you 1 + 1 = 2 all right?

104
00:05:47.530 --> 00:05:49.260
That would be the encryption algorithm.

105
00:05:49.260 --> 00:05:52.500
Now they're a lot more
advanced than that but,

106
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:57.090
if I say 1+1 is 2 and then you're
gonna multiply that times 3 and

107
00:05:57.090 --> 00:06:01.890
put a square, exponential on it,
and that's the key.

108
00:06:01.890 --> 00:06:06.200
That makes that mathematical operation
unique now to you and I, right.

109
00:06:06.200 --> 00:06:09.210
Somebody's not gonna understand how
1+1 equals some crazy long number.

110
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:11.880
They're gonna say well wait a second,
what kind of math are you doing?

111
00:06:11.880 --> 00:06:14.720
Well, that's because we applied a modifier
to it and that's what the keys do.

112
00:06:14.720 --> 00:06:18.470
The greater the modifier,
the greater the key if you will,

113
00:06:18.470 --> 00:06:25.090
length in bits makes it a greater
complexity to try to break that key.

114
00:06:25.090 --> 00:06:27.770
Well, with 64 bits, that wasn't much.

115
00:06:27.770 --> 00:06:31.460
The other problem is agin once
it bumped up to 128 and 256,

116
00:06:31.460 --> 00:06:34.730
computers started to get stronger and
stronger and

117
00:06:34.730 --> 00:06:40.800
even on 128 bit which was the most common
and widely used deployment in WEEP.

118
00:06:40.800 --> 00:06:47.930
By the end of 2005 the FBI had
proof of concept that WEP was weak.

119
00:06:47.930 --> 00:06:51.650
They could break a WEP encryption
key in about two minutes.

120
00:06:51.650 --> 00:06:58.190
All right so WEP I want you to understand
was the initial security release.

121
00:06:58.190 --> 00:07:00.170
It was never meant to be
a one size fits all and

122
00:07:00.170 --> 00:07:04.080
a stop gap for everything that
would need security in general.

123
00:07:04.080 --> 00:07:05.860
So we had to move away from it and,

124
00:07:05.860 --> 00:07:09.065
eventually, WEP became
a thing of the past.

125
00:07:09.065 --> 00:07:10.960
>> Does anyone ever still use WEP?

126
00:07:10.960 --> 00:07:13.370
>> Yeah, some people, I've asked before.

127
00:07:13.370 --> 00:07:17.350
Sometimes you need due diligence and
people don't really care about how secret

128
00:07:17.350 --> 00:07:20.760
the information is, so they're not
necessarily doing it to be secretive.

129
00:07:20.760 --> 00:07:23.700
But they're just doing it to,
again pull the blinds down so

130
00:07:23.700 --> 00:07:26.810
somebody walking past the street
can't casually look in, right?

131
00:07:26.810 --> 00:07:28.260
>> That's a great analogy.

132
00:07:28.260 --> 00:07:31.450
>> It's not done for the purposes
of keeping your data confidential,

133
00:07:31.450 --> 00:07:33.660
it's just keeping the average
person off the network.

134
00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:35.050
However-
>> Got it.

135
00:07:35.050 --> 00:07:37.910
>> It certainly isn't going to stop

a certificate and I have a certificate.

00:20:34.780 --> 00:20:39.770

using EAPTLS has a certificate,

00:20:45.160 --> 00:20:50.340
It's not really a big deal, but it's two
certificates that need to be present,

00:20:50.340 --> 00:20:54.620
valid, validated for
authentication to happen.

00:20:54.620 --> 00:21:00.760
And while that is secure, on a large scale

00:21:00.760 --> 00:21:02.960
a lot of certificates that we

00:21:02.960 --> 00:21:05.120
That's why we have public infrastructure,
right?

00:21:05.120 --> 00:21:07.300
It's a whole entire infrastructure
that's gotta be managed and

371
00:21:07.300 --> 00:21:08.824
maintained to use EAP-TLS.

372
00:21:09.980 --> 00:21:13.600
That takes us back to flexible
authentication vie secure tunnelling

373
00:21:13.600 --> 00:21:15.440
EAP FAST.

374
00:21:15.440 --> 00:21:19.420
Because EAP FAST allows, if you will,
for the mutual authentication.

375
00:21:19.420 --> 00:21:24.220
But what's great about it is it only
requires a server-side certificate.

376
00:21:25.390 --> 00:21:30.640
Alright when an EAP fast client
connects to an authentication server,

377
00:21:30.640 --> 00:21:33.420
just like I said, Zack if I was
the server connecting to me I'm gonna

378
00:21:33.420 --> 00:21:36.160
pass him over my digital certificate,
identifying who I am.

379
00:21:36.160 --> 00:21:39.930
Well that same process still happens,
but the difference is,

380
00:21:39.930 --> 00:21:45.360
now we're using what's known as
Protected Authentication Credentials.

381
00:21:45.360 --> 00:21:49.930
PACs that are generated by
the authentication server, not by public.

382
00:21:49.930 --> 00:21:54.030
So that the server can do
all before us for us and

383
00:21:54.030 --> 00:21:59.000
it saves a little of the complexities and
that's one of the benefits of EAP Fast.

384
00:21:59.000 --> 00:22:02.290
EAPTLS is still one of
the most highly used.

385
00:22:02.290 --> 00:22:07.389
In fact, today you'll see

386
00:22:07.389 --> 00:22:11.340
version two being used for

00:22:11.340 --> 00:22:17.580
you'll see EAPTLS being used, but again,

00:24:30.825 --> 00:24:33.865

Whitelisting means you're

So you can filter people off of your

And again it can be an allow

00:24:44.720 --> 00:24:47.580
All right and it can also be

00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:22.380
So you don't use them by them by yourself,

00:25:22.380 --> 00:25:23.920

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes look at some of the common networking attacks that administrators need to protect against. They will discuss attacks like various denial-of-service attacks, phishing, social engineering, evil twin attacks, spoofing and more.
episodes.title: Common Networking Attacks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.074
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet, [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.074 --> 00:00:06.975
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.975 --> 00:00:08.500
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.500 --> 00:00:10.768
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.768 --> 00:00:13.700
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.700 --> 00:00:16.620
helping you to learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:20.300
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA and Net+.

8
00:00:20.300 --> 00:00:23.710
In this episode,
common networking attacks.

9
00:00:23.710 --> 00:00:26.548
And we've asked Wes Bryan to
come along and show us the way.

10
00:00:26.548 --> 00:00:27.470
Wes, good to see you, sir.

11
00:00:27.470 --> 00:00:29.970
>> Hey, Zach, thanks for having me back,
that's right, great to be here.

12
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:32.790
And yes, this is going to be one
of those episodes, I have to say,

13
00:00:32.790 --> 00:00:36.147
that's gonna lend itself to a tin
foil hat by the time you are done.

14
00:00:36.147 --> 00:00:37.084
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

15
00:00:37.084 --> 00:00:40.649
that's because we're gonna be talking
about a lot of the different attack types

16
00:00:40.649 --> 00:00:42.760
that you, hopefully, will never encounter.

17
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:45.353
But at least need to be aware of for
the Net+ exam.

18
00:00:45.353 --> 00:00:49.270
And also as you transition into
your networking careers, right?

19
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:53.468
One of the things that I've
heard said before is can you

20
00:00:53.468 --> 00:00:57.400
show me an example of
a completely secure network?

21
00:00:57.400 --> 00:01:01.170
And a lot of people will tell you, well,
that's the one that doesn't exist.

22
00:01:01.170 --> 00:01:03.060
So it is important to understand.

23
00:01:03.060 --> 00:01:05.150
And remember, like we've talked
to you in other episodes,

24
00:01:05.150 --> 00:01:07.110
we mentioned the concept
of defense in depth, right?

25
00:01:07.110 --> 00:01:10.046
A layered defense system,
physical security is that second layer.

26
00:01:10.046 --> 00:01:13.930
And that very first layer is policies,
procedures, and awareness.

27
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:16.040
So you have to be aware
that things exist and

28
00:01:16.040 --> 00:01:18.440
some of the things that might
happen on your network so

29
00:01:18.440 --> 00:01:21.550
that you can be prepared to better
defend against them, all right?

30
00:01:21.550 --> 00:01:25.180
So let's go ahead and
let's dive right into networking attacks.

31
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:25.840
And we're gonna go ahead and

32
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:30.410
set the stage by talking about
some of the basic concepts.

33
00:01:30.410 --> 00:01:33.870
Cuz one of the things that they mention
in the exam objectives is, well,

34
00:01:33.870 --> 00:01:35.470
exploits versus vulnerabilities.

35
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:38.210
Now I'm gonna go ahead, and
we're gonna split these up.

36
00:01:38.210 --> 00:01:39.960
And we're gonna talk
about them individually.

37
00:01:39.960 --> 00:01:42.810
Let's go ahead and
start by talking about an exploit.

38
00:01:42.810 --> 00:01:45.590
An exploit, essentially, is nothing
more than an attack, if you will,

39
00:01:45.590 --> 00:01:47.530
that takes advantage of some weakness.

40
00:01:47.530 --> 00:01:52.780
Some weakness in a device, system,
or within a network, all right?

41
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:55.740
Now that's the exploit,
all right, what's the weakness?

42
00:01:55.740 --> 00:01:58.550
Well, the weakness is actually where
the vulnerability comes into play.

43
00:01:58.550 --> 00:02:01.900
We say that an exploit is
an attack of some weakness.

44
00:02:01.900 --> 00:02:03.638
Well, the weakness,

45
00:02:03.638 --> 00:02:08.675
we could also say the exploit is
an attack on some vulnerability.

46
00:02:08.675 --> 00:02:12.867
And the vulnerability is the weakness in
the system, or device, or network, if you

47
00:02:12.867 --> 00:02:17.237
will, that will, essentially, lead to some
kind of compromise in confidentiality,

48
00:02:17.237 --> 00:02:21.452
integrity, and availability of the system,
the data that resides on that system.

49
00:02:21.452 --> 00:02:24.880
And that's important to
understand the difference, right?

50
00:02:24.880 --> 00:02:28.360
Now an attack, right?

51
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:33.390
An attack is just the method that we used,
follow me here, the attacke

52
00:02:33.390 --> 00:02:36.970
is the method that we used to exploit
the vulnerability, if that make sense.

53
00:02:36.970 --> 00:02:41.158
And they don't really call out attack
as a definition, but let's go ahead and

54
00:02:41.158 --> 00:02:42.882
just define it for you, right?

55
00:02:42.882 --> 00:02:47.601
Now the next thing I wanna talk about,
because we are gonna mentioned pretty

56
00:02:47.601 --> 00:02:52.392
heavily through the different types of
attacks another concept that, in and

57
00:02:52.392 --> 00:02:54.860
of itself, it can be an attack.

58
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:58.150
But it also forms the basis for
other types of attacks that we talk about.

59
00:02:58.150 --> 00:03:00.660
And that's something known as spoofing,
all right?

60
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:07.292
When we talk about spoofing, spoofing is
just the attacker manipulates data, right?

61
00:03:07.292 --> 00:03:13.839
Maliciously manipulates data, falsifying
that data to basically impersonate or

62
00:03:13.839 --> 00:03:19.190
to represent themselves as someone or
something else, all right?

63
00:03:19.190 --> 00:03:21.213
So it's a misrepresentation.

64
00:03:21.213 --> 00:03:24.700
It could be, for instance, an IP address.

65
00:03:24.700 --> 00:03:28.640
If I wanna make it look like I'm
supposed to be on this network, and

66
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:30.790
I'm sending information from
inside of this network,

67
00:03:30.790 --> 00:03:35.930
then if I spoofed the IP address,
as an attacker, it's not my IP address.

68
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:39.450
But it's a completely different
IP address, I've spoofed it.

69
00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:43.520
And it makes it look, I'm impersonating,
I'm falsifying the information within that

70
00:03:43.520 --> 00:03:48.970
data packet to masquerade as being
something or someone completely different.

71
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:51.710
So it's important to
understand what spoofing is.

72
00:03:51.710 --> 00:03:56.380
Spoofing, itself, could be things
like impersonation, all right?

73
00:03:56.380 --> 00:03:59.959
Here's a spoof attack that lends itself
to social engineering that really

74
00:03:59.959 --> 00:04:02.478
doesn't have to deal with
the more technical side.

75
00:04:02.478 --> 00:04:07.810
We're talking about protocols and
stuff like that, impersonation, right?

76
00:04:07.810 --> 00:04:11.520
I call up the help desk, I'm on the phone,
and I call up the help desk.

77
00:04:11.520 --> 00:04:16.010
And I say, hey, we're part of the,
actually, I impersonate the help desk.

78
00:04:16.010 --> 00:04:17.141
Let's be a little more clear here.

79
00:04:17.141 --> 00:04:19.571
And I call somebody,
maybe the receptionist or

80
00:04:19.571 --> 00:04:23.500
somebody that's a little bit more
vulnerable, maybe not so tech-savvy.

81
00:04:23.500 --> 00:04:27.547
And I say, hey, at the end of the day,
we've got X, Y, Z, lay it on thick.

82
00:04:27.547 --> 00:04:30.600
We got this upgrade that needs to happen.

83
00:04:30.600 --> 00:04:35.326
And maybe earlier that day in our social
engineering attack we kinda found out

84
00:04:35.326 --> 00:04:37.299
what the name of the person was.

85
00:04:37.299 --> 00:04:39.720
And we found out a little
bit of information.

86
00:04:39.720 --> 00:04:42.602
And we say, hey, we're part of help desk,
we need your username and password.

87
00:04:42.602 --> 00:04:45.670
And if the person isn't aware,
they give you the username and

88
00:04:45.670 --> 00:04:47.584
password over the phone, all right?

89
00:04:47.584 --> 00:04:49.537
Now it's social engineering,
but what am I doing?

90
00:04:49.537 --> 00:04:53.290
I'm an impersonator, and
a probably a bad one at that.

91
00:04:53.290 --> 00:04:55.060
But I'm impersonating somebody else.

92
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:59.900
I'm masquerading as somebody that I'm not
for the purposes of exploiting a system.

93
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:01.855
Very basically, that could be spoofing.

94
00:05:01.855 --> 00:05:05.960
It's a social engineering attack
called impersonation, but

95
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:07.350
it's still a form of spoofing.

96
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:10.544
>> Is another form of spoofing, could that
be like when you receive an email that it

97
00:05:10.544 --> 00:05:11.795
might say this is from PayPal?

98
00:05:11.795 --> 00:05:14.434
And you you open it up, and
it's not really from PayPal?

99
00:05:14.434 --> 00:05:16.830
It kinda looks like it's from PayPal,
but it's not necessarily?

100
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:19.282
>> I could see that, but that's more
commonly what they call phishing.

101
00:05:19.282 --> 00:05:21.073
>> Okay.
>> That's called a phishing scam,

102
00:05:21.073 --> 00:05:21.630
all right?

103
00:05:21.630 --> 00:05:24.500
Now the underlying technique
is almost the same.

104
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:27.560
Cuz you're making it look like it came
from a legitimate source, absolutely.

105
00:05:27.560 --> 00:05:30.383
So I understand that, but that's
technically what they call phishing.

106
00:05:30.383 --> 00:05:33.480
>> And I'm glad you mentioned it because
it's one of the things on the list.

107
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:35.868
So either way, we need to talk about it.

108
00:05:35.868 --> 00:05:36.843
>> We will.

109
00:05:36.843 --> 00:05:41.669
>> And you will see as we go through
this list that some of these

110
00:05:41.669 --> 00:05:46.660
different attack types do
require some bit of spoofing.

111
00:05:46.660 --> 00:05:47.670
So keep that in mind.

112
00:05:47.670 --> 00:05:50.920
Now on the first one that we talk about,
attack type,

113
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:53.540
is something known as a denial of service,
all right?

114
00:05:53.540 --> 00:05:58.910
And when I talk about a denial of service
attack, a denial of service, at its very

115
00:05:58.910 --> 00:06:03.610
basic nature, is just you require service,
and you don't get it, all right?

116
00:06:03.610 --> 00:06:07.380
You require access to some data,
and you don't get it.

117
00:06:07.380 --> 00:06:10.660
You require communication across
the network, and you don't get it.

118
00:06:10.660 --> 00:06:14.448
You require access to a Wi-Fi network,
and you don't get it, right?

119
00:06:14.448 --> 00:06:15.800
Denial of service, right?

120
00:06:15.800 --> 00:06:20.560
Think that, whatever service is
across the network that you rely on,

121
00:06:20.560 --> 00:06:23.010
you don't have access to it, all right?

122
00:06:23.010 --> 00:06:26.636
Now when it comes to denial of service,
there are few different types, all right?

123
00:06:26.636 --> 00:06:30.033
There are three different types
that they call out in the exam.

124
00:06:30.033 --> 00:06:31.584
There's what's known as distributed.

125
00:06:31.584 --> 00:06:34.893
There's what's known as amplified and
reflective, all right?

126
00:06:34.893 --> 00:06:39.180
The first one, distributed,
sometimes I heard it called DDoS.

127
00:06:39.180 --> 00:06:43.030
Sometimes I've heard it called DDOS,
right?

128
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:49.550
I call it DDOS more often than not, but I
actually hear people call it DDoS, right?

129
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:52.439
This is a distributed
denial of service attack.

130
00:06:52.439 --> 00:06:54.840
And what do we mean by distributed,
all right?

131
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:58.721
Well, a basic DoS attack,
denial of service, right,

132
00:06:58.721 --> 00:07:03.272
is typically a single attacker
against an endpoint, all right?

133
00:07:03.272 --> 00:07:05.980
Whatever the target is.

134
00:07:05.980 --> 00:07:11.640
So I walk over, and I pull the power, if I
have physical access to your access point.

135
00:07:11.640 --> 00:07:13.823
And I pull the power on it,
now your wireless network goes down.

136
00:07:13.823 --> 00:07:17.110
Well, that's a denial of service attack.

137
00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:20.230
If we do a distributed
denial of service attack,

138
00:07:20.230 --> 00:07:22.480
it means that the attack vector, right?

139
00:07:22.480 --> 00:07:27.000
The point that the attack is being
made is coming from multiple sources.

140
00:07:27.000 --> 00:07:32.770
And they do this for specific reasons, in
fact, I got a little example here, right?

141
00:07:34.180 --> 00:07:37.974
Now there's a couple of things that
happened to propagate a distributed denial

142
00:07:37.974 --> 00:07:38.946
of service attack.

143
00:07:38.946 --> 00:07:42.397
And it's one that they don't call out on
the objectives, but I want you to know for

144
00:07:42.397 --> 00:07:43.467
the exam, just in case.

145
00:07:43.467 --> 00:07:47.703
And it's usually, a distributed denial of
service attack is accomplished through

146
00:07:47.703 --> 00:07:49.680
what's known as a botnet, all right?

147
00:07:49.680 --> 00:07:54.673
A botnet is when an attacker, so
our attacker right here, basically,

148
00:07:54.673 --> 00:07:59.432
spreads a piece of malicious code,
piece of software, all right?

149
00:07:59.432 --> 00:08:02.372
Sends it out through phishing
scams like we were talking about,

150
00:08:02.372 --> 00:08:05.918
an email that looks like it came from
a legitimate source with an attachment.

151
00:08:05.918 --> 00:08:08.637
You download the attachment,
you open it up.

152
00:08:08.637 --> 00:08:12.114
And it installs a piece of
software called a drone software,

153
00:08:12.114 --> 00:08:14.774
zombie software that
seats on your computer,

154
00:08:14.774 --> 00:08:18.540
installs itself and then quietly waits for
some kind of command.

155
00:08:19.970 --> 00:08:23.970
Then that propagates through
out maybe an email system,

156
00:08:23.970 --> 00:08:30.240
maybe a social media if you will and then
it infects more than one computer, right?

157
00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:30.920
So what's happening?

158
00:08:30.920 --> 00:08:32.160
Here's the distribution.

159
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:36.090
A distribution of that bot and
it's spreading that malware across to all

160
00:08:36.090 --> 00:08:40.660
of these computers and then the attacker
issues some kind of command.

161
00:08:41.670 --> 00:08:46.450
Maybe the software has all of these
machines attached to one of the old

162
00:08:46.450 --> 00:08:49.350
IRC the Internet Relay Chatrooms.

163
00:08:49.350 --> 00:08:53.712
The attacker hits that chatroom,
enters the command, and then all of these

164
00:08:53.712 --> 00:08:58.430
computers distributed simultaneously hit
a single target bringing in offline.

165
00:08:58.430 --> 00:09:00.870
And why do you have to do that?

166
00:09:00.870 --> 00:09:04.720
Well, because in some network attacks,
remember that in a denial service attack,

167
00:09:04.720 --> 00:09:08.670
if you're using network protocols
you have to overwhelmed the target.

168
00:09:08.670 --> 00:09:13.480
To bring it offline, to keep it busy
answering to bogus service requests so

169
00:09:13.480 --> 00:09:16.050
that it can't answer the service
requests of other people.

170
00:09:16.050 --> 00:09:18.940
So for instance you've got a web server
out there and it's serving up your

171
00:09:18.940 --> 00:09:22.640
company's website and your company's
website sells stuff and makes money.

172
00:09:22.640 --> 00:09:25.140
Well if you have one of these distributed
denial of service attacks and

173
00:09:25.140 --> 00:09:29.310
it's attacking that web server, and
it might not even be bringing it offline.

174
00:09:29.310 --> 00:09:32.170
It's making bogus web request.

175
00:09:32.170 --> 00:09:36.754
So here your poor web servers now sending
back these responses to the web request to

176
00:09:36.754 --> 00:09:39.744
all the infected machines and
it's keeping itself so

177
00:09:39.744 --> 00:09:43.070
busy that now Zach this time
you get your credit card.

178
00:09:43.070 --> 00:09:48.080
Zach comes to this credit card he wants to
purchase a product from that website but

179
00:09:48.080 --> 00:09:49.890
that websites to busy right now,

180
00:09:49.890 --> 00:09:54.290
it's to busy trying to respond to all
these bogus requests it's denial of

181
00:09:54.290 --> 00:09:59.230
service it's distributed because it's
distributed across all of these computers.

182
00:09:59.230 --> 00:10:03.170
Now you also have another one
that they don't call out but

183
00:10:03.170 --> 00:10:07.552
it's a form of distributed or
DDOS but it's a coordinated attack.

184
00:10:07.552 --> 00:10:12.940
All right, and that's where,
maybe what I do, is I don't have,

185
00:10:12.940 --> 00:10:19.680
a botnet per say but what I do here is,
I have multiple people,

186
00:10:19.680 --> 00:10:24.500
let me just replace these, these,
apparently with a circle there.

187
00:10:24.500 --> 00:10:28.670
Let me replace that code with
multiple attackers, right?

188
00:10:28.670 --> 00:10:33.260
This is still a distributed denial
of service attack because it

189
00:10:33.260 --> 00:10:38.180
is distributing the attack
amongst multiple computers here.

190
00:10:38.180 --> 00:10:41.390
If I can do that without
creating all these crazy lines.

191
00:10:41.390 --> 00:10:45.300
What we see is going on here though is
that it is coordinated in the fact that

192
00:10:45.300 --> 00:10:50.120
there's more than one person orchestrating
the attack against the target.

193
00:10:50.120 --> 00:10:53.338
That's still a distributed
denial of service attack, but

194
00:10:53.338 --> 00:10:57.647
it is called a coordinated attack again
because it is more than one attacker that

195
00:10:57.647 --> 00:11:01.407
are working in tandem, working
together to bring a target offline.

196
00:11:01.407 --> 00:11:06.097
Now, typically, another reason you have
to do a distributed denial of service

197
00:11:06.097 --> 00:11:10.297
attack is because anyone of these
machines by themselves would not have

198
00:11:10.297 --> 00:11:15.127
the computational power and be able to
make the request fast enough to overwhelm,

199
00:11:15.127 --> 00:11:19.750
or make the resource so busy that it
can't respond or it crashes the computer.

200
00:11:19.750 --> 00:11:22.515
So you have to up the ante a little bit.

201
00:11:22.515 --> 00:11:27.210
You've gotta basically overwhelm the
target with more resource requests than

202
00:11:27.210 --> 00:11:28.610
it can handle.

203
00:11:28.610 --> 00:11:32.850
You've got to hit it with more information
essentially than the network can handle.

204
00:11:32.850 --> 00:11:36.180
You're exceeding the bandwidth
capabilities of the network.

205
00:11:37.470 --> 00:11:39.800
That's why we do distributed
denial service attacks.

206
00:11:39.800 --> 00:11:41.100
I say we, but not we.

207
00:11:41.100 --> 00:11:44.880
The attackers do but
then there's other ones too.

208
00:11:44.880 --> 00:11:49.610
There's what's known as reflected and
amplified and they are not the same.

209
00:11:49.610 --> 00:11:54.590
Okay, let's go ahead and
let's talk about first I'll go ahead and

210
00:11:54.590 --> 00:11:55.420
take this out of here.

211
00:11:55.420 --> 00:11:57.210
We'll talk about the reflective first.

212
00:11:57.210 --> 00:12:00.000
All right, here's where
spoofing comes back into play.

213
00:12:00.000 --> 00:12:03.050
All right, notice it for
the most part our diagram looks the same.

214
00:12:03.050 --> 00:12:04.990
All right, but

215
00:12:04.990 --> 00:12:08.500
you notice the packet internet grouper
the pane utility that we used, right?

216
00:12:08.500 --> 00:12:10.980
The pane utility is interesting
because what do we do?

217
00:12:10.980 --> 00:12:14.190
We send out a little bit of information,
right?

218
00:12:14.190 --> 00:12:16.630
And we request a little
bit of information back.

219
00:12:17.860 --> 00:12:23.460
Well, what if I could multiply that
distributor across multiple computers,

>> And we will see you soon.

453
00:24:44.492 --> 00:24:50.033
[MUSIC]

454
00:24:50.033 --> 00:24:54.460
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes look at some of the common networking attacks that administrators need to protect against. They will discuss attacks like various denial-of-service attacks, phishing, social engineering, evil twin attacks, spoofing and more.
episodes.title: Common Networking Attacks Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

California.

choosing ITProTV,

8

9

I'm Zach Memos, and I'm your host as

part two.

And bringing us all the information we

Wes, good to see you, sir.

13

>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Zach.

14
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:33.770
That's right,
we're going back to our tinfoil episode.

15
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:36.670
We talked a little bit
about In the first part

16
00:00:36.670 --> 00:00:38.030
about some of the attacks
that you could see.

17
00:00:38.030 --> 00:00:42.040
And we really touched base with
just some basic terms, if you will.

18
00:00:42.040 --> 00:00:44.950
For instance,
things like spoofing, as well

19
00:00:44.950 --> 00:00:49.725
as the different between an exploit and
a vulnerability, as well as attacks, too.

20
00:00:49.725 --> 00:00:53.155
If you are not aware of those,

21
00:00:53.155 --> 00:00:55.495
And then we'll come back, and

22
00:00:55.495 --> 00:00:56.865
>> Yeah, just because you're paranoid,
