really not out to get you.

24
00:00:58.270 --> 00:01:00.575
[LAUGH].
>> That's true, that's true.

25
00:01:00.575 --> 00:01:03.520
Just because I don't believe people
are after me, doesn't mean they're not.

26
00:01:03.520 --> 00:01:05.120
That is right, so
we are going to go ahead and

27
00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:08.640
we are going to pick up where we left off,
and one of the things we left off with,

28
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:12.400
we were just about ready
to talk about logic bombs.

29
00:01:12.400 --> 00:01:16.320
That's the next one in the list here,
but I didn't mention it and

30
00:01:16.320 --> 00:01:18.020
we had to put a comma in that episode, so

31
00:01:18.020 --> 00:01:21.690
that's where we are going to pick up here,
and logic bombs.

32
00:01:21.690 --> 00:01:26.200
When we look at a logic bomb, a logic bomb
is really any kind of malicious code that

33
00:01:26.200 --> 00:01:31.250
sits on your computer and it usually sits
idle for a while, or dormant if you will.

34
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:36.450
And it doesn't perform any action
until a certain trigger event happens.

35
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:41.280
In fact, when we talk about things like
botnets, we talk about distributed

36
00:01:41.280 --> 00:01:43.870
denial of services attacks,
that's one that we did talk about.

37
00:01:43.870 --> 00:01:44.580
>> DDoS.

38
00:01:44.580 --> 00:01:46.260
>> In the first episode there.

39
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:53.300
Keep in mind that that, to create
a distributed denial of service attack,

40
00:01:53.300 --> 00:01:56.150
you have to make sure that the malware
that's gonna control the computers,

41
00:01:56.150 --> 00:01:58.950
the zombies, the drones if you will,
that's going to infect them

42
00:01:58.950 --> 00:02:02.780
Has a chance to propagate through
all of these thousand and thousands,

43
00:02:02.780 --> 00:02:04.400
if not tens of thousands, of computers.

44
00:02:04.400 --> 00:02:06.150
So how do we do that?

45
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:10.127
Alright, well, logic bombs are the way
that we can spread things like botnets, or

46
00:02:10.127 --> 00:02:10.920
attackers.

47
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:14.350
Not necessarily us, alright,
let's put our white hat on and

48
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:16.220
take the black hat off for a little bit.

49
00:02:16.220 --> 00:02:19.790
And it's a way that we can propagate
the malware across tens of

50
00:02:19.790 --> 00:02:21.780
thousands of computers.

51
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:27.290
And what happens is,
after a certain amount of time, the logic

52
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:30.210
bomb will wait for that trigger event,
and then when the trigger event happens,

53
00:02:30.210 --> 00:02:34.079
it performs some kind of malicious action,
all right.

54
00:02:34.079 --> 00:02:36.470
So for instance, if you look at a botnet,

55
00:02:36.470 --> 00:02:40.350
the way it just kinda affects
multiple computers, what happens is,

56
00:02:40.350 --> 00:02:44.840
the logic bomb that becomes the botnet,
will wait for a trigger event.

57
00:02:44.840 --> 00:02:48.730
And maybe everyone on the the computers
will simultaneously hit

58
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:50.220
a signal target at the endpoint.

59
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:54.540
Keep in mind that a logic bomb is
nothing more than a piece of malware,

60
00:02:54.540 --> 00:02:58.010
sits on your computer waiting for
that kind of trigger event.

61
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:02.820
The trigger event could be, when it sees
things like Internet Explorer open up.

62
00:03:02.820 --> 00:03:06.930
Or when you go to access the file system.

63
00:03:06.930 --> 00:03:11.060
Or when a certain executable is launched,
when a certain utility is launched.

64
00:03:11.060 --> 00:03:13.210
Or a time, could be a time as well.

65
00:03:13.210 --> 00:03:15.310
>> Yeah, in fact I was just gonna
ask that, like an alarm clock?

66
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:17.020
>> Yes.
>> And set it for a time and a date.

67
00:03:17.020 --> 00:03:21.864
>> Yeah, definitely, you know,
for instance, a Wow,

68
00:03:21.864 --> 00:03:24.835
well, over a decade if
I could spit this out.

69
00:03:24.835 --> 00:03:26.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well over a decade ago.

70
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:27.790
>> It's overwhelming.

71
00:03:27.790 --> 00:03:31.690
>> We had things like, for instance,
the 9-11 thing happen, and

72
00:03:31.690 --> 00:03:36.620
people might be waiting, their code might
be waiting for something like that, wait

73
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:42.180
until the clock strikes 9, 11 and then
implement whatever the attack might be.

74
00:03:42.180 --> 00:03:46.620
So again, logic bombs, just a piece of
malware waiting for a trigger event.

75
00:03:46.620 --> 00:03:50.960
Now, there are a couple other things that
we also need to talk about when we look at

76
00:03:50.960 --> 00:03:53.050
different types of attacks.

77
00:03:53.050 --> 00:03:57.820
One of the things we need to worry about
is, and I kind of lump these together,

78
00:03:57.820 --> 00:04:00.850
even though they're
technically not the same.

79
00:04:00.850 --> 00:04:02.660
They're both wireless attacks, right?

80
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:04.840
They talk about what's known
as a rogue access point and

81
00:04:04.840 --> 00:04:07.640
they also talk about what's
known as an evil twin.

82
00:04:07.640 --> 00:04:11.360
All right, now, let's start with
the rogue access point, all right?

83
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:15.330
A rogue access point, so when we look
at our wireless infrastructure, right?

84
00:04:15.330 --> 00:04:17.070
We have our stations,
we have our access points.

85
00:04:17.070 --> 00:04:21.540
The access points are those devices that
are managing all the wireless devices on

86
00:04:21.540 --> 00:04:22.130
the network, right?

87
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:25.260
We've talked about them in
our wireless architecture.

88
00:04:25.260 --> 00:04:30.290
Now, what would happen if I would just
grab a wireless access point, not yours,

89
00:04:30.290 --> 00:04:32.880
in your business, and I bring it online?

90
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:35.650
And I put it in the proximity
of your wireless network.

91
00:04:35.650 --> 00:04:37.640
Well, here's what might happen.

92
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:43.186
What might happen is, people could start
to connect to that rogue access point and

93
00:04:43.186 --> 00:04:45.760
at very basic, it could give
them a denial of service attack.

94
00:04:45.760 --> 00:04:49.350
Because they're expecting to connect
to the wireless network, your users,

95
00:04:49.350 --> 00:04:51.330
if you will,
let's say it's a business, right?

96
00:04:51.330 --> 00:04:53.380
They're expecting to connect
to the wireless network and

97
00:04:53.380 --> 00:04:58.220
have access to whether it's the internal
network or the internet, right?

98
00:04:58.220 --> 00:05:00.990
Maybe even more so
social media and YouTube.

99
00:05:00.990 --> 00:05:04.090
All the great things we have
our wireless devices for.

100
00:05:04.090 --> 00:05:06.650
Well, when they connect to
that rogue access point,

101
00:05:06.650 --> 00:05:09.580
the rogue access point doesn't
have internet connection.

102
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:12.640
It's quite literally just an access
point that I brought online and put in

103
00:05:12.640 --> 00:05:16.700
the proximity of your wireless network, so
that people will no longer connect to your

104
00:05:16.700 --> 00:05:20.510
access point, they're gonna connect and
jump back over to this rogue access point.

105
00:05:20.510 --> 00:05:24.360
Now, when that happens, your users cease

106
00:05:24.360 --> 00:05:29.050
to have the normal functionality that
they would on the wireless network.

107
00:05:29.050 --> 00:05:32.720
Now, if we take a look here,
we could couple this now, and

108
00:05:32.720 --> 00:05:35.350
this is what I call an evil twin attack.

109
00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:39.980
All right, see, a rogue access point is
just an unauthorized wireless access point

110
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:42.720
in the proximity to your network
that starts handing out, or

111
00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:45.110
allowing people to connect to it.

112
00:05:45.110 --> 00:05:47.430
And, again, the purposes could
be to scrape your information.

113
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:50.100
It could be just simply to bring people
off of your wireless network and

114
00:05:50.100 --> 00:05:52.730
disrupt your day-to-day productivity.

115
00:05:52.730 --> 00:05:55.300
However, if we go a little bit
farther than that, and what we do,

116
00:05:55.300 --> 00:05:59.090
is we have an access point that
starts to broadcast an SSID,

117
00:05:59.090 --> 00:06:01.620
the service set identifier
that identifies the network,

118
00:06:01.620 --> 00:06:06.000
just generically a string of
characters that we call a network name.

119
00:06:06.000 --> 00:06:09.620
Now, if I end up bringing up an access
point online and I configure that

120
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:14.140
SSID to look just like the one at your
company or maybe the coffee company.

121
00:06:14.140 --> 00:06:15.800
I put the coffee shop up here, right?

122
00:06:15.800 --> 00:06:20.360
And the SSID looks identical,
well now it's an evil twin attack.

123
00:06:20.360 --> 00:06:23.470
Now keep in mind that I accomplished
it through a rogue access point.

124
00:06:23.470 --> 00:06:24.870
We went a little bit farther there, and

125
00:06:24.870 --> 00:06:28.420
we configured it to look like
it's the authorized network.

126
00:06:28.420 --> 00:06:32.440
When really, it's an unauthorized access
point that's broadcasting an SSID that

127
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:36.650
looks identical to the one that is
coming off of your legitimate network.

128
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:38.480
That's why we call it an evil twin, right?

129
00:06:38.480 --> 00:06:39.450
Mwah, hah, hah, hah.

130
00:06:39.450 --> 00:06:43.760
And it looks like it's a benign network,
like it's an authorized network.

131
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:44.900
Again, but it's not.

132
00:06:44.900 --> 00:06:47.310
It's a rogue access point with
your server set identifier,

133
00:06:48.600 --> 00:06:51.520
basically broadcasting out
an SSID that's identical.

134
00:06:51.520 --> 00:06:54.390
Now what happens is pretty
much the same thing.

135
00:06:54.390 --> 00:06:57.440
People start connecting to it because
they believe that it's a legitimate

136
00:06:58.570 --> 00:07:02.340
network for whatever the intent and
purpose is.

137
00:07:02.340 --> 00:07:04.590
It might be, again,
to scrape your information, right?

138
00:07:04.590 --> 00:07:08.360
Putting a wireless network adapter in
promiscuous mode, you start to see that

139
00:07:08.360 --> 00:07:13.210
information as it traverses the rogue
access point's evil twin-based network.

140
00:07:13.210 --> 00:07:15.910
All right?
So, know that these concepts are pretty

141
00:07:15.910 --> 00:07:16.900
close to the same thing.

142
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:18.320
One is accomplished with the other.

143
00:07:18.320 --> 00:07:21.080
Rogue access point can just be
something that, again, just an AP

144
00:07:21.080 --> 00:07:25.190
that's brought online but within
the proximity of the wireless network,

145
00:07:25.190 --> 00:07:28.600
and users start to connect
to the unauthorized network.

146
00:07:28.600 --> 00:07:31.015
An evil twin goes a little
bit farther than that.

147
00:07:31.015 --> 00:07:37.465
Same process, where now we're
configuring the SSID to broadcast out,

148
00:07:37.465 --> 00:07:42.535
or the access point to broadcast out
an SSID that is going to be the same one,

149
00:07:42.535 --> 00:07:46.550
or close to the same as the one
that is the legitimate network for

150
00:07:46.550 --> 00:07:48.190
the purposes of having
people connect to it.

151
00:07:49.260 --> 00:07:52.377
All right so, those are a couple of things
that we need to worry about as well.

152
00:07:52.377 --> 00:07:55.602
Now, there are a couple of things
that are associated with, well,

153
00:07:55.602 --> 00:07:59.223
one thing that I can think of that's
associated with your wireless networks

154
00:07:59.223 --> 00:08:00.710
that we need to be aware of too.

155
00:08:00.710 --> 00:08:02.779
And this is something
known as war driving.

156
00:08:02.779 --> 00:08:07.191
All right, war driving and
I've heard many different terminology,

157
00:08:07.191 --> 00:08:12.198
it all starts with war if you will, but
it's the mode of transportation that can

158
00:08:12.198 --> 00:08:18.720
differ a little bit, for instance, you'll
see war driving, war flying, war boating.

159
00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:24.390
It just basically means what
we do is we have a laptop and

160
00:08:24.390 --> 00:08:27.720
its wireless adapter is turned on,
and what we're doing is we're going

161
00:08:27.720 --> 00:08:31.980
through different locations trying to find
open access points that we can connect to.

162
00:08:31.980 --> 00:08:36.470
And maybe they're an open system, right,
we'll talk about basic wireless security

163
00:08:36.470 --> 00:08:41.200
in another episode, but basically an open
system is one that doesn't pass or

164
00:08:41.200 --> 00:08:44.060
doesn't require a password,
anybody can connect to it.

165
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:48.025
Now when I find that, when I'm let's
say driving around, war driving, and

166
00:08:48.025 --> 00:08:51.870
I do find an open access point, I can
then do whatever it is that I need to do.

167
00:08:51.870 --> 00:08:55.230
Whether it's maliciously,
whether it's scrape your information,

168
00:08:55.230 --> 00:08:58.366
whether it's do something
maliciously through your network, so

169
00:08:58.366 --> 00:09:00.550
I don't get charged for
whatever it might be.

170
00:09:01.600 --> 00:09:05.677
War walking I've heard, same thing,
again think of a metropolitan type area

171
00:09:05.677 --> 00:09:09.447
where you're walking around,
maybe even with your cellular device and

172
00:09:09.447 --> 00:09:12.691
you've got the Wi-Fi network on and
your Wi-Fi scanner on.

173
00:09:12.691 --> 00:09:16.930
Then you're just trying to find open
access points, maybe a coffee shop,

174
00:09:16.930 --> 00:09:20.180
maybe a business down in
the metropolitan area network.

175
00:09:20.180 --> 00:09:22.740
You find one,
I said metropolitan area network,

176
00:09:22.740 --> 00:09:26.260
doesn't necessarily have to be a man,
but you know around the city.

177
00:09:26.260 --> 00:09:29.735
And then, it goes even farther than that,
that when I do find one of these

178
00:09:29.735 --> 00:09:34.425
wireless networks with my device, I go and
I do what's known as warchalking.

179
00:09:34.425 --> 00:09:35.985
Warchalking, you just
grab a piece of chalk and

180
00:09:35.985 --> 00:09:38.655
on the sidewalk you mark a little
symbol that lets other people know

181
00:09:38.655 --> 00:09:43.745
that if they have a wireless device and
they stand right in this spot.

182
00:09:43.745 --> 00:09:46.925
They turn their wireless adapter on,
they can find this network and

183
00:09:46.925 --> 00:09:48.425
they can connect to it as well.

184
00:09:48.425 --> 00:09:50.375
You've basically done the work for
other people so

185
00:09:50.375 --> 00:09:54.400
that they can identify open networks
likewise, that's called warchalking.

186
00:09:54.400 --> 00:09:58.747
Now war boating, same thing, now that's
probably got a little bit of limitations

187
00:09:58.747 --> 00:10:02.510
too it, you're got to be the water but
war flying doesn't.

188
00:10:02.510 --> 00:10:06.197
Now I used to say, well you know that's an
interesting concept because of the range

189
00:10:06.197 --> 00:10:07.290
of wireless networks.

190
00:10:07.290 --> 00:10:11.249
Boy, you'd have to get close and you'd
have to have a pretty important network

191
00:10:11.249 --> 00:10:13.922
for a helicopter hovering
outside of your building.

192
00:10:13.922 --> 00:10:21.220
But I want you to think smarter, drone
technology and internet of things, IoT.

193
00:10:21.220 --> 00:10:26.190
It doesn't take much to put one little
wireless module on the back of a drone and

194
00:10:26.190 --> 00:10:29.410
fly it next to a building and
do the exact same thing.

195
00:10:29.410 --> 00:10:34.063
So war flying isn't necessarily anymore
sophisticated as it might sound,

196
00:10:34.063 --> 00:10:37.180
it doesn't mean you have
to get up in a helicopter,

197
00:10:37.180 --> 00:10:39.680
it doesn't mean you have
to be inside of a plane.

198
00:10:39.680 --> 00:10:43.690
It quite literally means that you
have some radio controlled drone

199
00:10:43.690 --> 00:10:47.670
that you can start to find
open access points as well.

200
00:10:47.670 --> 00:10:52.120
So ward driving is the one that they call
out, and remember for the most part,

201
00:10:52.120 --> 00:10:56.395
everything is the same, you're trying
to find them an open access point.

202
00:10:56.395 --> 00:10:58.920
You're doing this with war walking,
you couple it with war chalking,

203
00:10:58.920 --> 00:11:01.910
you're marking some kind of symbol
that lets people know that if we stem

204
00:11:01.910 --> 00:11:05.552
that location, they can gain access
to the wireless network as well.

205
00:11:05.552 --> 00:11:09.290
All right, so a couple other things that
we have, that I don't really have any

206
00:11:09.290 --> 00:11:13.542
slides for, one is ransomware,
ransomware is interesting.

207
00:11:13.542 --> 00:11:17.602
All right, I want you to think of
the term ransom, right, somebody grab,

208
00:11:17.602 --> 00:11:18.898
in the movies, right?

209
00:11:18.898 --> 00:11:21.824
Somebody steals, I don't know, a CEO and

210
00:11:21.824 --> 00:11:23.960
holds him for ransom or-
>> Kidnapping.

211
00:11:23.960 --> 00:11:24.630
>> Steals a kid.

212
00:11:24.630 --> 00:11:28.610
Yeah, exactly, kidnapping,
steals the, takes the child and

213
00:11:28.610 --> 00:11:32.840
then is holding that person ransom
unless they pay some kind of money or

214
00:11:32.840 --> 00:11:35.920
some kind of monetary fee
to get that person back.

215
00:11:35.920 --> 00:11:39.640
All right,
now I want you to think of your data, and

216
00:11:39.640 --> 00:11:44.070
put your data into that spot that has
been kidnapped if you will, right?

217
00:11:44.070 --> 00:11:47.188
Where you get some kind of virus and

server just return the response,

440
00:24:50.752 --> 00:24:53.180
speeds up the process, right?

441
00:24:53.180 --> 00:24:58.832
Well, what if, all right,
we could poison that cache?

442
00:24:58.832 --> 00:25:05.440
What if I could, when a request comes
out to, where's www.google.com and

443
00:25:05.440 --> 00:25:10.740
the IP address we return is
something completely different.

444
00:25:10.740 --> 00:25:15.552
Now understand any of you that
are watching out there have these domains,

445
00:25:15.552 --> 00:25:17.190
I made them up on the fly.

446
00:25:17.190 --> 00:25:20.523
So if you've got something called
you've just got hacked.net, sorry.

447
00:25:20.523 --> 00:25:22.288
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, but

448
00:25:22.288 --> 00:25:26.451
the point is it takes you to,
now what happens is,

449
00:25:26.451 --> 00:25:30.831
when we're asking for
www.google.com, right?

450
00:25:30.831 --> 00:25:34.427
Instead of giving us a legitimate IP
address, it goes to an IP address of,

451
00:25:34.427 --> 00:25:36.400
let's just say something completely.

452
00:25:36.400 --> 00:25:38.773
And I'm using private IP addresses,
just so

453
00:25:38.773 --> 00:25:43.280
I'm not using anybody's public IP address
out there I don't wanna do that, right?

454
00:25:43.280 --> 00:25:48.310
But we return an IP address of this right
here and what that's actually going to

455
00:25:48.310 --> 00:25:52.090
is not Google,
it's going to a completely other website.

456
00:25:52.090 --> 00:25:56.820
It redirects you to a website that you
probably don't wanna be at, right,

457
00:25:56.820 --> 00:25:58.520
that's DNS poisoning.

458
00:25:58.520 --> 00:26:03.060
Because if the hacker can
poison the cache, right and

459
00:26:03.060 --> 00:26:07.350
we can put an entry that says,
google maps to this IP address, and

460
00:26:07.350 --> 00:26:12.260
that IP address is being used by
a malicious attacker at that time,

461
00:26:12.260 --> 00:26:14.920
they can redirect you to
any IP address you want.

462
00:26:14.920 --> 00:26:18.000
Remember what DNS does, I got a name,
I need to find the IP address.

463
00:26:18.000 --> 00:26:21.313
Normally, non-maliciously we
can return the IP address

464
00:26:21.313 --> 00:26:25.843
of the legitimate website's domain,
the owner right, Google, Microsoft,

465
00:26:25.843 --> 00:26:29.670
Facebook, right these
are legitimate websites.

466
00:26:29.670 --> 00:26:35.320
But if my response comes back and
it's got a poisoned DNS entry,

467
00:26:35.320 --> 00:26:39.040
again, same process as ARP,
or same concept as ARP.

468
00:26:39.040 --> 00:26:44.320
I've got IP addresses now in the cache
that actually map the malicious websites,

469
00:26:44.320 --> 00:26:45.930
it redirects you there.

470
00:26:45.930 --> 00:26:52.490
Or even worse, it redirects you to
a domain that doesn't even exist,

471
00:26:52.490 --> 00:26:55.660
don't even care if the address is real,
why?

472
00:26:55.660 --> 00:26:59.190
Because now we've got another
denial of service attack.

473
00:26:59.190 --> 00:27:02.770
If you can't find the website cuz you
can't find its IP address you can't get

474
00:27:02.770 --> 00:27:04.530
there, that's denial of service.

475
00:27:04.530 --> 00:27:10.236
But remember the process here is
essentially, To cut out the authorized

476
00:27:10.236 --> 00:27:15.252
DNS server so
that that process never goes any farther.

477
00:27:15.252 --> 00:27:18.969
You infect the cache and
I ask that DNS server,

478
00:27:18.969 --> 00:27:22.760
what is the DNS record I'm looking for?

479
00:27:22.760 --> 00:27:25.832
And it gives me a bogus record, we can
redirect that information anywhere we

480
00:27:25.832 --> 00:27:27.710
need, all right, so that's DNS poisoning.

481
00:27:27.710 --> 00:27:33.007
A couple more there, Zach, I know
we're running a little short on time

482
00:27:33.007 --> 00:27:38.410
on this one, but I do wanna mention
just two more attack types all right.

483
00:27:39.520 --> 00:27:42.962
Now remember that we've talked
about spoofing in the last episode

484
00:27:42.962 --> 00:27:46.649
the very first part we talked about
spoofing and I wanted to set spoofing

485
00:27:46.649 --> 00:27:49.986
ahead of everything else because
we talked about DNS spoofing.

486
00:27:49.986 --> 00:27:53.415
You can say DNS spoofing,
DNS poisoning right,

487
00:27:53.415 --> 00:27:58.346
a DNS spoofing just means that I could
put a fake server in between there

488
00:27:58.346 --> 00:28:03.130
that looks like it's a DNS server,
but it's actually malicious.

489
00:28:03.130 --> 00:28:09.040
We talked about ARP poisoning it uses
spoofing right, because what am I doing?

490
00:28:09.040 --> 00:28:12.690
I'm responding back to ARP, and
I'm pretending to be somebody I'm not.

491
00:28:12.690 --> 00:28:15.233
And I'm saying that's my IP
address when it really isn't, and

492
00:28:15.233 --> 00:28:19.510
it maps to my MAC address rather than the
legitimate MAC address, that's spoofing.

493
00:28:19.510 --> 00:28:23.515
Well, this next concept forms the basis
for a lot of different attacks, and

494
00:28:23.515 --> 00:28:25.216
it's called the MITM, right?

495
00:28:25.216 --> 00:28:27.122
Nope, we're not talking
about a university, and

496
00:28:27.122 --> 00:28:29.029
we're not talking about
a technical school here,

497
00:28:29.029 --> 00:28:31.670
we're talking about
the man-in-the-middle attack, all right.

498
00:28:31.670 --> 00:28:34.470
And if we could take a look at this,
man-in-the-middle attack attack could be

499
00:28:34.470 --> 00:28:36.620
used as the basis for
many other attacks, right.

500
00:28:36.620 --> 00:28:39.877
We talk about session hijacking attack or
a replay attack where I,

501
00:28:39.877 --> 00:28:43.307
get in between the source and
the destination in the communication and

502
00:28:43.307 --> 00:28:45.343
I steal some information and
I replay it or

503
00:28:45.343 --> 00:28:48.974
I send it back to the server later as
I'm spoofing like it's you, right?

504
00:28:48.974 --> 00:28:52.090
Now we're pulling them all together,
all right.

505
00:28:52.090 --> 00:28:55.000
And session hijacking
attack where you currently

506
00:28:55.000 --> 00:28:58.300
have an active session between you and
let's say a web server,

507
00:28:58.300 --> 00:29:01.420
and I steal the session cookie because I'm
in between the source and destination.

508
00:29:02.520 --> 00:29:05.880
And now I can present your session
cookie to the web server, and

509
00:29:05.880 --> 00:29:09.460
it thinks I'm you and I could take
you completely out of the mix, right?

510
00:29:09.460 --> 00:29:14.180
So man in the middle all right, is you
have a victim Whatever the target is and

511
00:29:14.180 --> 00:29:16.570
there's a resource, some kinda
service that's being provided and

512
00:29:16.570 --> 00:29:19.550
you have somebody that sits in
between that communication.

513
00:29:19.550 --> 00:29:23.895
Now, why they do it,
could be different reasons,

514
00:29:23.895 --> 00:29:26.870
all right and I put just some
of the basic reasons right.

515
00:29:26.870 --> 00:29:29.650
Intercepting your information,
eaves dropping all right and

516
00:29:29.650 --> 00:29:31.540
this is why we use encryption protocols.

517
00:29:31.540 --> 00:29:36.427
That's why we use HTTPS With TLS 2.0 and
higher, right?

518
00:29:36.427 --> 00:29:41.122
That's why we use things like Secure File
Transfer protocol because I want encrypted

519
00:29:41.122 --> 00:29:45.164
information so that if I'm sending or
pulling a file from an FTP server and

520
00:29:45.164 --> 00:29:47.789
somebody sits in between
that communication.

521
00:29:47.789 --> 00:29:51.710
That information is scrambled so
they can not read it, right?

522
00:29:51.710 --> 00:29:55.934
That's man in the middle, right could
be redirecting information again,

523
00:29:55.934 --> 00:30:00.630
could be modifying that information could
form the basis for a lot of other attacks.

524
00:30:00.630 --> 00:30:06.959
All right, last one,
is what's known as VLAN hopping.

525
00:30:07.970 --> 00:30:10.990
All right, why do we set up
virtual local area networks?

526
00:30:10.990 --> 00:30:15.826
We setup VLANs so that we can isolate a
segment or a group of computers together,

527
00:30:15.826 --> 00:30:19.520
and they can't communicate
with other computers, right?

528
00:30:19.520 --> 00:30:23.988
It basically allows us to take a physical
switch, and logically divide it up, and

529
00:30:23.988 --> 00:30:26.190
make it multiple switches.

530
00:30:26.190 --> 00:30:29.720
And the only way that these computers
can talk to one another is if

531
00:30:29.720 --> 00:30:31.530
you put a layer of re-routing in there,
right?

532
00:30:31.530 --> 00:30:35.229
We do it for network security purposes,
again segmentation,

533
00:30:35.229 --> 00:30:38.176
I can put a set of crucial
servers within one VLAN.

534
00:30:38.176 --> 00:30:41.495
I can put voice of IP phones
within another VLAN, right and

535
00:30:41.495 --> 00:30:43.340
the communication separates.

536
00:30:43.340 --> 00:30:44.630
Well here's the problem, all right.

537
00:30:46.230 --> 00:30:50.830
Attackers can manipulate
the Ethernet frames, and they can

538
00:30:50.830 --> 00:30:55.760
manipulate things like, for instance,
trunks, as well as the tag itself.

539
00:30:55.760 --> 00:30:58.211
And they can actually hop
from one VLAN to the next,

540
00:30:58.211 --> 00:31:00.548
when they really shouldn't be able to,
right?

541
00:31:00.548 --> 00:31:03.579
One of the ways, and
they don't call them out individually,

542
00:31:03.579 --> 00:31:07.950
but there's a couple of different types
of VLAN hopping I just wanna mention.

543
00:31:07.950 --> 00:31:12.573
One is where the attacker
basically leverages

544
00:31:12.573 --> 00:31:18.390
the 802.1Q trunk,
remember what a trunk is, okay.

545
00:31:18.390 --> 00:31:22.089
A trunk basically a switchboard that

546
00:31:22.089 --> 00:31:26.750
multiple VLANs can use as their port,
right?

547
00:31:26.750 --> 00:31:30.361
So if I've got information that's
going to a certain location,

548
00:31:30.361 --> 00:31:33.615
I can trunk the port together,
and all VLANs can use that.

549
00:31:33.615 --> 00:31:35.740
Or if I can manipulate that trunk,

550
00:31:35.740 --> 00:31:40.380
that means not only can all the VLANs
use it but the attacker can gain

551
00:31:40.380 --> 00:31:44.760
access to all the VLANs through that trunk
port because they are all sharing it.

552
00:31:44.760 --> 00:31:49.322
All right, the other one is
the manipulation of the VLAN tag itself,

553
00:31:49.322 --> 00:31:53.976
and this is called a double tagging
VLAN hopping attack, if you will.

554
00:31:53.976 --> 00:31:58.081
All right, so the attacker is part
of one VLAN all right, and and

555
00:31:58.081 --> 00:32:00.755
that's the very first VLAN, all right?

556
00:32:00.755 --> 00:32:03.680
So this is the VLAN that
the computer is a part of, but

557
00:32:03.680 --> 00:32:08.488
there's an extra tag that's in there and
the tag, that extra tag, double tagging.

558
00:32:08.488 --> 00:32:15.203
That second tag is actually the VLAN
that the attacker wants to access.

559
00:32:15.203 --> 00:32:20.802
So what happens is the very first
switch receives that VLAN tag,

560
00:32:20.802 --> 00:32:26.711
sees it as part of that VLAN,
removes it and reveals the second tag,

561
00:32:26.711 --> 00:32:31.080
and then that's handed
off to the second switch.

562
00:32:31.080 --> 00:32:35.072
And the second switch says, yeah I see
the VLAN tag here, the second tag here,

563
00:32:35.072 --> 00:32:37.510
you're supposed to have
access to this VLAN.

564
00:32:37.510 --> 00:32:40.990
And now what's happened,
through manipulation of the tagging,

565
00:32:40.990 --> 00:32:44.221
is that the attacker has now
gained access to the second VLAN,

566
00:32:44.221 --> 00:32:47.037
that they weren't originally a part of,
all right?

567
00:32:47.037 --> 00:32:52.074
That's VLAN hopping, VLAN basically,
instead of being isolated like

568
00:32:52.074 --> 00:32:57.290
those virtual local area networks
should give us that network isolation.

569
00:32:57.290 --> 00:33:00.070
They actually manipulate
things like the trunks and

570
00:33:00.070 --> 00:33:05.170
things like the VLAN tag
within the Ethernet frame, and

571
00:33:05.170 --> 00:33:10.558
essentially make their way on
unauthorized on to another VLAN.

572
00:33:10.558 --> 00:33:15.410
All right Zach so that does look
like it wraps everything up keep in

573
00:33:15.410 --> 00:33:18.280
mind be aware of some of these
network attacks for the exam.

574
00:33:18.280 --> 00:33:19.494
If they put you in a scenario,

575
00:33:19.494 --> 00:33:21.883
where you just have to know
the characteristics, right?

576
00:33:21.883 --> 00:33:26.011
We want you to be aware of them keep in
mind, there are many more out there, so

577
00:33:26.011 --> 00:33:29.171
keep studying, and
the next time you sit that Net+ exam,

578
00:33:29.171 --> 00:33:30.931
we think you'll be doing well.

579
00:33:30.931 --> 00:33:34.620
>> Great episode as usual,
Wes Common Networking Attacks, Part 2.

580
00:33:34.620 --> 00:33:38.568
Make sure you see Part 1 and
see everything in the CompTIA Net+ series,

581
00:33:38.568 --> 00:33:41.104
that Wes and
ITProTV had put together for you.

582
00:33:41.104 --> 00:33:44.844
And while your in the course library,
there's hundreds of other videos there,

583
00:33:44.844 --> 00:33:47.822
and they're all designed to do one thing,
help you go further.

584
00:33:47.822 --> 00:33:50.575
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
they'll be really glad you did.

585
00:33:50.575 --> 00:33:52.500
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

586
00:33:52.500 --> 00:33:53.280
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

587
00:33:53.280 --> 00:33:54.140
>> And we will see you soon.

588
00:33:54.140 --> 00:34:01.200
[MUSIC]

589
00:34:01.200 --> 00:34:04.206
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Zach and Wes look at some of the common ways in which to harden network devices from attacks. They discuss modifying default settings, avoiding common passwords, using secure protocols and more.
episodes.title: Network Device Hardening
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.020
Welcome to I ProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.020 --> 00:00:06.939
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.939 --> 00:00:08.352
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.352 --> 00:00:12.206
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.206 --> 00:00:14.227
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.227 --> 00:00:16.650
empowering the world
through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.650 --> 00:00:20.446
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with CompTIA Net+ and

8
00:00:20.446 --> 00:00:23.769
hardening network devices is
the name of this episode.

9
00:00:23.769 --> 00:00:27.050
I'm gonna say that again,
hardening network devices.

10
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:30.230
And the person bringing this information
we need is one and only Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:30.230 --> 00:00:32.066
Wes, good to see you, sir.

12
00:00:32.066 --> 00:00:32.967
>> Hi Zach, thanks for
having me back here.

13
00:00:32.967 --> 00:00:37.593
That's right we are going to be looking
at not quite a tin foil hat episode, but

14
00:00:37.593 --> 00:00:40.212
it definitely relates to security.

15
00:00:40.212 --> 00:00:42.880
So we're gonna have to know
a little bit about how

16
00:00:42.880 --> 00:00:46.110
we make our network devices
a little bit more secure.

17
00:00:46.110 --> 00:00:49.978
But before we do that, I kinda want to set
the stage for this term hardening, right?

18
00:00:49.978 --> 00:00:53.490
You heard Zach say it a couple of times,
what the heck does hardening mean?

19
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:57.120
Well, I want you to know that it doesn't
matter if we're talking about a network

20
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:01.910
device, it doesn't matter if we're talking
about an application, an operating system

21
00:01:01.910 --> 00:01:05.910
if you will, any kind of piece of software
or component embedded system, right?

22
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:09.440
When we talk about the term hardening
then, what we're talking about is

23
00:01:09.440 --> 00:01:13.370
reducing our attack surface, making
the device a little bit more secure.

24
00:01:13.370 --> 00:01:16.820
Again, or the application or
the operating system, right?

25
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:19.550
We say,
reducing our attack surface, right?

26
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:20.570
I want you to think of it this way.

27
00:01:20.570 --> 00:01:25.050
The more vulnerabilities you have in a
system, whether it is a misconfiguration,

28
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:29.770
a lack of configuration,
maybe misuse of certain protocols, right?

29
00:01:29.770 --> 00:01:36.090
Any kind of weakness that you
basically have inside of that system,

30
00:01:36.090 --> 00:01:39.740
means you're gonna be more susceptible
to different types of attacks.

31
00:01:39.740 --> 00:01:44.030
The more attacks you're susceptible too,
or vulnerabilities and the exploits or

32
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:48.160
the attacks that go wrong
with those vulnerabilities,

33
00:01:48.160 --> 00:01:50.950
the greater the bull's
eye on your chest right.

34
00:01:50.950 --> 00:01:52.790
So what we wanna do is we want to,

35
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:57.720
we wanna basically secure
the components within a system or

36
00:01:57.720 --> 00:02:01.760
different configurations within our
network devices so that we can reduce

37
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:05.940
the size of that bull's eye or
reduce the size of the attack surface,

38
00:02:05.940 --> 00:02:10.420
thereby strengthening our system's
resiliency to these vulnerabilities or

39
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:12.670
the attacks that could
exploit the vulnerabilities.

40
00:02:12.670 --> 00:02:14.280
So that's what hardening is and

41
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:16.420
that's what we're gonna be
looking at in this episode.

42
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:18.680
>> I was a little dyslexic
about the way I said that but

43
00:02:18.680 --> 00:02:21.390
it's network device hardening not
hardening network devices but

44
00:02:21.390 --> 00:02:26.100
it's basically the same thing and in fact
what I wanted to ask you Wes is defaults.

45
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:27.760
Are not defaults enough?

46
00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:29.190
Lets talk about defaults.

47
00:02:29.190 --> 00:02:33.090
>> Defaults are something that we all have
to deal with when we are configuring or

48
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:34.350
when we are buy a device.

49
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:36.682
And again,
we're looking at network devices, but

50
00:02:36.682 --> 00:02:39.598
it might be the same thing when you
install an operating system for

51
00:02:39.598 --> 00:02:41.894
the very first time and
you have not done anything.

52
00:02:41.894 --> 00:02:44.509
Post installation,
you can see your desktop for

53
00:02:44.509 --> 00:02:48.580
instance in Windows you can log in,
you can work with the machine right?

54
00:02:48.580 --> 00:02:52.700
Could be an application that maybe you've
installed for the very first time and

55
00:02:52.700 --> 00:02:54.960
it's just fresh out of the box right?

56
00:02:54.960 --> 00:02:59.900
Well, with default, it usually means that
there's some kind of configuration or

57
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:03.130
lack thereof,
it might be no configuration.

58
00:03:03.130 --> 00:03:08.670
That again is, just straight out of
the box, right, and the problem is that

59
00:03:08.670 --> 00:03:14.090
default introduces a weakness in
the system, a vulnerability if you will.

60
00:03:14.090 --> 00:03:17.560
And again remember, this is about reducing
the vulnerabilities there by reducing

61
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:22.240
the attack surface of the vectors that
they use in order to attack your system.

62
00:03:22.240 --> 00:03:24.080
Can't really be all eliminated but

63
00:03:24.080 --> 00:03:27.070
we can definitely reduce it down
to an acceptable level, right.

64
00:03:27.070 --> 00:03:32.550
So when we talk about defaults this again
is just standard normal configuration.

65
00:03:32.550 --> 00:03:34.050
Let me give you an example for instance.

66
00:03:34.050 --> 00:03:39.841
So Zach and I we buy the same
let's say home router right.

67
00:03:39.841 --> 00:03:43.442
It could be the same access point, right,
it could be the all in one device,

68
00:03:43.442 --> 00:03:46.900
not only is it a wireless access point,
it's got switch ports on it too.

that you have to keep in mind.

462
00:24:37.770 --> 00:24:39.590
So that when you sit that Net+ exam,

463
00:24:39.590 --> 00:24:43.440
if they put you in a scenario,
you'll be able to answer those questions.

464
00:24:43.440 --> 00:24:45.000
And not only answer the questions.

465
00:24:45.000 --> 00:24:47.030
We don't want you to
just pass the Net+ exam.

466
00:24:47.030 --> 00:24:48.870
We want you to knock it
out of the ball park.

467
00:24:48.870 --> 00:24:49.700
>> Thanks a lot Wes.

468
00:24:49.700 --> 00:24:51.260
Network advice happening part two.

469
00:24:51.260 --> 00:24:51.880
There was a part one.

470
00:24:51.880 --> 00:24:55.818
See them both and see everything in the
CompTIA Net+ series Wes has put together

471
00:24:55.818 --> 00:24:58.752
for you, done a great job and
will help you in the long run and

472
00:24:58.752 --> 00:25:02.257
while you are there in the course library,
hundreds of other videos.

473
00:25:02.257 --> 00:25:05.359
They're all designed to do one thing,
help you go further, and

474
00:25:05.359 --> 00:25:07.320
tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

475
00:25:07.320 --> 00:25:09.680
They'll be very glad you did.

476
00:25:09.680 --> 00:25:10.821
I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

477
00:25:10.821 --> 00:25:12.030
>> Thanks for watching,
we'll see you soon.

478
00:25:12.030 --> 00:25:19.947
[MUSIC]

479
00:25:19.947 --> 00:25:22.743
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.339
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:03.339 --> 00:00:05.003
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.003 --> 00:00:08.324
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.324 --> 00:00:12.345
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello, thank you for

5
00:00:12.345 --> 00:00:17.240
choosing ITProTV, empowering
the world through engaging learning.

6
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:20.930
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with CompTIA Net+.

7
00:00:20.930 --> 00:00:25.092
This is common network service issues,
part two.

8
00:00:25.092 --> 00:00:29.010
And once again, Wes Bryan is here to
help us out, Wes, great to have you.

9
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:30.462
>> Thanks for having me back, Zach,

10
00:00:30.462 --> 00:00:33.979
that is right, we are moving along in some
of the service issues that you might see.

11
00:00:33.979 --> 00:00:37.402
Remember in part one, we really just
dealt with name resolution issues.

12
00:00:37.402 --> 00:00:42.011
Cuz DNS is a major part of our
networking communications, and

13
00:00:42.011 --> 00:00:46.099
without it,
a lot of applications can start to break.

14
00:00:46.099 --> 00:00:50.385
We might not find those websites out there
because we cannot map those names to their

15
00:00:50.385 --> 00:00:51.136
IPs.
>> Not good.

16
00:00:51.136 --> 00:00:52.482
>> In this episode,

17
00:00:52.482 --> 00:00:58.530
we're gonna talk about things that can,
if you will, have to do with DHCP.

18
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:03.030
As well as just an overall
misconfiguration of the network adapter's

19
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:06.250
basic network adapter properties, right.

20
00:01:06.250 --> 00:01:09.797
So one of the things that they call
out is an incorrect gateway, right.

21
00:01:09.797 --> 00:01:14.068
And in this context, understand that we're
not talking about a translation device

22
00:01:14.068 --> 00:01:16.365
between two dissimilar protocols, right?

23
00:01:16.365 --> 00:01:20.556
That is a gateway as well, but
we're talking about, just generically,

24
00:01:20.556 --> 00:01:22.130
TCP/IP default gateway.

25
00:01:22.130 --> 00:01:27.170
Remember that the default gateway is how
I send traffic off of my local network

26
00:01:27.170 --> 00:01:29.160
onto another network, right.

27
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:31.825
A lot of times, where we see that
is Internet communication, right.

28
00:01:31.825 --> 00:01:34.340
It doesn't have to be,
cuz you can have a heavily

29
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:37.730
routed large enterprise network
that this could also happen.

30
00:01:37.730 --> 00:01:38.531
But commonly,

31
00:01:38.531 --> 00:01:42.597
you might identify it as being able to
communicate from your local area network

32
00:01:42.597 --> 00:01:45.317
out there across the Internet.
>> So is this like when I go on

33
00:01:45.317 --> 00:01:48.449
the Internet, I try to find a website,
and I get back something that says,

34
00:01:48.449 --> 00:01:52.490
incorrect gateway?
>> Well, that's actually that's

35
00:01:52.490 --> 00:01:56.780
something that's returned, if you will,
on the back end of the web server.

36
00:01:56.780 --> 00:02:00.560
That might be the fact, and
I'm not sure, cuz be different things.

37
00:02:00.560 --> 00:02:04.640
But it might be the fact that, cuz
remember, when you hit a web page, right,

38
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:07.030
you have the front end,
which is the web application, and

39
00:02:07.030 --> 00:02:08.810
the back end is the database.

40
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:12.467
And there's no telling how they're routing
traffic or how they're communicating.

41
00:02:12.467 --> 00:02:14.192
So that's more on the application side,

42
00:02:14.192 --> 00:02:15.158
if you will.
>> Okay.

43
00:02:15.158 --> 00:02:16.528
>> Let's go ahead, and

44
00:02:16.528 --> 00:02:21.110
I'll show you where we could see this
in a couple of issues, all right?

45
00:02:21.110 --> 00:02:23.820
So in our Windows 10 machine here,
if I go ahead,

46
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:27.170
the first thing I'll do is
bring up our command prompt.

47
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:33.520
And we'll do an ipconfig, all right, if
you notice, I've got an IP address, right?

48
00:02:33.520 --> 00:02:37.800
I've got my subnet mask, cuz the other
one, too, by the way, is mask, right.

49
00:02:37.800 --> 00:02:41.790
I said gateway, but there's incorrect
gateway and incorrect mask, right.

50
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:47.156
When you're using DHCP,
a lot of times this doesn't happen.

51
00:02:47.156 --> 00:02:49.505
It's not to say that it couldn't happen,

52
00:02:49.505 --> 00:02:54.460
somebody could misconfigure the DHCP
server, and that could cause problems.

53
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:57.280
A lot of times, what you're gonna see
is where the static configuration

54
00:02:57.280 --> 00:02:58.510
comes in, right?

55
00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:03.408
Because if I do, I'll tell you what,
let's rerun that ipconfig command,

56
00:03:03.408 --> 00:03:04.873
but we'll do a /all.

57
00:03:04.873 --> 00:03:09.667
And you'll see that yes,
this is a DHCP enabled address, so

58
00:03:09.667 --> 00:03:12.310
we called out to a DHCP server.

59
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:14.650
I can see that it's got a lease time,
right?

60
00:03:14.650 --> 00:03:19.010
And I can see that the DHCP
server gave me a subnet mask, and

61
00:03:19.010 --> 00:03:21.230
gave me my default gateway, all right?

62
00:03:21.230 --> 00:03:26.085
Well, notice what happens if I ping
an external address 4.2, oops,

63
00:03:26.085 --> 00:03:31.836
if I can type an IP address, 2.1, right,
I'm getting replies back, all right?

64
00:03:31.836 --> 00:03:34.789
I can also open up a web browser,
and you can see,

65
00:03:34.789 --> 00:03:38.176
I can connect from this machine
out to the Internet, and

66
00:03:38.176 --> 00:03:43.580
essentially out to our web servers,
right, that's what we want to happen.

67
00:03:43.580 --> 00:03:47.550
However, when you start configuring things
wrong, you could get some issues, so

68
00:03:47.550 --> 00:03:48.800
let me go ahead and close this down.

69
00:03:48.800 --> 00:03:51.515
My head's kind of covering this up,
but same place we've been going for

70
00:03:51.515 --> 00:03:54.250
awhile now, just right clicking
on the little monitor icon and

71
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:56.080
choosing Open Network and Sharing Center.

72
00:03:57.210 --> 00:04:00.450
And then we're gonna get into
the properties of our network adapter.

73
00:04:00.450 --> 00:04:02.265
All right, and I'm gonna go ahead and

74
00:04:02.265 --> 00:04:05.061
I'm gonna reconfigure
the TCP/ IP properties, right?

75
00:04:05.061 --> 00:04:06.488
So now we're gonna do a static assignment

76
00:04:06.488 --> 00:04:08.200
where you can start to see the problem,
right?

77
00:04:08.200 --> 00:04:13.150
First we'll show you how it should look,
right, if you're doing static assignment.

78
00:04:13.150 --> 00:04:14.250
All right, so I'm gonna go ahead and

79
00:04:14.250 --> 00:04:17.720
I'm gonna select our
Internet Protocol Version 4 properties.

80
00:04:18.790 --> 00:04:22.190
And notice that we are obtaining
an IP address automatically,

81
00:04:22.190 --> 00:04:25.310
it's a DHCP signed address.

82
00:04:25.310 --> 00:04:30.550
And I'm gonna go ahead and
configure this a little bit different,

83
00:04:30.550 --> 00:04:33.220
I'll do 10.0.200.200, all right.

84
00:04:33.220 --> 00:04:39.770
And I'll give it the right subnet mask,
which is basically a class B subnet mask.

85
00:04:39.770 --> 00:04:42.620
I'm gonna give it the right
default gateway, and again,

86
00:04:42.620 --> 00:04:46.310
this is what it should look like, and
then we'll introduce the problem.

87
00:04:47.380 --> 00:04:49.805
And for this, I'm gonna go ahead and

88
00:04:49.805 --> 00:04:53.964
I'm gonna statically map
our DNS servers to 8.8.8.8.

89
00:04:53.964 --> 00:04:57.240
Even though our DHCP server did the same
thing, it gave me these options.

90
00:04:57.240 --> 00:05:01.550
I'll go ahead, and we're gonna do it
manually, and we'll keep it the same.

91
00:05:01.550 --> 00:05:06.450
I could do this, I could put the default
gateway as the preferred DNS server.

92
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:08.500
And then what's just gonna happen
is when I get to the gateway,

93
00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:10.590
it's gonna say, I see this.

94
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:15.320
This is port 53, UDP, DNS query,
I'll just pass that on to the DNS server.

95
00:05:15.320 --> 00:05:19.090
But I'm gonna go ahead and
statically map it, choose Close, and

96
00:05:19.090 --> 00:05:23.727
we will let it apply these configurations.

97
00:05:23.727 --> 00:05:27.260
Now, while this is running in
the background, we'll go ahead and

98
00:05:27.260 --> 00:05:29.290
we'll see if that's taken effect yet.

99
00:05:29.290 --> 00:05:33.620
Looks like I'm not quite patient enough
cuz we still have our DHCP address,

100
00:05:33.620 --> 00:05:35.770
so we'll just give it a second here.

101
00:05:35.770 --> 00:05:39.090
And hopefully what we're gonna see is,

102
00:05:39.090 --> 00:05:43.600
when I've statically mapped this, we can
perform those same tests that we just did,

103
00:05:43.600 --> 00:05:46.020
with a DHCP server
giving me those options.

104
00:05:46.020 --> 00:05:49.940
Again, the subnet mask and
the gateway, all right?

105
00:05:49.940 --> 00:05:52.590
So we'll go ahead and
give that just a second here.

106
00:05:52.590 --> 00:05:56.058
It's running a little slow here,
and sometimes I just get impatient.

107
00:05:56.058 --> 00:06:00.190
I say I tell you Zach, the faster
computers get, the more impatient I get,

108
00:06:00.190 --> 00:06:01.997
that's for sure.
>> [LAUGH]

109
00:06:01.997 --> 00:06:02.999
>> All right,

110
00:06:02.999 --> 00:06:07.523
so it's taking its sweet time,
that's for sure.

111
00:06:07.523 --> 00:06:11.061
It looks like it just connected there, I
just had to be a little bit more patient,

112
00:06:11.061 --> 00:06:12.043
right?
>> There you go.

113
00:06:12.043 --> 00:06:13.099
>> So let's go back to our command prompt.

114
00:06:13.099 --> 00:06:13.668
>> I want patience and

115
00:06:13.668 --> 00:06:16.841
I want it right now.
>> [LAUGH] And we'll run ipconfig, and

116
00:06:16.841 --> 00:06:18.340
there we have it.

117
00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:22.668
All right,
now notice that information looks kind of

118
00:06:22.668 --> 00:06:25.755
the same when we run out our ipconfig.

119
00:06:25.755 --> 00:06:29.940
Because I have an IP address,
got a subnet mask, and a default gateway.

120
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:37.860
If I rerun that ipconfig utility,
and choose the all option.

121
00:06:37.860 --> 00:06:40.717
It will let me know that this is not,
right,

122
00:06:40.717 --> 00:06:45.687
this isn't a DHCP enabled address,
right, this is statically assigned.

123
00:06:45.687 --> 00:06:52.595
All right, and if I run my ping utility
again, we do a ping of 4.2.2.1,

124
00:06:52.595 --> 00:06:59.100
I can communicate across my local network,
that's what I wanna see.

125
00:06:59.100 --> 00:07:00.800
I close that down, go ahead and

126
00:07:00.800 --> 00:07:03.630
close this down for now,
clean up the desktop here a little bit.

127
00:07:04.810 --> 00:07:08.330
Then I open up the web page,
there we go, right, ITProTV.

128
00:07:08.330 --> 00:07:12.051
It loads up statically assigned,
it's not a problem.

129
00:07:12.051 --> 00:07:15.482
All right,
now let's introduce the problem,

130
00:07:15.482 --> 00:07:20.640
the incorrect subnet mask, or
the incorrect, if you will, gateway.

131
00:07:20.640 --> 00:07:22.520
Let's start with the subnet mask,
let's see, now,

132
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:25.730
I'll tell you what,
we'll start with the gateway.

133
00:07:25.730 --> 00:07:28.650
All right, let's open up Network and
Sharing Center again.

134
00:07:28.650 --> 00:07:31.450
And we'll go ahead and
look at our adapter settings.

135
00:07:31.450 --> 00:07:34.569
And one of the first things, let me go
ahead and bring up the properties here.

136
00:07:34.569 --> 00:07:39.077
And we're gonna make sure that
our DHCP server is actually

137
00:07:39.077 --> 00:07:41.200
issuing out that address.

138
00:07:41.200 --> 00:07:43.681
Let me go ahead and
just change this here real quick.

139
00:07:43.681 --> 00:07:47.998
We'll let it identify,
we'll look at the status real quick, and

140
00:07:47.998 --> 00:07:50.247
it's still taking a second here.

141
00:07:50.247 --> 00:07:53.948
Again, I'm a little bit too quick
on this or just a little impatient,

142
00:07:53.948 --> 00:07:55.219
probably a bit of both.

143
00:07:55.219 --> 00:07:58.634
Now, Looks like it did obtain
its IP address and all right.

144
00:07:58.634 --> 00:08:01.600
So we've got our,
again we've got our IPv4 address.

145
00:08:01.600 --> 00:08:06.000
DHCP has give us our subnet mask and
our default gateway.

146
00:08:06.000 --> 00:08:08.630
Again, a lot of times what's going
to happen is this will be a static

147
00:08:08.630 --> 00:08:09.640
configuration issue.

148
00:08:09.640 --> 00:08:13.425
I'll show you where, on the server side,
it could cause problems, too.

149
00:08:13.425 --> 00:08:17.030
If it's a configuration
problem with the DHCP server.

150
00:08:17.030 --> 00:08:19.070
All right, so what I'm gonna
do is I'm gonna go ahead and

151
00:08:19.070 --> 00:08:23.020
just right click on our
Network Adaptor and choose Properties.

152
00:08:23.020 --> 00:08:29.450
I'm gonna choose the TCP, IPv4 properties
and we'll go ahead and bring those up.

153
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:32.370
And let's go ahead and
what we'll do is we'll do a one,

154
00:08:32.370 --> 00:08:36.018
let me just statically
map an IP address here.

155
00:08:36.018 --> 00:08:41.610
I'll do 10.0.200.200 and
we will use a class B

156
00:08:41.610 --> 00:08:46.792
subnet mask and let's go ahead and
assign the right default gateway.

157
00:08:46.792 --> 00:08:53.950
And I'll give it our 8.8.8.8 for
our dns server and choose okay.

158
00:08:53.950 --> 00:08:56.486
We'll go ahead and choose close to this.

159
00:08:56.486 --> 00:09:00.614
Give it a second, sometimes it can
take a little bit I've seen it,

160
00:09:00.614 --> 00:09:04.840
this is just more of this machine's
running a little bit slow here.

161
00:09:04.840 --> 00:09:08.262
And hopefully what we see here is that
once this is statically assigned the IP

162
00:09:08.262 --> 00:09:11.896
address, we should see, if everything goes
all right, and I betcha if I run an IP

163
00:09:11.896 --> 00:09:15.813
config, there's Zach, I am gonna find that
yeah, it's still got the DHCP address.

164
00:09:15.813 --> 00:09:20.783
And that's okay it's taking a little
bit to assign these settings to

165
00:09:20.783 --> 00:09:22.900
the network adapter.

166
00:09:22.900 --> 00:09:27.210
So we'll just give it a second here,
and run our ping.

167
00:09:27.210 --> 00:09:29.200
Looks like we still got the ping.

168
00:09:29.200 --> 00:09:31.830
But again, we want to make sure.

169
00:09:31.830 --> 00:09:32.920
There we go.
And again,

170
00:09:32.920 --> 00:09:34.320
just had to wait a little bit longer here.

171
00:09:34.320 --> 00:09:35.580
Let's rerun ipconfig, and

172
00:09:35.580 --> 00:09:38.560
make sure that it is the static
assignment that we just configured.

173
00:09:38.560 --> 00:09:41.120
And I do see that yes, it is, right.

174
00:09:41.120 --> 00:09:48.078
So we can see that our IP address,
right, IPv4 address, 10.0.200.200.

175
00:09:48.078 --> 00:09:50.884
We also have our subnet mask,
class B subnet mask,

176
00:09:50.884 --> 00:09:53.120
as well as our default gateway, right.

177
00:09:53.120 --> 00:09:55.897
We are good to go as far
as statically assigned and

178
00:09:55.897 --> 00:09:59.101
we hopefully can ping off of
our local network, right.

179
00:09:59.101 --> 00:10:00.459
So we run our ping utility.

180
00:10:00.459 --> 00:10:04.085
We send that information off
of the local network, right.

181
00:10:04.085 --> 00:10:06.068
That's what we wanna see
when the gateway is right.

182
00:10:06.068 --> 00:10:11.960
All right, however, if I go ahead and
do that same thing again, we'll bring back

183
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:17.090
up the Network and Sharing Center here,
and we'll change the adapter settings.

184
00:10:17.090 --> 00:10:22.020
And this time,
we're gonna basically introduce the error,

185
00:10:22.020 --> 00:10:24.320
the issue that we're talking abou
>> And we'll go ahead and

406
00:23:28.982 --> 00:23:33.800
10.10.10.250 is at my MAC address,
the server's MAC address.

407
00:23:34.820 --> 00:23:37.480
It listened out and
it didn't get a response back, and

408
00:23:37.480 --> 00:23:38.860
it said, it must be unique.

409
00:23:38.860 --> 00:23:43.060
I'll go ahead and apply it to the
properties of this network adapter, and

410
00:23:43.060 --> 00:23:44.969
we can communicate, all right?

411
00:23:44.969 --> 00:23:46.795
So that's something that you might see,
too.

412
00:23:46.795 --> 00:23:51.949
Now, the other duplicate, and I know
we're kind of running a little bit short

413
00:23:51.949 --> 00:23:56.728
on time, so let's do one more here,
Zach, is a duplicate MAC address.

414
00:23:56.728 --> 00:24:00.545
Now if you're watching this for the first
time, this might confuse a little bit.

415
00:24:00.545 --> 00:24:04.080
Cuz you might have paid attention to some
of our other episodes where I told you

416
00:24:04.080 --> 00:24:07.970
a MAC address is a six-byte
hardware identifier, right?

417
00:24:07.970 --> 00:24:10.060
It's burned into the network adapter.

418
00:24:11.580 --> 00:24:14.190
Well, how could there be two
that are the duplicates, right?

419
00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:15.200
There shouldn't be any duplicates.

420
00:24:15.200 --> 00:24:18.280
It's one of the reasons we
have that unique identifier.

421
00:24:18.280 --> 00:24:23.570
Well, here's the thing, virtualization,
I have multiple computers right now,

422
00:24:23.570 --> 00:24:28.370
multiple operating systems all running
on this Mac, and I can show you, right?

423
00:24:28.370 --> 00:24:30.230
If we go back to my screen here, right?

424
00:24:31.330 --> 00:24:33.690
I have a Mac desktop, right?

425
00:24:33.690 --> 00:24:35.460
I'm running them in VMWare.

426
00:24:35.460 --> 00:24:39.770
And inside of VMware,
it's virtualizing the MAC address.

427
00:24:39.770 --> 00:24:43.640
So it's allowing me to run
multiple operating systems.

428
00:24:43.640 --> 00:24:47.955
And we're not breaking the rules of TCP/IP
cuz it's virtualizing the MAC addresses,

429
00:24:47.955 --> 00:24:48.620
right?

430
00:24:48.620 --> 00:24:51.310
Well, this is where you could
potentially get a duplicate.

431
00:24:51.310 --> 00:24:54.670
If I look at the virtual machine it's
where the duplicate MAC address comes in,

432
00:24:54.670 --> 00:24:56.500
typically a problem with virtualization.

433
00:24:56.500 --> 00:24:59.830
And if I look at settings, all right?

434
00:24:59.830 --> 00:25:04.448
And more so, I go to the network adapter
and some of the advanced options,

435
00:25:04.448 --> 00:25:05.201
all right?

436
00:25:05.201 --> 00:25:08.866
Notice the MAC address right here,
the hypervisor,

437
00:25:08.866 --> 00:25:13.191
the virtualization software is
generating this MAC address.

438
00:25:13.191 --> 00:25:15.448
And if this machine was turned off,
I could sit there and

439
00:25:15.448 --> 00:25:16.850
I could regenerate a MAC address.

440
00:25:17.920 --> 00:25:21.700
And there's a lot of possibilities,
lot of possibilities, right?

441
00:25:21.700 --> 00:25:26.340
But there is also a possibility that
potentially if you statically map

442
00:25:26.340 --> 00:25:28.730
these MAC addresses through
the virtualization software,

443
00:25:28.730 --> 00:25:30.270
that you get a duplicate as well.

444
00:25:30.270 --> 00:25:32.310
All right, typically that's gonna
be a virtualization problem.

445
00:25:32.310 --> 00:25:34.180
That's gonna be an issue
in your virtualization, and

446
00:25:34.180 --> 00:25:37.600
it doesn't really mean that it's gonna
be a problem with the hypervisor,

447
00:25:37.600 --> 00:25:42.290
the virtualization software,
you could try to manually generate this.

448
00:25:42.290 --> 00:25:44.560
That's why it's good to let
the hypervisor generate them.

449
00:25:44.560 --> 00:25:47.720
Cuz, the hypervisor, if it generates them,
or the virtualization software generates

450
00:25:47.720 --> 00:25:51.410
them, it's keeping track of what the MAC
addresses are that are being used.

451
00:25:51.410 --> 00:25:53.290
But you could get a duplicate.

452
00:25:53.290 --> 00:25:57.270
And these are some of the service issues
that you might run into on your machines.

453
00:25:57.270 --> 00:25:59.490
Keep in mind that we still got more to go.

454
00:25:59.490 --> 00:26:02.930
But Zach's looking at me over there, and I
don't think we have time in this episode.

455
00:26:02.930 --> 00:26:04.434
>> Common Network Service Issues part

456
00:26:04.434 --> 00:26:05.741
three will be coming your way.

457
00:26:05.741 --> 00:26:07.629
There's a part one and part two,
make sure you see that.

458
00:26:07.629 --> 00:26:10.857
And see everything in the CompTIA Net Plus
series that Wes put together and

459
00:26:10.857 --> 00:26:12.750
he's done a wonderful job at doing that.

460
00:26:12.750 --> 00:26:14.040
Thank you again Wes.

461
00:26:14.040 --> 00:26:17.610
And by the way, when you're looking at
that course library there are thousands of

462
00:26:17.610 --> 00:26:21.170
videos there and
they are there to help you go further.

463
00:26:21.170 --> 00:26:22.310
Check them all out.

464
00:26:22.310 --> 00:26:24.298
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

465
00:26:24.298 --> 00:26:26.390
ITPROTV is binge-worthy.

466
00:26:26.390 --> 00:26:28.620
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

467
00:26:28.620 --> 00:26:31.250
>> And we will see you again soon.

468
00:26:31.250 --> 00:26:37.281
[MUSIC]

469
00:26:37.281 --> 00:26:39.210
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.
